title: Manny and Nina, It Will Not Do
description: To the Editor:

title: GARY MCLAIN IN FRONT RANK
description: LEXINGTON,Ky.

title: DUARTE'S PARTY CLAIMS VICTORY
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte's Christian Democratic Party claimed an upset victory in national elections here today.

title: Next Trade Representative
description: What with the warlike rhetoric surrounding trade with Japan, speculation over the imminent appointment of a new United States trade representative to succeed Bill Brock is becoming lively.

title: Connally Gets Chapman Post John B. Connally, Secretary
description: of the Treasury in the Nixon

title: Purchasers Report March Downturn
description: The first quarter ended on a sobering note, with the economy easing in March after improving during the first two months of the year, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.

title: AN ALLIED DUST STORM
description: DALLAS A new obsession has seized Western leaders to the point where it

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, credits were omitted in The Living Section on Wednesday for an illustration and photographs with an article on Passover foods. The drawing was by Mark Podwal and the photographs were by Fred R. Conrad.

title: MCENROE DEFEATS JARRYD
description: John McEnroe, returning to action after having been sidelined by an aching wrist, trounced Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 6-4, 6-1, today in the final of the Fila Indoor Trophy tennis tournament.

title: DELAYS IN SELECTING JUDGES SNARL FEDERAL COURTS
description: The Reagan Administration's difficulties in filling 115 judgeships is causing delays and hindering the operation of Federal courts throughout the nation, according to senior judges and members of Congress.

title: U. A. W. ACCORD IS REACHED ON CANADIAN INDEPENDENCE
description: An agreement has been reached allowing the Canadian division of the United Automobile Workers to leave the union.

title: ART OF GATHERING OYSTERS
description: WEST TISBURY, Mass.

title: Shifts in Rankings Of Underwriters
description: The business of bringing new stock and bond offerings to market underwent some important shifts in the first quarter of 1985. More and more corporations went to Europe to do their financings. And intensifying competition juggled some of the traditional rankings.

title: Apache Makes a Deal To Replace Oil Reserves
description: Unlike some of his industry colleagues, who have run down oil and gas holdings without undertaking efforts to restore them, R. Raymond Plank, chairman and chief executive of the Apache Corporation, is one oil man who believes in replacing depleted reserves.

title: A YOUNG GIRL'S DILEMMA IN 'LOVE LIVES ON'
description: DRUGS, alcoholism, unwed mothers, battered wives, terminal illnesses, abortion considerations, crises of faith - these are the depressingly typical problems scattered over the landscapes of countless television movies. Now, tonight at 9 on ABC, ''Love Lives On'' may be setting a record of sorts. April Smith's script manages to stuff not one or two but all of the above into a single story that is ''based on actual events,'' which may or may not be the same as being based on a true story.

title: DMINSKI ROLE VITAL IN NET PLAYOFF DRIVE
description: Darryl Dawkins, the Nets' center, drew two quick technical fouls and was ejected from Saturday night's game against the Knicks for complaining too strenuously about the foul calls. He was never missed.

title: San Francisco Strike Puts Burials on Hold
description: A strike by graveyard workers entered its third day today with no negotiations scheduled and bodies accumulating in mortuaries throughout the Bay Area.

title: St. Bart's a Bright Jewel in City's Crown
description: To the Editor:

title: U. S. SPENDS HUNDREDS OF MILLIONS PER WEAPON FOR TRAINING MANUAL
description: The Pentagon estimates it spends hundreds of millions of dollars per weapon system for training manuals that Defense Department officials say are overpriced and frequently riddled with errors.

title: Gooden And History
description: THEIR ''secret'' files are no longer secret. In 1975, the Elias Sports Bureau began supplying major league baseball teams with computerized reports, each several hundred pages long. The reports detailed the performance of every major league player in ''specific game situation, based on the presence or absence of base runners, their position on the bases, and the inning and the score.'' But now this year's reports are available to the public in ''The Elias Baseball Analyst,'' (Collier Books, $12.95), a 407-page monument constructed by Seymour Siwoff, Steve Hirdt and Peter Hirdt to what baseball fans treasure more than do those of any other sport - the significance of statistics.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day on Thursday with the Market Place column misstated the 52-week low and high prices for Bankers Trust stock. The low was 37 3/4 and the high 66.

title: SHEDULE IS SET
description: Garden State Park will offer 66 nights of thoroughbred racing this spring, nightly except Sunday with post time at 8 o'clock. There will be two daily doubles, two trifectas and six perfectas on a typical 10-race card.

title: REDMEN TO PAUSE TO REFLECT
description: Perhaps at a different time and in another conference, St. John's would have reigned supreme.

title: HOW TO TORPEDO PRIVATE COLLEGES
description: A college president, as described by the young son of a friend who held the post, is ''someone who lives in a big house and begs.'' The youngster put his finger on the key job requisite for those of us who head the more than 1,800 independent colleges in America.

title: LIE DOWN WITH DOGS
description: SAN DIEGO Ever since Gov. Thomas Dewey

title: No Headline
description: The education of Doug Flutie into the ways of pro football continued here Saturday night and for the first time the Generals' neophyte quarterback displayed some temper.

title: GAMBLER STREAK STOPPED
description: Chuck Fusina passed for 310 yards and the Baltimore Stars converted two of Jim Kelly's second-half turnovers into touchdowns to hand the previously undefeated Houston Gamblers a 27-14 loss today.

title: PRETORIA ORDERS TROOPS TO PATROL BLACK TOWNSHIPS
description: The South African authorities ordered army units into black townships in the troubled Eastern Cape region today to mount joint patrols with the police. The order was given after weeks of unrest and the killing by the police of 19 blacks near Uitenhage in the same area 10 days ago.

title: SENSING RISE IN RACISM, THOUSANDS MARCH IN PARIS
description: Thousands of Parisians, marching in a densely packed mass through the narrow streets of the old Jewish quarter of the city, demonstrated today against what they said was a renewal of racist violence in France.

title: TEAMSTERSS AND MAJOR FREIGHT CARRIERS REACH A PACT AS OTHER TALKS GO ON
description: Negotiators for major trucking companies and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters tentatively agreed on a contract today, but talks continued between the union and representatives of hundreds of smaller companies.

title: Chilean Police Battle 300 Demonstrators
description: Policemen used riot sticks and water cannon to disperse 300 demonstrators gathered outside Santiago's Cathedral today to protest the killing of three opponents of the military Government.

title: Pastor to Be Jailed For Withholding List
description: A state judge has ordered a Baptist minister jailed on a contempt charge for defying a court order and refusing to turn over a church membership list to dissident members.

title: Lacy Out Till May
description: Lee Lacy, the Baltimore Oriole rightfielder who injured his right thumb diving for a ball, will undergo surgery Wednesday to repair ruptured ligaments, the team said today. Lacy will be out of action for a minimum of eight weeks and will return to active duty in mid-May, the team said.

title: No Headline
description: ON TELEVISION, he is merely persuasive, the clear blue eyes staring straight into the camera as Robert Brennan explains that securities are just like racehorses and that you should join his winning team at First Jersey Securities. In person, he is almost hypnotic, the eyes even bluer and more riveting, the voice so soothing that anything he says sounds true - even when he says he is glad that he has chosen April 1, the same night as the college basketball final, to reopen Garden State Park.

title: U. S. ARMY SCHOOL FOR LATINS STARTING NEW LIFE IN GEORGIA
description: The School of the Americas, the United States military academy that had to be moved out of Panama last fall, has quickly begun a new life at the Army's infantry center here.

title: Image Polishers Keep Busy
description: You can tell who has image problems these days. Public relations firms introduced Washington news organizations to two new accounts last week.

title: Doctor Joins Ex-Salesman In Orchestrating Merger
description: When Thomas F. Frist Jr. was in medical school and serving as a surgical resident, he used to envy his friends who were businessmen. ''They got the weekend off,'' he said, ''while I was always working.''

title: 2 L. I. Gunmen Kill Market Manager
description: Two gunmen forced a supermarket manager to a back office Saturday night and shot him fatally in the head while his wife was kept outside the office.

title: POP: UB40 AND PABLO MOSES PERFORM AT THE BEACON
description: REGGAE bands from Jamaica and Britain turned the Beacon Theater into a dancehall Thursday. Both UB40, from Birmingham, England, and the Jamaican singer Pablo Moses enfold somber political messages in sinuous rhythms; the full house danced through both their sets.

title: IN ASSOCIATIONS' ROSTERS ARE MANY MISMATCHES
description: Browsing through bookcases in capital offices can be bracing.

title: U. N. CHIEF, IN PERSIAN GULF, SEEKS TO END WAR
description: The Secretary General of the United Nations began a 10-day trip to four Persian Gulf countries today, and he was conferring with colleagues about whether he would also visit Iran and Iraq in an effort to help end the Gulf war.

title: A Loving Tribute To a Generous Heart
description: ''I know the word for Grandmother

title: MusicNoted in Brief;   Antonio Carlos Jobim Sings at Carnegie Hall
description: As interesting a movement as there is in contemporary British-American popular music is the influence of musical cultures from elsewhere. And no such culture has made a bigger impact in recent years in New York than that of Brazil. For that reason alone, the first American concerts in nearly 20 years of Antonio Carlos Jobim, over the weekend at Carnegie Hall, took on a special significance.

title: Our Debt to the Displaced
description: America's apparel industry is under siege from low-cost foreign competitors. Hopelessly outgunned in the shopping malls, domestic garment makers and their labor union allies are counterattacking in the only place they have an advantage: the U.S. Congress. Bills have been introduced in both houses to roll back imports to 1983 levels and allow very limited growth in the future.

title: DETROIT'S NEW JAPAN STRATEGY
description: Having conceded Japanese superiority in low-priced small cars - at least for now - Detroit is bracing to meet its adversaries head-on in a marketing battle over the $10,000 car.

title: Clothes Exempted From Sales Taxes
description: For the first time in more than a decade, Connecticut residents on Monday will get a genuine tax cut: Clothing and footwear costing up to $50 will be exempt from the state's sales tax.

title: Bridge: Withdrawal of Resignation Is a Problem for Committee
description: Whether there is such a thing as an ''unresignation'' is a question that will be decided shortly by the executive committee of the American Contract Bridge League.

title: THOMPSON-EWING'S RITE OF PASSAGE
description: It is always a deep, emotional moment, one that high school and college coaches endure each year as athletes leave their institutions for greater challenges. The annual rite is never easy, but late Monday night, as the final seconds tick in college basketball's national championship game, it will be especially difficult for the Georgetown coach, John Thompson. He will be saying goodbye to someone who has had a major impact upon his life. He will be saying goodbye to Patrick Ewing.

title: STEWARD'S RULING UNPOPULAR
description: Charlie Rose, John Veitch's assistant trainer, has worked with such horses as Alydar and Davona Dale, but likes Proud Truth better than any of them. Veitch credits Rose's close work with the colt for much of his success and Rose calls Proud Truth ''potentially the best horse I've ever been around.''

title: Chagall's Gift
description: It is no longer included on the public

title: CORPORATE ADS ON PBS SPARK DEBATE
description: Over the last year, viewers of public-television stations in such places as New Jersey, Los Angeles, New Orleans and Philadelphia have been seeing an increasing number of 30-second corporate advertisements. Complete with music and promotional tag lines, the advertisements are similar, and in some cases identical, to those seen on commercial stations.

title: 'OUR MARRIAGE,' PROJECT OF FRANCE AND SPAIN
description: ''OUR MARRIAGE,'' a French-Spanish co-production directed by Valeria Sarimento, has a dark, somber visual style and a plot any soap-opera writer would kill for. It concerns a little girl named Lola, who grows deathly ill when her father cannot pay for medical care. An operation saves Lola, thanks to wealthy, childless Lorenzo and Marcelina, who live next door. But Lola's father is so offended by their charity that he disowns his daughter.

title: STATE BROADENS BAN ON STRIPED-BASS FISHING
description: The Cuomo administration today banned commercial fishing for striped bass in New York Harbor and along both shores of western Long Island because of dangerous levels of PCB's in the fish.

title: CAMP DAVID AT TOP IN U. S. POLICY POLL
description: The American public regards the Camp David peace negotiations of 1978 as Washington's most successful foreign policy venture of recent years, according to a New York Times poll that shows considerably broader support for the Middle East accords than for the invasion of Grenada in 1983.

title: Rosenfeld to Handle Yugoslav Car Import
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson has been named agency for Yugo America, the Montvale, N.J., company that is going to import a Yugoslav automobile that will be the lowest-priced car available in the United States. The ad budget for the introduction of the car in just the Boston-Washington corridor could be as much as $10 million.

title: A Welcome Tip
description: If you have been wondering whether

title: TOWN FEARS NEW LOS ANGELES RAIL LINE THREATENS RENEWAL
description: County officials here say they are ready to start building an electric railway between Los Angeles and Long Beach that would mark the return of rapid transit to Los Angeles. But the county's plans have collided with the efforts of one municipality along the route to renew its aging downtown area.

title: LAOTIANS STILL POUR INTO THAILAND DESPITE EFFORTS TO STEM THE FLOW
description: Refugees from Laos are continuing to stream into Thailand at the rate of about 1,000 or more a month, despite Thai Government efforts to stop the flow, according to refugee workers and police officials in the country's northeast.

title: 'Xerxes' at Juilliard
description: Handel's opera ''Xerxes'' will be performed by the Juilliard American Opera Center beginning April 24 at 8 P.M. at the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street.

title: IN 'BILOXI BLUES,' SIMON RECAPTURES HIS YOUTH
description: In ''Biloxi Blues,'' Neil Simon's new hit play that opened last week on Broadway, it is 1943, and Eugene Morris Jerome, the young hero played by Matthew Broderick, is spending his stint in the wartime Army, trying to grow up and become a writer. Eugene sees himself as an outsider, an invisible witness to the hectic events of the world around him, and he is constantly scribbling down his observations of his fellow soldiers in a little marbled-cover composition book, feeling ''a little ashamed for betraying their secret and private thoughts.'' Instead of serving on the battlefield, he will go on to work for a G.I. newspaper, but while this will cause him to ''suffer pangs of guilt because my career was enhanced by World War II,'' he will have found his vocation. He will indeed grow up and become a writer. He will grow up and become Neil Simon.

title: TOPS AT SENATORS' TABLE
description: Senators have been known to beg for his bread pudding. His sweet potato pie is a bit of Southern ambrosia. And his ham and redeye gravy have graced many a legislative table.

title: Pan Am Negotiations Go On Past Deadline
description: Negotiators for 6,000 flight attendants and Pan American World Airways continued bargaining early this morning past a midnight strike deadline.

title: A MODEL CHILD-ABUSE PREVENTION PROGRAM
description: Beyond the sensational headlines about the national epidemic of child sexual abuse, the difficult, practical questions remain: What can communities do to stop it? How can it best be prevented and treated?

title: What Do Corporate Greenmailers Manufacture?
description: To the Editor:

title: AN AFGHAN DIARY: MISSILES, MIG'S AND MYNA BIRDS
description: The MIG's attacked in pairs, their missiles leaving a trail of white vapor in the sky.

title: MAPLE SUGARING IS REBORN IN NORTHERN CONNECTICUT
description: ''Chappy'' Rich turned his face away from the opened firebox and quickly threw fresh pine slabs into the blaze. The boiling sap frothed higher, sending clouds of sweet steam over the cow pastures.

title: CABARET: CHICAGO CITY LIMITS
description: -member comedy and improvisational troupe that is a fixture at the Jan Hus Theater (351 East 74th Street), has been delighting New York audiences for several years with its light slapstick humor. In ''X (the Roman Numeral),'' the group's 10th revue, the mood is consistently merry and sportive.

title: Tokyo Revamps the Rules for Three Industries
description: A series of measures designed to reshape Japan's telecommunications, financial and tobacco industries and open them to foreign competition go into effect Monday.

title: MusicNoted in Brief;   Lagrene, Guitarist, Plays at Fat Tuesday's
description: Bireli Lagrene, the young European Gypsy guitarist whose first records five years ago revealed him as a virtual carbon copy of the brilliant Django Reinhardt, is now 18 years old and he is coming out of his Reinhardt shell. At Fat Tuesday's, where he led his own trio through yesterday, there are still occasional references to Mr. Reinhardt in his playing but it is his own musical personality and his own style of virtuosity that now dominate his performance.

title: Jackson Repels Two Attackers
description: Two men shouting racial slurs attacked Reggie Jackson Saturday with a tire iron in a hotel parking lot, but he fended them off, the police said today.

title: CELTIC'S STREAK BROKEN
description: Terry Tyler scored 11 of his 20 points in a fourth-quarter surge today to help the Detroit Pistons snap Boston's 10-game winning streak with a 113-105 victory over the Celtics.

title: BALLET: 'LA Sylphide,' STAGE BY MARTINS
description: -century Danish ballet, ''La Sylphide,'' that Peter Martins has staged for the Pennsylvania Ballet and which will be seen at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in May, promises to be highly controversial. It is a startling and modern approach to a classic that has often been performed as a museum piece.

title: Another Suspect Held In Radio Host's Death
description: -SALEM, N.C., March 31 (AP) - Heavily armed Federal agents arrested another suspect Saturday in the killing of a Denver radio talk-show host who the police say was shot by white supremacists.

title: Administration Rejects A Candidate for Judge
description: More than a year after William E. Hellerstein, a Legal Aid Society lawyer, was recommended for a Federal judgeship in Manhattan, the Reagan Administration has decided not to seek his confirmation for the position.

title: NEAR PLAYOFF BERTH
description: In like lambs and almost out like lions. The Rangers, who opened March with a defeat and went on to lose 10 of 16 games, closed the month with a 7-5 victory over Toronto last night at the Garden.

title: STOCKS SURGED WORLDWIDE IN QUARTER
description: After generally dozing during 1984, stock markets around the world awoke last quarter charged with an energy that set records on stock indexes around the globe.

title: Nancy Bolotin Marries D. L. Magida in Miami
description: The marriage of Nancy Ruth Bolotin, a senior systems analyst for the Xerox Corporation in Stamford, Conn., and Daniel Leon Magida, a senior vice president and general counsel of the P.S.F.S. Credit Corporation in Norwalk, Conn., took place yesterday in Miami. Rabbi Mitchell Chefitz officiated at Vizcaya Gardens, a public mansion.

title: Advertising;   Ted Bates Wins Avis Account
description: TED BATES ADVERTISING/

title: Karim Khalef Is Dead at 50; Former Mayor in West Bank
description: Karim Khalef, a former Mayor of the West Bank town of Ramallah who was maimed in a bombing in 1980, died Saturday of a heart attack, the Israeli radio reported. He was 50 years old.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY PIONEERS RECALL PROGRAM'S BIRTH
description: The elderly visitors looked out of place in the cafeteria of the Social Security Administration's data processing facility here. Few of the 700 workers, most of them young, knew that half a century earlier, these visitors wrote and carried out the legislation that created their agency.

title: Ekaterina Novitskaya In Debut at Town Hall
description: born pianist who became in 1968 the youngest contestant and the first woman to win the Queen Elisabeth competition in Belgium. After 10 years of struggle, she was permitted to travel outside the Soviet Union, and defected to marry a pianist she had met at the competition. Tuesday, as a Belgian citizen, she made her New York debut at Town Hall.

title: Is Suing the Only Way?
description: How to reform the American way of compensating consumers injured by defective products? Class-action shakedowns of the kind brought against Agent Orange and the morning sickness drug Bendectin are only one of the things wrong with the present system of holding manufacturers to account. The process clogs the courts and too often results not in justice but delay and confusion. Yet business and consumer groups have repeatedly failed to agree on how to improve the system.

title: Joel Smirnoff, Violinist, At Carnegie Recital Hall
description: Joel Smirnoff, a versatile violinist who took second prize in the 1983 International American Music Competition, chose an appealingly diversified program for his Thursday evening concert at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Jet Pilot Saved In Crash Off L.I.
description: A Marine Corps jet fighter crashed in the Atlantic near the tip of Long Island yesterday after apparently developing engine problems, the Coast Guard said.

title: FISHER IMPRESSIVE IN YANKEE OUTING
description: Mark Connor, the Yankees' pitching coach, reflected on the competition for bullpen jobs before the game today and said, ''It's kind of getting down to a pitch-off and guys are rising to the occasion.''

title: HOSPITAL COMPANY AND NO. 1 SUPPLIER PLAN HUGE MERGER
description: The Hospital Corporation of America, the nation's largest hospital management chain, and the American Hospital Supply Corporation, the largest distributor of hospital supplies, said yesterday that they had agreed to merge.

title: A SUPPORT NETWORK IS URGED
description: ''There is no point in implementing the prevention curriculum if you aren't prepared to treat large numbers of children,'' said Marlys Olson of the Tacoma Council on Child Sexual Abuse.

title: FOREIGN CAPITAL GROWTH IN U. S. CAUSES CONCERN
description: A spirited debate is developing in the financial community about the risks and benefits of a huge influx of foreign capital, which has strengthened the dollar and helped finance the Reagan Administration's large budget deficits.

title: U.N. OFFICIAL SAYS RELIEF GOAL IN AFRICA DROUGHT IS HALF MET
description: ''Not only are lives at stake,'' the coordinator for the United Nations famine relief effort in Africa said a few months ago, ''but in a sense the international community is on trial.''

title: BERENYI OPTIMISTIC DESPITE SORE ARM
description: If you ask Bruce Berenyi how his right shoulder feels, he says: ''Pretty good. But a little tender. I have inflammation in there and, every time I pitch, it feels it'll be tough for me to pick up a ball for two or three days.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: SHAH OF SHAHS. By Ryszard Kapuscinski. Translated from the Polish by William R. Brand and Katarzyna Mroczkowska-Brand. 152 pages. Helen and

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, APRIL 1, 1985

title: Massacre Is Reported At Wedding in Uganda
description: Young gunmen belonging to the ruling Uganda People's Congress Party opened fire on a rural wedding ceremony southwest of Kampala, killing 30 villagers, including the groom, an opposition Member of Parliament said today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Are there any major leaguers still playing who were in the first game ever held at the Astrodome? How did the game turn out?

title: Debt Issues
description: Bache Group Inc. is redeeming its 14 percent sinking fund debentures due 2000.

title: NO WAY TO TREAT SOLIDARITY REFUGEES
description: One of the best- kept secrets since martial law was declared in Poland on Dec. 13, 1981, is the abysmal treatment of Solidarity refugees by the United States.

title: Futures;   Confusing Soybean Market
description: THE market for soybeans, one of

title: Waiting It Out
description: * Michael Graham's shaved head and menacing glare were as much a part of the Georgetown basketball scene as the towering presence of Patrick Ewing, until academic difficulties led to Graham's departure last fall. Now two other things are different: Graham has a full head of hair, and is not playing basketball.

title: STATE, LACKING BUDGET, TO USE FEDERAL FUNDS
description: Still unable to agree on a budget for the fiscal year that starts at 12:01 A.M. Monday, state officials narrowed their differences tonight and arranged to use Federal funds for welfare and Medicaid advances to local governments.

title: Grant Is Awarded On Subway Crime
description: Federal officials said yesterday that the Urban Mass Transportation Administration had allocated $11 million for mirrors, gates, lights, closed- circuit television cameras and other anticrime equipment for the city's subways.

title: DANCE: DUNN AND TROUPE PERFORM
description: B

title: TELEPHONE: A FRIEND OR FOE?
description: AFTER a hard day at the office, at

title: Manila Opposition Issues Warning on Aquino Trial
description: Opposition leaders warned today that the failure of key witnesses to testify in the Aquino murder trial and other courtroom developments threaten to turn the proceedings into a ''mockery of justice.''

title: Tokens for Sale
description: If you have been wondering why

title: POLITICAL PRISONERS, FROM EAST TO WEST
description: To the Editor:

title: Bid on Suspension Expected by Jets
description: John Ferguson, the Winnipeg Jets general manager, said he will ask the National Hockey League Monday to suspend Denis Savard, the Chicago Black Hawks center, for at least three games.

title: Pilot Unhurt in Accident
description: A student pilot whose plane hit a street light and struck the side of a freeway overpass in an emergency landing walked away uninjured, the police said. Wieslaw J. Checinski, 56 years old, was on his way from Santa Maria to Whiteman Airport, 25 miles north of Los Angeles, when his plane lost power Saturday.

title: Miss Goldstein Weds James Grady, Author
description: Bonnie Goldstein, the daughter of Mrs. William Holland of St. Paul and the late Howard E. Goldstein of New York, was married in Washington yesterday to James Grady, the son of Mrs. Thomas Grady and the late Mr. Grady of Shelby, Mont. Judge Abner J. Mikva of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia performed the ceremony at the home of Barbara Guss and R. Scott Armstrong.

title: Show Boat
description: Arriving with spring and the cherry blossoms this week, a charming if somewhat anachronistic craft will begin plying the placid Potomac. Named the Cherry Blossom, she is a 110-foot reproduction of a 19th Century stern-paddlewheeler, designed for charter and corporate entertaining.

title: Newsprint Output Up
description: Newsprint production in Canadian mills rose 19.3 percent in February, to 741,000 metric tons, from the period a year ago, the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association said Friday. For the first two months of 1985 production was 1.53 million tons, up 11 percent from a year earlier.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: BEHIND THE FOOTLIGHTS New York is certainly not a one-industry town, but the one ''industry'' that it is identified with more than any other in America is theater. The Alliance of Resident Theaters/New York is an organization that represents New York's nonprofit theaters, a group that produces more than 700 plays a year.

title: Jails Chief Apologizes For Remarks on Crime
description: Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, the Commissioner of Correctional Services, issued a statement tonight apologizing for the way in which he presented remarks about crime and minorities in a recent newspaper interview.

title: MGM Hotels And Insurers
description: MGM Grand Hotels Inc. said yesterday it had reached an agreement settling disputes with Frank B. Hall & Company, its retroactive insurance carriers and the Del E. Webb Corporation and its insurance carriers. The disputes followed MGM Grand's 1983 settlement of liability claims stemming from a fire at the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas in 1980.

title: MUSIC: GROUP PRESENTS NEW WORKS FROM SPAIN
description: MUSICIANS' ACCORD presented an evening of new music from Spain Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, but most of the material sounded as though it could have been just as easily composed in New Zealand, or Yukon territory, or Botswana, or, more than likely, at a big Midwestern university.

title: Doctors in the Sudan Call for a General Strike
description: Doctors extended a work stoppage today and called for a general strike to unseat President Gaafar al- Nimeiry, who is visiting the United States.

title: ARBITRATION SET IF TRANSIT TALKS REACH AN IMPASSE
description: The State Legislature, over the objections of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, voted last night to have a panel of arbitrators impose a new contract for New York City subway and bus workers if negotiators cannot reach a settlement.

title: ISRAEL SAID TO SEIZE CONTROL OVER 52% OF WEST BANK LAND
description: The Israeli Government has seized direct or indirect control of 52 percent of the land on the occupied West Bank, according to an authoritative study issued today.

title: Mantle Invited To Yank Opener
description: The Yankees announced yesterday that Mickey Mantle would throw out the ceremonial first ball at the Yankee Stadium opener April 16.

title: Jack H. Klein, Partner In an Accounting Firm
description: Jack H. Klein, treasurer of the Friars Club and an accountant whose clients included prominent entertainment and business figures, died at Beth Israel Hospital on Friday, two days after having suffered a stroke. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CABARET: TIMPANARO
description: -faced singer with a casual air and a voice that has the potential to shatter the glass-lined walls of Don't Tell Mama, 342 West 46th Street, where she wound up an engagement Saturday, opened her act with a song in which, among other things, she pantomimes a dance with arm movements and facial expressions but does not really dance.

title: E-Z ED PINCKNEY FILLS A NEED
description: Long ago, Ed Pinckney understood the value of making his own observations and forming his own opinions. The sport he plays has been described as the city game, but Pinckney realized that it was more complex than that. When he was growing up on White Plains Road in the Bronx, he would go out in search of basketball nuances and styles. All he needed was a pair of sneakers and a couple of subway tokens.

title: 869 in Jersey Made $1 Million
description: Nearly 900 New Jersey residents earned more than $1 million in 1983, state tax officials said.

title: Rachel Van Voorhees Weds J. S. Dixon
description: Rachel Faye Van Voorhees, a daughter of Dr. Sylvia Van Voorhees of Woodmere, L.I., and the late Emmett Francis Van Voorhees, was married yesterday to John Shea Dixon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Frank Dixon of New Orleans. Judge Nat H. Hentel of the Civil Court of the City of New York performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Market Place;   Natural Gas Forecasting
description: FORECASTING the timing of potential takeovers in natural gas pipeline companies, a

title: JACKSON BRANDS NEW YORK CITY 'SLUM LANDLORD'
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson yesterday accused the City of New York of being a ''slum landlord'' and called on local officials to make more housing available to the city's poor and moderate-income residents.

title: MERGER FORCING STATION SALES
description: WABC, an AM radio station in New York, was for years the nation's most influential and listened-to popular- music station, and its call letters made it virtually synonymous with its corporate parent, the American Broadcasting Companies. Some time in the next year, however, the station and many other notable broadcasting properties are likely to be put up for sale by ABC and Capital Cities Communications Inc. to meet the financial and regulatory requirements of their proposed $3.5 billion merger, analysts say.

title: PEETE WINS T.P.C. GOLF BY 3 SHOTS
description: Calvin Peete, who made his living 20 years ago by selling dry goods to migrant farm workers up and down the East Coast, today earned the second largest winner's purse in PGA Tour history when he won the 12th annual Tournament Players Championship by three shots over D. A. Weibring and took the $162,000 first prize.

title: Japan Payments Gain
description: Japan's balance of payments swung to a surplus of $143 million in February, from a deficit of $154 million a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said Friday. February's current account surplus rose to $2.54 billion, from a surplus of $2.01 billion a year ago.

title: Canada Plans Energy Shift
description: Canada will lift Government controls on domestic and export prices of oil on June 1 and is moving to phase out other parts of a national energy program adopted in 1980, according to Energy Minister Pat Carney.

title: NAKASONE, U. S. ENVOY TALK TRADE
description: President Reagan's special trade envoy asked Japan's Prime Minister today to take the lead in resolving growing trade frictions that, the envoy warned, could harm Japan's relationship with the United States.

title: West All-Stars Triumph, 97-90
description: Detlef Schrempf, the Washington forward, scored 16 points to lead the West to a 97-90 victory over the East today in the 23d Annual Coaches' All-America game at Memorial Coliseum.

title: Miss Schatz, Law Student, Is Bride of Mark Lefkowitz
description: Temple Beth Israel in Hartford was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Debra Jane Schatz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Michael Schatz of Avon and Westbrook, Conn., and Mark Lefkowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lefkowitz of Brooklyn. Rabbi Harold Silver officiated.

title: Rothschild Unit Picks President
description: Rothschild Ventures Inc., the venture capital arm of Rothschild Inc., has named Jess L. Belser president, effective today. He replaces Arch J. McGill, who resigned, according to a Rothschild spokesman, ''to pursue personal interests.''

title: Dr. Herbert E. Walker Jr. Dies; A Psychiatrist and Professor
description: Dr. Herbert E. Walker Jr., a psychiatrist and a clinical professor of psychiatry at the New York University Medical Center, died of cancer Saturday at New York University Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DANCE: WORK BY MEL WONG
description: T HE perception of time, that ordering and motivating element in dance, has been a concern of many choreographers. The latest to investigate it is Mel Wong, whose ''Buddha Meets Einstein at the Great Wall,'' a new, multi-media dance was performed on Friday at the Asia Society.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of Boston Corp. has elected to its board J. Richard Bullock, president and chief executive officer of Wyman-Gordon Co., and Stephen J. Sweeney, president and chief executive officer of Boston Edison Co.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's an impediment to trying to get the contract to reflect what we want to do.

title: 3 THOROUGHBREDS DIE IN ACCIDENT
description: -- Three thoroughbred horses were electrocutied this morning at Woodbine Race Track when the machine that was walking them malfunctioned.

title: Old Dominion Tops Georgia for Title
description: The women's basketball team from Old Dominion University in Norfolk, Va., was well aware that the idea of the game was to put the ball in the basket. It had trouble doing that today, but it created so many extra opportunities with its rebounding that it won the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship.

title: Washington Watch;   Capital Alumni Ponder Deficits
description: WASHINGTON

title: SINGLES SEEK SOCIAL LIFE AT HOUSES OF WORSHIP
description: With increasing frequency, young adults in Manhattan are turning to singles programs set up by churches and synagogues for their social life, according to clergymen and social scientists.

title: 'SMOKESCREEN' STRATEGY
description: College basketball coaches have a clever phrase for publicly assessing an opponent. They call it ''blowing smoke,'' as in setting up a screen that hides the truth.

title: SEAPORT MUSEUM IN DISPUTE ON GOALS
description: The South Street Seaport Museum, a small cultural institution that became involved in the real-estate boom of lower Manhattan and then could not decide whether it was primarily a museum or a real-estate corporation, is emerging from a period of paralysis.

title: Samuel D. Goos Weds Sarah Jane Rosenblatt
description: At the Central Synagogue in New York yesterday Sarah Jane Rosenblatt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Rosenblatt of New York and Remsenburg, L.I., was married to Samuel David Goos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius J. Goos of Augusta, Me. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony.

title: John Moynahan, 73, Of Manhattan Project
description: John F. Moynahan, communications officer for the Manhattan Project during World War II and later an international public-relations consultant, died Tuesday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 73 years old and had been ill with cancer and heart disease.

title: Banner Bob Wins Jim Beam Stakes
description: Banner Bob bounced back today from his disappointing fourth-place finish in the Florida Derby to take a three-quarter-length victory in the $350,000 Jim Beam Stakes, the second-richest prep race to the Kentucky Derby.

title: DEMOCRATIC CHIEFS DIVIDE ON WAYS TO REBUILD PARTY
description: Five months after President Reagan's landslide re-election, many Democrats have come to the conclusion that a ''sea change'' may be occurring in American politics and that their party must be rebuilt if it is to be competitive again in national elections.

title: GOSPEL GROUPS COMPETE AT ST. JOHN THE DIVINE
description: ''It's starting to feel like a real church in here,'' announced the Rev. Timothy Wright shortly before midnight on Saturday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. By then, the cathedral, which had been overflowing four hours earlier, was half empty. But for the hardy 300 or so who remained for the culmination of Gospel Fest '85, a six-hour competitive marathon involving 13 New York area gospel groups, the spirit had finally taken hold. Half the crowd was on its feet swaying and clapping.

title: King to Undergo Surgery
description: Bernard King will undergo surgery today to repair a torn ligament and torn cartilage in his right knee, sustained in the closing minutes against the Kansas City Kings on March 23. Dr. Norman Scott, the Knicks' team doctor, will perform the surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Sally Abravanel Weds Educator
description: Robert H. Donaldson, who was inaugurated Friday as the fourth president of Fairleigh Dickinson University, was married yesterday to Sally S. Abravanel, an institutional research coordinator and adjunct lecturer in mathematics at Herbert H. Lehman College of the City University of New York. The Rev. Henry F. Knight Jr., a Methodist minister, officiated at Mr. Donaldson's home in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Mesa Finance Chief Plays Unusual Role
description: David H. Batchelder is the chief financial officer at an oil company. But the company he works for, the Mesa Petroleum Company, is not just any oil company. And Mr. Batchelder, who is 35 years old, does not have an ordinary job description.

title: 2 More Arrested in Shooting Of Police Officer in Paterson
description: Two more men were arrested today and charged in the shooting of a police officer who interrupted an armed robbery at a gas station here.

title: Olson Withdraws Name
description: Lute Olson, the University of Arizona basketball coach, announced Sunday night that he was no longer a candidate for the head coaching position at Kentucky.

title: BARRY CALLS ACCUSATION 'MORE SMOKE THAN FIRE'
description: Marion S. Barry Jr. is on a diet, gulping glasses of orange juice and protein powder two or three times a day, and limiting himself to one square meal, usually at some civic function in the evening.

title: Thomson Triumphs LOS ANGELES, March 31 (AP) - Peter Thomson of Australia rolled in a five-foot par-saving putt on the final hole today to hold off Don January for a one-stroke victory in the $250,000 Carta Blanca Seniors Classic at Mountaingate Country Club.
description: Thomson's final-round 71 gave him a 205 total for the 54-hole tournament and a check of $37,500.

title: IN CHINA, DOUBT ON SOVIET TIES
description: Recent conversations with high officials in Peking cast serious doubt on reports from Moscow that the meeting this month between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and China's Deputy Prime Minister, Li Peng, presages a significant improvement in Chinese-Soviet ties.

title: Storer Plans F.C.C. Appeal Storer Communications Inc.

title: Daniel Kuper Plays The Guitar in Recital
description: The young Argentine guitarist Daniel Kuper began his debut recital half an hour late, but once he arrived on the stage of Cami Hall Thursday it did not take him nearly that long to establish his credentials as an accomplished and interesting player. One short bit of the French Baroque aside, it was a program of German music in transcription and Hispanic music mostly composed for the guitar. Mr. Kuper may not have the assurance or bravura of a virtuoso, but his playing was always musical and sensitively phrased.

title: Faulty Jet Gear Forces 2 Emergency Landings
description: A Jet America airliner with 139 people aboard made two emergency landings over the weekend at O'Hare International Airport because of a landing gear problem that ground crews apparently failed to correct, the authorities said.

title: RALLY TIED TO POLICY REPORTS
description: Hints of a slightly more generous monetary policy were enough to bring lower interest rates to the Treasury note and bond market last week, despite a heavy supply of new issues and widespread skepticism that the rate declines would endure through the spring and summer.

title: STATE AND ITS TOP UNION REACH A PACT
description: New York State and its largest union reached tentative agreement today on a contract that provides wage increases of at least 17.5 percent over three years for 100,000 employees. Under the settlement, the state agreed for the first time to set up a fund to be used partly for extra pay increases for jobs traditionally held by women and members of minority groups. The intent is to make the salaries for those jobs more equitable with the salaries for jobs traditionally held by white men. The settlement - with the Civil Service Employees Association - provides at least $16 million for the fund in each of the contract's second and third years. But details of exactly how that money will be distributed and what jobs will be affected remained to be worked out, pending the results of a study and future negotiations. ''We view this as very substantial,'' said Michael P. Moran, a spokesman for the union, which represents blue-collar and service employees, such as members of highway maintenance crews, clerks and hospital physical therapists. ''An important step is being taken to correct past inequities.''

title: IRAQIS ANNOUNCE ATTACKS ON IRAN AFTER EXPLOSION SHAKES BAGHDAD
description: Iraq announced that it carried out air raids against five Iranian towns today, just hours after an early-morning explosion shook Baghdad.

title: 'ANCIENT LIVES,' IN EGYPT
description: ''ANCIENT LIVES,'' a four- part series, examines ancient Egypt, a land where the living shared territorial rights with the dead. Apparently, this worked to everyone's advantage. A sense of community led to great art and interesting artifacts. The series begins on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

description: A teen-ager drowned in a park pond while being chased by park security guards, the police said.

title: UNION PUT OFF A STRIKE IN QUEENS BUS DISPUTE
description: The union representing workers at four private bus lines in Queens put off early this morning a strike that had been scheduled for today and agreed to work under an old contract until 12:01 A.M. Thursday.

title: Pesticide Price Rises
description: Union Carbide Agricultural Products Inc. has notified suppliers in Georgia and other states that it now can guarantee shipments of only 75 percent of last year's supplies of the pesticide, Temik, officials said Friday.

title: A Debunking
description: The home advantage presumably enjoyed by teams playing before their local rooters has long been one of the most-cherished chestnuts in sport. Now a new statistical study has provided evidence that, at least when a championship is on the line, there is indeed an advantage - for the visiting team.

title: SHADOW OF FORMER MAYOR HANGS OVER PROVIDENCE
description: It was rush hour on a recent Thursday afternoon and Vincent A. description: The stocks of companies being pursued for takeover were among the top performers in the nation's three major stock markets in the first quarter. Conversely, the stocks of high- technology companies, affected by continuing weaknesses in the industry, performed poorly.

description: The big rumor last week was that the International Business Machines Corporation was ending its long relationship with Doyle Dane Bernbach. Asked about that, Toni Emerson, director of advertising of the I.B.M. Information Systems Group, simply said, ''Untrue.'' In addition to handling such I.B.M. products as its typewriters, copiers and some computers, the agency buys all network television for the entire corporation.

title: SCOUTING ;   Honeymoon Over For Star Skier
description: Just what is it with Bill Johnson, anyway? How is it that an athlete - to be sure, a brash, even abrasive athlete with a seeming propensity for rubbing people the wrong way - could nonetheless emerge as a national hero by taking a 1984 Olympic downhill gold medal, and then so thoroughly lose his glow only a year later?

description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, contending that the political opportunity for comprehensive tax revision may be lost if consideration is delayed until 1986, said last night that the Administration intended to push for Congressional passage of a tax overhaul plan before the end of this year.

description: FOR a growing number of computer buyers it often comes down to a choice between the I.B.M. PC and the Apple Macintosh. Both are excellent machines, but each has special strengths and weaknesses. Many shoppers feel the decision requires the wisdom of Solomon.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Chilean Mourners Turn Funeral Into Protest
description: Thousands of mourners chanting anti- Government slogans turned the funeral march today for two slain Communist Party activists into the largest protest against military rule under Chile's five-month-old state of siege.

title: DUARTE, SEEMING ELECTION VICTOR, CALLS FOR UNITY
description: Speaking in the flush of what appeared to be almost certain electoral victory, President Jose Napoleon Duarte promised late Sunday night to seek national unity for his divided country, inviting his opponents ''to participate in the democratic process and the process of confronting the crisis in which we live.''

title: HAROLD PEARY, 76, RADIO STAR
description: Harold Peary, who played the Great Gildersleeve during radio's golden age and helped make ''You're a hard man, McGee'' a national catch phrase, died Saturday at Torrance Memorial Hospital at the age of 76.

title: BRIEFS
Elbow Chips Trouble Knight
description: Chips were detected today in the right elbow of Ray Knight, the third baseman for the Mets. The outlook was that he would either undergo arthroscopic surgery that would force him to miss the opening of the season, or that he would skip surgery now and play the season with pain.

description: His lines call for a mention of the Kama Sutra. Suddenly, Jim Dale is transformed from a British schoolteacher into a lascivious Indian, leering at the audience with gleeful lewdness. For a moment, he almost seems to drool.

title: MUSIC: MORTON ESTRIN, PIANIST
description: BACH, Chopin and even Scriabin are known for their keyboard preludes, but so is Rachmaninoff, who published 24 of them, in all the keys (there are also a few unpublished ones). Although integral recital performances of the canonical 24 are not unknown, they are also not common, and so Morton Estrin's traversal Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall was a welcome one. It proved doubly welcome, given the quality of his performances.

title: State Under Washington's Double-Barreled Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics;   Untoward Results
description: Truth at Last It's another big one for the literary agents: a New Hampshire woman says that she falsely accused an Illinois man of rape, expresses remorse for the six years he has spent in prison and obtains his forgiveness. Cathleen Crowell says that fear of pregnancy led her to lie about an assault and identify Gary Dotson as the assailant.

title: PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $737,000, or 14 cents a share, representing cumulative effect for years prior to 1984 of accounting change. The net also includes $339,000, or 6 cents a share, attributable to the effect of the accounting change on 1984 net income.

title: Yugoslav Prices Climb
description: Many prices were increased in Yugoslavia today. Railroad tickets and freight rates rose 15 to 32 percent, newspapers rose 50 to 66 percent and gasoline rose 3 to 9 percent.

title: FINANCIAL CORP. POSTS HUGE LOSS
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it lost $512.1 million in the fourth quarter, largely because of an increase in its reserves against bad loans and real estate property by $472.5 million.

title: Advertising;   Young Miss Magazine Changing
description: AS part of its effort to attract an older crowd and the advertisers that are sure to follow, Young Miss magazine will adopt the name YM with its June issue.

title: A SWAN ON THE MOVE
description: RESEARCHERS in Minnesota say a wildlife program has led to the first documented migration of rare trumpeter swans in the continental United States in more than a century.

title: Odyssey of Dith Pran Will Appear as a Book
description: ''The Death and Life of Dith Pran,'' by Sydney Schanberg, the account on which the motion picture ''The Killing Fields'' is based, will be published in paperback by Penguin on May 20.

TELEBYTE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 2, 1985

title: STAGE: A NEW VISION OF 'TARTUFFE'
description: As a conceptual director, Lucian Pintilie has tried to do for ''Tartuffe'' what his Rumanian countryman, Andrei Serban, did for Greek tragedy - to clear the air of expectation and of all previous productions. As intended, the result is like no other Moli ere one has ever seen. In Mr. Pintilie's hands, the play becomes an explosive extravaganza of burlesque commedia dell'arte and, eventually, the tragicomedy of ''Tartuffe.''

title: SECOND-CLASS REFUGEES
description: In the last six months, 18 people have been indicted for their efforts to provide refuge for Central Americans seeking asylum in the United States. The people involved in this ''sanctuary movement'' - it is a grassroots effort, organized largely by church groups in the Southwest - argue that political considerations here are determining whether or not those seeking asylum are able to obtain refuge from political violence and persecution at home. Their argument has undeniable force.

title: CELLO: BARBARA MALLOW
description: BARBARA STEIN MALLOW is one of the less visible members of the Fuchs family of string players. Daughter of Lillian Fuchs, the violist, and niece of Joseph Fuchs, the violinist, Mrs. Mallow plays the cello and does so exceedingly well.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: No Headline
description: The Government of Trinidad and Tobago and Texaco officials have signed the final agreement for the sale of Texaco's money- losing refinery on the east coast of Trinidad and some of Texaco's other assets in Trinidad for $189.2 million.

title: Shamrock Agrees To Purchase Soya
description: A limited partnership led by the Roy E. Disney family said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire all the outstanding shares of the Central Soya Company for $24.25 a share in cash.

title: BRIEFING ;   Salaries at the Top
description: No matter what the United States pays its top officials, it never seems to be enough, according to some officials.

JEWS ASSAIL BOOK ON PASSOVER
description: The Jewish Welfare Board's Book Council and other major Jewish organizations have protested the release of a new children's book about Passover, calling it ''misleading'' because it includes a painting of Jesus at the Last Supper and violates what the council considers the traditional holiday story.

title: THE TOKYO MAYOR'S TWO GIFTS
description: In the midst of trade tensions between the United States and Japan comes the reminder of a time when the friendship between the two countries was in full blossom.

title: Addendum
description: Sports Illustrated is increasing its rate base 3.8 percent, to 2,725,000, with its Sept. 2 issue, and its advertising rates 3.1 percent.

title: 'STAR WARS' SCIENCE EXPECTED TO SPAWN PEACEFUL INVENTIONS
description: WHATEVER finally comes of President Reagan's proposed ''Star Wars'' defense against nuclear missiles, current research at the nation's weapons laboratories promises a bumper crop of spinoff discoveries and gadgets, many of which will spur progress in medicine, industry and basic science.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Utility Bills Going Up For Polish Consumers
description: The costs of electricity, natural gas and heating fuels were raised by 20 to 32 percent today in the second phase of a price-rise package. But there was no visible response to a call by the outlawed Solidarity union for demonstrations in support of wage increases to pay for the price rises.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in Metropolitan Report on Saturday under a picture of a young girl on a seesaw at Sagamore Park in Teaneck, N.J., misidentified her. She was Jessica Waxenberg.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Chrysler Unit Arranges $4.8 Billion Refinancing
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation, the Chrysler Corporation's financing subsidiary, said yesterday that it had agreed with more than 200 banks and other lenders on refinancing $4.8 billion of private debt.

title: AREA FOR SHIPS TO BURN WASTES IS FOUND TO BE WHALE HABITAT
description: An area site off the New Jersey coast in which the Environmental Protection Agency wants specially equipped ships to burn toxic wastes has been found an important habitat of the endangered sperm whale and other marine mammmals.

THE RACES IN MISSISSIPPI: OLD ORDER AND NEW
description: A recent issue of The Jackson Advocate, a black newspaper here, carried an article and a photograph reporting that Fred L. Banks Jr., the newest black county judge, had been sworn in by Justice Reuben Anderson, the first black member of the Mississippi Supreme Court. Next to it was an article with the headline, ''Cross Burned - Youth Abducted and Beaten in Strife-Torn Durant.''

title: Jersey Adds Lanes To Inspect Autos
description: Additional lanes are being created at state motor-vehicle inspection stations, because more than half of the 4,000 private garages licensed to conduct inspections are expected to leave the program, officials said today.

title: Hearst Magazines' Discount Ad Buys
description: Free lunches at the ''21'' Club must stimulate concentration, why else would so many magazines use them when they want to communicate with agency people and advertisers. Yesterday it was Hearst Magazines in the upstairs room, and the slide show, presented by Judd Vear, vice president and director of corporate advertising sales, told the story of the new, reconstituted corporate buy. Originated more than 10 years ago by Ray Petersen, executive vice president, the corporate buys provided additional discounts over and above the regular frequency discounts of individual publications, for large purchases in combinations of magazines.

description: THE past year has seen a veritable explosion in the so- called paint packages for personal computers, those designer programs that allow users to create freehand drawings on the computer screen using a joystick, a graphics tablet or a mouse as their scribe.

title: WILDCATS QUELL EWING
description: Patrick Ewing played his last game for Georgetown here tonight, ending one of the most brilliant careers in recent college basketball history on a sad note as Villanova took away much of his strength and took the title away from his team.

title: COURT TO WEIGH JAPAN TV SUIT
description: The Supreme Court, responding to pleas from both the Federal Government and the Government of Japan, agreed today to decide whether a number of the biggest Japanese manufacturers of color television sets must stand trial on charges of violating American antitrust laws by selling their products in the United States at artificially low prices.

title: Iberia's Rite of Passage
description: Forget about olives, wine, fruit and fish, those perennial staples of Europe's family quarrels. It will be a bigger, freer family next year when Spain and Portugal become the 11th and 12th members of the Common Market. The good news is that more of Western Europe will be freely welded to common political values than at any time since Charlemagne. Assuming 12 parliaments assent, the market's territory will grow by a third and its population will jump from 280 million to 325 million. On paper, that will make it the West's largest market.

title: SOUTH AFRICA POLICE USE TEAR GAS AGAINST BLACKS
description: The police opened fire today with tear gas and rubber bullets in a black township near the synthetic fuel plant of Sasolburg in a continuation of the unrest that has taken root since last September.

description: The Lebanese Government prepared today to dispatch more troops to southern Lebanon in an effort to halt two weeks of clashes around the Mediterranean port of Sidon.

title: JUSTICE WILLIAMS IS APPOINTED ADMINISTRATOR OF CITY COURTS
description: Justice Milton L. Williams of State Supreme Court, a 53-year-old former police officer who has been a city judge for eight years, yesterday was named to the top administrative position for New York City's court system.

title: 'STREETWISE,' ON HOMELESS YOUTHS
description: HERE is a way, as demonstrated in the documentary ''Streetwise,'' of having a free meal: phone in an order for a pizza, preferably a pizza no one else would want (pineapple-and- pepperoni is the choice of the boy demonstrating this technique). Call from a pay phone near the restaurant, and stay by the telephone until the restaurant calls back to make sure the order is legitimate. After that, wait in the parking lot. It won't take an hour before one lukewarm pineapple-and-pepperoni pizza finds its way to a Dumpster, which you can then raid.

description: Special laws to meet a state payroll and to pay doctors, hospitals, nursing homes and other Medicaid providers were approved by the Legislature today as Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders inched closer to full agreement on a belated budget.

description: A moderate earthquake was reported in northwestern Montana early today but caused no significant damage, the authorities said.

title: CUT IN STARTING PAY REPORTED AT PAN AM AND TRUCK CONCERNS
description: A two-tier pay system providing lower wages for new workers was accepted in agreements reached this weekend between the teamsters' union and major trucking concerns and between Pan American World Airways and its flight attendants.

title: Chess:Canadian and Indian in a Tie At Commonwealth Tourney
description: The third Commonwealth Championship in London ended in a tie for first between Kevin Spraggett, a 30- year-old Canadian international master, and Praveen Thipsay, a 25-year- old Indian international master. In scoring 8-3 in the 11-round Swiss-system tournament, each achieved his first grandmaster norm.

description: For a brief moment, it was just like old times. The leader of the Transport Workers Union was warning that the subways could stop rolling if management remained intransigent.

title: Man With Von B"ulow Tapes Will Not Be Primary Witness
description: A man who said he recorded incriminating conversations with Claus von B"ulow will not be a primary state witness in Mr. von B"ulow's retrial on charges he tried to kill his wealthy wife, a prosecutor said today.

title: MACY'S: FLOWERING OF A PARTY
description: The King and Queen of Protea turned up the other night at a charity party in Macy's. So did lots of other flowers.

title: South Africa Border Death
description: A black man was electrocuted trying to enter South Africa illegally through a newly built electrified fence along part of the border with Zimbabwe. A Defense Force spokesman said the man, whose body was found Saturday, was the first person to die trying to cross the fence.

title: SIX-MONTH-OLD COAL MINERS' STRIKE GROWS BITTER
description: For six months, several hundred coal miners have waged an emotional and sometimes violent strike against subsidiaries of the A. T. Massey Coal Company near the dusty town of Williamson, a stone's throw from the Kentucky border.

title: POLITICAL FORCES COME UNDER NEW SCRUTINY OF PSYCHOLOGY
description: IN a recent rapprochement, psychologists and political scientists are merging disciplines to form a new field, political psychology. The mutual interest comes from psychologists who are applying their skills to the political arena and political scientists who are coming to appreciate the importance of psychology in the world of politics.

title: 'Grind' Opening Postponed
description: ''Grind,'' a musical with book by Fay Kanin, music by Larry Grossman and lyrics by Ellen Fitzhugh, has postponed its opening until April 16. Directed by Harold Prince and starring Ben Vereen, the play will continue in previews at the Mark Hellinger Theater.

title: BLACK POLICEMEN IN SOUTH AFRICA: TARGETS OF INCREASING BLACK RAGE
description: The yellow police van pulled to a stop across the dirt road in one of South Africa's black townships, and an officer bearing a rifle tumbled out to block the path of the approaching sedan. To the rear, a second police car cut off retreat. The sedan's occupants were trapped.

title: REAGAN'S BID FOR 48 MX MISSILES IN '86 CUT TO 21 BY SENATE PANEL
description: A Senate Armed Services subcommittee voted tonight to approve production of 21 more MX missiles next year, rejecting President Reagan's request for 48, according to Congressional sources.

description: A Presidential committee called today for accelerated research that could produce a trans-Pacific supersonic plane and a broad range of new subsonic civil and military aircraft by the year 2000.

title: KEAN TO DECLARE RE-ELECTION BID IN JERSEY TODAY
description: Governor Kean is expected to announce his candidacy for re-election on Tuesday, ending months of speculation that centered more on when he would announce than on whether he would.

title: U. S. COURT CITES LACK OF FAIRNESS IN ROBBERY TRIAL
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday overturned a Queens robbery conviction because the trial judge had questioned the defendant's right to remain silent and pronounced him guilty before the trial was completed.

description: Dave Engle, whom the Minnesota Twins converted from outfielder to catcher three years ago because he couldn't see fly balls hit directly at him in the Metrodome, is now working on a problem that he's having at his adopted position.

title: Medicare Change Is Proposed
description: The Department of Health and Human Services has made public a study that proposes shifting millions of dollars in past and future Medicare payments, mostly to rural hospitals.

title: Comptroller Denies Bids
description: The Comptroller of the Currency, C. Todd Conover, has rejected applications from the BankAmerica Corporation and the American Security Corporation to set up ''non-bank'' bank subsidiaries.

title: Stewart Meacham, 74, Dies; Leader in Antiwar Movement
description: Stewart Meacham, a Methodist missionary who rose to prominence as a leader of the movement against the Vietnam War, died March 24 after a long illness at the Friends House retirement home in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: KOCH CRITICIZES JACKSON SERMON ABOUT HOUSING
description: Mayor Koch charged yesterday that a Palm Sunday sermon by the Rev. Jesse Jackson on New York's housing problems was politically motivated and he urged Mr. Jackson to ''administer to his own flock'' elsewhere.

description: Yonkers Raceway closed its gates to spectators tonight because of a strike by parimutuel clerks, but the races went off as scheduled even though two had only one horse entered in each. Afterward, the track announced it was suspending racing indefinitely.

title: An Institutional Broker Has an Eye on Tenneco
description: The Canarsie section of Brooklyn is a long way from the oil patch. But Alan Gaines, who grew up in Canarsie, has something in common with T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who is the chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Bulls , at Chicago, 8:30 P.M. The Nets have won the last two meetings and hold a 3-1 season edge. description: About a quarter of the 36,479 beds in New York City's general hospitals are unused and unnecessary, according to State Health Department officials.

title: Sotheby's to Auction Beatles' Rolls Royce
description: The Beatles' Rolls Royce, a 19-foot- long limousine decorated with colorful scrollwork and psychedelic designs, will be sold June 29 at a Sotheby's auction of rock-and-roll memorabilia.

title: Topics;   Untoward Results;   Ketchup by Robot
description: Peter Hughes, a robot maker, thinks he can teach a computer costing a mere $100,000 to wait on tables in fast-food restaurants. The six- armed machine would trundle around a U-shaped track taking orders, delivering food, making change, even wiping up spills.

description: David H. Murdock, the West

title: ABDUCTED DUTCH PRIEST SLAIN IN LEBANON
description: A shepherd found the body of a missing Dutch priest today at the bottom of a ravine in the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, a Christian radio station reported.

title: NEW MYSTERY ON CBS AN OLD-STYLE JIGSAW
description: THE less said about ''Guilty Conscience,'' the better are your chances for enjoying it. The TV movie, on CBS at 9 this evening, is one of those old-fashioned jigsaw dramas, strewn with unexpected twists right down to when the last piece is put cleverly in place. The writers and executive producers are Richard Levinson and William Link, a team that knows a thing or two about constructing mysteries. They created the series ''Columbo,'' and one of their TV movies, ''Rehearsal for Murder,'' was given a 1982 Edgar Allan Poe Award. They are also consultants for the current series ''Murder, She Wrote.''

title: SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Liberian Leader Reports Close Call With Gunmen
description: Samuel K. Doe, the head of state, reported that assassins led by the deputy chief of his personal guard poured machine-gun fire into his jeep today in an attempt to kill him.

title: IODINE DEFICIENCY IN HIMALAYAS IS BELIEVED TO DISABLE MILLIONS
description: NEW DELHI HEALTH experts along the southern fringe of the Himalayas have become alarmed by recent evidence that a lack of iodine in the diet is dooming millions of children to mental and physical disabilities.

title: Kennedy Son Robbed of $7
description: Patrick J. Kennedy, the 17-year-old son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, was robbed of $7 at a convenience store early Sunday, and Dwayne Hopkins, 19, of Hyannis was arraigned today on a robbery charge. Patrick Kennedy was not injured in the robbery, which occurred when he stopped to buy some doughnuts and apple juice on his way from a dinner in Medford to the family's Cape Cod home, a family spokesman said.

title: Emigres' Spy Trial Delayed
description: The trial of two Soviet emigres charged with espionage was postponed today until April 10, Federal District Judge David Kenyon announced. He gave no reason for the delay in the the trial of Svetlana and Nickolay Ogorodnikov, which had been scheduled to begin Wednesday. The Ogorodnikovs are charged with conspiring with Richard W. Miller, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to pass secret government documents to the Soviet Union.
