title: Senators Plan Soviet Visit
description: Four Senators said today that they had accepted an invitation from the Soviet Academy of Sciences to visit the Soviet Union April 9-15 to discuss arms control with Soviet scientists. The four are William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine; Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware; Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, and Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire.

title: BAD NEWS ON ACID RAIN, ON CHANNEL 13'S 'NOVA'
description: GOOD documentaries stay on top of the news. ''Acid Rain: New Bad News'' seems to be slightly ahead of it. The convention is to think of acid rain as a dismal byproduct of coal-burning power plants. The ''Nova'' program, which will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 tonight, says it is more complicated than that. Sulfur dioxide is not the only villain.

title: MINIMUM TAX LEVEL PROPOSED
description: A group of House Democrats today proposed legislation for a minimum tax on corporations and individuals, a proposal they hope could become part of a deficit-reduction package.

title: OUR KIDS AND COCAINE
description: For those who think that serious

title: PRIMAGES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
TOP HONDURAN JUDGE, IN JAIL, REFLECTS ON QUALITY OF JUSTICE
description: The newly named Chief Justice of the Honduran Supreme Court was relaxing in a comfortable jail cell in the central penitentiary today, patiently waiting for the current political conflict to be resolved so he can be released.

title: Accord at Pan Am
description: Pan American World Airways and negotiators for flight attendants reached an agreement yesterday that would change work rules to the carrier's benefit and would provide much lower salaries for new workers, according to company and union officials.

title: E. S. M. TRUSTEE WEIGHS AMERICAN SAVINGS SUIT
description: The American Savings and Loan Association of Miami has already estimated that its dealings with the failed E.S.M. Government Securities will cost it more than $55 million in losses, after taxes. But that may not be the final bill.

title: CORRECTION
description: Two articles in Business Day yesterday about television station ownership misstated the effective date of a rule changing the station-ownership limit to 12 for any one individual or company, in place of the present 7. It takes effect today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
DNA Distortions
description: All life depends on the integrity of the structure of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid), the master chemical of heredity. Serious damage to a cell's DNA can kill that cell. More subtle damage can produce mutations and sometimes initiate the processes of abnormal cell growth that lead to cancer.

title: A Political Football?
description: ''Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin today informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that the New York City Employees Retirement System had acquired 5.7 percent of the outstanding stock of the Green Bay Packer Corporation Inc., operators of the National Football League's Green Bay Packers.

title: OPERA: MIGENES-JOHNSON AS LULU
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's production of Alban Berg's ''Lulu,'' which returned to the repertory last night for the first time since the premiere of the reconstructed full-length version in the 1980-81 season, is as fascinating a 20th-century music drama as the company has ever staged. It manages to be both remarkably faithful to the composer's intricate 12-tone score and a theatrical coup as well, by turns mordantly ironic, broadly comical, sickeningly realistic and penetrating in its insights into the behavior of the human animal. In the pit, James Levine and the Metropolitan orchestra give a gripping reading of one of opera's craggiest scores, which is, or should be, the first requirement of any presentable ''Lulu.''

title: Baldwin Posts $54 Million Net
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation said that it had a 1984 profit of $54 million, compared with a loss of $1.36 billion in 1983.

title: AWARDS ANNOUNCED
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters has announced that 14 American composers and the Group for Contemporary Music will share $80,000 as winners of the Academy's 1985 music awards. Sixteen authors were named as recipients of the group's literary awards, totaling $86,500. The awards will be formally presented at the annual event the Academy calls its ''ceremonial'' on May 15.

title: Review for Some Of Aetna Ratings
description: Moody's Investors Service, which is reviewing its ratings of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company and Aetna Casualty and Surety Company for possible downgrading, announced yesterday that the part of their debt that is insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association is currently not affected by the review. The M.B.I.A. is a consortium of five insurers, including the Aetna companies, that guarantees principal and interest payments on municipal debt.

title: Market Place;   Health Care In Spotlight
description: THE announcement on Sunday of plans to

title: Gulf Unit Is Sold
description: The Gulf Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chevron Corporation, said it had sold the Keydril Company, its offshore drilling operation, for $190 million in cash. A spokesman said that Gulf had agreed not to disclose the name of Keydril's buyer. Gulf said that the sale would assist Chevron in reducing debt incurred when it purchased Gulf.

title: FLOURISHING TREASURY MARKET
description: As the Treasury securities market has emerged from a Wall Street backwater to the forefront of the world's financial arena, the personality and style of the marketplace are being transformed by new participants, new products and, following repeated scandals, the possibility of Federal regulation.

title: SCOUTING ;   Don't Walk
description: Ramon Romero, a 26-year-old left- hander, showed exceptional control during spring training, and as a result he has been assured a bullpen job when the Cleveland Indians break camp.

title: STOCKS EDGE UP IN SLOW TRADING
description: Stock prices closed moderately higher yesterday on Wall Street but trading volume remained weak as investors entered the new quarter with grave concerns about the economy and corporate profits.

title: JUDICIAL NOMINEE'S REJECTION ASSAILED
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan charged today that the Reagan Administration's decision not to nominate an official of the Legal Aid Society to a Federal judgeship in Manhattan reflected a political approach that ''corrupts the system of appointment.''

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $12,064,000 from a Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock dividend for the quarter and year. c-Net income The company's loss for the year is primarily a result of provisions for losses on loans and real estate of $421.6 million. The latest year net also includes a $42 million provision for accounting adjustments and a $38.2 million charge to increase the reserve for losses on accrued interest. There was another $28.6 millin charge caused by the writedown of physical assets and other contingencies.

title: Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation said it had agreed with its lending banks to extend until October the $41 million in financing arranged in January. The company also said its $28 million of existing bank debt had also been extended until October. The telecommunications company, which has struggled in recent months to survive a severe cash squeeze, agreed last week to sell its E.F. Johnson subsidiary to Diversified Energies Inc. for $26 million.

title: TOMB OF CHINESE EMPEROR MAY BE INTACT, AFTER ALL
description: The possibility of an archeological discovery to rank with any yet made in China was raised today when experts said that they had found evidence that the tomb of China's first Emperor, the despotic Qin Shihuangdi, was not looted and burned in an uprising shortly after his death, as historians have long believed.

title: Topics ;   Untoward Results ;   What a Dump
description: Once upon a time you could look up at the sky and know that what you saw - the moon, a lot of stars, the occasional comet - was just about all there was to see. Any dust was cosmic, which made it O.K. But give a human being a clean, well-lighted place, like space, and he's bound to clutter it up.

title: DEMISE OF THE PCJR: VIEW FROM I. B. M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, stung by press and industry charges that it has abandoned the home computer market by ceasing production of its PCjr, suggested yesterday that another inexpensive PC offering was in the works.

title: Execution in Iran Reported
description: The brother-in-law of Massoud Rajavi, the Paris-based leader of the People's Mujahadeen, an Iranian group oppposed to the Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, was executed in a prison in Teheran, Mr. Rajavi's organization said today. A statement from the group said Mr. Rajavi's brother-in-law, Mojahed Asghar Nazemi, was executed in Evin Prison in Teheran last month.

title: SOVIET USE OF WEST'S DATA DETAILED IN FRENCH PRESS
description: Confidential Soviet documents obtained by French intelligence indicate that Moscow's acquisition of Western technical data has saved the Soviet Union millions of dollars in arms research, according to reports here.

title: Gail B. Shapiro Is Married To Patrick M. McGovern
description: Gail B. Shapiro, a lawyer in New York, and Patrick Michael McGovern, a lawyer with the London firm of Lovel, White & King, were married yesterday by the Registrar, L. S. Johnson, in Reigate, Surrey, England.

title: REPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $203,000 for the quarter and $261,000 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LEG-STRETCHER

title: Debt Issues
description: General Foods Capital Corp. is offering $75 million of 11 1/2 percent five- year Euronotes due in 1990 at a price of 99 3/4, through underwiters led by Salomon Brothers, and in the U.S. is offering $25 million of 12 1/8 percent six-year notes and 12 1/4 percent seven- year notes priced at 100, through Salomon Brothers.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SENATE HEARS OF ABUSE IN STATES' MENTAL CARE
description: Residents of state institutions for the mentally ill and mentally retarded have been beaten and abused and they often receive little treatment except for medication to keep them quiet, according to testimony given today at a Congressional hearing.

title: VILLANOVA STUNS GEORGETOWN, 66-64, IN FINAL
description: This was supposed to be a coronation, a celebration of the mighty Georgetown Hoyas as one of college basketball greatest teams. Instead, the crowning was spoiled by a new and unlikely champion, the Villanova Wildcats.

title: The Sfogliatelle of Yonkers
description: Still smarting from the suggestion

title: NEW COMMITMENTS MADE BY JAPANESE ON TRADE, U.S. SAYS
description: The Reagan Administration, seeking to blunt Congressional anger over lack of access to the Japanese market, said today that Japan had made ''new commitments'' on trade.

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains on the net equity in the results of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $7,480,000 for the quarter and $13,303,000 for the year, a pre-tax provision of $2,872,000 for the quarter and year to reduce certain real estate held for development and sale to estimated net realizable value, and an after-tax loss of $1,186,000 for the year on minority interests in the results of MCO Resources Inc. c-Includes gains on the net equity in the results of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $137,000 for the quarter and $1,558,000 for the year, and an after- tax loss of $1,495,000 for the year on interest in MCO Resources.

title: COAST CHIEF IS DEFENDED BY MAYOR DESPITE OUTCRY
description: In response to a public outcry over police use of a fifth-grade classroom for a training exercise, Mayor Dianne Feinstein today defended Police Chief Cornelius Murphy as ''about the best the department produces.''

title: THE INJURED, FEW OR MANY, DESERVE COMPENSATION
description: ''The Cause and Defect of Orangemail'' outlined well the need to develop new approaches to the costly morass of toxic tort cases. And you noted that some creative judges are taking the lead in tackling the problems that these science- and health- related injury cases present. However, you missed the most promising potential for change - alternative dispute resolution procedures, developed by the private sector, which can resolve such cases economically and equitably out of court.

title: ENERSERV PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ACID FUMES AT PLANT CAUSE FEAR IN BHOPAL
description: Acid fumes leaking today from the same Union Carbide plant where an accident four months ago killed thousands of people caused widespread panic but only minor injuries to seven people.

title: IRAQ REPORTS AIR ATTACKS ON TEHERAN
description: Iraq said its jets raided Iran's capital today for the 13th time in 18 days.

title: MEDIA HORIZONS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $87,267 for a partnership interest in Phoenix Home-Farm, a consumer publication. c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $92,448 on the sublease and sale of leasehold improvements.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
WICHITA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1983 results were restated to reflect a change in accounting method.

title: HOW MATERIAL GETS PUT IN SECRET FILES
description: The following paragraph, taken from a memorandum setting out objectives for the Navy's 1986 budget, was classified ''Secret.'' In its entirety, it read:

title: GOLDSMITH BIDS FOR ZELLERBACH
description: Sir James Goldsmith yesterday proposed paying more than $1.14 billion in cash for the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, one of the nation's leading paper and forest products companies.

title: FIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Vote on Revising Constitution Fails
description: A legislative committee today killed a resolution calling on Congress to convene a constitutional convention to require a balanced Federal budget.

title: JOBLESS WORKERS LEARN NEW SKILLS
description: UNDER an innovative program to train unemployed automobile workers for new careers, several thousand laid off employees of the Ford Motor Company are enrolled in colleges around the nation, studying subjects ranging from welding to computer technology.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Bonds Show Little Change
description: Bond prices were little changed in light trading yesterday, as market participants decided to remain on the sidelines and assess conditions after last week's rally.

title: PITTSBURGH & WEST VIRGINIA RR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss includes a writedown of $26.9 million on assets.

title: OF TAXES, OLYMPICS AND DEATH
description: A decade of income for Rocky Mountain states from leasing public land for oil and gas exploration and from taxing coal shipped out of state apparently could not last forever, and the states are trying to adjust.

title: Ivan Boesky Buys 8.7% CBS Stake
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he and companies he controls have purchased 8.7 percent of CBS Inc. stock for $247.1 million.

title: OUTLAYS FOR BUILDING SHOW A SHARP 1.4% RISE
description: Spending on new construction climbed a healthy 1.4 percent in February, spurred by home remodeling and office and industrial projects, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Wildcats Wear Their Victory Well
description: As the horn sounded, Dwayne McClain lay on the floor of Rupp Arena, the final inbound pass in his arms, his body still, and the national championship in Villanova's grasp. The way he controlled the basketball in the minutes that followed made it seem that the only way it could be removed was by surgery.

title: BALANCED SCHEDULE IS SOUGHT
description: Many Western Conference teams are unhappy because, under the league's unbalanced schedule, some of the Eastern Conference's top crowd-pleasers - Larry Bird, Julius Erving, Michael Jordan and Isiah Thomas - make only one appearance each season in the 12 conference arenas.

title: REPORT TRIES TO REMEDY NEGLECT OF ART IN SCHOOL
description: WHEN somebody says, ''I don't know anything about art, but I know what I like,'' what the person likes is, in the eyes of many critics, usually awful. Consider the art displayed in some motels, probably selected by people who know what they like, their taste untouched by instruction.

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After securities losses of $15,000 for the quarter and $54,000 for the year. c-After a securities loss of $59,000. d-After a loss of $175,000 from discontinued operations and a securities loss of $77,000.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $646,000 for the quarter and $2,477,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $475,000 for the quarter and $2,687,000 for the year. -The company said share earnings reflect dividends and discounts on non-convertible preferred stock of $184,000 and $1,004,000 for the latest quarter and year, and $80,000 and $245,000 for the 1983 quarter and year, respectively.

title: MUSIC: SYMPHONY 5 BY GLENN BRANCA
description: GLENN BRANCA'S Symphony No. 5 (''Describing Planes of an Expanding Hypersphere''), Thursday night at the Irving Plaza, had a certain undeniable power. It also represented both a welcome return to basics and a hint of compositional growth.

title: DELTAUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $3,114,000. c-After a tax credit of $9,018,000 and an accounting credit of $1,549,000.

title: SEACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a provision for loss on disposal of containership operations of $4 million for the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $20,754,000 for the quarter and $25,499,000 for the year.

title: Judge Suspended From Duty Is Back at Pittsburgh Office
description: A judge, suspended from duty for dismissing rape charges because the teen-ager who said she had been raped was late for court, reported for work in his office today, but was barred from hearing cases or making rulings.

title: Cartier Robbed of Watches
description: One or more thieves broke into the Cartier jewelry store on Fifth Avenue at 52d Street early yesterday and stole four watches and other goods worth more than $10,000, the authorities said. Police officers and a security guard responding to an alarm at the store at 2:38 A.M. found two display cases inside broken and partly emptied, the store's security director, Alex Lazzarino, said. The watches, worth more than $1,500 each, were the most expensive items left overnight in the display cases, he said.

title: A DISMAL OPENER FOR TROUT
description: In the Catskills, the opening of the state trout season today was a dismal blend of freezing rain, hail, snow flurries and temperatures in the 30's much of the time.

title: OKINAWA, 40 YEARS LATER: NEVER-ENDING INVASION
description: It was big news the other day when a United States military trailer ran out of control and smashed into Tsuru Yokota's home here.

title: Fed Rules Urged for Dealers in Treasury Issues
description: Large banks and securities firms that dominate the largely unregulated market in Treasury debt issues yesterday came out in favor of legislation that would give the Federal Reserve the ability to regulate the Treasury securities market.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $73,000 for the quarter, a gain of $377,000 for the year from discontinued operations, and a gain of $23,576,000 for the year from the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $2,473,000 for the quarter and $5,816,000 for the year.

title: TEMCO HOME HEALTHCARE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FUTURISTIC RACETRACK OPENS
description: In a festive aurora borealis atmosphere of blinking lights, colored balloons, strolling tuxedoed musicians and old horseplayers who proved you can go home again, Garden State Park reopened tonight.

title: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary loss of $640,000 from reversal of tax benefit. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6,292,000 and an extraordinary gain of $5,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $146,000 and an extraordinary gain of $523,000. e-Net loss after loss from discontinued operations of $8,449,000 and an extraordinary credit of $158,000.The year-ago quarter includes provision of $2,365,000 for writedown of oil and gas properties and equity in loss of affiliates of $2,695,000. The year-ago loss from discontinued operations includes equity in loss of affiliate of $4,053,000.

title: SATELLITE MUSIC NETWORK reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $225,450 from an accounting change.

title: Longest-Tunnel Mark Restored to New York
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Kosar's Plans
description: The Youngstown, Ohio, dentist who is representing

title: JUDGE BARS BLACK FIREFIGHTERS' PROMOTION QUOTAS
description: A Federal district judge today struck down an affirmative action plan adopted by the District of Columbia Fire Department, ruling that it illegally used quotas to foster the promotion of blacks and thus violated the rights of whites.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on March 6 with an article about the strong dollar's impact on corporate assets incorrectly described the effect at 14 major companies from 1981 to 1984. The declines listed in the chart reflect only the amounts by which the strong dollar depressed growth, not an overall decline in assets.

title: Dayton Unit Retirement P. Gerald Mills, the 56-year-
description: old chairman of the Dayton-

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFING ;   New Calder Awaited
description: After years of delay, an Alexander Calder work called ''Mountains and Clouds'' is to be installed in the lobby of the Hart Senate Office Building. Just before he died in 1976, Calder gave the Capitol Achitect, George White, the model of a combined mobile-stabile for the building, which opened in 1983.

title: CASE OF MINISTRY STUDENT IS ACCEPTED
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state can constitutionally refuse to provide state funds to assist a student in becoming a minister.

title: LAURENTIAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Dow Backs Cooper On Rorer Plan
description: The Dow Chemical Company, which owns 9.5 percent of the shares of Rorer Group Inc., said it intended to vote in favor of a Cooper Laboratories Inc. proposal that seeks the redemption of share purchase rights issued by Rorer. Rorer, a health-care company based in Fort Washington, Pa., adopted the anti-takeover measures two months ago.

title: DEFINITIONS USED FOR CLASSIFICATION
description: Although no law authorizing Government officials to classify information has been adopted by Congress, an executive order signed by President Reagan on April 2, 1982, permits the following categories:

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Group Warns Baptists To Back Candidate
description: Conservative fundamentalists are threatening to withdraw financial support from the Southern Baptist Convention if their candidate for president is not re-elected in June, the church's news agency said today.

title: Operation Goes Well For King
description: Bernard King underwent two hours of reconstructive surgery on his right knee yesterday morning at Lenox Hill Hospital. Dr. Norman Scott, the Knick team doctor, replaced a torn ligament with tendon taken from another part of the knee, and also removed torn cartilage.

title: Pennsylvania Official Loses Appeal in a Shoplifting Case
description: Pennsylvania's Secretary of Agriculture, Penrose Hallowell, today lost his appeal to have his conviction of shoplifting a $4.99 cassette tape overturned.

title: FLORIDA LAWMAKERS FACE GROWTH ISSUES
description: Brimming with good intentions, the Florida Legislature today opened a new session that has been billed by the state's leaders as one that must confront a multitude of social and environmental problems created by continuing unrestrained growth in the state.

title: CENTRAL JERSEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Not available, the company said its main source of revenue during these periods was interest income.

title: Thon's Comeback
description: He appeared a bit shaky after a fast start in exhibition play, but

title: Economic Scene;   Summit Talks: German View
description: -year old West German Minister of Economics and the new leader of the Free Democratic Party, considers it urgent for next month's summit conference in Bonn to initiate a new round of trade negotiations. ''The protectionist mood is rising,'' he said in an interview in New York last week, ''and we need a new effort to defend a multilateral trading system.''

title: TED TURNER SAID TO GET AID ON CBS
description: Ted Turner, who was reported late in February to be seeking a takeover of CBS Inc., is preparing for a move on the company, sources in the broadcast industry said last night.

title: 100,000 Homeless in Brazil
description: Heavy rains and flooding have hit northeastern Brazil after a long drought, leaving at least 100,000 people homeless in three states, the authorities said today. The worst-hit state was Ceara, on the Atlantic coast. Similar conditions were reported in the states of Piaui and Maranhao.

title: UNCERTAINTY ON JAPAN'S TRADE PROMISES
description: Amid confusion over exactly what commitments Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone offered an American trade envoy, Japan today announced new regulations governing its telecommunications industry.

title: ROBINS SETS UP DALKON SHIELD PAYMENTS FUND
description: The A. H. Robins Company, a Richmond pharmaceutical concern, said yesterday that it had set aside $615 million to settle legal claims from thousands of women who used its Dalkon Shield birth control device.

title: Kings of High School Chess
description: Led by a 17-year-old Russian-born

title: Report Cites E. S. M. Methods
description: After suffering trading losses of millions of dollars in the Government securities market, E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. was able to continue in business only by erecting an elaborate house of cards that stood up for many years.

title: JORDAN ROLLS UP 31 TO HELP BEAT NETS
description: Michael Jordan and Orlando Woolridge led the Chicago Bulls to a 108-94 victory over the Nets tonight.

title: Shea Opener
description: All ready for the New York baseball opener next Tuesday? All set to watch Dwight Gooden flip the Cards while Hernandez, Carter, Strawberry and Foster take turns pounding away at Joaquin Andujar?

title: MICROFAST SOFTWARE CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $3,364 from discontinued operations and a gain of $154,507 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After income of $3,833 from discontinued operations.

title: Stars of Chile's Theater Seized at Protest Rally
description: The police seized at least 81 people, including dozens of Chile's leading actors and actresses, as they marched today to protest the murder of a leftist son of one of their colleagues, the actors' union said.

title: GUNMAN RELEASES CHILDREN HELD AS HOSTAGES AT SCHOOL
description: A man held three children hostage for almost four hours today at an elementary school, demanding $8,000 and an automobile so that he could make a new start on life, the authorities said.

title: CARTER URGES PARTY TO OFFER A POLICY MIX
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that Democrats should take a lesson from his 1976 Presidential campaign and offer a combination of conservative and liberal policies as they try rebuild the party's political base.

title: North Dakota Bishop Named
description: An Auxiliary Bishop in Michigan, the Rev. James S. Sullivan of Lansing, has been appointed Bishop for the 100,000-member Roman Catholic Diocese of Fargo, N.D., church officials said today. Mr. Sullivan, 55 years old, succeeds Bishop Justin A. Driscoll, who died Nov. 19. The Fargo Diocese covers 30 counties Mr. Sullivan, a native of Kalamazoo, Mich., has been an Auxiliary Bishop in Lansing since 1972.

title: JUDGE IS HURT
description: A car bomb apparently intended for an Italian magistrate exploded in this seaside town today, killing a woman and her two children. The judge escaped with minor injuries.

title: Dow Drops by 7. 07 in a Late Selloff
description: Selling pressure erupted in blue- chip issues during the final hour yesterday, causing the stock market to suffer its worst decline in two weeks as trading remained moderate.

title: LATEST ALBUM BY THE FALL APPEARS ON AMERICAN LABEL
description: THE FALL, who performed twice in New York last weekend and will be back on Saturday for a show at the Peppermint Lounge, are a kind of institution within the avant-garde of British rock. Mark E. Smith, the group's singer and lyricist, put together the first fall lineup in Manchester, England, in 1977, at the height of the British punk-rock explosion. The bands The Fall shared stages with in those days, most notably the Buzzcocks and Joy Division, are history now, but the Fall, despite various personnel changes, has endured.

title: Laws on Liquor Prices Upheld in Two Rulings
description: New York State's highest court issued two rulings today upholding the State Liquor Authority's regulation of liquor prices.

title: AMERICAN GUARANTY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $7,547,000 for the quarter and $5,656,000 for the year and a tax credit of $3,094,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,474,000 for the quarter and $11,584,000 for the year.

title: Senate Unit Seeks Cut In Budget for S.I. Port
description: A Senate subcommittee has voted to cut $7 million from the funds to prepare Staten Island as the new home port of the battleship Iowa and six escort ships, Navy and congressional sources said today.

title: Truman Statue Protected
description: The City Council approved a plan Monday calling for a $2,500 alarm system for a statue of Harry S. Truman. Vandals have stolen or damaged the statue's cane three times since August 1983, and the city has spent $10,000 on repairs.

title: Airport Parking Being Restored
description: Three levels of the five-level parking garage at La Guardia Airport that was closed Friday for emergency repairs are expected to reopen today.

title: BRINGING SCRUTABILITY TO CHINESE COOKING
description: ''A LOT of people misunderstand Chinese cooking,'' said Lily Lee Levin during a recent visit to New York. Mrs. Levin, who was born and raised in China, is the wife of the United States Consul General in Hong Kong, Burton Levin. She is also an enthusiastic exponent of the art of Chinese cooking, which, she insists with disarming conviction, is not so difficult as Westerners make out. If millions of Chinese women can turn out three meals a day, Mrs. Levin says, there is no reason why the rest of us should find it daunting.

title: Letter
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Toy Maker Offers Debentures, Stock
description: Hasbro Bradley Inc., a toy manufacturer, yesterday began offering a $60 million of convertible debentures, as well as 2.25 million shares of common stock.

title: HASIDIM MAINTAIN MATZOH TRADITIONS
description: In the hectic weeks before Passover, fathers and sons gather in the basement of Congregation Zemach David Synagogue in this Rockland County village to bake matzohs. They are following the tradition of their ancestors, who hastily made the unleavened bread during their exodus from slavery in Egypt.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Comings and Goings
description: The Generals released an offensive tackle,

title: A 'Super Super'
description: Most building superintendents

title: POET ACCLAIMED FOR EPIGRAMS
description: James Vincent Cunningham, a poet and professor emeritus at Brandeis University, died Saturday of heart failure at Marlboro Hospital.

title: PICKENS, UNOCAL CHIEF SQUARE OFF AT HEARING
description: The gloves came off on Capitol Hill today as the flinty chairman of the Unocal Corporation traded insults with T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who says he might try to take over Unocal.

title: COMP-U-CARD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 21
description: b-Not available c-After extraordinary tax credit of $1,632,000, or 22 cents a share. d-Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid March 18.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
Pro Hockey;   EYE PROTECTION BECOMES ISSUE
description: It becomes more apparent each season that the National Hockey League will not make eye protection mandatory until one of its rank and file suffers a blinding injury.

title: U.S. Drive On Bank Fraud Set
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today announced plans for a multi-agency attack on bank fraud, which he said had been a factor in more than half of the bank failures over recent years.

title: ROCKWOOD HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: CHILDREN EMBRACE FAITH OF FOREBEARS
description: HOWARD M. HALPERN, a Manhattan psychologist, left behind most of his parents' Jewish observances when he left home for college. By all odds, his daughter Sharon might have forsaken even the few to which he clung. But as a young girl she evinced a religious sensibility, and four years ago, in a telephone call from Israel, the depth of her feelings took him by surprise.

title: END OF TAX LAW NEARS ON CAR USE
description: Under heavy pressure from constituents, the House of Representatives voted today to repeal the new law and regulations that require people who drive company cars or use their own cars on business to keep detailed records for tax purposes. The vote was 412 to 1.

description: The latest quarter and year had 14 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively, compared with 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the year-earlier quarter and year, respectively.

title: Trade Envoy to Japan Is Not New to Country
description: Gaston J. Sigur may at first appear an unlikely candidate to serve as President Reagan's special trade envoy to Japan. He is known by his colleagues at George Washington University as first and foremost a scholar and historian; his name is rarely mentioned among economists or trade specialists.

title: 'RIDDIGORE,' IN PBS'S GILBERT AND SULLIVAN SERIES
description: PUBLIC television's presentation of ''The Compleat Gilbert and Sullivan,'' a series produced a few years ago in Britain, returns tonight, on WNET Channel 13 at 9, with an offbeat production of ''Ruddigore.'' This odd little work deserves nothing less.

GORBACHEV IS SAID TO FAVOR MEETING WITH REAGAN
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the new Soviet leader, has responded positively to President Reagan's proposal for a meeting, but the site and time of the meeting must still be worked out, White House officials said today.

title: DEFAMATION IS LAID TO CITY AIDES IN WEST 44TH ST. DEMOLITION CASE
description: Sol Goldman, one of the city's largest real-estate owners, charged city officials yesterday with falsely accusing him of demolishing four buildings on West 44th Street in the middle of the night and with harassing tenants in buildings on Eighth Avenue.

title: BLACK SOUTH AFRICA BABY IS VICTIM OF VIOLENCE
description: A year-old black infant was reported burned to death in a gasoline-bomb attack after a crowd of youthful black militants attacked his parents' home overnight, believing it to be that of a person collaborating with the white authorities

title: KIDNAPPED FRENCH DIPLOMAT IS FREED IN LEBANON
description: A French diplomat who was held by kidnappers for 10 days has been freed in Lebanon.

title: PLEA BARGAIN TALKS REPORTED IN SPY TRIAL ON COAST
description: Negotiations are being held toward a possible plea bargain agreement for a Russian immigrant couple accused of spying for the Soviet Government, sources close to the case said today.

title: TEAMSTERS AND PAN AM CONTRACTS: DUAL WAGE SCALES MAY PROVE DISRUPTIVE
description: By accepting a lower pay scale for newly hired workers, the teamsters' union and flight attendants for Pan American World Airlines appear to have resolved their most immediate need: to protect existing jobs. Labor experts say, though, that the strategy may prove divisive for unions in the long run because it essentially pits older employees against their newly hired colleagues.

title: Away With the Libel Hash
description: Angered by a bad review, Mr. Chow, a New York City restaurant, sued the publisher and editors of the French-language Gault/Millau Guide to New York. Amazingly, Federal Judge Thomas Griesa let the case actually go to trial. Even more amazingly, the judge then told the jury that the guide's disparaging remarks about Mr. Chow's

title: Sparkman Board In Tender Offer
description: The Sparkman Energy Corporation said its board had approved a tender offer of $9 a share, or $25.5 million, for the 71.4 percent of the company's stock not already owned by the Yankee Companies, Sparkman's largest stockholder. Sparkman, which operates natural-gas pipelines in southern Texas and Oklahoma, said, though, that if a ''financially responsible third party'' presented a higher offer, its board would drop its own tender offer.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $12,000. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $82,000 for the quarter and $434,000 for the year. d-After a gain of $992,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Whooping Cranes Migrate
description: The world's only wild flock of whooping cranes has begun leaving on its 2,000- mile flight to the Wood Buffalo National Park in Canada, a United States Fish and Wildlife Department biologist said today. The biologist, Tom Stehn, said three family groups and three pairs totaling 15 birds left the Aransas Wildlife Refuge on the South Texas coast in the past week, according to an air survey of the area. He said the remaining 68 whoopers were expected to begin their spring migration over the next two weeks.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES A TRADE REPRISAL AGAINST JAPANESE
description: The Senate Finance Committee today approved tough trade reprisals against Japan. The Administration opposes the bill but may use it to demand further entry for American-made goods into the Japanese market.

title: Letter
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Bill Would Stop Westway Funds
description: Representative Frank J. Guarini of New Jersey, joined by more than dozen other lawmakers, introduced a bill in the House today to prevent the Federal Government from helping build the proposed $2 billion Westway along the Hudson River in Manhattan.

description: Results reflect the use of the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method of determining merchandise inventory costs.

title: British Talking Clock Becomes a Baritone
description: At precisely 11 A.M. today a man's voice was heard on Britain's telephone talking clock for the first time.

title: O'Brien, Cohen Set Swim Marks
description: Mike O'Brien and Tiffany Cohen, Olympic champions from Mission Viejo, Calif., won the first titles and broke American records tonight as the five-day United States short- course swimming championships began.

title: SALVADORAN RIGHTIST PARTIES ASK FOR NEW VOTE
description: A coalition of right-wing parties that appeared to be the losers in national elections here demanded tonight that the vote be nullified because of improprieties, according to Mario Samayoa, president of the El Salvador's Central Elections Commission.

title: CHEMICAL MAY BUY OHIO UNIT
description: Chemical Bank has emerged as the most likely purchaser of the failed Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati, but despite an announcement by Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio that a buyer had been found, the New York bank issued a statement saying there was no agreement.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SENATE ARMED SERVICES COMMITTEE VOTES FOR 21 FURTHER MX MISSILES
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee, in a closed session, today approved production of 21 more MX missiles in the 1986 military budget, rejecting Democrats' efforts to cut the program more sharply, Senate aides said.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Rates Up in Quiet Trading
description: Interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday for short- and long-term Treasury securities.

title: ILLEGAL WILDLIFE BRINGS HIGH PRICES
description: In the course of an undercover investigation into black market dealings in birds of prey, a young man handed $36,000 in hundred- dollar bills to an undercover agent for six illegal gyrfalcons, a large, fierce hawk coveted by falconers.

title: MUSEUM OF AMERICAN INDIAN ENDS ITS ACCORD WITH TEXAN
description: The Museum of the American Indian has decided to end its agreement to negotiate exclusively with H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer executive, in its efforts to move the museum's collection of artifacts to more spacious and well-funded quarters, a lawyer for the museum said yesterday.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

title: FILM: TWO SHORT WORKS BY HERZOG
description: WERNER HERZOG continues to go his own way, sometimes with triumphant results, often at great physical and emotional risk to himself and, in the case of ''Fitzcarraldo,'' to others.

title: F .D. I. C. Sues Iowa Bank
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has sued the United Central Bank of Des Moines, contending that the bank should have known that a former stockbroker, Gary Lewelleyn, was using it to funnel stolen money from his father's bank in Humboldt, Iowa. Officials of United Central said on Monday that the suit was unfounded. Mr. Lewellyn was sentenced to prison for embezzling $17 million from the First National Bank in Humboldt, causing it to fail in April 1982.

title: ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $2,451,000.

title: Times Beach, Mo., Votes Itself Out of Existence
description: The dioxin-contaminated town of Times Beach officially ceased to exist today when its aldermen voted unanimously to disincorporate and Gov. John Ashcroft approved the action.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Sign of SpringSoft-shell crabs have arrived. The seasonal delicacies, a certain sign of spring for New Yorkers, are coming from Florida waters and are available in a few fish establishments around town. As the season progresses, they will become more widely available. According to Fulton Fish Market representatives, prices are reasonable, considering that it is the start of the season. The crabs will be cheaper later as supplies from Chesapeake Bay become abundant.

title: Sewer Bonds Yield Up to 9% The Milwaukee Metropolitan

title: Breakfast for Carter
description: When Glenn Godden, the head of catering at the Sheraton- Carlton Hotel, learned that Jimmy Carter was coming to breakfast, he called the White House and inquired about the former President's favorite dishes. As a result, when Mr. Carter arrived Tuesday morning for a reporters' gathering, he found grits and country ham on the menu, as well as scrambled eggs and fried potatoes for those with stubbornly Yankee regional tastes.

title: M. T. A. Inspector Confirmed
description: Sanford E. Russell was confirmed by the State Senate as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's new inspector general. Mr. Russell, 54 years old, has served since 1983 as the M.T.A.'s deputy inspector general for audits and analysis and before that was director of the Legislative Commission on Expenditure Review for four years. He will earn about $82,000 in his new post. Mr. Russell succeeds Sidney Schwartz, who left to join the staff of State Senator Roy Goodman, a Manhattan Republican.

title: THAIS HOSTILE TO ETHNIC VIETNAMESE
description: Tens of thousands of ethnic Vietnamese living in Thailand are finding themselves in a precarious position as public anger mounts over daily reports of incursions into Thai territory by Vietnamese troops pursuing Cambodian guerrillas.

title: WASHINGTON WARNS LIBYA ON CREATION OF TERRORIST GROUP
description: The Reagan Administration criticized Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya today for his formation of a ''Pan Arab command'' to carry out acts of violence against the United States, other Western nations and moderate Arab regimes.

title: A False Transit Peace
description: Governor Cuomo's swift gift of open-ended arbitration to New York City's transit workers looks like a bid for peace and quiet. There will be no strike this year - and no need for the Governor to punish workers for an illegal act.

title: Argentina Marks Lost War
description: Argentina today marked the third anniversary of its ill-fated invasion of the Falkland Islands. President Raul Alfonsin attended a religious mass in memory of the more than 650 servicemen who died in the 1982 war.

title: VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 17

title: PENTAGON REPORT SAYS SOVIET SPURS ITS ARMS PROGRAM

title: MAINE SHIPBUILDER GETS NAVY CONTRACT FOR A NEW DESTROYER
description: The Navy today selected a Maine shipyard to build a new class of destroyers, passing over two major rivals for the service's biggest shipbuilding program for the rest of the century.

title: RANGERS LOSE, BUT GAIN PLAYOFF
description: The Rangers clinched the last playoff spot in the Patrick Division last night, despite setting a club record for most losses in a season. Unfortunately, their opponent in the playoffs will be the Flyers, who defeated the Rangers last night, 2-1, at Madison Square Garden for a sweep of their seven- game series.

title: BRITON SEES ALLIED INTEREST IN 'STAR WARS' RESEARCH
description: Britain's Defense Minister said here today that there was potential Western European interest in joining the United States research effort on a space-based missile defense system. He said the motivation was the potential technological gain.

Jascalevich, the former New Jersey surgeon whose trial on charges of murdering five patients turned into a major test of the rights of journalists to protect news sources, died last September of a cerebral hemorrhage in Mar del Plata, Argentina, members of his family confirmed yesterday.

title: REAGAN ASSURES TURK ON AID FOR MILITARY

title: 1,000 LEBANESE PRISONERS ARE MOVED TO ISRAEL
description: The Israeli Army transferred more than 1,000 prisoners to Israel today from its Ansar detention camp in southern Lebanon, and it is due to release 600 others on Wednesday, Israeli Army officers said.

description: The House of Representatives bowed to White House pressure tonight and adopted legislation that would gradually eliminate a benefit program for long-term unemployed workers.

title: IN CALIFORNIA, WINE MAKERS TAP INTO HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: At first glance, the Charles Krug Winery might pass for a small refinery. Gleaming stainless-steel towers pierce the sky. Pipes run hither and yon. Wires and a thin optical fiber relay data from the tanks to a central computer, which each morning prints out graphs showing the temperature changes in each tank.

title: MacBeth Suspended
description: Donald MacBeth , the jockey whose mount, Chief's Crown, was disqualified and placed second after finishing ahead of Proud Truth in the Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah last Saturday, was given a 10-day suspension for cutting in front of two other horses in the race. MacBeth continued to insist that the disqualification had not been warranted, but said he would not appeal the suspension because he was afraid he could lose and end up serving the suspension during major stakes races later in the season.

description: From the outside, the long, low, brown brick building looks like just another warehouse along the bank of the East River in Long Island City, Queens. But inside the scene is a tumult of artistry.

title: A MODEST EFFORT AT MAKING YOUR PARSNIPHOBES TRUE BELIEVERS
description: 'FAIRE words,'' said an anonymous writer in 1639, ''butter noe parsnips.'' He could be axiomatic about the humble parsnip because in the 17th century, and indeed back to Roman times, buttered to be sure, it was a genuine staple and not the rarity it is on tables today. But why so rare? Why do so many people even profess to hate parsnips or shrug them off, as a friend did recently by saying, ''Well, you have to draw the line somewhere.''

title: The Center Grows in Salvador
description: those are the words that once stuck adhesively to El Salvador's President, Jose Napoleon Duarte. It's time to free him from that condescension. His Christian Democrats appear to have scored a remarkable upset in Sunday's election - a 54 percent win that should assure them a majority in the National Assembly and put them in charge of 200 of 262 municipalities.

title: SOVIET SEEN EASING EXIT-PERMIT CURBS

description: New York City, with its reservoirs at 59 percent of capacity, is preparing to announce a drought warning today. Normally at this time of year the reservoirs are 96 percent full.

title: DANCE: MARTHA GRAHAM GIVES PREMIERE OF 'SONG'
description: ''I AM a rose of Sharon, a lily of the valleys.'' These familiar words come from the Bible, and more specifically from ''The Song of Songs.'' And when Thea Nerissa Barnes of the Martha Graham Dance Company steps sensuously forward while Jeremy Brett, the British actor, speaks these lines, she is unabashedly a flower abloom.

title: 'ALAMO BAY,' ETHNIC STRIFE IN TEXAS

SUTTON NEW KENTUCKY COACH
description: Eddie Sutton, saying he would not have left Arkansas for any other job, was named today to succeed Joe B. Hall as Kentucky's basketball coach.

title: Bridge: Game's Skills May Resemble Ones Necessary in Business
description: One could make a good case for the thesis that the qualities required for success in bridge closely resemble those needed for success in business. An example of a successful businessman and bridge player was Walter Jacobs of Bay Harbor Island, Fla., who died recently at the age of 88.

title: NEW FINDING BACKS IDEA THAT LIFE STARTED IN CLAY RATHER THAN SEA
description: Scientists in California yesterday reported a major discovery that supports the emerging theory that life on earth began in clay rather than the sea.

title: 4 MILITARY CHIEFS OPPOSE ANY CHANGE IN PENSIONS
description: The Chiefs of the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines today adamantly opposed any changes in the military retirement system or its benefits.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the role of Government regulators in the closing of E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. incorrectly listed a party in a suit. The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Jose Gomez, a partner of the accounting firm of Alexander Grant & Company, but not the firm itself.

title: MODEST GAINS FOUND FOR WORLD'S WOMEN
description: Despite some progress in education, economics and political participation, changes around the world in the status of women have been ''extremely uneven and, on the whole, modest'' since World War II, a survey released today said.

title: KREMLIN TO SPEED COMPUTER STUDIES
description: The Soviet leadership under Mikhail S. Gorbachev has ordered high schools to start training in computers next fall.

title: 27TH F. D. A. DELAY ON ADDITIVES BAN
description: The Food and Drug Administration has delayed until at least early June a decision on whether 10 widely used food and drug dyes pose unacceptable threats to human health. By one count, it is the 27th time action on the matter has been delayed in the last 22 years. A decision on a possible ban was supposed to have been made by Jan. 12, 1963.

title: Alfa Romeo Loss
description: The Italian auto maker Alfa Romeo said its losses more than tripled, to $49 million, last year despite an increase in sales.

title: TERRORIST THREAT TO SUBWAYS PUTS TORONTO POLICE ON ALERT
description: The police continued to keep a close watch in and around the subway system today, a day after an Armenian terrorist group had said it would detonate a bomb there.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Sports People column on Saturday misidentified a newspaper that had published an erroneous account of the purchase of basketball uniforms and, in some copies, misidentified the school involved. The newspaper was The Arizona Daily Star (not The Arizona Republic), and the school was the University of Arizona (not Arizona State).

title: SUNNY ARUBA DRAWS THE DRUG-SMUGGLING CROWD
description: Off to one side of the main runway at the modern airport on this sun-bleached resort island there are a dozen or so tattered private planes that some officials jokingly refer to as ''the Aruban Air Force.''

title: City's Schools Are Benefiting From Increased State Aid

title: HENDERSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said that the latest year revenue includes a gain of $394,500 from the sale of assets. It also said that during 1984 it concluded the sale of a portion of its proved developed gas reserves resulting in a pretax gain of $452,600.

title: Building a Cathedral
description: When ''The Stone Carvers'' won a documentary Academy Award last week, there were flutters of local pride in several Washington quarters.

title: FEW WEST VIRGINIANS GO TO BRIEFINGS ON UNION CARBIDE PLANT
description: Few local residents have attended community meetings called by the Union Carbide Corporation to discuss the planned reopening of its methyl isocyanate plant here.

description: An eighth arrest was made here today in a case involving accusations of point- shaving in two Tulane University basketball games.

description: STEPHEN TABB is a conservative when it comes to picking stocks. Lately, however, he finds it increasingly difficult to find issues that meet his stringent standards.

description: b-After gains from the termination of a pension plan of $301,000 for the quarter and $1,651,000 for the year, a loss from discontinued operations of $273,000 for the year, and an extraordinary loss of $609,000 for the quarter and year based on equity in an affiliate. c-Net income.

title: City Can Countersue in Cases Of Brutality, U. S. Court Rules
description: New York City has the right to countersue people who bring civil suits against police officers charging brutality, a Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

title: Comerica Seeking Michigan National
description: Comerica Inc., the second-largest bank holding company in Michigan, said that it had filed with the Federal Reserve Board for authority to take steps toward aquiring the troubled Michigan National Corporation.

title: DECOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Ailing Bird to Rest
description: Larry Bird , the Boston Celtic star, is suffering from a sore right elbow and has decided to sit out a game or two to give the injury a chance to heal before the playoffs. . . .

title: STOCK FUNDS ROSE 8.93% IN 1ST QUARTER
description: Thanks to the January surge in the stock market, the average equity mutual fund gained 8.93 percent in the first quarter. That was almost as much as these funds have gained for the entire year, on average, in each of the last 15 years, according to Michael Lipper , president of Lipper Analytical Services, which compiled the quarterly performance statistics.

title: COMPANY NEWS ;   AMP Announces 7-Day Layoffs
description: AMP Inc., citing a slowdown in the domestic electronics industry, said it would furlough its 17,000 United States employees for one week and trim its work force by an undetermined amount. The one-week, unpaid holiday, to occur before June 28, will be the third in nine months, and will save roughly $6.5 million in payroll costs, an AMP spokesman said.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS ASOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Envoy to Colombia Named
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Charles A. Gillespie Jr. as Ambassador to Colombia. Mr. Gillespie, 50 years old, has been Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for the Caribbean since 1983. A career Foreign Service officer, Mr. Gillespie has held posts in the Philippines, Belgium, Mexico and Nicaragua.

title: METROPOLITAN LIFE, VACATING TOWER, NOW A LANDLORD
description: For the first time since the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company office tower opened 75 years ago, space is being leased to outside tenants. By vacating the building it owns at Madison Avenue and 24th Street, the insurance company is taking full advantage of its real estate holdings in an area of Manhattan that is emerging as a strong new office center.

title: SOUTH AFRICA IS IN A MESS
description: They write to me from the United States, they come to see me, they call me long-distance. Some of them are my friends, and they are anxious about me and my family. They want to know if South Africa is blowing up. Why do the police kill so many black people? Is it civil war? Is this the end? Is this the revolution?

title: ACCOUNTING OFFICE MAY REVIEW U. S. CONTRACTS, JUDGE RULES
description: A Federal district judge has upheld a law authorizing the General Accounting Office to review disputed Government contracts despite the Reagan Administration's view that the law violates the separation of powers embodied in the Constitution.

title: W. E. STEVENSON, 84, A LAWYER, EDUCATOR AND DIPLOMAT, IS DEAD
description: William E. Stevenson, a lawyer, educator and diplomat, died last night

title: German Jobless Rate
description: West Germany's unemployment rate fell to 10 percent in March from 10.5 percent in February, the Government said today.

title: BUSINESS IDGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 3, 1985

title: AMF to Drop 150 Positions
description: AMF Inc. said it was eliminating 150 positions from its White Plains and Stamford, Conn., corporate headquarters. It also said it planned to move to a single location that has not yet been determined in the Stamford area in late 1985.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;  $625 Million Financing From a Power Agency
description: A $625 million debt financing for the Northern California Power Agency was heavily oversubscribed yesterday, according to underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, who offered a wide array of notes and bonds. Demand was strong enough that prices were raised and yields reduced slightly from the tentative levels announced yesterday morning.

title: F. N. M. A. Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association yesterday announced an interest rate of 12 percent for a $1 billion issue of debentures due April 10, 1992. Securities dealers said the debentures, which yielded about 36 hundredths of a percentage point more than seven-year Treasury notes, were in heavy demand.

title: William Tobey, Retired Chief Of Sales Promotion at A. & S.
description: William Tobey, sales promotion director of Abraham & Straus for 32 years until his retirement as a senior vice president in 1977, died in his sleep on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old.

PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax provision of $2,400,000 for estimated expenses related to store closings.

description: I've had a nasty suspicion lately

description: ''I would say we've finally been adopted by the city of Philadelphia as one of its bragging points.'' - Gene Ruane, a Villanova University spokesman. (B10:2.)

title: Sikhs Excommunicate India Cabinet Member
description: Sikh religious leaders announced today that they had excommunicated of a prominent Sikh aide of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and a rebel sect leader for defying their authority.

title: MORE REVENUE-SHARING AID PROPOSED FOR CITY IN BUDGET
description: Clearing one of the last obstacles to agreement on a belated state budget, legislative leaders today agreed to give New York City 40 percent of new revenue-sharing funds.

title: WEDTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $2,048,256 for the quarter and $713,949 for the year. c-Net income.

title: Letter
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Cable TV Reward
description: Goaded by a recent speech by Keith L. Reinhard, chairman of Needham Harper Worldwide, the board of the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau has elected to monetarily reward annually a person or group within an agency coming up with the most creative use of cable as an advertising medium. There will be separate rewards for national and local achievement. Although the size of the prize has not been set, the board promises it will be ''substantial.''

title: Correction
description: TA Passover recipe in Living last Wednesday omitted an instruction in the preparation of sweet and sour lamb with okra. In Step 2, the lamb and onions should be sauteed for 10 minutes after the turmeric and pepper have been sprinkled over the lamb.

title: MICHAEL GRADE BRINGS HOLLYWOOD STYLE TO BBC
description: When Michael Grade was appointed head of programming for the British Broadcasting Corporation's main channel last September, he was asked if he had learned anything from Hollywood that he was going to use in his new position.

title: Bowman Gray 3d Dead at 46; Former Head of Grand Union
description: Bowman Gray 3d, former chairman of the Grand Union Company, died Friday of a heart attack. He was 46 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: REAGAN PICKS NEW TRADE CHIEF
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Clayton K. Yeutter, a deputy special trade representative in the Ford Administration, as the new United States trade representative.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THERE may still be snow on the ground in some parts of the country, but now is the time for children and their parents to start thinking seriously about summer camp. Although the usual image of camp is that of a horde of healthy children enjoying a wide range of supervised activities, camp is not just for the able-bodied.

title: TRINIDAD ADJUSTS ITS VIEW ON 'OUTSIDE WORLD'
description: For nearly 25 years, the islands of Trinidad and Tobago, 10 miles off the coast of Venezula, have pursued a course of proud independence, coolly distant from their neighbors in the Caribbean, the great powers and the rest of the world.

title: GRAPHIC MEDIA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $31,365 from discontinued operations, a gain of $31,611 on disposal of school and camp segment and an extraordinary gain of $70,350 representing a reversal of deferred income taxes resulting from the availability of various tax credits and net operating loss carryforwards. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $65,918.

title: Nunn Makes Refund Offer
description: Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, a runaway winner for re-election last fall, has offered to refund more than a third of his campaign contributions, his spokesman said Monday. Ed Nagy, the spokesman, said Senator Nunn had sent a letter to the contributors ''offering a pro-rata refund'' of 37 percent of each contribution. He said that in the past the Senator refunded contributions after campaigns. Mr. Nunn raised $1.13 million for the 1984 campaign and spent $715,558.

title: MET OPERA: MIGENES-JOHNSON SINGS THE SEASON'S FIRST 'LULU'
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's production of Alban Berg's ''Lulu,'' which returned to the repertory Monday night for the first time since the premiere of the reconstructed full-length version in the 1980-81 season, is as fascinating a 20th-century music drama as the company has ever staged. It manages to be both remarkably faithful to the composer's intricate 12-tone score and a theatrical coup as well, by turns mordantly ironic, broadly comical, sickeningly realistic and penetrating in its insights into the behavior of the human animal. In the pit, James Levine and the Metropolitan orchestra give a gripping reading of one of opera's craggiest scores, which is, or should be, the first requirement of any presentable ''Lulu.''

title: FRESH BAKED HAM: PIQUANT VARIATION ON AN EASTER MOTIF
description: FOR those cooks who are just getting around to considering what to serve on Easter Sunday, thoughts most likely turn to the traditional leg of lamb, the symbol of peace in the Christian tradition, or a festive baked ham, which always seems appropriate when families get together. I usually alternate the two, and this year I eagerly look forward to preparing a ham.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Pacific Bell Issue
description: A $300 million issue of Pacific Bell Telephone Company's 12 3/4 percent debentures was offered yesterday at 99 1/4 to yield 12.85 percent to maturity in 2025 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The debentures, rated A-1 by Moody's and Ax by Standard & Poor's, were all sold in the first day, and were allowed to trade freely in the secondary market. By midafternoon, the issue was offered at 99 1/4.

title: Shot Clock for N. C. A. A.
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association will use a 45-second shot clock for all basketball games, and all fouls that are judged intentional will entitle the fouled team to two free throws and then automatic possession of the ball.

title: LIBERACE IS HERE, WITH HIS GLITTER UNDIMMED
description: Sure, Liberace could get by with using chintzy rhinestones. But he doesn't. Liberace uses the finest rhinestones available in the world today, multi-faceted, hand-cut Austrian rhinestones.. ''I only use the best of everything,'' Liberace explained. ''People know a phony.''

description: April 3, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

GOLDBERG CHOSEN FOR INQUIRY INVOLVING RHODE ISLAND JUDGE
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, a retired Justice of the United States Supreme Court and a former chief United States representative to the United Nations, was named today to investigate the ties of the chief justice of Rhode Island's Supreme Court to reputed organized crime figures.

title: Home Group's Stock Distribution
description: The City Investing Company, the manufacturing, services and financial concern that is in the midst of liquidation, said its board of directors had decided to distribute all the common stock of the Home Group Inc., the parent of the Home Insurance Company and a City Investing unit, to City's shareholders.

title: ;   Pound for Pound, You're Better Off Thin
description: To the Editor:

title: Disabled Writers
description: Disabled persons confined to hospitals will be able to study creative writing under a program designed by the National Committee-Arts with the Handicapped and the PEN American Center. Supported by the Omega Watch Corporation, members of PEN will lead workshops all over the country.

title: JEWS OF WEST GERMANY WRESTLE WITH APRILS PAST
description: A policeman discreetly keeps an eye on Frankfurt's sole kosher restaurant, which has no sign to advertise its existence. A closed-circuit television monitors the entryway.

title: SYMPTOMS OF PREGNANCY IN FATHERS-TO-BE
description: When Michael Finley was an expectant father, he gained weight, was easily irritated, took afternoon naps and had excruciating backaches. But the day his daughter was born, the backaches disappeared. He started losing weight and was soon back to his easygoing, energetic self.

description: Flags of the American Army

title: Two German Radicals Are Given Life Sentences
description: Two leaders of the radical Red Army Faction were convicted today of killing three prominent West Germans and their bodyguards and trying to kill a United States Army general. The judge sentenced them to life in prison.

title: COMPANY NEWS ;   New I.B.M. Computer Prices
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced two new versions of the PC-XT and made modest price cuts across its personal computer line.

title: Advertising ;   HUMANA'S CARE PLUS CAMPAIGN
description: HAVING learned that it can increase the sales of group health plans to about 34 a week, from about four, by the simple addition of TV advertising in a test market, Humana Inc. of Louisville, Ky., is bumping its annual ad budget to more than $5 million from a mere $1 million, and is planning an incursion into Chicago, Miami and Oakland, Calif. It will be selling its Humana Care Plus plan.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized losses of $131,000 for the quarter and $86,000 for the year. c-Includes realized gains of $76,000 for the quarter and $164,000 for the year.

title: BAN ON STRIPED BASS
description: Last year, prompted by a national alarm over the potentially adverse health effects of the fumigant EDB in the nation's grain supply, the State Health Commissioner asked Governor Cuomo to impose stringent standards for the chemical in products like cake mixes, cereal and flour. The Governor responded quickly. Shortly after the Federal Government had issued its guidelines on EDB - ethylene dibromide - Mr. Cuomo declared them inadequate and imposed much stiffer state rules.

title: Tainted Milk Sickens 543 in Illinois and Iowa
description: More than 500 people in Illinois and Iowa have been stricken by food poisoning apparently caused by a batch of contaminated milk, public health officials said today.

title: HENDERSON TO MISS YANKEES' OPENER
description: The Yankees put their opening- day lineup through a full dress rehearsal today against the Boston Red Sox, but rain kept the performance short.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON FARM PROGRAM CUTS
description: Senate Republicans said tonight that they had reached a tentative agreement with the White House to cut projected spending for agricultural programs by nearly $3 billion in 1986.

title: BIG JUMP FOR METS' MCDOWELL
description: When the manager summons a rookie into his office in the final days of spring training, it is often an invitation to the minor leagues. So, Roger McDowell was overpowered when Dave Johnson summoned him Monday and told the rookie pitcher that he would go north with the Mets next Sunday to open the season.

title: CITIZEN LOBBYISTS RECALL FIGHT FOR CHLORDANE BAN
description: Dr. Elizabeth Borque recalls the early days of the crusade when she would drive her 10- year-old Toyota hundreds of miles to Albany to confront ''three-piece suiters all by myself.'' She hoped nobody would ask where she was staying, she said, because dingy motels were all she could afford.

title: HOW VILLANOVA UPSET GEORGETOWN
description: It is necessary to clarify something right away: Villanova's 66-64 stirring upset victory over Georgetown in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship Monday night should not be likened to North Carolina State's unexpected 54-52 triumph over Houston in the 1983 title game.

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Defense States Case In Taiwan Trial
description: Lawyers defending two reputed gangsters charged with killing a Chinese- American writer in California, told the court today that they were not guilty because they had been carrying out orders, like soldiers.

title: F. A. A. TO PROPOSE TOUGHER REQUIREMENTS FOR AIRLINER SEATS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration informed Congress today that it would propose a rule in June to require stronger airline seats and was considering a rule to limit the amount of luggage that could be stuffed in overhead bins.

title: Julian Bond Held in Protest
description: State Senator Julian Bond of Georgia, his wife, Alice, and teen-age son, Michael, were among five people arrested Tuesday for demonstrating outside the South African Embassy. The Bonds, who were protesting that country's racial segregation policies, were charged with demonstrating within 500 feet of a foreign embassy, a misdemeanor. They were released after each paid a $50 cash bond, the police said.

title: OHIO MATTRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results for the latest quarter include the operations of Woodstuff Mfg. Inc. since its acquisition by Ohio Mattress on Feb. 4.

title: PANEL BARS CUTS G.O.P. WANTED IN MILITARY STAFF
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee today rejected a Republican-led proposal to cut military personnel by 175,000 soldiers and civilians, Congressional sources said.

title: U.S. HALVES QUOTA FOR SOVIET FISHING
description: The Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, announced today that the amount of fish the Soviet Union may catch in United States waters would be cut by at least half because of Soviet violation of an international whaling agreement.

title: ISRAELIS REPORTED TO DETAIN 300 MEN
description: Israeli troops were reported to have detained 300 men today in a search for guerrillas in a Moslem market town near the Ansar dentention camp in southern Lebanon.

title: EDWARDS, A G & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The year-ago fourth quarter and full year earnings include a $12 million charge to establish reserves on the sale of annuities of Baldwin- United Corp. units. The company said that due to an accounting change the latest year and fourth quarter earnings increased $1.1 million, or 8 cents a share, and revenue by $5 million.

title: Indian Writer Honored For Bhopal Warnings
description: A freelance journalist in India who warned more than two years ago of safety hazards at a Union Carbide pesticide plant in Bhopal has been given a national journalism award here for ''perseverence'' and protecting the public interest.

title: No More Chicken
description: What does acting as host of the Final Four mean for a relatively small city? Hear it from Doug Gibson, an economic-development official in Lexington, Ky.: ''We now have credibility in America. It won't be just a southern-fried-chicken town.''

title: SULCUS COMPUTER reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
DOLE SEEKS BUDGET PLAN REAGAN COULD BACK
description: The Senate Republican leadership and White House negotiators struggled toward a budget accord today, with Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, focusing on developing a package that President Reagan could support rather than trying to avoid opposition from Republican senators.

title: Money Funds Up; C.D.'s Firm
description: For the fourth consecutive week money market fund compound yields continued their climb, while yields on bank money market and certificates of deposit saw little movement.

title: Bridge:A Considerate Player Eases The Pressure On His Partner
description: All players, or almost all players, would agree that an essential element in a successful partnership is thoughtful consideration for the player sitting opposite.

title: LATE MARCH CAR SALES ROSE 6.9%
description: Sales of new domestically made cars rose moderately throughout March, gaining 6.9 percent in the last 10 days of the month from the 1984 period, the major manufacturers said today.

title: 30'S CHAIRS FIT 80'S MOOD
description: SHE was a fashion designer and now is part owner of Provechos, a Caribbean restaurant at 21 West 17th Street. And that was how Deborah Donchian, right, started looking for chairs.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;  $87 Million Settlement Approved in MGM Suit
description: A Federal judge today approved an $87.5 million settlement of a suit against a consortium of insurance companies by MGM Grand Hotels Inc.

title: Topics ;   Exceptions to the Rule ;   Special Case
description: President Reagan inveighs against special interests at the drop of a hat - except when the issue is Presidential libraries. Then Mr. Reagan turns out to be a special interest himself.

title: Wang Executives In Big Stock Sales
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is ''very much aware'' that executives of Wang Laboratories Inc. sold $2.8 million worth of stock two months before Wang announced an earnings decline, an S.E.C. official said. ''It's not going unnoticed,'' said Willis Riccio, the S.E.C.'s regional administrator.

EXPERIMENTAL HEART DRUG FOUND HIGHLY EFFECTIVE
description: A new genetically engineered drug is nearly twice as effective as medication now used in halting heart attacks, a major Government-sponsored study shows.

title: Teacher Protest Shuts 10 Schools
description: Ten of Connecticut's 17 vocational-technical high schools closed today as hundreds of teachers walked out and marched on the State Capitol to protest inaction on their demand for a pay increase.

description: A higher entrance fee and the rising costs of staying competitive have reduced the number of entries received for the Indianapolis 500, according to the organizers.

title: Required Reading ;   Press Prospects
description: What is the most improved institution in America today? Is it the American corporation, the Congress, the Presidency, the American newspaper, our magazines, radio, television, the medical profession, the legal profession, the university in America, the American military forces, the economics profession, American science, our professional sports, American churches and synagogues, our vigorous trade assocations, our public schools, the entertainment industry? Some institution I have overlooked?

title: Paul Wohl, Journalist, Dead; Wrote About Political Affairs
description: Paul Wohl, a journalist and commentator on political affairs and international transportation, died Tuesday at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx. He was 84 years old and for the last three years had lived at the Pelham Parkway Nursing Home in the Bronx.

title: Latest Champ
description: Of all the athletes from New York, who's the most recent individual champion in major amateur competition? Mark Breland? Nope. And no again if, still thinking about Los Angeles after all this time, you named Rick Carey or some other summertime hero.

title: Convicted Official Resigns
description: Pennsylvania's Agriculture Secretary, Penrose Hallowell, resigned today, saying he could not stay in office after being convicted twice for shoplifting a $4.99 cassette tape. The 56-year-old millionaire farmer, in a letter to Gov. Dick Thornburgh, maintained his innocence and said he would appeal the nonjury verdict.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING NEAR MISS OF JETS
description: An urgent inquiry is under way into a near collision in which a Northwest Orient Airlines jumbo jet, on takeoff, passed 50 to 100 feet above another Northwest jumbo jet crossing the runway at the Minneapolis-St. Paul airport Sunday evening.

title: 'WHEEL' FROM KOREA
description: THE full title of ''The Wheel,'' the South Korean film playing tonight and Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art, translates ''A History of Brutality to Women: O Spinning Wheel, O Spinning Wheel.'' And the title tells you a lot. Not that the film is an actual history, but the story it recounts of one unfortunate woman is brutal in the extreme.
