description: Eddie Sutton acknowledges that he'll be under enormous pressure in his new job as Kentucky's basketball coach: ''I guess I'll get to feeling like a state park - everybody owns a piece of me.''

THE STAGE: DAVID CALE
description: ''REALITY is something you rise above,'' says David Cale, and, taking his own advice, he explores the ethereal reaches of a surrealistic comic imagination. As a monologuist and performance artist, he works on an almost bare stage at P.S. 122, and with a feral intensity views life through a distorting mirror.

title: 'FELA'A DOCUMENTARY ON THE NIGERIAN ON PBS
description: ''FELA'' bursts with energy. Streets swarm with people; the music is Afro-beat. And who is Fela? Possibly ''the greatest musician in Africa,'' the documentary answers, possibly ''prophet,'' possibly ''rebel'' - possibly all three. ''Fela,'' the documentary, looks at Fela, the man, with unconcealed admiration. He stands ready to save Nigeria, and perhaps all Africa, too. The documentary will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: HERS
description: WHEN I went to register my son Bruno for first grade at the local public school, I was told that unless he had documented proof of having attended kindergarten in Arizona - where we had spent the last two years - he would have to repeat it. Knowing that obtaining such proof would involve negotiations on the scale of Yalta with Bruno's disorganized and unashamedly meretricious preschool, I asked to see the principal, who explained the value of this regulation: If they let one child skip kindergarten, they would have to let them all. ''But Bruno's 6 years old,'' I said. ''He can read and write and use my computer.'' In reply, the principal fixed me with the blankest stare I've ever seen and said: ''Of course.

title: Conservative Majority Is Cut In Newfoundland Legislature

title: Vote Delayed on U.S. Aide
description: The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee today delayed a vote on the reappointment of Donald J. Devine as chief of the Federal civil service system, said an aide to Senator William V. Roth, Republican of Delaware and chairman of the committee. The aide attributed the delay to scheduling difficulties, but an article in Thursday's issue of The Washington Post asserted that the vote had been delayed because Mr. Roth had decided that the committee would have voted not to reappoint Mr. Devine, who has been criticized for extensive Republican political activities.

title: WHEN SUBJECT IS TAXES, ALL CONSTITUENTS LISTEN
description: Just about everybody knows someone, a sales person or a deliverer or an electrician or a business executive, who has a company auto or van or pickup. Mostly, they drive the car for business. But they also use it to commute to work, to go to the store and to drop the children off at school. At the very least, it often means the family does not need a second car.

title: EMBARRASSMENT AT TULANE
description: On the surface, the university that is sometimes called the Harvard of the South dozes in the noonday sun. Tulane's grassy quadrangle is dotted with students in shorts lying beside open books. Huge old oaks reach toward red brick neoclassic buildings and more modern structures such as the library and the University Center. Magnolias and camellias are showing bright green. Spring vacation is about to begin, signaling an exodus to the beaches of Florida.

title: AVOIDING SAFETY HAZARDS
description: REMOVING paint or varnish can be hazardous because of the solvents and chemicals used or because of the dangers of some stripping tools and techniques. title: THE PEOPLE'S NEST EGGS
description: WASHINGTON We used to think of April 15 with dread, as the deadline day for filing our Federal income tax. That deadline still exists, but now - thanks to a deafening drumfire of bank advertising - we think of April 15 with a mixture of panic and benign greed, as the last day we can get a tax break by putting aside some money in an Individual Retirement Account.

title: Police Seize a Suspect In 22 Bank Robberies
description: A man who the police say held up 22 banks since Jan. 7 was arrested yesterday by a stakeout team at a Citibank branch at Park Avenue and 57th Street as he tried to make it 23, authorities said.

title: TOP SOVIET GEOGRAPHER

title: Bids on Channel Linkup
description: The British and French Governments have asked private industry to bid on proposals to link the two countries across the English Channel by bridge or tunnel. The Governments on Tuesday set a deadline of Oct. 31 so that a winner could be chosen by the end of the year. The guidelines for bidding, published Tuesday, envision completion of the linkup by the mid-1990's.

title: 21% CUTBACK IN SOCIAL SECURITY STAFF PLANNED

title: WOMAN, 22, DIES AS MAN SHOVES HER UNDER SUBWAY
description: A 22-year-old woman on her way to work was crushed to death yesterday morning when an apparent stranger shoved her off the BMT subway platform at Union Square into the path of an incoming train, the police said.

title: TYPE OF ARTHRITIS IS SEEN AS CURABLE
description: Injections of penicillin appear to cure a form of arthritis caused by Lyme disease, a recently recognized and spreading illness that is carried by deer ticks, researchers say.

title: ORIGIN OF THE SPECIOUS, OR HOW A PUN IS BORN
description: ''THE man who could make so vile a pun,'' an 18th-century critic once grumbled, ''would not scruple to pick a pocket'' - and you know he would have been unlikely to talk in the same way about a vile epigram, or a vile paradox, or a vile bon mot. Punning has traditionally got a bad press; the punster is assumed to be no better than a funster, and often a positive monster. But then as Walter Redfern reminds us, puns do after all ''make people groan, squirm, flinch, grimace or wince, as we do of course when we witness a physical collision.''

title: Schoolboy Picks Duke
description: Danny Ferry , one of the nation's most acclaimed high school basketball players, said he had decided to attend Duke next fall after considering North Carolina and Maryland.

title: SOVIET U.S. ARMS TALKS HELD

title: Japan-Bashers, on the March
description: Friction between America and Japan over trade is nothing new. One Administration after another has found grounds for protest in unfair competition in automobiles or rigging of the value of the yen or quotas on American oranges. And year after year, diplomats have defused tensions and maintained the special relationship between the two countries. This year's friction is different; this year, the Japan-bashers are on the march.

title: A TOUGH TRADE NEGOTIATOR

title: Skating Her Way To West Allis
description: The North American speed-skating championships were held in Winnipeg, Manitoba, a few weeks back, and by the time everybody finished going round and round, it turned out that the winner of three of the four women's races was a resident of the Wakefield section in the East Bronx. This may not be quite the same as growing up in the Sahara and then becoming a star in the N.H.L., but the fact is that Leslie Bader's performance in Winnipeg certified her as the first prominent female speed skater from New York since two sisters from Flushing, Carole and Leslie Moore, won medals in national competition a decade ago.

title: LAPSES OFF THE FIELD IRK METS' JOHNSON

title: CARNEGIE HALL OPENS STUDIO FOR REHEARSAL AND RECORDING
description: Isaac Stern, in his capacity as a world-famous violinist and recording artist, tried out a new studio at Carnegie Hall last month. He taped a Bach solo partita and liked the result just fine. Yesterday, in his capacity as president of Carnegie Hall, he opened the studio to the musical community, dedicating it as the Alice and Jacob M. Kaplan Space.

title: CONCERT: BACH'S 'ST. JOHN PASSION'
description: BACH'S ''St. John Passion'' suffers so seriously in comparison with his greater choral works, particularly the ''St. Matthew Passion'' and the B minor Mass, that we tend to resist its occasional emotive power and very real beauties. When at the end the choir sings its solemnly consoling ''Ruht wohl,'' the listener cannot help growing slightly impatient because it suggests so strongly the final pages of ''St. Matthew'' without evoking anything like the same sublimely elegiac mood. It is a case of genius being trumped by his own ace.

title: BURNETT AND MADIGAN STAR IN 'LAUNDROMAT'
description: ''THE Laundromat'' is little more than a well-acted curiosity but there is something reassuring about seeing it on Home Box Office. Being presented on the pay-cable channel tonight at 10, the short play is at least original with a certain integrity. It does not smack of ''produced by committee'' calculations, of let's-talk- dirty-and-get undressed silliness. ''The Laundromat'' is slight, and even flawed, but worth doing.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times on March 19 about the incidence of multiple sclerosis in Henribourg, Saskatchewan, misstated the nature and prevalence of the disease. Multiple sclerosis is a disorder of the brain and spinal cord and is often disabling, although its symptoms and their severity vary widely. In the United States it is found in 58 out of every 100,000 people; in Canada the rate is thought to be greater than 100 per 100,000.

title: Topics ;   Exceptions to the Rule ;   Winterspring Economists use a base year to measure changes. The base year for prices, for example, is 1967, a golden time when a single dollar was worth three of today's dollars. Now for gardeners in New York, there's a base year for winters: 1985, a golden time for weather. It was unexpected. On Feb. 1 New York's weather page read: ''Below normal this year: 84'' degrees. On Feb. 10 the cumulative reading was 135 degrees below normal. Then things turned. On Feb. 25 the word ''below'' disappeared: ''Above normal this year: 2.'' By this week, it was 138 above normal.

Tomorrow, the Nashville rock band Jason and the Scorchers will perform after 1 A.M.; tickets are $10. Information: (212) 477-3728.

title: O'NEILL CALLS PLAN RUSE: REPUBLICANS OPTIMISTIC
description: Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, today called President Reagan's new proposal to aid the Nicaraguan rebels a ''dirty trick'' that would be rejected by Congress, but some Republicans expressed cautious optimism that the proposal would sway enough swing votes on Capitol Hill to win the day for the Reagan Administration.

title: THE TRIAL OF JESUS
description: History's memorable trials - those of Socrates, Galileo, Dreyfus - often tell more about the persistence of malice than about the defendants. The trial of Jesus is no exception.

Celeste of Ohio. Chemical Bank has two senior officials in Ohio negotiating the purchase of Home State, which closed on March 9.

title: THE TALE OF A WEST SIDE CONDOMINIUM

Last week, however, just as the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission was conferring historic district status on the building - and the area around it on West End Avenue - renovation work was being completed instead on 24 high-priced condominiums.

title: NICARAGUA POLICE CRITICIZED ON RIGHTS
description: The Nicaraguan security police use death threats and other forms of psychological coercion to obtain confessions from people accused of anti-Sandinista actions, a human rights group said in a report issued yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Comings and Goings
description: Chris Mullin , or a reasonable facsimile thereof, has been reported missing, but nobody is taking the report seriously. The missing Mullin is not the St. John's basketball player but a mannequin uniformed and wigged to resemble him that had been on display at the Lexington, Ky., hotel where the St. John's team stayed during the N.C.A.A. playoffs. . . .

title: SYNAGOGUE CRACKS SAFE TO FIND RICHES
description: Yielding slowly to hammer and drill, a six-foot-high safe was opened yesterday for the first time in decades to reveal a silver collection whose value at auction would be impressive but whose value in Lower East Side history is beyond estimate.

title: 2 WORKERS DIE IN AN EXPLOSION UNDER BELLEVUE
description: Two workers at Bellevue Hospital were killed last night when an acetylene tank exploded and set off a fire in an tunnel beneath a hospital administration building, authorities said.

title: IN A TRADE WAR, U.S. IS WELL-ARMED
description: In any trade conflict with Japan, the United States has many weapons to curb Japanese business in this country. These range from tariff increases and import quotas to onerous customs inspections and delays in granting such things as airline landing rights.

title: Bancroft Winners
description: Suzanne Lebsock, author of ''The Free Women of Petersburg: Status and Culture in a Southern Town, 1784- 1860'' (published by W. W. Norton), and Kenneth Silverman, author of ''The Life and Times of Cotton Mather'' (Harper & Row), have been named winners of the 1985 Bancroft Prizes in American History at Columbia University. Dr. Lebsock is associate professor of History at Rutgers and Dr. Silverman is professor of English at New York University. The Bancroft Prizes honor ''books of exceptional merit and distinction in American American history.'' Each winner received $4,000.

title: BATTERY PARK CITY OFFERS HOLOCAUST MUSEUM A SITE

As chairman and president of the Golden Nugget Inc., which had revenues of $385 million last year, he seems to have fulfilled that goal.

Less than three weeks after a bout billed as ''The Grand Finale,'' the undefeated heavyweight champion is trying to put together a defense of his International Boxing Federation title against the undefeated light-heavyweight champion, Michael Spinks.

ART: CHINESE PAINTINGS AND CALLIGRAPHY AT MET
description: THE second installment of the ''John M. Crawford Jr. Collection: Chinese Painting and Calligraphy,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through May 15, is the latest evidence that the art of China has as much to tell us as the art of any other nation. In an American culture with an increasing imbalance between image and word, the bond between the two in Chinese art has a special urgency. Since Chinese painting evolved from calligraphy, a first-rate exhibition of calligraphy and painting can also bring us closer to the language of painting and to what makes paintings work.

title: COMPROMISE WOULD LIMIT INCREASE IN SOCIAL SECURITY

title: ART: THE AMERICAN PRE-RAPHAELITES
description: ''PAINT the leaves as they grow! If you can paint one leaf, you can paint the world,'' wrote the English critic John Ruskin in his epic ''Modern Painters.'' And in the mid-19th century, a small group of American artists took the advice to heart, rendering Nature close up with such fidelity as to make today's Photo-Realism look - well, out of focus. They came to be known as the American Pre-Raphaelites, and their work - celebrating Ruskin's bless-every- blade-of-grass esthetic - left something of a mark on American landscape and still-life painting. Now ''The New Path: Ruskin and the American Pre-Raphaelites,'' the first show to study this short-lived movement in depth, has been mounted by the Brooklyn Museum, where it will run through June 10 before moving to Boston.

The first week of each month the Government makes a fleeting pass with the dole in the capital's social underbrush and sends out Social Security and welfare payments from the bulky Federal bastions across town.

title: A touch of Paris on West 12th St.
description: ANYONE who has spent time strolling through the sidestreets of Paris, ducking into restaurants or bistros that appear inviting - perhaps the name is intriguing, or the ornate 18th-century facade is irresistible - will feel a twinge of nostalgia upon encountering Au Troquet, an enchanting little restaurant in the West Village. Everything about this 18- month-old establishment evokes France - the lettered awning shielding white-framed windows with gauzy curtains, the small bar where handsome young waiters flirt with a pair of neighborhood girls who have stopped in for a drink, the simple and lovingly arranged dining room highlighted with paintings by the owner, and the sincere feeling of hospitality, not a well-rehearsed ''Good evening, I'm Reginald your waiter and we will be dining together tonight'' type of welcome, but the kind conveyed by a warm smile and a bottle of cool white wine.

Both of them tell me they'll be ready to pitch when the season opens Monday. I told them I wasn't about to use somebody up there who hasn't been working down here. When you throw the ball that hard, your arm's supposed to hurt some, isn't it?''

title: Economic Scene ;   German-U.S. Split on Soviet
description: ECONOMICS lies at the heart of the conflict between the United States and West Germany over strategy for dealing with the Soviet Union. The Reagan Administration means to put heavy pressure on the Soviet Union by a rapid increase in military spending, new technology and economic development that will either put unbearable strains on the Soviet economy or force the Russians to disarm and reduce their threats to the West and in other parts of the world. The Americans favor restricting Western trade with the Russians and denying them advanced technology.

title: FRANK BARNETT, 72, EX-HEAD OF UNION PACIFIC CORP., DIES
description: Frank E. Barnett, retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Union Pacific Corporation and a key figure in the reorganization of Northeastern railroads into Conrail, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan and Ridgefield, Conn.

title: A CHANCE FOR YOUNG PLAYWRIGHTS TO BLOOM IN THE SPRING
description: ONCE a year, and appropriately at the onset of spring, the New York theater sets aside the fretting and the carping, the worrying and the whining, to celebrate youth. The occasion is the Young Playwrights Festival, which opens this weekend at Playwrights Horizons.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 5, 1985 International

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and a chart in Business Day on Monday about the stock market's best and worst performers in the first quarter misstated the reason for the 65 percent rise for Williams Electronics Inc. The company's intention to continue seeking acquisitions apparently contributed to the gain. Also, the chart misstated the reason for the decline by the Chicago and North Western Transportation Company. The company lost a bid to acquire the Milwaukee Road.

title: SCHOOL TO GIVE UP BASKETBALL
description: Three basketball players and five others were indicted today in the Tulane University point-shaving case, and the university's president announced plans to drop Tulane's men's intercollegiate basketball program.

title: ESSENCE MARKS 15 YEARS OF SERVING BLACK WOMEN
description: Susan Taylor walked into a candy store in the Bronx one day to buy a magazine. Faces of white fashion models and white movie stars smiled from the magazine covers on the rack. Reaching for a familiar magazine, she noticed a new one - Essence. The date of that first issue was May 1970, and the face on the cover was young and black, like hers.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Liberians Said to Jail American as Conspirator
description: An American was reported today to have been sentenced to 10 years in jail in Liberia after he had been convicted of plotting to overthrow Gen. Samuel K. Doe, the Liberian leader, last November.

title: Big Board President Is Named
description: Robert J. Birnbaum, president and chief operating officer of the American Stock Exchange, was named president and chief operating officer of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: PRESSES REBEL AID
description: President Reagan today coupled a call for talks between the Nicaraguan Government and United States-backed rebels with a request to Congress to approve $14 million in aid for the insurgents.

title: Pohang, U.S. Steel
description: The Pohang Iron and Steel Company is not negotiating a partnership arrangement with the United States Steel Corporation, a Pohang spokesman said. The spokesman, commenting on reports in the United States that the two companies are planning to establish a link, said no negotiations were under way and Pohang had no plans to acquire equity in United States Steel.

title: A CHRONICLE OF SPORTSWEAR
description: Fashion can often appear to be an idle pastime, a form of ego massage or self-indulgence. But in a serious exhibition that ties the various changing forms of dress to social and cultural conditions, fashion's progress seems to be preordained.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   New Top Candidate
description: Bob Donewald of Illinois State has moved into first place in the speculation on a replacement for

title: ISRAELIS REPORT KILLING 8 IN A RAID ON SHIITE TOWN IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israeli soldiers searching for guerrillas swept through this Shiite Moslem village in southern Lebanon today and reported that they had killed eight people they described as armed terrorists in the raid.

title: Shawmut Bank Investigated
description: The Shawmut Bank of Boston, which said it had disclosed all its failures to obey Federal cash-reporting rules, was told today that Federal auditors were looking at violations unreported by the bank.

title: SALEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Big MGM/UA Deficit
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company said today that it lost $82.2 million in its second fiscal quarter, one of its biggest quarterly losses ever and the first since 1982.

title: CIRCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Get Out the Vote, Now
description: When does a voter-registration effort become a partisan scheme? The question is raised anew by the Reagan Administration's continuing harassment of get-out-the-vote efforts by several states.

title: EGG GAMES AROUND TOWN TO CELEBRATE EASTER
description: Besides joining the Easter Parade, the midtown meander that isn't a parade at all and that gathers force about 11 A.M. on Fifth Avenue, there is much to do this weekend for adults and children - especially with eggs. You can roll them in Central Park, throw them in Staten Island and see them dipped on Second Avenue.

title: WOMEN'S ANSWER TO BROOKS BROTHERS
description: On a Madison Avenue corner long the preserve of men in pin stripes, women are passing their lunch hours pawing through racks of pastel clothing, sniffing color-coordinated azaleas and signing a leather guest book atop a polished Regency table.

title: G.E. Pleads Not Guilty
description: The General Electric Company, the nation's fourth- largest military contractor, pleaded not guilty in Federal court today to allegations that it overcharged the Government by $800,000 on contracts on Minuteman nuclear warheads.

title: Air Force Accused of Waste
description: The Air Force, while jointly producing radar-jamming equipment with the Navy, is wasting $3 billion by also developing its own system for some combat aircraft, a Congressional investigator said today.

title: JAPAN PONDERS MARKET-ACCESS PLAN
description: Japanese Cabinet ministers and political leaders today began to consider a series of measures intended to open Japan's market wider to imports.

title: PHILHARMONIC: MAHLER
description: THE first time we hear a great musical work played well is an unforgettable event. It need not be the performance to end all performances, because we are in no position to judge that. But the mark remains indelibly on our souls or hearts or brains or kneecaps, or wherever the seat of esthetic experience is thought to reside in this scientific age. For many New Yorkers, the indelible performance of a Mahler symphony must have come from Leonard Bernstein, when the Philharmonic's music director was in the midst of his Mahler revival a generation ago. For older ones, perhaps it was Bruno Walter, or - in extremely rare instances nowadays - Mahler himself, when he was a New Yorker all too briefly in the first decade of the century.

title: TWO FACTOR'S LED TO REAGAN'S PLAN
description: White House officials said today that when President Reagan met with Republican Congressional leaders on Wednesday, two factors emerged that led to his announcement that the Administration would go ahead with its request for $14 million in financing for the rebels in Nicaragua.

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SENATE COMMITTEE CUTS REAGAN MILITARY BUDGET
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee today approved a military budget $10 billion lower than President Reagan's request, and the panel's chairman, Barry Goldwater, warned the President he would be lucky if Congress did not cut more.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PRICK OF NOON. By Peter De

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Indiana Defection
description: Marty Simmons , a former Illinois high school basketball star who failed to live up to his promise during two seasons at Indiana University, said he would transfer to another school because he couldn't expect much playing time at Indiana. ''It was just one of those things where I wasn't going to play,'' said Simmons, a 6-foot-5-inch forward who started just 9 games, only 4 in Big Ten play, and averaged 3.6 points in 23 games during Indiana's 19-14 season.

title: NEVADA RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Renegades Top Showboats, 28-17
description: The Orlando Renegades got a touchdown on the opening kickoff and another on Reggie Collier's 63-yard run with 33 seconds left tonight to defeat the Memphis Showboats, 28-17, in a United States Football League game.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Cardinal Is Penalized
description: Lonnie Smith, the St. Louis Cardinal outfielder who was involved in an altercation with an umpire in an exhibition game March 20, was fined an undisclosed amount and suspended for three exhibition games by the baseball commissioner,

title: A.T.&T. MEMO WARNS OF DELAYS IN INSTALLATION
description: A senior executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has warned that long delays might reappear in the installation of private wires - telephone lines used by thousands of companies to connect their far-flung offices. He also hinted that price increases beyond the substantial ones already planned might be inevitable.

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Gannett Curbs
description: The Gannett Company is asking shareholders to approve two proposals it says would reduce the likelihood of a hostile takeover.

title: I.B.M. Circuits
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said its scientists had made the world's densest integrated circuits using a new fabrication process. It did not predict when it might be able to develop a commercial product using the new technology. The process, I.B.M. said, shrinks circuits into an area 16 times smaller than that permitted by current semiconductor technology.

title: ACTING LIKE DEMOCRATS
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick has followed

title: BRIEFS
Massacre in Philippines
description: A provincial councillor and 18 militiamen were slain in the southern Philippines by gunmen believed to be members of the New People's Army, a Communist group, the Philippine press agency said tonight. It said about 100 guerrillas raided a village Wednesday in Zamboanga Province, rounded up the councillor and the militiamen and shot them.

title: 10-Day Vacation for Reagan
description: President Reagan will leave Friday morning for a 10-day vacation at his ranch near Santa Barbara, Calif. The vacation is a prelude to a journey to Europe two weeks later. He will leave for Europe April 30, traveling to an economic summit meeting in Bonn, and making stops in Spain, France and Portugal before returning to Washington on May 10.

title: PRESIDENT ACCEPTS G.O.P. PLAN TO CUT BUDGET $52 BILLION
description: Senate Republican leaders and the Reagan Administration agreed today on a budget package that would reduce projected spending by $52 billion in the next fiscal year and by almost $300 billion over three years.

title: LEAD GIVEN IN SUBWAY SLAYING
description: A Criminal Court judge told the police yesterday that a man who had been arraigned before him on Tuesday in Manhattan on a burglary charge resembled the sketch of the man who pushed a 22-year-old woman to her death under a subway train at the Union Square station Wednesday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Grand, Grand, Larceny, Larceny, Auto, Auto
description: Some gifts keep on giving, but Dr. Joshua Berger has found recently that gifts can keep on taking and taking.

title: Accounting Firm Calls E.S.M. Case 'a Betrayal'
description: The actions of Jose Gomez, the accountant for Alexander Grant & Company who reportedly helped to produce fraudulent financial statements for E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., were ''clearly a betrayal'' of the firm, Peter Skomorowsky, regional managing partner in New York for Grant, said in a telephone interview yesterday.

title: Goetz Trial Might Not Supply the Answers
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Honoring Judge Alexander
description: The Jewish Lawyers Guild has presented the Golda Meir Memorial Award to Associate Judge Fritz W. Alexander 2d of the New York State Court of Appeals, the first black named to a full term on the state's highest court.

title: Soviet China Pact Provides For Educational Exchanges
description: China and the Soviet Union agreed today on a program of educational and research exchanges for 1985-86, the New China News Agency said.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO) reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
description: b-Net income which is after a loss of $269,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $16,000. The latest quarter had 13 weeks compared with 14 weeks in year- earlier period. Year-ago sales have been restated.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 17
Humanities Chairman Named
description: President Reagan today nominated Edwin A. Curran to be chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, succeeding William J. Bennett, who recently became Secretary of Education.

title: N.F.L. Firm Disqualified By United Press International A Federal judge yesterday disqualified the lawyers retained by the
description: National Football League to defend the league in a $1.3 billion antitrust

title: MUSIC: BACH'S 'ST. JOHN PASSION' AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: BACH'S ''St. John Passion'' suffers so seriously in comparison with his greater choral works, particularly the ''St. Matthew Passion'' and the B minor Mass, that we tend to resist its occasional emotive power and very real beauties. When at the end the choir sings its solemnly consoling ''Ruht wohl,'' the listener cannot help growing slightly impatient because it suggests so strongly the final pages of ''St. Matthew'' without evoking anything like the same sublimely elegiac mood. It is a case of genius being trumped by his own ace.

title: PIPLINE SETTLES SUITS BY CUTTING GAS PRICES 11%
description: A major pipeline company that supplies natural gas to the Northeast agreed today to cut prices by as much as $1 billion to settle a host of private lawsuits charging that it had paid producers imprudently high prices for gas since 1981.

title: MUSIC: VIOLIN RECITAL BY HUDSON
description: BENJAMIN HUDSON'S violin recital Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y offered what amounted to a small overview of the modernist tradition, violinistic subsection.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   White Supremist Seized By F.B.I. in Arkansas
description: A man the Federal Bureau of Investigation says is a member of a white supremist group known as the Order has been arrested here, the bureau said today.

title: HEART RECIPIENT'S MOVE FUELS DEBATE ON PRESS
description: Early this week his doctors decided that William J. Schroeder, who has now lived 131 days on an artificial heart, was well enough to be moved from his hospital room to a ''transition apartment'' across the street tomorrow. The move will be a news event as well as a medical landmark.

title: ROONEY PACE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
description: b-After losses of $2,943,203 for the quarter and $5,674,196 for the 9 months from equity in the loss of an affiliated company. c-Net income The latest quarter and 9 months' results include a $1 million reserve as a hedge against certain expenses associated with the scaling down of operations. The company's results reflect an equity loss in the Norlin Corp.

title: STAGE: IN 'VIENNA NOTES,' IMAGE AND REALITY CLASH
description: ''THE VIENNA NOTES,'' the 1979 Richard Nelson comedy in revival at the Second Stage, is so admirable in principle that one feels like an ingrate to complain that it proves dull in the theater. In contrast to the other Nelson effort seen this season, the domesticated Broadway adaptation of Dario Fo's ''Accidental Death of an Anarchist,'' this work offers hard- headed social criticism, as well as a free-wheeling approach to theatrical form and language. Yet ''The Vienna Notes'' stubbornly remains one of those plays that is more rewarding to think about than to sit through.

title: Friday BACH INSTRUMENTS
description: J. S. Bach's ''St. John Passion'' was written to be performed as part of the Lutheran liturgy on Good Friday, and so it seems only appropriate that the oratorio will be presented tonight by the Florilegium Chamber Choir and Baroque Orchestra in a concert sponsored, in part, by the Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church. The performance, which is at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall, will use a new English translation by JoAnn Rice, the musical director of Florilegium. While the translation is modern, in keeping with Bach's intention that his choral works be performed in the vernacular to enable audiences to understand the text, the musical instruments are not; all strings and woodwinds to be used in the concert are Baroque instruments, including the viola d'amore, oboe d'amore, oboe da caccia, violone, flauto traverso, viola da gamba, harpsichord, lutes and baroque violins. Tickets are $10 and $12.50 at the box office (362-1911) or through CenterCharge (874-6770). LATE-NIGHT DANCE

title: Nynex Business Going To Hill, Holliday
description: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos of Boston has become agency for Nynex Business Information Systems.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds were down $1.84 billion, to $208.60 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE boom in wines by the glass offered by restaurants and bars around town has given diners the opportunity to sample some unusual selections from around the world. As patrons become more experimental about wine, restaurateurs are responding by offering some exotic labels that a few years ago were unheard of.

title: TEHERAN PUTS THE DEATH TOLL AT 36
description: Iraq said today that it had fired long- range missiles into two Iranian cities, and Iran said dozens of people were killed.

title: INQUIRY ON DRUGS ENDED IN CAPITAL
description: A Federal grand jury that had been examining charges of drug use by former associates of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and city employees ended its term today ''without further indictments,'' the United States Attorney's office announced.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
TEXAS LOOKS AHEAD
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: From 'The Double Man'
description: ''During the meeting at the pavilion, now nearly a month past, Chandler had satisfied himself that Memory had invaluable information to share. Memory had confirmed, in his strange Socratic way, that the terrorists' acts were somehow related, that they were connected to the upsurge in drug traffic, that Fabricante had been killed because he knew too much, and finally and perhaps most importantly, that ZRRIFLE, the C.I.A. assassination capability, was an important piece in the puzzle.''

title: Nicaragua Rejects Plan As Publicity Maneuver
description: Nicaragua's leftist Government today rejected President Reagan's call for a cease-fire and peace negotiations with anti-Sandinista rebels, calling it ''a public-relations maneuver.''

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Presidential Salute
description: The champion Villanova basketball team stopped by the White House to recruit a new player yesterday, but not before the prospect had proved himself a master of the slam quip. ''You're being called the Cinderella team,''

title: Reaching Higher
description: Art Schlichter, still undergoing therapy for the gambling habit that almost ended his career, hopes to be the Indianaplis Colts' No. 1 quarterback next fall: ''My future is as bright as it's ever been.

title: ALBANY ENACTS TAX AMNESTY AS IT TIGHTENS EVASION LAWS
description: New York State would for the first time offer delinquent taxpayers - individuals and small companies - a limited, three-month amnesty period in which to pay their taxes, under the terms of a measure given final approval by lawmakers today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Rangers Drop Rivers
description: Mickey Rivers , who carries a .295 career average into this season, was placed on waiver by the Texas Rangers. Rivers, a 36-year-old outfielder who hit .300 in a part-time role for the Rangers in 1984, has a guaranteed contract that will pay him $450,000 for 1985.

title: French Film Classics
description: Free screenings of French film classics will be given over the next four Saturdays at the Queens Museum, New York City Building, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: Revolution Is What Is Happening in South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, APRIL 5, 1985
description: The Economy

title: UNIVERSAL HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BRIEFING ;   Dr. Seuss Persists
description: Over the years, politicians to the left of center have often characterized their conservative opponents as mean, stingy and joyless, but few were prepared for the introduction given Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, an outspoken conservative, at a recent conference in Dallas. Trammell Crow, the Texas real estate magnate, outlined the Republican's increasingly active role in national and party affairs and concluded: ''Ladies and Gentlemen, I give you Congressman Grinch!''

title: Equimark Plan
description: The Equimark Corporation said it expects to sign agreements next week to sell 23 of its bank branches for $32 million, moving it closer to fulfilling a regulatory requirement that it raise $100 million in new capital by mid- summer. The 23 branches, which have about $480 million in deposits, are to be sold to seven small Pennsylvania banks. The Pittsburgh-based bank holding company has 55 other branches with more than $2 billion in deposits.

SELF-TAUGHT SCIENTIST HAS GOOD TIES TO JAPAN
description: American executives eager to develop business ties with Japan might profit from studying how Stanford R. Ovshinsky, the 62-year old president and chief executive officer of Energy Conversion Devices Inc., has nurtured his commercial relationships in that country.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE FORMIDABLE TED TURNER
description: Ted Turner has often talked about his ambition to own a television network. And for a month now, the broadcast entrepreneur from Atlanta has been rumored to be interested in taking over CBS Inc. But so far he has made no move, and many analysts think he has no chance.

title: Turkish Jet Hits Coffeehouse, Starting a Fire and Killing 14
description: A Turkish Air Force jet fighter crashed into a coffeehouse in the western city of Balikesir today and exploded, starting a fire that raced though a score of shops. Officials said 14 people had been killed and 21 injured.

title: KELLY, FINALLY, STARTS RISE FROM THE SHADOWS
description: Jim Kelly's problem seems to be timing.

description: To the Editor:

title: SHULTZ MAY GO TO MIDEAST AS U.S. PLANS A MORE ACTIVE ROLE
description: The United States has decided to play a more direct diplomatic role to keep alive the latest Middle East peace initiatives of Jordan and Egypt, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think it's critical that we do reaffirm the university's primary mission as an academic institution in terms of teaching, in terms of learning and in terms of research and to indicate our unwillingness to permit this kind of activity in our intercollegiate programs.'' - Dr. Eamon M. Kelly, president of Tulane University. (A1:6.)

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Marc Chagall last Friday misidentified his first wife. She was Bella Rosenfeld.

title: Winning Without Pressure
description: For most American sports fans, swimmers emerge every four years, win a barrelful of gold medals and hibernate four more years.

title: YANKS WEIGH PITCHING CUTS
description: The Yankees, just four days from their season opener in Boston, continued the cruel business of paring their roster today. But even by trimming four players and getting down to 26 - just one over the opening-day limit - they still left some interesting questions to be answered.

title: SCOUTING ;   From the Bench
description: So what's in a name? Larry Bird, a bursitis victim, says that ''sitting out two games was like being in a cage.''

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   South Korea Agrees On Talks With North
description: South Korea announced today that it had accepted dates proposed by North Korea for resuming talks on economic issues and Red Cross cooperation. The resumption, originally scheduled for last January, was postponed by a North Korean boycott that began that month.

title: FILM GROUP IS SHOWN IN A PROFILE
description: IT can be argued that stories about the film industry are more fascinating than most of the films coming out of that industry. The business has long been a magnet for impossible children, no matter their age, and colorful scoundrels. Hollywood is in a category by itself, of course. But it is not unique. Consider the independent organization known as Merchant Ivory Productions, which is the subject of a profile entitled ''The Wandering Company,'' tomorrow evening's ''Film on Film'' presentation on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock.

title: CBS Curb On Meetings The CBS board of directors
description: amended the company's

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Forest Fires Across South Force Hundreds to Flee
description: Forest fires destroyed thousands of acres of woodlands in five Southern states today. A South Carolina man died while trying to stop a fire from spreading in Summerville, S.C.

title: Advertising ;   Campaign For Sports Illustrated
description: SPORTS ILLUSTRATED, now in its 31st year, is about to embark on its first image advertising campaign aimed at beefing up both circulation and advertising.

title: PEC ISRAEL ECONOMIC CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Revenue includes $8,218,714 in 1984 relating to a wholly owned subsidiary which was previously 50 percent- owned and accounted for on the equity method in 1983. Share earnings reflect the payment of a 10 percent stock dividend on Jan. 8.

title: EX-N.F.L. UNION CHIEF AIMS FOR U.S. SENATE
description: In 1960, 22 years before he derailed a National Football League season, Edward R. Garvey was student president at the University of Wisconsin here.

title: SAXON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from the restructuring of debt of $64,994,142 for the quarter and $65,159,179 for the year. c-Net loss. d-Includes a gain of $24,771,331 from a settlement with trade creditors. Results for the latest year include writedowns of oil and gas properties amounting to $8,100,000 and the year- ago results include $5,600,000 of such writedowns.

title: DANCE 2 MARTHA GRAHAM REVIVALS
description: IMAGINE Mary, Queen of Scots, and Elizabeth I, Queen of England, playing tennis to settle their dynastic dispute and you might envisage the tremendous dramatic symmetry Janet Eilber and Peggy Lyman projected so powerfully in Martha Graham's ''Episodes'' on Wednesday night. Imagine a Greek hero like Ulysses straying into the wrong part of town, where the welcoming committee seems headed by a madam, and you will get the feel of Miss Graham's ''Circe.''

title: Jazz Sextet
description: The fluegelhornist Art Farmer, the saxophonist Benny Golson and the other members of their six-man ''jazztet'' will perform tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South north of Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum. Reservations: 242-1785.

title: Dead Babies
description: A low infant-mortality rate denotes a society that cares, and four years ago the Federal Government announced that it hoped to lower the death rate for black infants to 12 per 1,000 births by 1990. No way.

title: The Pentagon's Misuse of Technology
description: Bobbing about in the military budget now before Congress are many lemons, like the Sergeant York gun, which costs far too much and shoots far too poorly. Congress would do well to try correcting such specific blunders - and do much more to address a common flaw: the Pentagon's systematic misuse of technology.

title: THE QUESTIONS ON HERB LIFE
description: Promises that Herbalife's herbal products will reduce weight and cleanse the body have attracted a fervent following for the five-year-old company, as well as more than $500 million in sales.

description: b-Net income.

title: BOON TO MAINE SHIPYARD MAY RESULT IN A STRIKE
description: Just before the first shift at the Bath Iron Works ended Tuesday afternoon, the public address system gave word from the Pentagon that echoed through 58 acres of yards and shops, bringing cheers from thousands of men and women in hard hats.

title: BRIEFING ;   Peace on Both Houses
description: When Easter and Passover coincide, Temple Micah Synagogue and St. Augustine's Episcopal Church are presented with a challenge. For the two congregations occupy the same building, near the Potomac waterfront in Southwest Washington.

title: KIMBARK OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Inmates Briefly Seize Island Prison in Peru
description: Some 400 accused guerrillas imprisoned on an island off Peru's coast held the warden and seven Government officials hostage for 30 hours, demanding better jail conditions. The hostages were released today after authorities agreed to most of the inmates' demands.

title: BAY STATE RESTRICTS SEABROOK FINANCING
description: The Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities told three partners in the beleaguered Seabrook nuclear project yesterday that they could not issue new stocks and bonds to pay for the reactor, unless they submitted ''binding assurances that their stockholders, and not their ratepayers, will assume all the risk of any future investment.''

title: Cleveland Electric Ratings Lowered
description: The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company's debt ratings were lowered yesterday by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: SOMETIMES a painting gathers bits of history to it, just as it gathers dust and cracks and darkens with age. Such is the case with a painting of St. John the Baptist by the Italian master Andrea del Sarto, which not too long ago was found in a church storage space in Worcester, Mass.

title: L.I. MURDER TRIAL OPENS: CONFESSION IS DESCRIBED
description: The prosecution and the defense agreed in opening statements today that James Troiano was present during the drug- induced ritualistic killing of Gary Lauwers in a wooded section of Northport, L.I., last summer.

title: No Headline
description: Chief's Crown and Proud Truth are the early favorites for the Kentucky Derby on May 4. Rhoman Rule, who won the Everglades and is likely to meet Proud Truth in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct April 20, is the third choice, with Stephan's Odyssey next. The other prominent spots will be determined by a trio of prep races tomorrow, which are unusual in that the favorite for each is trained by D. Wayne Lukas.

title: U.S. DISPUTE OVER MAJOR DENIED
description: The chief spokesman for the Defense Department said today that there were no differences between Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Secretary of State George P. Shultz over a response to the Soviet Union for the death of an American Army officer.

description: Mexico City is sputtering into its traditional Holy Week tranquillity.

title: 55% RISE IN MEDICAL MALPRACTICE RATES GRANTED
description: A 55 percent increase in medical malpractice insurance rates was awarded yesterday to Medical Liability Mutual Insurance Company, New York State's largest medical malpractice insurer.

title: Academic Pursuit
description: Anyone who's ever gone off to college has found himself facing an insurmountable backlog from time to time, but Troy Wortham may be the first student who ever had to seek postponement of a final in order to take his midterms.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: DECODING BUDGETBABBLE
description: The world narrowed today for the principal players as the state budget game approached its tardy end, nearly a week after the start of the fiscal year.

title: WIDE STRIKE BRINGS THE SUDAN TO A HALT
description: A general strike organized by opponents of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry crippled the Sudan today, forcing the shutdown of businesses, transportation and basic services.

description: Treasury note and bond prices rose sharply yesterday afternoon after traders learned of a Federal budget accord between the White House and Republican senators that could substantially reduce deficits.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $5.6 million from the sale of real estate for the quarer and 6 months. c-Includes a gain of $913,900 from the sale of a parcel of land.

title: British Hint Oil Price Cut
description: The British National Oil Corporation has proposed its first reduction in oil prices this year, a lowering of the price of the major grade of North Sea oil by $1.15 a barrel, to $27.50, oil industry sources said today.

title: Bridge: Search for Editor Succeeds At Game's Oldest Magazine
description: The world's oldest bridge magazine seemed headed for extinction three months ago but has taken on a new lease of life. The British publication Bridge International, which until last year had gone under the name Bridge Magazine for 58 years, was in difficulty because its editor, Phillip Alder, was about to emigrate to New Zealand.

title: LEADER IN SHORE POSTS 68
description: Myra Blackwelder shot a surprising four-under-par 68 in extreme heat today to take the lead by one shot in the first round of the 14th annual Nabisco Dinah Shore Invitation.

title: ALMOST NO ONE WAS HOME TO THE JAPANESE ENVOY
description: In ending a trade war, timing is everything.

title: BROADWAY
description: 'Captain America' boasts a hero-sized $4 million budget.

title: RANGERS BEAT BLUES, 5-4
description: Anders Hedberg scored his 19th and 20th goals, both on power plays, to break open a tight contest in the middle period, leading the Rangers to a 5-4 triumph tonight over the St. Louis Blues.

title: 'WILDROSE' BY HANSON
description: LISA EICHHORN, who appeared in ''Cutter's Way,'' has gotten heftier since her days as an ingenue, so that she fits very convincingly into the role of a miner in ''Wildrose.'' Miss Eichhorn plays June Lorich, employed as a pit laborer and a truck driver at a strip mine, in the Mesabi Range in Minnesota. The film was shot there and in Bayfield, Wis., and the best parts of it present a simple, documentarylike look at living and working conditions in those places. The film has a flat, unadorned style that is much better suited to documentary than drama.

title: REVOLUTION IS WHAT IS HAPPENING TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Leaders Order Steps To Combat 'Ugly' Alcoholism
description: The Politburo today described alcoholism in the Soviet Union as an ''ugly phenomenon'' and ordered new laws and other measures to intensify the battle against it.

title: MORE TAX CUTS ARE SUGGESTED IN CONNECTICUT
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today proposed $37.6 million in new tax cuts, many of which would benefit the elderly.

title: CARME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $289,470 resulting from the discontinuance of U.S. Naturals Food division for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: BLENDING HIGH TECH AND SOFT SELL ON COAST
description: Esprit, the most recent addition to the burgeoning Los Angeles fashion scene, is a 30,000-square-foot emporium of ideas. In a setting that is a cross between a supermarket and a discoth eque, women's sportswear is presented in a dramatic 17,000- square-foot space. Shopping carts, checkout counters, speckled Zolatone walls and metal catwalks compete for the shopper's attention in a startling contemporary setting. Designed by Joseph Paul D'Urso of New York, the palatial boutique was commissioned by Doug and Susie Tompkins, the company's youthful owners.

title: THE DANCE: MARTHA GRAHAM'S 'CORTEGE OF EAGLES'
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company has taken the unusual step of reviving some of Miss Graham's lesser known works this season at the New York State Theater. One of these revivals, the mysteriously cinematic ''Cortege of Eagles'' of 1967, returned to New York for the first time in 16 years on Thursday night on a program that included one of Miss Graham's rare comic pieces, ''The Owl and the Pussycat,'' and the Graham-Copland classic, ''Appalachian Spring.''

title: GEN. SHERMAN LEFT A (QUOTATION) MATK ON U.S. HISTORY
description: Thomas V. DiBacco is a historian at The American University.

title: VERSATILITY WINS BRADLEY YANKEE JOB
description: It was just a coincidence. One day, Scott Bradley showed up at spring training with a first baseman's mitt. Two days later, Don Mattingly underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee.

title: Bridge: Transfer Bids Are Popular As Response to No-Trump
description: The concept of transfer bidding, in which a player bids the suit immediately below the one he holds, has become very popular in response to no- trump openings. A few theorists have tried to extend it to other situations, such as opening pre-emptive bids.

title: IT'S A NEW GAME FOR A TV BROKER
description: THE Federal regulation of broadcasting has been

title: Man Who Held a Boy For 7 Years Is Paroled
description: A man who kidnapped a boy and kept him for nearly seven years was paroled today on the the condition that he stay away from children and attend regular therapy sessions.

title: CHURCH READY TO MEDIATE
description: The Roman Catholic Primate of Nicaragua said today that the church hierarchy was ready to mediate the Nicaraguan conflict, but only if both sides accepted its services.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Chauvinistic Stand
description: If you like to watch women's tennis, that's fine with

title: Transactions
description: Optioned Randy O'Neal, pitcher, and Dwight Lowry, catcher, to Nashville. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Reassigned Rick Reuschel, pitcher, and Sammy Khalifa, shortstop, to minor-league camp and released Hedi Vargas, first baseman, to Hawaii.

title: Taft Agrees to Sell 5 Radio Stations
description: The Taft Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it plans to sell five radio stations, two of its own and three belonging to the Gulf Broadcast Company, in order to pave the way for Taft's acquisition of several Gulf properties.

title: A SALVADORAN REBEL LEADER REPORTED DEAD OR WOUNDED
description: A Salvadoran Army spokesman said tonight that the army believed it had wounded or killed the country's leading guerrilla commander.

title: Busy Mr. Bush
description: While President Reagan is away on vacation for the next week, Vice President Bush will be unusually active and visible in Washington and elsewhere.

title: PLAYER SAYS COACH, NOW AT FAIRLEIGH, PAID HIM AT TULANE
description: A basketball player indicted in the point-shaving case at Tulane University has told prosecutors that Tom Green, now the head basketball coach at Fairleigh Dickinson University, gave him $10,000 to enroll in Tulane four years ago, sources in New Orleans said yesterday.

title: Max Yavno, 73, Photographer Known for California Scenes
description: Max Yavno, a California photographer best known for his black and white photographs of Los Angeles and San Francisco in the 1940's, died Thursday at Cedars-Sinai Hospital here.

title: LEGAL AID ON A THIN IDEOLOGICAL ROPE
description: W. Clark Durant 3d, chairman of the Federal Legal Services Corporation, wants Congress to appropriate $305 million for legal aid for poor people in civil cases next year, the same amount as in the current budget.

title: CAMBODIA FORGOTTEN
description: It is 10 years this month since Indochina fell to the Communists, and

title: The Columnist Who Was Taken Over
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBERT M. SCHMON
description: Robert M. Schmon, retired chairman of the Ontario Paper Company Ltd. and a director of the Tribune Company since 1969, died here today in the wake of injuries he received Wednesday in an automobile accident in the Bahamas.

title: SCOUTING ;   Losers' Tonic
description: Manager Doug Rader tries to explain why effervescent Mickey Rivers will be missed by the Texas Rangers, who dropped him Thursday: ''The one reason why - and don't misconstrue this - that Mickey was so special to this club was that our team was so bad, he took our minds off what was going on out there.''

title: 'HEIMAT,' A CHRONICLE OF GERMANY
description: Edgar Reitz's ''Heimat'' is a cinematic event, if not quite a masterpiece. It's a massive, nearly 16-hour chronicle of life in Germany, from 1919 to 1982, as reflected in the fluctuating fortunes of the members of one family, initially peasant-farmers, in the fictitious village of Schabbach in the Rhineland. As literature, ''Heimat'' bears the same relationship to Rainer Werner Fassbinder's magnificent, equally long adaptation of Alfred Doblin's ''Berlin Alexanderplatz'' that Herman Wouk's ''Winds of War'' bears to Thomas Mann's ''Buddenbrooks.''

title: Dynalectron Pact
description: The Dynalectron Corporation said its Granada Data Systems had agreed with the Xerox Corporation's Century Data Systems to provide ''end of life'' maintenance for Century's 20,000 Marksman M20 and M40 disk drives, which Century has discontinued producing. It also said that Granada had purchased the spare-parts inventory to support the models.

title: Century Brass Financing Plan
description: An interim financing plan has been approved in United States Bankruptcy Court that should allow Century Brass Products of Waterbury to keep its general products and defense divisions in operation at least through June 2. The agreement approved Thursday calls for the General Electric Credit Corporation to provide up to $10 million in new financing to pay the company's wages, fringe benefits, vendor charges and other obligations.

title: 7 STATES IN SOUTH FIGHT FOREST FIRES
description: Fires fanned by gusting winds swept seven drought-plagued Southern states yesterday, destroying many homes and thousands of acres of woodlands.

title: The New Bid to Nicaragua
description: President Reagan now wants 60 days to show whether or not diplomacy can win a cease-fire in Nicaragua and a deal between its Marxist rulers and the United States-backed opposition. In return, he asks a skeptical Congress not to cancel the next $14 million in aid for the ''contra'' insurgents, as it was threatening to do. He would use it only for food, clothing and medicine and delay buying more weapons until diplomacy had clearly failed.

title: G. A. O. STUDY CITES RISK IN OIL STOCKPILE DELAY
description: A Reagan Administration proposal to temporarily delay completion of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, the nation's protection against a sudden oil shortage, may set back the country's ability to withstand such a shortage, according to a study by the General Accounting Office.

title: Pacific Lighting Settles Suit
description: The Pacific Lighting Corporation said it had reached an out-of-court settlement covering the bulk of a $118 million lawsuit brought against it last November by two major oil companies. The agreement with the Union Oil Company of California unit of the Unocal Corporation calls for Pacific Lighting, the parent of the Southern California Gas Company, to resume its purchases of natural gas.

title: Every Little Breeze
description: The official Cherry Blossom Festival starts Sunday, just as the

title: Motion to Postpone Trial Of von B"ulow Rejected
description: The prosecution today failed in an effort for an indefinite postponement of Claus von B"ulow's new trial on charges of attempted murder to allow more time to examine 25 potential defense witnesses.

title: SYRIA SAID TO WARN LEBANON TO HALT FIGHTING NEAR SIDON
description: An explosion destroyed part of a major elevated highway in the northern section of the Iraqi capital today, according to witnesses.

title: William Stansbury, Ex-Mayor Of Louisville, Is Killed by Car
description: Former Mayor William B. Stansbury, 62 years old, and his mother, Eileen, 84, were killed Thursday night when they were struck by a car while on their way to church, the authorities said. Mr. Stansbury's wife Mary Ellen, 46, was injured.

title: Xtra Computer Prices Cut ITT Information Systems
description: announced price

title: O'BRIEN WINS 500 FREESTYLE
description: Mike O'Brien, an Olympic champion from Costa Mesa, Calif., won the men's 500-yard freestyle tonight for his second victory in the national short-course swimming championships. Neatly, of course.

title: PAUL DEAN ARNOLD, EX-CHAIRMAN OF BAKING CONCERN, IS DEAD AT 76
description: Paul Dean Arnold, the founder and former chairman of Arnold Bakers, the maker of Arnold Brick Oven Bread, died Thursday at Hartford Hospital. Mr. Arnold, who was 76 years old and lived in Millbrook, N.Y., had had cancer for some time.

title: CELTICS DEFEAT BULLETS
description: Larry Bird scored a game-high 26 points tonight as the Boston Celtics defeated the Washington Bullets for the fifth consecutive time, 115-104.

title: FIFTH DIMENSION INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
PITTOCK FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW EXPLOSION IN BAGHDAD INCREASES DOUBTS ABOUT MISSILE ATTACKS
description: An explosion destroyed part of a major elevated highway in the northern section of the Iraqi capital today, according to witnesses.

title: 'Legends' Break Barrier
description: McEnroe may not approve, but

title: More Losses At Regent Air LOS ANGELES, April 5 (AP)
description: The Regent Air Corporation

title: DeLorean Sells Film Rights
description: John Z. DeLorean, trying to help defray legal costs of the drug conspiracy trial in which he was acquitted, has sold the rights to his film biography to a new movie company for a reported $1.3 million. The Los Angeles Times reported today that the former automobile executive signed the deal with the DeLorean Plus Film Group.

title: Research-Cottrell
description: Research-Cottrell Inc. said it and CRS Sirrine Inc., a Houston- based construction management company, had received a $150 million Air Force contract to manage the design, construction and start-up of communications and intelligence facilities for Saudi Arabia. Research- Cottrell, which provides engineering and consulting services, said that its share of the contract was $65 million. Additional contracts under the program would be awarded in 1986 and 1987, it said.

title: Pemex Case Convictions
description: An oilfield equipment company, its chairman and three other businessmen have been convicted after entering pleas of no contest to Federal charges of paying almost $10 million in bribes to high-ranking executives of Pemex, Mexico's national oil monopoly.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HIGH ROLLER The first taste of spring in New York might well be described as the first gulp of sea air at Coney Island when it ''opens'' for the season. It doesn't open all at once, and some of it, like the Aquarium, works around the calendar. But two perennials in the special Coney Island tradition have opened their doors once again.

title: Age Limit Urged
description: Concerned about the effects of competitive stress on young tennis professionals, a special committee of the International Tennis Federation will propose that players be prohibited from turning professional before they are 16 years old and be banned from playing in any professional match before they are 14. According to

title: Brazil's Leader Reported In Stable Condition
description: President-elect Tancredo Neves of Brazil was said today to be in stable condition amid signs that there had been some reduction in an infection that led Thursday to his fifth abdominal operation in three weeks.

title: ACCIDENT LEADS TO PRISON FOR VICTIM WITH RECORD
description: On May 31, 1984, Daniel Garcia of Manhattan was struck by a speeding taxicab near Park Avenue South and 22d Street. The impact knocked him out and left him, in the words of one witness, ''a bloody mess.'' A few hours later, however, he was to learn that the taxi was by no means the worst thing to hit him that day.

title: ROSE PEABODY PARSONS
description: Rose Peabody Parsons, a former president of the National Council of Women, died March 28 at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. She was 93 years old and had lived at the Glengariff Nursing Home in Glen Cove for the last four years.

title: Federal Court Delays Deportation of 26 Cubans
description: A Federal district judge has stopped the Government from returning 26 Cubans to their homeland.

title: Yugoslav Costs Rise
description: Yugoslavia's cost of living rose 70.4 percent in March from a year earlier, and was up 5.2 percent from February, the Federal Statistics Bureau said today.

title: JAPAN AGREES TO END WHALING
description: The Japanese Government, yielding to years of pressure from the United States, agreed formally today to end all commercial whaling by March 1988.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about political psychology misidentified Robert Jay Lifton. He is a professor of psychiatry and psychology at John Jay College of the City University.

title: JAPAN TRADE: A NEW HEAT
description: Until the last few days, Japan apparently thought that as a veteran of the world trade wars it had seen all the hardships that combative negotiations could bring. This may explain why many Japanese officials were not prepared for the virtually unanimous warnings from Congress of reprisals against Japanese products unless Tokyo started immediately chipping away at its ever-expanding trade surplus with the United States.

title: University President Resigns After Threat to Accreditation
description: The president of Cheyney University, which is threatened with loss of accreditation, has announced his resignation, effective April 20.

title: Consolation Prizes
description: Their teams may not have won championships, but

title: CONCERT: DELOS STRING QUARTET
description: One would not ordinarily expect sensitive and idiomatic performances of Middle-European music from a chamber ensemble based at the University of Delaware, but that's just what the Delos String Quartet provided last Sunday night at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue.

title: WITH POPE'S APPROVAL, NBC EXPLORES THE VATICAN
description: Few television programs ever had such an opportunity for a promotional spot - or such an imprimatur.

title: Sharon Planning a Campaign To Be Israeli Premier in '88
description: Former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, chief architect of Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon, said today that he intended to run for Prime Minister in 1988.

title: INSIDER PROFIT TO THAYER DESCRIBED
description: The Government said today that Paul Thayer, a former Deputy Defense Secretary who pleaded guilty to lying to the Securities and Exchange Commission, and close friends made a $200,000 profit on confidential information he passed along about the LTV Corporation's proposed takeover of the Grumman Corporation in 1981.

title: ABUNDANT BUDGET
description: As legislators roamed the third floor of the Capitol Thursday night, waiting for bills to be delivered so they could vote on the $39 billion state budget, Senator John B. Daly, a Republican from Lewiston, cheerily sang, ''We're in the money.'' Indeed they were. As it turned out, there was something for just about everyone in the budget that the Legislature approved early this morning.

title: EAST GERMAN CHIEF WILL VISIT ROME
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, will make an official visit to Italy later this month, his first ever to a North Atlantic Treaty Organization capital, the East German press agency reported today.

title: Herbalife Halts F. D. A. Lawsuit
description: Herbalife International has

title: DDI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company's fiscal year was changed to end Dec. 31, 1984 instead of Feb. 28, 1985.

title: NEW POLITICS EMERGE IN ITALY
description: ROME Italy enjoys a wide audience in America for its fashions and wines. Yet, has comparable attention been paid to Italy's new politics since Washington's preoccupation in the 1970's with the Eurocommunism fad? Will our American friends be prepared to read, for example, May's regional and local elections in the light of an electoral trend that stems from a deep transformation in postwar Italian society?

title: MOVIELAB INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses of $814,189 from discontinued operations and $2,901,648 on disposal of film processing operation for the latest year and a loss of $2,310,371 from discontinued operations for the previous year.

title: BERENYI PASSES TEST, BUT HE'S NOT 100%
description: With their pitching in danger of falling apart on the brink of the new season, the Mets today gave a final medical check to Bruce Berenyi, their No. 3 starter, and held a wave of high-level meetings on the fate of Sid Fernandez, who was expected to be No. 4.

title: Judge Cleared to Stay On 3 Mile Island Case
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that allegations of bias against Ivan Smith, an administrative law judge, were unwarranted, and that he would continue as the presiding judge in proceedings involving the restarting of one of the Three Mile Island nuclear reactors near Harrisburg, Pa.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits of $2.8 million for the latest quarter and $550,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: 2 KEY STATE PROSECUTORS CHARGING INTERFERENCE BY ATTORNEY GENERAL
description: Two key state prosecutors have accused Attorney General Robert Abrams of threatening the independence of their offices by seizing a greater role in an effort to expand his own reputation.

title: Students Continue Columbia Protest
description: A student coalition at Columbia University, joined by students from New York University and City University, yesterday pressed its demand for Columbia to sell off its investments in companies doing business with South Africa.

title: Accord in Suit Ends 11 Years Of Dispute Over the Retarded
description: A Federal district judge today accepted a settlement ending 11 years of litigation over the state's Pennhurst Center for the mentally retarded and calling for closing the institution next year.

title: McEnroe Rallies, Gains Semifinals
description: Top- seeded John McEnroe survived a first-set loss today to score a 4-6, 6-4, 6-1 victory over Paul Annacone, a fellow New Yorker, and advance to the semifinal round of the $315,000 Volvo Tennis-Chicago Tournament.

title: JIM CROW IS GONE, BUT WHITE RESISTANCE REMAINS
description: Like Birmingham and Montgomery and Selma, those other shrines of the civil rights movement, Greensboro marked an important turning point for blacks in the South. Here, 25 years ago, four young black men sat down at a white-only lunch counter and refused to leave.

title: SUDAN'S PRESIDENT IS RETURNING HOME IN FACE OF UNREST
description: The President of the Sudan cut short his overseas tour today and headed home from the United States to deal with the growing challenge to his one-party rule.

title: Thais Kill Vietnam Soldier
description: Border policemen killed a Vietnamese soldier in Thailand during a 10-minute fight near the border with Cambodia, Thai authorities said today. The clash was said to have occurred Thursday at Laem Nong Ian, a restricted area 15 miles southeast of this Thai border town, after five Vietnamese intruded about 875 yards into Thailand.

title: NICARAGUA SCORNS REAGAN PROPOSAL FOR REBEL TALKS
description: Nicaragua today officially rejected a proposal by President Reagan for talks on the guerrilla war there.

title:
PATENTS ;

BUILDING A REACTOR IN SEGMENTS
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 38.

title: 3M Acquisition
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said it had acquired the Electronized Chemicals Company, a division of the High Voltage Engineering Corporation of Burlington, Mass. Terms were not disclosed. It said the acquisition includes administration, production, laboratory and warehouse facilities of Electronized, which manufactures electrical insulation products.

title: Mabern at Jazz Center
description: The pianist Harold Mabern will lead a quintet tonight in a program dedicated to the music of the trumpeter Lee Morgan at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street, near East Third Street. Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $8, $6 for students and the elderly. Information: 505-5660.

title: A Peanutty Issue
description: It is not considered reprehensible or

title: Judge Sentences 4 to Prison For Fishing Contest Cheating
description: A Federal judge sentenced four men to prison today for their roles in a cheating ring that netted participants more than $350,000 in fishing tournament prizes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, APRIL 6, 1985
description: The Economy

title: An Elizabethan Garden
description: An Elizabethan garden made of plants and glass objects is on view through next Saturday at Steuben Glass, Fifth Avenue and 56th Street.

title: Defense Tactic Fails In Molestation Case
description: A judge today refused to dismiss any charges against seven former teachers at the McMartin Preschool, ruling that a new law affecting the statute of limitations in cases of molestation of children did not apply. The seven are charged with sexually molesting 41 pupils from 1978 to 1984.

title: LEGISLATORS GIVE FINAL APPROVAL TO STATE BUDGET
description: At 2:59 A.M. today, the New York Assembly voted the final bill of the state's $39 billion budget, a 279-page document that provides for a cornucopia of purposes - from a new ambulance for the LaFargeville Fire Department to a new tax-cut program.

title: DIPLOMAT ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FOUNDERS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $188,000, or 3 cents a share. c-Net income after realized investment gains of $223,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $275,000, or 5 cents a share, for the year. d-Includes a loss of $18,000 from investment activities.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Monday about the Xerox Corporation misstated an appointment by its insurance subsidiary Crum & Forster. William E. Buckley Jr. was named chairman and chief executive of the Westchester Fire Insurance Company and the International Insurance Company.

title: Germany's Wartime Generation Lives On
description: To the Editor:

title: SPENCER-DEVLIN TIES CLARK FOR LEAD
description: Muffin Spencer-Devlin described her poor tee shot at No. 8 today as a ''skinky 8-iron to the green'' and her popped drive at No. 12 as ''funky.''

title: FOREIGNERS FIND TERROR EXEMPTS NO ONE IN BEIRUT
description: A week ago, a British professor decided to rush his blond daughter, a student, out of West Beirut after a secretary at the French Embassy was kidnapped.

title: Rightist Danger Cited in Court
description: A Federal judge today refused to hand over evidence that he said could provide right-wing extremists with clues to which of their colleagues have cooperated with the authorities.

title: After Turbulent Years, Guatemala Undergoes a Political Opening
description: To the Editor:

title: COAST ELECTRONIC PLANTS FIGHTING DRUG ABUSE AMONG WORKERS
description: When the San Jose Police Department set up a neighborhood bar and grill for a nine-month undercover operation to recover stolen goods, it expected to be buying such household- burglary items as television sets, jewlery and guns.

title: BAGHDAD SECURITY GETS EVEN TIGHTER
description: Every day, the state-owned publication known as The Baghdad Observer prints a list of international direct-dialing codes for Iraq's telephone system, one of the Middle East's most modern, efficient networks.

title: CHANGE AND CONSTANCY AT THE HEART OF RICHMOND HILL
description: With nearly the precision of a birth certificate, the old-timers in Richmond Hill date themselves with memories of the triangle formed by the intersection of Jamaica Avenue, Myrtle Avenue and 117th Street.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: MORE DINERS OBJECT TO RESTAURANT NOISE
description: If designers wonder about the impact their settings have on restaurant diners, they need only look at a new Gallup Poll. The deliberate addition of loud music in restaurants - along with surfaces that reflect rather than absorb noise - has drawn much attention, not all of it positive.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Vida Blue , suspended for last season by the former commissioner of baseball,

title:
PATENTS ;

NASA Latching Gear
description: A hemispherical latching apparatus, which is being considered for use in the space shuttle to control a payload, was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration by Keith H. Clark of the Marshall Space Flight Center in Alabama. Patent 4,508,296 explains that the equipment automatically retains in a fixed position articles that have a wide range of sizes and shapes. Such articles may include scientific instruments.

title: SATELCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes the effect of year-end adjustments of about $3,887,000 related to allowance for doubtful accounts, accrued line costs associated with access charges and revision to the carrying value of certain assets.

title: FREEZE ON DYNAMICS EXTENDED
description: The Pentagon said today that it would extend its freeze on payments to the General Dynamics Corporation until it had recovered $154 million in contested billings from the company.

title: DEPORTED FAMILY GETS A NEW START
description: A Mexican couple whose son has a congenital heart defect was deported from the United States today but returned to the country legally 15 minutes later.

title: G.E. Trial Set May 13
