description: The General Electric Company prepared today for a May 13 trial on charges that it defrauded the Federal Government by padding expenses on a $47 million Minuteman nuclear warhead contract.

title: Markets Closed
description: The stock, commodity and credit markets in the United States and most markets in Europe were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday.

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After gains from operations of $184,000 for the latest quarter and $108,000 for year-earlier period.

title: After-Tax Profits Down
description: Manufacturers' after-tax profits averaged 4.1 cents per dollar of sales in the final three months of 1984, down 9 percent from the July-September quarter, the Commerce Department reported.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Urban Geysers
description: The fountain at Lincoln Center

title:
PATENTS ;

Method Reduces Coke In Production of Iron
description: A blast furnace system invented for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation of Pittsburgh reduces the amount of coke usually required for the production of iron. Maurice G. Fey of the staff is named as inventor in patent 4,509,177, issued this week.

title: Indians Should Rejoice at Museum's Dallas Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRCO MFG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-earlier quarter and year results include $354,000, or 17 cents a share, from the sale of real estate.

title: CHEMICAL AGREES TO BUY HOME STATE
description: The Chemical Bank of New York announced yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to buy the failed Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati, whose financial problems last month precipitated a bank crisis in Ohio, and transform it into a federally insured commercial bank.

title: TO BE FULLY, UH, CANDID
description: F. Champion Ward was an undergraduate dean at the University of Chicago.

title: A SALUTE TO BRITISH FASHION
description: It was tea and scones, music videos, clingy knits, oversize jackets and pattern-on-pattern-on-pattern. It was Saks Fifth Avenue's salute to British fashion, and it began Thursday with a lively show on the store's fifth floor.

title: Suspect in Drug Killing Is Returned to Mexico
description: Rafael Caro Quintero was returned to Mexico tonight under armed guard for questioning about the slaying of an American narcotics agent.

title: Jenrette Begins Serving Term in Abscam Case
description: Former Representative John W. Jenrette Jr., Democrat of South Carolina, entered a Federal prison today to begin serving two years for bribery and conspiracy convictions resulting from a Federal investigation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BPI Systems Inc., Austin, Tex., said it had hired David R. Pernald, a senior vice president at Datapoint Corp., as its new president and chief executive officer.

title: A. T. & T.'S RIVALS ASK NEW RULES
description: The main rivals of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today recommended major changes in the process by which Americans are being asked to select a primary long- distance telephone company. If enacted nationwide, industry experts said, the changes could help smaller long-distance companies compete with A.T.&T.

title: FAMILY FACES GRIM LIFE AS JOBLESS BENEFITS END
description: Bill Smith was laid off last September after 10 years of assembling mechanical parts at the Kingsbury factory here. Now he is down to his next-to-last unemployment check, and he has applied for welfare.

title: Books of The Times;   Climbing the Ladder
description: QUEENIE. By Michael Korda. 650 pages. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: 6 Soldiers and Policemen Killed in Ambush in India
description: Six Indian soldiers and policemen were killed today and six others wounded in an ambush by separatist guerrillas in the northeastern state of Tripura, the Press Trust of India said.

title: RENEWED CHURCH A SYMBOL OF EASTER
description: On her first Sunday at Mariner's Temple Baptist Church two years ago, the Rev. Suzan Johnson preached to the 15 die-hard members who still regularly turned out for services. Most expected her to be interim pastor for a few weeks before the impoverished church would be forced to close.

title: Required Reading;   Entities of Democracy
description: I see principal problems to be dealt with in the coming years.

title: MUSIC: A SALUTE TO BROADWAY
description: Star-studded pop galas tend to be uneven affairs, and ''Back to Broadway: A Salute to Broadway of the 80's,'' presented at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening by the New York City Gay Men's Chorus, was no exception. The event - with the High Heeled Women, four sassy cabaret comediennes who suggest Bette Midler times four, as hosts - interspersed star turns by 10 Broadway personalities with choral medleys from ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' ''La Cage aux Folles,'' and ''Ain't Misbehavin'.''

title: SCOUTING ;   Honoring Ruud
description: Because they take medals in the downhill as well as in the slalom and the giant slalom, Pirmin Zurbriggen and Marc Girardelli have been heralded as the shining stars of a new breed of generalist ski racers. But if you think that what they do is truly special, then you've likely never heard of Birger Ruud.

title: WARNING ON TAX PREPARERS
description: DURING a surprise inspection of 62 local tax preparers last week, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs found 45 of them to be in violation of city regulations.

title: BRITISH DUO IN CHINA FOR FIRST POP CONCERTS
description: The British pop duo Wham - chosen for what Peking officials have described as its ''healthy'' image - arrived here yesterday for a two-concert tour that will give Chinese audiences their first exposure to big-time Western popular music.

title: SINCLAIR VENEZUELAN OIL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Sinclair is a 97 percent-owned subsidiary of the Atlantic Richfield Co.

title: Wrong Way to Reject a Judge Rejecting the advice of New York's Senators, the Reagan Administration has refused to nominate Will Hellerstein, a highly regarded lawyer, to a Federal judgeship. Though this violates custom, it is the President's prerogative. But the case was handled so crudely that it raises questions about the Administration's hidden agenda.
description: The Senate's power to advise and consent on judges has produced a selection system in which senators of the President's party recommend appointees in their states. Unless utterly repugnant to the bar or Justice Department, they are usually accepted.

title: POPE LEADS GOOD FRIDAY SERVICES
description: Pope John Paul II carried a wooden cross tonight in a torchlight procession commemorating the final agonies of Jesus on Good Friday.

title: JOBLESS RATE HOLDS STEADY DESPITE EMPLOYMENT RISE
description: Unemployment in March was 7.2 percent of the labor force, virtually unchanged from the six previous months even though there was an unusually large increase in the number of people employed, the Labor Department reported today.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 6, 1985 International
description: The growing challenge in the Sudan to President Gaafar al-Nimeiry's one- party rule has cut short his visit to the United States and altered his plans to visit Egypt and Pakistan this month. Mr. Nimeiry, who has been in the United States since last week, told United States officials he had decided to return home this weekend after a brief stop in Cairo to consult with officials about the situation in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital. A general strike in the Sudan began Wednesday. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: BIG WASTE CONCERN IS FINED $2.5 MILLION FOR ILLEGAL DUMPING
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it was fining a subsidiary of the nation's largest disposal company for hazardous wastes $2.5 million for violating toxic waste laws at its dump in Vickery, Ohio.

title: PRESIDENTS SEEK CONTROL
description: The chairman of a commission of college presidents said today that steps had to be taken to ''eliminate corruption'' in collegiate athletics.

title: The Day-Care Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOUTING ;   Miami's Spice: Big-Time Names
description: For an outfit on the Class A level, right on the lowest rung of the minor leagues - and for an unaffiliated outfit, at that - the Miami Marlins have certainly been loading up with a lot of players accustomed to more lofty surroundings.

title: PLAN TO SHIFT SCHOOL CHIEFS STIRS MONTCLAIR DISTRICT
description: The public school system here has been thrown into turmoil by the proposed transfers of three popular principals.

title: MASS-MARKETING THE I. R. A.
description: The pre-April 15 advertising blitz designed to attract Individual Retirement Accounts is taking a different turn this year. The lavish promotions and interest-rate wars have given way to a strategy of seeking to broaden the appeal of the tax-favored savings accounts to millions of people who have not had $2,000 to put aside.

title: THE EARLY GOALS OF ED PINCKNEY
description: In recent months several youths who live in the

title: NOW PITCHING AGAINST DISEASE
description: There was nothing unusual about

title: Myers Seeks Deal
description: A buyer is being sought for all or part of the L.E. Myers Company, a financially troubled supplier of construction services to utility companies. The company also said it does not expect to agree on a restructuring of its $23.5 million debt. The four banks involved are the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the First National Bank of Chicago, the Texas Commerce Bank and the Bank of Detroit. L.E. Myers posted a loss of $17.5 million in 1984.

title: SUMMIT OILFIELD CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,447,981 for the latest year and $1,355,220 for the prior year.

title: DETAILS OF WESTINGHOUSE SUIT
description: The Justice Department has accused employees of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation of routinely filing false expense vouchers on Federal Government defense contracts to raise cash for picnics, Christmas parties and baseball uniforms.

title: FINE ART ACQUISITIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $28,800, or 1 cent a share.

title: PRAISE AND SOME RESPECT FOR WOMEN PATROLLING QUEENS
description: ''Sometimes the perpetrator asks you out.''

title: Sometimes in Arrears Doesn't Make a Debtor
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS ;

Inventors Exposition In New York May 3-7
description: At least 25 countries are to have displays in 175 booths at the ninth annual Worldwide Inventors Exposition, to be held May 3 through May 7 at the Sheraton Exhibition Center in New York. About 500 or more patented inventions are to be shown.

title: MUSIC: BERLIN OCTET
description: an elegant group consisting of a string quartet, double bass, clarinet, bassoon and horn extracted from the Berlin Symphony Orchestra - began its Sunday afternoon program at Carnegie Hall with Beethoven's Septet in E flat (Op. 20). Here, immediately, the ensemble's strengths and weaknesses were apparent.

title: Truck Operation Halts
description: The California Cartage Company has announced that it is ceasing its 40- year-old freight trucking operation immediately, blaming deregulation and competition from nonunion truck drivers in southern California. More than 100 workers in the company's terminals in San Diego and in Compton, a Los Angeles suburb, will be laid off, cutting the work force in half, the company's president, Robert A. Curry, said Thursday.

title: BUDGET COMPROMISE EASES ORIGINAL CUTS IN AID FOR STUDENTS
description: Federal aid for many college students would be reduced under the budget package endorsed by President Reagan and Senate Republicans, but the cut would be less than the Administration originally proposed.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an after-tax gain of $41,313,000, or $3.44 per share, from the sale of the Alliance Mortgage Company in February 1985. The per share data for 1984 has been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed to stockholders June 29, 1984.

title: CREDIT MARKETS STUDY JOBLESS DATA
description: The credit markets were closed yesterday, with no new offerings of Treasury, corporate or municipal securities, and no trading in the American cash or futures markets.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What President Reagan has said is, 'You drop dead, or I will kill you.' '' - Miguel d'Escoto Brockman, Foreign Minister of Nicaragua. (1:4.)

title: China to Open Talks on Oil
description: China will open negotiations with foreign oil companies by the end of 1985 for onshore exploration and drilling in 10 southern provinces, an official said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Ragtimer's Last Wish
description: Sixty-eight years after he died,

title: THATCHERISM: POPULAR ABROAD, NOT AT HOME
description: Margaret Thatcher is having more success persuading the international financial markets than the average Briton that she has Britain on the right track economically.

title: GERMANY'S WARTIME GENERATION LIVES ON
description: To the Editor:

title: Jewish Book Council Names Award Winners
description: The Jewish Welfare Board Book Council has named Frederick Busch, author of ''Invisible Mending,'' the winner for fiction and Joan Peters, author of ''From Time Immemorial: The Origins of the Arab-Jewish Conflict Over Palestine,'' winner in the Israel category of its annual literary prize-giving.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The Bucks and the Nets both have playoff berths, and Milwaukee leads the season series, 3-2. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:45 P.M. tape. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M. live.) Baseball

title: AT YALE, WORLD ACCORDING TO SCHMIDT
description: Helmut Schmidt, the former West German Chancellor, who fell from power in the autumn of 1982, is now 66 years old. He has a pacemaker and is hard of hearing. He climbs steps with studious deliberation. A heavy smoker once, he now confines himself to snuff. He speaks softly enough that his listeners must sometimes strain to hear him.

title: TEAMSTER CHIEF ORDERED TO TESTIFY ABOUT UNION
description: A Federal district judge has ordered the president of the teamsters' union to testify before the Presidential Commission on Organized Crime, which is investigting allegations of bribes, kickbacks and other illegal payments to teamster officials.

title: INDIA ISSUES PASSPORT ORDER
description: The Government issued an unusual order today requiring all foreigners in New Delhi to carry their passports or residential permits at all times for two weeks beginning Monday. The Government statement announcing the order did not offer any explanation.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE FALLS SLIGHTLY IN THE CITY
description: The unemployment rate for New York City decreased slightly in March while the unemployment rates for New York State and New Jersey remained largely unchanged, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: LIMIT ON BENEFITS IS ASSAILED
description: President Reagan said today that he thought the budget compromise reached by White House negotiators and Senate Republican leaders was ''a very good plan'' for reducing the deficit. But he was immediately attacked for his agreement to limit the cost-of-living increase for Social Security for three years.

title: Capistrano Bank On Coast Closed
description: Federal regulators declared Capistrano National Bank insolvent. It was the third bank in California and the 22d in the nation to be closed so far this year, officials said.

title: Cholera Said to Kill 1,000 in Somalia
description: Cholera has killed 1,000 people in Somalia, and as many as 300,000 others in the East African nation risk contracting the disease, the Red Cross said today.

title: Drug Agency Head Named
description: President Reagan announced Thursday that he would nominate John C. Lawn, deputy administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, as administrator of the agency. Mr. Lawn, a 49- year-old former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, would succeed Francis M. Mullen Jr.

title: NAVY SAYS CONVERTED VESSEL HAS MADE DIVE TO 20,000 FEET
description: The Navy said today that a tiny three-man submarine, the Sea Cliff, had made an ocean dive of 20,000 feet off the coast of Central America, completing the conversion of the former research vessel so that it can work in the depths of the ocean.

title: Ex-Paris Aide Calls New Vote Plan Harmful
description: Michel Rocard, whose surprise resignation as Agriculture Minister has thrown French politics into turmoil, said today that he left because new electoral plans threatened political stability.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   A Unicorn Tempest
description: Is it a unicorn - or really a goat cruelly transformed into that mythical, one-horned creature?

title: Jersey Prisons Keeping Cubans in Segregation
description: About 150 Cuban refugees serving sentences in New Jersey prisons and facing deportation hearings have been segregated from other prisoners because of reports that some of the Cubans were planning to kill guards at two prisons, a correction spokesman said today.

title: Cardinals to Stay
description: Bill Bidwill, the owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, citing a proposal for construction of a $100 million domed stadium, said that the football team would remain in St. Louis, ending months of speculation about a possible move. He said the football team, which celebrated its 25th year in St. Louis last season, would stay for at least the coming season while plans to build the stadium, which would seat up to 100,000 people, are completed. . . .Add the Seattle Seahawks to the list of National Football League teams planning to make overtures to

title: ACTOR WALKING DOG ON 23RD ST. IS KILLED AS CAR RUNNING RED LIGHT HITS CAB
description: An unemployed actor was killed early yesterday on a West Side street when a taxicab was struck and hurled into him by a car that had run a red light, the police said.

title: Mitsubishi-Rolm
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said it is considering purchasing telecommunications equipment from the Rolm Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., and marketing it in Japan. Mitsubishi said it had not yet reached a final decision on purchasing digital private branch exchanges, or PBX's, from Rolm, a subsidiary of the International Business Machines Corporation of Armonk, N.Y. Since Japan's telecommunications market became liberalized on April 1, the Toshiba Corporation, one of Mitsubishi Electric's competitors, has begun discussions with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, apparently aimed at cooperation in marketing telecommunications equipment in Japan.

title: Palestinians Attacked Jet
description: The Palestinian organization Black September took responsibility today for a rocket attack on a Jordanian airliner at the Athens airport on Thursday, when a rocket was fired at an Alia Boeing 727. No one aboard the plane was injured. An anonymous caller to Agence France Presse said today, ''One of our combat units shot a rocket at a plane of the Jordanian regime at the moment it was leaving Athens airport.''

title: Spanish War Veteran, 107
description: Purl A. Mulkey, one of the nation's oldest Spanish-American War veterans, died Thursday at the age of 107. Mr. Mulkey joined the 45th Volunteer Infantry in November 1897 and embarked for the Philippines. At discharge he was a corporal. At the time of his 100th birthday in November 1977, he was named a national aide de camp of the Veterans of Foreign Wars and President Carter sent him two letters of congratulation.

title:
PATENTS ;

A Versatile Grill Offered for Campers
description: A versatile and portable grill for campers was patented this week.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY PIZZA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Opening Day at Coney I.
description: For Norman Siegel and a lot of other

title: REINVESTING DIVIDENDS
description: PLANS through which shareholders can automatically reinvest their dividends in a company's stock instead of receiving cash have been a fixture on the American business scene for more than 15 years. But a slowing growth rate for the plans has spurred companies to devise some changes recently that are intended to attract greater investor interest.

title: POLITICAL FILMS FLOURISH IN BRAZIL'S FREER CLIMATE
description: Projecting a romantic, exotic and even escapist vision of the country, such films as ''Dona Flor and Her Two Husbands'' and ''Bye, Bye Brazil'' have in recent years earned Brazil's movie industry a solid reputation abroad.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE KILL BLACK
description: A black man was shot to death by the police in a small black township near the southeast coast after a group of blacks began stoning police officers and firefighters who were responding to an incident of arson, a police spokesman said today.

title: Pickering Nominated As U.S. Envoy to Israel
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Thomas R. Pickering, the United States Ambassador in El Salvador, to become the new Ambassador to Israel.

title: 5 CHILDREN DIE AS FIRE ENGULFS BROOKLYN HOUSE
description: A fire burned through a two-family house in Brooklyn early yesterday, killing five children. Two other children were reported in critical condition and four older residents were also injured.

title: Atheists' Meeting Countered By Religious Son of Leader
description: The evangelist William Murray, son of Madalyn Murray O'Hair, the atheist leader, says a ''God and country'' rally he has planned for the Easter weekend is intended to divert attention from his mother's convention of athiests at a nearby hotel.

title: Like, Continued
description: Our plea a few weeks ago to rescue the preposition ''like'' from unjust exile brought a pile of letters. Some are interesting because of what they say about the word.

title: Comsat Units
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation has created two new divisions - Communications Services and Space Communications - to position itself for an expected deregulation of satellite ground stations.

title: AMERICAN SHARED HOSPITAL SERVICES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The year-earlier results are pro forma.

title: GRINGOS AWAKE AT LAST
description: The world is always changing in

title: Subpoenas In E.S.M. Case FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.,
description: Investigators

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with the TV Weekend column reversed the identities of the founders of Merchant Ivory Productions. James Ivory was on the left, Ismail Merchant on the right.

title: UTAH MEDICAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW WAYS OF ASSESSING JOBLESS RATE
description: Without any great debate or political recriminations, the Administration and Congress have apparently come to accept 7 percent unemployment as the norm for the economy of the 1980's. In the process, the Government is retreating from a historic goal, dating to the days after World War II, when 4 percent was widely accepted as the objective for unemployment in a growing economy.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MENGEL, TWO WITNESSES ISOLATED IN JAIL
description: TWO passengers in the car Alex J. Mengel was driving when he allegedly shot a Westchester County police officer six weeks ago have been in jail almost as long as the defendant and are being held under the same conditions of ''semi-isolation,'' although they have not been charged with any crime.

title: COLLEEN MEALEY PLANS TO MARRY
description: Colleen Therese Mealey and Harold Casey Geary plan to marry Aug. 17, the bride-to-be's father, Carroll J. Mealey of Albany, has announced.

title: 18-1 SHOT TAKES GOTHAM STAKES
description: Eternal Prince, a front-runner who faded badly going seven furlongs in the Bay Shore Stakes 15 days ago, scored a five-length upset victory over a mile in the $201,400 Gotham Stakes for 3-year-olds yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Photography View column on page 24 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the architect of the Whitney Museum. He was Marcel Breuer.

title: U. N. SECRETARY NOW PLANS VISIT TO IRAN AND IRAQ
description: The Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar, announced today that, in a change of plans, he would visit Iran and Iraq during his Persian Gulf tour to try to help end the war between the two countries.

title: THE REGION ;   A DRY SEASON
description: New York City announced a drought warning last week, a water-conservation step that requires government agencies to cut back by not washing the streets and by using nonpotable water to wash buses and subway cars.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: IN WHAT is said to be the first

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

STAMFORD SHOULD SAVE ITS HISTORIC BUILDINGS
description: ;Ralph C. Loomis is chairman of Stamford's Historic Neighborhood Preservation Committee

title: A BOUQUET OF BRITISH PARKS
description: The slant of late afternoon sun enhanced the spring green of New York's Central Park as I walked home along its winding paths and around the still, dark waters of the reservoir. Although I had walked this route hundreds of times over the years, the experience was enriched by having recently walked in the public park in England that gave Frederick Law Olmsted, Central Park's creator, the idea in the first place.

title: LeRoux Favors Moving Red Sox From Fenway
description: Too few parking spaces and the lure of the wide-open spaces of the suburbs mean that little Fenway Park cannot remain home to the Boston Red Sox for much longer, one of the American League baseball team's three owners has said.

title: PAMELA SHERRID PLANS TO BE MARRIED IN JULY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel D. Sherrid of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Rose Sherrid, to Lanny Schwartz, the son of Posey Silberman of Palm Beach, Fla., and Milton H. L. Schwartz of Philadelphia. The wedding is planned for July.

title: THE DEMOCRATS NEED MODERATED LIBERALISM
description: Louis Nizer is senior member of the law firm of Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim & Ballon, and is an author.

title: GUIDELINES SOUGHT FOR COMMUNITY TV
description: THE commissioners of the State Department of Public Utility Control wanted some help in putting more of the public in public-access cable television.

title: Data Bank;   April 7, 1985

THE LIVELY ARTS;

ADELPHI PUTS BARD ON CENTER STAGE
description: OFFICIALLY, Adelphi University doesn't call ''The Bard Transformed: The Arts and William Shakespeare'' a festival. The three-week outpouring of lectures, exhibits and performances that begins Friday with a talk by Sir Stephen Spender, the noted British poet, is merely tagged a ''celebration,'' leaving the festival designation to Adelphi's academic neighbors: Hofstra University, which did its Shakespeare Festival last month, and the C. W. Post Center, which will hold its American Theater Festival later this month.

title: TENNECO'S BATTLE TO STAY BIG
description: -flung

title: SUSPICIOUS NICARAGUANS SAY 'PEACE INITIATIVE' IS INTENDED ONLY TO HUDGE CONGRESS
description: Strictly as a strategy to obtain renewed aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, President Reagan's Central America ''peace initiative'' last week appeared to be a strong move. Whatever the reaction elsewhere, the White House seemed likely to gain some votes in Congress, where it has met strong resistance to the release of $14 million to help the rebels. Mr. Reagan offered to withhold military aid if Nicaragua's Government agreed to negotiate with the rebels and to hold new elections - conditions a senior Administration official said would be ''utterly impossible'' for Nicaragua to accept.

title: MISS TERNES TO BE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Ternes of Sherborn, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Frances Ternes to Michael G. Zeiss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Zeiss of Red Hook, N.Y., formerly of Indianapolis.

title: DISCREET AMERICAN PRESSURE WOULD HELP PERES
description: The world is in danger of missing an almost unprecedented opportunity to make progress toward peace in the Middle East. Why? The cause is not so much Israeli intrasigence, Arab negativism or even Soviet obstructionism but rather the immobilism of the United States.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: THE ONG ISLANDER 'IS ALIVE AND HEALTHY'

title: THE MYSTERY OF SORREL'S DECLINE
description: -dried tomatoes and raddichio have almost become a staple in the American kitchen, it is strange that sorrel is not more widely known. This green leafy vegetable is much loved by the French, who use it in sauces, as a filling for omelets and for a delicious soup that is thickened with egg yolks and cream.

title: LOUIS MALLE: AN OUTSIDER'S ODYSSEY
description: IN 1980, LOUIS MALLE, THE FILM DIRECTOR, read an article in The New York Times Magazine about the Vietnamese on the Gulf Coast of Texas, and their difficult but eventual acceptance in America. Having arrived in this country from France five years earlier (stung by the reception of ''Lacombe, Lucien''), having obtained his green card and having established permanent residence, having bought an apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side, and having married the American actress Candice Bergen, Malle identified with these refugees, because he, too, was becoming accepted by America. He decided to make a ''homage to America'' - a fictional film about the efforts of one Vietnamese to get into the shrimping business in Texas, set against the real-life opposition of ''Anglo'' fishermen organized by the Ku Klux Klan.

title: THE CRAFT OF PYSANKY
description: TODAY will find decorated eggs tucked into baskets, dyed eggs hidden in outdoor crevices for Easter hunts and chocolate eggs so tantalizing that they may be devoured before breakfast. But the traditional Ukrainian art of decorating eggs, known as pysanky, has a special appeal all its own.

title: 2 HOUSING EMPLOYEES SHOT, 1 FATALLY, AFTER TELLING OF CORRUPTION IN AGENCY
description: A New York City Housing Authority employee was shot to death and another employee was shot and wounded after each had told officials about possible corruption and other irregularities in the agency, according to court and police records.

title: 'LITMUS TESTS' FOR FEDERAL JUDGES
description: Should the political philosophy of judges be considered in making appointments to the Federal bench? Some Senate Democrats have said no and criticized what they see as Republican efforts to insure that only conservative judges are selected. In one case, the White House withdrew a District Court nominee after 13 Republican senators said they would oppose him. He had supported abortion rights and gun-control groups. Then the White House angered Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan by deciding not to appoint his candidate to Federal District Court in Manhattan. The judge was rejected because the Administration thought he was too liberal, Mr. Moynihan said. In a third case, three Republican senators acknowledged that they sent a questionnaire to a nominee for Federal District Court in New Jersey, asking him about his views on various social issues.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Votes in Congress;   Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title:
GARDENING;

HELP FOR SPRING PLANTING FROM PLASTICS
description: THERE are times when one wonders how gardeners managed in the days before plastics. Today almost everyone uses plastic pots, greenhouses are covered with plastic and plants from mail-order nurseries are wrapped in plastic. Plastics are lightweight, usually inexpensive and extremely versatile. Let's look at some of the ways they can be helpful in gardening.

title: APRIL, A TIME OF YEAR THAT'S JUST MAAAA-VELOUS
description: TWO weeks ago my wife gave me a beautiful Japanese toy robot for my birthday. I was 37. I guess that tells you how I feel about the opening of baseball season tomorrow. What is it about baseball? There's not much action. There are no wrestlers in sequined capes screaming, ''I hope the Lopez Brothers are watching this, sitting in front of their velvet painting collection.'' There are no car crashes, guns or weapons. (Except in the bleachers during the '77 Series. That's when fans tormented the Dodgers, who responded with, ''What sign are you?'') There's no sex. Yet when April rolls around, I'm suddenly that kid from Nebraska with the weed sticking in his mouth, playing a make-believe World Series game by himself, in the horse corral.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN LASER TECHNOLOGY ;

MAKING COPPER WIRES OBSOLETE
description: LAST year, in New York City alone, some 35,000 miles of opticalfibers were installed between telephone exchanges and inside office buildings. Fiber optic communication links are already in place between Boston and Washington, San Francisco and Bakersfield, Calif., and numerous other cities. Telecommunications analysts say that by 1990, fiber optic networks will span the North American continent and the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

title: MISS BAKER TO BE BRIDE OF PHYSICIAN
description: The engagement of Jane Eliza Baker to Dr. John Aldo Pasquini, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gino Amerigo Pasquini of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Alan Griffin Baker Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., parents of the future bride. A July wedding is planned.

title: WENDY WHITLOCK TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Mrs. Palmer H. Whitlock of Summit, N.J., has announced that her daughter, Wendy Ellen Whitlock, and Judson Ames Cornish, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Judson Edward Cornish of La Jolla, Calif., are to be married in June.

title: HOW SPUTNIK CHANGED US
description: . . . THE HEAVENS AND THE EARTH; A Political History of the Space Age.

title: NEED CITED FOR SCHOOLING OF ADULTS
description: A NEW report showing that a large number of adults in Connecticut lack a high school diploma has educators concerned the problem will grow worse unless a large-scale effort in adult education is mounted.

title: DESIGNERS TAKE THE TUNER TO NEW LEVELS OF EXCELLENCE
description: It's hard to keep track of more than one thing at a time,

title:
DINING OUT;

SEAFOOD IN A COUNTRY SETTING
description: NEW ZEALAND mussels, scallops from Nantucket, raspberries in December, Malpeque and Golden Mantle oysters - these are only a few of the enhancements that gild the platters at one of the county's new and notable restaurants. Open since last December, A Country Place has taken over the 1875 farmhouse of ungainly charm last occupied by Ardo's and The Vineyard. The red flocked wallpaper of this restaurant's several past lives has been replaced with a backdrop of Hunter green, and more important changes have occurred in the kitchen. While the farmhouse may be a relic, the restaurant's cooking philosophy espouses the best of today's culinary trends - basic ingredients of high quality, light sauces, reasonable invention - brought, for the most part, to their logical conclusion by the chef, Davis Barnes, whom many may remember from Covington in Armonk.

title: Protesters at Columbia Now Face Disciplining
description: Columbia University issued formal warnings yesterday to students barricading a campus building that they would be subject to disciplinary measures ranging from probation to expulsion.

title: VETERINARIAN MAKES HIS MARK IN WINES
description: NEW JERSEY'S reputation for winemaking may be limited, but what other state has a winery in a horse hospital?

title: MISS HERMELEE TO WED DAVID W. RIPS IN JUNE
description: Mrs. Jay Feder of New York and Laurence Hermelee of Key Biscayne, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Noelle Brooke Hermelee to David Wolfe Rips, a son of Barbara Wolfe Rips of Palm Springs, Calif., and Sheldon Isaac Rips of Omaha.

title: ANNE S. RIDER, A LAWYER, TO MARRY A. J. HILL IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Decker Rider of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Sherwood Rider to Anthony John Hill, a son of Mrs. Henry Hill of Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, and the late Mr. Hill.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;

 EASTER PARADE
description: It's not exactly the world-famous Easter Parade, but until something else comes along - and for 25 years nothing has - Garden City's annual Antique Car Parade will pass for the Island's answer to what happens on Fifth Avenue every Easter Sunday. Today, in its 26th edition, the event will follow tradition, starting at 1 P.M. with the parade itself along Franklin Avenue and ending at the Village Hall, 351 Stewart Avenue. At the hall there will be an Easter egg tree, costumed bunnies handing out lollipops, an exhibit of the cars and the awarding of trophies. How Long Islanders dress up for this parade is an extra added attraction. SPARKLING NANCY

title: EAST MEETS WEST
description: IT IS THE KIND OF DISCOVERY THAT could turn even the most generously minded city dweller green with envy. One morning, a tiny classified advertisement in the French newspaper Le Figaro led Kenzo Takada, the Japanese-born fashion designer who is internationally known as Kenzo, to Paris's 16th arrondissement and to the Villa Montmorency. The unusual enclave of turn-of-the-century houses is a quiet, luxuriously planted oasis in the middle of the city.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

ON MARATHONS AND MEDICINE
description: ; Joan M. Quigley is vice president for corporate affairs of St. Francis Hospital in Jersey City.

title: GETTING MERRILL LYNCH MOVING AGAIN
description: THERE is no other firm in the world quite like

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: STILL SHUT OUT OF THE HOME MARKET

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No Government can avoid having policies that profoundly influence family relationships. The only option is whether they will be purposeful, intended policies or whether they will be residual, derivative, concealed ones.'' - Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. (15:1.)

title: CONCERT: EMMYLOU HARRIS
description: During the past week, Emmylou Harris celebrated two anniversaries. On Tuesday, the woman whose pristine, country-pop style epitomizes the new strain of urban gentility that entered the country-music mainstream over the last decade turned 38.

title: THAILAND PLANS A SPECTACULAR CREMATION
description: The body of the widow of Thailand's last absolute monarch is to be cremated here Tuesday in a spectacular ceremony that has taken more than six months to prepare and has cost more than $1 million.

title: DANCING WEST OF THE HUDSON
description: To the question Anna Kisselgoff poses in ''Has the Dance Boom Run Its Course?'' (Mar. 3) I have a few observations. The increase in attendance from 1 million to 58 million is a remarkable statement about the dance profession in America. The effect on the artist (which began with the artist's effect on the public) is a statement with which I strongly agree. The artist's effect on the public is the only way in America for dance to survive; he lives, works and relates to his own environment and through that, builds his support. My question about the article is: Are the 58 million dance attendees all in New York? Miss Kisselgoff discusses dance only from a New York point of view, with reference to an American director in Frankfurt and two Canadian choreographers.

title: Troubled Towers
description: When the construction of Taino Towers was approved by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development in 1971, it was viewed as more than just another rent-subsidized, low-income housing project.

title: SPRINGTIME ALONG THE POTOMAC
description: WASHINGTON

title: THE WORLD ;   U. S. WARNINGS TO LIBYA AND IRAN
description: The United States has threatened to retaliate against Iran if the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's followers in Lebanon carry out a threat to kill an American prisoner. Similarly, Libya will be held ''fully responsible,'' the Administration said, if Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's latest endorsement of terrorism is translated into action.

title: Looking Good And Staying Healthy
description: John Duka's article, ''Looking Good'' (Fashions of The Times, March 3), is an excellent starting point to discuss the psychological effects of fashion and the impact of the continuous images projected by advertisements.

title:
DINING OUT;

SOMETIMES IT'S TIME FOR A CHANGE
description: SIX years ago, Le Chateau in Tenafly was considered one of the best restaurants in New Jersey and was given a three-star rating. It also was one of the very few to serve genuine French food, and that, in a state filled with Italian restaurants, must have been one reason so many accolades were heaped upon it.

title: A SPECIAL CENTER FOR THE AGED
description: -care facility in Windham for the elderly that would include a 110-bed nursing home, a day-care program and residential apartments, would be unique in the state, its planners say.

title: STATE COLLEGES FEAR PLANNED REDUCTIONS IN STUDENT AID
description: -writing campaigns, petition drives and hearings to oppose proposed reductions in Federal student- aid programs.

title: HEADLINERS
description: VIETNAM LETS HIM GO Treasure hunters usually collect bounties, not pay them. But in Thailand last week,

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Comings and Goings
description: Herb Brooks , who was dropped as coach of the Rangers earlier this season, has been asked to return to coaching at the University of Minnesota. ''I've asked him if he would be a candidate, and he's thinking about that and will probably give me an indication sometime next week,'' said

title: A PIONEER IN PROFITING ON FAMOUS NAMES
description: -day Michelangelo someday carve the likeness of the two characters at the foundation of the business called licensing, he would do well to fashion the monument in the image of none other than Mickey Mouse and Howdy Doody.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDTIOR
description: STUDENTS' REACTION TO 'FACADE'S FATE'

title: A REBEL GROUP IN INDIA TURNS FROM ARMS TO TALKS
description: The leader of an insurgency in India's remote northeast says he is willing to negotiate a settlement with the Indian Government because the issue cannot be resolved by military means.

title: DON'T LOOK NOW, BUT THERE'S NEW LIFE ON BROADWAY
description: To say that a dream came true with the back-to-back Broadway openings of Peter Nichols's ''Joe Egg'' and Neil Simon's ''Biloxi Blues'' is not to indulge in idle rhetoric. The dream that came true was an actual dream - the one in which the dreamer runs into some old friends and discovers, to his amazement, that the familiar faces and personalities have suddenly been altered almost beyond recognition.

title: TYING PERSONAL COMPUTERS TOGETHER
description: ONE of the hallmarks of the office is the water cooler, a communications node where people gather to exchange information. The talk is probably as often about nonbusiness matters as it is about any consuming office projects at hand, but regardless of the content, people are communicating. The point is, people talk to each other, computers do not.

title: CAREFREE OR CAREFUL IN JAMAICA?
description: Street protests in Jamaica earlier this year, with roadblocks and bonfires, raised the question of whether the Caribbean island is a safe place for a vacation. The answer, with perhaps the kind of mild qualifications that a New Yorker might offer a friend visiting the city, is ''yes'' - a visitor who exercises reasonable caution is not likely to have trouble.

title: POP: KINGSTON TRIO SINGS
description: Like the legendary Charlie who rode forever on Boston's M.T.A. in one of the Kingston Trio's most popular songs, the trio itself, now in its 28th year, will apparently go on forever. The group is back in town for the first time since 1981 at Fat Tuesday's where, through tonight, it is singing its timeless repertory of ''Tom Dooley,'' ''Scotch and Soda,'' ''Worried Man,'' drinking songs and, of course, ''Charlie and the M.T.A.'' as well as other songs that have become attached to the trio over the decades.

title: RELAY MARKS SET BY RAHWAY TEAM
description: Gary Satterwhite, Rahway's outstanding sprinter, powered his school's sprint relay team to meet records today at the Kearny Relays. More than 4,000 boys and girls from 103 New York and New Jersey high schools took part in the outdoor season's first major track and field meet.

title: FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE DESERVES BETTER
description: Obsessed with demographics and winning the brass ring of the largest possible audience, American television has become suspended in an aspic of formulas. Armed with research statistics purporting to reveal what will attract the average Yuppie, that most treasured of all spending viewers sought by advertisers, television executives set about constructing endless variations of supposedly fail-safe ploys. There are the adventures with the inevitable car chases or the inspirationals with their uplift payoffs. Of course, the results have a failure rate of shameful proportions, but the formula mentality, in tandem with the phenomenon of production by committee, effectively works against originality and almost guarantees a certain level of numbing mediocrity. Which brings me to ''Florence Nightingale,'' the TV movie on NBC this evening at 8. It runs for three hours, a clear sign that this is considered an above-average, ''prestige'' offering.

title: FAITH IN WORDS AND PICTURES
description: IN children's books these past few years, Noah has sailed his ark across an astonishing variety of pages. Perhaps his recent popularity began in 1977, with Peter Spier's wholly successful ''Noah's Ark,'' a nearly wordless Caldecott Medal book and an American Book Award winner.

title: Card Clash
description: Hotter than a major-league pennant race has been the decadelong battle between two major bubble- gum manufacturers for dominance in the multimillion-dollar baseball-card business.

title: IN SHORT
description: FAMOUS OPERATIONS. By Harold Ellis. (Harwal Publishing Company, $12.95.)

title: THE SWARMING SEASON FOR TERMITES
description: SPRING is when underground termites enter their most active phase - fully developed colonies send out their reproductive members to start a new colony close by. These termites sprout wings and fly into the open air for the first and only time in their lives. They swarm until they find a suitable new site that has plenty of food (cellulose) nearby, then shed their wings and head underground to establish a new colony where they will remain for the rest of their lives.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;

BEYOND STILL IMAGERY
description: Some of the most innovative works of art in the current Whitney Museum Biennial exhibition aren't to be found under the spotlights of Frank Lloyd Wright's bright and spacious galleries, but in the dark of the second-floor film and video theater. There, as part of an impressive schedule of independent film programming that comprises one limb of the Biennial, one can partake of two highly entertaining and idiosyncratic slide shows created by Nan Goldin and Perry Hoberman.

title: HONORS FOR AUDUBON
description: Still another new issue. In a back-breaking load for the United States Postal Service, as well as for stamp collectors, comes the 22- cent John J. Audubon stamp which celebrates the 200th anniversary of the artist-naturalist's birth.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

CHILDREN AND GOURMET FOOD DO NOT MIX
description: Annette K. Bonin lives in Westport

title: FOR MOMENT, SERENE QUIET VISITS VATICAN
description: For a moment, all was quiet in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: MERIDEN'S SWEET BUNNIES OFF TO THEIR BIG DAY
description: EVERY day, the greedy German giant on South Vine Street in Meriden drinks hundreds of gallons of molten milk chocolate. With a grinding of gears, it vibrates the chocolate, rotates it, spins it and chills it. Finally, with a sigh of air hoses, out pop 86,000 perfectly proportioned ''Chubby Bunnies.''

title: PROGRAM TO REWARD NEW TEACHING IDEAS IS PROPOSED IN NEW JERSEY
description: Public school teachers who devise new ways to educate students would qualify for up to $15,000 in grants from the state under a proposal by the New Jersey Department of Education.

title: MIGRATORY SONGBIRDS FOUND DECLINING HERE
description: ALPINE A STUDY of forest songbirds at the Greenbrook Sanctuary here shows that 30 species - mostly long-distance migrants such as warblers and vireos - either have declined precipitously or disappeared.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SCRABBLE SCRAP

title: THE GREAT INJUSTICE AND THE GREAT HUMILIATION
description: SHAH OF SHAHS

title: 'Baseball as We Know It'
description: To the Editor:

title: STAE PSYCHIATRIC UNITS URGED TO FOCUS ON COMMUNITY CARE
description: State psychiatric hospitals in New York should stop admitting new patients and begin emphasizing the treatment of the mentally ill in the community, a symposium on mental health was told last week.

title: ON CANCER AND PERSONALITY
description: After reading the article ''Cancer- Stress Book Stirs Controversy,'' I would like to address some vital points because of their overwhelming significance.

title:
GARDENING;

HELP FOR SPRING PLANTING FROM PLASTICS
description: THERE are times when one wonders how gardeners managed in the days before plastics. Today almost everyone uses plastic pots, greenhouses are covered with plastic and plants from mail-order nurseries are wrapped in plastic. Plastics are lightweight, usually inexpensive and extremely versatile. Let's look at some of the ways they can be helpful in gardening.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES ;   Lionel Richie: All Night Long
description: MusicVision 33 minutes. $19.95

title: NEW PLAINTIFFS SUE IN BHOPAL
description: American lawyers who rushed to India after the gas leak disaster at the Union Carbide factory in Bhopal started their own lawsuit last week. They are suing in New Delhi and Bhopal to prevent the Indian Government from leaving them ''out in the cold,'' as one of the attorneys put it, in more than $100 billion of damage claims they have filed on behalf of the victims in Federal courts.

title: DANCE: GRAHAM'S 'RITE OF SPRING'
description: Every so often a dancer makes a career breakthrough before the public's very eyes - and this was the case with Christine Dakin in Martha Graham's ''The Rite of Spring'' Friday night at the State Theater.

title: PAUL BEATS ARROYO TO WIN I. B. F. TITLE
description: In the Kronk Gym, where Jimmy Paul earned the nickname ''the Ringmaster,'' they knew all along. Paul let the rest of the boxing world in on the secret today by knocking down Harry Arroyo three times, in addition to inflicting one standing-8 count, and scored a wide and unanimous decision over the previously undefeated fighter to capture the International Boxing Federation lightweight title.

title:
ANTIQUES;

QUALITY ITEMS IN DEMAND
description: FOR most collectors and connoisseurs of fine early American furnishings, the Connecticut Antiques Show this weekend at the State Armory in Hartford is required viewing. One of the nation's premier events in the field of antiques, it not only concentrates on American objects made before 1840, but is also known for its emphasis on authenticity, quality and rarity.

title: DR. HAWKINS TO MARRY T. A. BYRNES, SURGEON
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Van Duzer Hawkins of Chappaqua, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Catherine Crissey Hawkins, to Dr. Timothy Andrew Byrnes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Byrnes of Madison, Wis. The wedding is planned for June.

title: IN SHORT
description: YIDDISH IN NEW ORLEANS; WE LIVED THERE TOO: In Their Own Words and Pictures - Pioneer Jews and the Westward Movement of America 1630-1930 (Marek/St. Martin's, $24.95)

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in the Westchester Weekly section last Sunday about Indian Point, one reference to the nuclear plant owned by the New York Power Authority included an incorrect numerical designation. The authority owns the Indian Point 3 plant. Indian Point 2 is owned by Con Edison.

title: TAKING BACK A TAX LAW
description: ''Every once in a while we do something that touches off fireworks,'' said Senator David Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat. He was talking about a law passed last year that required people who use their cars on business, or drive their company's vehicles, to keep detailed records for tax purposes.

title: MARY SPENCE IS AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Spence of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., have announced that their daughter Mary Burton Spence is to be married May 25 to Christopher Liston of Boston. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Liston of Atlantic Beach, Fla.

title: SUDANESE PRESIDENT DEPOSED IN HIS ABSENCE
description: -Nimeiry lost power in the Sudan yesterday the way he won it 16 years ago - by a military coup. It was in large measure the price for yielding to the United States and the International Monetary Fund, which had pressed him to impose austerity on a people already burdened by poverty. In Washington last week, he reaped a reward - $67 million in economic assistance that the Reagan Administration had been withholding and another 225,000 tons of grain for some 6 million starving people.

title: SERGEI N. VISHNEVSKY
description: Sergei N. Vishnevsky, a Pravda press commentator on American affairs, has died in Moscow, the Communist Party daily announced last Tuesday. He was 55 years old. A graduate of the Moscow Institute of International Relations, he joined Pravda in 1956 and served as its correspondent in Washington in the 1960's.

description: IT is an axiom, maybe even a

NUMISMATICS;

THREE COMPOSERS
description: Two of the nation's most imaginative medalists, Alex Shagin and Marika Somogyi, prepared intriguing works to honor Johann Sebastian Bach on the 300th anniversary of his birth. Both bronze medals are of unusual shape and design and both are limited editions.

description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL '85: A. L. EAST HAS THE MOST CLOUT
description: RICKEY HENDERSON thinks he plays better against teams in the American League's Eastern Division than he does against the Western Division teams. ''The teams in the East are really competitive,'' says Henderson, who this year has moved from the West (Oakland) to the East (Yankees). ''They have all those great players. I feel I'm in that class and my performance is better.''

title: BATTLE OF THE BELLS
description: RICHARD HOWARD of Port Jefferson didn't pay much attention when he first began hearing the bells. They started on Thanksgiving, and since it was the holiday season he thought they would end when the Christmas season did.

title: BETTE MILLER ENGAGED TO DR. ROBERT GROMIS
description: Announcement has been made by Elaine Miller of Baltimore and Samuel Miller of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Bette Miller to Dr. Robert Marvin Gromis, a son of Irving Gromis of Rego Park, Queens, and the late Anna Gromis. A June wedding is planned.

title: LOVE AND AGE: A TALK WITH GARCIA MARQUEZ
description: GABRIEL GARCIA MARQUEZ is in the midst of a new novel, and a predictable order is imposed on his life. The 1982 Nobel Prize in Literature is behind him and so is the publication of his most recent novel, ''Chronicle of a Death Foretold.'' Still, his fans seek out the 57- year-old author of ''One Hundred Years of Solitude'' - the book that made him a celebrity.

title: Talking Reserve Fund;   Keeping A Co-op Solvent
description: ALTHOUGH the sponsor of a cooperative conversion is required by law to set up a reserve fund, there has been little agreement over the years on the most prudent way to manage and replenish the fund, how much should be kept in it - or, indeed, whether a fund is really necessary.

title: SUDAN'S PRESIDENT IS OUSTED IN COUP BY MILITARY CHIEF
description: The 15-year-old Government of the Sudan was overthrown today in a military coup led by the Defense Minister, according to statements by the new Government.

title: CLELIA LeBOUTILLIER PLANS TO BE MARRIED
description: The engagement of Clelia LeBoutillier to Thomas Elling Zacharias has been announced by Mrs. G. Cheston Carey Jr. of Baltimore and Martin LeBoutillier Jr. of Lyme, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Elling Zacharias of Essex, Conn., formerly of Wilton, Conn.

description: Announcement has been made by Jean S. Meenan of Sarasota, Fla., and Dennis A. Meenan of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Dianne Lynn Meenan, to Richard Todd Croland, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry I. Croland of Haworth, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: REAGAN PLEASED BY REPLIES ON NICARAGUA
description: President Reagan said today that he was encouraged by initial reactions from abroad to his proposal for providing $14 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

description: SPURRED by the actions of corporate managers intent on repulsing ''hostile'' takeover attempts, the New York Stock Exchange is re-examining its 60-year- old ban against listing the securities of companies that issue two classes of common stock that have different voting rights.

title: 'WAR OF THE CITIES' CAUSES CONFUSION BUT LITTLE ALARM IN BAGHDAD
description: Last week, in the 55th month of the war between Iran and Iraq, Iraqi warplanes daily pounded the Iranian capital of Teheran. Baghdad was rocked by its eighth powerful explosion since mid-March.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in the special High Technology section on March 24, with an article about women's careers, misidentified a woman giving a lecture. She was Pamela Surko, national president of the Association for Women in Science.

description: Alice Miller sank a 40-foot birdie putt that broke two feet left to right before dropping in the cup at the 18th hole today, giving her a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the $400,000 Nabisco Dinah Shore Invitation.

title: NEW PLAY PROMISES MORE THAN IT GIVES
description: EDWIN SHERIN'S exit as artistic director of the Hartman Theater in Stamford might have been a grand one if the most anticipated play of the season were up to snuff.

title: Brazil's President-Elect Still in Stable Condition
description: Brazil's President-elect, Tancredo Neves, continued in stable condition today, with new tests revealing a slight increase in a lung inflammation but apparently the elimination of an abdominal infection that prompted emergency surgery Thursday.

title: No Headline
description: In his discharge from the hospital today, William J. Schroeder leaves behind one of the stormiest courses of surgery for heart disease in the annals of medicine.

title: MATH PROBLEMS ADD UP TO NEW ONES
description: PARSIPPANY FEW of the 2,500 teachers, most of them from New Jersey, who met here recently for a conference of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics talked about teacher shortages, low salaries, Federal cutbacks or other hot topics in education today.

title: WHITE HOUSE AND SENATORS STRIKE DEAL ON THE BUDGET
SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Better Late . . .
description: First he had to pay off $404,763 in liens against the team's parent company held by the Internal Revenue Service. Then he had to deliver $500,000 to the United States Football League's contingency fund, which is used to help the Los Angeles Express and Houston Gamblers meet their payrolls.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN LASER TECHNOLOGY ;

FAST PRINTERS FOR THE HOME MARKET
description: MANY people sing the praises of home computers, but few enthuse over the printers that are used with them. The fast printers made shoddy copies. The letter-quality printers moved at a clankety- clank pace. And the laser printers that churned out as many as 120 letter-quality pages a minute carried price tags that hovered around a quarter of a million dollars.

title: SPECIAL PAINTINGS FROM A GOLDEN AGE
description: TEXAS is making a visit to Connecticut by way of the exhibition ''A Golden Age of Painting'' at the Benton Museum at the University of Connecticut at Storrs. The age is that dating from the early 1500's to the late 1600's and the painting is Dutch, Flemish and German. It comes from the Sarah Campbell Blaffer Foundation of Houston, except for a few works drawn from the Benton's collection.

title: THE DEFICIT'S CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER
description: Vermonters who read Governor Snelling's article on balancing the budget wish our former Governor had taken his own advice.

title: PECKED TO DEATH BY EDUCATIONAL REFORM
description: CHALLENGE TO AMERICAN SCHOOLS; The Case for Standards and Values.

title: THEFT ALMOST STOPS CHINA TRIP
description: NEWARK WHEN thieves broke into the Newark Boys Chorus School next to Symphony Hall on Broad Street, not only did they take $12,000 worth of computers, typewriters and cameras, but they also almost made off with the chorus's hopes for a trip to China.

title: Manufacturers Advertise Recall of Some Tampons By United Press International
description: Manufacturers of tampons have begun a voluntary recall of products containing a fiber linked to toxic shock syndrome.

title: STEPPING OUT FOR SPRING
description: FOR MANY WOMEN, EASTER is the beginning of spring. Fashionwise, this means not only new body-enhancing finery, but fresh footwear. And this season, when it comes to shoes, the daytime look is clean, clear and often classical; by night, in contrast, the shod profile is more decorative and dramatic, usually accented by sexy high heels.

title: SARAH BARISH TO WED OSCAR STRAUS 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Barish of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Mimi Barish, to Oscar S. Straus 3d, the son of Mr. Straus 2d and Marion Miller Straus, both of New York.

title: ARTISTS FIND EGGS MAKE A FINE CANVAS
description: IF Peter Cotton Tail came hopping down the Boston Post Road, he would undoubtedly stop at the A. I. Friedman store in Port Chester to visit the Easter eggs amassed there. On view through next Sunday is a display of unusual egg art, the result of the Second Annual Artists' Egg Invitational.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

CHEFS OF THE FUTURE
description: -agers, eager to learn a new profession. Place in two-year food-preparation course taught by expert chefs. Add desire to get practice not only in making food but also in serving it to the public. Yield: one gourmet restaurant, open one day a week, during the school year only.

title: Ben Novack Sr.,78 Is Dead; Founder of Fontainebleau
description: Ben Novack Sr., founder of the Fontainebleau Hotel, a popular vacation place for the rich and famous in the 1950's, died of heart and lung failure Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 78 years old.

title: THE NATION ;   FIRE DEPARTMENT RACIAL QUOTAS RULED ILLEGAL
description: In early March, the Government, which of late has been on the move against affirmative active programs all round the country, went to court to challenge the promotion policies of the District of Columbia Fire Department. Last week, Federal District Judge Charles R. Richey ruled that the department had illegally used quotas to foster the advancement of blacks.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: ANOTHER VIEW OF ADOPTED CHILDREN

title: Ford Recalls 23,000 Autos
description: The Ford Motor Company recalled more than 23,000 automobiles Thursday, most because of a possible electronic problem that could cause parked cars to catch fire, the company said. The company recalled 19,628 1985 Continental and Mark VII cars for possible replacement of the electronic control modules of their air suspension systems. It also recalled 3,683 1985 Thunderbirds and Cougars that might require replacement of the brake master cylinders.

title: RUSSO'S RACE TAKES A CUE FROM CUOMO
description: THE State Senate majority leader, John F. Russo of Toms River, says he has never found a goal that was out of his reach if he decided to work for it, and so the 51-year-old legislator is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor in a year when the party faces an uphill fight to unseat Governor Kean.

title: U. N. PROJECT
description: The first two structures built by the United Nations Development Corporation, the United Nations Plaza Hotel and its ''sister,'' a 40-story office and residential building at First Avenue and 44th Street, were glass-clad skyscrapers.

title: Marchers Support Tulane Basketball
description: More than 100 people marched today to the campus residence of the Tulane University president, Eamon Kelly, to show their displeasure with his decision to drop men's basketball because of a team scandal.

title: Sandra Gardner
description: ''WE HAVE not done what we should about lead poisoning,'' said

title: IN SHORT
description: PINSTRIPED SUMMERS: Memories of Yankee Seasons Past.;

title: CITY RACES TO MEET DEADLINE FOR 2 SEWAGE PLANTS
description: Each work day, 1,200 workers scuttle about the mammoth concrete and steel platform that juts out into the Hudson River from the West Side.

title: TWO-CLASS COMMON COULD BE HARMFUL
description: FOR more than half a century, shares of common stock on the New York Stock Exchange have carried equal weight in proxy voting - one share, one vote. Now, however, this important safeguard of shareholder democracy is threatened. Earlier this year, a study group appointed by John J. Phelan Jr., the exchange's chairman, broke with tradition in recommending that listed companies, with shareholder approval, be permitted to create two classes of common stock with disproportionate voting rights.

title: DALKON CLAIMS BREAK RECORDS
description: Even by the dizzying standards of product liability law, no one had ever seen anything quite like it. And yet there were some who worried that the $615 million the A. H. Robins Company said last week it had set aside to settle lawsuits prompted by the effects of its Dalkon Shield would not be enough to close a most unhappy chapter in the pharmaceutical concern's history.

title: A ROMAN RETREAT FOR BODY AND SOUL
description: Just two blocks from Bernini's Four Rivers Fountain in the Piazza Navona one can shake the tour buses and traffic jams of 20th-century Rome and escape to the quiet of an Italian monastery. Ai Monasteri (literally ''to the monastery''), at 72 Corso Rinascimento, is a store specializing in liquors, honeys and natural restoratives made in convents and monasteries across Italy.

title: EVENTS TO MARK LIBRARY WEEK
description: ALTHOUGH National Library Week, April 14 to 20, will be celebrated nationwide, many libraries in the county will be going their own way when it comes to a theme. ''Many librarians felt that the slogan of the American Library Association, 'A Nation of Readers,' did not say enough,'' said Amy Small, a public-information specialist for the Westchester Library System.

title: THE LATEST FIGHT IS ON FIFTH AVENUE
description: New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission appeared two decades ago out of the cloud of dust created by the demolition of the arches and columns and scale of old New York. In the 20 years since then, this tiny municipal agency has thrown its protective arm around 20,000 of the city's 850,000 buildings, often against the will of the owners.

title: CHEERS FOR THE PHILHARMONIC'S INVENTIVE NEW SEASON
description: The New York Philharmonic is not famous for pulling off programming coups, but it has a couple to boast of now. For one thing, the orchestra's subscription schedule for next season will pay tribute to Aaron Copland on the occasion of his 85th birthday by offering 16 of his works - not one of them named ''Appalachian Spring.'' That's an administrative achievement of sorts. It is a genuine tribute to any artist's productivity that a major retrospective can be mounted without resort to his most famous work. In lieu of that overexposed masterpiece, we will have a chance to hear such rarities as ''Inaugural Fanfare,'' ''Ceremonial Fanfare,'' Cortege from the ballet ''Grogh,'' ''Prairie Journal,'' ''Letter from Home,'' ''John Henry,'' the world premiere of the orchestral version of ''Proclamation'' and the revised version of Symphony No. 1 (without organ). Less esoteric pieces of Coplandiana will be on hand, too, of course: ''Billy the Kid'' Suite, ''Fanfare for the Common Man,'' Symphony No. 3, ''Dance Symphony,'' ''Short Symphony,'' Clarinet Concerto, ''Inscape'' and ''Tender Land'' Suite.

title: AT RUTGERS, THREE ARTS IN ONE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK

title: State to Add Acreage To Its Forest Preserve
description: New York State has agreed to buy 2,676 acres of wooded land in the Adirondack Mountains from Paul Smith's College for $1.3 million to add to the State Forest Preserve.

title: RELIEF FOR THE BLUE JAYS AND POWER FOR THE TWINS
description: The following American League preview was prepared and writte by Murray Chass. The order of teams reflects the predicted order of finish, with the Yankees picked for fifth in the East.

title: AIRLINE BATTLES EAST HAMPTON
description: FRUSTRATED by the pace of negotiations to obtain the right to operate year round at East Hampton Airport, Long Island Airlines has filed a $10 million lawsuit against the Town of East Hampton, the airport manager and a rival carrier, East Hampton Aire.

description: HARTFORD WITH three months gone in the current five-month session of the General Assembly, most of those New Year's resolutions vowing bipartisan harmony have been long forgotten.

title: Cable TV
description: When it comes to this week's new movies, someone familiar and someone all but unknown are providing the delights. The familiar name is Federico Fellini, the Italian maestro, who will be represented by last year's widely praised ''And the Ship Sails On,'' Sunday at 8:30 A.M. and 11:30 P.M. on Cinemax, 8 P.M. and 1 A.M. on Bravo.

description: They were forced to march 43 years ago this week 70 miles to a Japanese prison camp in the Philippines. Those who survived ended up slave laborers for Japanese corporations in coal mines and elsewhere.

title: LESS PAY FOR NEW WORKERS
description: In two major settlements last weekend, unions accepted a wage arrangement that has long been anathema to organized labor. The teamsters' union and the Independent Union of Flight Attendants agreed to lower pay scales for newly hired workers.

title: Montreal Is First In Adams Division
description: Mike McPhee and Alfie Turcotte scored less than three minutes apart late in the second period tonight to rally the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-4 tie with Boston Bruins and enable the Canadiens to clinch first place in the Adams Division.

description: WOMANGUIDES; Readings Toward a Feminist Theology.

description: FAIR LAWN THE undiscriminating imitation of past styles often produces a feckless art. Imitators might grasp the formalities of what they see in past styles, but they rarely grasp the impulses that generated them.

title:
CAMERA;

SUMMER WORKSHOPS
description: For photographers, a worthwhile alternative to the typical spring and summer vacation might be a workshop. Designed to teach in a photographic atmosphere, workshops offer a concentrated program that promotes interaction between students and faculty. An adventurous photographer can learn anything from improving one's darkroom techniques to a new way of seeing.

description: If there were a prize for the saddest

title: Museum Moves
description: The welcome offer of New York's Governor Cuomo to create a more appropriate site in Battery Park City for a museum commemorating the destruction of Europe's Jews promises to leave the nearby United States Custom House as it has been for 14 years - vacant but available for imaginative use. What better spot than the tip of Manhattan for the Museum of the American Indian?

STAR CORAL
description: Size: In colonies to five inches wide. Polyps to one-half inch high.

description: 'Determinate sentencing can bring uniformity and predictability to the sentencing process.

description: MORE than 50 years ago, three young women left Ireland to become Catholic missionaries, but not in Africa or Asia. Sister

title: CHAMBER ORCHESTRA TO MAKE ITS DEBUT
description: LAURENCE GILGORE is proof that conductors no longer have to be middle-aged to be accomplished. The 26-year- old is conductor of the Connecticut Grand Opera Company, based in Stamford, and also of the newly formed Stamford Chamber Orchestra.

title: BRIDGING THE CORPORATE GENERATION GAP
description: IT is a scenario oft-repeated in the halls of corporate America. The 57-year-old chief operating officer of a huge industrial and military products company, recognizing that costs were too high and technology was lagging, brought some 300 managers from all over the country in for a conference. ''The only purpose of this company,'' he told them, ''is to make a top return on the capital invested in it. We're not around to build the best products, that's just what we do to get return on equity. That's what you should be thinking about.''

title: MUSIC: THE PRISM CHAMBER ORCHESTRA
description: Wednesday's Prism Chamber Orchestra concert at Symphony Space looked for a pervasive Romantic theme in three very different pieces. Each may have had its separate attractions, but together they occupied their common ground uneasily.

description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. K. Evan Gray of Princeton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Anne Wendland Gray to Jeffrey Thomas Scuteri, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Joseph Scuteri of Boxford, Mass.

title: Clint Eastwood, Seriously
description: It certainly brightened my Sunday when I opened The New York Times and found my favorite actor, Clint Eastwood, staring at me from your magazine cover (''Clint Eastwood, Seriously,'' by John Vinocur, Feb. 24). The article was insightful and interesting.

title: POP: LIBERACE, A PIANO, ROCKETTES AND ROLLS
Dam in Canada Could Endanger Shad
description: WILL a power project in Canada's Bay of Fundy affect the future of East Coast fishing as far south as Florida? As farfetched as that question at first may seem, both Canadian and American scientists say the concern is warranted, for though it would produce virtually pollution-free energy, the environmental costs of harnessing the Fundy tides of more than 50 feet may be too high.

title: LOOKING BETTER CAN BE BENEFICIAL
description: SANDRA PIERCE, an image consultant from Westport, says she emphasizes ''dignity, not vanity'' when she advises her clients on how they can look better.

title: PICKING A MANAGER
