title: PLACES
description: To the Editor:

title: GUITAR: EDUARDO FERNANDEZ
description: In most hands, the classical guitar is a lovely instrument of intense difficulty and narrow expressive range. Eduardo Fernandez's recital at the 92d Street Y Thursday night, however, reversed the impression - offering a startling breadth of interpretive possibilities and making us forget how hard the guitar really is to play.

title: AZZEDINE ALAIA: NEW SOPHISTICATION
description: All the excitement in Paris did not happen at the recent formal showings in the mammoth tents in the Tuileries. Some designers had small shows in their ateliers where you could see clothes that did not resemble everyone else's. Azzedine Ala"ia was one of them. He managed to fill his small, all-gray showroom in the Marais twice a day during the fall collections with people who were willing to go off the beaten track. They seemed to think it was worth the trip.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: More than one observer of the concert scene has begun to fear that modern musical life, or modern musical education, tends to iron the individuality out of young players - to leave them technically proficient but artistically uncertain. The myriad sociological and musical factors that might be advanced in explanation need not be raised here, but this week's debutants (violinists and pianists all) did little to refute the notion.

title: HIGH RISING
description: The transformation of Hoboken, N.J., from a gritty port town into a residential haven for the upwardly mobile has been taken a step further.

title:
ART;

2 WAYS OF LOOKING AT THE SUBWAYS
description: NEW YORK'S subways are given their day in the sun in ''The Subway Show'' at the Herbert H. Lehman College Art Gallery in the Bronx through April 21.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

'NOW WE ONLY HAVE EACH OTHER'
description: I HAVE one sibling, a brother,

title: RELIGION MAKES AN IMPACT AS A THEME IN TODAY'S ART
description: Ask Thomas Lanigan Schmidt why he makes religious tableaux and ceremonial objects with tinfoil, Baggies and Magic Marker, and he'll tell you he wants to ''transfigure the garbage; give a sense of desperate worthlessness making itself not worthless.'' Adrian Kellard builds his shrines and furniture out of ''conviction and a lot of hope, and the feeling that religion has to deal with day to day life.'' And Hunt Slonem, who is Jewish, paints pictures of saints ''because I feel guided to.'' The three, whose work is currently seen in the exhibition ''Precious: An American Cottage Industry of the Eighties,'' at New York University's Grey Art Gallery, are part of a small but interesting group of - mostly younger - artists who feel that religious art is possible, even viable, in our relentlessly secular age.

title: SUSAN FIELD IS AFFIANCED
description: Announcement has been made by Alma Redding Field of Princeton, N.J., and William S. Field of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Louise Field, to Jude Kimball Hammerle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth B. Hammerle of Quincy, Mass.

title: THE TECHNOLOGY IS IRRESISTIBLE, BUT THE STRATEGIC RATIONALE COULD TAKE A LOT OF HARD SELLING
description: Anxiety has seized Western European governments as they try to come to grips with the Reagan Administration's bold vision of space-based anti-ballistic missile defenses. But this single emotion simultaneously propels politicians, defense planners and industrialists in opposite directions - to spurn the Strategic Defense Initiative and to embrace it.

title:
GARDENING;

HELP FOR SPRING PLANTING FROM PLASTICS
description: THERE are times when one wonders how gardeners managed in the days before plastics. Today almost everyone uses plastic pots, greenhouses are covered with plastic and plants from mail-order nurseries are wrapped in plastic. Plastics are lightweight, usually inexpensive and extremely versatile. Let's look at some of the ways they can be helpful in gardening.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ;   OF BATTING AVERAGES AND BOTTOM LINES
description: With one new Commissioner, 10 new managers and many new overtones, the baseball season opens tomorrow in Cincinnati, Detroit, Boston, Baltimore and Kansas City, and in eight other cities one day later. This is year No. 110 in the National League and No. 85 in the American League. Once again, as John McGraw used to say, ''the main idea is to win.'' But a variation on the legendary manager's theme is also being heard these days. The main idea, the owners of the 26 big league teams are saying, is to survive.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Women Honored
description: The Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., which now includes 143 men and four teams, will increase by seven members in ceremonies scheduled for July 1, and for three of them it will mark a first. Those three inductees will be women:

title: WHEN MONEY MATTERS
description: You wouldn't guess it as they walk on stage together beaming, but that soloist up there and the pianist who plays the accompaniments may be nourishing hatred for one another in their bosoms. Not often, thank goodness - but if they do it is probably over some misunderstanding about money. But now, there is an organization formed for the purpose (among other purposes) of helping to avoid such misunderstandings: the American Association of Accompanists and Coaches.

description: An August wedding is planned by Marisa Lynn Hanania and Mitchell Warren Spitz, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. N. David Hanania of White Plains, have announced.

title: AIRLINES FACE DEADLINE ON THE USE OF TIME SLOTS
description: THE lottery system to allocate space at the Westchester County Airport among the airlines has resulted, in its initial phase, in the airlines choosing enough ''slots'' of time to expand their flights by 73 percent and to more than quadruple the number of daily passengers, according to figures made public by the county.

title: A GOLDEN TOUCH FOR BEST SELLERS
description: IN AN EPHEMERAL BUSINESS OF WILD UPS and downs, in which the reasons why a book does or does not sell in satisfying quantities are often impossible to decipher (was it the writing, was it the jacket, was it the author identification), Phyllis Grann has proved herself to be something of a best-seller machine, good for a remarkable five or six hits every year.

title: COMMON CLAY AS LIFE CREATOR
description: Metaphor seemed to become reality last week in a report by a group of scientists that supports the theory that life on earth began in common clay.

title: SECRET GARDENS OPEN TO ALL
description: One can make the case that pleasure gardens are an urban phenomenon, inspired by urban taste and the need to escape, even briefly, from the clamor, grime and disorder of city life. Serious country people have enough nature to bother with - without concerning themselves with nature on a contrived and intimate scale.

title: BID TO LURE BASEBALL STEPPED UP
description: EAST RUTHERFORD LIKE the robin's return or the appearance of the first crocus, baseball fans have long considered the closing of training camps in Florida and Arizona the official harbinger of spring.

description: Otis Chandler, the chairman and editor in chief of the Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles, has been chosen to receive the Rochester Institute of Technology's Isaiah Thomas Award for newspaper management. The award is to be presented Tuesday.

title: LYNN A. CAMPBELL TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. M. John Campbell of Spring, Tex., formerly of Ramsey, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Ann Campbell, to Todd Kelley Anderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald E. Anderson of Centerville, Mass., and Boston. The wedding is planned for June.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ATLANTA
description: The season begins slowly, in March, when the cherry trees and daffodils start to bloom, quick flashes of white and pink and yellow against the brown winter landscape. By the middle of April, the whole city is afire with the incandescent colors of spring: the rich pink of plum trees and azalea, the lacy white blooms of dogwood, the yellow of forsythia. If spring is Atlanta's best season, April is clearly the city's most favored month, a time not only of brilliant colors but of average daytime temperatures reaching into the low 70's.

title: LARGESSE, ERUDITION, WIT AND SWEETNESS
description: GRACE SCHULMAN'S ''Hemispheres'' is full of beautiful, clear writing, and it has that first requisite of poetry - the world comes alive in the work. It opens with a blessing, a poem that leaps into the flames:

title: LIBEL SUIT: TOOL AGAINST ACTIVISM
description: THEIR case is not as well known as the libel suits brought by Generals William Westmoreland and Ariel Sharon, but the 16 members of a Brookhaven Town civic group who are being sued by a developer in a multimillion-dollar libel action say their situation is just as stressful.

title: THE SWEET ALLURE OF OTHER PEOPLE'S JUNK
description: GARAGE sales. Yard sales. Tag sales. With spring upon us, they will be sprouting in everybody's neighborhood faster than crab grass. Now, I can grasp the motives of people who unload their worldly goods like this - the house floors are sagging under the decades of junk; you've sold the house and you don't want to truck all the odds and ends of your life to the next house - but why must people buy what other people don't want anymore?

CURING BLINDNESS AND HEART ATTACKS

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: THE PROLIFERATION OF FLY-DRIVE OFFERS
description: The good news in auto rentals this year is that the market is so competitive in many places that bargains abound. The not-so-good news is that unless you understand what the advertisements really mean, you may end up with much less than the best deal around.

title: Sports of The Times;   The Other Game Plan
description: LARRON JACKSON remembers

title: TRIAL RECALLS NIGHT OF DEATH THAT ROCKED NORTHPORT
description: FROM Trinity Episcopal Church down to the harborfront gazebo, Main Street in the Village of Northport bustles with young people on a Saturday night.

title: IN SHORT
description: THE TURQUOISE DRAGON. By David Wallace. (Sierra Club, $12.95.)

title: ACTIVITY AND HOPE RISING AT CONEY I.
description: Sporting a silk top hat, Dick Zigun strode onto the Coney Island boardwalk yesterday and invited passers- by to step right up to Sideshows by the Seashore, a new theater that blends art and amusement with a healthy dose of nostalgia.

title: ELAINE S. KELLOGG TO MARRY JUNE 1
description: A June 1 wedding is planned by Elaine Spaulding Kellogg and Peter Brooke Pope, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Roy Kellogg of Stowe, Vt., have announced.

title: PHIL COLLINS: POP MUSIC'S ANSWER TO ALFRED HITCHCOCK
description: Phil Collins, whose third solo album, ''No Jacket Required'' (Atlantic 81240-1) recently rose to number one on the charts in the United States and in England, is quietly revolutionizing and expanding the role of the drums in pop record making. The 34-year-old singer, drummer, keyboardist and leader of the rock group Genesis uses the drums not merely to supply a backbeat or to provide an atmospheric dance pulse but as a crucial psychological ingredient of popular music. At a time when pop is dominated by impersonal, computerized rhythms, Mr. Collins's ingenious mixtures of synthesized and nonsynthesized drums reveal a refreshingly individual point of view.

title: 'CAMILA': ARGENTINA'S FORBIDDEN STORY
description: -year-old Argentine film maker, ''Camila'' is her third directorial venture - so it was a particular pleasure when the film became an Oscar nominee for Best Foreign Film. But Miss Bemberg has less official, though equally telling, evidence that her historical romance has seized the hearts of her countrymen and women. ''Since the film's release last May,'' says the black-bobbed, improbably youthful Miss Bemberg, in her melodic Oxbridge accent, ''every day in Buenos Aires, five or six infant girls are named Camila.''

title: TREK OF THE FOSSILS
description: Like some impressive prehistoric migration, thousands of fossils are on their way from New Jersey to New Haven. Princeton University announced last week that it was giving Yale University one of the world's finest collections of vertebrate fossils, some 24,000 fossils of mammals that lived after the extinction of the dinosaur about 60 million years ago.

title: VIEW FROM A BALLOON
description: Officials of the Hudson River Museum readily concede that their plans for a gala spring celebration are really a lot of hot air.

title: A SPLIT AMONG FRENCH SOCIALISTS
description: President Fran,cois Mitterrand's long-awaited decision to change France's voting system to proportional representation drew the expected fire last week from his conservative opponents. Less expected was the turmoil in the ruling Socialist Party and the resignation of Agriculture Minister Michel Rocard, one of the country's most popular political figures.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of erroneous information supplied by UPI/ Bettmann Newsphotos, an incorrect photograph and caption accompanied the review of ''Geneen'' March 10. The photograph was of Francis J. Dunleavy, a former president of the ITT Corporation.

title: DEVALUATION OVERTAKES THE OSCAR FOR BEST FOREIGN FILM
description: Attention all of you Oscar losers out there who might still be sore: There's every reason to believe that most of you should count your blessings. It's not easy, I realize, having gotten rigged out in all your late-evening finery at some ungodly, afternoon hour, having braved rude crowds more interested in Prince than in you, then sitting through that still-endless show, awaiting the big moment, only to be forced to put on a game smile and applaud heartily when some lesser talent's name is announced.

title: Foe of Qaddafi Killed By a Libyan in Bonn
description: An exiled opponent of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, was shot and killed today by a Libyan gunman on a crowded Bonn shopping street.

title: Photography
description: From the start, fashion photographers have looked to art to put the icing on their couture confections. Baron de Meyer favored gauzy Luminism, Edward Steichen and George Hoyningen-Huene the Greek sculptural ideal, Cecil Beaton the excesses of Rococco.

title: LIFE IN SHARDS AND FRAGMENTS
description: MUSEUM PIECES

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about crime among Cuban refugees misidentified Sergio Pereira. He is now the City Manager of Miami.

title: Greece Moves to Limit Powers of President
description: The Greek Parliament approved in principle today constitutional amendments that would trim the powers of the President. The action brings the nation closer to early legislative elections that are expected to be held in June.

title: LIKE LOS ANGELES, BRADLEY STANDS TALL ;   THE MAYOR IS FAVORED TO WIN FOURTH TERM THIS WEEK
description: On clear days, the slender new towers of downtown can be seen from miles away, gleaming in the sun. Despite traffic congestion, among other complaints, the cityscape that has arisen in the last decade has become the pride of Los Angeles. It is no less the pride of Tom Bradley, who counts as a premier achievement of his 12 years as Mayor the bringing together of business and labor interests to make the new skyline a reality.

title:
PROSPECTS ;

An Odd Twist for Trade
description: The gospel according to Introductory Economics holds that when the dollar drops in foreign currency markets - as it has over the past month - America's trade balance should improve.

title: A CLASSIC CONFUSION
description: I HAVE OFTEN heard one educated cook or another mistakenly refer to the French dessert called les oeufs a la neige, or snow eggs, as ^ile flottante, or floating island. It recently occurred to me that, in the interests of a better world, we might print recipes for both desserts with a full explanation of each. It just so happens that oeufs a la neige is conceivably my favorite of all French desserts.

description: To the Editor:

TAG SALES BLOOM IN THE SPRING, TRA LA
description: ; Sharon White Taylor lives in East Hampton

title: U.S. WORRIES OVER SUDAN'S STABILITY
description: United States officials voiced concern today over the stability of the Sudan in the aftermath of the overthrow of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry. The coup occurred less than 12 hours after he had left here to fly home to try and put an end to unrest.

title: Double-Bassist in Recital
description: Ludwig Streicher, the former principal double-bassist of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra and the Vienna State Opera Orchestra and a noted soloist on the instrument, will appear in recital Monday at 8 P.M. in the Horace Mann Auditorium of Columbia University, 120th Street and Broadway.

title: NINE SERIES ENDING THEIR SEASONS
description: ALREADY it is time to report the seasonal finales for a number of musical series. Let's begin at the State University of New York campus at Purchase, where a remarkable series of preview concerts has allowed Westchester residents to enjoy the celebrated Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in precisely the same programs that New York City audiences pay a lot more to hear. The last event, this Thursday at 8 P.M., should be one of the most appealing: it lists Handel's Harp Concerto in B flat, the ''Sacred and Profane Dances'' of Debussy and the Brahms F minor Piano Quintet(253-5900).

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: IMAGES FAR FROM ETHIOPIA'S FAMINE
description: An official sat in his office at the Government's Relief and Rehabilitation Commission recently, answering questions about why, in this time of severe drought and famine, Ethiopia is still selling livestock and other food products to customers abroad.

title: THE BIG DISH-SATELLITE ANTENNA IS BECOMING A BEST SELLER
description: The million-mark is about to be passed. Right now, roughly 900,000 viewers no longer tune to television stations, nor do they link up with cable. They draw their video from outer space, aiming big-dish antennas directly at the satellites that carry the network and cable programs and scatter their signals all over the continental United States. With those antennas, they pluck the programs right out of the sky, just like the network affiliates and cable services do. The big dish is becoming so popular that sales have tripled within a year and are still going up, especially with the return of warm weather easing the task of installation.

title: NOTATION PROVIDES THE KEY TO MANY BALLETIC TREASURES
description: Certain dance scholars appear eager to offer this piece of advice: If you know a dance, write it down - now! Preferably in some accepted form of notation. But if you've never studied notation, don't worry. Put the dance down on paper in any way you think will be comprehensible. That dance may one day be considered a treasure.

title: 61 Food Outlets Cited by City
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 61 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Moss Attempting A Quiet Comeback
description: Twenty-two years ago, Stirling Moss was acknowledged to be the best active racing driver. At the age of 32 he had been driving in automobile races - and most often winning them - for more than half his life. In the five years between the retirement of Juan Manuel Fangio in 1957 and the flowering of the great Scottish driver Jim Clark in 1962, Moss was the man to beat in any race he entered.

title: GENERALS PLAN TO CONTROL BALL
description: The Generals need a big game from Herschel Walker and Maurice Carthon today when they take on the Houston Gamblers at Giants Stadium. Their intent will be to keep the ball from Jim Kelly, the Houston quarterback who directs pro football's most prolific offense.

title: CONTEMPORARY FRESCOES ROOTED IN LATE GOTHIC ART
description: The artistic climate may finally be right for the English sculptor Raymond Mason to get his due in New York. Mason makes painted reliefs, some of them monumental in size and free- standing, none of them like any other sculpture around. His subjects are landscapes and crowds. The aim is to weave sculptural tapestries, to construct blocks of time in which we encounter not only people and events, but just about everything that gives those people and events meaning.

title: Citizen Mouse
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: FELD'S 'INTERMEZZO NO.1,' SET TO BRAHMS
description: Back in 1969, Eliot Feld's work suggested that he had ambivalent feelings about Romanticism. That was when he choreographed ''Intermezzo,'' a work to Brahms piano music that showed three couples dancing dreamily together. Yet amidst their Romantic yearnings came some gently mocking jokes, as if Mr. Feld sought to indicate that, however impetuously his characters might behave, as choreographer he did not always wear his heart on his sleeve.

title: FUTURE EVENTS Spring Salutes
description: -13 - Since 1941, the Blue Hill

title: CUBS KEPT THEIR TALENT, AND PADRES ADDED SOME
description: The following National League preview was prepared and written by Joseph Durso. The order of teams reflects the predicted order of finish, with the Mets picked for second in the East.

title: HOSPITAL-BED SURPLUS GROWS
description: The number of patients in New York City hospitals has declined so rapidly in the past two years that nearly one-fourth of the hospitals' 36,479 beds are empty, State Health Department officials reported last week. The oversupply is nearly seven times that reported two years ago.

title: CAROL BAUGH TO MARRY
description: Announcement has been made by Murr Sinclair Baugh of Wellington, Fla., and Samuel Baugh 2d of Jamestown, R.I., of the engagement of their daughter Carol Archer Baugh to Geoffrey Townley Thomas, the son of the late Eileen Dugan Seaton of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and the late Geoffrey Veeder Thomas of New York. Miss Baugh is a vice president of Edwin Bird Wilson Inc., a New York advertising agency, and Mr. Thomas is director of sales and marketing for Alitta, a New York sportswear manufacturer. They plan a fall wedding.

title:
ANTIQUES;

NEWARK ACADEMY: 'QUALITY' SHOW
description: LIVINGSTON THE annual Northern New Jersey Antiques Show and Sale at Newark Academy, one of the major events of the busy spring season, will open Friday with 30 dealers from as far away as Maine and Missouri.

title: HEADLINERS
description: A $4.99 SCANDAL When

title: TWO PENN STATE PLAYERS ARE KILLED IN CAR CRASH
description: Two Penn State football players were killed Friday in a fiery automobile crash five miles east of here, the State Police said today. The victims were Gene Lyons, 21 years old, of Westfield, N.J., a junior who was a reserve defensive end, and William James, 18, of McKeesport, Pa., a freshman.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: AT HEAVEN'S GATE, by Robert Penn Warren. (New Directions, $9.95.) Writing here 42 years ago, Maxwell Geismar described ''At Heaven's Gate'' as ''a novel of the new industrial South by a talented young writer.'' It deals with the business and family of a Southern speculator, Bogan Murdock. Sue Murdock, his daughter, is the heroine. Brought up amid her father's friends - politicians, manipulators and manipulatees - she gravitates toward rebels - labor organizers, bohemians and intellectuals. Geismar praised Mr. Warren's ''enviable command of the medium.''

title: N. B. A. ;   PACERS EDGE 76ERS TO END 12-GAME SLIDE
description: Vern Fleming sank two free throws with 8 seconds left to help the Indiana Pacers beat the Philadelphia 76ers, 121-117, tonight and snap a 12-game losing streak.

title: WHY THE RICH RULE THE TV ROOST
description: Esther Shapiro, an effusive, dark- haired, lively-eyed woman who produces ''Dynasty'' with her husband Richard Shapiro and therefore has a firm grip on the tiger tail of the television industry, recently had brunch at the Helmsley Palace Hotel's Trianon Room restaurant. All around her in the opulent space, leaning on the peppermint-pink tablecloths and looking up at the wall paintings of riders and horses, were diners dressed in the expensive sheen of the mid- 1980's: ladies in gloves and white broad- brimmed hats, men in ascots and double- breasted blue blazers. The room looked so much like a set from ''Dynasty'' that it was easy to imagine she was talking from within an episode of the series.

WESTCHESTER OPINION;

FAITH MOVES TO THE HEAD OF THE TABLE

title: Italy to Sell China Arms And Train Its Troops
description: Italy will sell arms to China and will train Chinese troops and scientific personnel under an agreement reached here today, the Italian Defense Minister, Giovanni Spadolini, said.

title: MORE QUESTIONS ABOUT THE CONRAIL SALE
description: AFTER a fast start, the Reagan Administration's proposed sale of the Consolidated Rail Corporation is not moving along at full throttle these days.

description: To the Editor:

description: AFRO-AMERICAN LITERATURE IN THE TWENTIETH CENTURY: The Achievement of Intimacy.;

title: DR. KIM HUTCHINS TO WED JAMES MILLAR
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard James Hutchins Jr., of Mystic, Conn., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Dr. Kim Lesley Hutchins, to James Jude Millar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Millar Jr., of Ocean City, N.J.

title: BUDDHISM FUELS A BUSINESS BOOM
description: The office of Dr. Snoh Unakul, the head of Thailand's Economic and Social Development Board, an alumnus of Columbia University and one of Southeast Asia's leading national planners, is dominated not by computer terminals or shelves of statistics, but by a Buddhist shrine.

title: NEW CHALLENGE TO WESTWAY TRIED IN CONGRESS
description: Opponents of Westway have taken their fight to Congress, where they hope to convince a key House committee chairman from New Jersey that the Federal Government should not pay for an essential part of the project.

description: The Great Recession

title: REP. JIM COOPER OF TENNESSEE IS WED TO MARTHA BRYAN HAYS, ORNITHOLOGIST Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, and Martha Bryan Hays, an ornithologist, were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Gulfport, Miss. The Rev. Dr. Richard L. Summers performed the ceremony.
description: Mrs. Cooper, a daughter of Mrs. Charles Daniel Taylor Jr. of Pass Christian, Miss., and the late Dr. Arthur Vernon Hays, is a research assistant to the vice president for science at the World Wildlife Fund in Washington. A graduate of Sweet Briar College, she received a master's degree in zoology from Mississippi State University.

title: PAMELA FRANZHEIM TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Barbara Franzheim of New York and Kenneth Franzheim 2d of Houston of the engagement of their daughter Pamela Courtney Franzheim to Whitney Tower Jr., a son of Mr. Tower of New York and Mrs. John Train of Bedford, N.Y. A June 21 wedding is planned.

title: CHARTING 30 YEARS OF DANCE WITH PAUL TAYLOR
description: Paul Taylor is now in his early 50's and his once imposing dancer's body is comfortably rumpled - he stopped dancing in 1974 - but his artistic output has, if anything, sharpened in the past decade. Choreographically there seems to be no end to the stream of his invention. Season after season new works pour forth. This prodigious output of imaginative, musical, risky dances has made him one of our most distinguished and acclaimed modern dance choreographers.

title: KEAN IS OFF AND RUNNING AHEAD
description: When Governor Kean of New Jersey announced last week that he would run for reelection, he warned his supporters about the pitfalls of overconfidence. ''No candidate is unbeatable,'' Mr. Kean said, reminding them of the gubernatorial campaign four years ago when he was the underdog facing Representative James J. Florio.

title: Broadcast TV
description: When it so chooses, Channel 5 can do right by vintage films, though the station tends to bury classics at 2 A.M. and even later, trailing a lot of tired series re-runs. But not this Saturday.

title: DENVILLE V. MT. LAUREL: TOWN FEARS CHAOS
description: DENVILLE

title: THE SCENE: WARTIME BUDAPEST. THE HERO: WALLENBERG
description: The story of how Raoul Wallenberg, scion of Sweden's most influential banking family, saved nearly 100,000 Budapest Jews from the Nazi murder machine in 1944 and was then arrested and imprisoned by the Russians occupying the Hungarian capital has been told in thousands of newspaper and magazine articles over the world, as well as in chapters of history books and in 10 complete books in four languages.

title: A MINIMALIST EXPANDS HIS SCALE
description: America is famous for ignoring its own. In particular, American composers have often found little resonance at home but resounding applause abroad. One might think, though, that in our enlightened time such reverse chauvinism would be a thing of the past. No such luck, as Morton Feldman can testify.

title: MEDICARE REVIEWS BEING FELT
description: UNDER Medicare's tough new program to save money and monitor the care of its beneficiaries, medical reviewers are visiting hospitals around the state to check the records of Medicare patients hospitalized in the last six months.

title:
PROSPECTS ;

Mutual Funds Roar Back
description: Mutual fund sales - not counting money market mutual funds - last year topped $45 billion, up from $15 billion only two years ago. And sales for 1985 are barreling along at an annual $60 billion to $70 billion clip, says Claude G. Thomas, executive vice president of the giant Massachusetts Financial Services Company in Boston.

title: The Great Budget Compromise
description: President Reagan's big new compromise with the Senate Republican leadership on budget cuts is a good start, but only that. White House trumpeting aside, the compromise is really no more than Round Two in Washington's most important task this year: reducing the deficit.

title: METHOD IN THE MADNESS?
description: BOSTON Can a great power build a successful policy on a base of paranoia? That is the question raised by President Reagan's policy toward Nicaragua.

title: LAUREL AXINN TO MARRY MARK FRIED IN SUMMER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Axinn of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laurel Jill Axinn to Mark Ennis Fried, a son of Lila O. Fried of Great Neck and Sidney Fried of Glen Cove, L.I.

title: POPULATION'S RISE IN THE NORTHEAST REVERSES A TREND
description: Despite earlier forecasts to the contrary, the population decline that plagued the Northeast in the 1970's appears to have reversed itself since 1980.

title: National Security's New Insiders
description: In his article, ''National Security's New Insiders'' (March 3), Michael Wright gives a good account of the strategic studies ''community.'' But he places its origin too late when he labels it a postwar phenomenon.

title: KATHRYN R. WEBB TO WED IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Webb of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Karyn Rogers Webb to Robert Anthony Gough Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gough of Quincy, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: CHABRIER'S OPERAS MAKE A CASE FOR POPULARITY
description: This may be the year of Bach, Handel and Scarlatti, but 1984, at least in France, was l'annee Chabrier. Not content to wait another seven years for the 150th anniversary of Emmanuel Chabrier's birth, the French saluted the composer with presentations of his two major stage works last year, and showed good sense in recording both. The composer who today is best known for his short, orchestral ''Espana'' has been acclaimed by fellow composers, critics and musical connoisseurs as one of the greatest of French composers, though widespread popular acclaim eluded him. Yet, without Chabrier, it is doubtful Ravel, Debussy, Poulenc, or Satie, among others, would have composed the way they did.

title: MARKING THE COURSE OF COUNTY'S HISTORY
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: THE SOFTWARE APPROACH TO TOUGH PROPERTY PROBLEMS
description: FOR Joseph H. Sullivan, a management consultant based in Menlo Park, Calif., the problem went like this: What would be the after-tax cost of acquiring for investment a condominium in Northern California?

title: WHAT'S NEW IN LASER TECHNOLOGY
description: Lasers have blasted their way into the public mind, mainly as tools to zap imagnary enemies (''Star Wars'', the movies) or real ones (''Star Wars'', President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative).

title: The Origins of Game Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: TWO COMPOSERS PERFORM AT THE KITCHEN
description: The Kitchen presented a long, diffuse double bill Wednesday night, centered on two performer- compos ers, Guy Klucevsek and David Lopa to.

title: JUST AN OLD-FASHIONED SAFARI
description: Only a little more than a decade ago, people who went to Kenya still journeyed into the bush Hemingway style, with tents, bearers and a ''white hunter,'' mostly to shoot the game rather than look at it.

title: NEW NEEDS PUT DEMANDS ON MANAGERS
description: NEW YORKERS complain about their managing agents almost as much as they do about the small size of their apartments and how much they had to pay to get them. From the million-dollar co-ops of Park Avenue to the converted factory buildings of the Brooklyn waterfront, the subject of management evokes continual low-level grumbling, like static.

title: MARY OLIVER TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. George H. Oliver of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Peyton Comegys Oliver to Paul William McKechnie, a son of Margaret McKechnie of Woodstock Valley, Conn., and George S. McKechnie of Newtown, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: PAMELA BLUM PLANS TO BE BRIDE
description: Max Blum and Dr. Florence Blum of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Pamela Brenda Blum, a manager with Price Waterhouse in Los Angeles, to Robert Blattner 2d, president of RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video in Burbank, Calif. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Blattner of Stamford.

title: Trade Talks Fail: Yankees Demote 2
description: The other day in the Yankee clubhouse, Yogi Berra sat behind a desk and grinned widely as soon as the questions began. He spit once into a cup of tobacco juice, then shrugged and threw up his arms. If there was a trade in the works, Berra knew nothing about it.

title: Body of Rights Activist Is Found in Guatemala
description: The body of the secretary of the Support Group for Families of the Detained and Disappeared in Guatemala was found Friday in her car in a ravine nine miles south of Guatemala City, according to a spokesman for the group. The bodies of her brother and young son were also in the car.

title: PURCELL ACTS TO BOLSTER POLICE FORCE
description: FOR several years, Nassau County has been blocked from appointing new police officers because of a dispute with the Federal Government over hiring practices. But now County Executive Francis T. Purcell says up to 200 new officers will be hired with or without Federal approval because, police officials say, the shortage of officers is threatening police services.

title:
GARDENING;

HELP FOR SPRING PLANTING FROM PLASTICS
description: THERE are times when one wonders how gardeners managed in the days before plastics. Today almost everyone uses plastic pots, greenhouses are covered with plastic and plants from mail-order nurseries are wrapped in plastic. Plastics are lightweight, usually inexpensive and extremely versatile. Let's look at some of the ways they can be helpful in gardening.

title: 16 Die in Indian Bus Crash
description: Sixteen people, including 6 women and 3 children, were killed and 39 were injured when a bus fell into a ravine near Marble Rocks in Madhya Pradesh in central India today, the Press Trust of India news agency quoted the police as reporting.

title: NEWTON LAMSON WED TO PATRICIA A. QUINN
description: Patricia Anne Quinn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Quinn of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Newton W. Lamson, a son of Bertha G. Lamson of Cumberland Foreside, Me., and the late Stewart T. Lamson. The ceremony was performed in the home of the bridegroom's mother by John A. Mitchell, a justice of the peace and brother-in-law of the bridegroom.

title: State to Use Boat To Promote Coasts
description: There is nothing unusual about finding a yacht with the home port ''New York'' painted on its stern almost anywhere in the world. New Yorkers are generally curious, and their boats often end up in remote places. But now there are plans to acknowledge New York State and its coastal resources by building, naming and sailing a world-class ocean racer in its behalf.

title: FUR SALES BOOM-AND SO DO IMPORTS

title: A Swimmer of Great Promise
description: To her great disappointment, Julianne Brossman did not make the United States Olympic team last year. She has never broken a world nor American record. She has never won a United States senior swimming title.

title: Gene Bernard Davis, Abstract Artist, Dies
description: Gene Bernard Davis, an abstract painter prominent among the Washington Color School, whose color-stripe canvases are displayed in leading museums, corporate headquarters and fashionable department stores, died yesterday after suffering a heart attack at home in Washington. He was 64 years old.

title: DENTISTS AND F. T. C. CLASH ON ADS By States News Service
description: WASHINGTON THE New Jersey Board of Dentistry will meet Wednesday to consider criticism by the Federal Trade Commission of rules the board has proposed to control advertising by dentists.

title: ENTER ON MADISON
description: Since it was built 54 years ago, the only entrance to 275 Madison Avenue has been around the corner on East 40th Street. But for Bobwin Associates, the new owners of the 43-story, Art Deco office building, this side door was not good enough.

title: ELIZABETH KEEHN TO WED JOHN LEWIS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Silas Keehn of Winnetka, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elisabeth Keehn to John J. Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Lewis of Wilmette, Ill.

description: STUDENT'S REACTION TO 'FACADE'S FATE'

title: Soul-Searching For Graham Greene
description: Surely the tragic and the ludicrous cohabit as shamelessly in life as they do in any modern novel, (''The Soul- Searching Continues for Graham Greene,'' by John Vinocur, March 3). Not three paragraphs into John Vinocur's melancholy piece on Graham Greene is a terse anecdote to illustrate surviving oneself: ''His 90-year-old uncle, on his way to a meeting at the Admiralty to discuss whether to introduce reindeer in Scotland, fell under a train in a wartime London tube station.

title: TALKING TO GHOSTS
description: FOR 40-ODD YEARS, I have conversed with ghosts. Perhaps you think that, as a longtime writer of fantasy (over 20 novels and more than 80 short stories in that genre), I believe in ghosts in the usual, supernatural sense. I do not. These phantoms of mine are ''No things of gauzy mist, or rattling bones,/ Or clanking chains, or marrow-freezing moans. . . .'' They dwell only in my mind; they are memories of my parents.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF CHARITABLE IMPULSES
description: PEOPLE who give generously to their alma mater or the United Way are, of course, generous to themselves as well at tax time. The deductions for charitable donations can cut a substantial chunk from the amount a donor would otherwise owe Uncle Sam. But the opportunity to be charitable and at the same time do well by your tax bill may change: Treasury proposals to simplify the tax system could sharply reduce the tax benefits of charitable gifts. For now, however, both gifts and trusts offer attractive opportunities for making the most of your charitable impulses.

title: Phils Trade DeJesus to Cards
description: The Philadelphia Phillies traded Ivan DeJesus, a shortstop, and Bill Campbell, a veteran relief pitcher, to the St. Louis Cardinals for Dave Rucker, a pitcher.

title: IN SHORT
description: THE GOOD FATHER. By Peter Prince. (Carroll & Graf, $13.95.)

title: High Divers Set Marks At Hong Kong Event
description: Randy Dickison of Minneapolis and Lucy Wardle of San Jose, Calif., set world records for men's and women's high dives today, but Dickison fractured his leg in the process.

title: POP: U. T. F. O. RAPS AT RITZ
description: ''Roxanne, Roxanne'' by U.T.F.O. has been the top rap single for most of 1985. Fans got to hear it twice more when U.T.F.O. - three rappers and a disk jockey - performed Thursday at the Ritz, where the audience doubled as extras for a video shooting.

NEW JERSEY OPINION;

DEBUNKING DIABETES MYTHS
description: PETER A. LODEWICK ;Alan P. Braun, M.D., is chairman of the Governors Advisory Comission on Diabetes; Peter A. Lodewick, M.D., is a member of the panel and president-elect of the New Jersey affiliate of the American Diabetes Association.

title: JOBS GROW SCARCE ON THE EASTERN CAPE
description: Five years ago, South Africa's intelligence service, then called the Bureau of State Security, handed a report to the Government saying that the eastern Cape region was headed for unrest. The reasons for the assessment lay in years of official neglect that had left the region's black townships among the poorest in the country and the gap between black and white living standards among the widest.

title: AN OUTPOURING OF PERIOD TOYS
description: An stounding number of toy boats are docked, circuses parked and soldiers billeted in New York these days in three memorable exhibitions of vintage toys. The abundance of quality examples of 19th- and 20th-century toys - lead soldiers, cast-iron banks, tin boats, trucks, cars and planes - represents a rare feast for those curious about studying and collecting such artifacts. These shows presenting period toys make it abundantly clear what collectors of these playthings have always known - that toys are among our greatest cultural assets, documenting the importance of childhood fantasy in every age.

title: CONTRIBUTION CASE NEARS DAY IN COURT
description: A CASE that could provide a rare glimpse of the inner workings of one of the best political fund-raising operations in the country - the Nassau County Republican organization - is coming close to resolution after several years of legal maneuvering.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

WITHOUT A JOB, WITHOUT DIGNITY
description: THE feeling of losing a job is often compared with the death of a loved one, divorce or a fire in a home. It is an enormous feeling of personal abandonment that must be experienced to be fully comprehended.

WESTCHESTER OPINION;

SISTERS: OH, HOW THEY ENDURED LITTLE BROTHER
description: in the 1920's - I believed sisters were a dark penance for little brothers who had strayed from God's will. Sisters, and I had three older ones, were strange and cruel beings dedicated to insuring that a brother's time on the planet would be as heartwarming as a long stay on Devil's Island.

title: THE LESSONS OF NOT WINNING THE BIG ONE
description: LAST week, on the playgrounds where fantasy begins, boys and girls across the country recreated Villanova's stunning upset over Georgetown. All, of course, were playing for the Wildcats, because childhood dreams always end in victory, often with stunning upsets.

title: A LESSON FOR FUTURE TAXPAYERS
description: SANDWICHED between classes in English and American history, Barry Wages is learning how to fill out his income tax return. This year his father helped him with the forms, but next year he plans to do it himself.

title: RATING A HOME ON ITS ENERGY EFFICIENCY
description: WHEN it comes to saving energy at home, the device most often used by New Jerseyans is the sweater. Since the first oil-price shocks of 1973, homeowners have installed elaborate solar heating systems, superinsulated their homes and even built windmills to generate their own electricity. But, according to the State Department of Energy, the most common residential energy-conservation measure by far has been simply lowering the thermostat.

title: PCjr., R.I.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW WORLDS FOR NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC
description: Although it has roamed the earth's every extremity, the National Geographic Society is pushing into new territory: cable. Starting this evening, ''National Geographic Explorer'' will bring three hours of nature and documentary programming to the Nickelodeon service, every Sunday at 5 P.M.

title: DONORS RESPONDING TO A GROWING NEED FOR BLOOD
description: Jim Otton gives in memory of his sister. Joan Murtagh gives because she knows there is a shortage. Cathy Mahan gives to help a critically ill 15- year-old boy she has never met.

title: PAPANDREOU:THE POLITICS OF ANTI-AMERICANISM
description: IN MARCH 8, Greek President Constantine Caramanlis went to bed believing that the following morning he would be endorsed by the ruling Socialist Party as its candidate for re-election. Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou had just sent an emissary to tell the 78-year-old Mr. Caramanlis, the country's grand old man, that when the central committee of the Socialist Party met the next day, it would unanimously endorse the Prime Minister's nomination of the conservative President.

title:
PROSPECTS ;

House-Hunting Season?
description: The single-digit long-term mortgage rate may have gone the way of the dodo, but the American dream of owning a home is alive and well. And this spring and summer may be a good time to buy a house, according to mortgage experts.

title: HARPSICHORD: COMPARONE
description: The best thing on the harpsichordist Elaine Comparone's program Thursday night at Merkin Hall was a new Quintet for harpsichord and strings in homage to Bach's birthday by Robert Baksa, commissioned by Miss Comparone's Harpsichord Unlimited organization.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 7, 1985 International

title: DUARTE, STRONGER, HAS THE NEXT MOVE
description: Politicians and foreign diplomats here say President Jose Napoleon Duarte's unexpected electoral triumph over his rightist opponents is almost certain to give him the power he needs to alter the economic and political structure of El Salvador.

title: CAN U.S. GOODS SUCCEED IN JAPAN?
description: ECO INC THE last time that Akie Nishioka bought American, she got a Mark Cross pen, Avon cosmetics, Calvin Klein jeans, oranges, grapefruits and cherries. ''When I buy things,'' she said, ''I look for design, function and price. I don't care where they're made.''

description: April 7, 1985Fiction*1

title: DEDICATED TO THE RELIGION OF ACTING
description: Although the question of ''Who are the best acting teachers around?'' is usually good for a lengthy debate, there seems to be little doubt that the three most influential American acting teachers of this century have been Lee Strasberg, Stella Adler and Sanford Meisner. All were members of that revolutionary stage company of the 1930's, the Group Theater, and all went on to make their most important contribution to the modern theater in their role as teachers. But while a great deal has been written about Strasberg and Miss Adler, little is known about Sanford Meisner outside of the confines of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theater, where he has been training actors for 45 years.

title: ANNE W. DUPONT MARRIES JOHN MCKEE JR. ON L. I.
description: Anne Warner Dupont, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre R. Dupont of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to John Lewis McKee Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McKee of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: NEW TEAMS OF LAWYERS START RETRYING VON BULOW TOMORROW
description: Rhode Island's second effort to convict Claus von B"ulow of trying to murder his multimillionaire wife, Martha, begins tomorrow with a new judge, new prosecutors, a new defense team and a new location, the County Superior Court in downtown Providence.

title: BODY OF L.I. MAN, KIDNAP VICTIM, IS FOUND IN A TRUNK IN MANHATTAN
description: The body of a Long Island real-estate broker who had been kidnapped March 20 was found stuffed in a trunk in a Harlem apartment last night, the police said.

title: ISRAEL REBUKED IN PRISONER SHIFT
description: There has been nothing unusual in the attacks by Arab and other states against Israel's handling of the violence against its occupation forces in south Lebanon, which are now withdrawing. But last week, the United States, which had refrained from criticism since the withdrawal began, joined the chorus.

title: ISLANDERS GAIN TIE ON GOAL BY TONELLI
description: The Islanders ended the regular season tonight with a 5-5 tie against the Devils for their worst record since 1974, when they failed to gain the playoffs.

title: BIG MERGER PLANS GET MIXED REACTION
description: Merger fever hit a number of companies, but a few of the deals are less than assured. Hospital Corporation of America and American Hospital Supply want to merge, creating a company worth as much as $6.6 billion . . . Sir James Goldsmith offered more than $1 billion for Crown Zellerbach, but only if it eliminates a poison pill. An unenthusiastic Crown board will meet Wednesday. Sir James may be interested more in a quick profit than in acquiring the company: He earned $50 million in a rebuffed takeover at St. Regis.

title: THERE IS ROOM FOR DWARF FRUIT TREES IN A CONTAINER GARDEN
description: Containers provide a garden for those with limited space, either a small yard or apartment terrace or balcony. Beyond the usual flowers and vegetables, fruit trees are possible. A wide variety of dwarf cultivars adapt to this type of growing.

title: SINPLE FARE WITH A VIEW
description: IT is not without a touch of wonderment that

title: IN SHORT
description: DUNN'S CONUNDRUM. By Stan Lee. (Harper & Row, $15.95.)

title: SCHROEDER MOVES OUT OF HOSPITAL
description: William J. Schroeder today became the first person to live outside a hospital with a permanent artificial heart.

title: Cheapening the Series
description: AS baseball awaits the charm and tradition of its season openers, the World Series has already been cheapened. In a $9 million sellout to television, the two league championship series have been extended, at least for this October and probably forever, to four-of-seven games after 16 years of three-of-five playoffs. Once the World Series was at baseball's center stage, a solo act. But in equating the length, and in a sense the importance, of phe league playoffs with the World Series, baseball threatens to turn the World Series into an afterthought.

title: FEWER OFFICES FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: If the Reagan Administration has its way, the Social Security Administration will be substantially cut back in the next few years.

title: LEGAL LOFTS
description: The conversion of commercial space into residential lofts has spread to Little Italy and Chinatown in the last few years as such spaces in SoHo have grown scarce and more expensive.

title: DIANE PATTON MICHELFELDER TO BE WED TO ROBERT WOLF
description: Diane Patton Michelfelder, an assistant professor of philosophy at California Polytechnic State University in San Luis Obispo, and Robert Stanley Wolf, an associate professor of mathematics at the same school, plan to be married in June. Mr. and Mrs. Walter Michelfelder of Stratford, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Bert Wolf of Hollis Hills, Queens, and the late Lee Wolf.

title: SAVNG THE LAND
description: THE cry ''Save the Village Green'' is rising

title: A BIT OF ICING ON THE BUDGET FOR THE PEOPLE BACK HOME
description: From the Johnson City Senior Center ($100,000) on page 4 to the rail improvement program of the Chautauqua County Industrial Development Agency ($200,000) on page 212, the state budget adopted Friday contained millions of dollars in what are known among legislators as member items.

title: MOYNIHAN REASSESSING PROBLEMS OF FAMILIES
description: Twenty years after he wrote a highly controversial report on black families, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan plans to renew the call he made in 1965 for a ''national family policy'' to preserve the traditional family structure.

title: U. S. FACTORY SHIPS SEEN AS FISHING THREAT
description: HUGE factory vessels equipped to catch and freeze fish at sea have been scouring the waters off Montauk Point, casting dark shadows over smaller trawlers closer to port. Unlike the foreign factory fleets that have been crossing the Atlantic Ocean since the mid- 1950's, these new catcher-processors carry the American flag and can harvest in waters barred to foreigners.

Buy Me Some Peanuts.
description: Colorado skiers will be happy if predicted blizzards blow in, but most Americans elsewhere are in the throes of spring fever - and many are thinking baseball. Concessionaires, in turn, are thinking hot dogs, beer, peanuts, pretzels, nachos, sodas, popcorn, ice cream, candy, coffee and souvenirs.

title: MCENROE, CONNORS IN CHICAGO FINAL
description: John McEnroe, using excellent passing shots and a dozen lobs, moved into the final of the $315,000 Volvo Tennis-Chicago tournament with a 6-4, 6-1 triumph over Scott Davis of Balmoor, Fla., today.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

THE HARBINGERS OF ANOTHER SPRING
description: Jane S. Gitlin lives in Roslyn Heights A long time ago, when the weather on the Island behaved as it was supposed to, I used to anticipate the arrival of spring by all the traditional signs. Purple and white crocuses pushing through damp soil. Fragile yellow buds of forsythia on thick bushes. And, of course, the classic harbinger of spring - the robin red breast.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing last week of Long Island hospitals that offer acute-care psychiatric units inadvertently omitted St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, with 20 beds, and Syosset Community Hospital, with 20 beds.

title: TULANE'S FINAL SHOT
description: With some of its basketball players heading for a different kind of court to face point-shaving charges and reports that National Collegiate Athletic Association recruiting rules were violated, the president of Tulane University, Eamon M. Kelly, decided last week that enough was enough. Dr. Kelly said he would ask the school's board of administrators to drop men's basketball permanently and was certain it would agree.

title: PROMENADES IN EUROPE'S PARKS
description: God Almighty first planted a garden, Francis Bacon reminded us over 400 years ago. But since that first Garden of Eden, mankind has been busily planting and shaping its own parks and gardens to its own image. And today Europe's plentiful public parks - and the way people use them - offer the perspicacious visitor a fascinating glimpse into a country's traditions and life style, just as a promenade past the picnickers, joggers and well turned out strollers of Central Park sums up the mixture of chic and informality that is New York.

title: CLAY THAT QUALIFIES AS SCULPTURE
description: OCEANVILLE

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

WHAT WE SHARE WITH OUR PETS
description: TWELVE years ago, when I graduated from veterinary school, we were told that ''pet ownership is a luxury.'' Today, having cared for many of these luxuries and empathized with their owners, I am convinced pet ownership is a necessity.

title: SHERIDAN RIDGWAY TO WED GUSTAF PETERSON JR. IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lynn S. Ridgway of Armonk, N.Y., and Torrington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheridan Elizabeth Ridgway, to Gustaf Henry Peterson Jr., the son of Jane Peterson of Armonk and Mr. Peterson of Key Biscayne, Fla., and Armonk. The wedding is planned for June 15.

title: THE STORY UP TO 1550
description: THE SPOILS OF TIME; A World History From the Dawn of Civilization Through the Early Renaissance.

title: WHAT GOES WITH WHAT
description: rives at my desk regularly. Or it may be a telephone call. It goes like this: ''We are having eight for dinner on the 25th. Very important people. We are going to do a crown roast of lamb (or a duck, pheasant, whatever). What wines should we serve?'' It is always tempting to reply: ''White with the fish and red with the meat.'' But what people really want to hear is something like this: ''The only possible wine to drink with a crown roast of lamb is 1976 Chateau Brane-Cantenac, opened 30 minutes before dinner and served at exactly 66 degrees Fahrenheit. In a Bordeaux glass, of course.''

title: DANCE: GARRARD TROUPE IN MOVEMENT STUDIES
description: Mimi Garrard is known for her ''prop'' pieces - dances in which objects or film are as important as other elements - and for her work with computerized lighting. But a performance by the Mimi Garrard Dance Theater on Thursday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater suggested that Miss Garrard has grown increasingly interested in the quality of sheer movement.

title: 2 STUDENTS SLAIN ON FLORIDA VISIT
description: Two young women found beaten to death and dumped in a Florida river have been identified as roommates at the State University College at Buffalo who disappeared last week on a spring break, hitchhiking trip to Fort Lauderdale, authorities in Florida said yesterday.

description: WEST TRENTON THE Delaware River Basin Commission is debating a plan to raise $140 million for new reservoir storage by charging cities, utilities, industries and other users for water drawn from the Delaware or its tributaries.

title: Rain Helps Quell Fires In 8 Southern States By The Associated Press
description: Heavy rain has helped suppress fires that blackened 80,000 acres of brush and woodland across eight Southeastern states, but gusty winds fanned the embers yesterday and firefighters stood by for new outbreaks.

title: Music
description: Gilbert Becaud will make his first appearance in New York in 15 years on Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall. Although he has not performed in the United States for 15 years, Mr. Becaud has frequently been in this country, but only to compose and to record.

description: RHYTHM-A-NING, Jazz Tradition and Innovation in the '80s.

title: The Deficit's Clear And Present Danger
description: Richard Snelling's article, ''The Deficit's Clear and Present Danger'' (March 3), was excellent. Governor Snelling says that one out of every five dollars the Federal Government spends these days is a dollar it doesn't have.

title: MEREDITH MALLOY AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. T. Downs Mallory of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Meredith Brooks Mallory, to William Whitney George, the son of Mrs. F. Whitney Clark of Bedford, N.Y., and Watch Hill, R.I., and William D. George 3d of Sewickley, Pa., and Beaumaris, Ontario. The wedding is planned for September.

title: A $14.5 BILLION PACKAGE WAS ADOPTED BY COMMITTEE LAST WEEK
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee decided last week that an aid program for the Upper Huallaga Valley in Peru could go forward only after the Agency for International Development determined that the valley had reduced the cultivation of coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals , at St. Petersburg, Fla. The next meeting of the teams will be one that counts, Tuesday afternoon in Shea Stadium. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.)

title: THE REGION ;   ONE AGREEMENT REACHED, ONE MAY BE IMPOSED
description: The budget was late but it was never better, Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders said last week as they gathered in Albany to announce that they had settled on a spending plan of $39 billion. Having agreed on the biggest tax cut in state history and on more money to clean up the environment and help New York City, nearly everyone had praise for everyone else.

title: Federal Agents Raid Tax Protesters' Buildings
description: Agents of the Internal Revenue Service, seeking information on tax protesters, raided a warehouse, homes and offices in seven cities and seized records, documents and gold bullion, a spokesman for the service said today.

title: Topics ;   Reconciliations
description: Koch and Garlic

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: The main article in The Times Magazine today analyzes the political style of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece. On Wednesday, after the magazine went to press, his Socialist Government announced that it would call for early elections, with voting expected in June.

title: Anderson's Running Leads Bandits, 31-17 TAMPA, Fla., April 6 (UPI) - Gary Anderson padded his league-leading rushing and scoring totals tonight with three touchdowns, sparking the Tampa Bay Bandits to a 31-17 triumph over the Jacksonville Bulls.
description: Anderson, who rushed for 54 yards on 17 carries, broke open a close game by catching two touchdown passes from John Reaves within a 2-minute span of the fourth period.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: What aspirin is to a headache a new drug called tissue plasminogen activator may prove to be to a heart attack. If that seems farfetched, consider the findings of a Government- sponsored study reported in last week's New England Journal of Medicine.

title: THE WORLD ;   THE ARMY BACKS DUARTE'S ELECTIONS WIN IN SALVADOR
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte's party won the Salvadoran national elections last week, but the armed forces cast the deciding vote. Defeated rightist leaders demanded a rerun, accusing the army of partisan behavior and Duarte supporters of stuffing ballot boxes. The military, which worked closely with the rightists in past elections, saw things Mr. Duarte's way this time.

title: 10 Afghans Killed in Iran
description: The Afghan radio said today that 10 Afghan refugees had been killed and nearly 100 injured in clashes with Iranian security forces in Meshed. The radio, monitored here, said the clashes occurred when Iran sought to enlist the Afghans in the army to fight against Iraq.

title: U.S. TO ORDER A NEW TACTIC IN BATTLE WITH CAR THIEVES
description: The Federal Government, having just about conceded that automobile thieves will be able to defeat almost any antitheft gadget devised by manufacturers, is completing regulations to make it easier to recover cars after they are stolen.

title: Easter's Tapestry
description: Who now remembers the Quartodecimans? They cared passionately about the date of Easter, believing the rite should be held not on a Sunday, as today, but on Passover, celebrated yesterday. The Emperor Constantine convened the Council of Nicaea to resolve that issue in A.D. 325, but despite the Church's search for unity, diversity has flourished.

title: DANCE: RONDO GROUP RETROSPECTIVE
description: The Rondo Dance Theater has assembled a fine repertory. Under Elizabeth Rockwell's direction, this company from Bedford, N.Y., seeks to revive representative examples of modern dance from many periods. On Tuesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, it offered works by five major choreographers.

title: U. S. PLAN TO CURB DAMAGE CLAIMS AIMS TO AVERT VACCINE SHORTAGES
description: The Reagan Administration will soon propose major changes in the system of compensation for children harmed by vaccines, according to Administration officials.

title: PROFESSIONAL OPINION
description: Those who watch ''The Cosby Show'' may soon find a familiar name in the credits: Dr.

title: SPASSKY, THE RACONTEUR, DELIGHTS CHESS DEVOTEES
description: Boris Spassky, the chess champion of the world until he ran afoul of Bobby Fischer in 1972, spoke the other day about the mysterious termination of the recent KarpovKasparov championship match in Moscow, about life after Fischer and even about how to stop smoking.

title: STAGE: LIFE WITHOUT HEARING
description: THEATER THREE in Port Jefferson has been making a concerted effort to raise the level of its work so it can present consistently professional- quality productions. This has been a conscientious process that has seemed at times painfully slow. Still, each succeeding season has been better than the one before.

title: ELIZABETH ADAIR WILL BE MARRIED TO LANCE DAVIS
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arja P. Adair of Bradenton, Fla., and Montrose, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Robinson Adair to Lance Barrow Davis of Kansas City, Mo., a son of True Davis of Washington and the late Virgina Motter Davis.

title: RECONCILIATIONS Sending a Message Two current television commercials show that someone wants to send a positive message to America's subconscious about a subject nowadays fraught with negativity - race relations.
description: A commercial for Michelob Light beer shows two young men, one black and one white, in business suits, striding together down a city street. In the next scene, these Yuppie business colleagues are shown in sweatsuits playing basketball one on one.

title: The Button Conspiracy
description: THREE MONTHS AGO my buttons started falling off.

title: Inhalers for Asthma Recalled
description: A drug company is voluntarily recalling two prescription inhalers used by asthmatics because the products may not contain enough medication to provide relief, the Food and Drug Administration announced today. The F.D.A. said the products were Metaprel Metered Dose Inhaler and Metaprel Asthma Mist, distributed by Dorsey Laboratories of Lincoln, Neb.

title: VIRGINIA LANGNER TO WED PHYSICIAN
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jay Langner of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Langner, to Dr. Neal E. Luppescu, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Luppescu of Roslyn, L.I., and Atlantis, Fla.

title: COMPOSTING MAY ONE DAY REPLACE OCEAN DUMPING
description: For more than 60 years barges and boats have hauled loads of sludge, the residue of sewage treatment plants, to a spot 12 miles east of the New Jersey shore town of Sea Bright and dumped their cargoes. As the sludge sank through 80 feet of sea water to the bottom, it created a plume of organic and toxic waste that poisoned fish in the area and, during storms, washed ashore on the beaches of New Jersey and western Long Island.

title: FROM TRUMBULL HIGH TO THE N. C. A. A. CROWN
description: LIKE most high school basketball coaches, Stan Suchenski of Trumbull High School encourages his players to practice during the off-season, in keeping with a coaching axiom that basketball players are made between March and December, when the new season starts.

title: EUROPEAN FARMERS FEAR GLUT OF WINE AND OLIVE OIL
description: Driving two hours southwest from Madrid, through the central plains of Castille to this small village in Extremadura on the road to Portugal, a traveler can see why the agreement last weekend to admit Spain and Portugal to the European Common Market took eight years to reach.

description: Adversity stalked the 13th annual San Diego Crew Classic, but through the determination of the organizing committee, 1,400 men and women were provided the opportunity to race today on East Mission Bay.

title: WIDENING SCANDAL AT TULANE HAD UNLIKELY BEGINNINGS
description: Unlike the school's flashy football stadium, the Louisiana Superdome, Tulane's basketball arena is no palace. Fans call it ''the Cracker Box.''

The Atlanta-based cable and broadcasting entrepreneur, who has lately been downplaying reports of his designs on the network, was reported to be in New York trying to line up financing.

description: THERE probably is not a town in Connecticut that has changed with as much velocity as Chester has in the last five years. The addition of two theaters, Goodspeed- at-Chester and the National Theater of the Deaf, has added impetus to an already fast-changing scene.

The operator is Lindblad Travel Inc., 1 Sylvan Road North, Westport, Conn. 06881 (telephone: 203-226-8531). The cruises may be booked from them directly or through travel agents.

title: NEW SUDAN LEADER SAID TO ASSURE U. S. HE'LL FAVOR WEST
description: The new military ruler of the Sudan met separately today with the senior American, Egyptian and Saudi Arabian diplomats in Khartoum and reassured them he would keep the Sudan on a pro-Western course, State Department officials said.

title: Japanese Starts Solo Voyage
description: A 60-year- old man left the port of Takamatsu today in a 42-foot steel boat, hoping to become the first person to row from Japan to North America. Takeo Fujita, who has enough supplies for 18 months, said he would not actually row but rather drift on the current to the West Coast of the United States. Mr. Fujita, whose boat has no power source except for one oar in the rear, told the Kyodo News Service that he set out on the journey to show ''the guts of a 60-year- old man.''

title: CRENSHAW TRYING TO REKINDLE MAGIC OF MASTERS VICTORY
description: WHEN Ben Crenshaw won the Masters Tournament a year ago, he climbed up on cloud nine and rode that cushion of contentment for months, even though his game quickly slipped back into the doldrums.

title: Insurance Unit Head Is Named
description: Arthur W. White is an insurance executive who likes taking risks.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH ;   Capital Cities and Minorities
description: Capital Cities Communications Inc. seems be making every effort to smooth the way for its proposed takeover of the American Broadcasting Companies. Having been warmly received at the Federal Communications Commission and winning some approving nods from key members of Congress, Capital Cities is now courting groups that advocate increased ownership of media properties by racial minorities.

title: DUTCH SAY SOVIET MISSILE FREEZE WILL NOT AFFECT PLANS FOR CRUISE
description: The Dutch Government sees no reason to alter its stance on the stationing of cruise missiles in the Netherlands as a result of a Soviet moratorium on the deployment of SS-20 missiles in Europe, a Dutch Foreign Ministry spokesman in The Hague said tonight.

title: FREEZES MISSILES
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said today that he was prepared to hold a summit meeting with President Reagan and announced a moratorium on the deployment of Soviet medium-range missiles in Europe. He called on the United States to respond with a similar freeze.

title: ONE DOUBT HOVERS OVER METS
description: The Mets ended spring training today and headed for New York, where they will open the season Tuesday against the St. Louis Cardinals. And, said Keith Hernandez, with all their new power, their chances of success still hinge directly on whether the widely advertised ''young arms'' can survive in the big leagues.

title: STORY OF WALLENBERG BEING SHOWN IN 2 PARTS
description: PERHAPS because the subject is so overwhelming, so monumentally horrifying, the Holocaust resists sweeping dramatizations. Fictionalized manipulations are almost obscene in the face of searing reality. The enormity of the crimes is often captured best in small, comprehensible chunks having roots in fact - ''The Diary of Anne Frank,'' for instance, or ''The Wall.'' The story of Raoul Wallenberg provides, in this sense, a splendid opportunity to use a close-up portrait as a means for understanding the larger picture. And much of that opportunity has been skillfully seized in ''Wallenberg: A Hero's Story,'' a two-part, four-hour NBC presentation being broadcast tonight and Tuesday at 9 o'clock.

title: Investors Are in Wary Mood
description: Faced with a host of conflicting economic developments, the credit markets seem vulnerable to continued sudden shifts of mood that may be exciting for traders but are anathema to many potential investors.

title: U. S. OUTLINES EMIGRE'S TIES TO F. B. I.
description: Government documents filed in connection with the espionage trial of Svetlana Ogorodnikov shed new light on her activities and her relationship with the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Red Sox, at Boston, season opener for Yogi Berra's Yankees. Ron Guidry turned up with a sore neck, so the opening-day starting assignment falls to Phil Niekro, the veteran knuckleballer, who is 0-6 in eight starts and one relief appearance in openers, all of them with the Atlanta Braves.

title: BATTLES LOOM OVER IMPORTS
description: Imports are at record levels in many industries, hitting jobs and profits and spurring widespread demands for protection.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Russ Berrie to Warwick
description: Warwick Advertising last week proudly announced its fourth piece of new business in the last two months - Russ Berrie & Company, maker of plush and impulse gift items. According to Warwick, the budget will be $5 million. Berrie previously did its own advertising.

title: M. T. A. SEEKS MODIFICATIONS IN WORK RULES
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which is negotiating a new contract with 36,000 bus and subway workers, is pressing for 72 changes in work rules and pay practices. It says the new procedures would allow the agency to cut costs and increase employee efficiency and productivity.

title: ;   It's Time to Rethink Urban Rail Transit
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympic Medalist Takes a Break
description: Antonio McKay, a gold medal winner in the 1984 Olympics, said today that he will not compete during the current outdoor season and instead will concentrate on his studies at Georgia Tech .

title: RANGERS SET MARK WITH 44TH LOSS
description: The Rangers gladly bid adieu to the 1984-85 regular season tonight with yet another loss, their 44th for the year. No team has ever made the Stanley Cup playoffs with so many defeats.

title: Light Schedule of Treasury Issues
description: The Treasury market is in the midst of several weeks of light financing, with no new issues of notes or bonds expected until the two-year note auction on April 24.

title: CAREY TAKES RARE LOOK BACK AT ADMINISTRATION
description: It has been said that no governor in history faced more problems nor more trying times than we did in 1975. I was there, and I affirm that opinion with deep conviction.''

title: NEW MARKETING PUSH FOR IRISH WHISKEY
description: Although some Irish drinkers give up whisky for Lent, Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. does not normally stop producing and distributing it. This year, though, a labor dispute shut down the giant distilling complex on the rolling outskirts of this town just east of Cork from the beginning of the pre-Easter religious observance in February until April 3.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH ;   Maryland Deposit Insurer
description: -Share Insurance Corporation, the company that insures 102 state-chartered savings and loan associations, has taken advantage of the public spotlight to argue that it should be exempt from Federal income taxes.

title: Debt Issues ;    Common Stock
description: General Telephone Co. (Southeast), a unit of GTE Corp., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $75 million of first- mortgage bonds due in 1995.

title: FREEZE BY SOVIET IS BRUSHED OFF BY WHITE HOUSE
description: The White House today dismissed the statement by Mikhail S. Gorbachev that he was halting deployment of nuclear missiles aimed at Western Europe as an attempt to maintain Soviet nuclear superiority.

title: FASHION PUBLICATIONS FOR MEN
description: First there was GQ, and then there was M. Now there is MGF - the latest ''initial'' magazine to appeal to men's fashion sense and vanity.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRAVDA INTERVIEW WITH GORBACHEV ON RELATIONS WITH U. S.
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a Pravda interview with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, as translated and distributed today by Tass:

title: SPAIN IN THE MAINSTREAM: KAFKA, DISCOS, COCAINE
description: There is still the blood of bullfights, the sultry swishing skirts of flamenco, the shuffle of old women in black going daily to mass.

title: U.S.-Red Bloc Trade Up
description: Two-way trade between the United States and the Communist bloc rose 43.2 percent, to $12.4 billion, in 1984, the International Trade Commission said Friday in a report to Congress. Exports rose 41.8 percent, to $7.2 billion, and imports increased 45.4 percent, to $5.2 billion, the report said.

title: GLUT OF DOCTORS CREATING A PATIENT'S MARKET
description: Dr. Andy P. Morley sends a quarterly newsletter to each of his patients that offers information on treating the flu, handling high blood pressure and generally staying ''out of my office.'' He says it helps his patients, in the Atlanta suburb of Decatur, to hold down the cost of health care and helps his business at the same time.

title: KIWI FRUIT IS CRUCIAL FOR NEW ZEALAND
description: It may be homely on the outside, often likened to a small suede potato or dubbed the ''hairy berry,'' but the kiwi fruit is being hailed as the wave of New Zealand's future.

title: RENE PORTOCARRERO
description: Rene Portocarrero, considered Cuba's finest modern artist, died today at the age of 73, the state-run press agency Prensa Latina reported.

title: Undercover Fly in the Lawyer-Client Ointment
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLLYWOOD COMPETITORS RISE FROM TEXAS TO THE CAROLINAS
description: The newly built outdoor set of plaster and plywood - a lifesize copy of Manhattan's Chinatown - rises from the raw earth of the 32-acre movie studio, two dozen neon signs flashing garishly. Fields and a small wood surround six sound stages crammed with sets for four movies. There is no smog and the temperature on a February day is 67 degrees. It might be southern California in 1935. It is, instead, Wilmington, N.C., in 1985.

title: NEW STUDY EVALUATES WAYS TO RUN CONVENTION CENTER
description: Private management of New York's new convention center might be efficient and profitable, but public management would promote greater economic benefits for the city and the state, a voluminous study compiled for the center's operating corporation has found.

title: GUNSLINGERS WIN BEFORE ONLY 8,873
description: Nick Mike-Mayer kicked three field goals as the San Antonio Gunslingers defeated the Birmingham Stallions, 15-14, today before only 8,873 fans - the smallest home crowd in the Gunslingers' two-year history.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Now, a Different Map
description: Democrats who may be depressed by the low estate of their party nationally can take cheer from a new map being distributed by party headquarters on Capitol Hill.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, APRIL 8, 1985

title: MAN ACCUSED OF KIDNAPPING OF 2 HE SAID ROBBED HOME
description: A man tracked down two men he said had looted his house, but he was apprehended by a special police team and jailed on charges of kidnapping the two men at gunpoint, the police said today.

title: NORDIQUES DEFEAT WHALERS
description: Brad Maxwell snapped a 1-1 tie at 7 minutes 2 seconds of the third period as the Quebec Nordiques defeated the Hartford Whalers, 4-1, tonight to clinch second place in the Adams Division.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ;   Canucks Reported To Dismiss Coach
description: The Vancouver Canucks, completing the worst season in their 15 years, have notified the coach- general manager, Harry Neale, that he will be dismissed, a newspaper reported today.

title: FLYERS ARE GREATER THAN SUM OF THE PARTS
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Taking Fight to Streets
