description: Can a labor union legally put a picket line in front of a restaurant and try to keep out would- be diners because it disagrees with the report of a Presidential commission that was headed by the chief executive officer of the corporation that owns the restaurant?

title: PENTAGON ACTS TO CURB SCIENCE PARLEY PAPERS
description: The Defense Department has told the sponsor of a technical symposium to be held here this week that it must cancel the presentation of about a dozen unclassified research papers because the information might help the enemies of the United States.

title: RECORDS FALL AT ARIZONA MEET
description: The Santa Monica Track Club quartet of Carl Lewis, Ferran Tyler, Benny Hollis and Johnny Gray set an American standard and a world's best with a time of 3 minutes 10.76 seconds in the men's 1,600-meter sprint medley relay Saturday night at the sixth Sun Angel Track and Field Classic.

title: Music/Noted in Brief ;   Bach, Handel, Scarlatti By Quadro Barocco
description: The Friends of Central Park held a friendly and informal gathering in Carnegie Recital Hall before setting out on a walking tour of the park Easter afternoon. Quadro Barocco, a touring old-instrument group, provided the music in pleasant fashion.

title: Music/Noted in Brief ;   'Saint Matthew Passion' At Carnegie Hall
description: Saturday night's performance of the ''Saint Matthew Passion'' at Carnegie Hall sought Bach's monumentality not in the application of massive weight but in the accumulation of small details. The Male Choir and Orchestra of St. Luke's, the American Boychoir and seven soloists - all under the direction of John Nelson - gave us this music in swift, gracefully born tempos and phrases carefully subdivided and accented.

title: MCENROE WINNER ON CONNORS DEFAULT
description: For the first time in his career today, Jimmy Connors was unable to play a scheduled match. Because of a back injury, he defaulted to John McEnroe in the final of the Chicago Volvo Grand Prix event.

title: STOCK UP ON MITTENS
description: THE Mets and the Yankees could not have picked a better time for their organizational soap operas of the past week. The injuries and the second-guessing have set a tone of reality just in time, before everybody wages the family subway tokens on an IRT World Series.

title: 3 Connecticut Men Die in Cycle Crash
description: Three Middletown men died early today when the motorcylce they were riding hit a tree, the police said.

title: Jamaica Protest Broken Up
description: The police made several arrests and used tear gas to disperse a demonstration outside an international youth conference that opened here this weekend, the Caribbean news agency CANA said today. It quoted witnesses as having said about 200 people took part in the protest by members of the major opposition People's National Party and the small Workers' Party of Jamaica, which are boycotting the conference because of what they call its right-wing political slant.

title: BOTHA, IN ADDRESS TO A BLACK SECT, WARNS AGAINST EVIL FROM ABROAD
description: A huge throng of blacks who belong to a Christian sect gathered in an Easter celebration on a remote hillside today and heard President P. W. Botha warn against ''forces of darkness'' from outside South Africa.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ;   Swoon, Semillero Win Turf Races
description: Swoon, the favorite, and Semillero, a Chilean import, captured $60,000 divisions of the San Marino Handicap on the turf at Santa Anita today.

title: SILVERY FISH, NOT FLOWERS, TELL THAWED CHICAGO IT'S SPRING
description: In most cities, crocuses and daffodils are sure signs that spring has arrived. In Chicago, it is smelts.

title: ACID RAIN'S POLITICAL POISON
description: Pres ident Reagan has brought United States relations with many of our southern neighbors to the lowest point in decades. Now he risks doing the same with our northern neighbor.

title: STAGE: 'SEPTEMBER IN THE RAIN' PRESENTED AT HUDSON GUILD
description: ONCE a year, Liz and Jack, a Yorkshire couple, take their holiday on the beach in Blackpool. That is the beginning, the end and the sum of John Godber's ''September in the Rain,'' opening yesterday at the Hudson Guild Theater.

title: Ex-White House Aides See Threat of Trade War
description: Two former chief White House economists, warning that retaliation against Japan could set off a global trade war, said today that the strong dollar was responsible for the American trade deficit.

title: OUTDOORS: SOLITUDE AND RHYTHM OF SINGLE SCULLING
description: IT happened last summer. My

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: MONDAY, APRIL 8, 1985 International

title: WHITE HOUSE STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of the statement read today by Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, in response to comments made by Mikhail S. Gorbachev in his interview with Pravda:

title: Unhanging Portraits
description: When an unusual event makes Washington headlines, local authorities often come forward to argue that the same phenomenon has actually happened several times before. Take the practice of demurization: removing from the wall of a Government agency the picture of a former official who has fallen from favor.

title: An Alternative Existed In Westmoreland Case
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIDGE:THE CAVENDISH CLUB MOVES TO MORE PERMANENT HOME
description: The world's most famous bridge club, the Cavendish, has had four midtown Manhattan homes in the past 30 years. Yesterday it moved to a fifth, and in more than one sense the members may think it is a step up.

title: Mayor Who?
description: You would think he was better

title: WHERE WILL OZ LAND?
description: INSTEAD of looking into the Land of Oz for the winners of baseball's four divisions this season, it's

title: ADVERTISING ;   Bozell Modifies Name
description: Bozell & Jacobs, which acquired Ruvane.Leverte, a pharmaceutical advertising agency in 1983, is changing its name to Bozell & Jacobs/ Healthcare. And Robert Laverte, president, has also been named chief executive, replacing John Ruvane, who was chairman before he left.

title: FROM THE NATIONAL TRUST, COPIES OF A CHURCHILL DESK
description: Sir Winston Churchill wrote many of his wartime memos in bed and most of his books standing at a lectern-style desk. But he did occasionally use more conventional desks both in London and at his country home, Chartwell, in Kent. A reproduction of one of these, from the library at Chartwell, is spearheading a marketing drive in the United States by the National Trust, which now owns the house.

title: Columbia Moves To Halt Protest
description: A judge last night granted Columbia University a temporary restraining order barring 100 students from continuing to barricade the entrance to Hamilton Hall, a classroom and administration building. The students are protesting the university's investment in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: French Prices Higher
description: French industrial wholesale prices rose a provisional eight-tenths of 1 percent in February after a 1 percent revised January rise, the National Statistics Institute said Friday.

title: Law Said Not to Detect Toxic Waste Dumping
description: Illegal dumping of hazardous waste occurs undiscovered by a complex reporting system in effect since the middle 1970's, the General Accounting Office says.

title: SOAP OPERA FORMULA RE-EVALUATED
description: Week after week, two long-running soap operas, ''Dallas'' and ''Dynasty,'' vie for the top spot in the Nielsen ratings. And two more of these fervid serials, ''Knots Landing'' and ''Falcon Crest,'' are generally not far behind. That success rate has inspired the networks to look for more sex-and- glamour-soaked soap operas, but not all have been able to repeat the high ratings of their forerunners.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day last Monday with an article about leading underwriters in the first quarter omitted Deutsche Bank. It was ranked seventh in terms of combined United States and European securities, and was the lead manager for $1.749 billion of securities offered in 15 issues.

title: The Governor in the Budget Mirror
description: When you ask Mario Cuomo about foreign affairs, his eyes drift and his mouth shuts. New York's Governor, darling of the 1984 Democratic convention, is being careful to present himself as someone who knows where Washington is but has no immediate desire to go there. That he might develop such a desire, however, is evident from the state's new $39 billion budget.

title: David P. Apgar Weds Ann Moeller on Coast
description: Ann Marie Moeller and David Puschel Apgar, a legislative assistant to Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, were married in City of Industry, Calif., yesterday. The Rev. Constance Parvey performed the Lutheran ceremony at the Workman and Temple Homestead, a museum where the bride is the assistant director of education.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ;   Fan, 14, Is Killed In Soccer Brawl
description: A teen-ager was killed, 50 persons were injured and 100 others were arrested in a brawl between fans at a soccer game today in the industrial suburb of Avellaneda.

title: Q. AND A. ;   FAITH WHITTLESEY ON WHITE HOUSE
description: As assistant to President Reagan for public liaison for two years, Faith Ryan Whittlesey has been the highest ranking woman in the White House. She has been in charge of mobilizing special interest groups and various constituencies, such as members of minority groups, women, labor, business and farmers.

title: CAMPAIGN FOR VIRGINIA GOVERNOR IS CLOUDED BY THE POLITICS OF RACE
description: The candidacy of a black State Senator for Lieutenant Governor is shaping up as a key factor in the Democratic Party's effort to retain the governorship of Virginia.

title: SENATE VOTE NEAR ON GENOCIDE PACT
description: After almost 36 years of delay and intermittent debate, the Senate is nearing a vote in which it is expected to consent to United States ratification of the United Nations treaty condemning genocide.

title: Arson Inquiry Held In Utah Mine Fire
description: Officials are investigating reports that the fire at the Wilberg Mine that killed 27 people last December was caused by arson resulting from jealousy over an attempt to set a coal-production record.

title: SNAG ON CAPITAL GAINS SEEN FOR TAX PLANNERS
description: Of the myriad tax issues now under consideration as the Reagan Administration puts together its proposal for overhauling the nation's tax system, one of the most difficult to resolve, according to insiders, is the question of how best to deal with capital gains.

title: Bhopal Suit Is Imminent
description: India is expected to file suit, possibly as soon as Monday, against the Union Carbide Corporation over the Bhopal disaster, the lead attorney of a Minneapolis law firm hired last month by that nation said today.

title: EGYPT PLEASED AS SUDAN LEADERS PLEDGE TO MAINTAIN TIES TO CAIRO
description: Egyptian officials expressed relief today that the new military Government in the Sudan appeared to be pro-Egyptian, pro-Western and ostensibly committed to a prompt transfer of power to civilian democratic rule.

title: HOW TO DRIVE DOCTORS OUT
description: Legally and financially, it has been a trying winter for New York metropolitan area physicians, and, for many, the coming years promise to be nothing less than catastrophic.

title: JUDY CHICAGO: WOMEN'S LIVES AND ART
description: The woman's body is massive, a landscape as big as the earth. Her breasts and legs rise up like mountains; her head is the sun, hair radiating outward in brilliant rays; her fingers become rivers flowing over a voluptuous terrain. She is giving birth in a traditional childbirth position: one figure supports her, another kneels before her to receive the baby - except that the head of this crouching midwife is itself a placentalike form emerging from the woman giving birth.

title: RULES SEEN NEAR ON BANK DISCLOSURE
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is likely to approve in the next two weeks new rules under which it would publish weekly all enforcement actions that it takes against the banks it regulates, according to William M. Isaac, the agency's chairman.

title: 'HOLI,' ABOUT A HIGH SCHOOL IN INDIA
description: ''HOLI,'' an Indian film directed by Ketan Mehta, is set in what appears to be an Indian equivalent of one of our coeducational high schools, where the students live on campus and suffer the same frustrations of students their age all over the world. Most of the faculty members are dolts, the curriculum is out of touch with the students' needs and the male students and female students lust after each other, but discreetly.

title: Homeless Shelters Are Dangerous Places
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on March 29 about the Bank of Boston Corporation omitted the total amount of earnings it expects to report for the first quarter. It is $2.20 a share, which includes 30 cents a share from the sale of securities.

title: POPE'S EASTER TALK LAUDS NAZIS' VICTIMS
description: Pope John Paul II, invoking the 40th anniversary this year of the end of World War II, delivered an Easter message today in praise of ''the men and women in each country who offered their lives in sacrifice for the right cause, the cause of the dignity of the human person.''

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS ;   Plea for Shoeless Joe
description: He was an innocent who admitted his guilt, which was as real as his natural swing. But somehow, even today, more than 65 years later, the mind of baseball still rebels at the monstrous fact that one of the greatest hitters and most appealing heroes who ever played the game plotted with seven Chicago teammates to throw the 1919 World Series to the Cincinnati Reds.

title: FOR PUBLIC ARTISTS, NEW YORK CITY IS A GIANT STAGE
description: In Washington Square Park, Clyde Romero chips away at an old, dead tree with a mallet and gouges, carving a sculpture called ''A Tribute to Hannibal.''

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ;   Korean Triumphs
description: Oh Min Gun of South Korean won a close, unanimous 15-round decision over Irving Mitchell of San Diego and retained his International Boxing Federation featherweight title today. The champion put on a relentless attack.

title: APARTMENT-BUILDING UNION NEGOTIATING A NEW CONTRACT
description: A union representing 30,000 employees of apartment buildings in New York City has begun talks with building owners, and for the first time it is seeking a single contract covering both 1,500 independent buildings and 2,500 buildings represented by the Realty Advisory Board.

title: A.T.&T. and MCI Go Back to Court
description: Jury selection begins today in Chicago in the damages portion of the MCI Communications Corporation's antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its former Bell operating companies. If its full request is granted, MCI would receive $17.4 billion - one of the largest awards in an antitrust case.

title: MARRIAGE: SOME SEEK EARLY HELP
description: IN these days of persistently high divorce rates, mental health professionals say engaged couples are increasingly seeking premarital counseling, even after the wedding date has been set and the invitations sent out.

title: THE VOLATILE COCOA MARKET
description: -moving, volatile market. They do not have to look far these days for a cliffhanger that has been offering a fast swing for the money. It is the May cocoa futures contract, traded on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, which has swung between a contract high of $2,570 a metric ton and a contract low of $1,998 a metric ton.

title: WALKER RUNS FOR 233 AS GENERALS WIN
description: The team with the great runner, the Generals, beat the team with the superb passer, the Houston Gamblers, today in a game that had everything, including excitement, for a crowd of 34,573.

title: U. N. CHIEF ARRIVES IN IRAN TO DISCUSS POSSIBILITY OF PEACE WITH IRAQ
description: The United Nations Secretary General arrived in Teheran today for talks with Iranian leaders in an effort to help end the four-and-a-half-year war with Iraq.

title: IN NEVES ILLNESS, ANXIETY RULES BRAZIL
description: Barely three weeks after the return of civilian rule to Brazil, the continuing illness of President-elect Tancredo Neves has transformed a nationwide mood of optimism into one of collective anxiety and political uncertainty.

title: LIBRARIANS RALLY THE TROOPS TO BATTLE U. S. ON INFORMATION
description: The reputation of librarians suggests that they are reticent types who speak in hushed tones and urge others to do likewise. Their native habitat is cloistered, literate, genteel. They are not usually considered combative.

title: 7 Held in Slaying Of Man in Trunk
description: Seven people were in custody yesterday on charges of second-degree murder and kidnapping in connection with the death of a Long Island real- estate broker whose body was found locked in a trunk in a Manhattan apartment Saturday.

title: KNICKS FALL AGAIN AS BIRD SCORES 38
description: Medically, this afternoon's game between the foundering Knicks and pro basketball's best team, the Boston Celtics, was a standoff as players from both sides nursed aches and pains in preparation for, respectively, the offseason and the postseason. But in this sport, Larry Bird is the great unequalizer, and he again showed why today.

title: CURBING BANKS IN REAL ESTATE
description: WASHINGTON

title: LONG ODDS FOR A DATE ON LOTTERY
description: In the give and take of ordinary lawmaking, legislators and administrators can work together in hearings and debates to shape workable measures.

title: Bombs Found in Belfast Before Nationalist Event
description: Thousands of Irish nationalists marched today in cities throughout this British-ruled province to mark the 1916 Easter Rising in Dublin that foreshadowed the creation of the independent Irish Republic to the south.

title: ANALYSTS TRIMMING PROFIT FORECASTS
description: The strong dollar and signs of weakness in the economy are forcing economists and stock market analysts to cut their estimates of corporate profits for the first quarter and for the year.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Cinematographer Hired For Pentax Campaign
description: It takes a pretty strong (or heartless) person not to feel an emotional tug while watching those down-home Kodak commercials from J. Walter Thompson. Of course, given the sponsor, the demands for good photography are high.

title: A National Test for Teachers
description: With the prospect of a severe teacher shortage, educators are searching urgently for ways to promote the profession and maintain high standards. Albert Shanker of the American Federation of Teachers proposes a national certifying exam.

title: FLYERS ROUT DEVILS, 6-1, IN SEASON FINALE
description: After their 6-1 trouncing of the Devils here tonight, the Philadelphia Flyers appear to be peaking at precisely the right time for the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Why Lock Up Money in Prison?
description: There's no doubt that ''fixed'' sentencing - which sharply reduces the leeway of judges and parole boards to say how long convicts remain in prison - appeals to a public angry about crime. The question prompted by a New York commission report is whether that is worth the likely price: the expensive expansion of an already-swollen prison population.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: NINE INNINGS. By Daniel Okrent. 272

title: Catching Up
description: * Ray Grebey, the management negotiator whose handling of the 50- day baseball strike in 1981 drew the ire of the players' union, is now a senior vice president of Pan American World Airways industrial relations department. In that capacity he played an important role in settling the recent 29-day strike by mechanics and other ground personnel.

title: 'HOMECOMING,' VENTURE OF HONG KONG AND CHINA
description: IN Yim Ho's ''Homecoming,'' a

title: Christians in China Mark Day
description: Foreigners took a bus from Peking and celebrated Easter at a sunrise service atop the 2,500-year-old Great Wall today, and thousands of Chinese Christians flocked to churches. Five buses carrying Peking-based diplomats, business people, students and a few tourists left the capital at 4 A.M. for the 90-minute journey to the Great Wall here, where a minister from Hong Kong led a 30-minute service.

title: Up to 18 Youths Arrested In Philadelphia Violence
description: Looting and vandalism erupted today as an estimated 5,000 youths congregated in Philadelphia's downtown area, and as many as 18 people were arrested, the authorities said.

title: BankAmerica Appoints Mortgage Group Chief
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said that Charles E. Reed, a former president of the Sears Mortgage Securities Corporation, had been named director of its residential mortgage banking unit.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: The 'Wild Guy' of Mexican Drugs
description: Investigators tracking the career of Rafael Caro Quintero call him one of Mexico's biggest drug dealers and say he ''loves what money can buy.'' Too often, they suspect, what it buys in Mexico are freedom from arrest and escape from prosecution.

title: Fall in World Birth Rate Since 1983 Is Reported
description: The world's birth rate has fallen from 29 to 27 births per 1,000 people since 1983, largely because of sharp curbs on China's population growth, a private population study group has reported.

title: SECTOR FUNDS: GROWTH TOOL
description: ONE way to expand in the mutual fund business is to offer specially packaged industry sectors of the stock market to the investing public. This strategy has met with considerable success for Fidelity Investments of Boston, the nation's largest privately owned mutual fund company, and the approach seems likely to gain favor.

title: Guadeloupe Protesters Demand Independence
description: Several thousand people held a rally on this Caribbean island today to demand an end to three and a half centuries of French rule.

title: HYPER-INFLATION TRAUMATIZES BOLIVIA
description: Bolivia has entered the world of hyper-inflation, a twilight zone where banks no longer function, bills are paid with foot-long bundles of folding paper money and buying sprees overtake the most sensible person.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Magazine Devoted To Chefs
description: MAY 7 will be the 60th anniversary of the birth of Sandy Lesberg, an event that will be largely ignored. It will also be the day of birth of the American edition of his magazine, Master Chef, which he hopes will not suffer a similar fate.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 8, 1985: *2*MONDAY Amer Broadcstg Co *2*TUESDAY AAR Corp Procter & Gamble Bank of New York Staley Contl Inc Central Soya TECO Energy Inc Crompton & Knowles Travelers Corp ITT Corp *2*WEDNESDAY Celanese Corp Southwestern Energy Dayton-Hudson Tokheim Corp Pacific Corp Walgreen Company Robertshaw Controls Woolworth (FW) Safeway Stores *2*THURSDAY Ford Motor Co Universal Foods Kaufman & Broad Inc Winsconsin Pub Serv NERCO Inc *2*FRIDAY Aluminum Co Amer Sterling Drug

title: Vietnamese Forces Retake Cambodian Guerrilla Camp
description: Vietnamese forces recaptured a Cambodian guerrilla camp near the Thai border today in a two-hour battle that began at dawn, Thai military sources said. They said six guerrillas were killed and 35 wounded.

title: BIONDI SETS FASTER PACE FOR SWIMMERS;
description: The first thing you notice about Matt Biondi is his size - 6 feet 6 inches, 195 pounds, shoulders that require a size 46 jacket tapering to a 33- inch waist.

title: GENOVESE TO GOETZ
description: WASHINGTON Twenty years ago, the most stirring story about crime and our

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Are there now any changes for the better in Soviet-American relations? There is no simple answer to this question.

title: DANCE: TWO PREMIERES PRESENTED BY FELD BALLET
description: KAREN KAIN, Richard Cragun and Gary Chryst appeared as guest artists with the Feld Ballet Saturday night, and there was even a guest choreographer - David Parsons of the Paul Taylor Dance Company - on the rolls as well.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Who are the baseball players who will enter the new season with batting averages of .300 or better and at least 10 years in the major leagues?

title: Rita Lavelle Reports Motive for Grant Delay
description: Rita M. Lavelle, former assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency's toxic waste fund, says she now recalls being told that the agency delayed awarding a grant for political reasons.

title: TRIANGLE TO ACQUIRE CAN MAKER
description: The National Can Corporation has agreed to be acquired by Triangle Industries for $42 a share, or about $430 million, bringing to an end a year of jockeying among several suitors for control of the Chicago-based packaging company.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS ;   Revival on Hudson
description: When Jim Rogers got the idea a couple of years ago of organizing a crew race in New York between American alumni of the venerable Oxford-Cambridge rowing competition, some city boosters saw it as the perfect antidote for a local embarrassment: that New York, once a center of rowing competition, had long since been upstaged by Boston and Philadelphia, where regattas regularly drew thousands of spectators to the Charles and the Schuylkill.

title: A Big Surprise For a Goetz Look-Alike
description: A struggling young actor named

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS ;   Dome Anniversary
description: The Astrodome in Houston will be 20 years old tomorrow night, and the anniversary will be marked in Texas style, as was the opening on April 9, 1965, when the major leagues went indoors for the first time.

title: Get Them Off the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: MILLER WINS SHORE, TYING MARK ON 275
description: Alice Miller, who said she was nervous all day, let a five-shot lead with 11 holes to go dwindle to a one- shot lead with five holes to play today in the $400,000 Nabisco Dinah Shore Invitation tournament. She birdied three of the last five holes, including a birdie on the final green, to beat Jan Stephenson by three shots.

title: BOYD HAS INCENTIVE AGAINST YANKEES
description: The season-opening game between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park today was supposed to feature a couple of lightweights, but Ron Guidry spoiled the matchup by developing a stiff neck. That will leave Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd and his 145-pound body as the only lightweight on the field.

title: Tracking Down Voices Of a Generation
description: ''Johnny Boy.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
PICKENS MAKES BID FOR UNOCAL
description: An investment group led by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, is making a $3.46 billion bid to buy 64 million shares of the Unocal Corporation's stock for $54 a share in cash.

title: THE MESSAGE FROM MOSCOW
description: The public exchange between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the White House today signaled that despite talk of a Soviet- American summit meeting the sharp political differences between the two sides may intensify in coming months.

title: U.S. SEEKING GLOBAL TRADE TALKS EARLY IN 1986
description: The Reagan Administration will press its industrial allies this week for a firm pledge to open negotiations early next year aimed at freeing international trade, according to trade experts.

title: SOVIET SEEKS SOUTHEAST ASIA DIPLOMATIC ROLE
description: The Soviet Union, which has been increasing its military presence in Southeast Asia through the use of port and air installations in Vietnam and Cambodia, is now apparently trying to play a larger diplomatic role in the region.

title: Mademoiselle Publisher Is Formerly of Hearst
description: Former Country Living magazine publisher, Ronald A. Galotti, has left Hearst Magazines to join Conde Nast as publisher of Mademoiselle, its thriving monthly fashion publication.

title: Texan's Social Debut
description: Gerald D. Hines is a formidable name in Houston, where his construction company has reshaped the skyline with gleaming office towers, as well as building hotels and shopping centers. Despite more than 300 major construction projects there and elsewhere from San Francisco to Atlanta, he is not well-known in Washington, where his first building is only now going up on Pennsylvania Avenue in downtown.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: G & S The Blue Hill Troupe, one of New York's oldest repertory companies and one of several that slake the unquenchable New York thirst for Gilbert and Sullivan, begins its 61st annual presentation tonight at 8 at the Hunter College Playhouse, 68th Street at Lexington Avenue, with a production of ''The Sorcerer.''

title: MANAGING THE GAME TO WIN IT
description: When a name is called over the public address system in the Longworth Building on Capitol Hill, the person whose ears perk up fastest has sometimes paged himself. ''It's a sure way of calling attention to yourself in front of 400 or 500 people,'' says John L. Sherman, a staff aide on the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington yesterday on Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's planned lectures at Harvard University misstated the timing of his departure from the Government in 1965. Mr. Moynihan left his position as Assistant Secretary of Labor in June, several months before public controversy arose over a report on the black family he had presented to the White House.

title: SINDELAR WINNER BY SHOT
description: Joey Sindelar fired a 3-under-par 69 today to charge from four strokes off the pace and win the Greater Greensboro Open - his first victory on the PGA Tour - with a 3-under-par total of 285.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS ;   A.C.C. All-Stars Win Shootout KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 7 (AP) - Dan Meagher of Duke scored 18 points to pace the Atlantic Coast Conference all-stars to a 114-109 victory over the Southeastern Conference all- stars today in the college basketball Southern Shootout. Meagher was named the game's outstanding player. Buzz Peterson of North Carolina added 14 for the A.C.C. team and six other players finished in double figures.
description: Tennessee's Michael Brooks led the S.E.C. with 18. Gerald Crosby of Georgia, Bobby Lee Hurt of Alabama and Mississippi State's Ken Harvey had 16 each.

title: GIRL WINS RESPECT, NOT CASH, IN CHESS
description: In her last game in the New York International chess tournament yesterday, 15-year-old Susan Polgar of Hungary paused midway and realistically appraised her chances against her opponent, the grandmaster Dmitri Gurevich of Brooklyn.

title: Dallas Voters Re-elect Mayor for a 2d Term
description: Mayor A. Starke Taylor won a second term by a slim margin Saturday, but his challenger, City Councilman Max Goldblatt, refused to concede defeat.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART: TEST OF TECHNOLOGY
description: William J. Schroeder's first full day today of living away from a hospital tethered to his mechanical heart's power plant marks a milestone in the history of the development of artificial organs and the battle against heart disease, the nation's leading killer. But despite the historic occasion, the full significance of Mr. Schroeder's release cannot be determined now, partly because he has not returned to his real home in Jasper, Ind., and more importantly because doctors need a series of cases to assess an experiment.

title: Mondale Admits Mishandling Of His Case to the Electorate
description: Walter F. Mondale, looking back on his landslide defeat in the 1984 Presidential election, said today that he ''fundamentally mishandled my case to the American people'' by failing to emphasize the positive side of his message.

title: ATOM PLANT INVESTMENT WEIGHS HEAVILY ON TOWN
description: This lovely colonial town has a famous prep school, neat white clapboard houses, apple orchards and a $29 million investment in a nuclear power plant that may never be completed.

title: TROTTIER PREDICTS A RETURN TO FORM
description: Fluorescent lights brighten the locker room, and at any time it could be day and it could be night. If you have played enough hockey games and gone to enough practices, it's easy to forget which is which, to lose yourself.

title: WANTED MEXICAN WINS A ROUND
description: Lawyers for Arturo Durazo Moreno, a former Mexico City police chief and the focus of the Mexican Government's campaign against corruption, have won a series of victories in the opening weeks of extradition hearings here. As a result, the hearings may extend well into the summer.

title: INDIAN MUSEUM GETS STATE AID OFFER
description: The State and the City of New York have announced that each will allocate $13 million to help pay for the construction of a new Museum of the American Indian, if it merges with the American Museum of Natural History in New York City.

title: U.S. ACCUSES EX-MINISTER FROM BELIZE IN PLOT TO IMPORT MARIJUANA
description: A former Cabinet member of the Belize was seized in Miami today by Federal undercover agents and charged with conspiracy to import marijuana into this country.

title: JETS' CARSON SEEKS DEFENSIVE LEADERS
description: Once upon a time, Bud Carson helped create a mighty Steel Curtain defense at Pittsburgh.

title: Violent Crime Stable in 1984, Overall Rate Down, U.S. Says
description: A Government gauge shows overall crime fell by 4.5 percent last year, but there was no drop in the rate of violent crimes such as rape, robbery and assault, the Justice Department said Sunday.

title: People
GANDHI TRIES TO REACH SIKH ACCORD
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi is stepping up the Indian Government's attempt to negotiate with Sikh leaders to avert a confrontation that many fear may occur next weekend.

title: 4th Nuclear Test of Year
description: The Department of Energy announced Saturday that it had tested a nuclear device beneath Rainier Mesa, 93 miles northwest of Las Vegas. It was the fourth nuclear device exploded this year.

title: Thatcher Rejects Plan For Arms Moratorium
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain declared today that a Soviet moratorium on the deployment of medium-range missiles in Europe was unacceptable because it would leave Moscow in a position of overwhelming superiority.

title: SOME UNITS OF JERSEY FIRM SHUT
description: After a day of complex and hectic legal maneuvering, several members of the Bevill, Bresler & Schulman group of securities companies were closed down today by a court order.

title: Amy Carter Arrested
description: Amy Carter, who said she was acting with her father's permission, was arrested today in an anti-apartheid demonstration at the South African Embassy.

title: TAIWAN CONVICTS 2 IN U. S. KILLING
description: A civilian court convicted two reputed gangsters today of planning and carrying out the murder of a Chinese-American writer last year in California. They were sentenced to life in prison.

title: READY TO LIVE UP TO TOWERING IMAGE
description: Dwight Gooden had been told all about the mural. ''But I had to see it,'' he said, ''so I just decided to go that way.'' He was in New York after last season, when he found his way to 42d Street near Ninth Avenue. Suddenly, there he was on the mound, larger than life on the side of a building, one of the few pleasant scenes on that street and certainly one of the most imposing. Even in an area where all sorts of names appear on all kinds of marquees, Gooden became one of the best known while he was still a teen-ager.

title: Music/Noted in Brief ;   Outrage, Go-Go Group, Appears at the Kitchen
description: Washington has begun to export go- go music, the grass-roots urban funk that fills arenas there with dancing teen-agers. The Kitchen, 59 Wooster Street, cleared away its chairs for a show Friday by Outrage, a seven- man Washington go-go band, and the audience didn't stand still for long.

title: CAPITAL TRACING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Year-ago figures not available.

title: MASSACHUSETTS TOWN ADOPTS PROPOSAL TO AID ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: The Cambridge City Council, after a noisy hearing before 200 supporters, voted 5 to 4 tonight to approve a resolution declaring the city a sanctuary to Latin American refugees.

title: SIFTING THROUGH CLAIMS OF I.B.M. COMPATIBILITY
description: WHAT does ''I.B.M. compatible'' really mean? Many computer manufacturers use compatibility as a selling point for their machines, but the term can be misleading. After all, some I.B.M. models are not I.B.M. compatible.

title: RUSSIANS REDEFINE OXFORD ENGLISH
description: An Oxford University dictionary prepared for students learning English in the Soviet Union has been altered by the Russian publishers to change definitions of words such as capitalism and socialism.

title: REVIEW BARS 13.9% OF PAYMENTS BY MEDICARE TO HOSPITALS IN CITY
description: A review program established by Congress to cut Federal health costs is disallowing nearly 14 percent of Medicare payments to hospitals in New York City, primarily because care was unnecessarily prolonged.

title: Gruccis to Trade Land With Suffolk
description: A land swap that would allow the Grucci family to manufacture fireworks on 88 acres in Yaphank was announced today by the Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan.

title: PEACE IS UP TO THE SHIITES
description: Israel is in the final stages of redeploying its army, and soon it will have no troops in Lebanon. This prospect raises a number of questions about our relationship with our Shiite neighbors. We Israelis have made our position clear. The future now depends on the Shiite leadership.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Congress Should Act on Weapons Profiteering
description: To the Editor:

title: A RIVERBOAT GAMBLE
description: In dealing with Congress, Ronald

title: Weeks Stake In Asarco
description: The Federal Trade Commission is investigating whether Weeks Petroleum Ltd., owned by Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian investor, violated Federal antitrust reporting requirements when it bought 8.9 percent of Asarco Inc. common stock, Weeks Petroleum said.

title: Required Reading ;   What to Teach
description: Surely one of our highest charges in teaching is to teach what we ourselves have loved: ''The Call of the Wild,'' ''Beautiful Joe,'' ''Treasure Island,'' ''Swiss Family Robinson,'' ''Huckleberry Finn.'' If we remove this kind of content from our courses, we take away the very things that make students love to be students, and which lead to the improvement of skills.

title: 'CRISIS IN CENTRAL AMERICA,' ON PBS
description: ''CRISIS IN CENTRAL AMERICA'' confronts a question it does not explicitly raise: Is the United States responsible for the crisis? The four-part ''Frontline'' series provides no answer, expecting us to find it ourselves. We can, although we must work at it, perhaps harder than we may wish. The series, beginning on Channel 13 at 9 tonight, continues through Friday.

title: U.S. RENEWS STRESS ON ADVANCE PLANS FOR SUMMIT TALKS
description: The Reagan Administration said today it was pleased that Mikhail S. Gorbachev had agreed in principle to meet with President Reagan but that ''much serious work'' is needed before a meeting is arranged.

title: THYSSEN'S BIG PUSH TO REVITALIZE BUDD
description: After Thyssen A.G., the big West German steelmaker, bought the Budd Company here in 1978, its new American possession was hit by an unexpected one-two punch.

title: Fannie Mae Plans Offering of Stock
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, announced plans yesterday to offer about seven million common shares through a group of underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: Agency Rejects 3d Hudson Tunnel
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday rejected a proposal for a third tunnel under the Hudson River to connect New Jersey and Manhattan.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals , at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Dwight Gooden, last year's National League rookie of the year, goes against Joaquin Andujar in the sold-out season opener. Vice President Bush, the former Yale first baseman, is scheduled to throw out the first ball.

title: F.C.C. to Review Storer Decision
description: The Federal Communications Commission said it would review a staff decision allowing dissident shareholders in Storer Communications Inc. to solicit proxies in an effort to oust the Storer board.

title: SMOKERS HAVE RIGHTS, TOO
description: Enough is enough, and we have seen enough of the harassment and intimidation of smokers.

title: DELAYED SHUTTLE TO LIFT OFF FRIDAY
description: AFTER five postponements in two months, the next space shuttle mission is set for launching Friday morning with a crew of seven ready to deliver two satellites to orbit and conduct several a biological and physiological experiments.

title: PROSTATE, BANE OF AGING MEN, IS YIELDING TO NEW TREATMENTS
description: DISORDERS of the prostate, which sooner or later afflict virtually every man who lives long enough, are yielding to improved treatments with far less risk, especially of impotence, a dreaded side effect that has long kept many victims from seeking the most effective remedies.

title: INFOVIEW INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-No comparable year-ago figures because the company completed its initial public offering in October 1984.

title: U. S. WEAPONS MAKERS RING UP HEALTHY PROFITS
description: The nation's largest military contractors, whose high earnings are being questioned by the Pentagon and Congress, enjoyed a rate of profit last year that was much greater than the average for industrial corporations, according to corporate annual reports.

title: Talent From the Colonies
description: An ancestor of his sailed on the Mayflower. He was elected president of one of the nation's oldest universities. He followed John Adams's footsteps as Ambassador to the Court of St. James's.

title: Restraint Advised By Unocal
description: The Unocal Corporation advised its stockholders today ''not to act hastily'' in response to a $3.46 billion offer by an investment group led by T. Boone Pickens to acquire majority control of the oil company.

title: Gold Trader Prison Term
description: One of the men who ran the failed International Gold Bullion Exchange was sentenced today to six years in prison on fraud charges and ordered to repay $2.3 million to the company's former customers.

title: Business and the Law;   Lawyers' Fees In Bhopal Case
description: AS if the legal profession did not get enough public criticism about venality, lawyers in perhaps the biggest personal injury suit ever are squabbling with each other over clients, fees and legal control of hundreds of thousands of poor, injured foreigners.

title: MUSTANG DRILLING & EXPLORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Du Pont in Joint Venture
description: Du Pont Japan Ltd. and the Mitsubishi Gas Chemical Company have signed a letter of intent to form a joint venture in Japan to produce and sell a key material used in polyimide products, Du Pont said today.

title: KNOWLEDGE: IT'S NOW CHIC
description: MANHATTAN'S social elites are sharply divided between those who have a sure grasp of world affairs and those who don't. But the information explosion is brightening some of the darker corners. Even the dimwits seem to feel they need to know something more than who went where wearing what for dinner last night.

title: Nelson P. Rose, 75, Is Dead; General Counsel at Treasury
description: Nelson P. Rose, a former general counsel of the Treasury Department, died April 6 of a viral infection at Naples Community Hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 75 years old.

title: Debt Issues
description: Durr-Fillauer Medical Inc. has filed an offering of $30 million of convertible subordinated debentures, through underwriters led by E.F. Hutton.

title: NATIONAL HARDGOODS DISTRIBUTOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-After tax credits of $14,000 for the quarter and $152,000 for the year. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in October 1984 and a 5-for-4 split paid in April 1984.

title: SEATTLE TRUST & SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HONDURAS AS ALLY: A BLOT ON THE IMAGE
description: The handful of riot policemen who stood on guard in front of the Supreme Court building here this week did not look nearly so frightening as the tight- lipped soldiers who patrol the streets of San Salvador or Guatemala City. But their presence reflected the difficulty Honduras faces as it seeks to consolidate civilian rule.

title: CABINET APPROVES MORE U.S. JOB CUTS
description: Reagan Administration officials today approved a plan to cut 80,000 Federal jobs through attrition over the next three years.

title: Wafer-Mounted Chips
description: Mosaic Systems Inc. said today that it had developed an alternative to the conventional circuit board on which computer chips are mounted. Mosaic's process uses microscopic current conductors deposited on a wafer rather than using wires to link chips.

title: Sallie Mae Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $275 million of floating-rate notes due Oct. 10, 1985, at a price of 100. The interest will not be paid until maturity but will be adjusted weekly to two-tenths of a percentage point above the bond equivalent yield of 91- day Treasury bills.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $5,124 for the quarter and $81,493 for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $66,237 for the quarter and $134,196 for the 9 months and extraordinary tax credits of $14,190 and $97,810 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The year-ago sales exclude DME Equipment discontinued product line.

title: A's Ban Norris
description: Oakland A's pitcher

title: Sambito Is Released
description: Joe Sambito, one of the top relief pitchers in Houston Astros history, was given his unconditional release yesterday after he declined to accept a move to the National League club's Class AAA affiliate at Tucson. Sambito, who is 32, had been attempting a comeback from a series of elbow operations.

title: DOW JONES & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Missourian Shoots Fugitives Who Tried to Steal His Truck
description: The flight of two men who had escaped from an Arkansas prison ended after they were shot by a man who stopped to help them with their car and found himself facing their rifles, officials say.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -minute opera about murder, but not quite a murder mystery. To the contrary, it is a bit of comedic nonsense created by Gertrude Stein and, in 1971, turned into an opera by Ned Rorem. It is rarely performed, but it will be staged tonight at 8 o'clock by the Center for Contemporary Opera in the Universalist Church at Central Park West at 76th Street.

title: Lawsuit Against Zellerbach Filed
description: Two shareholders of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation filed a suit against the company in an attempt to rescind the company's so-called poison pill provision.

title: Evans Products
description: The Evans Products Company said it had completed agreements with its lenders providing $50 million in revolving credit agreements to members of its retail group, including Grossman's Inc. and Evans Steel City Inc. Evans Products, which is controlled by the Miami investor Victor Posner, previously filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws. Evans said its units would have the money available until Nov. 30 to finance their seasonal working capital needs.

title: Long-Distance Phone Plan Backed
description: The Justice Department endorsed a plan today under which customers who do not choose a carrier to handle their long-distance phone service would be automatically allocated to one of several companies, including the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SUDANESE UNIONS CALL OFF STRIKE THAT LED TO COUP
description: Unions representing professional workers in the Sudan formally called off a five-day general strike tonight that helped touch off the overthrow of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry on Saturday.

title: 'NEW' METS TO FACE ANDUJAR
description: The Mets will open their season in style and clamor today with Vice President Bush in the club box, Dwight Gooden on the mound, 14 players on the roster who were not there a year ago and a sellout crowd of more than 50,000 in Shea Stadium.

title: BECK SAYS HE'S 100 PERCENT FOR PLAYOFFS
description: With the mellifluous sounds of a new baseball season wafting from the radio, Barry Beck strutted through the Ranger dressing room and heaved his stick a few feet toward his locker and his gloves toward the wall. The serenity of spring was shattered.

title: GORBACHEV CRITICAL OF SOVIET ECONOMY INT HE FIRST QUARTER
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, called today for discipline, efficiency and accountability in the economy.

title: Addenda
description: * New Woman magazine's rate base will increase 15 percent, to 1.15 million, with its August issue, and its advertising rates will also increase 15 percent.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Bonds With Put Option From Aetna's Portfolio
description: Prudential-Bache Securities yesterday began offering $201 million of long-term bonds with a put option, allowing investors to redeem the bonds in three or four years at various prices. The bonds, with maturities ranging from 20 to 30 years, were part of the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company's investment portfolio.

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontined operations of $2.1 million. The year-earlier results were restated for the discontinuance of the company's videodisc pressing operations and the CBS musical instruments division.

title: Official to Quit Federated Unit Federated Department
description: Stores Inc. said Bruce M.

title: Marine Bank Insurance Plan The Marine Midland Bank
description: said yesterday that it had arranged to offer a wide range of

title: AT OLD BALL GAME, NEW BREW IS NO HIT
description: Low-alcohol beer was the only intoxicating beverage sold at Tiger Stadium today, the opening day of the baseball season. Team officials said the new brew would curb rowdiness, but some fans complained that it tasted weak and bitter.

title: Arraignment Is Set In Tulane Case
description: Arraignment of the eight defendants in the Tulane point-shaving case has been scheduled for next Monday.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
PETROMINERALS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
FOLLIES ON ICE: RELIEF FOR ARCTIC ANGST
description: When Hans Lennie ran his vehicle into a boat, damaging both and winding up in a ditch, his mishap was awarded nine points. Dan Norris, who only skidded off the road, earned a modest three points. Both men were cited in ''In the Ditch,'' the best- read column of The Inuvik Drum, a weekly newspaper in Canada's most northerly major town.

title: Boeing Vetrol
description: The Boeing Vetrol Company, a subsidiary of the Boeing Company, said it had received a five-year, $1.17 billion procurement contract from the Army to remanufacture 240 early-model Chinook helicopters. The award is part of the Army's plan to modernize 436 CH-47's through the early 1990's. The rebuilding process involves removing the rotors, engines, transmissions and other assemblies as well as stripping the frames and inspecting the aircraft for defects.

title: Senator Moynihan and the Children
description: On the left, the Democrats buzz about how their party must reinvent itself, rightward. On the right, Republicans puff about the need to hack more from social welfare programs. Who speaks for the center, on issues of profound national concern? No one, until last night.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 9, 1985 International

title: Long Lasting
description: As every son of a baseball fan knows, spring in New York does not officially begin until this afternoon, when the Metropolitans kick things off out in Flushing. And, as every son of a Met fan knows, spring promises to look greener this year than it has for any of the last 15, ever since the day when the National League locals opened up as defending world champions.

title: Job Search
description: Herb Brooks, the former Ranger coach, has expressed interest in the coaching vacancy at the University of Minnesota, where he coached from 1972 to 1979.

title: NOW HE'S NO. 1: SIWAR EL-DAHAB
description: When Gen. Siwar el-Dahab was promoted to be the Sudan's Minister of Defense and Chief of Staff of the army three weeks ago, he was viewed by many Sudanese and foreign diplomats as a loyalist who would stand by the teetering presidency of Gaafar al-Nimeiry.

title: A 'FREQUENT FLIER' TAX IS UNDER STUDY FOR I. R. S.
description: The Internal Revenue Service will hear testimony next week on whether ''frequent flier'' programs that provide free flights to passengers ought to be viewed as taxable fringe benefits to participants.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a loss of $1,084,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Affluence and the Homeless
description: Spreading into affluent neighborhoods and, thus, into middle-class consciousness, the city's homeless now touch most New Yorkers.

title: FIRST LINE OF PROTECTION FOR DEFENSE CHIEFS ET AL
description: The standard mode of operation, according to Muriel Hartley, is candy first, then flowers.

title: FOREIGN TV SHOWS SEEN AS TEACHING TOOL
description: WHEN we turned on the television during a recent trip to Italy, we were startled to hear a tough Brooklyn cop address a suspected criminal in elegant dubbed-in Italian. Such transplanted American programs, along with commercials for familiar products, did more than any travel dictionary to improve our deplorable Italian.

title: FERROVANADIUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the primary cause for the increased net loss for the first 6 months of the latest fiscal year was a foreign exchange loss of $187,189, compared with foreign exchange gains of $162,954 for year- earlier period. All figures including the results and footnotes are in Australian dollars. As of Dec. 31, 1984, the Australian dollar was exchangeable for 83 cents in U.S. currency.

title: Cubs Are Ready
description: From most perspectives, everything will be familiar in Wrigley Field today when the Chicago Cubs open their baseball season against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Closings Most foreign
description: stock markets

title: THE SUIT IS HEADING FOR NEW LIFE THIS FALL
description: The suit is the daytime style endorsed by designers throughout the European fashion collections for fall and winter. They have focused on the jacket with either skirt or trousers as the most useful fashion for board meetings, business lunches and more frivolous pursuits such as shopping.

title: ELECTRICITY MAY PLAY ROLE IN PLANT GROWTH
description: ELECTRICITY plays a vital role in transmitting nerve signals in every animal species on earth, but plants too seem to be influenced by electric current, even though they have no nervous systems. Research workers are finding evidence that plant cells' sensitivity to electric current can be exploited to enhance their growth.

title: THE DOORMAN'S BATTING ORDER
description: BOSTON

title: Datapoint Plan
description: Asher B. Edelman, chairman of the Datapoint Corporation, said the cost-reduction program announced by the board April 1 would involve further reductions in the company's work force and reductions of $40 million in operating expenses. But, he said, the program should return the company to profitability soon.

title: NATIONAL BANCORP OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BANCO DE PONCE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AROUND THE WORLD ;   Neves's Condition 'Good,' Spokesman Says
description: President-elect Tancredo Neves, who is recovering from five abdominal operations in three weeks and the resulting complications, was in good condition today, the Government spokesman reported.

title: JURY SELECTION STARTS IN SECOND TRIAL OF VON BULOW
description: Jury selection began here today for the second trial of Claus von B"ulow on charges of trying to murder his wife, Martha, with insulin injections in 1979 and 1980.

title: 13 ARE NAMED WINNERS OF MEDAL OF FREEDOM
description: President Reagan has named the entertainer Frank Sinatra, the actor James Stewart, the Nobel Peace Prize winner Mother Teresa and 10 others as recipients of the nation's highest civilian award, it was announced today.

title: Judge Approves Starrett Accord
description: A Federal judge has approved an out-of-court settlement under which the 5,900-unit Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn may continue a renting policy that it says maintains racial integration by keeping a majority of its apartments occupied by white families.

title: HOTTEST KNOWN STAR HOTTER THAN THOUGHT TEMPE, Ariz., April 8 (AP) - A codiscoverer of the hottest known star says it appears to be even hotter than first thought and may be evolving so rapidly that scientists will be able to watch its death over the next decade. Sumner Starrfield, an Arizona State University physics professor, said in an interview published today by the Tempe Daily News that the star known as K1-16 is in the Draco constellation, near the Little Dipper.
description: Dr. Starrfield, Edward Sion, a visiting associate physics professor at Arizona State, and scientists Arthur Cox and Russell Kidman of New Mexico's Los Alamos National Laboratory, announced the discovery of K1-16 in December. They estimated then that the star's surface temperature was about 300,000 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Service to Buy Showroom Units
description: The Service Merchandise Company, a catalogue showroom operator based in Nashville, has agreed to acquire two other showroom operators.

title: ARMS DEALERS DOUBLED OUTLAYS UNDER REAGAN
description: The nation's largest military contractors have doubled their political donations since President Reagan took office, with the top 20 companies pouring $3.6 million into 1984 Congressional and Presidential campaigns.

title: RED SOX ROUT YANKS IN OPENER WITH 3 HOME RUNS
description: Snow played games with the opening games of the baseball season today, but following an overnight snow that decorated Fenway Park, the Boston Red Sox rained home runs on the Yankees and thrashed them, 9-2.

title: 2 NAMED FOUR-STAR GENERALS
description: President Reagan has nominated and the Senate has approved the promotion to the rank of four-star general two retired lieutenant generals, James H. Doolittle and Ira C. Eaker, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Lotus Set to Acquire Software Arts
description: Software Arts, the company that rose to stardom in the computer industry when it developed the Visicalc spreadsheet program, yesterday became the latest victim of the software industry shakeout.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
Silver Anvil Award For Artificial Heart
description: The Humana Heart Institute submitted its world-renowned first artificial heart implant for a Silver Anvil Award of the Public Relations Society of America under the Business subcategory of Institutional Programs.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Atlanta Police Union Files Suit Over Test
description: A predominantly white police union asked a Federal judge today to force the city to promote police officers according to results of a recent test.

title: INTERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $20 million for an asset redeployment program.

title: CARBIDE IS SUED IN U.S. BY INDIA IN GAS DISASTER
description: The Government of India filed suit against the Union Carbide Corporation yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, seeking compensation for the victims of the Dec. 3 gas leak at the Union Carbide pesticide plant in Bhopal, India.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Rates Mixed in Light Activity
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday with yields falling slightly or holding steady for Treasury issues due in two years or less, but rising slightly for longer term issues.

title: Music/Noted in Brief ;   Meredith d'Ambrosio, Upstairs at Greene St.
description: When the cabaret room Upstairs at Greene Street (103 Greene Street) brings in a performer to do a single one-hour show, as it did Thursday evening with Meredith d'Ambrosio, the situation does not allow a reserved and somewhat withdrawn person like Miss d'Ambrosio to appear at best advantage.

title: WHEN A CHILD'S SLEEP TURNS TO TERROR
description: EVERY night at bedtime, Michael Espach's parents braced themselves for his tortured sleep. His thunderous snoring, interrupted by gasps for breath, frightened the Espaches more than his thrashing and crying. Michael's pediatrician hoped he would grow out of the condition, but by his second birthday, it only seemed to get worse.

title: U.S. Agency to Check A Purported Unicorn
description: The Federal Department of Agriculture said yesterday that it would inspect a circus animal billed as a ''living unicorn,'' the mythical one- horned horselike animal.

title: MARYLAND IS OPENED TO CITICORP
description: Citicorp today won a monthlong lobbying battle that pitted it and Gov. Harry Hughes against Maryland's bankers. In an overwhelming vote, the state's Legislature passed landmark legislation that will give the nation's largest banking concern full banking powers in Maryland and direct access to the lucrative Baltimore-Washington market.

title: Betty D. Boegehold, 71, Dies; Writer of Books for Children
description: Betty Doyle Boegehold, a children's book writer and director of the Bank Street Writers Workshop, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at her home in Bronxville, N.Y. She was 71 years old.

title: Cureton Is Suspended
description: Earl Cureton , the Detroit Pistons' center, was suspended for one game and fined $2,500 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for elbowing

title: ATE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
BRIEFING ;   The Faces of Queens
description: For many Americans, Queens,

title: 2 HITS, 3 R. B. I. FOR ROSE
description: Pete Rose, who will be 44 years old next Sunday, drove in three runs with a double and a single today to lead the Cincinnati Reds to a 4-1 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: GORBACHEV ON STAGE
description: With a piece of well-timed diplomacy addressed largely to Western Europe, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, has quickly shown himself ready to challenge President Reagan in the court of international public relations. Officially, members of the Reagan Administration have brushed aside Mr. Gorbachev's six- month moratorium on missile deployment in Europe as nothing new and have accused him of breaking the confidentiality of the Geneva arms talks by making public part of the Soviet neby making public part of the Soviet negotiating position.

title: ANTI-SANDINISTA INDIANS REPORTED QUITTING BATTLE
description: Miskito Indian rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Army are disenchanted with their leaders and have largely stopped their guerrilla operations in recent months, two former rebel commanders say.

title: 'Surf City' Halts Previews
description: ''Surf City,'' a musical using compositions by the Beach Boys, has suspended previews indefinitely and will go into full-time rehearsals, a spokesman for the production said yesterday. The show began previews on March 28 at the Entermedia Theater, 189 Second Avenue. No date was announced for resumption of previews and for the show's opening.

title: QUAREX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $95,543. Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in December 1984.

title: MOORE FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects an extraordinary charge of $6,000,000 to increase provision for credit losses and a tax credit of $990,000.

title: STERLING COS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Latest year results reflect the acquisition of an automobile dealership and the opening of a state-chartered savings and loan.

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes income from the company's interest in the Angel Engineering Corp. of $17,686 for the quarter and $20,390 for the 9 months. c-Includes income of $7,417 for the quarter and $26,842 for the 9 months.

title: Article 152413 -- No Title
description: Cox Communications Inc. yesterday became the latest media company to enter the acquisition spotlight, as the Cox family offered $75 a share, or a total of $1.2 billion, for the 55 percent of the broadcaster that it does not already own.

title: TRUST COMPANY OF GEORGIA (MET LEBANON, PA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FINANCIAL PROGRAMS ARE NOT ALL WINNERS
description: THE difference between what a computer can really do and what people think it can do is sometimes staggering, particularly when those people are novices in the black-magic world of electronics. I remember watching an elderly businessman in a computer store as, checkbook in hand, he prepared to plunk down close to $10,000 for his first computer system. The salesman's three-hour demonstration of how a data base management system could completely meet the man's mailing list requirements was about to be amply rewarded when the customer asked a question that must have seemed startlingly naive to the salesman.

title: Owners Meet On Seabrook
description: The owners of the Seabrook nuclear power plant, at a meeting today, reaffirmed their commitment to completing the plant's first reactor, a project spokesman said.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a loss of $127,186 from discontinued operations. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 4.

title: CAMBODIA FORGOTTEN (2)
description: ''Now let's look at Cambodia. We've made a conscious decision not to send American troops in. There will be no American combat troops or advisers in Cambodia. We will aid Cambodia. Cambodia is the Nixon Doctrine in its purest form. . . . in Cambodia what we are doing is helping the Cambodians to help themselves.'' - President Richard Nixon, at a press conference, Nov. 15, 1971.

title: Anti-Sandinista Calls Reagan Plan Acid Test
description: An anti-Sandinista leader said in New York yesterday that proposals for talks on the guerrilla war represent ''the acid test'' for the Nicaraguan Government.

title: Theology Clarified
description: Theology according to Mayor Koch on Sunday morning at the Mount Nebo Baptist Church, on Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard near 114th Street in Harlem:

title: Chess: From Solid Play to Disaster: The Course of Many a Game
description: The inside story of many a game goes this way: Reasonably solid play has produced a fairly even position that seems to be heading for a draw; but the opponent is ambitious and works to develop an attack; after some anxious moments, a fully adequate defense is thought out; overcome by new confidence, it is our turn to be overoptimistic and the opponent sharply metes out the proper punishment; full of self-recrimination, we fail to find the best defense and blunder into disaster.

title: TELECONFERENCING SYSTEM INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BRIEFING ;   Helen Hayes Awards
description: Sir Oliver Wright, the British Ambassador, and Lady Wright are

title: State Lottery Division Adds 'Struck by Luck' Daily Game
description: The State Lottery Division announced today that it would begin a new instant lottery game, ''Struck by Luck,'' in which players can win up to $1 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 9, 1985

title: SOUTH LEBANON CEASE-FIRE CALL IS FUTILE
description: Factional fighting continued in the Sidon area in southern Lebanon today despite a call by Moslem and Christian leaders for an immediate cease-fire.

title: Sanctuary Leader Enters Jail
description: A leader in the sanctuary movement, Jack Elder, today began serving a 150- day Federal prison sentence for helping two Salvadoran aliens enter the United States. Mr. Elder, 41 years old, was greeted by supporters as he arrived at the Halfway House of San Antonio, where he is to serve his sentence. He has been director of Casa Oscar Romero, a shelter for Central Americans in San Benito, Tex.

title: It Is Up to Courts to Rule on Lawyer Involvement in Mob Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: STRONG IMPRESSION IS LEFT BY WALKER
description: Doug Flutie handed the football to Herschel Walker and then commenced his ''vacation,'' the word he chose in describing his role in the Generals' 31-25 victory Sunday over the Houston Gamblers.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article March 4 about defensive space weapons misstated Dr. Edward Teller's role in the founding of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. It was founded by the United States Government, primarily at the urging of Dr. Teller and Ernest O. Lawrence, who was a physicist at the University of California, according to the public affairs office at the laboratory.

title: CPC International Sues McKesson
description: CPC International Inc. said it had filed suit in New York against the McKesson Corporation, three former McKesson executives and Morgan, Stanley & Company.

title: ITT Will Sell 12 Companies The ITT Corporation said
description: yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to sell 12 industrial companies for $370 million

title: Dow Retreats 6.07 Points, to 1,252.98
description: Stock prices closed lower yesterday on Wall Street in light post-holiday trading. The market was reacting in part, analysts said, to investors' reassessment of the announcement last Thursday that the White House and Republicans in Congress had reached an agreement on cuts in the Federal budget.

title: Jesuit Shortage Is Less Severe on West Coast
description: To the Editor:

title: Playing Father
description: Coach Chuck Daly of the Detroit Pistons explains how you try to keep a playoff-bound but struggling team on the right track: ''I've had more heart-to-heart talks with these guys than with my daughter of 19 years.''

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 9, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bridge: A Sextet Fit Together Well To Fashion Upset Victories
description: Whether 26 cards fit well together is a vital question in bidding success. Whether six players fit well together is a vital question in tournament success.

title: STRONG QUAKE JOLTS CHILE
description: An earthquake jolted Chile for three minutes during the supper hour today, sending hundreds of people into the streets. One man died of a heart attack. The quake measured 7.4 on the Richter scale and was centered in the ocean off the coast near Pichilemu, 100 miles southwest of Santiago.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SIMON BID REJECTED
description: Multimedia Inc., a major broadcasting and publishing company, said yesterday that an investor group that includes members of the founding families and senior management had increased its offer for the company to about $54 a share, or $900 million, from the $49.50 a share offered earlier this year. At the same time the company confirmed that it had rejected an offer of $60 a share, or a total of $1 billion, from Wesray Inc., a New Jersey investment company headed by former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon.

title: Coming and Goings
description: The Minnesota Twins have signed

title: BANKER, GUILTY ON LOAN, IS ASSESSED $516,235
description: The former president of a large Georgia bank pleaded guilty today to Federal criminal charges that he made an unauthorized $900,000 loan to finance a new life insurance company he had founded.

title: BENEFICIAL STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $31,368,000 on the disposal of certain insurance businesses. c-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $5,662,000 for the quarter and $12,109,000 for the year.d-After income from discontinued operations of $4,008,000 and a loss on disposal of insurance business of $13,147,000. The losses on disposal of insurance businesses in the latest fourth quarter and year included provision of $47,140,000, less applicable income tax credit of $4,987,000, for writeoff of investment in a property-casualty subsidiary held for sale.

title: Eagleton Has Heart Atta
description: Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, suffered a mild heart attack over the weekend and today was reported to be in good condition at the Bethesda Naval Hospital. Mr. Eagleton, 55 years old, is ''in excellent spirits'' and is expected to remain in the hospital 10 days, officials said.

title: Races Resuming At Monticello
description: Monticello Raceway will resume its winter meeting as the parimutuel clerks strike continued at Yonkers Raceway, track officials announced today.

title: LERNER CANCELS ALL ORDERS
description: The Lerner Stores, the 800-shop apparel retailer acquired last Tuesday by The Limited Inc., yesterday canceled all outstanding orders to the trade in an unusual action taken to re- examine its business and determine its direction under the new ownership.

title: Louisiana Democrat in House To Seek Senator Long's Seat
description: Representative John B. Breaux, a Democrat who is the senior member of Louisiana's delegation to the House, said today that he would run next year for the Senate seat being vacated by Russell B. Long, who is retiring.

title: AARON RENTS OF ATLANTA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CAVALIERS' BAGLEY TURNS JEERS TO CHEERS
description: During a timeout in the Cleveland Cavaliers' game against the Washington Bullets last Tuesday night, the crowd at the Coliseum in Richfield, Ohio, gave John Bagley, the once-maligned Cavalier playmaker, a standing ovation.

title: Berkline Corporation Replaces Its President
description: The Berkline Corporation, a maker of reclining chairs and other furniture, has named Charles S. Shaughnessy Jr. president and chief executive officer, effective immediately. He replaces Lawrence W. Whalen Jr., who said he had resigned in a ''parting of the ways'' with the company's board.

title: CBS PLANS FOUR SERIES FOR AUGUST
description: CBS yesterday announced that it would introduce four new series in August, moving the network closer to the 52-week television season it has forecast for some time.

title: JURY IN L. I. CASE IS GIVEN DETAILS OF RITUAL DEATH
description: The deputy medical examiner of Suffolk County testified today that Gary Lauwers was either held down or otherwise ''incapacitated'' last summer when he was stabbed at least 32 times in a wooded area in Northport.

title: DATATAB INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
THE PHILHARMONIC RETURNS TO A CHURCH IN HARLEM
description: Zubin Mehta and the members of the New York Philharmonic say there's nothing quite like Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church for glorious, wraparound sound and the sheer joy of making and hearing music.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Vote Recount Resumes On Disputed House Seat
description: The Federal recount of a disputed Congressional election resumed today, with each candidate saying that the new tally may not settle the race.

title: BRIEFING ;   Neglected Champs
description: The White House tossed up an

title: SCHULMAN, A INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Loews Negotiating To Sell Theaters
description: The Loews Corporation confirmed today that it was negotiating to sell its Loews Theaters division to a group headed by A. Jerrold Perenchio, a producer and co-owner of Embassy Communications.

title: SYSTEM FOR DETECTING UNSTABLE CITY POLICE RAISES SOME DOUBTS
description: Tucked away in a row of filing cabinets on the 10th floor of Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan are the names and records of some 2,100 police officers. Labeled ''Personnel Concerns,'' the files are a key element in an early warning system used to try to uncover emotionally unstable officers.

title: PENTAGON PLAN TO CONTROL SCIENTIFIC DATA DISPUTED
description: Many engineering and scientific associations may be subject to Government efforts to restrict access to research papers that do not contain Government secrets, a Defense Department official said today.

title: 41 Shuttle Flights Set, Including First by a Teacher
description: An American teacher chosen to fly aboard the space shuttle will make the trip next January, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration says.

title: The Sudan After the Fall
description: There is a textbook quality to the decline and fall of President Nimeiry, the soldier who dominated the Sudan for 16 years. Last week he risked a visit to Washington despite clear warnings of trouble at home. Food riots and a general strike darkened Khartoum. He finally hurried homeward, but too late. General Nimeiry now sits in Cairo, brooding about his ouster by General Dahab, his hand- picked Defense Minister. And the new regime proclaims its earnest hope for better times, free elections and ''dialogue'' with the disaffected.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Mediators Named In State Deadlock
description: At the state's request, two mediators were appointed today to break a deadlock in contract talks with the 52,000-member Public Employees Federation.

title: ALLIED TO SELL HALF OF OIL UNIT
description: The Allied Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell half of its Union Texas Petroleum Corporation to an investment group led by the New York investment firm of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company for $1.7 billion.

title: TOKYO'S MARKET ENTRY PLAN
description: Japan's Government completed work today on a package of measures intended to head off complaints that the Japanese market is closed to foreign products.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   U.N. Chief Meets With Iraqi President
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations met with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today to seek an end to the four-and- a-half-year Persian Gulf war.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: HELENE DEUTSCH. A Psychoanalyst's

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Tractor Executive To Join Marmon
description: David D. Koentopf, the president and chief executive who has led Steiger Tractor Inc. in difficult times, will leave the company in June to take ''a senior executive position'' with Marmon Group, the Chicago conglomerate controlled by the Pritzker family.

title: Market Place;   Northwest's Spinoff Delay
description: NORTHWEST INDUSTRIES, the Chicago consumer and industrial products company, had investors whirling in confusion last year when it held protracted and unsuccessful negotiations for its takeover. Analysts say shareholders are again bewildered, this time over the spinoff of its Lone Star Steel Company subsidiary.

title: Robert Hume a Partner In Wexler McCarron
