description: Robert Hume, 48 years old, a New York agency executive who has always been keen to be in business for himself, has left the big city to find his fortune in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: ENLISTMENT DECLINE BRINGS CALL FOR NEW DRAFT
description: The Defense Department, after four years of increasingly successful recruiting, is finding that young men and women have become less interested in enlisting in the armed forces.

title: DEADLY LUNG AILMENT HAS BATTLEFIELD ORIGINS
description: It is an often fatal lung condition

title: Jersey Crime Rate Continues Decline
description: The rate of reported crimes in New Jersey decreased by 6 percent in 1984 compared with 1983, Governor Kean announced today. The decline continued a pattern shown in the last three annual reports compiled by the state police.

title: Underground Mystery
description: To the Editor:

NOTES ON FASHION
description: PERRY ELLIS is a designer who

title: DEVILS ARE HAPPY WITH IMPROVEMENT
description: The Devils are no longer ''easy picking.''

title: For the Fans
description: Largely lost amid the news of Jimmy Connors's injury-induced default Sunday was that his opponent, John McEnroe, mindful that 6,000 fans had shown up for the final at the Chicago Pavilion, beseeched the organizers to round up somebody who could give the people a show. Eliot Teltscher, an early-round loser to Mike Bauer, was still in town, and he agreed to the exhibition, for which neither player, according to Grand Prix officials, received any extra money. Final score: McEnroe 8, Teltscher 7.

title: MICROSIZE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income.

title: WOLF, HOWARD B INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $28,060.

title: 2 SITCOMS: 'LUCIE ARNAZ' AND 'HAIL TO THE CHIEF'
description: TUESDAY'S new sitcoms are offering a menu of sweet and sour television. At 8 P.M., ''The Lucie Arnaz Show,'' introduced by CBS last week, stars the always ingratiating Miss Arnaz as a psychologist who not only writes an advice column but also takes calls from listeners on her own radio program. She is, in other words, a successful career woman. This is the sweet one. Then, getting under way at 9:30 this evening on ABC, ''Hail to the Chief'' features Patty Duke as the first female President of the United States, surrounded by assorted misfits in a format that is intended to be, as they like to say, zany and irreverent. This one's sour, to say the least.

title: FIRST ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quake on Coast
description: A mild earthquake centered a few miles off shore rocked a Southern California coastal area early today, the area's second quake in 24 hours, but no one reported feeling the temblor, the officials said.

title: STAGE: A ROCK REPRISE IN 'LEADER OF THE PACK'
description: ALTHOUGH there are as yet no candidates in the competition for best musical of the Broadway season, the race for most calamitous musical has gained a strong new contender with ''Leader of the Pack,'' a purported tribute to golden rock-and-roll oldies at the Ambassador. While not as pointless as ''The Three Musketeers'' or as lengthy as ''Harrigan 'n Hart'' or as becalmed as ''Quilters,'' this show does lead the pack in such key areas as incoherence (total), vulgarity (boundless) and decibel level (stratospheric, with piercing electronic feedback).

title: A RARE HABITAT IN ASHES
description: GALAPAGOS ISLANDS, Ecuador THE manmade inferno that has ravaged the largest island in the Galapagos group for the last month seems finally to be more or less under control. But the unique plants and animals that make these islands a natural laboratory of evolution have suffered losses from which some groups may never recover.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Alienable Rights
description: The Orlando Renegades have decided not to sign

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The bottom line is that in this day of people fearing episodes in ballparks, we want them to know it's not a place to go to get drunk or be rowdy.''

title: Article 152093 -- No Title
description: The Ford and Rockefeller Foundations and the Carnegie Corporation have teamed up with several major companies doing business here to announce the creation of the Puerto Rico Community Foundation, the first community foundation on the island.

title: Payments Stopped on Loan to Brazil
description: The World Bank has stopped disbursements on nearly $500 million of loan commitments for development of Brazil's northwest frontier because conditions for protection of Indians and the environment have not been met, according to members of Congress and environmental groups.

title: U.S. AIDES SEE SUDAN COUP AS 'PRE-EMPTIVE' MOVE
description: United States officials said today that the military leaders of the Sudan decided to oust President Gaafar al-Nimeiry on Saturday to forestall a move by younger military officers who were plotting a purge of the country's leadership.

title: Israel Says It Favors a Role In U.S. 'Star Wars' Research
description: Israel said today that it would have a ''positive attitude'' toward President Reagan's invitation to join the research program on a space-based missile defense.

title: We're Killing One Another at a Great Rate
description: To the Editor:

description: Andres Segovia dropped by the New

title: CPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
HAWAII TAPS NEW POWER SOURCES
description: KAMUELA, Hawaii THE 30,000 acres of Kahua Ranch here produce cattle, dairy products, sheep, carnations and up to two million watts of power to the Big Island's electric grid.

title: LLOYDS BANK
description: Lloyds Bank P.L.C. of Britain said it was considering the sale of its James Talcott Inc. factoring and commercial finance unit in the United States. The company said it had retained Merrill Lynch Capital Markets to assist in the transaction. The company said Talcott, which had been consistantly profitable since its acquisition in 1980, had factoring volume of $1.3 billion last year.

title: BRIEFS
Q&A

title: JACKSON LEADS PEACEFUL PROTEST OF FARM FORECLOSURE
description: After a fiery speech by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, more than 1,000 farmers and sympathizers chanted ''no sale'' at a farm foreclosure auction here today, then stood quietly as Perry Wilson, 73 years old, saw his home and 127 acres bid away by his banker.

title: LIMELIGHT FALLS UPON SUSAN BAKER'S GOSPEL WORK
description: In this city's trellis of liaisons to the powerful, Susan Baker has become a most unusual go-between. For many in trouble, the wife of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has acted as a quiet intermediary both to the top echelon of the Administration and to higher authorities.

title: DANCE: GRAHAM'S 'FRONIER' REVIVED
description: THIS year marks the 50th anniversary of the first collaboration between Martha Graham and Isamu Noguchi. The distinguished sculptor has created so many set designs and sculpture for the great choreographer's works that it is easy to forget how evolutionary and revolutionary that association has been.

title: How Not to Lower Wages
description: Item : Pan Am's new contract with its flight attendants provides a modest pay increase to current employees but will pay newly hired attendants 37 percent less.

title: BRIEFING ;   New Envoy Expected
description: Winston Lord, who was a top assistant to Henry A. Kissinger, is expected to be named Ambassador to China, according to State Department officials.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Yugoslavs Go on Trial For Independence Plot VARAZDIN, Yugoslavia, April 8 - Eleven people went on trial here today on charges of planting explosives and engaging in hostile propaganda to gain independence for the Yugoslav republic of Croatia.
description: The indictment charges the principal defendant, Stjepan Deglin, 40 years old, with being a member of three Ustashi organizations in West Germany. The Croatian group called Ustashi, which has led a long struggle for Croatian independence, set up a separate Croatian state in World War II with support from Nazi Germany. Mr. Deglin is accused of smuggling into Yugoslavia explosive devices, weapons, anti-Communist books and hostile leaflets, the Tanyug press agency said.

title: GOLD TOPS OUTLAWS
description: Bill Johnson rushed for a team-record 165 yards and a touchdown tonight, and the Denver offense gained 478 yards as the Gold defeated the Arizona Outlaws, 28-7.

title: BONANZA FROM HAGLER-HEARNS
description: Lou Falcigno, the largest operator of

title: CBS Net Tumbles 57.1% in Quarter
description: CBS Inc., citing a large but expected loss in its publishing division, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1985 plunged 57.1 percent on a decline in revenues of 2.6 percent.

title: Heritage Federal In Proxy Battle
description: A group of investors said it had begun a proxy solicitation in opposition to management of the Heritage Federal Savings and Loan Association.

title: LOS ANGELES VOTES TODAY ON 4TH TERM FOR BRADLEY
description: If Tom Bradley wins, as expected, a fourth term as Mayor of Los Angeles on Tuesday, the big political question in California will be whether he runs again for Governor.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Liberia Executes Officer In Assassination Plot
description: A colonel in the bodyguard of the Liberian leader, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, was executed by a firing squad today after he was accused of trying to assassinate the general.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mengel Pleads In Officer's Killing
description: Alex J. Mengel pleaded not guilty in Westchester County Court today to a charge of first-degree murder in the Feb. 24 shooting of Gary Stymiloski, a county police officer.

description: President Reagan often telephones or writes to people to

SOVIET SAYS U.S. IS TRYING TO BLUNT IMPACT OF OFFER ON WORLD OPINION
description: The Soviet press said today that the United States had dismissed Moscow's latest proposals in an effort to diminish their effect on world public opinion.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Pittsburgh and Atlanta In Billboard War
description: A good-natured war between the cities is developing between Pittsburgh, rated the most livable city in the nation, and Atlanta, which is deposed from the top of the list to No. 11, as ranked by Rand McNally's Places Rated Almanac.

title: 'HENRY IV' CLOSES EARLY IN CAPITAL
description: The American National Theater's first production, a staging of Shakespeare's ''Henry IV, Part 1,'' closed over the weekend, two weeks ahead of schedule.

title: ROBBED MAN FACES LIFE TERM IN KIDNAPPING
description: A man who tracked down two men he believed had robbed his house is facing a possible life sentence if he is convicted of charges that he kidnapped the men, officials say.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ENSEMBLE STUDIO SEEKS DONATION BY 'ANGELS'
description: The brainstorming session began over Styrofoam cups of coffee in Curt Dempster's office at the Ensemble Studio Theater, and by the time Risa Bramon came up with her ''revolutionary'' new concept for financing the studio's annual marathon of one- act plays, everyone felt kind of silly that no one had thought of it already.

title: Music/Noted in Brief ;   Jason and the Scorchers Rock at Irving Plaza
description: Wild-eyed rock-and-roll meets the mythic South in the music of Jason and the Scorchers, who played an incandescent set Saturday at Irving Plaza (15 Irving Place). A year of touring has toned up the Nashville-based band's showmanship and further revved up its music, making Jason and the Scorchers one of the great rock bands of the 1980's.

title: LIGHT TOUCH BY MILLER WITH WEDGE
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.

title: CREAM PIE THROWN AT DEAN LEADS TO TRIAL OF STUDENT'S MOTHER
description: When ''Tickles the Clown'' socked the school dean with a pie in the face, the eighth graders roared with delight. A few parents tittered, too.

description: a settlement of a 1979 private

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Advertising;   Promotion Industry Defended
description: AFTER a broadside such as was leveled last week by Alvin A. Achenbaum and F. Kent Mitchel at the promotion industry, it was only a matter of time before supporters of that industry would be heard from.

title: DEFYING JUDGE'S ORDER, COLUMBIA STUDENTS CONTINUE SIT-IN, BUT 7 END FASTS

title: WHY BOTHER?
description: DIANA VREELAND insists that she hates to dine by herself and that when she faces that possibility, she simply goes to sleep. Miss Vreeland is not alone in her dislike for solo dining. Mealtime, for many, is very much a social occasion. Still, there are people - those who endure daily business lunches, for example - who, as the day comes to its tumultuous close, welcome the prospect of a quiet, relaxed dinner at home by themselves. What's more, they may set a table or a tray. They may even go so far as to measure, mix and cook an entire meal. In short, they will

description: An Army laboratory has identified the remains of six American servicemen killed in the Vietnam War, the Pentagon announced today.

title: OPERA: WAGNER'S 'PARSIFAL' AT THE MET
description: ''PARSIFAL'' is not an opera in any conventional sense. Nor is it, despite the piety that audiences sometimes affect in its presence, a religious ceremony. It is best understood and appreciated as a solemn ritual of the esthetic cult known as Wagnerism, whose grip on the musical public's imagination seems as strong today as at any time since the composer's death a century ago. The spell that ''Parsifal'' can cast in a glorious performance is difficult to explain to nonbelievers in the Wagnerian creed, but it rests heavily on the mesmerizing power of pure ritual and ritual's handmaiden, ecstatically solemn music.

Nineteen of 25 that he saved are on exhibition starting today at the Gotham Book Mart and Gallery, at 41 West 47th Street (719-4476).

title: The Social Security Cleverness
description: No part of President Reagan's proposed budget compromise with Senate leaders stirs more passion than the cut in cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security. It hits 36 million people, all elderly. Yet no plan that does not curb the soaring costs of middle- class benefits will be credible as a deficit reducer. Provided that he takes care to keep this cut from hitting the elderly poor, Mr. Reagan deserves credit for a courageous flip-flop.

description: F OR a quarter century Frank D. Drake has searched for clues that humans are not alone. Dr. Drake is one of a small band of earthlings devoted to the search for extraterrestrial intelligence, known by those who do it as SETI. He and his brethren scan the heavens with huge dish-shaped antennas, listening for signals from advanced civilizations.

title: BRIEFS
IN THE SUDAN'S BOAT, OTHER AFRICANS

THEATER: ROY DOTRICE IN 'ENEMY OF THE PEOPLE'
description: THE heart does not exactly leap at the prospect of seeing ''An Enemy of the People,'' the Ibsen play now on view at the Roundabout. While too many of this writer's major works are unjustly perceived or produced as melodramatic tracts these days, this lesser achievement does at times uphold that simplistic characterization. Written in anger after ''Ghosts'' received its hostile initial reception, ''An Enemy of the People'' can seem a didactic and self-righteous, if eternally pertinent, polemic. When the virtuous hero, Dr. Stockmann, is persecuted by his small Norwegian town for exposing the pollution of its lucrative municipal mineral waters, the audience is left with little doubt as to who the good and bad guys are.

title: INDICTMENT ACCUSES 4 OF PLOT TO TRANSPORT ARMS ILLEGALLY
description: Four men were accused yesterday in a Federal indictment in Brooklyn of scheming to ship guns or other military equipment illegally to the Soviet Union, Poland, Iraq and Argentina.

Kennedy Library Foundation, the foundation said today. Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis will also attend, said John J. Cullinane, chairman of the foundation. Contributions earned at the benefit are to be used for educational programs, exhibitions and public conferences.

Sales edged up 2 percent, to $670.4 million, from $657.3 million.

description: The Labor Department has decided that it will not require farmers to provide field workers with toilet facilities or drinking water, department officials said today.

title: Southwest-Muse
description: The Justice Department has raised questions about the competitive impact of a merger between the Southwest Airlines Company and the Muse Air Corporation, thus blocking the proposed merger between the two Dallas-based airlines from proceeding immediately. But Paul Seligson, a lawyer for Southwest in Washington, said the Justice Department would not ask for a full hearing, which would cause a long delay. The Justice Department, he said, would make a recommendation to the Transportation Department by May 15.

title: GORBACHEV, RECEIVING O'NEILL, URGES U.S. TO END 'ICE AGE'

title: A USEFUL BONN SUMMIT
description: If the Bonn economic summit conference in May is to have durable value, the seven main industrial democracies will have to take concrete action to resolve growing trade and economic problems. The Europeans have suggested some steps. What's needed is American leadership.

description: b-Includes equity in net income of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $76,900,000. c-After a loss of $16,800,000 from equity in net of unconsolidated subsidiaries and a loss of $1,100,000 on the sale of investments. The use of equity accounting for certain investments increased net income by $7,500,000 in the latest quarter and decreased net income by $20,300,000 in the year ago quarter. The year-ago quarter included a loss of $34,000,000 representing Teledyne's equity in a net loss reported by Kidde Inc.

title: HERS
description: LAST summer a friend who was about to drive alone across country asked me to read the tarot cards for her. For weeks I kept putting it off: I was rusty, hadn't looked at the cards in years, wasn't quite sure where they were. But by the night before she left I'd run out of excuses. I told her I just didn't want to, and she said, ''Oh, thank God.'' Whatever the future held, we didn't want to know it. And I was struck by how much had changed since I started reading cards 20 years ago and would read them for anyone, anywhere, because on some level I must have believed that the future threatened nothing worse than a few minor setbacks and disappointments.

Marcos ordered all the bank's directors to resign. According to the Monetary Board, only $1.5 million remains of the bank's capital of $5.4 million.

description: Five children were killed and one was badly wounded today when a mortar shell they found near their gypsy camp exploded while they were playing with it, the police said. A police spokesman said the blast occurred about 500 yards from a Greek Army firing range near Thebes.

title: WOMEN'S HEALTH: BOSTON COLLECTIVE REFLECTS ON GAINS
description: BOSTON THE year was 1969. A group of young Boston women were beginning to get together to exchange names of doctors and information about health care. Information was hard to come by - the age of the self-help book had not yet dawned - so each woman would pick a topic, such as childbirth, rape or abortion, do her own research and write a paper.

title: FAMILIES RELIEVED BY RETURN OF SIX BODIES FROM VIETNAM
description: Capt. Michael Chwan, an Air Force flier from Bayonne, N.J., met Dana Bass at a party in February 1964, and they were married soon thereafter. Fourteen months later, in September 1965, his jet was shot down over North Vietnam. Mrs. Chwan was three months pregnant at the time.

title: A SETBACK FOR DEADLY FORCE
description: The bad news has been dominating the headlines: In New York, we have read and heard about Bernhard H. Goetz; about Eleanor Bumpurs, whom a police officer shot to death during an attempt to subdue and evict her from her apartment; about Michael Stewart, who was allegedly beaten to death by transit officers after he was arrested in 1983 for scrawling graffiti in the subway. And in Detroit, the shooting by a homeowner of a fleeing burglary suspect provoked controversy when the district attorney announced that prosecution was barred by a state law making such shootings privileged.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Minnesota Court Assails Reprimand of Prosecutor
description: A judge's public scolding of a prosecutor over a widely publicized child sex abuse trial that ended in acquittal must be stricken from the record, the Minnesota Court of Appeals panel has ruled.

description: Since the office of Robert L. James, president and chief executive officer of McCann-Erickson, has the most nautical motif to be seen in adland, it is no surprise to learn that he is on the advisory board of the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum tied up in the Hudson.

For the second consecutive week, the average maturity of the funds' holdings remained at 41 days.

title: MUSIC: ST. LOUIS GROUP
description: JOSHUA BELL is 17 and still a student of Josef Gingold's at Indiana University, but his stage career already is 11 years old. The young violinist, who made his Carnegie Hall debut last night with the St. Louis Orchestra as soloist in Bruch's Concerto in G minor, is therefore anything but a novice and his technically adept performance showed it. However, Mr. Bell did not play with the complete expressive freedom that he may develop as he matures further and his rather small tone did not really blossom in this hall as it should in so lushly Romantic a work as the Bruch.

title: STRAWBERRY DOUBTFUL

description: The net income in both quarters was reduced $400,000 by an amortization expense.

title: Number Magic
description: Did it catch you by surprise when Bill Latham escaped the Mets' final cut and came north with the big club? It shouldn't have, because throughout spring training there was a clue, right there on Latham's back for all the world to see: His uniform number down in St. Petersburg was 64, and only once earlier in this decade had a Met player worn it. That was in camp last year, when it belonged to Dwight Gooden.

title: FARLEY AND NORTHWEST PLAN $1.3 BILLION MERGER

description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the world's largest maker of earth- moving and heavy construction machinery, yesterday named Peter Donis president and chief operating officer, effective June 1. He succeeds Robert E. Gilmore, who will retire after turning 65 next month.

title: The Urge to Help Cambodia
description: Cambodia remains perhaps the most pitiful victim of the Indochina wars and it is again contending for a modest American involvement. The House Foreign Affairs Committee, hardly a nest of hawks, has voted 24 to 9 for a $5 million military aid program to two small non-Communist armies resisting Vietnam's six-year-old occupation. If that is a policy worth adopting - and the Administration has changed its mind and thinks it may be - that meager sum ought to be an embarrassment.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The world situation is disquieting, even dangerous, and a kind of ice age is being observed in relations between the U.S.S.R. and the United States, at least it has been until recently.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. (A13:2.)

The sources, who asked not to be identified, also said the board might vote to seek protection from creditors under bankruptcy laws.

But when Mr. Sorkin, the regional administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commisission, asked Mr. Cohen if he would serve as trustee for some failed units of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman, a New Jersey securities dealer, Mr. Cohen was prepared.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about an appeals court ruling in a libel suit against The Washington Post misidentified Boisfeuillet Jones Jr. He is vice president and counsel of the newspaper; the vice president, general counsel and secretary of the Washington Post Company, the parent concern, is Alan R. Finberg.

title: CUOMO SEES POLITICAL NEWS AS OVER SIMPLIFIED
description: News coverage of politics and the Washington political world is overly dependent upon labels, Governor Cuomo of New York said here today.

title: CHASE MAY BUY 2 OHIO THRIFT UNITS
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had applied to purchase two troubled savings and loan associations in Ohio, and that it might purchase more if it were allowed to convert the additional acquisitions into commercial banks.

title: DESPITE BACKLOG, I. R. S. VOWS TIMELY REFUNDS
description: The head of the Internal Revenue Service promised today that most Americans would get their Federal tax refunds on time, despite a large backlog caused by a new computer system.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LIBERTY LILT The first public performance in more than 100 years of a piece written by Charles Gounod in honor of the Statue of Liberty will be given tonight at 8 o'clock at Alice Tully Hall. The piece was last known to have been played at a French fund-raising affair in 1876, a decade before the statue was delivered to New York Harbor. Today, it is part of one of the first musical programs celebrating the statue's centennial next year.

title: CENTERRE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: GREENS AT MASTERS CALLED TOO FAST
description: The Masters committee came close to admitting there was a defect in the Augusta National Golf Club course today when the chairman, Hord Hardin, said that the greens were too fast and too soft for his liking.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Florida Citrus Menaced By More Fruit Flies
description: The Florida Agriculture Commissioner said today that inspectors had discovered two more Mediterranean fruit flies, signaling an infestation of the citrus menace in the Miami area, and officials announced that a quarantine had been imposed on a 110 square-mile area in Dade County.

title: BRIEFS
LeClair Retiring
description: Jim LeClair, the Generals' 34-year- old linebacker who has been hampered by persistent neck and shoulder injuries, announced his retirement yesterday after a 14-year professional career that included a dozen seasons with the Cincinnati Bengals. LeClair, one of eight National Football League players signed as free agents by the Generals last year, said he planned to return to his native Minnesota to operate a farm he owns there.

title: Pilot's License Is Revoked
description: An American Airlines pilot's license was revoked after he took off from the wrong runway in Mexico City on March 29 and his plane struck a light pole, damaging the plane's landing gear, the Federal Avaition Administration said today. There were 152 people aboard the plane. According to the order, issued Friday, Capt. Anthony Kowalski of Ormond Beach, Fla., will not be able to pilot an airline plane unless he is recertified by the aviation agency.

title: IN MUGABE'S ZIMBABWE, ELECTION TO END ELECTIONS?
description: Five years ago, in tawny bushlands, British policemen could be seen guarding polling booths that symbolized the end of 90 years of white minority rule in Britain's last African colony.

title: Hilton Sees Gain in Ruling
description: Barron Hilton, chairman and president of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, said yesterday that the Internal Revenue Service had tentatively ruled in his favor in a dispute with his late father's estate over ownership of 6.8 million shares of stock in the company. Hilton Hotels also said that it had increased its bank credit lines to $600 million, from $250 million.

title: ITALIAN IS HOPEFUL ON SOVIET OFFER
description: The Prime Minister of Italy said today that the moratorium on the deployment of intermediate range missiles announced by the Soviet Union this week is a gesture that ''deserves more than a simple nyet.''

title: SUDAN CHIEF ANNOUNCES TALKS TO FORM A CABINET
description: The Sudan's new military leader said today that he was negotiating with civilian opposition groups to form a coalition Cabinet, and that he had sent an envoy to start negotations with guerrillas in the southern part of that north African nation.

title: The Cuomo-Abrams Brawl
description: The always uneasy relationship between New York's Governor Cuomo and Attorney General Robert Abrams has degenerated into a damaging brawl. Good government requires a significant retreat by Mr. Abrams and at least some gestures of conciliation from the Governor.

title: Save the Job Corps
description: For supporters of the Job Corps, the budget compromise between President Reagan and Senate Republican leaders is no compromise at all. The White House proposed killing it. The senators, after proposing to scale it down, agreed. That should not be the last word.

title: RANGERS THREATEN, BUT FALL TO FLYERS
description: Frightfully inept for most of the season, the Rangers threw a momentary scare into the Flyers tonight at the Spectrum before succumbing in a 5-4 overtime loss in the opening game of a best-of-five Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: 2 MOSLEMS TO BOYCOTT LEBANON CABINET
description: Moslem participation in Lebanon's nine- member Cabinet was in effect suspended today when Prime Minister Rashid Karami and a colleague announced that that they would not attend any Cabinet meetings until the crisis in the southern port city of Sidon was resolved.

title: WESTINGHOUSE NET UP
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, citing higher sales and the benefits of its cost-reduction program, announced yesterday that it had narrowed its loss in the first quarter of 1985 to $70 million, compared with a loss of $109 million in the first quarter of 1984.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Pakistanis Install A Civilian Cabinet
description: Pakistan's first civilian Cabinet in eight years was sworn in today.

title: IN BUSY LIVES, HOUSEWORK IS NO LONGER A TOP PRIORITY
description: WHEN Robert Horowitz was growing up, his mother had a system for cleaning. There was a day for doing the laundry, a day for washing the floors, a day for polishing the furniture. When Karen Kessler was growing up, her mother had a system too. She would clean the house from top to bottom - just before the maid came.

title: TRACKING ICEBERGS FROM AIR HELPS SAVE SHIPS AND LIVES
description: As spring reaches north into Newfoundland this month, the peak of the iceberg season is under way. And the job of tracking the icebergs in the North Atlantic's busiest shipping lanes falls to a little- known Coast Guard unit based here, the International Ice Patrol.

Stover, told securities analysts. Mr. Stover said any major acquisition would probably be in the semiconductor equipment or defense sectors. He said the transaction could be accomplished with the company using a 40 percent debt-to-capital ratio.

title: Military Contract
description: The Pentagon, making an exception to its suspension of the General Electric Company from new contracts, awarded a $422.9 million contract to a company owned partly by G.E. The award, for engine work on tanker aircraft, was made to CFM International of Cincinnati because CFM was not wholly owned by G.E. and to withhold the contract would be unfair to the other owner, the French company Snecma, the Pentagon said. G.E. was suspended by the Pentagon because of its indictment on March 28 on fraud charges in connection with previous Air Force work.

description: Lawyers for Columbia University and students protesting its investment policies offered conflicting interpretations yesterday of their clients' obligations under rulings issued by four different judges in recent days.

title: Ford Payout Rise
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would raise its quarterly dividend to 60 cents a share, from 50 cents, because of its strong earnings and cash position. It is the fifth time the dividend has increased since it was restored at 20 cents in the third quarter of 1983 after being omitted during most of the recession. The new dividend is payable on June 1 to shareholders of record May 2.

title: Reviving Jazz
description: Larry Miller , an auto dealer, paid $8 million yesterday to become half- owner of the Utah Jazz. Miller bought into the financially strapped franchise after putting together a loan from four Utah banks.

title: MONMOUTH'S SALE IRKS LOSING BIDDER
description: The announcement Wednesday evening that the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority has agreed in principle to buy Monmouth Park has Robert Brennan hopping mad. Brennan, the securities broker who purchased Keystone Race Track near Philadelphia last year and reopened Garden State Park last month, had been trying to buy Monmouth for the last two years.

description: The wreckage of a single-engine aircraft was found Wednesday on a snow- covered mountain range in central Pennsylvania. The police confirmed that all five people aboard died when the plane crashed Sunday night, less than a mile from the Lock Haven Piper Airport. The victims were identified as Ruth Giordano, 33 years old, and her 6-year-old daughter, Holly Jo, both of Newport News, Va.; and Mrs. Giordano's sister, Mary E. Matthews, 30; her husband, Dr. Stephen Matthews, and his 5-year-old son, Ryan, all of Asheville, N.C.

title: STAGE: FOUR PLAYS BY YOUNG WRITERS
description: AT a time when our theater needs all the new blood it can get - both in the wings and in the audience - the Young Playwrights Festival remains one of the most valuable events of any theatrical season. By offering full professional productions to the best plays written by aspiring American dramatists under the age of 19, the festival makes the theater a palpable goal, rather than just an abstract dream, for young people nationwide. This year there were nearly 700 submissions - a cheering indication in itself that the stage still holds magic for a generation that is said to have seen every George Lucas movie three times.

title: ART: THE SETTLED WORLD OF MARQUET ON DISPLAY
description: THE place of Albert Marquet in the hierarchy of the great French painting of the last 100 years has never been spectacular, but it has never been insecure, either. It is the received, accepted, long-settled wisdom that Marquet (1875-1947) is in the front rank of the second rank. This he owes above all to ample, underpopulated and largely motionless townscapes and harborscapes, in which the world is seen from a window on the third or fourth floor and ordered with the hand of a true craftsman who from time to time doubles as a poet.

title: LASERS MEASURE DISTANCE TO MOON TO WITHIN AN INCH, SCIENTISTS SAY
description: The scientists said they believed the measurements, across perhaps 230,000 miles of space, were accurate to within an inch, 10 times more accurate than any made in the past.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS HAVE STARTED TO RISE UP
description: The era of protest politics has been set aside in South Africa, replaced by the first phase of a militant revolutionary era. As one youth leader put it last year: ''We are now at war.''

description: A Suffolk County detective testified today that the only witness to the slaying of 17-year-old Gary Lauwers lied when he testified that the police had beaten him to gain information.

title: Two Attempts to Kill Qaddafi Are Reported
description: Dissident military men twice attempted to assassinate the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, in recent weeks, according to intelligence reports, The Washington Post said today.

title: 37 DOCUMENTARY FILMS AT THE PUBLIC
description: The film maker John Grierson, who first used the term ''documentary'' in connection with movies, once said such a film created ''a magical opening in the theater wall, through which one may look out to the wide world.''

title: FEDERATED GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: The company said pretax income in the latest quarter and year includes a gain of $2,502,000 on the sale of a leasehold interest acquired this year.

title: SHULTZ OUTLINES STEPS TO AID WORLD ECONOMY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in a comprehensive economic address three weeks before the Bonn economic summit meeting, said today that achieving a stronger world economy required action by all of the industrial countries.

title: Spanish Court Rejects Limited Abortion Law
description: Spain's constitutional court today rejected a law that the Socialist-dominated Parliament enacted 17 months ago permitting abortion in limited circumstances. The law had not been put into effect, awaiting a court ruling.

title: SEQUENTIAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

description: Not since the adoption of the

title: U. S. Denies China Got Pledge on Atom Ships
description: The Reagan Administration today denied China's assertion that it had received assurances that visiting United States Navy ships would not be carrying nuclear arms.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE line between film making and rock music gets finer all the time, as evidenced by ''Return to Waterloo,'' a 60- minute feature written and directed by the Kinks' Ray Davies. ''Return to Waterloo,'' which is scheduled to open here May 17 together with two Firesign Theater shorts, marks Mr. Davies's first attempt at film directing, and probably not his last. He has two subsequent movies in mind, as well as a good all-purpose approach to titling further projects. ''Whatever the title is,'' he said, ''you can put a 'II' after it and make it look like a successful idea.''

title: Unocal Files Lawsuit
description: The Unocal Corporation today accused T. Boone Pickens and his investment partners of conspiring to limit competition for oil and gas exploration, a violation of antitrust laws.

title: BOOK ON LESBIAN NUNS UPSETS BOSTON, DELIGHTING PUBLISHER
description: Once again being ''banned in Boston'' is having an effect in the literary world, and, partly as a result, an extraordinary new book about homosexuality among nuns is gaining national attention.

description: In Ben Blaz's office the phone was not ringing off the hook the other day.

description: The General Electric Company, helped by productivity improvements, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter rose 5.4 percent.

description: The dollar fell sharply yesterday, largely because of concern that lower-than-expected retail sales figures indicated a slowing of the American economy.

description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday in response to a surprising 1.9 percent decline in retail sales in March.

description: House members collected a record share of their 1984 re-election campaign money from political action committees, Common Cause, the public affairs lobbying organization, said today.

title: ART: SULTAN'S TAR-ON-TILE TECHNIQUE
description: -30's, Donald Sultan is descended from the Process artists of the late 1960's in that he makes art out of materials that are very much a part of contemporary life. Yet even as his coeval, Julian Schnabel, has cornered plates as a medium, Sultan seems to have been the first to work in tar, combining it with spackle and latex on a ground consisting of vinyl tiles attached to Masonite.

title: REVIVAL FOR LONDON MEN'S CLUBS
description: Their names are somehow peculiarly British: Boodle's, White's, the Garrick, the Gresham, the Eccentric Club.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   For Ted Turner, Charity First
description: When the Atlanta Braves play the first home game of the season tonight, their highly visible owner won't be anywhere in sight of the Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium.

title: GROWTH PAINS AFTER LOSS OF OBLIVION
description: ''It's kind of strange,'' remarked an engineer, helping to install a $12 million supercomputer at Florida State University recently, ''when you think we're on the cutting edge of computer technology right here in little old Tallahassee.'' For years this moss-draped Southern capital seemed to be on the cutting edge of oblivion. Campaigns were periodically mounted by legislators from the rapidly expanding urban areas of South Florida to move the capital to some sensible central location like Orlando. Tallahassee, which is 500 miles from Miami and 170 from the nearest major city, Jacksonville, was dismissed as provincial and boring.

title: KRUEGER, W A CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ADVERTISING ;   Accounts
description: * Newsday to Van Brunt & Company for broadcast promotion of its Queens edition.

title: ART: THE UNEXPECTED FROM JENNIFER BARTLETT
description: AS unexpected as Jennifer Bartlett's new show seems, it is very much a Jennifer Bartlett show. Her work has to do with the unpredictable, the unsystematic and the unexpected. While this show occupies the floor as well as the walls of the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street, this is a logical development of her longstanding environmental ambition. All of the beached objects - blown-up Monopoly-like houses, enamel-painted wood boats, a plywood swimming pool, flagstones, a wood and a chain- link fence and a concrete sea wall and dock - also appear in the landscape paintings around them that, as usual, evoke a variety of moods and styles. And everything in this show, too, is held together by narrative threads and by a sense of life as an exhilarating, desperate game of surfaces and reflections.

title: C.I.A. Recruiters Leave, Ending Campus Protest By The Associated Press
description: Three days of protests against Central Intelligence Agency recruiting efforts at the University of Colorado at Boulder ended late yesterday when the recruiters left. The poet Allen Ginsberg was among 164 protesters arrested yesterday, bringing to 478 the total number of arrests since Tuesday.

title: Integrated's Stock Continues Climb
description: Integrated Resources Inc.'s stock has been one of the best performers on Wall Street for the last week and traders say the credit goes to takeover rumors.

title: FOR MY MONEY, T. BOONE PICKENS IS NO HERO
description: Don't get me wrong. I admire T. Boone Pickens, the oil company takeover artist from Amarillo, Tex. He has made hundreds of millions of dollars for himself and his pals and a lot of speculators in oil stock. More power to him. I wish I could do it myself.

title: French Bus Wreck Kills One
description: A bus carrying 55 supporters of the Bordeaux soccer team went out of control on a sharp turn today and fell onto a ledge in a ravine, killing one person and injuring 17, the police said.

title: FISHING FOR ELUSIVE HYBRID

Mr. Deaver, who turned 47 years old today, has been a confidant, public relations adviser and friend to Mr. and Mrs. Reagan for more than 18 years. Here are some insights into the man, as provided by him:

title: INDIA AGREES TO INQUIRY ON SIKH DEATHS
description: The Indian Government announced today that it had agreed to three major demands from Sikh opposition groups, including a judicial investigation of widespread killings of hundreds of Sikhs in the aftermath of the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: INFLUENTIAL INTERIOR DESIGNER
description: Angelo R. Donghia, one of America's most influential interior designers, died of pneumonia Wednesday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BROADWAY
description: Keith Baxter to play a dual role in Moon's 'Corpse.'

title: Florida Cypress
description: The board of Florida Cypress Gardens Inc. has entered into a $23 million merger agreement with the parent company of another popular tourist attraction, Sea World. Under the proposed deal, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., which owns Sea World, would acquire the outstanding shares of Florida Cypress. The stock was quoted at $7.50 bid in over-the- counter trading today, up $3, making it the biggest percentage gainer.

title: A SAMPLER OF THE ART OF STATE U.
description: More than 25,000 works of art are scattered across 25 campuses of the State University of New York. Now an excellent sampling of them can be had in a visit to the State Museum in Albany, where 408 pieces have gone on display.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Plan to Place the Homeless In Old Morrisania Hospital
description: For each homeless family sheltered in the Martinique Hotel, the city has been paying $1,300 a month or more. The rundown hotel, at Broadway and 32d Street, has become a sad symbol of the city's homeless problems.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Julian Lennon Makes New York Debut
description: Julian Lennon has overcome one of the hurdles of being a rock legend's son with a debut album that has surprised many people by selling more than a million copies. The album, ''Valotte,'' is understandably indebted to the lavish ''psychedelic'' art-rock of the late 60's Beatles, in both its mood and texture.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Two Notable Changes In the Book Field
description: Among the various types of specialty ad agencies are the ones that specialize in books. Generally not an unruly group.

description: The developers who are building the 15-story midblock condominium at 60 East 88th Street gave themselves a choice some months ago among three alternate plans. They could provide 14, 18 or 32 apartments.

description: A judge today sent a 28-year-old man back to prison for a rape that his accuser said never occurred.

title: STOCKS CLOSE WITH MODERATE GAINS
description: Wall Street stock prices finished with moderate gains, after soaring early in yesterday's session as news of weak retail sales brightened the outlook for interest rates.

title: REDUCING DOCTORS' COSTS
description: New York State insurance officials say the only certain way to make a significant cut in soaring medical-insurance rates is to place a ceiling on court awards for pain and suffering and to reduce sharply the volume of malpractice suits, which has increased 300 percent in the state since 1975. That was not done 10 years ago when the Legislature last grappled with the medical-malpractice problem. And there were no ceilings on awards included in the malpractice-insurance program Governor Cuomo offered the Legislature last week. That is why some legislators question Mr. Cuomo's program as a long-term solution to the medical malpractice crisis.

title: ADAC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: RESTAURANTS
description: FOR a major seaport city, New York offers lean pickings when it comes to good no-nonsense fishhouses. Devoted seafood eaters enjoy their fish the way connoisseurs of bourbon take their drink: straight, unembellished and often. A simple broiled or poached red snapper, for example - served whole, please, so it resembles the dignified swimmer it recently was - is all that is desired. And unassailable freshness goes without saying.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS ;    Debt Issues
description: Canon Inc. is planning to offer 100 million Eurodollars of 15-year convertible bonds and 25 billion yen of 10- year convertible bonds.

THE BEST PLACES TO PERCH TO SEE THE BIRDS CHECK IN
description: THE Big Parade has begun, and it's time to get out there and watch. From points as far south as the Antarctic, birds are arriving in the metropolitan area. Some will stay until that much-studied but still mysterious migratory urge turns them around and sends them south in the fall; others will be here only long enough to rest and refuel before continuing north.

description: The dozens of reports issued

title: ART: NARRATIVE WORKS WITH A LATIN TWIST
description: QUICKENED by the revival of interest in the figure, narrative art, which has been around since the cave era, is hard to avoid these days. The storytelling mode is suitable not only to reportage, but also to the fantastical, the visionary and the apocalyptic with which many artists are now concerned. With a Latin twist, it is the subject of a modish show - or rather, two shows - at P.S. 1, the alternative space at 46-01 21st Street, Long Island City, Queens (through May 26). Both shows were organized for a Mexican audience by Robert Littman, director of the Museo Rufino Tamayo in Mexico City.

description: The Swedish Navy fired antisubmarine grenades today at a suspected foreign submarine near the entrance to Karlshamn Harbor on Sweden's southeast coast, according to the national news agency TT.

description: About 400 State Labor Department employees are to be dismissed in late June and 28 department offices closed because of a $15 million reduction in Federal funds, state officials said today.

description: Claus von B"ulow's chief prosecutor said today that he would try to introduce videotapes or transcripts of testimony that was considered particularly damaging in Mr. von B"ulow's first trial on charges of attempted murder.

title: SUDAN UNIONS GIVE NEW CHIEF A YEAR
description: Professional unions whose general strike led to the ouster of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry have agreed to give the Sudan's new military leaders a year to restore civilian government, a spokesman for the unions and political parties said today.

description: Bond ratings of the Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Company, which provides electricity to municipally owned utilities in Massachusetts, were suspended yesterday by Moody's Investors Service.

description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $700,000. c-After an extraordinary loss of $4.3 million. The results are reported at the exchange rate of 1 pound sterling equals $1.16.

title: RECITAL: BEVERLY SOMACH
description: THE most compelling feature of Beverly Somach's violin playing is a sense of linear continuity. Miss Somach, accompanied by the excellent pianist Jonathan Feldman, played music by Stravinsky, Szymanowski, J. S. Bach and Poulenc at the Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67 Street, Monday night and, from the first note of each composition, the listener was caught up in what seemed an inexorable vortex.

title: Approval Seen for Atom Plant
description: A Nuclear Regulatory Commission panel disclosed today that it would recommend that power production be resumed at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant's undamaged Unit 1 reactor.

title: F.C.C. Refuses to Ban Shows Starring Toys
description: The Federal Communications Commission rejected a request today to ban childrens' television shows starring such toys as Papa Smurf and Strawberry Shortcake.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation, reporting its first profit decline in more than three years, said yesterday that its net income in the first quarter fell 18 percent, to $986 million.

title: RETAIL SALES FELL 1.9% IN MARCH
description: Sales at the retail level plunged 1.9 percent in March from February's level, the steepest drop in more than seven years, the Government reported today. But analysts were split over whether the decline was a sign of growing economic weakness or simply a one-month fluke.

title: RPM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Year-ago quarter and 9 months are restated to reflect the acquisition of the Westfiled Coatings Corp. Share earnings reflect a 25 percent stock dividend in November 1984.

title: Brazil Holds Its Breath
description: The serious disability of President-elect Tancredo Neves puts Brazil's political transition to a most difficult test. The importance of a personality in politics usually varies inversely with the strength of a country's institutions. Brazil's paradox is that its institutions are simultaneously sturdy and weak.

Kirk Jr., the Democratic National Committee is quietly revamping its structure to provide more political services to local officials and candidates and de-emphasize direct representation of such groups as blacks, women and homosexuals in the national party.

title: ROOKIE IS STOPPER AS METS WIN IN 11

Sets are at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, 8:30 and 10:30 P.M. Sunday; there is a $12.50 cover and a $6 minimum. Information: 228-3788.

description: Two of the country's leading bank holding companies, the Chemical New York Corporation and Marine Midland Banks Inc., yesterday reported double-digit gains in earnings for the first quarter of 1985.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE private print collection of Tatyana Grosman, who has been credited with turning print publishing from a business into an art, will be on view this weekend and auctioned next Thursday at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street. Mrs. Grosman, who founded Universal Limited Art Editions in 1957, was the first publisher in the post-World War II period in America to produce original prints by major artists.

description: Some bridge theorists, like some sociologists, worry about the rights of minors. Diamonds and clubs, like boys and girls, are in some danger of being neglected and scorned.

title: Celtics Clinch Home Advantage
description: Larry Bird scored 29 points and Kevin McHale hit a baseline shot with 36 seconds to play tonight as the Boston Celtics clinched the home-court advantage for the coming playoffs by defeating the Cleveland Cavaliers, 121-115.

title: Red Sox Complete Sweep of Yankees
description: The Yankees continued to be a model of consistency today, keeping their perfect record intact. They have played three games and they have lost three games. Their 6-4 loss to Boston today in what George Steinbrenner had billed as ''a very crucial game'' dropped them three games from first place.

description: The Navy today announced plans to eliminate 5,540 jobs at eight Government ship repair facilities through a combination of layoffs and attrition.

Chile Approves Treaty
description: The Chilean military junta approved a treaty today that settles its century-old sovereignty dispute with Argentina over the Beagle Channel. The treaty, which has been approved by the Argentine Parliament, confirms Chilean sovereignty over three islands at the mouth of the Beagle Channel at the southern tip of South America, but awards to Argentina large areas of sea that had been claimed by Chile.

description: It won't be an interleague game, but when the Generals take on the Portland Breakers at Giants Stadium Sunday, there will be a couple of familiar National Football League faces under Breaker helmets.

title: Why Rape Statistics Lie
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SCREEN: 'FRATERNITY'
description: A TRAVEL note: a month ago Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was full of lonely college boys, doubtless lured there by movies like ''Fraternity Vacation.'' Movies like this - and lots of other, funnier ones in the same vein - hold out the promise of meeting just the right kind of girl. The type who might want to get physical early in a relationship, like during the first five minutes. The type who, when she brings a book to the pool, has everybody guessing (''Could be for effect - or, uh, maybe she reads.''). The type over whom two frat boys can make a gentlemen's bet: ''A grand says I get her before you do.''

title: Japan's Cease-Fire on Whales
description: Prime Minister Nakasone's plea that Japanese buy more foreign goods is a well-meant gesture that may do little to appease the Japan-bashers in America. But amid the crescendo of differences on trade, the two countries seem close to resolving another bruising issue.

title: SIEBERT SEEKS BEVILL'S DISCOUNT BUSINESS
description: Muriel Siebert & Company, a discount brokerage, has expressed interest in purchasing the discount brokerage business of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc.

title: ENVER HOXHA, MASTERMIND OF ALBANIA'S ISOLATION
description: Enver Hoxha, the Albanian leader, who died in Tirana yesterday, kept his isolated mountain country rigidly cordoned off for four decades.

title: YONKERS PACT IS REACHED YONKERS, N.Y., April 11 (AP) - A tentative settlement was reached tonight between Yonkers Raceway and striking parimutuel clerks, officials announced. The contract could be ratified in time for harness racing to resume Friday night.
description: The members of Local 32E of the Building Services Employees Union were expected to vote on the proposed pact at a meeting Friday afternoon. If they accept it, the track will reopen at 6:30 P.M., with post time at 8 P.M.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: During the 1930's, Sir Stephen Spender and some of his fellow ''bright young poets'' - W. H. Auden, Christopher Isherwood, Louis MacNeice, C. D. Lewis - revolutionized English poetry, influencing an entire generation of writers. They, of course, were influenced by their own literary antecedents, and this weekend Sir Stephen will share his views on one of literature's most inexhaustible sources of inspiration - William Shakespeare. Tonight at 8 o'clock, Sir Stephen will deliver the Groves Lecture on ''Shakespeare and the Literature of the 20th Century'' at Adelphi University. Tomorrow, the poet will take part in an all-day poetry conference - from 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. - on ''Poetry Between the Wars,'' reading from and discussing his own works. Both events are free and will be held at the Ruth S. Harley University Center, which is on South Avenue, between Nassau Boulevard and Rockaway Avenue, in Garden City, L.I. Information: (516) 663-1120. OPERA FOR YOUNGSTERS AND GROWN-UPS

title: Footnotes, Please
description: When Representative Carl C. Perkins of Kentucky took the House floor late in February to criticize the Administration's proposed cuts in student aid, he noted that all but one member of the Reagan Cabinet had gone to private colleges and universities, which would suffer financially from such action. ''If these institutions were good enough for President Reagan's top advisers,'' the Democrat inquired, ''why aren't they good enough for able but needy young men and women?''

title: ALBANIA: THE FUTURE
description: The death of Enver Hoxha raises to a new dimension the mystery and anxiety that Albania has posed to its neighbors, as well as to the Western and Communist camps in general, since World War II. However bristlingly hostile Albania's position has been toward the outside world in recent decades, it was a consistent stance. The small and mountainous Balkan nation has been aggressively isolationist, not hesitating to fire across its land or sea borders at any real or imagined intruder. It has been suspicious of foreigners and has repressed ethnic minorities, particularly the Greeks.

title: Klansman Gets a Life Term

Mr. Knowles said he and another Klansman, Henry Francis Hays, 29, killed Mr. Donald to ''show Klan strength in Alabama.'' Mr. Hays received the death sentence in January 1984.

title: Hedberg's 'Fight' Against Violence
description: PHILADELPHIA ling$12The lasting image of Anders Hedberg's professional hockey career will include so much more than the stick-raising celebration of a goal. The memory will include scenes like those at The Spectrum Thursday night, in the playoff game between the Rangers and the Flyers, when the buzzer to end each period merely provided an opportunity for everyone to push and shove and grab and fight without being thrown out of the game, and when the officials condoned the type of game Hedberg has long despised. When Hedberg's Ranger teammate Barry Beck reached around a pile of bodies to punch Rick Tocchet, the linesman Will Norris fell to the ice and writhed in pain. When the pile was dispersed and the linesman was still lying on the ice, Hedberg was the one to go back and check on his condition. When the game was over, the Rangers were one game away from the end of their season - Hedberg's last season - and the Spectrum organist was playing the theme from "Mission Impossible." Hedberg went around the dressing room, giving little pats of encouragement to his teammates. And when the time came to discuss what had just happened, Hedberg looked each questioner right in the eye and swore that his career had more than one game to go. "I'm not going to play my last game Saturday; I'll tell you right now," he said. "We're going to be back here next Tuesday. That's it." His testimony bore no resemblance to the customary empty-sounding words that come from a mediocre team this close to the end of its season. For two nights the Rangers had been far from mediocre. The difference between the best team in the league and the team with the most losses ever to make the Stanley Cup playoffs had been minimal. "Nothing," Hedberg said. He does not wear a captain's "C" on his shoulder, but his actions seemed a quiet attempt to squeeze every effort out of his final Ranger team. After 11 consecutive losses to the Flyers, including two in this three-of-five series, Hedberg knows that his insistence on making his 11th professional season his last means that yesterday's practice could be the last of his career, and the game tonight could be the end. But after a loss in overtime, and another in a game that was tied 1-1 in the third period, there is too much work ahead to allow for sentiment. Hedberg seemed offended at the thought that the end could be on his mind. "I'm not thinking about that," he said. "Why should I? Not at all. I think forward. I'm not thinking backwards." There are athletes who become misty-eyed near the end, realizing that an important part of their life will soon be over. As Hedberg's final season drew to a close, Ranger management suggested a ceremony and a presentation at a Garden game; he wanted no part of it. The same person who has stood so firmly against the game's fighting preferred to carry out his own fight quietly. A comeback victory over the Flyers, Hedberg said, would mean "nothing other than we would go on to the next series. That's it. I don't think it would mean any more to me than to a guy who has 10 years to go in this league. I just refuse to believe we're not going to go on to the next series." His lasting satisfaction can come from his importance as a leader of the European influence into the North American game. In four seasons in the World Hockey Association, and especially when they became Rangers in 1978, Hedberg and Ulf Nilsson were curiosities who were often treated as if they had come from Mars rather than Sweden. Seen as hockey pacifists, they became targets in a sport that often considered thuggery a necessary ploy. Hedberg eventually saw the game take a more positive shape. At least now, the confrontations, the posturing, and the illegal and ignored stick violence in this series is an exception, not the norm. "I accept it, obviously," Hedberg said. "Otherwise I wouldn't play. Support it? Absolutely not. But hockey has changed tremendously towards a direction where you have a lot less dirty play. And that doesn't mean it's less physical." The beatings he took in the W.H.A., Hedberg said, were no worse than those in his early days as a Ranger. "But times have changed," he said, "and teams have changed. Personnel has changed. Thoughts have changed." For now, though, he remains unwilling to accept any consolation prize. His entire effort now is aimed at postponing that final, playoff-ending handshake. "Our breaks might come any day," Hedberg said, and smiled a thin smile. "Unfortunately, we can't wait that much longer." - PLAYERS

title: NEW YORK CAN SAVE $21 MILLION ON PRISONERS
description: New York State legislators could save taxpayers an estimated $21 million a year by enacting a law that would allow prisoners to earn time off for good behavior. More than 24 states, including New Jersey and Connecticut, already have such laws.

Henry, the chronicler of New York City's ''Four Million'' at the beginning of this century. But the city is making amends with a weeklong festival celebrating the writer known as Will Porter when he left here at the age of 19 for Texas and later New York.

title: 'Anatol' to Close Sunday

The play was directed by Ellis Rabb, who co-wrote the adaptation with Nicholas Martin. It opened on March 6 and features Philip Bosco, Stephen Collins, Michael Learned, Valerie Mahaffey, Mary-Joan Negro and Pamela Sousa.

title: Shawmut Corp. Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the Shawmut Corporation for possible securities law violations related to its failure to report some large cash transactions, the bank holding company said. Shawmut said the S.E.C. had informed it that the investigation should not be taken as ''an indication by the commission or its staff that any violations have occurred.'' Shawmut Bank of Boston said in February that it had not reported cash transactions of more than $10,000 each with 28 institutions, as required by Federal law. The Bank of Boston Corporation, which has admitted similar reporting failures, disclosed earlier this week that it was being investigated by the S.E.C.

Rietano pleaded no contest Wednesday to charges of professional gambling, using a telephone to transmit and receive gambling information and possession of gambling records.

title: 51 YEARS LATER, U.S. EXPATRIATE LEAVES RUSSIA
description: Fifty-one years after he arrived in Russia, the man known to his friends as ''America'' left today to return to what he likes to call the old country, New York City.

title: SENATOR WHO AIMS HIGH: EDWIN JACOB GARN
description: When Jake Garn goes after something, he bears down so hard he has been known to talk about a goal even in his sleep. More often than not he gets what he wants, and his colleagues in Congress were not surprised when the senior Senator from Utah finally snared the space shuttle ride he had long been angling for.

title: Freelance Libel Law
description: Two of three appeals judges in Washington have declared that a newspaper's reputation for ''muckraking'' may increase its vulnerability to libel judgments. The opinion implies that the more aggressively a newspaper pursues investigations of possible wrongdoing, the more it risks being judged guilty of malice.

title: THE POWER BREAKFAST - ALL WORK AND NO FOOD
description: Sooner or later, warns Jonathan Gerard, financial analyst and veteran breakfast-eater, droves of young account executives, junior partners and the like will just start going face down in the eggs Benedict, victims, all, of P.B.S. - Power Breakfast Syndrome.

title: Moscow's Condolences Are Rejected by Albania
description: Albania today rejected Soviet condolences on the death of the Albanian leader, Enver Hoxha, and refused to let any foreigners attend his funeral.

title: MORE DEALS UNCOVERED AT BEVILL
description: The bankruptcy trustee for the Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Asset Management Corporation said yesterday that he had uncovered previously unknown transactions amounting to $5 billion on the securities company's books, increasing the uncertainty over the size of the securities firm's losses. He said a number of other discrepancies with previously reported figures had also been found.

title: CONCERT: MUSICAL SALUTE TO STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: The idea of a concert to celebrate the Statue of Liberty's dedication a century ago seemed such a good one to Hugh Ross that the venerable conductor of the Schola Cantorum could not wait for next year, when the actual centennial of the statue will be marked. So, at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday evening, Mr. Ross marshaled his own 32-member mixed chorus, the Concert Choir from the New York All-City High School Chorus, an orchestra from the Manhattan School of Music and a pair of vocal soloists for a night entitled ''Liberte/Liberty.'' The program concert was made up, in a sense, of torch songs.

title: Off to Lisbon
description: White House officials say President Reagan will soon nominate Frank Shakespeare, chairman of the board that oversees Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, to be Ambassador to Portugal. Mr. Shakespeare, who is also vice chairman of RKO General Inc. and a former director of the United States Information Agency, has been saying privately that he wants the job.

title: CITY IS FORCED TO LET 43 HOMELESS STAY THE NIGHT IN WELFARE OFFICES
description: Forty-three homeless people, including 26 children, slept in emergency welfare offices in Manhattan and Brooklyn Thursday night because every bed available for homeless families in shelters and hotels around the city was filled, city officials said.

description: Jimmy Connors and Ivan Lendl struggled early before rallying for victories tonight in quarterfinal matched of the Buick WCT Finals tennis tournament.

title: A GORBACHEV MEETING: REAGAN SEEMS DETERMINED
description: After seeming for years to avoid any direct contact with Soviet leaders, President Reagan now appears determined to hold some sort of meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, even if it produces no tangible results. His interest in meeting the Kremlin chief has been evolving over the last year, aides say, ever since he decided in January 1984 to pursue a new policy of less confrontation with the Soviet Union.

title: TRUST SUIT DROPPED BY CHRYSLER

description: Martha Graham can be choreographically surprising - even cantankerous. That was demonstrated at the New York State Theater Tuesday when her dance company gave the season's first performance of ''Night Journey'' and Peggy Lyman appeared in the solo ''Frontier.''

title: Intergroup Lowers Net
description: National Intergroup Inc. said today that its 1984 profit was nearly $39 million less than originally stated, leaving the diversified manufacturer with net income of $13.7 million. The change follows the recent disclosure that the domestic trading operation of its subsidiary, the National Aluminum Corporation, had agreed to buy large amounts of aluminum ingot in long-term contracts. Intergroup said an investigation of the matter had begun.

title: 18 Die in Philippine Clashes
description: At least 18 people were killed today in two clashes in the southern Philippines, military and local officials said. Col. Orlando Soriano, the army district commander, said at least 10 rebels and 2 militiamen were killed in a skirmish in Alegria in Cotabato Province. In Zamboanga Province, about 200 miles northwest of General Santos, four suspected Communist rebels, a policeman and a militiaman were reported killed after guerrillas raided a town hall.

title: FORUMS AROUND THE STATE
description: NEW YORK STATE is holding its annual Consumer Week from next Monday through Saturday - a week before the national version.

title: Diane M. Riccio Marries R. R. Ryan in Connecticut

title: U.S. Carrier Badly Damaged In Tanker Collision Off Cuba
description: The United States aircraft carrier Coral Sea and an Ecuadorean tanker collided off Cuba last night, and the carrier was significantly damaged in its bow area, the Navy said today.

description: The directors of the McKesson Corporation and Spectro Industries unanimously agreed to merge the two large distributors of drug and health-care products.

description: About 4,000 people marched through central Wellington tonight, singing and chanting protests against a proposed New Zealand rugby tour of South Africa. The protesters carried banners calling for the rugby team not to go to South Africa because of the racial segregation policy of the white-minority Government there.

description: The songwriter Loudon Wainwright 3d will perform tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street at Mercer Street. Shows begin at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $8.50. Information: 228-7880.

HEATER BLAMED
description: An 8-year-old boy and four relatives were killed early today in a fire that apparently began when the boy tipped over a kerosene heater, authorities said.

description: The accountant who audited the financial statements of the collapsed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. has agreed to an injunction barring him permanently from auditing the records of any public company or any financial company, public or private, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

Citrus Canker Is Found At a Florida Nursery
description: Citrus canker was confirmed today at an 18-acre nursery, the first discovery of the disease this year, while agriculture workers in Miami hung insect traps to combat a new infestation of the Mediterranean fruit fly.

TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: About 550 students gathered in front of the Rutgers Student Center here today to demand that the school stop investing in companies that do business with South Africa.

UNGERMANN-BASS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Television Minister Stabbed
description: The Rev. George E. Vandeman, a Seventh-day Adventist minister known for his weekly television program, ''It Is Written,'' was stabbed at his home Thursday and his son, Ronald, was arrested as a suspect, the authorities said. The minister, 68 years old, was taken to Los Robles Hospital with face and back wounds.

title: New Carbide Unit
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said it would build a $55 million facility in Marietta, Ohio, for making polyarylates commercially in 1986. It said the polyarylates, to be marketed under the brand-name Ardel, are high-performace engineering thermoplastics that have ultraviolet stability, impact resistance and toughness.

title: SAUDI WOMEN START TO PEEK FROM BEHIND THE VEIL
description: While Hend al-Khuthaila was pregnant with her fourth child, she worked full- time as assistant dean of the Women's Center of King Saud University until the day she checked into the hospital to give birth.

title: David McDowell Dies; A Publisher and Editor
description: David McDowell, a book editor and publisher, died April 8 in Monteagle, Tenn. He was 67 years old.

title: A STEEL COMPANY ON THE EDGE
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest steelmaker, has long been viewed as the most financially vulnerable company in an industry that so far has been unable to reverse its decline.

title: OF EASTER, PASSOVER AND QUARTODECIMANS
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $681,900 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $2,387,000 for the year. c-Net income, which reflects an extraordinary charge of $120,000. d-Full year figures for 1983 are not available because the company changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from March 31. Results for the latest quarter reflect a merger with Treco Inc. effective Dec. 31.

title:
PATENTS;

Promoting the Growth Of Animals and Plants
description: A method of promoting the growth of animals by administering leupeptin was patented this week for the Genetic Diagnostics Corporation of Great Neck, L.I. Herbert Platt and Alfred Stracher of the staff are the inventors named in patent 4,510,130.

title: JUDGE REAFFIRMS ORDER ON COLUMBIA
description: A State Supreme Court Justice yesterday refused to lift his order barring Columbia University from ''improperly'' taking action against students protesting the university's investments in companies that do business in South Africa.

title: Henry C. Brunie Dies;Ex-Empire Trust Chief
description: Henry C. Brunie, a former chairman of the Empire Trust Company and a retired vice chairman of the Bank of New York, died of Alzheimer's disease Thursday at Craig House Hospital in Beacon, N.Y. He was 84 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: Janie Miller Winters Marries Carl Kappes
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan yesterday Janie Miller Winters, assistant to the vice president of development at Brunschwig & Fils, the fabric house, was married to Carl Henry Kappes 3d, a vice president of Farr Mann & Company, international commodity brokers. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Police Kill 2 Blacks In South African Clashes
description: Two blacks were shot and killed by the police in separate incidents today, the day before a mass funeral for 19 people slain when the police fired into a crowd of black marchers last month.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;   Jazz
description: Young jazz musicians tend to look forward rather than back. But in the late 1970's a trickle of jazz musicians began arriving in New York who were in their late teens and early 20's and were fascinated by jazz of the 1940's, 30's and even 20's. Several of them have since been building notable careers from that foundation, broadening their viewpoints and developing their own musical personalities. This week several of the most interesting members of this younger but now well-seasoned generation of jazz musicians can be heard in New York.

description: IF you have never used one, a

title: PHILHARMONIC: TORADZE OFFERS PROKOFIEV WORK
description: Alexander Toradze, the Soviet Georgian pianist who has replaced an indisposed Ivo Pogorelich for the New York Philharmonic subscription program that began Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, would seem to be a Prokofiev specialist. He made his New York debut with the Moscow Philharmonic in 1979 playing Prokofiev's Concerto No. 5; in 1983 he was back with the Los Angeles Philharmonic in the Concerto No. 2. He broke the string a year ago with his New York Philharmonic debut, offering the Liszt Concerto No. 1. But now he's back with the Prokofiev Third. Never mind that this was the concerto Mr. Pogorelich had planned to play; Mr. Toradze tore through it as if he owned it.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

JANE AUSTEN'S TIME
description: ''The dining-parlour or the noble room, suitable in its dimensions to a much larger drawing room than the one in common use, and fitted up in a style of luxury and expense which was almost lost on the unpracticed eye of Catherine.'' Devotees of Jane Austen might know that the quotation comes from ''Northanger Abbey,'' but would they know what objects might be found in that dining room and what the design of the room would be?

title: SCHOOLONG IN THE HOME: A GROWING ALTERNATIVE
description: -YEAR-OLD Joseph Pagnoni of Methuen, Mass., was big for his age. So he was seated next to the class bully to calm down the bully. But because he had been taught by his parents to respect the rights of others, he kept coming home with bruises, scratches and bite marks.

title: EARLY EDUCATION THRIVES OUTSIDE PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: -awaited adventure, the new encounter with desks and teachers and lunchrooms and other well-scrubbed 6-year-olds, both excited and anxious about this new experience called school.

description: THE LAST ROMANTIC

title: DICKSON LANE MARRIES GEORGENE LUCY IN OHIO
description: Georgene Lucy, the daughter of Shirley Whitlock of Warren, Ohio, and Charles Richard Lucy of Brookfield, Ohio, was married yesterday to Dickson Anderson Lane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Van McKibben Lane Jr. of Greensboro, N.C. The Rev. Thomas Jewell performed the ceremony at the Central Christian Church in Warren.

title: MEG PRICE BRIDE OF M. S. BRUNO JR. IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: At St. Bernadette Roman Catholic Church in Canadensis, Pa., yesterday Margaret Suber Price, the daughter of Mrs. Raymond Price Jr. of Stroudsburg, Pa., and the late Mr. Price, was married to Michael S. Bruno Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bruno of Tenafly, N.J., Sherman, Conn., and New York. The Rev. Steven Stavoy performed the ceremony.

title: A QUEENS CLASS LOOKS AT ETHNIC MYTH AND REALITY
description: The women were midway through their Queens College course, ''Italian American Women and Jewish American Women: Compared and Contrasted,'' and the assignment the other evening was to bring in photographs of their immigrant ancestors.

description: To the Editor:
