description: To the Editor:

title: SEEKING THE LOST AMUSEMENT PARK
description: On a suffocatingly hot day last July I saw an amusement park auctioned off. The crowd of buyers moved from building to building as the auctioneers sold Ferris wheels and kitchen equipment, signboards and merry-go-round horses. I was not there to buy, but because I've been drawn to amusement parks all my life, and the auction would be my only chance to see this particular one: Rocky Springs, just outside of Lancaster, Pa.

title: EXPERIMENTATION SHAPES 'CAST IRON TV'
description: For many viewers, public access - air-time provided free by cable operators to their community - remains a virtually impenetrable forest of programming, overgrown with erratically scheduled presentations that take up only the most parochial of concerns. Yet, several public-access programs belie that image, and endeavor to use cable as a means of providing innovative and substantial alternatives to conventional television fare.

title: THE 'APPLIED HUMANITIES': A BUSINESSLIKE APPROACH
description: AS a philosophy graduate student specializing in action theory, Vivian Weil examined human activity in the abstract. If a man raises his arm, she puzzled, has he completed an action at the halfway point? Today Professor Weil, who teaches at the Illinois Institute of Technology, takes a more concrete approach to action, exploring the responsibility of engineers in disasters such as the collapse in 1981 of an overhead walkway at the Kansas City Hyatt Regency Hotel.

title: IN SHORT
description: THREE VIEWS OF A MASTER Bernard Taper first published BALANCHINE (Times Books, $19.95) in 1963; a second edition appeared in 1974.

title: LIVING WITH THE PAST AND THE PRESENT
description: To judge from the overwhelming array of electronics for the home in stores this spring, it would appear that Americans are ever more immersed in technology. Everything from miniature vacuums and talking clock radios to compact disks and computerized answering machines has marched into contemporary life. But a glance at the recent work of interior designers and architects suggests something far different. Rooms festooned with chintz and laden with antique furniture, art and

title: COZY CHARM IN NEW LONDON
description: IT isn't just local residents who have reason to

title: Confessed Murderer Recants
description: Henry Lee Lucas, a drifter who admitted killing 600 people around the country and in five foreign countries, now says he killed only three people, The Dallas Times Herald reported Sunday. The newspaper reported that Mr. Lucas told his lawyer and one of its reporters that his confessions were a hoax ''to show that law enforcement doesn't do its job.''

title: CREATE A SYSTEM OF UNIVERSAL NATIONAL SERVICE
description: Our nation recently marked two important anniversaries. Fifty-two years ago, President Franklin D. Roosevelt created the Civilian Conservation Corps (C.C.C.), which enlisted the efforts of three million young people to transform the American landscape into a more beautiful and bountiful resource. And 24 years ago, President John F. Kennedy established the Peace Corps, which has sent more than 85,000 volunteers to promote peaceful change in the lives of people throughout the developing world.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: THE most interesting debut recitalist in a thin week was Douglas Wm. (so-billed) Walter, who plays the marimba and the vibraphone and who demonstrated his skills Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall; all of this week's debuts took place there.

title: IN SHORT
description: (Pantheon, $13.95.) This bizarre love story from Peter Dickinson represents quite a shift from the densely elegant circumlocutions of such earlier novels as ''Hindsight'' and ''The Last Houseparty.''

title: MALCOLM N. MCKINNON IS WED TO BLAIR COLLIER
description: Elizabeth Blair Collier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Marshall Collier of New Orleans, was married yesterday to Malcolm Nealand McKinnon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Malcolm McKinnon of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Bernard A. Grehan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Academy of the Sacred Heart in New Orleans, of which the bride is an alumna.

title: GARY STREICHER STEARNS MARRIES JULIA ANDREWS
description: Julia Elizabeth Andrews, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Chester Andrews of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Gary Streicher Stearns, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Jackson Stearns of Fairfield, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: THE LIBERAL ARTS AND THE MARTIAL ARTS
description: WHEN a neighbor heard I wanted to expound on the theme of the liberal arts and the martial arts, he quipped: ''That's like an essay on 'Lincoln, man and car'!'' I too would have seen it that way five years ago. Indeed, one reason I plunged into the martial-arts world was to find relief from the heady grind of professorial life at a demanding academic institution. Of course I was also after fitness, machismo, romance - who knows what else? - but surely nothing on a par with the high- minded trade I plied with my students at the university.

title: LIBERAL ARTS STUDENTS MEET TECHNOLOGY
description: To John S. Morris, the president of Union College, the gas leak at the Union Carbide plant in Bhopal, India, last year represents an academic challenge as well as a human tragedy. ''Methyl isocyanate makes it possible to grow good crops and feed millions of people, but it also involves risks,'' he says. ''And analyzing risks is not a simple matter.'' Mr. Morris's college, in Schenectady, is at the fore of a growing movement in American higher education - bringing the study of technology into the standard liberal arts curriculums.

title: SCULPTOR INTERPRETS THE CROSS
description: JOHN MACELLARI, a sculptor whose works are being shown in New London, says he does not mind if some viewers are offended by his creations in the theme of the Cross. But with the Deity, Mr. Macellari, who says he is an agnostic, wants to limit the criticism.

title: Men's Style;   JACKETS TO DRESS UP THE WEEKEND
description: FOR MANY IN THE EXECUTIVE ranks, and for those who hope to reach them, weekday dressing follows a relatively strict formula: shirt, tie and suit. But come Saturday, the last thing most men want to wear is a two- or three-piece business uniform. Weekends, whether spent in city or country, are days to break away from dress-code restrictions.

title: HELPING IN THE CAPTURE OF THE YOUTHFUL DOLLAR
description: ''YOU take a young man or woman coming out of Harvard with an M.B.A.,'' John J. (Jay) Conefry Jr. of Manhasset, the director of operations and systems for the Merrill Lynch Company, said as he surveyed the latest battleground where giant financial institutions are competing today for the billions of dollars in business of what he termed ''the early affluents.''

title: REAGAN TO SUBMIT PLAN TO OVERHAUL FEDERAL TAX CODE
description: President Reagan, urging legislators to ''seize this historic moment'' and overhaul the nation's tax system, said today that he would introduce a plan on tax revision to Congress next month.

title: 'HEIMAT': ANOTHER EXAMPLE OF A REVOLUTION IN CINEMA

title: REPUTED CRIME LEADER IN HAWAII TO BE TRIED IN 11-YEAR-OLD KILLING
description: In the latest of a series of crackdowns on organized crime in Hawaii, Wilford (Nappy) Pulawa, reputed to be one of Hawaii's top organized crime leaders, is to go on trial June 17 in State Court in an 11- year-old murder case.

title: Refinancing
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY WOULD I WRITE: MAKING NO BECOME YES
description: This Friday, April 19, in a ceremony to be held at the White House, Elie Wiesel will be awarded the Congressional Gold Medal in recognition of his life's work as a novelist, essayist, playwright, speaker and witness to the Holocaust. In May 1944, when he was 15, Mr. Wiesel was deported from his native town of Sighet, Hungary (now in Rumania), to the first of several concentration camps. Friday's ceremony will take place eight days after the 40th anniversary of his liberation from Buchenwald on April 11, 1945. Mr. Wiesel is the author of 25 books of fiction and nonfiction, among them ''Night'' and, most recently, ''The Fifth Son.'' A three-volume edition of his uncollected works will be issued later this year. This essay, adapted from a version published by Indiana University Press, explains why Mr. Wiesel feels compelled to write.

title: MY UNCLE, THE MANIAC
description: THE FIFTH ANGEL

title:
NUMISMATICS;

AUCTIONS SHOW STRENGTH IN THE MARKET
description: Reports of the coin market's weakness appear to be greatly exaggerated. Recent auction results suggest the market has underlying strength and may be much farther along the road to recovery than most observers realized.

title: JULIA DAUT TO WED IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Daut of Lexington, Ky. have announced the engagement of their daughter Julia Marie Daut to Paul John Tooher, the son of Edward W. Tooher of Glen Head, L.I., and the late Dorothy M. Tooher. A June wedding is planned. Miss Daut is a chemical sales representative for the Monsanto Chemical Company in Kenilworth, N.J. Her fiance is an area advertising and sales promotion manager for Coca- Cola in Needham Heights, Mass.

title: ALBANY TO STUDY STATE JOBS FOR PAY INEQUITIES
description: New York State will evaluate the jobs of all state workers as part of a new labor agreement that would provide money to make up for pay inequities, government and union officials say.

title: SIBYL PEYER HAS NUPTIALS
description: At the Riverside Church in New York yesterday Sibyl C. Peyer, an associate with the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts, was married to Andrew John Wertheim, an associate with Shearman & Sterling, New York lawyers. The Rev. Fanny Erickson performed the ceremony.

title: PANEL TO COMPARE NURSING COSTS
description: care officials look at the cost of patient care, they can single out X-ray and laboratory fees, but nursing care often is another matter.

title: Elliott Jaques
description: To the Editor:

title: PARTNERS IN A PARK
description: In 1979, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey bought from Conrail a 90-acre tract in Elizabeth, N.J., near Newark International Airport with plans to establish an industrial park that would help the area's economy.

title: Trapped in Illiteracy
description: About 40 million Americans don't read very well - not at twelfth-grade level anyway - and it's fair to say that a lot of them don't care. They get by.

title: VANDALS DAMAGE PRIVATE JEWISH ACADEMY ON L.I.
description: Vandals smashed furniture, windows, and computers and other equipment, turned on water taps and fire extinguishers, and caused about $125,000 in damage last Thursday at a private Jewish school in Great Neck, L.I., the police and officials of the school said yesterday.

title: IN SHORT
description: (NAL Books, $12.95.) The overweight and affluent., where (like all his neighbors) he worships money, sex and food. Clearly, though, something terrible is destined to befall Billy.

title: 100 FOOD OUTLETS LISTED FOR HEALTH VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 100 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: MUSEUMS TURN INSIDE AND OUTSIDE
description: WHEN it comes to the esoteric, the two exhibitions heralding the start of the major art season on the East End and opening today at the Parrish Art Museum and Guild Hall are right up there - in theme, if not necessarily in content.

title: LONDON'S GLITTERING SILVER VAULTS
description: Behind a nondescript post-World War II facade in the Holborn section, the London Silver Vaults are a mostly underground warren of some 35 shops and booths selling an infinite array of glittering prizes.

title: The Emergence Of Gorbachev
description: The tendency to view Mikhail S. Gorbachev as a potential reformer of the Soviet Union is predicated to a large degree on the notion of generational change (''The Emergence of Gorbachev,'' by Serge Schmemann, March 3). The dividing line is seen as World War II - the notion that Gorbachev's generation was only in its ''teens when the Red Army sacked Berlin and laid the foundations for the Soviet Union as a global superpower.''

title: DISPUTE OVER PACTS AT RESORT PERISTS
Spirit Sale
description: Paul Martha, the vice president of the Pittsburgh Spirit, denied a published report that the owner of the Major Indoor Soccer League club,

title: THE RICH FRESHNESS OF SALMON
description: FOR the last couple of years, salmon of impeccable quality and freshness has been increasingly available in our Eastern markets. Freshness? In a fish that is shipped either from the Pacific Northwest or from Norway? If that sounds unlikely, it remains a fact, assuming of course, that your fish market or supermarket takes good care of it and sells it without delay.

title: JOSHING IN THE JUNGLE
description: INTO THE HEART OF BORNEO

title: CORRECTION
description: In New & Noteworthy April 7, information about one title was omitted. ''New York City Baseball: The Last Golden Age'' by Harvey Frommer is published by Atheneum at $8.95.

title: HARTMAN GETS NEW DIRECTOR
description: THE search for a new artistic director of the Hartman Theater in Stamford - its third in 10 years - is over. On Oct. 1, Margaret Booker, who founded Seattle's Intiman Theater, will replace Edwin Sherin, whose resignation is effective at the end of the month.

title: A TALK WITH JUSTICE REHNQUIST
description: John Jenkins's article examines Justice Rehnquist's claim that his 1952 memo in support of legally enforced public-school segregation reflected the views of Justice Robert H. Jackson and not those of law clerk Rehnquist.

title: THE REGION ;   A Dome on The Horizon
description: City and state officials stepped up a drive to bring professional football back to New York City last week when they endorsed the construction of a domed stadium right next to Shea Stadium. After months of discussion, the Koch and Cuomo administrations agreed that the stadium would be built with private money - about $250 million to $300 million - on a 70- acre site in Flushing, Queens, and seat at least 78,000 people.

title: ANTISMOKING BILL PROMPTS DEBATE
description: A measure to ban smoking in almost every public place in New York City except designated areas would not work, opponents said at a City Council hearing. But supporters called it a long overdue step toward protecting the health and rights of nonsmokers.

title: CRIMINAL JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT
description: THE BLUE STAR. By Robert Ferro. (Dutton, $16.95.)

title: BUSINESS SAYS 'STOP' TO THE RAIDERS
description: BUSINESS expansions used to mean good times for corporate chief executives. But this recovery has brought with it a heavy dose of corporate stress. The creaking financial system, surging imports and shrinking profit margins have wrought misery on whole industries. And for specific companies in those industries, the hostile and unpredictable takeover wars of the last two years have raised corporate insecurity to new heights.

title: WHEN LAWS ARE TOO WEAK
description: the intoxicated driver. We need more than a weak state law to signal that driver, and all of his victims, that society's rights, not only the individual's, must now be served.

title: SOVIET AND U.S. AIDES, IN ATLANTA, TRADE ACCUSATIONS ON ARMS TALKS
description: Top officials from the Soviet Union and the United States today accused the other side of impeding the arms-control talks in Geneva.

title: Last Stalinist?
description: Under the 40-year rule of Enver Hoxha, Albania earned the distinction of being the darkest corner in the Communist world. His model was Stalin, but Mr. Hoxha ruled 2.8 million people, predominantly Moslem, like a thin-skinned Ottoman bey.

title: CORRESPONDENCE STUDY STREAMLINED
description: BECKY JONAS came across a correspondence course in what she considered an unlikely place. On a corner shelf of a video store in her hometown of Las Vegas, Nev., she noticed a computer-software package. On inquiry, she learned she could take a variety of academic courses via the computer she had recently bought for herself and her son. Through electronic mail, she would have access to a computerized library as well as an instructor.

title: 11-YEAR-OLD BRONX GIRL IS SHOT AT LOWER EAST SIDE BUS STOP
description: An 11-year-old girl waiting for a bus on the Lower East Side was shot in the chest and critically wounded yesterday afternoon, the police reported.

title: SURGICAL TEAM SET FOR HEART IMPLANT
description: A 20-member team that on Sunday is to perform its third artificial heart operation in four and a half months feels no need for trial runs to prepare to implant the plastic-and-metal pump in the 62-year-old patient, a spokesman said today.

title: YANKS TRIUMPH;   STRAWBERRY CLOUTS DECIDING HOMER
description: The Mets, the team of improbable encores, supplied another one yesterday when they won for the fourth straight time by the margin of one run: a ninth-inning home run by Darryl Strawberry that defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 2-1.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds , at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Pete Rose, the player-manager of the Reds, is 44 years old today and is off to a strong start in his pursuit of the major league career-hit record. Dwight Gooden gets his second start of the season for the Mets. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.)

title: STATE PRESSES BAR ON NUCLEAR SHIPMENTS
JAPAN'S TRADE PLAN WINS LITTLE PRAISE
description: Japan's market-opening measures were greeted unenthusiastically in the United States. Legislators, already threatening retaliation, said the moves were so unspecific as to be meaningless. They also noted that Japan has enacted six previous market-opening packages, to little effect. They did, however, praise Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's courage in appealing to Japanese citizens to buy more foreign products. For its part, Japan said its trade advantage comes from better-quality products and the strong dollar. But Mr. Nakasone acknowledged that he had miscalculated Congress's mood when he announced a big rise in auto imports.

title: NEW ROCHELLE HAS BIG PLANS (AND SMALL) TO DEVELOP
description: NEW ROCHELLE'S plans to build $221 million worth of offices and apartments over the railroad tracks have been shunted aside - but half a dozen other new projects encouraged by the city, ranging from tiny to monumental, are running along, apparently smoothly.

title: WHAT THERE IS TO EAT
description: THE STAFFS OF LIFE

title: ;   Was It Nemesis That Killed the Dinosaur?
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 158891 -- No Title
description: -Westchester Y.M.- Y.W.H.A. on Wilmot Road in Scarsdale has begun a campaign to raise $7 million to enlarge its present building by 70 percent, renovate existing facilities and add services and programs.

title: PICTURES WORTH A THOUSAND WORDS
description: THE best photojournalism is extremely compelling. It appeals to our interest in current affairs and it can produce strong emotional responses, particularly when there is a message commenting on the human condition. Photojournalism also has the ability to create images that remain long in the mind and heart, like that World War II icon, the view of the flag- raising at Iwo Jima.

title: LIMITS EYED FOR DIRT BIKES
description: TWO town supervisors in Suffolk County have stepped up efforts to have their town boards adopt ordinances restricting the use of dirt bikes as a result of a recent dirt-bike collision that claimed three lives in Port Jefferson Station.

title: WHEN CRIME VICTIMS FIGHT BACK
description: THERE'S this problem with fighting back against crime - whether you win or lose, you are left with questions that have no answers. After the adrenalin level settles back to normal you begin to doubt the wisdom of your actions, and to question the soundness of your instincts.

title: HOW ONE SCHOOL MARRIES BUSINESS THEORY AND PRACTICE
description: FRANK RODRIGUEZ has spent the last few weeks developing an employee-attitude questionnaire that he will use in his department at the American Express Company to uncover any morale problems. Surveys like his are not uncommon in large corporations, but what is unusual is that Mr. Rodriguez is conducting the research to meet an academic requirement in a novel undergraduate business program.

title: WHEN FIELD STUDY CALLS
description: ALEXANDRA LYRAS, a Scarsdale High School senior, is thinking about majoring in marine biology when she enrolls at Duke University next fall. ''Science was never my forte,'' she says, ''not until last summer.'' Miss Lyras's interest was triggered by the six weeks she spent in a marine-biology and scuba program sponsored by the Northfield Mount Hermon Summer School, in Northfield, Mass.

title: HIS INNOCENCE PROVES HIS GUILT
description: THE PIED PIPER

title: JESSICA M. ZIEGLER BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Jessica Madeleine Ziegler, a circulation manager at Time Inc., to Piers Anthony Cardew, an associate with the management consulting concern of McKinsey & Company, took place yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Gary B. Fertig performed the ceremony.

title: PAVEL'S PASSAGE
description: BUILDING A PRISON

title: White House Redraws Its Flow Chart
description: In announcing a major reorganization of the White House last week, President Reagan did more than affirm Donald T. Regan, his chief of staff, the first among equals in the inner circle. He formally acknowledged a fact of Washington life. No matter how strong an Administration's initial insistence that its style will be that of ''Cabinet Government,'' or of a corporate board of directors, power centralizes, generally in people with whom the President has been comfortable for some time.

title: SUDANESE RULER VOWS TO PURSUE AUSTERITY PLAN
description: The new leader of the Sudan said today that the military would rule the country for probably no more than one year, during which a painful economic austerity program would be kept in place.

title: BRAVES BEAT PADRES
description: Dale Murphy hit a two-run home run in the 10th inning today to give the Atlanta Braves a 7-5 victory over the San Diego Padres. Bob Horner's first home run since last May 23 led a three-run ninth-inning Atlanta rally.

title: U.S. Puts a Lid On Symposium
description: The annual symposium of the Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers held in a Washington suburb last week turned out to be a surprisingly hot ticket. The Defense Department required those attending sessions where about two dozen unclassified papers were presented to prove they were associated with Government programs or with companies doing business with the Government and made them promise to keep mum about anything they heard.

title: DR. DOROTHY A. POTTER TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Dr. Dorothy A. Potter, a resident in surgery at the New York University Medical Center and the Bellevue Hospital Center, plans to be married in June to Dr. Gerald L. Andriole, a urologic oncologist at the National Cancer Institute in Bethesda, Md. The ceremony is to take place in New York.

title: FRIEND OF JAMES AGEE, THE WRITER
description: The Rev. James Harold Flye, a retired Episcopal priest and teacher who was a mentor and correspondent of the writer James Agee, died Friday at Emerald-Hodgson Hospital in Sewanee, Tenn. He was 100 years old.

title:
GARDENING;

A NEW LOOK AT THE CRAB APPLE
description: MOST gardeners are still at a loss to know what to plant as a replacement for our ailing dogwoods. Many young dogwoods are being planted to replace those that have died, but the disease that has destroyed mature trees now seems to be attacking the young replacements, also. A satisfactory treatment program has not yet been discovered.

title: 5,000 SIKHS PROTEST PEACEFULLY IN PUNJAB
description: In a show of defiance, about 5,000 Sikhs, flanked by heavy security, moved through parts of Amritsar today shouting slogans against the Government and for a separate nation.

title: MET OPERA: STAPP AS TOSCA
description: Anyone singing ''Tosca'' at the Metropolitan Opera these days has to compete with Franco Zeffirelli's grand and gargantuan production. It is not an easy thing to do.

title: Q&A
description: Terminating a Sublease Question: About seven months ago, I obtained a sublease from the primary tenant. The apartment became a co-op prior to the expiration date of the sublease and was purchased by the primary tenant, who now wants to terminate the sublease in order to raise the rent. Does a co-op conversion prematurely terminate a sublease agreement? . . . A.S.R. The Bronx Answer: No, unless the lease has such a stipulation, points out Martin A. Shlufman, deputy counsel for rent administration for the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. A lease or a sublease is a contract that normally cannot be terminated prior to its expiration date. The $125,000 Exemption Question: I own a two-family house. I rent one apartment and use about half of the other as my home and business. I take a tax deduction for the part I use for business. I am over 55 years old, but my accountant says I cannot take the $125,000 tax exemption on gains from the sale of the house. Is this true? . . . S.F. Brooklyn Answer: Section 121 of the Internal Revenue Code requires that persons 55 or older who want to take the onetime $125,000 exclusion on gain must have owned and lived in the property as a principal home for at least three out of the five years preceding the date of the sale.

title: YALE GROUP PRESSES MOSCOW EXCHANGE
description: A SMALL group of Yale students and two faculty members spent 10 days in Moscow and Leningrad last month meeting with Moscow State University students and university officials trying to set up an annual student exchange to discuss relations between the two countries, the state of the third world, the arms race and the prospects for nuclear war.

title: THE FOURTH R, FOR RESIDING
description: There is perhaps no more telling symbol of the transformation of the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn than the current effort to convert the 63-year-old Sacred Heart and St. Stephen's School on Hicks Street into condominium apartments.

title: ENSEMBLES ENDING CONCERT SEASON
description: IT is time to report the seasonal

title: FOR SURVIVORS AND LIBERATORS, A COMMEMORATION
description: Forty years ago this week, Leon Bass, a 20- year-old Third Army corporal from Philadelphia, stumbled into the encounter that transformed his outlook on life.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on the Film page of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the theater where ''Lily in Love'' will open Friday. It is the Baronet.

title: MENTAL HOSPITALS: ARTICLE IS ASSAILED
description: I read with horror the insensitive article by a so-called ''professor.''

title: SATELLITE LOFTED BUT FAILS TO WORK
description: Astronauts today released a second communications satellite from the space shuttle Discovery's cargo bay, but a mysterious failure left the satellite powerless and unable to take off on its own to reach its intended higher orbit.

title: FIREHOUSE CROSS TESTED IN COURT
description: A CHRISTIAN symbol is dividing Greenwich. The Cos Cob Volunteer Fire Company wants to be able to erect a lighted, four-foot cross atop the firehouse at Christmastime, as it has done for 40 years. Three Greenwich residents are suing to block that, saying a religious symbol is out of place on a public building.

title:
PERSPECTIVES;

BELL CRITICIZES 'ASSAULT ON THE PRIVATE COLLEGES'
description: THE proposals advanced by the Director of Management and Budget, David Stockman, to place new limits on Federal aid to college students constitute an unwitting assault on the nation's private colleges and universities.

title: A WEDDING IN SUMMER FOR ERIN MCGILLICUDDY
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. McGillicuddy of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Constance Erin McGillicuddy to Jonathan Butler Mills, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Willis N. Mills Jr. of Wilton, Conn. The wedding is planned for August.

title: SENATOR DOLE DELIVERS REAGAN LETTER TO POPE
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, met with Pope John Paul II today and delivered a letter from President Reagan outlining the United States position on the Central American conflict and arms control.

title: TAKING THE BITE OUT OF SUMMER
description: As warm weather sets in, skin protection takes on the added dimension of pest control, and one of the most ubiquitous summer pests is the mosquito. It is attracted to humans by their warm moist skin, the air they exhale and their particular body chemistry. Everyone is a target. Yet some people - and it is not clear why - are more appealing to insects than others. Not only does this group get bitten more often, they may react more severely to the bites.

title: WORLD RARITIES ON SALE
description: How quickly times change. Three years ago at this time the philatelic investor held center stage, having attracted the attention of organized philately with a seemingly insatiable demand for better-grade stamps and covers. As it turned out, the demand for ''investment-grade'' material was not insatiable, the supply was unending and over-hyped prices collapsed.

title: Mets' Start Bodes Well A fast start may not guarantee a fast finish, but according to some
description: recent research, the Mets' 4-0 record gives strong assurance that the

title: RESIDENCES SOUGHT FOR DISABLED
description: PARENTS of the mentally disabled, concerned that the county is facing a crisis in the provision of group homes, will meet today at the Mental Retardation Institute in Valhalla with state legislators from the area and representatives of agencies that serve the disabled.

title: SOUND ;   HANDS OFF! 'SMART' TUNERS ARE HARD AT WORK
description: Discontent, divine or otherwise, leads to better mousetraps and other improvements. That quirky itch, springing from the notion that the best is not good enough, lately has had tuner designers scratching for new ideas. The result is a spate of genuinely innovative new models. Last week, this column began a mini-survey of these new FM tuners, and we'll look at a few more today.

title: FLOYD UP BY 1 SHOT
description: Ray Floyd, who has a secret game plan on how he should attack Augusta National Golf Club, said he followed that blueprint to move into the lead by one shot after three rounds of the 49th Masters. An eagle 3 on the par-5 13th hole did not hurt, either.

title: Soviet Official Promoted
description: Leonid A. Gorshkov, 55 years old, has been made a Deputy Premier of the Russian republic, the most important of the Soviet Union's 15 states. He was the party chief of Kemerovo Province, which contains the Kuznetsk Basin, Siberia's chief coal and steel district. The promotion, announced Friday, was part of a transfer of authority to a younger generation under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: PIONEER STUDIO'S PRINTS UP FOR SALE
description: DURING her lifetime, Tatyana Grosman, founder and guiding spirit of Universal Limited Art Editions, the West Islip graphics workshop that is generally regarded as the birthplace of modern fine-art printmaking in America, acted as a kind of creative guardian angel to the artists who visited her atelier.

title: FOR PARISIANS, IT'S SWEET IN THE 16TH
description: If you read Michelin's green guide to

title: HOW TAILLEVENT STAYS ON TOP
description: The world's finest restaurant? Only a handful of names might be considered, and surely high among them would be Taillevent, the discreet and elegant Parisian establishment that has held the top three-star Michelin rating since 1973.

title: U.S. AND JAPANESE SAY FREER TRADE IS AN URGENT GOAL
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe of Japan met today to continue efforts to avoid a trade war between their countries.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 14, 1985 International

title: KORCHNOI IS TOPS
description: For unbounded restless energy, for persistent jabbing and probing of the opponent, for maximizing the struggle throughout the five-hour playing session, Viktor Korchnoi still cannot be surpassed.

title: ON THE ROAD THROUGH BAJA CALIFORNIA
description: Baja California holds a special allure. Its northernmost fraction is an agreeable land of lobster burritos and vinos generosos, and the silent, arid southern tip is fringed by some of the world's emptiest warm- weather white sand beaches. But many visitors are most attracted by the stark central stretch of wild, mostly uninhabited coast along the azure Gulf of California, known to Mexicans as the Sea of Cortes. Monument Valley washed by the Caribbean: this was the vision that we wished to verify.

title: DANES SHOW U. S. HOW TO SAVE ENERGY WITH STYLE
description: FLUTTERING over the black tile roof of

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;   Dance
description: The Dance Canada Festival gets underway Thursday when Toronto Dance Theater opens at Brooklyn College in a program featuring works by Christopher House, a winner of the Jean A. Chalmers Award, Canada's most important choreographic prize. Funded by the Metropolitan Life Foundation, the festival will bring five Canadian groups to Brooklyn; the first attraction, Toronto Dance Theater, appears Thursday at 2 P.M., Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M. and next Sunday at 2.

title: No Headline
description: Brady Coyle, the Boston lawyer who ministers to the very rich, made his initial appearance about a year ago. He is now back in William G. Tapply's second novel,

title: WHY ORIENTAL ART SPEAKS TO THE CONTEMPORARY EYE
description: Oriental art was never going to have the same effect on us as tribal art. To Western eyes, tribal art seems rooted in the present. Its ingenuity, immediacy and rawness continue to satisfy 20th-century art's craving for convulsiveness and confrontation. The Chinese civilization, on the other hand, is the oldest on earth. Its art could hardly seem more immersed in a continuum, more at ease with itself and more discreet. Indeed, there has been a strong tendency among art professionals steeped in Modernism to perceive a devotion to Oriental art primarily as an escape or refuge from the hard realities of 20th-century Western art and life.

title: Senegal Leader to Visit U.S.
description: President Abdou Diouf of Senegal left here today for Washington on a five-day private visit during which he will meet President Reagan.

title: AMEE FOUCHE IS WED TO ANDREW VERMILYE
description: Amee Fouche, an aide to Representative Webb Franklin, Republican of Mississippi, was married yesterday to Andrew Riker Vermilye, a legislative assistant to Representative Buddy MacKay, Democrat of Florida. The Rev. Richard T. Harbison, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Charles Brown, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenville, Miss.

title: Michigan Priest Reinstated
description: The Roman Catholic Church has reinstated a priest who was suspended after serving as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention last year. The priest, the Rev. Robert H. Williams, was reinstated last week after agreeing to give up politics, according to a brief announcement in the current issue of The Michigan Catholic, the diocesan newspaper. The 29-year-old priest was reassigned as an associate pastor of St. Rene Goupil's Church in suburban Sterling Heights.

title:
THE LEARNINFG SOCIETY;

SCHOOLS THAT TURN A PROFIT
description: FOR 20 YEARS Donald E. Leisey worked in public education, six of them as superintendent of the San Rafael city schools in California. He was frequently frustrated, he said, over his lack of control in the school system, constrained by what he calls ''a lot of dumb rules.'' Today Mr. Leisey does things his way. He owns and operates - for profit - the Merryhill Country Schools, a chain of elementary schools in Sacramento and Modesto, Calif., that serve 600 children from preschool age through eighth grade. And he makes money.

title:
INDEPENDENT SCHOOLS;

INTERLOCHEN, THE PIONEER IN MUSICAL HIGH SCHOOLS
description: THEY SLEEP IN A DORM CALLED Brahms not far from Eugene Ormandy Avenue. They wear uniforms designed 56 years ago. They are students at the Interlochen Arts Academy, set amid 1,200 acres of Michigan woods and fields between two lakes.

title: Why Condos Are Edging Co-ops
description: ALTHOUGH the cooperative used to be virtually the only form of apartment ownership in New York, the great majority of ''for sale'' apartments now being built in the city are condominiums.

title: HIGH-TECH TRAUMA
description: A grade-school teacher told me the other day that some of her students were wholly nonplused by the concept of ''clockwise,'' and she had figured out why: All the timepieces they had been exposed to were digital.

title: The Agony Of Ulster
description: In her article ''The Agony of Ulster'' (March 10), Jo Thomas defends a sad truth that the news media doesn't always take the time to point out: ''When men and women of principle feel compelled to engage in horrific acts, one cannot simply dismiss them as terrorists and criminals.''

title: Islay
description: To the Editor:

title: IT TOOK 5 YEARS TO GET OVER GLORIA MOVING AWAY, SLIGHTLY, ON THE DATE
description: DATING was never fun. When I was growing up, my nextdoor neighbor, Richard, had all the girls. All I did was play catch, dribble in my basement and listen to the Knicks. How could he be so comfortable with girls, when they seemed so far beyond my reach?

title: JANET L. FIGG HAS NUPTIALS
description: Janet Leigh Figg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Figg Jr. of Inverness, Ill., and Leesburg, Va., was married yesterday to Edward F. Kelly Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelly of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Alstair Votaw performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. He was assisted by the Rev. James McGuire, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: THE REGION ;   Council Offers Its Budget Ideas
description: The New York City budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 would rise to almost $20 billion under a spending plan proposed by City Council leaders last week. The plan included enough money to hire 2,000 more police officers (compared to 3,000 proposed by Mayor Koch) and provided for enough new teachers to reduce the size of some high school classes.

title: City to Honor Dali
description: The City of New York will pay tribute to Salvador Dali on Wednesday, April 17, at 6 P.M. at the Explorers Club, 46 East 70th Street. A citation from the City will be accepted on the artist's behalf by his friend and business associate Robert Descharnes. Members of the Spanish diplomatic corps will be present for the event.

title: Time for New York to Simplify Its Income Tax
description: To theEditor:

title: WHEN A CAR TALKS, SHOULD ONE LISTEN?
description: WHEN we were children, we were warned by our parents to steer clear of people walking and talking aloud - to themselves. Anyone odd enough to do that, it was presumed, might exhibit other strange behavior. I was always perplexed by the explanation that such people might have ''too much money in the bank;'' enough presumably to cause some mental disturbance.

title: Cambodian Civilians Go Farther Into Thailand
description: More than 19,000 Cambodian civilians began moving today to a site deeper inside Thailand after intelligence reports circulated that Vietnamese forces were closer to their camp.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ;   'Unfiltered' News
description: The White House News Service, offering President Reagan's speeches and announcements verbatim, began operations six months ago with hopes, one official said, that the President could get his views across to the public more effectively if they were ''unfiltered'' by the news media.

title: CLASSIC, INNOVATIVE, COMMENDABLE
description: LA MASCOTTE in Commack has matured and is now, reliably, one of the finer restaurants on the Island. The service is carefully correct yet unpretentious, the wine list is serious, and many of the dishes on an updated menu that balances the innovative and the classic are commendably prepared. Adding to these attributes is the affordable luxury of dining at La Mascotte.

title: 21 I.R.S. COMPUTER CENTERS UNCOVER NONPAYERS
description: Operating from special centers in Manhattan and 20 other places around the United States, the Internal Revenue Service has established a computerized system to track down individuals and corporations that have failed to pay their taxes.

title: WILDERNESS LAND TO BE PROTECTED
description: IT is a ''wild and woolly'' tract,

title: MONTCLAIR STATE PUTS STRESS ON ARTS
Anti-Communist Guilty In 7 Miami Bombings
description: Eduardo Arocena, who is serving a life sentence for bombings in New York City, was convicted today in seven bombings of businesses and Latin American consulates in Miami from 1979 to 1983.

title: THE NATION ;   New York Banks' Outreach
description: Three of New York City's banks zeroed in on new, potentially lucrative beachheads last week.

title: GLASS INDUSTRY IS CUTTING COSTS TO HALT EROSION
ISLANDERS DEFEAT CAPITALS
description: Space on the ice was impossible to come by. The tension grew past two periods and still no scoring. But then, the Islanders, working and scrambling to remain in the playoffs, scored two third-period goals and ended up with a 2-1 victory over the Washington Capitals.

title: DEBATE: SHOULD MANDATORY RETIREMENT BE OUTLAWED?
description: ONCE again this year Representative Claude D. Pepper of Florida, 84 years old, has introduced a bill to outlaw mandatory retirement. It is strongly supported by the American Association of Retired Persons. The opponents include the United States Chamber of Commerce, the National Association of Manufacturers and many colleges. They favor keeping the current law, which permits non-Federal institutions and companies to establish a mandatory retirement age of 65 for executives and 70 for other workers. The law already forbids any mandatory retirement age for Federal employees. A companion bill to Representative Pepper's has been sponsored for several years in the Senate by Senator Alan Cranston, the California Democrat, who is 70. A similar bill, introduced by Senator John Heinz, a 47-year-old Pennsylvania Republican, would give colleges and universities another 15 years to continue to require that professors retire at 70. The Week in Review asked Richard L. Lesher, president of the Chamber of Commerce, and Cyril F. Brickfield, executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons, to present their very different views on mandatory retirement. Excerpts follow.

title: NEIL CULLIGAN, MEDICAL STUDENT, WEDS SHEILA MCCORMICK, PHYSICAL THERAPIST
description: Sheila Marie McCormick, a daughter of Mrs. John J. McCormick of Glen Rock, N.J., and the late Mr. McCormick, was married yesterday to Neil William Culligan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John William Culligan of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The Rev. Robert F. McCormick, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Rock. He was assisted by Msgr.

title: BOXER AND PUNCHER IN FIGHT FOR TITLE AND RESPECT ;   HAGLER FORTE IS STRENGTH
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.

title: GLASS BLOWERS IN DEMAND
description: ALTHOUGH employment in South Jersey's glass industry has been declining for many years, academic interest in the field has never waned.

title: THROUH MEXICAN EYES
description: David Cavitch, who teaches at Tufts University, is the author of ''D. H. Lawrence and the New World.''

title: PATMOS: ISLE OF THE APOCALYPSE
description: Neat, diminutive signs point through a copse of pines, over a sunny hillside, down a tumbling stairway between the milk-white flanks of a pair of chapels, in an epiphany of understatement, ''To the Apocalypse.''

title: A PLOTTER'S TALE
description: THE MURDER OF RASPUTIN

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

YOUTH AND TALENT
description: Never mind the old saying: next Sunday hundreds of county high school and college students will be converging on the State University of New York at Purchase to prove conclusively that neither youth, nor talent, is wasted on the young.

title: SWEATING OUT COLLEGE ADMISSIONS
description: THIS time last year, my husband, Herb, and I were sweating out the days until April 15 when our son David, then a senior at Commack High School North, now a freshman at Brown University, would find out whether he had been accepted at the college of his choice. The following suggestions may help other parents of college-bound high school seniors get through their ordeal more easily than I did:

title: THE WORLD ;   An Opening For Albania?
description: For more than 40 years, the people of Albania knew no other dictator but Enver Hoxha. They knew little about the world either, isolated by Mr. Hoxha's obsession with secrecy, Communist orthodoxy and independence from outside influences.

title: IN SHORT
description: By Nigel West, Nigel West is an English military historian and the author of the conscientiously done exposes ''MI-5: 1909-45,'' ''A Matter of Trust: MI-5, 1945-72'' and ''MI-6: British Secret Intelligence Service Operations 1909-45.'' Having accumulated unused notes and related left-over material, Mr. West has put these to use in ''A Thread of Deceit'' to show ''how overenthusiasm, poor research or a combination of both can end in fiction acquiring a mantle of fact.''

title: Peace Efforts in Central America
description: Five Central American countries last week tried to breathe new life into a stumbling two-year effort to promote peace among them. In Panama, they agreed ''in principle'' to establish a commission to monitor provisions on arms reduction that would be part of an overall treaty.

title: New Trial OpensFor von B"ulow
description: The second trial of Claus von B"ulow, accused of trying to kill his wife so he could inherit her fortune and marry another woman, got under way last week in Providence, R.I. It seemed certain to be as long, and as dramatic, as the first.

title: INDIAN PT. TEST RESULTS WAITED
description: In a daylong test, Westchester

title: CONDOMINIUM PLAN OPPOSED
description: A GROUP of residents in Inwood,

title: STATEN ISLAND GETS READY TO GO NAVY
description: Along Bay Street, the crumbled ribbon of boulevard that edges the northern shore of Staten Island, business is slow in the beery saloons. A vacant movie theater stands next to a string of ''antique stores,'' open at odd hours to sell used household goods. But the atmosphere of decay might change soon.

title: Ex-Expatriate During the Depression, the parents of
description: Bernard Lamport took him from New York to the Soviet Union in the search for a better life.

title: SEX IS STILL NOT SIMPLE
description: PLEASURE AND DANGER

title: BEYOND THE CLASSROOM
description: Jane's formal education begins at the age of 3 in a private day-care center. When she is 6 her parents, accustomed to dropping her off on their way to work

title: MENTAL HOSPITALS: ARTICLE IS ASSAILED
description: What a great idea Dr. Lester has. I'd rush to embrace it, too, if I weren't encumbered by my experiences in the Army as a psychiatric social-work officer, with the mentally ill in public psychiatric hospitals, in community psychiatric rehabilitation programs and with families of the mentally ill.

title: Headliners ;   Back in UniformClothes oft proclaim the man, but a lack of them has defamed more than one woman. That is what seemed to have happened to
description: Cibella R. Borges , a New York City police officer in the Public Morals Division who was dismissed nearly two years ago after it became known that she had posed nude for a sex magazine in 1980.

title: IN SHORT
description: JEWELS. By Jill Tweedie. (Morrow, $17.95.)

title: WHAT'S DOING IN FLORENCE
description: In spring, the light - always soft and mellow - sheds an apricot gauze over Florence at sunset and fireflies hover above the ranks of irises blossoming in its gardens. May is the month of flowers. The loggia alongside the Uffizi Museum is crammed with every hue of azalea, from snow- white to pinks, reds, crimsons and rusts, and iris bulbs from all over the world are planted in the Iris Garden below Piazzale Michelangelo for the International Iris Competition. From May 10 to 18 the irises are judged by an international jury, and nearly every year it is an American iris that wins the top prizes. The garden is open to the public throughout May.

title: HOSPITAL FAULTED FOR DRUG MISTAKE
description: Inadequate procedures for supervising resident physicians and handling medication led to the injection of the wrong drug into the spinal column of a pregnant cancer patient at the Albany Medical Center Hospital, the State Health Department has concluded. The woman is now comatose and paralyzed.

title: JAMAICA HOST FOR A FESTIVAL OF THE YOUNG
description: There was an Afghan rebel in a camouflage jacket and turban, three Cambodian exiles, a handful of Young Republicans and a teen-ager representing the 4-H clubs of America.

title: CHANGES FOR CENSUS AROUSE CONCERN
description: AS a result of proposed changes in the Federal Census rules, Willimantic could be enlarged by a couple thousand acres in 1990, while in nearby Mansfield, the population could drop by more than one-third.

title: NEW TERRAIN IN COLLEGE MATH
description: vented to define continuous movement, has given scientists from Archimedes to Sir Isaac Newton a tool to bring meaning to the abstract world of force and motion. Millions of college students, whether or not they appreciate its historical significance, have been exposed to its differentials and integrals, slopes and areas.

title: PAUL KEATING;   BRINGING COMPETITIION TO CANBERRA
description: CANBERRA, Australia

title: Bombs Explode at Bank And an Office in Paris
description: Two bombs exploded early today outside an Israeli- owned bank and a French Government immigration office in Paris, causing major damage but no injuries, French firefighters said.

title: MAINSTREAMING MY SON
description: WHEN my son, who is afflicted with cerebral palsy and epilepsy, was 9 years old, he had the opportunity to leave the school for handicapped children he had always attended and enroll in a special class in our neighborhood public school to be what is known as ''mainstreamed.''

title: BELL ASSAILS REAGAN'S PROPOSAL TO CUT STUDENT AID
description: T. H. Bell, President Reagan's first Secretary of Education, has assailed the Administration's proposals to cut back on Federal aid to college students, characterizing the plans as an ''unwitting assault on the nation's private colleges and universities.''

title: IN SHORT
description: BEYOND WAR: Japan's Concept of Comprehensive National Security.;

title: WESTPORT'S ARTISTIC HEYDAY IS RECALLED
description: NOT too long ago, nobody in Westport needed a book to learn about the famous artists who lived, painted and held much-talked-about parties there in the early 1900's.

title: 'Stars and Bars'
description: William Boyd's novels ''A Good Man in Africa'' and ''An Ice-Cream War'' were greeted with cries of approval from both literary critics and readers, so ''Stars and Bars'' raises more than the usual anticipation. It is about an eager but shy Englishman, Henderson Dores, who comes to New York hoping to lose what he regards as his terminal Englishness in the brash, open, unreserved world of America.

title: HARTMAN THEATER GETS NEW DIRECTOR
description: THE search for a new artistic director of the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Conn. - its third in 10 years - is over. Margaret Booker, who founded Seattle's Intiman Theater, will replace Edwin Sherin, whose resignation is effective in May.

title: A TALK WITH JUSTICE REHNQUIST
description: Justice Rehnquist describes himself as ''a strong believer in pluralism.'' He would thereby appear to champion cultural and political diversity, democracy and egalitarian access to the means of life that are the very essence of pluralism.

title: BITS & PIECES
description: Although some people have always relished living in the clutter of their collections, others who are now choosing to live in rooms that echo times past are converts from the minimalist look that prevailed in the last decade. One reason they often cite for making such a dramatic shift in design is that they simply missed being surrounded by ''things.'' So they have set aside the pristine beauty of the pared-down look and are filling those empty table tops and mantels with beautiful objects old and new, expensive and not so expensive. The result is rooms that are more personal and, to many, more inviting than those of the recent past. An artfully arranged group of accessories can help to make even a new high-rise apartment exude an aura of coziness. On these pages, some suggestions for those who do not have enough of the stuff - and those who simply want more.

title: THE COLLEGE-CREDIT BANK
description: FOR years, Thomas H. Van Arsdale had been a troubled man. He did not have a college degree and, as a prominent New Jersey banker, this posed problems. For whenever he was asked to speak in public or invited to exchange credentials at social gatherings others would look askance. ''It made everyone uncomfortable,'' he said. Though he had excelled on the job and in the finance courses offered through his professional organization, even he had begun to wonder how much further he could advance without a degree, especially at a time when employers were placing increasing emphasis on academic credentials.

title: IN SHORT
description: PRIZE STORIES 1985: THE O. HENRY AWARDS. Edited and introducted by William Abrahams. (Doubleday, $16.95.)

title:
OUTDOORS;

Pursuit of Trout as Lifelong Passion
description: NEWS about Opening Day of the trout season, which occurred nearly two weeks ago, a Monday, persists and is still news. Such news has been hard to avoid. It appeared - as befits its importance - on the first page of several national newspapers, slipped to the sports pages a few days later, and, given the severity of the weather, may even have surfaced without much notice with the obits. Besides, my telephone has not stopped ringing in the past two weeks, and now I am spending a considerable fortune on calls myself, getting the latest trout news.

title: BUILDING ON HISTORY
description: Ask most English architects, and many American ones, to name the greatest English architect of the 20th century, and the odds are strong that the answer will be Sir Edwin Lutyens - an architect who was celebrated in the early years of this century, fell into eclipse for at least a generation after World War II, and is now increasingly thought of as one of the triumphant figures of English architectural history. Lutyens was England's greatest architect of great houses in modern times - a crafter of villas that were this century's equivalent of the chateaus and country houses of the past, a maker of buildings that were sprawling in size and grand in scale. But it is not these aristocratic associations that have put Lutyens so much in fashion these days; it is the fact that he was among the most dazzlingly inventive architects who ever lived.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM KUBRICK TO SAINT-EXUPERY
description: The Doors: 'Dance on Fire'

title: WESPAC: A DECADE OF EVOLUTION IN ACTIVISIM
description: SOUVENIRS of yesterday's protests fill the walls of Wespac, the Westchester People's Action Coalition, but the placards and other mementos look down on volunteers like Art Kamell and Richard Evers, preparing for tomorrow's rallies and demonstrations.

title: NEW ALBANIAN LEADER: RAMIZ ALIA
description: Ramiz Alia, the 59-year-old Albanian President, was selected today as the nation's new leader of the ruling Communist Party, succeeding Enver Hoxha, who died Thursday at 76. Mr. Alia, whose selection by the party's Central Committee was reported by the Albanian radio, was apparently picked for the job three years ago by Mr. Hoxha. In addition being President, Mr. Alia had performed many of Mr. Hoxha's tasks since the summer of 1983. This became necessary when Mr. Hoxha's health deteriorated to the point where he was unable to do more than appear at occasional functions.

title: Residential Hotel Fire Injures 15 on the Island
description: A suspicious fire severely damaged a residential hotel this afternoon, injuring 15 people, one critically, a fire department spokesman said.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: AND FREE

title: THE COURTS TRY TO SORT OUT CHALLENGES TO AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: A Federal judge recently struck down an affirmative action plan adopted by the District of Columbia Fire Department, but he did not join the Administration in its sweeping condemnation of quotas and other ''race-conscious remedies.''

title: About Men ;   Following a Wife's Move
description: MY WIFE'S ANNOUNCEMENT was not dramatic. She walked into the house after work and said, ''They want me for the Paris job.'' The offer was not unexpected nor unattractive. The bank my wife works for was giving her a promotion and transferring her to its Paris office. I reacted with excitement. I imagined all the wonderful aspects of a life in Paris: springtime, restaurants, the Louvre and weekend jaunts to quaint country inns.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;

FED SHOULD POLICE TREASURIES DEALERS
description: ; Walter E. Fauntroy is chairman of the House subcommittee on domestic monetary policy, which recently held hearings on the government securities market.

description: A Roman Catholic Church proposal to channel millions of dollars from the West to Poland's private farmers has run into obstacles, with the church and the Government blaming each other.

title:
HIGHER EDUCATION;

. . .AND THE SOFTWARE FOR IT
description: MONTHS before it shipped the first batch of its new Macintosh personal computers last winter, Apple Computer Inc. sent detailed specifications for the machines to more than two dozen colleges and universities so faculty members would be ready to write programs for the product the moment it landed on campus. The move was just one of many signs that Apple, like other computer vendors staking claims to the higher-education market, is bent on capturing the attention and imagination of software writers in academia.

title: POUND RIDGE TRACES ITS HISTORY OF LIGHT
description: HIS was the first household in Pound Ridge to have indoor plumbing, so it seemed only natural that when electricity came to that northern Westchester community in 1910, Joseph Scofield would be the first to have it.

title: LYNN ELLEN ORLOVE MARRIES J. S. COHN, SALES MANAGER
description: Lynn Ellen Orlove, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan M. Orlove of Boca Raton, Fla., was married at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan last evening to Jeffrey Stuart Cohn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold S. Cohn of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Joel Gore performed the ceremony.

title: THE STAGE: 'PLANET FIRES,' AT GEVA IN ROCHESTER
description: Renewal is the key to the theatrical opening that took place recently in this city. The Geva Theater (Geva is an abbreviation of Genesee Valley Arts Foundation) moved to its modern new $2.8 million home in the former Naval Armory and Convention Hall, inaugurating the building with the world premiere of Thomas Babe's ''Planet Fires,'' an adventurous Civil War play. Mr. Babe happens to be a Rochester playwright and ''Planet Fires,'' which takes place on a campground near Rochester, celebrates, one year late, the city's own sesquicentennial.

title: Ballet Director Named
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet Association has appointed Thomas Philion its executive director. The association's chairman, Edwin E. Tuttle, said that Mr. Philion's ''proven abilities in the past as director of marketing and acting general manager will be an asset to the organization at a time when we are looking to attract even larger audiences and support for this superb group of artists.'' Mr. Philion was formerly vice president of marketing for the combined operations of the Connecticut Opera, Hartford Ballet and Hartford Center Orchestra.

title: A GOOD NUT TO CRACK
description: THERE IS A DEFINITE aristocracy in the world of nuts (the sort that can be shaken from trees). In the lesser ranks, I would place peanuts and pecans, hastening to add that I enjoy both; in the ultimate grades, I would place almonds, hazelnuts and walnuts. For me, it is the latter category that has the greatest appeal, black walnuts in particular.

title:
GARDENING;

A NEW LOOK AT THE CRAB APPLE
description: MOST gardeners are still at a loss to know what to plant as a replacement for our ailing dogwoods. Many young dogwoods are being planted to replace those that have died, but the disease that has destroyed mature trees now seems to be attacking the young replacements, also. A satisfactory treatment program has not yet been discovered.

title: PAMELA BRIGGS IS BRIDE OF ERIC TAYLOR KREUTER
description: At the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Pamela Ann Briggs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Briggs of Greenwich, Conn., was married to Eric Taylor Kreuter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Kreuter of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony.

title: WATER-SAVING PLAN AT ISSUE
description: PROPOSED cuts in one of the few Federal programs that benefit Long Island farmers would also hamper efforts to conserve ground water in agricultural areas of the East End, according to officials in Suffolk County.

title: A Talk With Justice Rehnquist
description: For one in the lower reaches of the Federal judiciary, there is a disquieting air about John Jenkins's article ''The Partisan: A Talk With Justice Rehnquist'' (March 3). The suggestion that the Justice is guided more by ''an inner compass that almost unfailingly evolved from a moral vision developed long ago'' than by

Cotzias Distinguished Professor of Neurology and the director of the Laboratory of Neurobiology at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Associate Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the former Burden mansion in Manhattan.

title: FESTIVAL HONORS MUSICAL THEATER
description: A total of 101 theater works will be presented at the Annenberg Center of the University of Pennsylvania between Sept. 12 and Oct. 13, as part of the American Music Theater Festival's 1985 season. Highlights will include the East Coast premiere of ''Seehear,'' by the George Coates Performance Works, with music by Paul Dresher; the world premiere of ''Mowgli,'' a musical setting of Rudyard Kipling's ''Jungle Book'' by Kirk Nurock, and a new staging of Lee Breuer and Bob Telson's musical ''Gospel at Colonus.''

description: Ernie Camacho, the Cleveland Indians' relief pitcher who recorded 23 saves last season, underwent minor surgery to remove a bone chip from his right elbow, according to the club, which said he would be out two to four weeks. . . .

In fact, he wasn't even the only player in Boston in that position. Marc Sullivan is a rookie member of the Red Sox, and his father, Haywood, is part owner, chief executive officer and chief operating officer of the Red Sox.

When Knopf republished his two best novels - ''The Good Soldier'' and ''Parade's End'' - in 1950 and 1951, their dust jackets were festooned with critics' praises and exhortations in an attempt to bully or seduce the public.

description: WHEN Clarence Pico, the Litchfield auctioneer, takes up his microphone and gavel, it is usually to sing the praises of an antique French armoire or an Oriental vase.

description: WHILE Manhattan has been something of a launch pad for apartment towers in the last two years, there has been no significant construction of unsubsidized apartment buildings in the other four boroughs.

description: As the cobblestone path sinks gradually below ground level, the black marble reaches gradually higher. In the grass above panel W66, someone has planted a tiny flag near the name GARY E. BECKER. At W52, there's another flag, near HENRY F. NUGENT. By W20, the panels rise taller than the people who inspect them with such urgent solemnity. ''There's Mike's name!'' says a young man in pressed designer jeans.

description: So Dr. David Lester (''Discipline for Mental Hospitals?'', Opinion Page, March 31) visited a psychiatric hospital and found the patients for the most part unkempt and apathetic. This is hardly news for relatives and professionals who must deal with the mentally ill.

title: OFF AND RUNNING AT YONKERS
description: Just after 7 o'clock tonight, Mike (Mickey) Murphy began a familiar routine. First he hit a white button marked ''clear,'' then a yellow button marked ''special report,'' then the number ''10,'' and finally his access code. Within seconds his American Totalisator machine, No. 141 in a field of 185 betting windows, was off and running at Yonkers Raceway.

title: OFFERING THE HANDICAPPED A SUMMER OF OPPORTUNITY
description: IN early January Bernadette Saunders of the Bronx began searching for the best place for her 14-year-old learning- disabled son to spend the summer. She talked to his teachers and counselors at school, called advocacy and referral agencies and spent a Saturday morning at a camp fair for children with special needs. ''He would have been very happy if I sent him back to the camp he was at last year,'' Mrs. Saunders said. '' But I want to give him a new challenge.''

description: The marriage of Marcia Bishop McCabe of New York, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bayard McCabe Jr. of Wallingford, Pa., to Christopher Paul Goutman of New York took place yesterday at the Swarthmore (Pa.) Presbyterian Church.

description: The marriage of Jean Marie Lombardo, a daughter of Lebert Lombardo of Sanibel Island, Fla., and the late Peggy Landers Lombardo, to Anthony C. Cudahy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony B. Cudahy of Omaha, took place yesterday.

title: CONTAMINATED TOWN IS RELEGATED TO HISTORY
description: For the past several years Times Beach, Mo., has been a pitiful name in the news, but that has come to an end. The small community some 24 miles west of here has ceased to be a town, and the name has been relegated to history.

title: 'SUSAN' DRAWS SPIRIT FROM THE SIDEWALKS OF NEW YORK
description: While patrolling the St. Marks Place set in the East Village during the first day of filming last September, a police officer approached the actress who appeared to be the star of ''Desperately Seeking Susan'' and said, ''Madonna, may I have your autograph?''

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: WHY BAGGAGE CHARGES CAN SOAR
description: When Avianca Airlines of Colombia charged him $63.70 for ''excess baggage'' on a flight from Barranquilla to New York last August, David Franco was annoyed. He, his wife and their 5-year-old daughter were traveling with six suitcases and a cardboard box. ''The six suitcases weighed no more than what they weighed when I left for Colombia from New York,'' Mr. Franco complained, ''and I was not charged for excess baggage in New York.'' He said the cardboard box contained two lampshades that he and his wife had bought in Colombia and ''could not have weighed more than four or five pounds.''

title: A SAFE APPROACH TO WEED CONTROL
description: Herbicides are chemicals used to hold weed growth to acceptable levels. In some cases they eliminate limited infestations of undesirable or poisonous plants. The effort to control weeds depends upon how undesirable the weeds may be to the homeowner.

title: Care Down to Tiniest Detail
description: MY first boss was a guy named Charlie Hontz, who ran the Diamond Garage in Catasauqua, Pa. He was a bear of a man and he brooked no nonsense when it came to cleaning the customers' automobiles.

title: 564-UNIT ADDITION
description: For decades the housing stock in Mount Olive Township, N.J., consisted primarily of single- family homes whose owners worked outside the community.

title: 2 CHORUS-LINE VETERANS EVOKE ERA OF THE APOLLO
description: The young dancers overflowed with energy and dreams yesterday. But when it came to that intangible known as glamour, they had a lot to learn from a pair of women in their 70's who had danced, a long timg ago, in the famed chorus line at the old Apollo Theater in Harlem.

Bierman. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony.

JUDGE WAIVES A RULE ON PAROLE ELIGIBILITY FOR EX-CITY OFFICIAL
description: A Federal judge has refused to reduce the 12-year prison sentence of New York City's former director of lease negotiations, who pleaded guilty last year to extorting $1.2 million from landlords who wanted to gain or keep city agencies as tenants.

title: A NOVELIST IN A DERELICT CITY
description: WHEN I WAS a child, Sheffield was a dirty and dangerous city. I was born there, in 1939, on the eve of the outbreak of World War II, and was promptly evacuated with my family to a safer spot - wisely, as it turned out, for Sheffield, the heart of British armaments manufacture and of the steel industry, was very heavily bombed. The air raids of 1940 killed more than 700 people, rendered many thousands homeless and destroyed the commercial center. When we returned after the war, the scars of the blitz were everywhere: in the town's principal shopping street, willow herb blossomed purple from craters and in the surrounding suburbs, intimate domestic interiors were exposed to the public gaze and forlorn scraps of wallpaper flapped from half-demolished walls - abandoned, and abandoned, moreover, for many years, for in the period of austerity after the war nobody could afford to rebuild. Prosperity returned gradually, and it was not until the late 1950's that vast new monuments of public building and socialist aspiration - the municipal government has long been staunchly Labor - began to arise from the ashes, creating the dramatic skyline that Sheffield now presents of high-rise apartment buildings and factory chimneys set against the surrounding hills.

title: 9-DIGIT ZIP CODE MEETS OPPOSITION IN HOUSE
description: When the nine-digit ZIP code went into effect in October 1983, the Postal Service described it as the wave of the future, ''addressing tomorrow today.''

title: FOR SALE: ZIP CODE 07837 AND A TOWN -- MORE OR LESS
RAIL EXCURSION IN THE ANDES
description: The little train - bright red, with yellow letters proclaiming Expreso Metropolitan - takes off from Chimbacalle Station in Quito on a sunny spring morning for a sightseeing trip along Ecuador's Avenue of the Volcanoes. The passengers look forward to two days on the Andean Plateau, flanked by two mighty mountain ranges and a dozen of the highest snow-capped cones in the Western Hemisphere. To add variety, there will be visits to markets and small towns with lilting names like Ambato and Latacunga, an overnight stay in the provincial capital of Riobamba and a return trip by bus along the Pan American Highway.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

FILLING THE MA BELL TAX GAP
description: ; William P. Schuber, a Republican, represents the 38th District (parts of Bergen County) in the State Assembly.

title: LIVING WITH BOTH
description: Though not initially drawn to technology, I have to report a conversion that was long, slow and somewhat reluctant. I was 14 when I placed my first telephone call, 27 when I watched my first television program and 39 when I first opened the door of a freezer. (After five minutes in front of the television set, I said, ''That thing will never get off the ground,'' thereby making what may have been the silliest remark since Madame de Sevigne said of Racine's plays that they were ''just a fad, like coffee.'')

We pulled out wooden boxes, file cabinets, cardboard cartons and ancient steamer trunks. We unwrapped familiar mementos as well as things we had never seen before.

title: MENTAL HOSPITALS: ARTICLE IS ASSAILED
description: As a psychiatrist, physician and human being, I was frightened by Dr. Lester's article. I kept waiting for a disclaimer that it was written tongue- in-cheek, but it never came.

title: STADIUM SALE OPPOSED
description: -year debate over whether to save or sell the Freeport Municipal Stadium - home for more than 50 years to midget and stock car racing - may now be played out in the courts.

title: THEATER: BRECHT'S 'ROUNDHEADS AND POINTHEADS'
description: As a great admirer of ''Measure for Measure,'' Bertolt Brecht borrowed the plot as the basis for ''Roundheads and the Pointheads,'' a pre-Holocaust parable about Hitler's racial policies. The Brecht version, written in the early 1930's and revised after Hitler's rise to power, was also an exploration of the playwright's theory that the Third Reich and the rich were ''birds of a feather.''

description: The Portland Breakers and the Generals, who meet today at Giants Stadium, were first assembled at the same time and same place - two years ago at the University of Central Florida.

description: Antonio Torres . Last month, when his wife reported a $50,000 burglary at their Hialeah, Fla., home, she did not tell the police that she had written down the license number of a ''suspicious'' car in the neighborhood.

description: Like so many other features of the economy these days, military spending no longer has the effect it used to.

description: WESTCHESTER'S state representatives return to Albany next week amid indications that attempts to reach agreement on county-requested legislation may be a more prolonged, and more acrimonious, process than was involved in reaching an accord on the state's recently passed $39 billion budget.

title: NEW WAY TO GROW ASPARAGUS FOUND
description: ASPARAGUS fresh from the farm? Endive from Connecticut, not Belgium, France or the Netherlands? The scientists at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in New Haven believe these are possibilities, and are eager to make them happen.

description: After having shot an 80 in Thursday's opening round of the Masters, Curtis Strange doubted that he would survive the 36-hole cut. He made a reservation for a flight home to Kingsmill, Va., following his Friday round.

title: ROMANCE OF THE PAST
description: The library is by far the most lived-in room in traditional English houses. It is also the room that is constantly changing as a favorite object is brought in to use and enjoy.

title: RATING A HOME ON ITS ENERGY EFFICIENCY
description: WHEN it comes to saving energy at home, the device most often used by New Jerseyans is the sweater. Since the first oil-price shocks of 1973, homeowners have installed elaborate solar heating systems, superinsulated their homes and even built windmills to generate their own electricity. But, according to the State Department of Energy, the most common residential energy conservation measure by far has been simply lowering the thermostat.

title: ON THE OBITUARY PAGE, TALES LARGER THAN LIFE
description: AS a boy growing up in Flushing, I remember frequent trips ''downtown'' to visit the library, a modest, neoclassic building since buried under a less human brick slab. Morning visits during the week were especially exciting, in part because of playing hooky; the library hushed, womblike, against the raucous flow of Main Street traffic. Its handful of patrons, mostly white-haired pensioners, slouched deep inside leather chairs and studied one of the seven or eight newspapers New York then supported.

title: NEW OWNER OF L.I. SITE ORDERED TO CLEAN UP WASTE
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that a Long Island landowner must clean up more than 600,000 gallons of hazardous waste on his land even though the waste was there before he bought the site.

title: ANIMAL MEDICAL OFFICE'S CARE RIVALS THAT FOR HUMANS

title: PROSPECTS
description: Growth's Slowing Track

title: TRANSFER STUDENT: TRYING TO FIT IN
description: WHEN Joyce Kelly transferred in her sophomore year from a small women's college to the University of Delaware, she wanted students to think she had been there all along. ''During my first week here, I used to duck into any women's bathroom I could find to look at my campus map and get oriented,'' said the adjusted senior, who transferred from Rosemont College in Pennsylvania. ''Opening up one of those huge maps on campus is like having a neon sign over your head that reads, 'Look at me. I'm new.' As a transfer, you usually want to separate yourself from freshmen because you've already gone through the trauma of that first college year.''

title: UNION-MADE SALE
description: The United Farm Workers of America is most often associated with the farmlands and vineyards of California and the citrus groves of the Southeast. But for more than a decade the union owned a limestone-faced town house on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: INVENTING A GROUP TO HELP INVENTORS
description: WHEN Murray Schiffman was five years old, he spent a summer at Coney Island working on an invention. The ''flywheel,'' as he called it, consisted of flies whose feet were glued, with a sticky substance from his chemistry set, onto toothpicks that were then set into a cork. When the device was placed in a pan of water, the flies flapped their wings and the flywheel spun like a merry- go-round.

title: BUILDING A HOME FROM THE GROUND UP
description: FOR many in Westchester, the dream of owning one's own home has become a difficult one to realize because of the soaring cost of land, materials, labor and mortgages. According to the Westchester Realty Board, the average cost of a single-family dwelling in the county last year was $190,000 and a custom-built new home could require more than $220,000.

title: DEFIANCE IN SOUTH AFRICA

title: New & Noteworthy
description: STENGEL: His Life and Times, by Robert W. Creamer. (Dell, $8.95.) In the autumn of 1960, when Casey Stengel - who began his baseball career in 1912 - was fired by the New York Yankees, he had managed the team for 12 years and it had won 7 World Series and 10 American League pennants, an unsurpassed record. Last year Lawrence S. Ritter commented here that ''Robert W. Creamer has done us a favor by bringing Casey Stengel to life again. This excellent biography makes us realize just how much we miss him - not only in Yankee Stadium, where the only wit and humor in recent years has been of the gallows variety, but throughout the world of sports and indeed in public life generally.''
