They said Mr. Sullivan, who killed Eleanor Bumpurs with two rounds from his shotgun, acted to protect a partner after Mrs. Bumpurs attacked them with a kitchen knife.

title: REPROGRAMMING THE BILL OF RIGHTS FOR THE COMPUTER AGE
description: A California legislator named Gwen Moore is battling to bring the state constitution into the computer age.

title: MINORITIES OFFERED PUBLIC POLICY STUDY
description: A SELECT group of 28 minority students who have completed their junior year of college will gather at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs this summer for a seven- week, all-expenses-paid educational program in public policy.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: April 14, 1985

title: PATRICIA SCHMID PLANS TO WED J. E. HOMAN IN MAY
description: A May 18 wedding is planned by Patricia Louise Schmid and John Edward Homan, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Emil Schmid of Vienna, Va., have announced.

title: THE SHULTZ-WEINBERGER FEUD
description: THUNDER ROLLED ACROSS the flight deck of the French aircraft carrier Clemenceau in the eastern Mediterranean. One by one, 14 Super Etendard jet fighters roared skyward and then banked toward Lebanon. Their mission: to retaliate for the truck bombings of the French and American military headquarters in Beirut that had killed 59 French paratroopers and 241 American servicemen. Until that day - Nov. 17, 1983 - the raid had been conceived and planned as a joint French-American effort to attack targets near the Lebanese town of Baalbek, a stronghold of pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militiamen believed by the Central Intelligence Agency to have been involved in the bombings. President Reagan had authorized Navy fighter planes attached to the Sixth Fleet to join the air strike, a decision that has remained one of the better- kept secrets of the Reagan Administration. It was the first time an American President had approved a counterterrorist attack.

title: THE RACE FOR THE RIGHT PC . . .
description: ''Let's say you are studying the writings of Thomas Jefferson,'' began Raymond K. Neff, assistant vice chancellor for information systems and technology at the University of California at Berkeley. ''You take a document that he wrote in 1815 and compare it with some writings from 1772. With both of those on your screen you call up what John Locke had to say on the subject - because Locke was a big influence on Jefferson - and you compare that with something from Rousseau. Then in a fifth ''window'' you have your scratch work space where you can be writing your own commentary on the subject.''

title: CONNORS, INJURED, DEFAULTS SEMIFINAL
description: Jimmy Connors's back injury flared up again today, forcing him to retire in the second set of the semifinals against Ivan Lendl in the Buick $500,000 World Championship Tennis Finals. Lendl will face Tim Mayotte in the final. Mayotte defeated Joakim Nystrom in four sets.

title: OVERTIME VICTORY GIVES OILERS SWEEP
description: Glenn Anderson struck for the game- winning goal 46 seconds into overtime tonight as the defending Stanley Cup champion Edmonton Oilers defeated the Los Angeles Kings, 4-3, to sweep their opening-round series.

title:
S LESSON IN WHEN TO GIVE UP THE RING;

; John T. Coiley III is a writer in Baltimore.$
description: T NINTEEN SEVENTY-ONE was fast drawing to a close, and I was about to carve a place in Boston's history books. The professional boxing card, scheduled for Saturday, Dec. 11, would be the first held in the Hynes Civic Auditorium. The 10-round main event was a rematch of six weeks earlier when, in New Orleans, I was clearly outboxed in losing a 10-round decision to Tony Licata.

title: NEW LIFE FOR THE DETROIT SYMPHONY
description: DETROIT

title: 1,000 HOLD PROTEST IN GUATEMALA
description: More than 1,000 people marched on the national palace today to dramatize their search for relatives who have disappeared after being abducted.

title: FOR MORE U. S. BENIGN NEGLECT OF THE MIDEAST
description: Arabs and Israelis are ready for peace, it is said by many in this country and in the Middle East: the missing ingredient, they argue, is an American role, an American peace plan. The other side of this promise is a threat: dire consequences are predicted, for the region and for American interests there, if the Reagan Administration fails to embark on an activist Middle Eastern policy.

title: WOMEN AND THE MORMEN CHURCH
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GRAND CONVIVIAL PLAZA-ATHENEE
description: In Paris, there are hotels that are cozy,

title: A LOOK AT GAMING'S ECONOMICS
RED SOX WIN, 7-2
description: Tony Armas hit a two-run home run in the second inning and Jim Rice had a pair of run-scoring singles this afternoon to spark the Boston Red Sox to their fourth straight victory, a 7-2 decision over the Chicago White Sox.

title: Verbatim: A Change of Heart
description: 'What made me fall off the bandwagon was the night of February 21, when President Reagan said he wanted to change the structure of the Nicaraguan Government.

title: Food-Poisoning Cases In Midwest Rise to 4,742
description: Nearly a thousand new cases of food poisoning were reported in 24 hours, bringing the total in the nation's largest outbreak of food poisoning to 4,742 in five Middle Western states, officials said today.

title:
GARDENING;

A NEW LOOK AT THE CRAB APPLE
description: MOST gardeners are still at a loss to know what to plant as a replacement for our ailing dogwoods. Many young dogwoods are being planted to replace those that have died, but the disease that has destroyed mature trees now seems to be attacking the young replacements, also. A satisfactory treatment program has not yet been discovered.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ;   Ivy League Boxer
description: His name was Henry Milligan, and he made the sports pages because, after all, how many Ivy Leaguers end up in the prizefight ring?

title: Chart of largest I. M. F. lending programs (International Monetary Fund);   THE I. M. F.'S HELP CAN SOMETIMES HURT
description: The Sudan, desperate for cash to pay mounting bills for fuel and other critical needs, signed a $90 million standby loan agreement with the International Monetary Fund last June 25. In return, President Gaafar el- Nimeiry's Government had to cut its budget deficit, curb subsidies on food (meaning prices would rise), check credit expansion and devalue the Sudanese pound.

title: The Climate Did It
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT
description: Gert Hofmann, whose novel ''The Spectacle at the Tower'' won Germany's D"oblin Prize in 1982, here shows how children can distill wonder from the dregs of war. ''Our Conquest'' places the children of the Imbach family in an apocalyptic setting.

title: BOTTLE BILL FLOOR VOTE POSSIBLE IN TRENTON
RIDING A WAVE OF ASIAN-AMERICAN HOUSING DEMAND
description: FIRST he was in Flushing. Then in Elmhurst. This month he is starting in Rego Park, but he will be back in Flushing later in the year.

title: PLIGHT OF DRIVERS WHO DRINK AIDS SOUTH CAROLINA LAWYER
description: A nationwide crusade to get drunken drivers off the highways has bolstered business for a South Carolina lawyer who specializes in getting them acquitted.

title: IN OPERA, RACE ISN'T A BLACK OR WHITE ISSUE
description: One of the brightest pages in Metropolitan Opera history was written on Jan. 7, 1955, when Marian Anderson became the first black singer to appear with the company. It must be hard for this generation to comprehend that only 30 years ago the Metropolitan, like many another American institution, had an unspoken rule against admitting blacks. When the Bing administration engaged her to sing the role of Ulrica in ''A Masked Ball,'' Miss Anderson was just three weeks short of her 53d birthday and well beyond her vocal prime, but her appearance on the Metropolitan stage was more than an operatic event; it stood as a symbol of a new social freedom that seemed to be stirring in this country.

title: DENISE L. CHRZAN BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Denise Lynn Chrzan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald John Chrzan of Milwaukee, was married there yesterday to Peter Morrell Shepherd, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Shepherd of Westfield, N.J. The Rev. Charles Burns, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Alverno College Chapel in Milwaukee, assisted by the Rev. John Seabrook, an Episcopal priest.

description: GIVE US EACH DAY

title: A FAIR SHAKE FOR THE SHOW THAT MAY NOT LAST
description: In recent years the theater seems to have got itself confused with a flower bed. It only comes to life in the

title: Marina Berths at a Premium
description: The waterfronts of Long Island Sound have come to life in the last few weeks. The sounds of once-dormant marine engines, of whining electric power tools, and of sandpaper on wood and fiberglass spell the onset of yet another boating season.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ;   Sweat Victory
description: The good news for Jose and Sylvia Carmona was that they had won a public drawing in Kansas City, Mo., that gave them the right to acquire an abandoned three-bedroom ranch house through ''sweat equity.''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: ONE OF the forces behind Washington's recent decision to shift a sewage- sludge dump site farther offshore was Clean Ocean Action, a Sea Bright-based antidumping coalition that has built a statewide constituency of 100,000 to 150,000 people in the last four years.

title: EAST RIVER TIDES TO RUN ELECTRICAL GENERATOR
description: The New York Power Authority plans to install an experimental hydroelectric generator on a drawbridge off Roosevelt Island in the East River this spring.

description: BARRING an unanticipated complication, the Town of East Hampton is about to make the largest land purchase for preservation in its history. At a recent meeting the Town Board voted to have Supervisor

title: Brazilian's Condition 'Extremely Serious'
description: President-elect Tancredo Neves remained in very serious condition today, with machines doing the work of his kidneys and lungs, a Government spokesman said.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Although the Great Neck Symphony has been celebrating its 40th anniversary all season long, tonight's the night of the official 40th Anniversary Concert. So at 7:30 P.M. at South Senior High School on Lakeville Road, the pioneering community orchestra, under Herbert Grossman's baton and with the violinist Bruce Dukov as soloist, performs Sibelius, Rossini and Tchaikovsky. For ticket information call 829-6612. WHITHER BLUEBIRDS?

description: To the Editor:

title: ALEXANDRA MANN PLANNING TO MARRY JOHN REID JR.
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Mann of New York have announced the engagement of his daughter Alexandra Mann to John Reid Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reid of Princeton, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: BOWLING THEM OVER
description: -step, two-step, drop the ball. But the pins go down and that's what's important, especially considering that she started bowling ''steady,'' as she puts it, 13 years ago when she was 78.

description: FOR those possessing even a month's experience in dealing with a personal computer, DOS, the disk operating system,

title: Chain Reopens Restaurant
description: A McDonald's restaurant opened Thursday to replace one at which, on July 18, James Oliver Huberty killed 21 people and wounded 19 others before he was slain by police. The new restaurant is a few blocks from the now-empty site of the killings. The fast-food chain donated the property to the city of San Diego, which governs this community near the Tijuana border.

title: CLAY FEET
description: ALLEGRO POSTILLIONS

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Film page of the Arts and Leisure section today about ''Desperately Seeking Susan'' misstates the number of theaters where it opened, as well as early box-office revenue and attendance figures. The film opened in 268 theaters, grossed more than $4 million in the first 10 days and was seen by 800,000 people.

title: Carr de Naskra Wins on Return
description: The feature race at Aqueduct yesterday was the $146,250 Excelsior Handicap, but the most interesting race was the $36,000 Zip Pocket Handicap, in which Carr de Naskra returned to the races with an impressive 1 3/4-length victory.

title: SAFE AT HOME
description: Historically, obvious has been the key word in describing home protection. Feudal lords dug moats around their castles and filled them with snapping crocodiles, poised to pounce on perpetrators. Technology later advanced to such attractive methods as steel gates and barbed wire, all effecting the nice, homey appeal of a maximum-security prison.

title: DOCUMENTING NATIONAL PARKS
description: Denali, Grand Teton, the Everglades, Big Bend and Shenandoah. Mesa Verde and Morristown, Cumberland Gap and Appomattox, Fort Laramie. The country of the Nez Perce, Overland Migrations and Glacier Bay.

title: STUDY FINDS USE OF SOME 'SAFE' PESTICIDES HARMFUL
description: NOW that spring is here, Westchester residents may ask themselves: At what cost to the environment and their own health are they willing to pursue the dream of a ''perfect'' lawn? According to Ward Stone, wildlife pathologist with the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, unnecessarily large amounts of toxins are being applied each year to suburban yards and golf courses and are finding their way into the food chain.

title: JERSEY COURT RULES OUT EVIDENCE FROM DEFECTIVE WARRANTS
description: Despite a recent United States Supreme Court decision, a New Jersey appeals court has ruled that evidence seized with a defective search warrant cannot be used in criminal trials even if the police were acting in good faith.

title: MAKING THE SUMMER JOB A CAREER LAUNCHING PAD
description: ''I DON'T think I would be here today if it were not for that summer job,'' said Mary Pisano, a staff accountant at Deloitte, Haskins & Sells, a Big Eight accounting concern. Miss Pisano, a 1984 graduate of Villanova University, worked as an accounting intern for the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities during the summer before her senior year. The experience she gained there gave her an edge over other candidates when she sought permanent employment.

title: TALKING TERMS ;   IT'S A DATE, BUT WHERE WHEN AND FOR WHAT?
description: WASHINGTONMIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV, the new Soviet leader, publicly turned his attention to relations with the United States last Sunday, touching off the most active week in East-West diplomacy in years. ''I am convinced,'' Mr. Gorbachev said in an interview with Pravda, ''that a serious impulse should be given to Soviet-American relations at a high political level.''

title: Artificial HeartUsed in Europe
description: A Swedish heart-attack victim last weekend became the first person outside the United States to receive an artificial heart. The implant operation, which left the patient in ''unexpectedly good shape,'' according to a hospital spokesman, was performed at the Karolinska Thoracic Clinic in Sweden, Scandinavia's leading health center.

title: Peter Steinfels, the editor of Commonweal magazine, is the author of ''The Neoconservatives.''
description: HABITS OF THE HEART

title: T.W.A. TAKES A $5 MILLION SEAT OVERSEAS

title: NORWALK FACTIONS DECLARE A TRUCE
description: -month battle over control of Norwalk's city government - although they disagree over who won.

title: THE POWER AND THE PERILS OF JUNK BONDS
description: THE financial press has been bulging with the latest examples of a world seemingly gone mad with corporate takeover fever. On Thursday alone, no fewer than half a dozen deals for companies worth a billion dollars or more each were reported to be on the trading block. The big names in corporate raiding - T. Boone Pickens, Carl Icahn and Sir James Goldsmith - were all on the scene, along with newcomer Stephen Wynn of Golden Nugget. However varied the prey and their pursuers, there is one common denominator in all of these deals: All are likely to rely on an increasingly popular technique - known as junk bond financing - that has raised the stakes and helped fuel the takeover frenzy that has gripped the nation in recent months.

title: Mailbox ;   One 'Purist' Fan Votes Against the Shot Clock
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Talking Landscaping ;   Be Sure Ordinances Permit It
description: AMONG of the pleasures of owning a single-family house on its own lot are the freedom to landscape the yard and to use it for recreation.

title: MARGARET FARLEY MARRIES IN JERSEY
description: Margaret Mary Farley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent W. Farley of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Patrick Steele, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Steele of Broadchalke, near Salisbury, England. Judge Charles M. Egan Jr. of the New Jersey State Superior Court performed the ceremony at the Canoe Brook Country Club in Summit, N.J.

title: Attitude Controls the Game
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: THE RIGHTS AND PRIVILEGES OF GRANDPARENTS
ENIGMA OF JUSTICE BLACK IS EXAMINED
description: Next year, when his alma mater marks Hugo L. Black's 100th birthday, the topic will be his years on the United States Supreme Court. Today, those who lived with Black or worked for him or have studied his long and eventful life gathered at the University of Alabama Law School to ponder something more complicated still: the kind of man he was when he got there.

title: CALIFORNIA AT THE READY, IT HOPES, FOR BIG QUAKE
description: As never before, California is preparing for a catastrophic earthquake that could kill thousands of people and injure hundreds of thousands, demolish whole neighborhoods and cripple the nation's economy for weeks or months.

title: Error Weighs HeavilyOn Purchasing Clerk
description: An Army clerk thought he was ordering a $6.04 incandescent lamp. But instead he sent for a 14,500-pound anchor, and now it is sitting in a shipping yard at Fort Carson.

title: The Deferred-War Plan for Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: PROTECTING THE ISLAND'S DRINKING WATER
description: Raising public awareness of the need to protect Long Island's only source of drinking water is laudable (''Bills Seek to Protect Aquifer,'' March 24). However, I would like to make several points regarding Federal legislation to preserve high-quality drinking water in the nation's 18 sole-source aquifers.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SOMEWHERE I have lost everyone who knew what was going on in Oceanside. For years I got most of my local news from fellow commuters, but my new commuting partners, all fine, lovely people, don't seem plugged in the way the old ones were. The 8:46 was a place where I could be sure to find out what was happening in School No. 8 or the library, the Mott Avenue zoning hearing and the Sanitation Department. Now, I hear stories about skiing in Switzerland.

title: GOOD THINGS IN SMALL PACKAGES
description: It is the small museums of Paris, hidden

title:
DINING OUT;

THE PASTA PARADE IS STILL GROWING
description: NEIL SIMON is supposed to have said that there are two universal laws: the Law of Gravity and Everybody Likes Italian Food.

title: WRITING FOR THE MOVIES IS HARDER THAN IT LOOKS
description: IF you confide to the person next to you on an airplane that you are a novelist, he will feel uncomfortable and hostile, assuming you to be a boastful liar, and he will be embarrassed because he hasn't read your books. But it is otherwise if you say you are a screenwriter. Now he will respond with sympathetic interest and talk about his favorite films. The screenwriter is widely believed to be a put-upon lackey who has sacrificed self-respect and any hope of true artistic achievement for the dubious interest of momentary association with movie stars and the chance for high pay. (And there may be some truth in this assumption.) It is this combination of glamour and moral compromise that seems to invite fellow-feeling.

title: Klosters
description: To the Editor:

title: ONCE HARD-BITTEN EDITORS PONDER NEW CORPORATE ROLE
description: In honor of this year's meeting of the nation's newspaper editors here, the staff at the convention's hotel simulated a newsroom in the lobby with a row of battered typewriters and ashtrays overflowing with cigarette butts, and projected a movie version of ''The Front Page'' on a small screen nearby.

title: Ex-Official Gets Prison Term
description: John Kerr, a former state official convicted of running a job-selling scheme in the Pennsylvania Auditor General's office that netted $200,000, was sentenced Thursday to two to five years in prison and fined $6,950. Mr. Kerr, 34 years old, was the top aide to the Auditor General from 1977 to 1983. He was convicted last June 30 on 139 counts of bribery, conspiracy and other charges.

title: STATES TRY TO HALT MILEAGE FRAUD IN USED CARS
description: When an automobile salesman here rolled back the mileage on a used car by almost 60,000 miles, he made a profit of $1,375, the Marion County sheriff's office says.

title: COST OF POWER: THE DEBATE CONTINUES
description: AS the completion of the Millstone 3 nuclear power plant draws closer - and with it the presentation of a bill for nearly $4 billion - the General Assembly is once again debating how electric users should pay it. But earlier this month the lawmakers decided to leave the key decision to the Department of Public Utility Control.

title: DIVER SETS RECORDS DESPITE HANDICAPS
description: JEANETTE LEFEVER, a University of Connecticut sophomore, is faced with several handicaps. Yet, despite her problems, the 19-year-old has managed to shatter all the women's diving records at her school and has captured a number of medals in state division circles this year.

title: BORROWED FROM BRITAIN
description: American-born though he was, George Washington no doubt appreciated the compliment once paid him by a foreign visitor to Mount Vernon: ''The General has never left America, but when one sees his house and his home and his garden, it seems as if he had copied the best samples of the grand old homesteads of England.'' He did it then, as many do it now, by the book. The book he had then was written in 1728 by the English landscape ''improver'' Batty Langley, and its full title was ''New Principles of Gardening, the Laying Out and Planting of Parterres, Groves, Wildernesses, Labyrinths, Avenues, Parks etc.; after a more Grand and Rural Manner than has been done before.'' Washington literally left no stone unturned at Mount Vernon. The same could be said of the contemporary American English-style gardens shown on these pages.

title: MISS CHURCHILL WED TO E. W. CATTAN JR.
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Evanston, Ill., yesterday Elizabeth Churchill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Alfred Churchill of Northfield, Ill., was married to Edmond William Cattan Jr., the son of Mr. Cattan of Cos Cob, Conn., and the late Louise Armstrong Cattan. The Rev. David Handley, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Harold Blake Walker, performed the ceremony.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT CAPTIALS;   FLYERS SWEEP, KERR SCORES 4
description: The Rangers knew from the beginning that they had to stop Tim Kerr or their season would be finished. They are now on their way home, defeated in three straight playoff games, and last night at the Garden Kerr placed his name in the record books, where it will likely reamin for years.

title: MEESE'S NEW POST HELD SIGN OF SHIFT
description: Both conservatives and liberals say the selection of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to head a new Cabinet council supervising domestic policy signals the dominance of a more ideological brand of conservatism in President Reagan's second term.

title: CRISIS-RIDDEN PERU VOTES FOR PRESIDENT TODAY
description: Deeply disillusioned with the results of the last five years of democratic rule, Peruvians will vote Sunday to pick a new President from among nine candidates offering leftist, centrist and conservative solutions to the country's worst crisis in memory.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE KING IN THE GARDEN

title: GREAT WORKS
description: Ralph Greenhill, a former photo archivist with the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, spent more than 12 years assembling the 90 daguerreotypes, stereographs and photographs that are handsomely presented inENGINEER'S WITNESS (Godine, $35). The picture taken by William England on the Niagara River in 1859 would be an unexceptional view of a family outing were it not for parallel, pencil-thin lines in the distance.

title:
INVESTING;

A NEW WAY TO PLAY EXXON'S STOCK
description: IN coming weeks a new investment trust will become available to investors that for the first

title: THE DANCE: PAUL TAYLOR
description: Who but Paul Taylor would set dancers to darting and sprinting across a stage studded with free- standing, cutout dogs? ''Diggity,'' performed by the Paul Taylor Dance Company on Thursday at City Center, does just that, and does it to the kind of ironically soupy, technicolor music that the composer Donald York is so good at putting together for the choreographer. The dogs happen to be the creation of Alex Katz, the noted artist. But irreverence is in the air. And all the while Mr. Taylor is busy at a magician's game of obscuring and revealing.

title: Three Bystanders Shot In Jackson Heights Bar
description: Three men who got into an argument in a Queens bar early yesterday went outside to obtain weapons and returned to shoot into the bar, wounding three bystanders but not the man they were looking for, the police said.

title: WAS IT NEMESIS THAT KILLED THE DINOSAUR?
description: Lost in the Stars

title: NEW STYLE AT HIGH POINT
description: DESIGNS AT THE SOUTHern Furniture Market in High Point, N.C., this spring have a decidedly European flair. Whether traditional mahogany highboys or sleek off-the-floor sofas, the newest merchandise (available commercially in coming months) are either European imports or American interpretations of French, Italian and English styles.

title: Judge RejectsRecanting ofA Rape Charge
description: Although he went to prison for a rape his accuser now insists never occurred, Gary Dotson said he harbored no bitterness. The 28-year-old man from suburban Chicago forgave Cathleen Crowell Webb, who said she made up the story when she feared she was pregnant by a boyfriend.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ASK CARY GRANT

title:
ANTIQUES;

AN ECLECTIC MIX AT SOUTHPORT/WESTPORT SHOW
description: LIKE a mixed bouquet of spring flowers, the 21st annual Southport-Westport Antiques Show will open April 26 with an eclectic mix of polished and painted English, French and American furniture and decorative accessories. The show, to be held in the Fairfield County Hunt Club, will run through April 28 and will help to raise funds for the Near and Far Aid Association.

title: CUTTING THE PIE TO MAKE IT BIGGER
description: THE SHARE ECONOMY

title: AVOID DRAMATICS, TEACHERS ADVISED
description: THE most dangerous way in which a school can react to a student's suicide is by holding a memorial assembly or closing for a day, warns a mental- health expert who has been called in to help teachers and school administrators deal with a suicide's aftermath.

title: SELECT SYSTEMS
description: The old adage that ''you get what you pay for'' should be taken with a sizable grain of salt when it comes to consumer products in general, and electronic home equipment in particular. If price corresponded to value, there would be no margin for profit, as economists have long realized. In the case of audio and video systems, price and performance don't always jibe, and the discrepancy can be quite wide.

title: THE FOURTH 'R' IS FOR REFORM
description: THE Governor of Tennessee expects to spend ''80 percent of my working hours'' in 1985 promoting educational reform. He plans to visit each of the 141 local districts to confer with educators, businessmen, and parents and to work with a bipartisan group of legislators on issues ranging from merit pay to mandatory kindergarten for 5-year- olds. ''The future of Tennessee depends on whether our educational system can be improved,'' said Gov. Lamar Alexander in a telephone interview. ''Without quality schools, Tennessee won't be able to generate new jobs, retain present ones or guarantee its children a satisfying future.''

title: PACIFIC OFFICIALS DIFFER ON PLAN FOR MICRONESIA
description: Congressional critics of the autonomy promised by Washington to two Micronesian island states, now under American administration as part of a United Nations trusteeship, have drawn mixed reactions from leaders of United States territories in the Pacific at a public hearing here.

title: India Sues In U.S. Court
description: The Government of India last week began what may become one of the biggest lawsuits in history, seeking damages against Union Carbide Corporation in a Federal District Court in Manhattan. India claimed Union Carbide was liable for the gas leak Dec. 3 in its Indian subsidiary's plant in Bhopal, which killed at least 1,700 people and injured perhaps as many as 20,000.

title: MARY ELIZABETH SHERK BECOMES BRIDE
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Winston-Salem, N.C., yesterday, Mary Elizabeth Sherk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Lincoln Sherk 3d of Winston-Salem, was married to William Joseph Fusco Jr., a son of Mrs. Carlisle Jones of New York and Lawrenceville, N.J., and Mr. Fusco of Essex Fells and Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. E. Dudley Colhoun performed the ceremony.

title: CARTOONIST RECALLS 50 YEARS OF POLITICS
description: JOHN MORRIS was very worried. Mr. Morris, the editorial cartoonist for the Associated Press, was in the Oval Office sketching John F. Kennedy when the President, standing beside his rocking chair, suddenly quit his pose and darted from the room.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;

FARMERS' ILLS: NOT THE DOLLAR'S FAULT
description: THE debate over the 1985 farm bill is evolving along a dangerous path. Increasingly, the perennial problems of low commodity prices, large surplus stocks and low farm income are attributed not to loan rates and Government price-support programs but to the high value of the dollar and its impact on agricultural exports.

title: C.W. POST IS A SURPRISE, EVEN TO ITSELF
description: THE lacrosse team at C. W. Post is flying in

title: K. J. FIELDER WED TO HEIDI JENSEN
description: Heidi Christine Jensen, a daughter of Gerda L. Jensen of Stamford, Conn., and Harold Jim Jensen of New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth James Fielder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph John Fielder of Clearwater, Fla. The Rev. Steven Kenny performed the ceremony at the Zion Lutheran Church in Stamford.

title: Fire Laid to Marines' Mishap
description: A fire that has burned nearly 4,000 acres along the coast was started accidentally by marines on maneuver, a state official said. The fire near Shaken Creek in Pender County ''was military- caused,'' Kay Scott of the North Carolina Forest Service said today. ''It was a smoke canister used during military operations by the U.S. Marine Corps,'' she said.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM KUBRICK TO SAINT-EXUPERY
description: Alberta Hunter: Jazz At the Smithsonian Sony Video 58 minutes. $29.95

title: ROBIN LANE BECOMES BRIDE
description: Robin Gail Lane, a daughter of Mrs. Alan Goldberg of Stamford, Conn., was married at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York yesterday to Frank David Ventura, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Ventura, also of Stamford. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman, assisted by the Rev. Alfred J. Sienkiewicz, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride attends the University of Bridgeport School of Nursing. Mr. Ventura is an associate in Ventura Associates, the Stamford real-estate firm owned by his father.

title: COMPUTER SNARLING I.R.S. OFFICE
description: ALTHOUGH millions of taxpayers are rushing to get their forms mailed to the Internal Revenue Service before 12:01 A.M. Tuesday, officials say the sprawling Brookhaven Service Center is 27 percent behind schedule in processing returns and many refunds may be delayed several weeks or even months.

title: THE AGONY OF ULSTER
description: As a historian, I would like to point out that the former province of Ulster, like the other three provinces of Ireland, has a majority of Roman Catholics living there.

title: TEACHING CHILDREN TO PREVENT ABUSE
description: CHILDREN in Fairfield's eight elementary schools are learning how to protect themselves from sexual abuse by knowing the difference between ''good and bad touches.''

title: REPORT BY LILCO: THE NEWS IS GOOD BUT COULD GET BAD
description: THE portrait of the Long Island Lighting Company painted by its most recent annual report is of a company on the verge of a major change. But whether that change will be bankruptcy or a return to stability is not certain.

title: HOW TO JUDGE YOUR OWN WORK
description: Critique of your own photography can be developed by setting standards of pictorial judgment. These guidelines will help to evaluate work when selecting images for display or publications.

title: FLORAL ATTRIBUTES
description: Chintz, it could rightly be said, is the basic black dress of the English-style interior. Whether it be a faded slipcover on the sofa in an English country house or the more formal treatment given to elaborate draperies in an upstate New York mansion, chintz offers an immediate point of reference to a popular decorating style.

title: DO IT YOURSELF, BUT DO IT SAFELY
description: AS MORE and more homeowners gain experience in doing their own repairs and maintenance, they find themselves tackling increasingly difficult projects that sometimes involve using potentially dangerous tools and materials. Many are not aware of the extra precautions that should be taken to avoid exposing themselves to health hazards or accidental injuries.

title: PACIFISTS WITH THEIR DUKES UP
description: LATER THE SAME DAY

title: NEW MUSEUMS HARMONIZE WITH ART
description: For a long time, the great question in museum design seemed to be whether it was the art that mattered or the architecture. Rarely did anyone dare to suggest, as recently as the late 1970's, that there was much sense in trying to have both - or that it was even possible to design a museum that would be a powerful architectural presence in its own right and at the same time respectful of the needs of art.

title: SCHOOL LIFE BEHIND BARS
description: OTISVILLE, N.Y.

title: THE LEBANESE HAVE A UNITY GOVERNMENT IN NAME ONLY
description: Prime Minister Rashid Karami's year-old Cabinet of National Unity has never lived up to its name. Last week, it seemed close to falling apart. Under sometimes conflicting pressures from Syria and from Moslem militants, Mr. Karami served notice that he and the other remaining Moslem member of the Cabinet would attend no further meetings until the crisis in the southern port city of Sidon was resolved.

title: THE FAMILY CAME FIRST
description: LABOR OF LOVE, LABOR OF SORROW

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

YOUTHS WANT TO DRIVE RESPONSIBLY
description: REDUCING the incidence of drinking and driving in Connecticut communities is possible if proper emphasis is placed on the problem. While many believe that publicity campaigns, media blitzes and special classes for young people and offenders has a limited impact, the fact is that the tide is beginning to turn in favor of sobriety behind the wheel.

title: Black Judge Temporarily Sits On Georgia's Supreme Court
description: A black judge sat as a member of the Georgia Supreme Court last week, but the history-making event lasted only 40 minutes.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM KUBRICK TO SAINT-EXUPERY
description: Make Mine Mink

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: Start fruit tree spray schedule for a clean summer harvest. . . . Finish pruning and feeding roses. . . . Continue planting shrubs, evergreens, saplings; set out hardy annuals and vegetables. . . . Remove mulches from perennials but work carefully as shoots are popping up; cut to the ground old stalks from last season. . . . Finish cleanup.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS ;   Not Guilty
description: Countless people were under the impression that the only way to settle a New York City parking summons by mail was to plead guilty - even if they were not guilty. A guilty plea was the only option listed in the instructions on the ticket.

title: SCHOOL ENROLLMENT DOWN 12% BUT STAFF SIZE DROPS ONLY 1%
description: The nation's public schools enroll 12.8 percent fewer students today than a decade ago, but the number of teachers and school administrators declined less than 1 percent in that period.

title: IN MOSCOW, A SOFT SPOT FOR ROOSEVELT
description: In Yalta, where the wartime Allies met to map the future, there is no street named for Stalin or for Churchill. But tree-lined Roosevelt Street, which runs into Lenin Square, is a favorite for strollers near the harbor.

title: Afghanistan Plans Elections
description: The Kabul radio said Friday that Afghanistan would hold elections this year to select its first National Assembly since the 1978 Communist coup. The elections will be held as Soviet and Afghan Government troops continue to battle an insurgency that began after the 1978 takeover.

title: MISS PRECHT, J. F. H. ONG PLAN TO WED The engagement of Katherine Anna Precht, an assistant editor at Doubleday & Company in New York, to John Francis Harlan Ong, a lending officer in the Middle East division of the Bankers Trust Company in New York, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Precht of Cairo and Washington, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Ong of Hudson, Ohio, and Ligonier, Pa.
description: A September wedding is planned.

title: THE MILITARY IS MAKING SERVICE A GOOD ROUTE TO COLLEGE DEGREE
description: NEARLY a decade after the United States armed forces launched advertising campaigns that sought to recruit young men and women by offering them a good education, the quality of that education is only now reaching the level that the advertisements promised, according to some educators.

title: THE INVISIBLE BLACK UNIVERSITY
description: BATON ROUGE, La.

title: BEATING THE WEATHER BUREAU AT ITS OWN GAME
description: ONE DAY last winter a small band of New York City teen-agers armed with satellite photos, temperature maps and wind readings beat the National Weather Service at its own game. The six young prognosticators, members of the meteorology club at Harry S. Truman High School in the Bronx, predicted that one inch of snow would fall before turning to rain; the Weather Service predicted three to four inches. The rains came after about an inch had fallen, and Russell Meyers, 15 years old, a meteorology club member, was jubilant. ''We called it!'' he whooped.

title:
ART;

CITY WITHOUT WALLS: 'OBJECTS OF COMFORT'
description: AT The City Without Walls gallery here, the subject of the current exhibition is architecture and well-padded comfort. The show, in two parts, is called, appropriately, ''Objects of Comfort.''

title: 60,000 BLACKS AT SOUTH AFRICA FUNERAL
description: Twenty-seven victims of recent violence in black townships were buried here today with 60,000 people attending the funeral ceremony that mixed solemnity with politics, mourning with exhortation and clenched fists with the soft swell of African singing.

title: ALLAN KELLOGG SMITH
description: Allan Kellogg Smith, a former United States Attorney for Connecticut and a leading municipal bond lawyer, died Tuesday at his home in Hartford.

title: PALMER SQ. DEVELOPERS WEIGH CONDO CONVERSION
PRINCETON CREWS WIN
description: Princeton's heavyweight crews made a clean sweep of the Child's Cup Regatta today, with its varsity crew beating the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia to gain possession of the cup for the third successive year.

title: LOIS STEINBERG TO WED HARRY LILLIS CROSBY 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Steinberg of New York and Tamarac, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lois Robbins Steinberg, to Harry Lillis Crosby 3d, a son of Kathryn Crosby of Hillsborough, Calif., and the late Bing Crosby.

title: BUCKS BEAT KNICKS IN FINALE
description: There are many who believe the Knicks' season ended long ago - perhaps even before it began - when they learned that both centers, Bill Cartwright and Marvin Webster, were out for the season with injuries.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: JERICHO
HOW THE PERSONAL BECAME POLITICAL
description: GENDER POLITICS

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Historic Creatures All

title: Affordability
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing in ''Long Island/This Week'' last Sunday for a performance of ''The Young Mozart'' last Wednesday at the Westbury Library was based on erroneous information.

title: THE REGION ;   Museum Is Playing It Cool
description: Last week, when Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch announced their latest plans to keep the Museum of the American Indian in New York City, they called it, respectively, ''an irreplaceable treasure'' and ''a crucial element in the city's cultural life.'' But flattery did not seem to get them very far.

title: HUNGARIANS HAVE TIPS FOR SOVIET FARMERS
description: In 1983, Mikhail A. Gorbachev toured Hungary and praised the policies that have made Hungarian agriculture a foundation for a vigorous economy.

title: THE NATION ;   Warming Up for Budget Debate
description: Floor debate on the budget compromise that President Reagan and Senate Republican leaders struck before their Easter breaks will not begin for another week. But the pressure starts now. As lobbyists for programs that would be cut oiled their machinery for the Senate's return, the Administration tried out the core of its argument for passage.

title: Auditing
description: To the Editor:

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Planning for Space In Small Quarters The Cooperative Extension in White Plains will give a lecture and demonstration Thursday, both morning and evening, called ''Living in Smaller Spaces.'' The program is designed to be a practical guide to avoiding a cramped feeling in living arrangements for first home buyers, would-be buyers forced to settle for apartments or former homeowners adapting to smaller living units, perhaps in add-on apartments in older homes already owned by their adult children.

title: A DAY TO REMEMBER
description: WITH the 40th anniversary of the liberation of Nazi concentration camps being marked this year, Yom Hashoa, the Day of Remembrance, takes on special significance, especially to Holocaust survivors, said

title: Former Chicago Mayor To Oppose Washington
description: Confirming speculation that started almost as soon as she left office two years ago, former Mayor Jane Byrne said today that she would challenge Mayor Harold Washington's re-election bid in 1987.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY ;   Libel Ruling Draws A Narrower Line
description: In a decision that shook the nation's press, a Federal appeals court in Washington last week reinstated a jury verdict against The Washington Post for libeling William P. Tavoulareas when he was president of the Mobil Oil Corporation. Newspaper editors, who happened to be meeting in the capital when the decision was announced, expressed dismay at the ruling that a newspaper's general orientation toward ''hard-hitting investigative stories'' could, along with other evidence, support an inference that it is inclined to publish reckless falsehoods.

title: ENTREPRENEURS IN A CORPORATE SETTING
description: Intrapreneuring, by Gifford Pinchot III. Harper & Row, N.Y., 368 pages, $19.95.

title: Brewer Helps Nets Top Bulls
description: Ron Brewer tugged his white knee socks into place Wednesday night just before he left the Nets' dressing room to warm up for the game against the Philadelphia 76ers His smile made clear that he was glad to be there.

title: FAST FOOD'S CHANGING LANDSCAPE
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IF HOLLYWOOD is where ''dreams are

title: DALLAS MAYOR GETS A RUN, FOR ALL HIS MONEY
description: Max Goldblatt, a City Council member and hardware store owner, said he was not surprised last weekend when he came within a whisker of forcing a runoff with Mayor A. Starke Taylor. But lots of other people here were, and Mr. Goldblatt was clearly enjoying the excitement generated by his strong showing. ''You'd think I was part of J. R. Ewing's outfit or something,'' he said. ''Everyone wants to shake my hand.''

title: A LIST OF MYTHS TO SORT OUT ON ETHIOPIA
description: IT was John F. Kennedy who once said

title: THE COMPUTER AS TUTOR
description: PERSONAL COMPUTERS are making it possible for students of all ages in a variety of life situations to learn academic subjects and job skills without ever setting foot in a traditional classroom. Employees can learn during slack time on the job. Military personnel can work toward college and advanced degrees no matter where they are stationed. Children can get extra help in subjects on which they are weak.

title: Data Bank;   April 14, 1985
63 SCHOOL SYSTEMS FAIL JERSEY NORMS
description: Sixty- three public school districts in New Jersey have flunked the state's certification test in the last 15 months, with rundown school buildings the most common problem, education officials said this week.

title: WAIVING THE RULES
description: There has long been a controversial restriction on foreign players who wish to compete in American national championships. They are barred from the three major team events because these play a role in selecting the American team for world championships. Critics feel that such a restriction is unnecessary, and that it would be sufficient to treat teams including foreign players as ''poisoned,'' or ineligible for international team play-offs.

title: PUBLISH AND BE DAMNED?
description: WASHINGTON Members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors were in Washington this week for their periodic look at the Administration and the cherry blossoms, but the editors didn't look very cheery. And no wonder!

title: BUYING BRITISH
description: The decorating firm of Colefax and Fowler Designs Ltd. is the king of the English Look, and its showrooms on London's tony Brook Street are usually almost as sedate as the living rooms it designs for its clients. But for the last few months, the antiques department, in particular, has resembled a football pileup or, as Tom Parr of Colefax put it the other day, ''the mob in the first hours of the annual sales in the big department stores.''

title: Ohio State Captures Gymnastic Team Title
description: Noah Riskin led Ohio State to its first National Collegiate Athletic Association men's gymnastics title today.

title: They Shuffle Papers For Humanity's Sake
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS JESSER AND DANIEL MAPES PLAN JUNE WEDDING
description: Announcement has been made by Dorothea Coogan Jesser of Ho-Ho- Kus, N.J., of the engagement of her daughter Dorothea Benn Jesser to Daniel Steven Mapes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Mapes of Minocqua, Wis. Miss Jesser is also a daughter of Benn W. Jesser of Nantucket, Mass.

title: BELLAMY OFFERS PLAN FOR ADDED TAXIS
description: Calling Mayor Koch's latest plan to improve taxi service ''strangely similar'' to one she had been working on for months, City Council President Carol Bellamy has also proposed increasing the number of yellow medallion cabs in increments of 1,200, or 10 percent of the present fleet.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM KUBRICK TO SAINT-EXUPERY
description: 2001: A Space Odyssey

title: CONDUCTORS FACE THE CHALLENGE OF GREAT SYMPHONIES
description: ''A man full of confidence, hope, and the consciousness of indomitable power'' - that is how J. W. N. Sullivan describes Beethoven in his middle period (1803-1817). Certainly, the heroic element we find in his compositions during those years - which mirror not only the revolutionary spirit of that age but also Beethoven's search for ever-increasing spiritual content - astounds us even today. Is it any wonder that recording those works remains an unceasing, and perhaps self-justifying, process? These thoughts cross my mind as I contemplate new recordings of the ''Eroica'' (Third) and the Fourth Symphony, as well as three simultaneous releases of the Seventh Symphony.

title: HELP FOR FAMILIES OF THE MENTALLY ILL
description: WITH nagging thoughts of her seriously disturbed son who now lives in a state mental facility, Martha G. recently attended her first meeting of the Family Assistance Program for the families of the chronically and acutely mentally ill. The meeting, held at the main offices of the Westchester Jewish Community Services in Hartsdale, was attended by spouses, parents and siblings, all of whom had experienced similar torment; each was related to, and primarily responsible for, a serihome or residing in an institution.

title: ACADEMIA'S BRUISING SUPER BOWLS
description: -yard line. You have five seconds. Name the longest river in Europe. That river question was one of 52 asked at last year's National Academic Super Bowl, held on the football field of Sandalwood High School in Jacksonville, Fla. The correct answer, the Volga, scored four points for a team of six high school students.

title: Air Carried by Mouth Saves a Trapped Girl
description: A man saved his 8-year-old daughter from drowning by carrying gulps of air to her until he could free her from the propeller of a houseboat on Lake Oroville, state park ranger said Friday.

title: 25 Left Homeless in Newark
description: Fourteen children and 11 adults were left homeless last night by a fire that damaged three 3-story frame apartment buildings, a Newark fire dispatcher said. The fire started at the buildings, Ridgewood and Runyon Avenues, at 6 P.M. and was under control an hour later. Several people were treated at the scene for injuries.

title: 2 WORLDS DOING BUSINESS IN HAUPPAUGE FACTORY
description: FROM the outside, the Autonumerics Incorporated plant in a Hauppauge industrial park appears no different from the other industrial buildings surrounding it. But inside, a bit of history is being made, and Mari Poola is part of it.

title: SINGAPORE STREET FOOD
description: It gets harder and harder to find the heart

title: DOES AMERICA HAVE A STAKE IN APARTHEID?
description: THE scene was fitting: the Columbia University campus, where some of the angriest

title: ARTIFACTS OF THE CHINA TRADE ON DISPLAY
description: THE present flood of imports from the Far East means, among other things, that the worm has turned. East-West trading history goes back 2,000 years, when Chinese goods reached the Mediterranean by way of the silk routes. But since the opening of the sea routes in the 16th century, the history of that trade has also been the history of imperialism, with first Portugal, then the Netherlands, and, finally, Britain and the United States playing dominant roles. For the most part, these powers ordered Chinese products made to Western specifications and in return supplied silver and other raw materials.

title:
DINING OUT;

BAKERY AND A RESTAURANT IN ONE
description: CLOSED five months for kitchen renovation, it is now business as usual at Kaffee Bazar. We report with pleasure that the bakery has emerged better than ever. With few exceptions, the cakes and pastries Manfred Hirz produces serve as testimonials to Vienna's unwavering reputation for finely wrought confections. But the cafe has changed, and although it retains some of the traditions of that venerable institution the Viennese kaffeehaus, it has recently taken on modern characteristics, diminishing the Old World charm that made Kaffee Bazar in Armonk such an unusual eating spot.

title:
THE SCHOOLS;

HELPING THE CHILD OF DIVORCE
description: ALONG with science, math and social studies, students at elementary schools in Washingtonville, N.Y., are learning about custody suits, alimony payments and visitation rights. The youngsters, whose parents are divorced or separated, are participants in a school-sponsored group-counseling program. ''The schools provide an ideal setting for such programs,'' said Dr. Paul J. Ciborowski, chairman of the National Committee on Children of Divorce. ''At a time when the family structure is falling apart, school is often the only stable, constant part of a child's life.''

title: SHIP SCUTTLED TO CREATE 5th FISHING REEF
KEEPING TABS ON PROPERTY PAYS OFF
description: MANY people who carefully save canceled checks and receipts to back up deductions they claim on their tax returns don't take the time to organize their property records. But the consequences can be costly: Those who keep sloppy records often end up with unnecessarily high tax bills when the time comes to sell their property.

title: THE COLUMBIA PROTEST
description: For the last 10 days students concerned about the system of racial oppression in South Africa have been carrying out a protest at Columbia University. Their demonstration raises questions of conscience and of law: hard questions but important ones.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;   Cable TV
description: Cable film-watchers who select strictly by title might miss a rewarding, original trio this week - namely ''Repo Man,'' ''Mississippi Mermaid'' and ''Wise Blood.'' Don't.

title: Iran Accuses Iraq Of Using Chemical Arms
description: Iran accused Iraq today of using chemical weapons against Iranian forces on Friday and Wednesday.

title: 'SPACE' IS A 'DALLAS' WITH ASTRONAUTS
description: ''James A. Michener's 'Space' '' - that's the offical title - is one of those grand and glossy productions that add up, almost amazingly, to vintage television. The 13- hour mini-series, made at a cost of more than $30 million, gets underway on CBS this evening at 8 with a three-hour installment. The rest will be broadcast tomorrow through Thursday, which means a significant commitment of time for even the most ardent of viewers. What they will get is not so much Mr. Michener's ''Space'' as Dick Berg's version of the best-selling novel.

title: ANGUISH OF THE HOMELESS OUTLASTS WINTER'S COLD
description: Like the flowers and the leaves, New York's homeless people appeared again this month, re- establishing their residences in doorways, on the plazas and on park benches. Behind them was more than a winter of a few bitter cold nights. It had also been cruel.

title: WOMAN SUES FATHER, CITING SEXUAL ABUSE OVER 11-YEAR PERIOD
description: A Vermont woman who says her father sexually molested her for 11 years during her childhood has filed a lawsuit in Federal court here seeking $600,000 in damages.

title: LEBANON REPORTS 8 KILLED IN SHIITE VILLAGE AND BLAMES ISRAELIS
description: The Government radio said today that Israeli troops killed eight people in the Shiite Moslem village of Yuhmur, 28 miles southeast of Beirut. The report could not immediately be confirmed, and Israel denied any involvement.

title: Abrams, Cuomo Make Peace
description: New York State's chief law enforcement officer, Attorney General Robert Abrams, settled a three-week feud with Governor Cuomo last week by offering an unrestrained apology for not consulting the Governor on personnel matters. The differences between the two elected officials began last month when Mr. Abrams appointed William F. Dowling, one of his assistants, to be a new special prosecutor to investigate corruption in New York City's criminal-justice system.

title: A Crisis Made in U.S.A. Bravely, Prime Minister Nakasone of Japan last week implored his people to buy something American. He warned that Japan's large trade surplus with the United States had stirred so much passion that America's reaction could ''affect the life and death of our country.''
description: If the Japanese now dig deep to appease their former conquerors, they might reduce the difference between their American exports and imports from $37 billion to perhaps $35 billion a year. And it is certainly in America's interest to give Mr. Nakasone's further effort to reduce trade impediments a chance. But as the numbers suggest, the anger being vented on Japan is a sideshow. Americans simply have to recognize that any palatable solution to our export problems requires above all a reduction in our own Government's huge budget deficit.

title: PRINT POWER
description: Chintz is blooming in profusion this spring. The cotton fabric, so closely associated with the coziness of the English country house, is in the midst of a resurgence on these shores. Many of the chintzes that are currently available are faithful revivals of classic designs; some are adaptations of traditional patterns, and others are brand-new. The chintzes of today may be glazed or not. In addition to making the fabric more durable and soil-repellent, the glazing gives the chintz's design its distinctive crisp, almost three-dimensional look.

title: OPEN-HOUSE TOURS ADD MOORESTOWN
20TH ANNIVERSARY FOR AN UNUSUAL JAZZ ENSEMBLE
description: This year, the Art Ensemble of Chicago - the saxophonists Roscoe Mitchell and Joseph Jarman, the trumpeter Lester Bowie, the bassist Malachi Favors Maghostut and the drummer Famoudou Don Moye - celebrates its 20th birthday. Although sticklers for accuracy could date the formation of the Art Ensemble's core and concept to as early as 1961, when Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Jarman and Mr. Favors met in a big band led by Muhal Richard Abrams, to as late as 1966, when Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Favors and Mr. Bowie recorded ''Sounds,'' it is undeniable that the Art Ensemble has reached a milestone few bands, let alone jazz groups, attain.

title: On Language ;   IS A PROBLEM
description: I AM BEING DRIVEN

title: THE ELECTRONIC PRESENT
description: The age of electronics is continuing to change the American home, both in terms of the way it functions and the way it looks. And it is doing so in ways large and small.

title: AN EXILE IN LITERARY AMERICA
description: LAST SUMMER, ON the way to our idyllic patch of Vermont, my wife and I turned off at Amherst, Mass., where I had been invited to take part in a conference sponsored by the Theater Communications Group. Amherst's own idyll was in full bloom - a large village green bordered by chestnut trees and white spruce, squat little buildings with shops on the ground floor, and the church and halls of the college. The hotel, where a room awaited us, was called the Lord Jeffery Inn and reminded us of Stratford-on-Avon.

title: STAGE: HEROIC TALE, 'HANNAH SENESH'
description: This is a season of remembrance of evil days 40 years and more ago, when the Nazis repressed the Jewish revolt in Warsaw, when Jews faced extermination in Europe and, finally, when the relatively few survivors were liberated by Allied forces. It is an appropriate time for the opening of the poignant Off Broadway production of ''Hannah Senesh'' at the Cherry Lane Theater, rounding out a week that started with a television drama about Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who worked to save the Jews of Budapest.

title: ATTENDANTS REJECT EASTERN PACT
description: Eastern Airlines' flight attendants, by a 4-to-1 margin, have rejected a tentative agreement with the carrier that included concessions to help solve the company's financial problems, union officials said today.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

CHARACTER STUDIES
description: THE seminar is called ''How to Deal With Difficult People,'' and the people in question must be difficult, indeed. For it is early on a bleak Saturday morning, a damp drizzly morning, and still participants are showing up. Never mind that it is an hour when most folk would rather be in bed: Everyone wants to know - just how

title: DEIDRE MCHUGH TO WED JOHN F. LEARNED IN JUNE
description: Deirdre Ann McHugh and John F. Learned plan to be married in June. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Nevin McHugh of Larchmont, N.Y., who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin G. Learned of Fitchburg, Mass.

title: ONE FOOT ON BROADWAY, THE OTHER IN HOLLYWOOD
description: Nobody had to tell a seasoned professional like Fay Kanin that bringing a big, expensive musical to Broadway is not

title: CUSTOM JEWELRY IN DEMAND
description: YOUR grandmother's diamond: You want it mounted in a special wedding ring that is really you. That old gold coin Uncle John gave you for graduation: You would like it suspended on a chain. Or, you think of jewelry as you do real estate: a wise investment, especially if a ''known signature'' can be obtained below retail price.

title: JAZZ TEACHER MAKES 'HOUSE CALLS'
description: DOROTHY SIMS gripped her hands tightly together as her son, Michael, hunched over a piano keyboard in Ranny and Georgia Reeve's Kings Park living room, working out a jazz improvisation. About 35 friends and neighbors were there - sitting on the floor and in an assortment of chairs and sofas dragged from other rooms - and they all appeared relaxed.

title: WHERE XEROX HONES SKILLS
description: LEESBURG, Va.

title: STANLEY P. DAVIES, ADVOCATE OF SOCIAL WELFARE PROGRAMS
description: Stanley P. Davies, a leading advocate of social welfare and mental health programs in New York for more than half a century, died April 5 after a brief illness at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 92 years old and lived in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: IN DEFENSE OF NUCLEAR POWER
description: Saul Schindler (Letters to the Editor, March 10) happens to be wrong, and Herbert Jaffe (Letters, Feb. 3) is right. There has not been a single death or serious injury in more than 25 years of nuclear power plant use (including Three Mile Island).

title: BIDDING OF THE PAST
description: All of a sudden, a new aura of glamour has descended upon furniture. At auction, breakfront cabinets from Georgian England and Louis XVI secretaires that once graced the private apartments of French royalty at Versailles compete with Old Master paintings. For the first time since World War II, furniture and works of art that once were called ''decorative'' with the merest hint of a sneer have become ''highly important'' in salesroom jargon. Just like Impressionist paintings. And rightly so.

title:
MORE IDEAS & TRENDS;

ISRAEL FINDS NEW WAYS TO BREAK CYCLE OF CRIME
description: Israel would only become a real Jewish state, according to a Zionist saying, when it had a Jewish policeman, a Jewish burglar and a Jewish prostitute. Well, it has all of these now - and a Jewish convict-rehabilitation program to boot. Some inimitably Israeli methods are being used to make honest citizens out of former criminals.

title: MISS LAIDLAW HAS NUPTIALS
description: The marriage of Mary Elizabeth Laidlaw, a daughter of Mrs. Robert Baldwin Ziegler of Bainbridge Island, Wash., and the late David Laidlaw, to Jonathan Franklin, a son of Sir Michael and Lady Franklin of Barnet, England, took place yesterday. The Rev. James Fraser, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., assisted by the Rev. Dr. William Foley, rector of the church.

title: UP FROM THE UNDERGROUND COME TWO FOLK-ROLK IDOLS
description: By coincidence, debut albums are being released this week by two female folk-rockers with about as potent an underground reputation in their respective communities as anyone in years. The two are Maria McKee, lead singer for the Los Angeles country-rock band Lone Justice, and the Greenwich Village singer-songwriter Suzanne Vega.

title: BOSTON COLLECTORS WHO APPLIED THEMSELVES TO THE PUBLIC GOOD
description: BOSTON

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;

DON'T RUSH TO REGULATE REPO MARKET
description: ; Ralph F. Peters is chairman of the Discount Corporation of New York, a primary government securities firm.

title: THANKS TO KAREEM AND HIS UNBROKEN LINE
description: ; Lance Compa plays basketball Wednesday night in Takoma Park, Md.

title:
THE LEARNING SOCIETY;

MUSEUM CLASSES AT A NEW HIGH ACROSS THE U. S.
description: SIX HUNDRED adults filed into the American Museum of Natural History on a recent evening, through the Great Hall of the Northwest Coast Indians and past the Kwakiutl ceremonial masks. They had not come to see the exhibits, however, but to attend formal education programs. Some, like Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Spadin, who live in and teach school in Manhattan, came to hear a lecture on Alaska to acquaint themselves with the Alaskan territory, which they plan to drive through this summer. ''We wanted to take the course here because we know the instructors are excellent,'' Mr. Spadin said.

title: CAROLINIAN FINDS A TEXTILE JOB, IN GUATEMALA
description: Early next month Lowery Hodges will board an airplane for Guatemala City, where he will assemble textile machinery in a mill. The South Carolinian will make $500 a week and live in a free house; all he needs to take are his passport, toolbox and work clothes.

title: Cheevers Investigation
description: Gerry Cheevers, who was replaced as coach of the Boston Bruins in February, is a target of a police investigation into sports betting, according to detectives in Boston. Cheevers, a former Bruin goaltender, was one of several persons who came to court last week prepared to testify as defense witnesses in a gambliing case, and afterward detectives said that all the potential witnesses had become targets of the investigation, but would not give any details.

title: OPULENCE REVISITED
description: One challenging task many designers are facing today is the restoration of old apartments that were ''modernized'' during the sleek era of the 1960's. Walls that were torn down to create open, loftlike spaces are being put back in their original locations.

title: HUBRIS ON THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Strong No to Comparable Pay
description: The doctrine that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth received an expected rebuff last week from the United States Commission on Civil Rights. In a 5-to-2 vote, the commission urged Congress and Federal agencies to reject the idea and ''rely instead on the principle of equal pay for equal work,'' which was written into law in 1963.

title: Q&A
description: Question:

title: Chinese Party Leader Arrives In Australia on a Pacific Tour
description: Hu Yaobang, the Chinese Communist Party leader, arrived here today at the start of a 12-day South Pacific tour.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: FEDERAL SHOWPIECE, PREHISTORIC PAINTINGS
description: Historic Mansion Open In Delaware I have very nearly finished my new building which considering the magnitude of the undertaking is a very gratifying circumstance.''

title: VASSAR PRESIDENT RESIGNING AT END OF THE NEXT SCHOOL YEAR
description: Virginia B. Smith, the president of Vassar College since 1977, has announced plans to resign at the end of the 1985-86 academic year ''to undertake new projects involving research, writing and teaching.''

title: SCHOOLS TRY TO CURB RISE IN SUICIDES
description: IN RAPIDLY increasing numbers, public schools

title: 2 Earthquakes Hit Indonesia
description: Two strong earthquakes rocked separate areas in Indonesia today, the national meteorological agency said.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY ;   In Japan and Europe, Officials Heed the Call for TradeReform
description: The Reagan Administration's drive for freer world trade got a boost from two important quarters last week. The 24 member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development agreed in Paris to begin preparations this summer for a new round of trade liberalization talks next year. And in Tokyo, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone responded to United States threats of retaliation by suggesting that Japan buy more American and other foreign goods and by taking measures to make that easier to do.

title: 'Reconciliation' Move Stirs a Storm
description: A sidelight of President Reagan's visit to Europe from April 30 to May 10 became a major issue last week. The White House announced that after the annual economic summit meeting of the seven leading industrial democracies, held this year in Bonn, the President would visit a West German cemetery where soldiers from the two World Wars are buried.

title: QUOTATIONS ON THE BUSINESS OF BUSINESS
description: ''The Macmillan Book of Business & Economic Quotations,'' edited by Michael Jackman. Macmillan Publishing Company, N.Y., 302 pages, $19.95.

title: STATE ABANDONING ITS ROLE IN EFFORT TO CONTROL GYPSY MOTHS
description: With a new gypsy moth season approaching, New York State has abandoned its program to control the leaf-eating insects and will turn it over to local communities and private enterprise.

title: MISS MCENIRY MARRIES DAVID SULLIVAN
description: The marriage of Catherine Eudora McEniry, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray W. McEniry of Scarsdale, N.Y., to David Edward Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Sullivan Jr. of Lackawanna, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. Robert Barth, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale.

title: THE WORLD ;   Mexico Seizes Two SuspectedTraffickers
description: Egged on by Americans, Mexican authorities have seized two suspected

title: AIRLINES REDUCE PROJECTED FLIGHTS
description: THE county got its first confirmation last week that the amount of new airline services at the County Airport would not be as large as had been indicated by the initial results of last month's lottery.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: April 14, 1985

title: AN ROTC OF TEACHERS
description: THREE important social forces have come together to create an opportunity for a new form of student aid.

title: IMAGES IN THE COMPUTER AGE
description: Once, photographs were the allies of truth. They seemed to show us reality itself, reflected in a flawless mirror. When the poet and critic Charles Baudelaire called photography ''art's most mortal enemy,'' in 1859, he was inveighing against the medium's verisimilitude, its kinship with the world it depicted. ''If it be allowed to encroach upon the domain of the impalpable and the imaginary. . . so much the worse for us!,'' he warned.

title: BOY SAYS LEBANESE RECRUITED HIM A CAR BOMBER
description: A 16-year- old Lebanese was captured by Israeli troops hours before he was supposed to get into an explosive-laden car and go on a suicide bombing mission to blow up the Israeli Army headquarters in Lebanon, according to Israeli officials and an account from the youth himself.

title: Barbara Harter Marries
description: At the Park Avenue United Methodist Church in New York yesterday Barbara Alice Harter and James Gilmore Fletcher Whitton Jr. were married by the Rev. Moffett Churn, a Presbyterian minister. Mrs. Whitton is the daughter of Mrs. Ralph F. Kerr of Albuquerque, N.M., and the late Joseph W. Harter of Lubbock, Tex. Mr. Whitton is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitton of Salisbury, N.C.

title: LISTENING TO THE AFRIKANERS
description: WAITING

title: HEARNS HAS LONG REACH
description: STYLES change. Twenty years ago, she would probably have had blue hair. Now, the middle-aged tourist who was angry about the hotel lobby had her hair dyed an improbable white.

title: FOR SHAMUSES AND GUMSHOES
description: Raymond Chandler, in his hard-boiled detective novels of the 1930's, managed to get a half nelson on the City of the Angels. He wooed the sprawling city, used it, basked in its golden light and lived with its imperfections. He and his private eye, Philip Marlowe, recognized its beauty the better for grappling with its dark underside. Who else ever described a palm tree as ''tough?''

title: CATHRYN KOHRMAN IS A BRIDE
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan yesterday Cathryn Ann Kohrman, a daughter of Janet L. Kohrman and the late Dr. Robert M. Kohrman of Chicago, was married to Mark McCampbell Collins Jr., a son of Phyllis D. Collins and Mr. Collins, both of New York. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Fashion Profile;   ON HER OWN
description: IN STORES LIKE BERGDORF GOOD

title: Hospital Costs Rose by 4.6% In '84, Lowest Rate Since '63
description: The cost to hospitals of providing health care rose by 4.6 percent in 1984, the smallest annual increase since 1963, the American Hospital Association has reported.

title: NEW YORK HOSPITAL PLANNING RESEARCH CENTER
description: The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center plans to build a new research center that will permit its staff members and students to expand into such advanced fields as molecular genetics.

title: DENTIST AFFIANCED TO MISS COPELAND
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr. of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leonore Copeland to Dr. David Francis Panno, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Francis V. Panno of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: $100,000 Jewel Box Recovered on Coast
description: The Comstock jewel casket, stolen from the Oakland Museum in 1978, has been found at an auction house, the authorities said today.

title: Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKS TRIUMPH;   GUIDRY STOPS SLIDE FOR FIRST VICTORY
description: The Yankees ended their brief reign of frustration today, even though they did not please their owner. George Steinbrenner called them ''sloppy,'' and without skipping a beat, insisted they had not found the right ingredient to become contenders.

title: TRACES OF A CHEMICAL EXPLOSIVE FOUND IN MADRID
description: Interior Ministry officials said today that an explosion Friday night that killed at least 18 people in a barbecue restaurant near an American air base here appeared to have been caused by a bomb.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TO ENGLAND'S SPRING

title: SPRING BRINGS MEMORIES, TOO
description: Memories of the past are not always sad just because they are long gone. They cannot be recreated, but one can recapture the happiness of something very precious.

title: ;   ANOTHER SIDE TO THE OCTAGON
description: The otherwise excellent article on the eight-sided house (''Legacies of the Octagon Movement,'' March 24) has a three-sided error. The section on Brentwood refers to ''the home of William Dane, a founder of the positivist settlement called Modern Times, which later became Brentwood.''

title: NICARAGUANS REPORT AN AMERICAN KILLED, BUT ARE DISPUTED
description: There were conflicting reports tonight on whether a man said to have been killed fighting for the Nicaraguan rebels was an American citizen.

title: 34 STATES MUST APPROVE CONSTITUTIONAL CHANGES
description: Sanford Weinreb (Opinion Page, March 24) argues against a Constitutional Convention on the familiar ground of possible wild things that such a group might do.

title: HOW MUCH FOR A FIRST FOLIO?
description: Book collectors will descend on New York over the next two weeks to view and attend several auctions and the 25th Antiquarian Book Fair. About 160 dealers from this country and Europe will offer other English and American volumes for collectors at the fair, which opens April 26 and remains through the weekend at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: the subject of a series of photographs and a book by

title: AT BUCHENWALD, CEREMONY OF BITTER MEMORY
description: Tens of thousands of people today commemorated the liberation of the Buchenwald concentration camp in a ceremony filled with bitter attacks on the United States and its allies.

title: THE TREASURES OF LUXORA BEACH
description: STARS AND BARS

title: ELIZABETH MURRAY BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Elizabeth Edwards Murray, a daughter of William Edwards Murray of New York, Charleston, S.C., and Sea Island, Ga., and the late Minnie Holmes Murray, was married yesterday to Daniel Peter Kelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Vincent Kelly of Longmeadow, Mass. The Rev. Susan Harriss performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York, assisted by the Rev. Patrick McNelis, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Future Events Institutional Moves
description: Moving Images

title: ELLEN D. CLARKE BECOMES BRIDE
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan yesterday Ellen Dean Clarke, a daughter of Mrs. Harry St. Clair Clarke of North Haven, Conn., and the late Mr. Clarke, was married to Pierre de Saint Phalle, a son of Thibaut de Saint Phalle of Washington and the late Rosamond de Saint Phalle. The Rev. Stanislaus Moseley performed the ceremony.

title: A TALK WITH JUSTICE REHNQUIST
description: Thanks so much for John Jenkins's article on Justice William H. Rehnquist.

title:
GARDENING;

A NEW LOOK AT THE CRAB APPLE
description: MOST gardeners are still at a loss to know what to plant as a replacement for our ailing dogwoods. Many young dogwoods are being planted to replace those that have died, but the disease that has destroyed mature trees now seems to be attacking the young replacements, also. A satisfactory treatment program has not yet been discovered.

title: THE INCORPORATION OF FOLK ART
description: TWO painted tables that were never meant to meet establish an unexpected connection between a pair of exhibitions that otherwise share nothing but simultaneity.

title: NEW YORK STATTE, AT 208, TO CELEBRATE WITH PARTY IN KINGSTON
description: New York State will celebrate its 208th birthday April 20 here in the city where its first Constitution was adopted in 1777.

title: Spring Again
description: John Bassett, the owner of the Tampa Bay Bandits who has been trying to block the United States Football League's planned move to a fall schedule next year, has given a broad hint that he is on the verge of winning his campaign. After meeting with

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I just said to myself, my God, what is this? What's happening here? How could people do this to other people?'' - Dr. Leon Bass, who was one of the first American soldiers to arrive at the Buchenwald death camp in 1945. (28:1.)

title: TWO LOCAL REACTIONS TO BUS STORAGE PLANS
description: Two nearby communities, two completely opposite concerns. In Yorktown, nearly 400 residents are opposing the construction of a county garage in their town (''Residents Oppose Bus Garage,'' March 24).

title: Market Place;   Buyback Aids Exxon Price
description: THE stock of the Exxon Corporation, the

title: Futures/Options;   Witching Hour For Investors
description: SUPERSTITIOUS or not, many stock investors have come to regard the last hour of trading on the third Friday of each month as the ''witching hour,'' a time when the market seems to plunge for no apparent reason. It is also a time when the current month's Major Market Index options expire.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has any player besides Wilt Chamberlain ever finished a National Basketball Association season as the league leader in both scoring and field goal percentage?

title: Nystrom Deciding Whether to Move
description: The tennis star Joakim Nystrom is considering leaving his home country of Sweden for either Monte Carlo or London to avoid high taxes.

title: TYCOONS IN CANADA IN A SERIES
description: ''THE CANADIAN ESTABLISHMENT,'' a seven-part series, seems to say this: The rich and powerful in Canada are civilized but tough, with old and new boys alike, however competitive with one another, all belonging to the same club. The series, intelligent and enlightening, begins on WNYC, Channels 31 and 3, at 10 tonight.

title: L. I. Youth Is Shot Dead In Fight Outside a Bar
description: Two youths were shot, one fatally, during an argument outside a bar here early today, according to the Nassau County police.
