title: Norma F. Cirincione Marries a Lawyer
description: Norma Frances Cirincione, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph Lewis Cirincione of Schenectady and the late Dr. Cirincione, was married yesterday to Edward David Kleinbard, a son of Mrs. Martin Kleinbard of Rye, N.Y., and the late Mr. Kleinbard. Rabbi Bernard Bloom performed the ceremony at the Hall of Springs in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: PROSECUTOR DISCLOSES A PLOT TO 'INFILTRATE' UNION CITY'S POLICE
description: The Hudson County Prosecutor said today that a plot to ''infiltrate'' Union City's Municipal Court and Police Department had been uncovered. He said the conspiracy was intended to protect illegal gambling and narcotics operations.

title: DANIEL WINS BY 2 SHOTS SAN DIEGO, April 14 (UPI) - Beth Daniel fought off Pat Meyers by shooting an even-par 72 today to win the $175,000 Kyocera Inamori Classic.
description: Miss Daniel, who neither bogied nor birdied in the final round, finished at 2-under 286.

title: INDONESIA REVISES PORT PROCEDURES
description: The Government of Indonesia, responding to reports that inefficiencies and corruption have severely hampered trade, is making radical changes in customs and port procedures.

title: 2 Agencies Announce Million-Dollar Accounts
description: MacNamara, Clapp & Klein and Shaller Rubin & Winer both reported Friday on getting new accounts billing around $1 million.

title: Washington Watch;   New Unease On Debt Crisis
description: WASHINGTON RUMBLINGS are being heard again in the big and little debtor countries. Meetings in Washington this week will take up some of the new problems, but no decisions are expected.

title: HAGLER VS. HEARNS: A CLASH OF STYLES
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the undisputed middleweight champion, and his challenger, Thomas (Hit Man) Hearns, seem as different as two men who have reached the heights of their bruising profession can be, from their physical makeup to their training habits, their boxing and life styles, and their gastronomic choices, or what we know of those choices.

title: Recount Bars a Runoff In Dallas Mayor's Race
description: Mayor A. Starke Taylor lost 25 votes in the recount of ballots cast in the city election April 6 but avoided a runoff and remains the winner, officials said Friday.

title: Lora D. Koenig Is Married To Ronald Martin Robins
description: Lora Davis Koenig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Russell Koenig of Cos Cob, Conn., and Ronald Martin Robins, a son of Mrs. Henry Abuza of Vernon, Conn., and the late Dr. Seymour Robins, were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Dr. Mitchell Pollack Wed To Dr. Marilyn L. Temkin
description: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday, Dr. Marilyn Lisa Temkin, assistant director of cardiology at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center in Patchoque, L.I., was married to Dr. Mitchell Coleman Pollack, director of emergency services at the John T. Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony.

title: AFTER24 YEARS ON CITY COUNCIL, FINANCE CHIEF SAYS HE'LL STEP DOWN
description: Edward L. Sadowsky, chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, has decided not to seek re-election this year, in effect bowing out of public life - though not for long, he predicts - after nearly 24 years in elective office.

title: Pickens Outlines Financing for Bid
description: To lend credence to the tender offer he initiated last week for control of the Unocal Corporation, T. Boone Pickens said yesterday that the financial commitments to pay for the shares are now in place. The $3.9 billion needed to buy 64 million shares of Unocal will come from more than 100 large investors and a group of 10 American and foreign banks, he said.

title: NORA S. TAUBMAN
description: Nora S. Taubman, who taught English at Seward Park and Julia Richman High Schools and at the High School of Music and Art in New York City in the 1930's and 40's, died of cancer Saturday at a convalescent home in Danbury, Conn. She was 74 years old and lived in Danbury.

title: WABC-TV Campaign: 'To Tell You the Truth'
description: If nothing else, the new ad campaign for WABC-TV's Eyewitness news should cause at least talk, if not controversy. And that is something that George Lois and his Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK agency has thrived on.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Key Ohio Banker Is Critical of Chase
description: Julien L. McCall spent 21 years as a New York City banker. But Mr. McCall, who is now chairman and chief executive of the National City Corporation, Ohio's largest bank holding company, does not approve of the way at least one Big Apple-based bank is trying to do business.

title: GROUP OFFERS 10 IDEAS TO IMPROVE NEW YORK CITY
description: A civic group warned yesterday that New York City's failure to deal with ''long-simmering social problems'' could prove as dangerous to the city as the threat of its bankruptcy was a decade ago, and urged the adoption of 10 ideas designed to improve the lives of all New Yorkers.

title: RECITAL: GARDEN STATE GROUP
description: THE Garden State Chamber Orchestra's program at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night was a success in thought, if not always in deed. The level of playing, in other words, could be described as rough competence, but who could have resisted this parade of fascinating pieces - a motet by Alessandro Scarlatti; ''Pygmalion,'' a cantata by Johann Christoph Bach; Virgil Thomson's ''Thoughts for Strings,'' and a blown-up version of Smetana's quartet ''From My Life'' for string orchestra.

title: Potvin's Desperate Moments
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.

title: LLOYD TAKES FINAL, BUT CHEERS ARE FOR SABATINI, 14
description: By lunchtime today, she had defeated two of the world's top 10 and had become the favorite of the tennis set here, many of whom had become volunteer coaches, shouting encouragement and advice from the stands. And even her loss later to Chris Evert Lloyd in the final of the Family Circle Magazine Cup did not diminish what 14-year-old Gabriella Sabatini accomplished this week in a tournament that might establish her as the most promising of a new generation of players.

title: 'Not in Anybody's Blood To Lay Up'
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Trying to Find Washington Heights
description: Let's welcome Pat Roach to New

title: Treasury Sets Regular Bill Auction
description: The only Treasury financings scheduled this week are today's regular auction of new three- and six- month bills, proceeds of which will retire maturing bills, but will not raise any fresh cash for the Government.

title: Miss McCabe Marries Robert Bianchi
description: Kathleen Tindell McCabe, director of community services for the Manhattan Psychiatric Center, and Robert Steven Bianchi, associate curator of the Egyptian department of the Brooklyn Museum, were married yesterday at St. Spyridon Greek Orthodox Church in New York. The Rev. John Poulos performed the ceremony.

title: New Dillon Managing Director
description: James W. Stevens, who for the past decade has been involved in investment banking activities at Citicorp, most recently as chairman of its venture capital unit, has been named a managing director at Dillon, Read & Company, the Wall Street firm announced. The appointment is effective today.

title: 1888 WORK IS POPULAR IN FRANCE
description: Lalo's ''Roi d'Ys'' has enjoyed steady popularity in France but has not traveled abroad with much success. First produced in Paris at the Opera Comique in 1888, the composer's last work and only completed opera had its 400th performance at the Comique on Jan. 6, 1940, after which it was transferred to the grander venue of the Paris Opera.

title: JORGE J. LARACH
description: Jorge J. Larach, owner of the Honduran newspapers La Prensa and El Heraldo, died in Miami on Saturday after a long illness, La Prensa reported. He was 70 years old.

title: 4-Year-Old Magazine Drops Nonprofit Status
description: For the four years of its existence, Channels of Communicatons Magazine has been foundation-funded and non-profit.

title: ARMY HAS A NEW BREED OF OFFICER
description: After being a college student through four years of turbulent protest against the war in Vietnam, Thomas A. Racioppi of Newark graduated from Rutgers in 1970 and promptly enlisted in the Army.

title: HE IS THE DEAN OF TAX FRAUD DEFENSE LAWYERS
description: FOR most taxpayers and tax accountants, this is the

title: RUNNERS SKIPPING BOSTON MARATHON
description: As recently as a decade ago, the Boston Marathon was the world's most celebrated foot race. Now, on the eve of its 89th running, it is tattered and torn and largely scorned, seemingly an amateur anachronism in a sport that in effect has become professional.

title: PAIRINGS DECIDED IN N. B. A. PLAYOFFS
description: The National Basketball Association ended its 39th regular season yesterday with no playoff berths at stake, but some jostling for position in the Western Conference.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Yeshiva Honors A Whistle Blower
description: Yeshiva University plans to honor

title: KEY DATA COME OUT THIS WEEK
description: Despite fears among many investors that the American economy may be faltering, most economists remain cheery. They say that although some manufacturers will continue to suffer, the overall economy will continue to grow at a modest pace.

title: Memories of the Game
description: He roomed with Honus Wagner, caught the sparrow that flew out of Casey Stengel's cap and threw the pitch that produced Babe Ruth's most picturesque swing. If you never heard of Carmen (Bunker) Hill, it might be because his career was not so much the stuff of record books as the footnotes of baseball history.

title: JUDGE 'SORRY' OVER RAPE CASE
description: The judge who ordered Gary Dotson back to prison on a recanted rape charge said today that he was sorry for Mr. Dotson and his family but that their expectations had been unrealistic.

title: Errol Parker and Group Play Big-Band Tunes
description: The Algerian-born drummer Errol Parker often convenes groups of New York's journeymen jazz musicians as the Errol Parker Tentet. Friday at Wollman Auditorium, Broadway at 115th Street, the group played circumscribed but invigorating big-band music.

title: S. E. C. Bars Stockbroker
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday barred a former stockbroker from working in the securities industry after it accused him of taking $800,000 from customers' accounts for his personal use.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: TENNESSEE: Cry of the Heart. By Dotson Rader. 348 pages. Illustrated. Doubleday. $16.95. THE KINDNESS OF STRANGERS: The

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Crime-Stopping Hands
description: Usually, Mitchell Korn thinks carefully before using his hands.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Crime-Stopping Voice
description: Usually, Kathy Barr thinks carefully before using her voice.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Traders See Lower Rates
description: Treasury note and bond yields fell sharply last week in response to fresh statistics showing that the economy was not so vibrant as previously believed.

title: Nets End Celtics' Domination
description: It was the final game of the regular season, and the coaching philosophies were different today as Stan Albeck of the Nets and K. C. Jones of the Boston Celtics were getting their teams ready for the playoffs that begin Thursday. The Nets open in Detroit against the Pistons and the Celtics play host to the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh, 7:35 P.M. The Mets embark on their first road trip, a 10-game swing. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Boxing

title: Advertising;   New Spots For Two Cereals
description: THERE is a new, more aggressive spirit in the land of cold cereals largely because the Kellogg Company, which dominates the market with about a 40 percent share, has adopted such a stance. So it can be felt too at General Mills, which has a 20 share, and at Post division, which has about 16.

title: CONVENTION-CENTER ISSUES UNSETTLED
description: Building the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center of New York has been hard enough.

title: Conover's Departure Scheduled
description: C. Todd Conover has scheduled May 4 as his departure date as Comptroller of the Currency.

title: THE STAGE: 'A TRUE STORY'
description: GENE RUFFINI'S ''True Story'' is the kind of cardboard melodrama in which supposedly intelligent, grown-up characters wallow in B-movie dialogue and spout sophomoric speculations about God and the Devil. The plot, whose final twist is all too reminiscent of the movie ''Under Fire,'' follows the adventures of Jack Nash (Bill Tatum), a successful, thrice-married journalist who travels to an unnamed Central American country to interview a famous humanitarian doctor named Paul Barenti (Charles Honce). A contemporary Albert Schweitzer type who runs a jungle clinic, Barenti is given to ponderous pronouncements. ''I think God invented the Devil to test us,'' he reflects. We also learn that the doctor is sterile but that ''It doesn't diminish my commitment to life.''

title: Maree Wins 3,000
description: -OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, April 14 (UPI) - Sidney Maree stole the spotlight at the end of a two-day track and field meet at Trinidad's National Stadium Saturday night, winning the 3,000 meters in 7 minutes 52.96 seconds. Paul Davis Hale of Britain was second, followed by Kevin Bryan of the United States.

title: TROTTIER AND JARVIS: KEY FACEOFF
description: Hundreds of times, thousands of times, Doug Jarvis has seen everything Bryan Trottier has to offer. But he saw something new this time. ''Different,'' said the Capitals' veteran center, after the Islanders' 6-4 victory tonight knotted the three-of-five-game playoff series at 2-2. ''It was a little different for him,'' said Jarvis, who lost a key draw to Trottier that led to the winning goal with only 68 seconds to play. ''He took a step inside on me, and the puck just seemed to be sitting there. Then he just took his shot.'' With each team having four skaters on the ice, Trottier and Jarvis, with a combined total of over 1,500 regular-season games between them, met in the faceoff circle to the right of Al Jensen, the Capital goalie. With the score 4-4, Jarvis was essentially in a defensive situation, hoping to prevent a shot on net. Both are among the league's toughest faceoff men, but Trottier was in an offensive frame of mind. He wanted to force the puck forward, but when asked later to explain the mechanics of the situation, he would not admit to much more. ''I was just hoping,'' he said. On the drop, the two clashed their sticks together and the puck momentarily stopped. Jensen was holding his ground in the crease. And Rod Langway, a defenseman, began to move toward the dormant puck. ''I anticipated too much,'' said Jarvis, blaming himself for Trottier's success. ''It was a four-on-four situation and I anticipated getting out of the faceoff circle and up ice to the point too quickly.

title: LENDL VICTOR
description: Ivan Lendl, serving strongly and hitting brilliantly from the baseline, defeated Tim Mayotte, 7-6, 6-4, 6-1, and won the $500,000 Buick World Championship Finals for the second time today. It was his third tournament triumph in three weeks.

title: OPERA: EDOUARD LALO'S 'ROI D' YS'
description: EVE QUELER cranked up her time machine once more last night at Carnegie Hall, this time in behalf of ''Le Roi d'Ys,'' Edouard Lalo's charmingly faded opera about a legendary city that barely escapes being engulfed by the sea when the patron saint of Brittany decides to hold back the rising floodwaters for reasons that only a librettist or catechist could hope to explain. This is the same legend that inspired Debussy's ''Cathedrale Engloutie,'' though Lalo's opera deprives the tale of some of its watery romance by arranging a happy, comparatively dry ending.

title: POSSIBLE RIVAL CRITICIZES GOLDIN
description: State Senator Franz S. Leichter, who is expected this week to announce his candidacy for city comptroller, yesterday accused the incumbent, Harrison J. Goldin, of using his office as a ''collection agency for his campaign.''

title: Susan Finesman Wed To Peter E. Israelson
description: Susan K. Finesman, a daughter of Mrs. Leonard Skirboll of Pittsburgh and Alvin B. Finesman of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter E. Israelson, the son of Fritzi Israelson of New York and the late Harold G. Israelson. Rabbi Harold Silver performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Cummings' Pulpit: The Court
description: ''He openeth also their ear to Discipline, and commandeth that they return from Iniquity. If they obey and serve Him, they shall spend their days in prosperity, and their years in pleasures.'' Job 36:10-11

title: OUTDOORS: SAILING IN ANY WEATHER
description: FOR those of us who live in the Northeast, talk of sailing in the spring is somewhat like bantering about skiing in the fall. It is a ritual of sorts, a process of getting the mind into gear for the advent of a new season.

title: O'NEILL PERFORMED FOR MAYO DOCTORS
description: It wasn't quite the usual production of ''Long Day's Journey Into Night.'' The actors, Jason Robards, his son, Sam Robards, Teresa Wright and Margaret Hunt, performed, and read, only specific scenes from the Eugene O'Neill drama - those dealing with the narcotic addiction of Mary Tyrone, the wife, and the reactions of her family.

title: Cast Changes at Met For Verdi's 'Rigoletto'
description: The Metropolitan Opera's Friday night performance of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' was a dreary affair. Aldo Protti, who made his company debut as the bitter, deformed court jester, is best known in the United States for some recordings he made in the 1950's with Renata Tebaldi; on Friday, his voice sounded tattered and unpleasant. Mr. Protti clearly knew the role, and he managed to salvage some scenes with a combination of experience and histrionic ability - vividly conveying poor Rigoletto's blustering, impotent fury - but fell apart entirely in legato passages.

title: RECITAL: CAMILLA HOITENGA
description: WHAT sets Camilla Hoitenga apart from most other flutists specializing in contemporary material is her ability to integrate unusual technical effects - harmonics, tongue flutters and the like - into a convincing musical context without a trace of Modernist ostentation. Miss Hoitenga's concert Thursday evening at Roulette, the most exciting program of new music this listener has heard so far this year, was characterized by arresting material (all composed within the last 12 years) realized in a manner that was unfailingly tasteful, intelligent, even lyrical.

title: 2d Post for Alcoa Head; Vice Chairman Resigns
description: The Aluminum Company of America has announced that James S. Pasman Jr., vice chairman since December 1982, had resigned ''in anticipation of early retirement.'' Mr. Pasman, who is 54, plans to pursue personal business interests, the company said. No successor was named.

title: ERA OF CHANGE FOR CAR DEALERS
description: The automobile dealership of the future may have taken root on the southeast side of this city by the bay. The San Francisco Autocenter, with models from six different car companies under one roof, has more in common with a beguiling shopping mall than with a traditional car dealership.

title: Marie Brenner Is Married to Ernest H. Pomerantz
description: The marriage of Marie Harriet Brenner, the special correspondent of Vanity Fair, to Ernest Harold Pomerantz, a managing director of E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Liberman in New York. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum performed the ceremony.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
KNICKS' FUTURE CLOUDED
description: ''Tennis season,'' the voice rang out loudly, ''begins Monday at 3 o'clock.''

title: Scali Officer Has New Titles
description: Alan D. Pesky, 51 years old and one of the founders of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, has been named vice chairman and chief operating officer, the first person to hold the titles in the agency's 17-year history.

title: TRINIDAD TO KEEP REFINERY GOING
description: With world oil prices down and many refineries closing, the Government of Trinidad and Tobago has reluctantly bought the sprawling Texaco Inc. refinery on the east coast of Trinidad.

title: Jets Clinch Series With 5-3 Triumph
description: Doug Smail and Laurie Boschman scored short-handed goals in the second period tonight to give the Winnipeg Jets a 5-3 victory over the Calgary Flames that clinched their Smythe Division semifinal playoff, 3 games to 1.

title: HOT-HITTING MURPHY SPURS BRAVES
description: Dale Murphy continued his long-ball hitting spree by ripping a two-run homer, his fourth homer this season, and Bruce Sutter pitched out of a ninth-inning jam today to lead the Atlanta Braves to a 3-1 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: AIR DISASTER TRIAL REOPENING TODAY
description: The trial of a negligence suit growing out of the crash of an Air India Boeing 747 in 1978 is being reopened today in Seattle for testimony about a subsequent incident that has emerged as an important element in the case.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: RETROSPECTIVE Felix Nussbaum was a German artist who, because he was Jewish, died at Auschwitz. The artistic legacy he left behind goes on exhibition today at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street (860-1888). He and his work exemplify the unquenchable will to create during one of the most destructive periods in history.

title: U.S. Sailor Dies in Vesuvius
description: A United States Navy seaman was killed today when he fell more than 300 feet into the crater of Mount Vesuvius, a Navy spokesman said. Another seaman remained stranded inside the volcano tonight but apparently was not injured. The identities of the men were not immediately released.

title: ISLANDERS SCORE FOUR LATE GOALS TO TIE PLAYOFF AT 2-2
description: With the drama at an almost unbearable level, Bryan Trottier scored with 1 minute 8 seconds to play tonight to break a tie, propelling the Islanders to a 6-4 victory over the Washington Capitals and sending their opening round playoff series to a decisive fifth game.

title: PETE ROSE MANAGING DUAL ROLE
description: PETE ROSE, the only playing manager in the big leagues, marked his 44th birthday yesterday the way he marks most days: By writing the name ''Rose'' in the No. 2 spot in the lineup of the Cincinnati Reds. Then he trotted out to his position at first base, one eye on Ty Cobb, two hats on his head.

title: WOOD LOOMS AS KEY TEST IN COUNTDOWN TO DERBY
description: The Wood Memorial at Aqueduct and five other prep races this week should help provide an answer to the riddle of the Kentucky Derby on May 4: Is it really a wide-open race rich with possibilities, or just a private contest among four top colts who raced in Florida this winter?

title: Toni Elizabeth Siegel Marries Peter M. Sturtevant
description: Toni Elizabeth Siegel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Siegel of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Mann Sturtevant Jr., a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Sturtevant of Cohasset, Mass. Associate Justice Arnold L. Fein of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: S. E. C. WILL CONSIDER OPTION-TRADING PLAN
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will step into a Wall Street crossfire on Tuesday when it considers whether to permit trading in over- the-counter stock options and index options and, if so, who should trade them.

title: A New Economic Council
description: Trade issues, fast exploding into perhaps the hottest potato of the second Reagan term, will get more concentrated attention under a White House reorganization announced last week.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 15, 1985: *2*MONDAY Bally Mfg Corp Lilly (Eli) & Co Burlington Northern Nicolet Instrument Disney Productions Southern Co InterFirst Corp Storage Equities Kenwin Shops *2*TUESDAY American Cyanamid Mary Kay Cosmetics Boise Cascade Corp Scott Paper Eastern Utilities Security Pacific Corp ENSERCH Corp Smucker (JM) Co Hillenbrand Indus Southern Ind G&EHoneywell Inc Triton Energy K mart Corp VF Corp Lehman Corp *2*WEDNESDAY Alberto Culver Luby'sBard (CR)Mesa Petroleum Cessna Aircraft Midwest Energy Co Conrac Corp Mortgage&Rlty Trust Dow Jones & Co Murphy (GC) Corp Dun & Bradstreet Owens-Illinois GTE Corp Winsconsin Pwr&Lt *2*THURSDAY Alagasco Inc Libbey-Owens-Ford Barnett Banks of FL Owens-Corning Black & Decker Corp PPG Indus Bundy Corp Parker-Hannifin Burlington Indus Pope & Talbot Diamond Shamrock Thomas Industries Federal Signal Time Inc First Wisconsin Corp Tull (JM) Indus Gillette Company Twin Disc Grumman Corp Weyerhaeuser Co *2*FRIDAY Acme Electric Levi Strauss & Co CentralLouisiana Elec Lomas&Nettleton Fin Church's Fried Chken Midland Ross Corp GATX Corp Wachovia Corp *2*SATURDAY Regal-Beloit Corp

title: JAMES BAKER'S BIG TEST IN ECONOMIC DIPLOMACY
description: Last week was Baker week, at home and abroad.

title: PORSCHE CAR ENGINE SET FOR LIGHT PLANES
description: Porsche, the West German auto maker whose sports cars could probably qualify as a kind of low-flying aircraft, has embarked on an ambitious project to adapt one of its most powerful sports car engines for use in single-engine light planes, company officials have disclosed.

title: QUESTIONS AWAIT IN RANGERS' FUTURE
description: Scattered around their dressing room, the Rangers sat mostly dry- eyed and silent after Saturday night's 6-5 loss to the Flyers and began to forget the season that had ended quickly in three straight defeats but not unexpectedly.

title: Bridge: As Female Stars Remarry, Confusion May Be a Result
description: Women who have great careers in the game create headaches for bridge writers when they remarry. Will the reader be able to recognize Helen Smith? Or Dorothy Truscott? Or Kathie Walvick? Or Edith Freilich?

title: RATINGS FOR TOP MOVIES ON HBO ARE FALLING
description: The ratings of the 10 most watched movies on Home Box Office in 1984 - including ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' and ''Tootsie'' - were down 25 percent from such top 10 movies of 1982 as ''Arthur'' and ''The Cannonball Run.''

title: BALLET: 'INTERMEZZO NO. 2,' SEQUEL BY ELIOT FELD
description: ''INTERMEZZO,'' a ballet that Eliot Feld created in 1969 when he formed his first company, the American Ballet Company, deservedly became one of the most popular works in the dance repertory. Now Mr. Feld has created a sequel, ''Intermezzo No. 2,'' for his present company, the Feld Ballet.

title: 81 PRIVATE PICASSOS TO BE SEEN IN MONTREAL
description: The harlequin, the horse, the matador, the musketeer, the beautiful woman - and many of the other familiar characters of Picasso's paintings - will appear this summer in an unusual exhibition of the artist's works that have for the most part never before been seen except by Picasso and his close family.

title: TIGERS DEFEAT ROYALS FOR 5TH STRAIGHT
description: Lance Parrish drove in four runs with an infield out and a homer and Willie Hernandez pitched out of a bases-loaded, none-out jam in the ninth inning as the Tigers remained undefeated after five games.

title: Johnson Wins
description: Chris Johnson of the United States birdied the last hole and won the First Yamaha Cup Ladies Open Golf Tournament today by three strokes for her first victory in Japan.

title: MOM-AND-POP FM STATION FILLS UPSTATE AIRWAVES
description: Peter Hunn is a captive of his dream.

title: Express Winner
description: Frank Seurer, the backup quarterback for Los Angeles, threw a 35-yard touchdown pass to Jo Jo Townsell with 1 minute 8 seconds to play to rally the Express to an 18-17 United States Football League victory over Houston tonight.

title: WALKER SCORES 2
description: The Generals had an easy time today. They beat the Portland Breakers, 34-7, before a quiet crowd of 38,245 at Giants Stadium for their fifth victory against three defeats.

title: LANGER'S RALLY WINS MASTERS
description: Bernhard Langer became the first German golfer to win one of the four major tournaments today when he came from four shots off the lead with nine holes to go at Augusta National and won the 49th Masters Tournament by two shots. Curtis Strange, Ray Floyd and Seve Ballesteros tied for second.

title: METS TAKE FIFTH IN A ROW
description: The Mets roared on to the best start in their 23-year history yesterday when they completed a sweep of the Cincinnati Reds and won their fifth straight game. And they did it with full star quality: Dwight Gooden pitched a four-hit, 4-0, shutout with 10 strikeouts, and Gary Carter hit his third game-winning home run.

title: Japan's Don Quixote
description: In Japan, as in the United States, losers are not a much-admired breed, but Japanese lore has always had a soft spot for the flawed hero who perishes in a noble, if vain, effort.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let's go for it.'' - Jack C. Burcham, before receiving artificial heart. (B7:2.)

title: NIEKRO GIVES YANKS 2-1 TRIUMPH
description: The afternoon became a flashback to the first half of 1984. Phil Niekro, baseball's grand old gentleman, was on the mound, his knuckleball fluttering in every direction. Bats were flailing helplessly. Everything was right with the Yankees.

title: WESTWAY FOES SPAR ACROSS HUDSON
description: Mayor Koch and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey fired salvos across the Hudson yesterday in a battle over Federal funds for Westway.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: MONDAY, APRIL 15, 1985 International

title: Agency Acts On Thrift Units WASHINGTON, April 14
description: (Reuters) - The Federal

title: ARGENTINA AWAITS ANTI-INFLATION PLAN
description: After nearly two months in office, Argentina's Economics Minister has failed to announce a convincing program to break the country's cycle of increasing inflation, according to American and Argentine bankers.

title: THEATER: REVIVAL OF 1959 'TAKE ME ALONG' OPENS
description: EUGENE O'NEILL'S only comedy, ''Ah, Wilderness!'', is a nostalgic reverie about the happy childhood its author never had. ''Take Me Along,'' the 1959 musical comedy adapted from it, can make one feel nostalgic for a Broadway that no longer exists. This show typifies the kind of solid book musical - unfailingly professional and tuneful, if never brilliant - that used to be the bread-and-butter of the commercial New York theater. Even in its time, it wasn't a smash hit, but it was sturdy enough to run a year alongside such more formidable musicals of the 1959-60 season as ''The Sound of Music,'' ''Fiorello!'' and ''Bye, Bye Birdie.''

title: ASSETS OF CRIME VICTIM, 84, BLOCK AID
description: When Jennie Sholin was mugged on her way home to her apartment in the Bronx one autumn afternoon in 1981, she was a spry, 80-year-old widow who prided herself on her independence.

title: STATUS OF PRIMARY DEALERS IN U. S. BONDS ASSAILED
description: While legislators in Washington work on plans to regulate the market in Government securities, a controversy is brewing over the privileged status of firms that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York designates as ''primary dealers.''

title: S.I. VILLAGE CLAIMS A PLACE IN HISTORY FOR ITS DEAD
description: Along a gravelly back road on the south shore of Staten Island is a lot that has stood for more than a century as a memorial to Sandy Ground - one of the nation's oldest surviving settlements founded by free blacks.

title: TEACHER TURNS STAGE INTO CLASSROOM
description: Late at night, in a tiny basement theater in Greenwich Village, the best part of Robert Thatcher's junior high school class in theater arts was about to begin.

title: Catching Up
description: * Gerard Phelan, the receiver of the long Doug Flutie pass that beat Miami on the last play, is quietly completing his senior year at Boston College and awaiting the National Football League's draft on April 30. ''I had a few talks with the Generals,'' he said, ''but nothing worked out.

title: Debt Issues
description: Bindley Western Industries is offering $55 million of 8 5/8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2010, priced at 100, through underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Co.

title: 5TH PATIENT RECEIVES ARTIFICIAL HEART, DESPITE PROBLEM
description: Jack C. Burcham, a 62-year-old retired railroad engineer, received a permanent artificial heart today in an operation that took six hours, longer than expected because surgeons had difficulty fitting the fist-sized device into his chest.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, APRIL 15, 1985

title: AREA RETAIL SALES UP JUST A BIT
description: Retail sales in New York City were disappointing in March, averaging only eight-tenths of a percent ahead of the corresponding month in 1984, a spot-check found yesterday. Sales in the metropolitan area were up 3.5 percent, the spot-check showed.

title: Wheeling Debt Negotiations Representatives of the
description: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company

title: CHINESE IMMIGRANTS IN 'NIGHTSONGS'
description: MARVA NABILI, an immigrant film maker from Iran, has written and directed ''Nightsongs,'' a fictional portrait of Chinese immigrants in New York. Having spent several years living near and even working in Chinatown, she has compiled a haunting biography of ''outsiders'' trying to survive in a new environment. The slice-of-life details are depicted with the immediacy of a documentary using a hidden camera. Being presented as part of public television's ''American Playhouse'' series, ''Nightsongs'' can be seen tonight at 9 on WNET/Channel 13.

title: YOUNG VICTIMS OF NAZI TERROR RECEIVE TRIBUTE
description: Jack Garfein, Auschwitz survivor and Broadway director, struggled to comprehend the enormity of the deaths of one million children in Nazi concentration camps.

title: Vineyard Opera Shop Presents 'La Griselda'
description: In one of those table-turning ironies of history, it is Domenico, not Alessandro, Scarlatti who presents his face to us today. Yet one of the reasons the former seemed to have left Italy for Portugal and Spain was the all-encompassing and stifling fame of his father. Nineteen eighty-five celebrates Domenico's 300th birthday, but the Vineyard Opera Shop is sidestepping that fact to present an almost forgotten work by Alessandro Scarlatti - ''La Griselda,'' written in 1721.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. Home opener. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.)

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: SOME CHARGES DROPPED ON ABORTION BOMBING
description: Federal prosecutors today dropped charges in one of four bombings of abortion facilities last year, but each of the four defendants still faces seven counts.

title: BONN MINISTER REJECTS U.S. ADVICE ON GROWTH
description: Gerhard Stoltenberg, the West German Finance Minister, expressed sharp disagreement today with the contention of top Washington officials that European governments should do more to stir their economies by stimulating investment and growth.

title: Recantation, Incantation and Rape
description: If Gary Dotson didn't commit the rape for which he is serving 25 to 50 years in an Illinois prison, he has to be the most forgiving prisoner imaginable. He forgives Cathleen Crowell Webb, who now says she falsely accused him of raping her six years ago when she thought she was pregnant at age 17. Though distraught that the trial judge has refused to set aside his conviction, he says he understands that he has an uphill battle because courts resist pleas based on recantations.

title: Defendant in Spy Case Asks Court to End Ban
description: Richard Miller, the only agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation ever charged with espionage, filed an emergency appeal today in an attempt to overturn an order issued by a Federal district judge barring out-of-court statements by attorneys.

title: COME FLUFF OR FINANCE, THE SUBJECT IS MONEY
description: Senator Robert Taft, the conservative Republican, denounced it as ''pouring money down a rat-hole.'' The Guaranty Trust Company (now Morgan Guaranty Trust) said nations could ''buy merchandise without being able to pay for it.'' The American Bankers Association said the United States was handing over ''the power to determine the destination, time and use of our money.''

title: AROUND THE WORLD;'A Blight on Islam,' Shultz Says of Iran
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Iranian Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was ''a blight on the history of Islam'' because of its persecution of members of the Bahai religious sect.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;M.A.C. in Surprise Sale Of Tax-Exempt Bonds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation suprised the tax-exempt market yesterday with a $205 million offering of new tax-exempt bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS TROOPS WILL LEAVE ANGOLA
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today that South Africa would complete the withdrawal of its forces from Angola by the end of this week.

title: REAGAN CAMPAIGNS FOR LATIN PACKAGE
description: Beginning a weeklong drive to win House and Senate approval of $14 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, President Reagan warned Congress tonight that a vote against the aid would be ''literally a vote against peace.''

title: CUOMO, BAKER PICKED TO GIVE RADIO TALKS
description: Governor Cuomo and former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee will provide weekday radio commentaries for the Mutual Radio Network, the network announced today.

title: TROOPS ARRIVE IN SIDON TO HALT FIGHTING
description: After a delay of two weeks, Lebanese Army reinforcements were sent from here to Sidon today in an effort to halt the fighting between Christian and Moslem gunmen.

title: THE REGION;Court Upholds Ban on Pigeons
description: A woman who races pigeons for a hobby lost an appeal to the United States Supreme Court today over her right to keep the birds at her home.

title: BRIEFING;What Conscience?
description: While yesterday was the taxpayers' deadline day, the Treasury Department issued a reminder that there is no deadline for contributing to the ''Conscience Fund'' or one of the other special funds for people who feel a need to give the Government money.

title: Bridge: Climbing the 5-Rung Ladder Toward Heights of the Game
description: The ladder to bridge stardom consists of five major steps: the beginnings, taking lessons and playing socially; the venture into novice games at the club and tournament level; the battles in Flight B competitions from which top-ranked players are excluded; serious efforts to win regional and national events, and, for a select few, national victories with world titles beckoning.

title: DECLINE IN HOSPITAL USE TIED TO NEW U.S. POLICIES
description: Hospitals across the country are experiencing the steepest decline in use in at least 20 years, largely as a result of Federal cost containment policies that took effect last year, health officials and hospital administrators say.

title: SHORTAGE OF PESTICIDES SEEN AFFECTING CROPS
description: A shortage of some important pesticides has developed just as the chemicals are being needed for planting starting this week, because of a long shutdown of a Union Carbide Corporation factory in West Virginia, according to the company, farmers and marketers.

title: EARLY APRIL AUTO SALES DOWN 6.6%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles fell by 6.6 percent in the first 10 days of April, the manufacturers reported today.

title: U.S. Says Algeria Is Eligible To Make Military Purchases
RESPONSIBILITY FOR JESUS' DEATH IS A NONQUESTION
description: Pilate's 1981 Escort

title: SUDAN GREETS SPRING IN AN ESPECIALLY JOYOUS MOOD
description: Sudanese today celebrated ''Shamnen- Nessim,'' the first day of spring. Families ignored the searing heat of the white desert sun and picnicked along the banks of the Blue and White Nile Rivers, which converge in this sprawling, beige-toned capital.

title: DANCE: MARTHA GRAHAM
description: NO legendary figure treated by Martha Graham ever remains in his historical time period. Legend and myth, history and Bible serve her as channel for comment on humanity as a whole.

title: IN ADIRONDACKS, RIVER RAFTERS GET ADVENTURE AND CHALLENGE
description: The river races here. Swollen with melted snows and spring rains, it rushes in a wild, white froth through still forests.

title: THE REGION;Redistricting Pact Is Set in Yonkers
description: All the parties in a dispute over political redistricting here have agreed to return to the ward system temporarily, lawyers said today.

title: MAN'S EXTRADITION TO ISRAEL ORDERED
description: A Federal district judge today ordered John Demjanjuk, a retired automobile worker, extradited to Israel for trial on charges that he committed war crimes while serving as a guard at the Nazis' Treblinka death camp in Poland.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;Poet on Wheels
description: Now that's a lovely place to be,''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about children's sleep disorders misidentified two researchers. They are Dr. Marc Weissbluth of Chicago and Dr. Lawrence W. Brown, associate professor of pediatrics at the Medical College of Pennsylvania.

title: CONFERENCE ON AIDS BEGINS IN ATLANTA
description: Preventing the spread of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, AIDS, could eventually require that everyone in the United States be vaccinated against the disease, when and if a vaccine is developed, the director of the Government's AIDS surveillance program speculated today. Researchers are still far from developing such a vaccine, however, according to reports presented here at an international conference on the disease. The conference was sponsored by the Federal Centers for Disease Control. When such a vaccine is developed, said Dr. James W. Curran, head of the Federal centers' AIDS Task Force, ''It will probably be desirable to vaccinate all Americans.'' Current efforts to prevent the spread of the illness, which has struck more than 9,000 people in the United States since 1978, are limited largely to counseling and educating the public, Dr. Curran said. He said that within the next year, AIDS will strike another 9,000 people, many of them homosexual men. Preventing the spread of the illness in homosexuals is becoming nearly impossible, Dr. Curran said, because although homosexuals are having fewer sexual partners, a higher percentage of those partners already will have been exposed to the AIDS virus. Furthermore, as the group of people exposed to the virus ages, the number of AIDS-related cancers and brain diseases will increase, Dr. Curran said. The AIDS virus recently has been shown to affect the brain as well as the immune system. In other presentations at the conference, researchers gave progress reports on two drugs that have shown some ability to block the growth of the AIDS virus in patients. However, it is too soon to say whether either drug will lead to a practical, effective treatment, the researchers said. Both drugs - suramin, being studied at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., and HPA23, being investigated at the Pasteur Institute in Paris - have shown some anti-AIDS activity in trials with a handful of patients.

title: ADVERTISING ;B.B.D.O., New York, Wins Visa U.S.A.
description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn has won the Visa U.S.A. advertising account, which is expected to bill at least $15 million.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;Tulane Senate Acts
description: The Tulane University Senate voted, 42-5, yesterday to ratify President

title: FALL PREVIEW FROM 4 AMERICAN DESIGNERS
description: As models tried on just-completed clothes for approval and other styles were sent back to the workrooms for changes, designers in New York paused this week to give their views on dressing for the new season and on the role of American fashion.

title: THE CITY;NOW Endorses Bellamy for Mayor
description: The New York City chapter of the National Organization for Women yesterday endorsed Carol Bellamy in her campaign for mayor.

title: BASEBALL;MARTINEZ A SMASH IN RETURN
description: Julio Cruz, an unlikely hero, hit a two-out, two-run single in the 11th inning today to give the Chicago White Sox a 6-5 victory over the Red Sox in Boston's annual Patriot's Day game.

title: Salmonella Cases on Rise
description: The number of confirmed cases of milk- borne salmonella rose above 5,000 today as the authorities linked the death of a fourth person to the bacteria that has plagued five states for more than two weeks. The death Thursday of Thomas F. Levins, 44 years old, of Rockford, Ill., was caused by salmonella poisoning, a coroner said. There were 5,295 confirmed cases of salmonella in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Wisconsin and Indiana, said Jeremy Margolis, acting director of the Illinois Public Health Department. This is an increase of 1,687 cases since Friday.

title: BONN TO WEIGH SOVIET FERRY LINK
description: West Germany is expected to seek negotiations with the Soviet Union on construction of a Baltic Sea rail-ferry link that naval experts have said poses potential security risks for the West.

title: MAN PLEADS GUILTY TO ASSAULT IN BEATING OF BLACKS BY A MOB
description: The remaining defendant indicted in the fatal beating of a black man by a group of young white men on a Brooklyn street in 1982 pleaded guilty yesterday to an assault charge.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;Murphy's Torrid Start
description: The torrid start by Atlanta's

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;Kramer Expects Trade
description: Tommy Kramer , who has been the Minnesota Vikings' No. 1 quarterback for the last several National Football League seasons, said he expected to be traded if the University of Miami quarterback,

title: SUPREME COURT ROUNDUP;JUSTICES TO RULE ON RACE LAYOFF APPEAL
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Constitution permits governments' employers to restructure lay- off procedures in order to protect the jobs of black employees with less seniority than white workers.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;Comings and Goings
description: Hubie Brown , the coach of the Knicks, will do the color commentary for CBS in Saturday's televised game between the Celtics and the Cavaliers for the National Basketball Association playoffs. . . .

title: Hans Bethe To Receive Bush Award
description: Dr. Hans A. Bethe, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist and professor emeritus at Cornell University, has been selected to receive the National Science Board's Vannevar Bush Award, it was announced today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;Xerox Buys A Rating Firm McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei
description: Inc., one of five bond rating

title: U.S. AND SOVIET GENERALS DISCUSS KILLING OF AMERICAN ARMY MAJOR
description: The chief Soviet and American Army commanders in Germany have held what a Reagan Administration official called today ''a reasonably productive meeting'' to draw up rules to avoid a repetition of the Soviet shooting of an Army major last month in East Germany.

title: EDUCATION;IS NATIONAL TEACHER TEST THE CORRECT ANSWER?
description: THERE are as many ways to become a schoolteacher in the United States as there are states, a fact that is leading some educators to advocate the use of a single examination that every teacher candidate in the country would have to pass.

title: ADVERTISING ;Miller May Replace L"owenbr"au Agency
description: The Miller Brewing Company confirmed yesterday that it would be looking over a number of agencies as a possible replacement for Backer & Spielvogel on the creative part of the L"owenbr"au beer account.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Cardinal Says Situation In Poland Is Unchanged
description: Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, arrived today for talks with Pope John Paul II and said he did not believe church-state relations in Poland had recently worsened.

title: TV REVIEWS;'HEARTBREAK HOUSE' ON SHOWTIME CHANNEL
description: ONE of the more welcome projects devised for a pay- cable operation is a sporadic series called ''Broadway on Showtime.'' The offerings consist of productions taken from the stage, sometimes directly, sometimes in specially tailored revivals. The ''Broadway on Showtime'' presentations have included Lanford Wilson's ''Fifth of July,'' Tennessee Williams's ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' starring Jessica Lange, and Athol Fugard's ''Master Harold . . . and the Boys,'' with Matthew Broderick. The latest, which can be seen today at noon and at 8 P.M. on the Showtime pay channel, is George Bernard Shaw's ''Heartbreak House'' in a version produced at New York's Circle in the Square in 1983.

title: THE WORM AND THE APPLE;RIDING/READING
description: Special DeliveryNew York City's bicycle messengers may be the fastest way to get deliveries around midtown at midday. But the messengers, paid by the job, have strong incentive to speed along oblivious to traffic lights, one-way signs and even pedestrians. Finally the law is catching up with them, but not fast enough.

title: PERIPHERALS;PORTABLE COMPUTERS SHOW SIGNS OF LOSING WEIGHT
description: ACCOMPANIED by much grunting, huffing and heaving, the first ''portable'' computers lumbered into the marketplace several years ago. Some of them weighed 30 pounds or more, hardly dainty enough to be carried gracefully while dashing through an airport, and they were priced as if they were worth their weight in gold.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;$150 Million Sale Of Housing Bonds
description: The Pennsylvania Housing Finance Agency is offering $150 million of single family mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs, with a maximum yield tentatively set at 9 5/8 percent for bonds due in 2016. For shorter maturities, yields range from 6 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 9 1/4 percent in 2000, and 9 1/2 percent in 2005.

title: HERBERT GAINS, PROFESSOR OF AMERICA
description: THE temptation is to say that Herbert J. Gans has studied cities, suburbs, Levittown and nostalgia for the rural past; Jews, Italians, Wasps, blacks, immigrants, factory workers and literary critics; class, race, poverty, equality and rising expectations; popular culture, the mass media, public libraries, what appears on British television, book awards and letters received at NBC Nightly News.

title: OPERA: EVE QUELER CONDUCTS LALO'S 'ROI D'YS'
description: EVE QUELER cranked up her time machine once more Sunday night at Carnegie Hall, this time on behalf of ''Le Roi d'Ys,'' Edouard Lalo's charmingly faded opera about a legendary city that barely escapes being engulfed by the sea when the patron saint of Brittany decides to hold back the rising floodwaters for reasons that only a librettist or catechist could hope to explain. This is the same legend that inspired Debussy's ''Cathedrale Engloutie,'' though Lalo's opera deprives the tale of some of its watery romance by arranging a happy, comparatively dry ending.

title: Marquess Is Fined in Britain For Breaking Into Pharmacy
description: The Marquess of Blandford, heir to a $64 million fortune, was convicted of burglary today and fined $1,270 after admitting he broke into a pharmacy in search of heroin.

title: 16.1% Gain For Nynex In Period
description: The Nynex Corporation, the regional telephone holding company serving New York and most of New England, yesterday reported a 16.1 percent rise in first-quarter net income, to $257.4 million, or $2.55 a share, compared with $221.7 million, or $2.29 a share, in the 1984 period.

title: WHEELING SAID TO VOTE FOR CHAPTER 11 FILING
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation decided last night to file for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code after it failed to win concessions from its creditors, a United Steelworkers of America official said. The creditors are owed $514 million.

title: SCOUTING ;Gaining on Time
description: When Mike Flanagan ruptured an Achilles' tendon while playing basketball in January, it was feared that the left-handed pitching ace of the Baltimore Orioles staff would be lost until July, at the earliest. There were even doubts that the Americaan League Cy Young Award winner in 1979, when he won 23 games, would ever regain the effectiveness that has produced 122 victories against 82 defeats since he began hurling regularly for Baltimore in 1977.

title: Gandhi Invites Investments
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today invited foreign business executives to invest in Indian industry and agriculture, saying the country was being opened up to cash and technology from abroad.

title: MARRIAGE: RESEARCH REVEALS INGREDIENTS OF HAPPINESS
description: IN the psychological web that is marriage, there is

title: VOTE IN PERU: POLITICAL PROFILE IS ALTERED
description: With over 70 percent of Peruvians giving their support to either Social Democratic or Marxist candidates, the general elections Sunday marked a major turning point in this country's convulsed political history. The conservative parties that have traditionally ruled Peru were rebuffed, while a majority of the 8.2 million voters endorsed populist and even radical measures to deal with the country's acute economic and social crisis.

title: Yanks to Curb Fan Drinking The Yankees announced yesterday measures tocontrol
description: potential problems from drinking by fans at the Stadium. For the first time, low-alcohol beer will be available at

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Applied Power Inc., Milwaukee, a maker of hydraulic equipment, has appointed William T. Neill senior vice president.

title: A REAGAN ECONOMIC REVOLUTION?
description: In his State of the Union Message, President Reagan held out the prospect of a Second American Revolution. At the time, I thought the phrase was exceptional hyperbole, even for the occasion. Other Presidents have offered us various ''Deals'' (Square, New, Fair) - the life span of a Deal is four or eight years - but if Mr. Reagan truly intended another American Revolution, he would be offering something that comes around only every 200 years or so. Thus, the more realistic question remains whether we are about to have the first Reagan Economic Revolution.

title: APARTHEID LAWS ON MIXED-RACE SEX TO BE ABOLISHED
description: The South African Government said today that it had decided to abolish the laws forbidding marriage and sex across racial lines.

title: BRIEFING ;Cambodians to March
description: Several hundred Cambodians

title: In Italy, Communists
description: Remain a Major Power

title: FLAIR INSURES SURVIVAL FOR A TATTERED THEATER
description: He produced ''Julius Caesar'' for $35. He put on ''Faust'' in an inner-city alley, with rats skittering past Satan and winos offering monologues from their fire escapes. And his recent ''Camille,'' set in Nazi-occupied Paris and flickering with blackouts, has been hailed by the few who saw it as the worst production of the Dumas play ever staged.

title: Xerox System
description: The Xerox Corporation said it was introducing an electronic publishing system that would automate the production of business publications, such as manuals, directories and catalogues. Xerox said the new XPS 700 publishing system would include editing and design pagination terminals, a 1,600-bit-per-inch magnetic tape drive, a high-capacity 456-megabyte disk drive and communications ports. The company said that in addition to input from the terminals offered with the system, the XPS 700 can accept input from a variety of word processing machines, personal computers and grapic scanning machines from Xerox and other vendors.

title: I.C.C., SHORT ON FUNDS, BEGINS 4-DAY WEEKS
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission, short on funds, instituted a 20 percent cut in its staffing today that its chairman said would further erode the agency's ability to handle its increasing workload.

title: Take Me Along' Closes
description: Take Me Along,'' the revival of the musical adapted from Eugene O'Neill's ''Ah, Wilderness!'' with book by Joseph Stein and Robert Russell and music and lyrics by Bob Merrill, closed Sunday evening after one performance at the Martin Beck Theater. The play, directed by Thomas Gruenewald, ran for seven previews.

title: PARAMOUNT APPOINTS NEW PRODUCTION CHIEF
description: A new president of production has been named by Paramount Pictures, assuming the post left vacant last September when Jeffrey Katzenberg left to join Walt Disney Productions.

title: SS Officer the Father Of a British Princess
description: Princess Michael of Kent, a member of Britain's royal family by marriage, has learned that she is the daughter of a Nazi SS officer, a Buckingham Palace spokesman said today.

title: TAX TUG-OF-WAR
description: While taxpayers rushed to meet the filing deadline, politicians joined battle over income tax revision, competing for advantage on an issue that many believe could determine whether the Republicans or the Democrats become the dominant party. Democrats are scrambling to reclaim the issue they allowed to slip away in last year's Presidential election. But the Reagan Administration is working on a tax plan, to be unveiled next month, that the Republicans hope will give them command of the issue that will bind middle-class voters to their party for years.

title: U.S. TO LET CONSUMERS SEE MEDICARE DATA ON HEALTH CARE QUALITY
description: The Reagan Administration will soon issue new rules giving consumers access to detailed information comparing the quality of health care provided by hospitals and groups of physicians.

title: PERES WINS VOTE ON ENVOY TO EGYPT
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres today narrowly defeated an attempt by the Likud leader, Yitzhak Shamir, to prevent an Israeli envoy from visiting Egypt.

title: METS' SHADOW COVERS YANKS
description: The Defense Minister the Sudanese President thought was his friend staged a coup d'etat and overthrew him recently while he was out of the country. The Mets, whose owners George Steinbrenner has repeatedly said are his friends, have staged a coup d'etat and overthrown the Yankees not only while they were out of New York but also before they even arrived in New York.

title: THEATER: 'TWO CAN PLAY'
description: IN a back-street neighborhood of

title: INTACT GENETIC MATERIAL EXTRACTED FROM AN ANCIENT EGYPTIAN MUMMY
description: HUMAN genetic material, largely undamaged after 2,400 years, has been extracted from an Egyptian mummy and has been grown in the laboratory. The achievement is the most dramatic of a series of recent accomplishments using molecular biology to study links between modern and ancient life.

title: LITTLE-KNOWN MEDICAL FIELD TREATS PAIN AND DISABILITY
description: PAIN sufferers, accident victims, increasing numbers of patients who survive strokes, cancer and other debilitating diseases, as well as countless tennis players between the ages of 65 and 70 who insist on remaining active into old age are finding help through a little-known field of medicine called physiatry.

title: NEW U.S. RULE SAYS HANDICAPPED INFANT USUALLY MERITS CARE
description: Doctors and hospitals must provide necessary treatment for severely handicapped infants unless death appears inevitable, the Government decided today.

title: TAXI HITS THREE PEDESTRIANS
description: A taxicab struck a man crossing Third Avenue at 46th Street and then, dragging the man underneath, mounted the sidewalk and injured two other pedestrians, the police said yesterday.

title: American Can's Jefferies Stake
description: The American Can Company has purchased the equivalent of 869,565 common shares of Jefferies Group Inc., or 9.8 percent of shares outstanding, according to a filing with the Securites and Exchange Commission. Jefferies is a Los Angeles-based securities company.

title: Mesa Units Sue Unocal
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said today that its Mesa Eastern Inc. subsidiary and Mesa Partners II had filed suit in Delaware Chancery Court against the Unocal Corporation and certain of its directors.

title: IN THE NATION;REAGAN AND DACHAU
description: President Reagan wants to emphasize ''the spirit of reconciliation'' between the United States and West Germany; consequently, said his spokesman, Mr. Reagan fears that visiting the former Nazi concentration camp at Dachau would send Germans ''the wrong signal.'' But that fear may imperil rather than serve the President's good intention.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of an address by President Reagan tonight on the Administration's drive to win Congressional aid for anti-Sandinista rebels, as made public by the White House:

title: THE WORM AND THE APPLE;RIDING/READING Public Access New York is a literary center for the world, but how many New Yorkers outside the book business ever get any personal exposure to the men and women who generate this richness? Thanks to the New York Public Library's two-year-old public education program, the answer is thousands. For the price of a movie ticket, the library welcomes all comers to a stately room on the second floor of its main building, there to hear and talk with the best and brightest of the literary community. A series on biography wound up recently with Robert Caro, prize-winning biographer of Robert Moses, now working on the second of three volumes on Lyndon Johnson.
description: Others included David McCullough (Theodore Roosevelt and the Brooklyn Bridge, now doing Harry Truman) Jean Strouse (Alice Adams) and Richard Sewell (Emily Dickinson).

title: INJURIES TAKE GROWING TOLL IN N.B.A.
description: Red Auerbach has been associated with pro basketball for nearly four decades. Never, the Celtic president said, has he seen so many players sidelined with injuries.

title: DALLAS, MICH.; BOSTON, GA.
description: During a recent flight down South, the attendant began to give the landing announcements as we closed in on Birmingham. Or was it Montgomery? I looked out the window as the white lines of the runway came up. It might as well have been Rochester. Airports all look the same as you land at them. The trouble is that the cities do, too, as you pass through them.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;Rangers' Consolation
description: Seven Rangers got the annual consolation prize for National Hockey League players when they were named to play for their countries in the world championships, in Prague starting tomorrow.

title: How Dual Pay Scale Drives Wages Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: When you have hate groups and groups espousing bigotry that cross from the threshold of rhetoric to the commission of violent acts, our response will be rapid and effective.'' - William M. Baker of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. (A16:1.)

title: DRIVE OPENED FOR VOTES FOR REDUCTION OF DEFICIT
description: The White House and the Senate Republican leadership began a campaign for their deficit reduction package today, with both uncertain about the outcome when the proposal comes to the Senate floor next week.

title: Responsibility for Jesus' Death Is a Nonquestion
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN WEIGHS VISIT TO CONCENTRATION CAMP
description: White House officials said today that President Reagan was considering a stop at a Nazi concentration camp site in addition to a visit to a military cemetery in West Germany next month.

title: McGraw-Hill's Net Increases McGraw-Hill Inc. yesterday
description: reported first-quarter earnings

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;Lenox Head Named President of Avon
description: Avon Products Inc. said yesterday that it had named John S. Chamberlin president and chief operating officer. Mr. Chamberlin is chairman and chief executive officer of Lenox Inc., the dinnerware and giftware manufacturer. The appointment is effective May 1.

title: MARKET PLACE;AMF Stock's Heavy Volume
description: game winning streak. But unfortunately for the White Plains concern, that impressive performance is on Wall Street's active trading list, often a sign that someone has been accumulating stock for other than investment purposes.

title: Portable Computer For Bird Watchers
description: Battery-run portable computers haven't yet joined field guides and binoculars as standard equipment for the bird watcher, but that day may come, says Edward Mair.

title: Chrysler-Maserati Car
description: A $30,000 sports car developed by the Chrysler Corporation and Maserati of Italy will bear the Chrysler name and will contain many Chrysler parts, Chrysler said today. Production in Italy will start late next year.

title: STRANGE PUZZLED BY COLLAPSE
description: The 49th Masters Tournament will be remembered as the one Bernhard Langer of West Germany won and Curtis Strange gave away - but not necessarily in that order. It was astounding that a golfer with the skills Strange has displayed for the last three months could lead by four strokes at the turn of the final round and virtually hand over the victory by losing a three-stroke advantage from the 13th through 15th holes.

title: COLOMBIAN OPPOSES U.S. AID TO NICARAGUAN REBELS
description: The President of Colombia said today that he and other Latin American leaders were opposed to renewed United States military aid for rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government.

title: KOCH PAYS HIS TAXES WITH A SMILE
description: selling book brought him so much extra income last year that he used income-averaging to help ease the tax bite, his 1984 tax returns disclose.

title: GEORGE A. CINCOTTA
description: George A. Cincotta, a former New York State Assemblyman, died of a heart attack Sunday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Financial Corp. Lists Payments LOS ANGELES, April 15 -
description: The Financial Corporation of

title: Canadian Sales Expand
description: Retail sales in Canada rose 2.3 percent in February from the month before and 5.6 percent from February 1984, the Government reported today.

title: STATE URGED TO HELP HOSPITAL IN HARLEM
description: A group of about 40 political, civic and business leaders yesterday asked the Cuomo administration to provide an ''emergency allocation'' of $2 million to prevent the closing of North General Hospital, the only private, voluntary teaching hospital in Harlem.

title: THE REGION ;Assembly Passes Antismoking Bills
description: The State Assembly gave final legislative approval today to four bills aimed at regulating smoking in public places.

title: Ozzie Smith Signs Extension of Pact
description: The all-star shortstop Ozzie Smith signed a four-year contract extension with the St. Louis Cardinals today that his agent, Ed Gottlieb, says will pay him more than $2 million a year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;Aerie on a Mast
description: There could have been no better

title: Interest Rates Are Mixed
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with short-term rates little changed while note and bond yields fell slightly.

title: FRENCH SEEK FUNDS FOR MISS LIBERTY
description: France appealed to the public today for funds to help pay for the restoration of the Statue of Liberty, which it gave to America in a gesture of friendship a century ago.

title: TV SPORTS;A 10-Week Show for Yuppies
description: Sports fans who wash down their

title: Goldsmith Gets Crown Financing
description: Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier, said yesterday that he had received commitments from a group of banks to provide $850 million in financing in connection with his $42.50- a-share, $1.4 billion tender offer to acquire the Crown Zellerbach Corporation.

title: PLAYERS;WHITSON IS QUICK TO FEEL THE HEAT
description: There was no sign around Ed

title: ADOPTED CHILDREN RATED AS PSYCHOLOGICALLY STABLE PEOPLE who wereadopted are as psychologically stable as those who were raised by their normal biological parents, according to a study published in this month's Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. The finding runs counter to the widespread belief that people who were adopted run a higher risk of psychological problems.
description: The study, conducted by Kathryn Marquis and Richard Detweiler of Drew University, included 167 teen- agers, 46 of whom had been placed for adoption within one year of their birth. The adopted teen-agers were more positive in their outlook on life compared to those who had not been adopted; they felt more in control of their lives and saw their parents as more nurturant, comforting, predictable and helpful.

title: Ames In Talks With Murphy
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. said it had options to acquire from Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, about 19.4 percent of the common stock of the G.C. Murphy Company, a retailer based in McKeesport, Pa. Ames also stated that it had initiated discussions with Murphy's management to acquire the remaining shares in the company for $42.50 a share, or about $137.1 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;A Conversion
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, a Republican

title: NEWEST HEART RECIPIENT UNDERGOES SURGERY TO HALT BLEEDING
description: Jack C. Burcham underwent two more hours of surgery today to stop excessive bleeding from ''tiny little leaks'' at the stitches around the artificial heart he received a day earlier. The doctors said the operation was a success.

title: ADVERTISING ;The Elle Magazine Campaign
description: ELLE magazine, which is already being talked about in fashion advertising circles, is going to further imprint its name on its advertising customers' consciousness with a dramatic print campaign from Peter Rogers Associates.

title: 19 ARE CHARGED IN INDIAN ESPIONAGE SCANDAL
description: Nineteen Indian nationals, most of them junior government officials, were formally charged with espionage today, marking the end of a five-month investigation into a spying case that reached into the Prime Minister's office.

title: JAIL TERMS IN HOME-TUTOR BATTLE
description: A couple who sent two of their children out of state in a home tutoring dispute that has attracted wide attention were sentenced today to 90 days in jail.

title: BRAZIL PRAYS AS NEW CHIEF FIGHTS FOR LIFE
description: A man dragged a large wooden cross along the hospital sidewalk. Another followed, flagellating himself with a whip. People have walked by on wounded knees, fumbling rosaries, praying, chanting out loud. Men and women who said they were healers have begged the doormen for a chance to lay their hands on the sick leader inside.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;SOFTWARE ENCOURAGING EXPLORATION
description: THE pedagogical promise of a computer on every desk seems still to pervade our schools. A kind of educational keeping up with the Joneses fueled by the computer manufacturers' high- pressure marketing and stoked by teachers' fears of being left behind, it plunges the schools into unknown electronic spheres that in all probability will not improve our instructional facilities one whit.

title: KELLOGG'S ROBUST TURNAROUND
description: Notwithstanding the robust image of its Tony the Tiger mascot, the Kellogg Company was not feeling

title: BRIEFING;Those Smiling Democrats
description: at the Democratic National

title: U.S. CONSIDERING NEW RULES ON WORKPLACE FORMALDEHYDE
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration is considering issuing new rules to protect more than 1.4 million workers who are exposed to formaldehyde, according to OSHA documents.

title: Alexander-Reed Terms Altered
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said yesterday that it had changed the share exchange terms of its agreement to purchase the Reed Stenhouse Companies, a Toronto-based insurance brokerage. The company said holders of class A and class C shares of Reed Stenhouse stock would now receive the equivalent of 0.576 an Alexander common share.

title: Required Reading;Survivors All
description: The Holocaust casts a long shadow down the corridors of the ages. The murdered six million speak eloquently from the silence of their mass graves and the winds which floated their ashes from the chimneys of the crematoria.

title: FLORIO ASSERTS E.P.A. GAVE IN ON SCHOOL ASBESTOS REMOVAL
description: Representative James J. Florio charged Sunday that because of pressure from the Office of Management and Budget, the Environmental Protection Agency did not order schools to remove asbestos, a cancer-causing substance.

title: Chess: Tukmakov of Soviet Union Wins Lugano International
description: The 10th Lugano International Open Tournament in Switzerland was won this year by Vladimir Tukmakov, a 39-year-old Russian grandmaster. Tukmakov scored 7-2 in the nine- round, 168-player Swiss-system event.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;$217 Million Issue From Port Unit
description: A $217 million issue of Delaware River Port Authority junior lien bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 9.55 percent for 9 1/2 percent bonds due in 2011, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 6.25 percent in 1988 to 8.80 percent in 1997, and 9.43 percent for 9 3/8 percent bonds due in 2002 tentatively priced at 99 1/2.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;Signal Picks Chemist As Director of Research
description: The Signal Companies said that Mary L. Good had been named president and director of research at the Signal Research Center Inc., its basic research laboratory.

title: Days Inns Units
description: Days Inns of America Inc. said it had agreed to sell seven hotel properties in California and one in Reno to California Days Ltd. for $62 million. Days Inns is owned by Reliance Group Holdings Inc. and California Days is an affiliate of Tollman-Hundley Hotels. The company also said it had granted Days of the West Inc., another Tollman affiliate, an exclusive franchise to build Days Inns in California. The company said Days of the West would build at least 40 new inns during the next five years at a cost expected to exceed $300 million.

title: CHRYSLER AND MITSUBISHI TO BUILD SMALL CARS JOINTLY IN THE MIDWEST
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation today announced a joint venture to build subcompact cars in the United States.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Recanter in Rape Case Passes Polygraph Test
description: A polygraph test taken by Cathleen Crowell Webb supports her recanting of testimony that sent a man to prison for rape six years ago, her lawyer said today.

title: JACKSON PRAISES COLUMBIA PROTESTERS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson added his support yesterday to the students demonstrating against Columbia University's ties with companies doing business in South Africa. He praised the protesters for setting a ''moral example'' and said he hoped it would help ''organize students on every campus in America.''

title: BONN SAYS REAGAN MAY BROADEN VISIT
description: The West German Government indicated today that consideration was being given to broadening President Reagan's program during his visit next month to permit him to pay tribute to Jewish victims of the Third Reich.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;For Women at City U.
description: It was a sweet moment for Lilia

title: SCOUTING ;Squaring Matters
description: Billy Graham, a popular boxer from New York's East Side who battled the top lightweight, welterweight and middleweight boxers in the world from 1941 to 1955, never won a championship. But he was the winner of 102 fights and never suffered a knockout, although he lost 15 decisions.

title: ADVERTISING ;Nadler & Larimer
description: Nadler & Larimer, which lost the major part of its fragrance business to Kenyon & Eckhardt last year, has agreed to part with those advertisers altogether on Aug. 1 so that it can go out and seek some new fragrance clients. That means giving up the shampoo brands, which will probably go to K.&E., too. The fragrances were Brut for men and Babe for women. N.& L. is a subsidiary of the Mickelberry Company. K.&E. is a subsidiary of Lorimar.

title: COURT TO HEAR PENNSYLVANIA ABORTION APPEAL
description: In an action likely to refuel the debate over abortion, the Supreme Court today agreed to hear arguments on whether Pennsylvania's Abortion Control Act violates the Constitution.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;A MARVELOUS EIGHT MINUTES
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

title: Keep Filling the Oil Buffer
description: Both the Administration and Congress seem inclined to save money by delaying oil purchases for the nation's strategic reserve. Though the public no longer lives in fear of gasoline lines and no industry seems to be protesting, the proposed moratorium is foolishly shortsighted.

title: NOMINATION OF A U.S. JUDGE IN JERSEY TANGLED IN DISPUTE
description: Joseph H. Rodriguez, the New Jersey Public Advocate, attended an orientation session for prospective members of the Federal bench in Raleigh, N.C., last week, a week before the Senate Judiciary Committee was to consider his nomination.

title: SHUTTLE IS USED AS A WORKSHOP IN REPAIR EFFORT
description: The crew members of the shuttlecraft Discovery turned it into a workshop today as they improvised ''fly swatter'' devices to be attached to the craft's mechanical arm for use - in what would be the first unrehearsed ''walk'' in space - in a bold attempt to repair a disabled satellite.

title: CHIP-TESTING PROBLEMS ABOUND, PENTAGON SAYS
description: A Defense Department inquiry, prompted by the discovery last fall that several vendors of computer components had shipped improperly tested microchips to makers of weapons systems, has concluded that irregularities in the testing of military equipment are pervasive in the electronics industry.

title: Suit by E.S.M. Trustee
description: The court-appointed trustee for E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. of Fort Lauderdale filed suit yesterday in Federal bankruptcy court against the American Savings and Loan Association of Miami in an attempt to recover some $45 million American managed to withdraw before E.S.M.'s collapse.

title: BRIEFING;A New Meese Spokesman
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is expected to appoint a new chief spokesman for the Justice Department. The $72,300-a-year position, officially Special Assistant to the Attorney General and director of the Office of Public Affairs, is to go to Terry H. Eastland, a former Virginia newspaper editor and Government speechwriter. He is to replace Thomas P. DeCair, whose plans were not disclosed.

title: MCI Claim Held Excessive CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -
description: The MCI Communications Corporation's $5.8 billion claim

title: UNOCAL'S CHAIRMAN DIGS IN
description: He was a refinery maintenance worker with a cast-iron will and a flair for chemical engineering. He had only $25 in his pocket when he joined the Union Oil Company 46 years ago.

title: 2 Die in Jersey House Fire
