description: Fire swept through a two-story frame house today, killing Frederick Dunbar, 24 years old, and Anthony Stevens, 19, authorities said. Marion Dunbar, 21, the brother of Frederick, and Sandra Stevens Parrish, 21, were injured.

title: Furnace Reopening Rejected
description: The United States Steel Corporation today rejected as overly optimistic a United Steelworkers study that said a landmark blast furnace tagged for demolition by the nation's largest steelmaker could be made profitable.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 16, 1985 International

title: Production Of Steel Rises By The Associated Press Steel productionrose to 1.861
description: million tons in the week ended

title: Valuation of Storer Disputed
description: The head of Storer Communications Inc., continuing his battle against dissident shareholders who want to liquidate the broadcasting concern, said yesterday that the company's breakup value was far less than the dissidents claim.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION;FAR RIGHT STEPS UP EFFORT TO CONTROL CLASSROOMS
description: IN Hillsboro, Mo., a parent group

title: U.S. INDICTS 23 IN WHITE SUPREMACIST ORGANIZATIION
description: Announcing indictments against 23 members of a white supremacist group today, the Government warned it would retaliate quickly against any further violent acts by racist sympathizers.

title: METHOD GIVING EMIGRES SECRET ACCESS IS ASSAILED
description: The Defense Department has granted security clearances to thousands of emigres from the Soviet Union and other Communist countries, although the Government has no reliable way of checking their backgrounds, according to a Senate investigation.

title: Stockholders Get Hurt in a Greenmail Squeeze
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. TO SEEK COMMENT ON DEALERS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it would seek public comment on how to control abuses by small, unregulated dealers in government securities.

title: BUSINESS HEALTH;H.M.O. GROWTH DISPLAYS VIGOR
description: NOT many years ago, organizers of the prepaid medical plans known as health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, often were sent packing when they sought cooperation from hospitals. Now the wheel has turned. Prepaid plans are thriving while hospitals, squeezed by Government and employer health-cost controls, welcome H.M.O. business. Hospital chains are even organizing their own H.M.O.'s as a way to attract patients and stave off empty-bed syndrome.

title: SCOUTING ;Strikeout Duel, Head to Head
description: Major league baseball's two leading strikeout leaders faced each other for the fifth time on Sunday in Houston, and for the first time in his 18- year career, Nolan Ryan managed to win a decision over Steve Carlton when his Astros defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-3.

title: ISLANDERS CALM FOR 5TH GAME
description: Should the comeback have been expected? Should everyone watching or listening to the game from anywhere have shut their eyes, clicked off their sets because they really knew that the Islanders would do what they did - score four times in the third period in the face of calamity?

title: SONY UNVEILS NEW VCR WITH INCOMPATIBLE FORMAT
description: Eager to catch the first glimpse of what may prove to be important trends in home video, distributors of electronic equipment and industry analysts converged today on Tucson, Ariz., and heard Sony Corporation unveil its latest developments.

title: HAGLER KNOCKS OUT HEARNS AT 2:01 OF ROUND 3
description: Until Thomas Hearns fell, with the assistance of a smashing right to his face by Marvelous Marvin Hagler, and was ruled the loser at 2:01 of the third round, hardly a second passed that one of the fighters wasn't throwing and landing a stunning blow.

title: HOLOCAUST GROUP BARS TRADE-OFF IN ITINERARY
description: Elie Wiesel, chairman of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, said yesterday that President Reagan would not assuage Jews by adding a visit to a former concentration camp or a synagogue to his scheduled trip to a West German military cemetery.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Ceausescu to Cut Short His Visit to Canada
description: Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian leader, is cutting short his visit to Canada because a tour of a nuclear plant near Toronto could not be arranged, a senior Canadian official said today.

title: INTRICATE WEB OF SENSORS ENABLES REFINED QUAKE PREDICATIONS
description: SANDRA SCHULZ carries a ''beeper'' radio link all day and puts it on her bedside table at night. It will sound an alarm if one of seven ''creep meters'' along the San Andreas Fault near Parkfield, Calif., records significant motion.

title: PLAN WOULD CUT DELAYS IN ARRAIGNMENTS
description: New York City's chief criminal-justice officials have agreed to major changes in arrest-to-arraignment procedures aimed at reducing delays now as long as two days in Manhattan.

title: Informatics Rejects Offer WOODLAND HILLS, Calif.,
description: The Informatics General Corporation

title: ENVIRONMENTAL MOVEMENT IS FACING CHANGES
description: A series of leadership changes and the beginnings of a structural reorganization appear to be altering the environmental movement in the United States.

title: 21 IN CITY CHARGED WITH CORRUPTION AT HOUSING AGENCY
description: Federal extortion charges were brought yesterday against 20 current and former New York City Housing Authority supervisors and building superintendents, in what prosecutors said was a widening investigation of corruption in the agency's repair and maintenance program.

title: FIRST PRODUCED IN PARIS IN 1888
description: Lalo's ''Roi d'Ys'' has enjoyed steady popularity in France but has not traveled abroad with much success. First produced in Paris at the Opera Comique in 1888, the composer's last work and only completed opera had its 400th performance at the Comique on Jan. 6, 1940, after which it was transferred to the grander venue of the Paris Opera. The work, based on a Breton legend about a cathedral city that is submerged under the sea, had its American premiere in New Orleans in 1890 but did not arrive at the Metropolitan Opera until Jan. 5, 1922. In Lalo's version, Ys miraculously escapes being engulfed and its populace survives.

title: SCOUTING ;Voice From Past
description: The new United States Basketball League, which will begin its first season during the last week of May, seems to be teeming with former Knicks. The commissioner is Earl Monroe; the owner of the Atlanta franchise (which will not begin competition until 1986) is Walt Frazier; the owner of the White Plains team is Dick Barnett, and Cazzie Russell last week was named coach of the New Jersey Jammers.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: DIASPORA. An Inquiry Into the Contemporary Jewish World. By Howard M.

title: 2-RUN PIRATE 4TH ENDS METS' STREAK
description: Unceremoniously and without much inspiration, the Mets' hopes of a perfect season came to an end tonight in a 4-1 loss to the Pirates at Three Rivers Stadium.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 16, 1985

title: THE REGION;Patient in a Coma After Drug Error
description: An 84-year-old man remained unconscious here today, fighting for his life after receiving 10 times a prescribed amount of morphine.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Isolation of Albania Goes On, New Ruler Says
description: Enver Hoxha, the Albanian leader, was given a hero's funeral today in Tirana, and his successor made clear in a eulogy that Albania would continue to follow a path of isolation.

title: DANCE: TAYLOR TROUPE AT CITY CENTER
description: PAUL TAYLOR is simultaneously a formalist and a moralist. Yet neither his formal patterns nor his moral precepts are rigid.

title: BILOXI BLUES' A TEST OF 2 ACTORS' ART
description: The sergeant tells Arnold, the new recruit, to do 125 pushups. Arnold says he has a ''slight deformity of the spine'' that prevents his being able to oblige. The sergeant orders his charges on a 15-mile, middle-of-the- night hike through a swamp. Arnold says he's not up to it because he has n't had a good night's sleep all week. The sergeant orders him to eat his creamed chipped beef on toast. Arnold says he can't because he has a ''nervous stomach,'' and produces a note from his doctor. The sergeant commands him to eat not only the creamed chipped beef, but also the note.

title: FIRE DAMAGES MIDTOWN BUILDING
description: More than 200 firefighters - many of whom had to walk up 14 flights of stairs carrying 50 pounds of gear - battled a smoky storage-room fire on the 28th floor of an office tower in midtown Manhattan yesterday morning.

title: NAPLES GANG WAR: AND NOW, THE COURTROOM SCENE
description: The scene here, surprising to those not schooled in Italian criminal justice, has become a commonplace to regular watchers of Italian television news.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 16, 1985

title: 107 GRANTS FOR THE DANCE ANNOUNCED
description: The National Endowment for the Arts today announced the award of 107 grants to choreographers, including $12,000 a year for three years to both Hanya Holm and Phoebe Neville of New York City.

title: Conglomerate Up; RCA in 29.2% Rise
description: The United Technologies Corporation, bolstered by the strong performances of its automotive group and its Pratt & Whitney subsidiary, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1985 rose 3.1 percent on an increase in revenues of eight-tenths of 1 percent.

title: High Infant-Mortality Rate in U.S. Requires National Action
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVERTISING ;Hilton Switch
description: Hilton International, which is in the hotel business but largely outside this country, has switched its $3.5 million account to Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle from Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, a subsidiary of the JWT Group.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Recount Nears an End In Indiana House Race
description: Auditors from the General Accounting Office were expected to begin work Tuesday in the last county where votes remain to be recounted in the disputed election to Indiana's Eighth District seat in Congress.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: BOUNTIFUL BROOKLYN There is often more to Brooklyn than meets the eye, and an exhibition that opens today, in Brooklyn, of course, is intended to let the modern eye meet scenes and artistic items from a Brooklyn that has, like old New York across the river, largely vanished.

title: 2 People Are Killed In a Blaze in Queens
description: Two people died last night in a one- alarm fire in Jamaica, Queens, fire officials said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., Jacksonville, said it had agreed to buy Niceville Bancshares Corp. Terms were not disclosed.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Jury Selection Proceeds In Retrial of Von B"ulow
description: Prosecutors and defense attorneys each used the first of their eight jury challenges today in the retrial of Claus von B"ulow on charges of trying to kill his wife.

title: Still Experimental
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS;Debt Issues
description: Bell & Howell Co. is offering $50 million of 12 percent Eurobonds due 1992 at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Banque Paribas Capital Markets.

title: Texaco Acquires Stake From Bass
description: Texaco Inc. said it had exercised its right to acquire for $656.6 million its Series A preferred stock held by the Bass family of Texas and their associates. The acquisition was made under terms of an agreement dated March 6, 1984. At that time, Texaco also announced it would buy the 9.7 percent of its common stock held by the Bass interests, thereby removing what Wall Street analysts described as the threat of a takeover.

title: CONTINENTAL HAS PROFIT
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation reported yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 30.6 percent, to $133.9 million, from $102.5 million in the comparable period of 1984. The per-share figure was up 14.5 percent, to $2.92, from $2.55.

title: UNION CITY PLOT INQUIRY LOOKS AT PLAN FOR POLICE
description: Law-enforcement officials said today that a purported plot to take control of the Union City Police Department might have hinged on an attempt to abolish the uniformed position of police chief and make it an appointive civilian job.

title: INMATES FREE 22 CAPTIVES UNHURT AFTER 10-HOUR SIEGE IN ALABAMA
description: Inmates took control of a section of a state prison today, holding the warden and 21 other people hostage for more than 10 hours before releasing all the captives unharmed, the authorities said.

title: BAKER JAMES CAUTHEN
description: The Rev. Baker James Cauthen, retired executive director of the Baptist Foreign Mission Board who led Southern Baptists in building a large missionary force, died today at his home. He was 75 years old.

title: 2 BLACKS LEAD FIELD OF 7 IN OAKLAND MAYORAL RACE
description: Two strong black candidates are expected to dominate a field of seven in Tuesday's race for mayor of Oakland.

title: SMITH WINS BOSTON MARATHON
description: For 20 miles of today's 26-mile-385-yard Boston Marathon, Geoff Smith was on a pace that would have given him the fastest time ever. Then the hamstring muscles behind both thighs cramped, and survival rather than a record became his priority.

title: Japan Phone Rules Argued
description: United States trade negotiators today began their effort to win simpler standards for telecommunications equipment in Japan amid concern that critical differences between the two sides remain.

title: TURNER BID FOR CBS EXPECTED
description: Ted Turner, the Atlanta-based broadcast and cable television entrepreneur, is expected to announce a bid this week to take over CBS Inc., broadcast industry and Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: JEAN SHEPARD'S AMERICA,' 13-PART SERIES ON PBS
description: JEAN SHEPHERD'S AMERICA,'' a 13-part, half-hour series, apparently will have its moments. It is not much like anything else on public television - or network television either, for that matter - and it is not so much America we are watching as it is Mr. Shepherd. His sensibilities are what count. They may not be as interesting as he thinks they are, but sometimes they are amusing. The series begins on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: CHICK DAVIES
description: Charles Robinson (Chick) Davies, Duquesne University's basketball coach from 1924 to 1948, died today in the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: MILTON BERLE HONORED BY BROADCAST MUSEUM
description: They laughed when he sat down to play. And they kept laughing when the piano collapsed. Waiters laughed, beautiful women laughed, Arnold Stang and Alan King and Red Buttons laughed, and so did the chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, Thornton Bradshaw.

title: DYNAMICS AND PANEL CLASH ON RECORDS
description: The General Dynamics Corporation's top financial officer denied under oath today that the company kept two sets of books on Navy submarine projects during the 1970's in an effort to mask cost overruns.

title: Dow, Up Again, Adds 1.10 Points
description: Wall Street stock prices closed slightly higher yesterday - the fifth trading day in a row that stocks gained. But trading activity was light, as investors continued to resist putting more money into equities.

title: Florida Citrus Area Is Sprayed In Effort Against Fruit Flies
description: Crews in helicopters sprayed 14.5 square miles of a citrus-growing area today to rid it of Mediterranean fruit flies, but rain may have made the effort ineffective, officials said.

title: THE CITY;U.S. Judge Upsets Bias Case Award
description: A Federal judge has overturned a jury verdict that held that the City Board of Education had illegally discriminated against a supervisor of bilingual education either because he was Jewish or because he was not Puerto Rican.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE blue and white welcome

title: CHARGIT SYSTEM PROPOSES CREDIT-CARD ACCESS TO SHOWS
description: Chargit, the national computerized telephone ticket-selling agency, announced plans yesterday for a new electronic entry system that would eliminate the use of tickets at theaters, sports events, concerts and other auditorium shows.

title: TOY TIME IN SPACE
description: When they were not working with their high-technology gear today, the Discovery astronauts took time out to play with their toys. They found that their yo-yo, jacks, Slinky and mechanical mouse did some peculiar things in the weightlessness of space flight.

title: U.S. Sailor Rescued in Italy From Crater of Mt. Vesuvius
description: Rescue teams using winches and steel cables pulled an American sailor from a deep crater on Mount Vesuvius today.

title: Dignity in the Field
description: Imagine yourself a laborer on one of the nation's farms. You are thirsty. Can you quench your thirst? Maybe. Fewer than half the nation's farm workers are provided with drinking water . . . Your hands are covered with pesticide residue. Can you rinse them off? Again, maybe. One-fifth have no place to wash up . . . You need to use a toilet. Can you relieve yourself? More than a third of the nation's farm workers can do so only if they don't mind using a ditch.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects charges of $14,200,000 primarily due to a restructuring of Smith-Corona typewriters in the second quarter.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST WEDNESDAY, APRIL 17, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Music/Noted in Brief ;   Joan La Barbara In Feldman Premiere
description: Morton Feldman's ''Three Voices'' is a quiet tour de force for its composer and for the soprano Joan La Barbara, who sang it live and on tape Sunday at its New York premiere at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street.

title: Music/Noted in Brief ;   David Zinman Directs Rochester Ensemble
description: The Rochester Philharmonic went to Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon, taking with it David Zinman, who is now in his last season as the orchestra's music director before taking over in Baltimore next fall. The music was Haydn's Symphony No. 88, the Sibelius Second Symphony and Stravinsky's Violin Concerto.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   U.S. Lifts Suspension Of Polish Flights to U.S.
description: The United States and Poland signed an agreement today to resume within two weeks the commercial flights that Washington suspended after the Polish Government imposed martial law in December 1981.

title: Group Seeks Currency Role
description: Developing countries today took issue with an American proposal to set up a steering group of industrial countries to control monetary revision discussions and said they wanted to be ''full participants'' in the process.

title: CARNEGIE HALL TELLS OF SEASON
description: The 1985-6 Carnegie Hall season, announced yesterday by the hall's managing director, Seymour Rosen, is to be opened Sept. 21 by the Israel Philharmonic under Leonard Bernstein. As in past years, the presentation of the world's leading orchestras forms the cornerstone of Carnegie programming.

title: BIG THINGS AND LITTLE THINGS
description: WASHINGTON Presidents have a way of stumbling over little things. The

title: PPG's Net Up 8.5% in Period
description: PPG Industries today reported first-quarter profits of $80.4 million, or $1.15 a share, up 8.5 percent from $74.1 million, or $1.06 a share, a year ago. Sales remained steady at $1.04 billion.

title: CENTER STAGE FOR A WORKER
description: For any worker without a flair, it always takes longer to be appreciated. It's that way for the salesman without a gift of gab, the doctor without a bedside manner, the lawyer without a courtroom con, the actor without a big part. Until now, it was that way for Marvelous Marvin Hagler as the world middleweight champion. But in the tempest of his third-round knockout of Thomas Hearns here Monday night, he finally ascended to boxing's center stage because of what he is - a worker. His flair is that he doesn't have any.

title: Bridge: 2 Players Take 2 Top Events In Association Tournament
description: The final sessions of the American Bridge Association National Championships in Cincinnati last week provided a notable double victory: Herbert Taylor of Chicago and Norman Coombs of Brookville, Ind., took the open pairs title and then captured the Swiss teams together with Chester Johnson and Robert Landry of Chicago and Robert Seymour of Newark.

title: KOHL SAYS HE URGED REAGAN TO VISIT A NAZI CAMP
description: The West German Government disclosed excerpts today from a letter delivered Monday to President Reagan in which Chancellor Helmut Kohl recalled that he had urged the inclusion of a former Nazi concentration camp or another monument to the ''victims of fascist terror'' in Mr. Reagan's itinerary next month.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: James B. Taylor, a veteran aircraft industry executive who led the successful marketing of the Cessna Citation business jet in the early 1970's, has been named vice chairman and chief executive officer of the financially troubled Gates Learjet Corporation, effective immediately.

title: ABC CANCELS 'REDS' AFTER PROHIBITION ON EDITING
description: Movie directors won a round today in what may be an continuing battle to guard their creative rights, when an arbitrator prohibited ABC from cutting nine minutes out of ''Reds.''

title: PARKER HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TEXAS COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Perkins Interest
description: Donald N. Smith, who resigned as president and chief executive of Diversifoods Inc. in January, said that he had signed a letter of intent to acquire an 80 percent interest in Perkins Restaurants Inc., a subsidiary of Holiday Inns Inc. The Memphis-based lodging company will retain a minority interest.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Charmin Ad Creator Now Magazine Editor
description: John V. Chervokas, who resigned as vice chairman from Warwick Advertising in February, had an opportunity to become a creative leader at another agency, but turned it down to become editor in chief of Madison Avenue magazine. The last time he worked for a publication, he was a Fordham undergraduate writing the ''Ramblings'' column for the weekly Ram.

title: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SOME G.O.P. SENATORS SEEK TO ALTER BUDGET DEAL
description: Several Senate Republicans said today that they wanted changes in the $52 billion deficit-reducing package agreed upon by the Senate Republican leadership and the White House.

title: Nordiques Take Series
description: Brent Ashton, capping a three-goalrally in the third period, scored unassisted with 1 minute 9 seconds left to give the Quebec Nordiques a 6-5 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight. Quebec took the playoff series, three games to two, and will meet Montreal in the Adams Division final starting in Montreal Thursday.

title: SPACE WALKERS RIG HANDMADE SNARES TO SAVE SATELLITE
description: Two space-walking astronauts successfully rigged handmade plastic and wire snares to the tip of a mechanical arm today, preparing for an ingenious attempt Wednesday to activate a dormant communication satellite.

title: JUSTICES GRANT C.I.A. WIDE DISCRETION ON SECRECY
description: The Supreme Court today gave the Central Intelligence Agency broad discretion to withhold the identities of its sources of intelligence information from public disclosure.

title: ATTACH STRINGS TO EMERGENCY RELIEF
description: George Bernard Shaw observed, ''All great truths begin as blasphemy.'' With this philosophy in mind, I put forth blasphemy: the United States should give no emergency food relief to countries that are unwilling to adopt long-term economic reforms and population control programs.

title: Girl Is Shot at a Playground
description: An 8-year-old girl on a playground slide was struck in the neck by a bullet yesterday evening in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Rodgers Speaks Out
description: Bill Rodgers says the 89th Boston Marathon proved that changes must be made to restore the tarnished reputation of the race. Rodgers, a four-time Boston winner who skipped this year's race to run in a more lucrative marathon in New Jersey next month, said that the Boston Marathon must follow the trend and offer cash prizes.

title: Pennwalt Pact With Key Investor
description: The Pennwalt Corporation said that it had reached an agreement with its largest shareholder, Philip F. Anschutz, an oilman, preventing him from either starting a takeover bid or transferring his 20 percent stake in the company to another investor for 10 years. Mr. Anschutz will immediately exchange the 2.8 million shares he wons through his Denver-based corporation for a new series of voting preference stock, said Lawrence J. Woodward, a spokesman for the drug and chemical company. In addition, Mr. Anschutz agreed to vote the new preference stock in accordance with the recommendations of Pennwalt's board.'' Pennwalt fell 50 cents to close at $38.25 on the New York Stock Exchange today, making Mr. Anschutz's holdings worth about $107 million.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
LATIN NATIONS' CAPITAL FLIGHT
description: THIS city, with the new buildings of scores of

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Heroism
description: Even for the nation's busiest firefighting force, this week has already been noteworthy.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
New Xerox Copier
description: The Xerox Corporation said it had introduced a small desktop copier, the 1025 Marathon, which operates at speeds of up to 21 copies a minute and can make copies as large as 11 by 17 inches with a stationary copying platen. The company said models with a moving platen require more space. It said the basic version of the machine would cost $2,595.

title: BUSINESSLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BRIEFING ;   Making Up
description: In some Washington circles, old

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: BRIGHAM YOUNG: American Moses. By

title: WEICKER AND EDUCATION CHIEF IN SHARP CLASH
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Education Secretary William J. Bennett clashed today over the appointment of an outspoken, conservative educator to Mr. Bennett's staff.

title: Brazil-U.S. Debt Pact
description: The Governments of Brazil and the United States reached an agreement to renegotiate $931 million in debts, an American Embassy spokesman said today. The new agreement calls for refinancing of 85 percent of the principal over 10 years, with a four- year grace period, and interest rates that vary from 3 percent to 12 percent. The remaining 15 percent of the principal and interest were divided into four payments.

title: KNAPE & VOGT MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about comments by Elie Wiesel on President Reagan's plan to visit a German military cemetery incorrectly described the Bitburg gravesite. The 2,800 German soldiers buried there are from World War I as well as the Nazi era.

title: STAGE: DOROTHY PARKER AND HER WIT RE-CREATED
description: -variety gadfly. She was an iconoclastic critic of her lessers and betters, and could not always distinguish one from the other. This was the writer who proudly boasted, ''Inseparable my nose and thumb.'' Depending on the point of view, she represented either a blaze of wit or the smoldering ashes of misanthropy and melancholy.

title: ITT Computer
description: The ITT Corporation said it had introduced a high-performance personal computer, the Xtra XP, that features processing speeds 3.5 times faster than those of the International Business Machines Corporation PC- XT. ITT said its model is compatible with the XT.

title: IN RICHMOND HILL, LATINS ARE LATEST IN MELTING POT
description: When Fanny and Eligio Meola bought a three-story brick house on a rutted dead- end street in Richmond Hill several years ago, their neighbors were wary of the Colombian newcomers and their four children.

title: Alcohol Rule Is Set for All Pilots
description: The Transportation Department today announced steps aimed at more stringent monitoring of potential alcohol or drug abuse among commercial and private pilots.

title: NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
College Graduates' Job Hunt
description: SPRING is here and so is that worrisome time for college seniors wondering where and if they will find a job after graduation.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on Saturday with an article about bonuses given top executives by the Detroit auto makers misstated part of the income of F. James McDonald, president of the General Motors Corporation. He received a bonus of $810,000, half in cash and half in stock, and did not exercise any stock options.

title: DOW CORNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company is a joint venture of Dow Chemcial Company and Corning Glass Works.

title: Ex-Georgia Aide in Prison
description: Former Labor Commissioner Sam Caldwell of Georgia will be assigned a job at the Atlanta Prison Camp, where he has begun serving a 30-month sentence for mail and insurance fraud, a prison spokesman said Monday. Mr. Caldwell, 56 years old, was convicted last fall of eight Federal charges.

title: FIRST BOSTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
AROUND THE NATION ;   Jet Carrying 89 Loses Engine but Lands Safely
description: An American Airlines Boeing 727 jetliner carrying 89 passengers and crew members lost an engine over Arizona today but landed safely in San Diego, officials said.

title: Smoke and Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: STERLING SOFTWARE CHIEF CALLS HIS BID 'FRIENDLY'
description: Samuel E. Wyly, chairman of Dallas-based Sterling Software Inc., does not see his $125 million offer to take over the Informatics General Corporation as a hostile proposal.

title: I.B.M. to Adopt A Rolm System
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would adopt its Rolm division's Phonemail system in place of a similar voice messaging system that I.B.M. developed.

title: CANADIENS ELIMINATE BRUINS
description: It ended here again for the Bruins, as it has so many times.

title: 4 Zoo Units Begun In Central Park
description: The renovation of the Central Park Zoo began this week. Excavation has started for four buildings to house polar bears, penguins, tropical animals and visitors' services.

title: PORT AUTHORITY TO EXPAND A SHIP TERMINAL ON S.I.
description: Under a plan worked out with the Koch administration, the Port Authority has agreed to spend $85.7 million to renovate and expand the largest port terminal in the metropolitan area, Howland Hook on Staten Island.

title: STAGE: 'GRIND,' FROM HAROLD PRINCE
description: FOR most of Act I, it is nearly impossible to figure out the real ambitions of ''Grind,'' the new musical that the director Harold Prince has brought to the Mark Hellinger. But as we discover when ''Grind'' grinds to its halt just before intermission, ignorance at this show is bliss. An enormous amount of show biz expertise, some of it striking and inventive, has been lavished on this gargantuan enterprise, and, as long as its creators' intentions remain cloudy, the sheer rush of imaginative activity churns up a strange air of mystery. We don't really know what's happening, but, for a while, there's so much to watch that we don't really care.

title: U S WEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Moulton Dance Benefit
description: There will be a gala benefit for the Charles Moulton Dance Company tonight at Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street.

title: NORTHWEST'S NEW-FOUND RICHES: ITS OWN FINE FOOD
description: THANKS to a new-found abundance of fresh local ingredients and the popularity of what is fast becoming a uniquely American style of cooking, the Northwest is now enjoying a food renaissance - and this lush green city is the focal point.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IT'S not easy to be a well-informed menopausal woman

title: Police Use 'Stun Gun' to Halt Suspect in Church Vandalism
description: The police used a new ''stun gun'' Monday evening to subdue a man who they said had ripped out 20 pews in a Brooklyn church and knocked over statues, a baptismal font and the altar tabernacle.

title: CORDURA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MRS. JOHN N. WHEELER
description: Elizabeth T. Wheeler, the widow of John N. Wheeler, a newspaper syndicate executive who retired as chairman of the North American Newspaper Alliance, died Monday at her apartment in Manhattan.

title: BEAUMONT CANDIDATE CHANGING POSTS IN CHICAGO
description: Gregory Mosher, who has been offered the position of artistic director of the Vivian Beaumont Theater, will step down as artistic director of the Goodman Theater in Chicago after its current season, it was announced yesterday. But Mr. Mosher meanwhile will become the artistic director of the New Theater Company, an offshoot of the Goodman that produces new American plays.

title: MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income, after a loss of $613,000 from discontinued operations.

title: FREDDIE MAC OFFERING 4 COLLATERALIZED SERIES
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation is offering nearly $1.04 billion of collateralized mortgage obligations, divided into four series, through various securities dealers. The obligations, known as C.M.O.'s, are secured by a pool of conventional home mortgages with an average interest rate of 12.9 percent that were purchased by the organization, commonly called Freddie Mac.

title: N.B.A. IS READY TO FIND SOME ANSWERS
description: Will the Boston Celtics become the first team in 16 seasons to repeat as champions? Can the Los Angeles Lakers stay hot? How good are the Milwaukee Bucks? Can the tired, injury-plagued Philadelphia 76ers rally?

title: MANUFACTURERS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BURROUGHS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $3,100,000 related to the restructuring of certain operations.

title: CARIBBENA FESTIVALS BRING OUT CALLALOO
Trading Heavy In Mohawk Stock
description: The Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation said it was continuing with its announced plan of divesting itself of certain divisions and could not account for the heavy trading of its stock yesterday. The stock closed unchanged at $4 on the New York Stock Exchange on a volume of 804,000 shares.

title: CHAPTER 11 PETITION FILED BY WHEELING
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, blaming the steelworkers union for the failure of negotiations to restructure the company, yesterday filed a petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. It is the largest bankruptcy filing in the steel industry's history.

title: Kings' Move Is Official The Kansas City Kings, who began as the Rochester Royals in 1948
description: Sacramento, Calif., yesterday in a unanimous vote by the National Basketball Association club owners. Despite the move, the Kings, who finished last in Midwest Division with a 31-51 record, will remain in that division with Denver, Houston, Dallas, San Antonio and Utah.

title: SCOUTING ;   Showcase Ruined
description: What better way, Mike Trainer figured, to show off his newest fighter, Shawn O'Sullivan, than to match him against someone who had just gone the distance with the celebrated Mark Breland?

title: HOW REGION VIEWS PLAN
description: The burst of diplomatic activity surrounding President Reagan's proposal on Nicaragua has obscured the fact that there has been little change in position either by the Administration or by Latin American governments. The President had been hoping to sell the new plan to Congress in part on the support it has garnered from Nicaragua's Central American neighbors. While that may be the case with Nicaragua's three closest neighbors - El Salvador, Honduras and Costa Rica, who are also Washington's staunchest allies in the region - it does not appear to extend much further.

title: MUSIC: ROCHBERG WORK BY NATIONAL ORCHESTRA
description: GEORGE ROCHBERG, like Stravinsky, has spent his career rummaging about the spare rooms of musical history in search of useful composition styles. Composers who do this and make no bones about it often come under attack from listeners for whom the appearance of originality is all that counts in art. However, most of the great music in any period is written by composers who bend stylistic conventions only slightly, making their big contributions within recognized boundaries.

title: Colleges Majoring in Scandal
description: Tulane is only the latest culprit in and victim of college sports scandals that now stretch back for a generation. Those ''campus'' sports have long been semi-pro, the minor leagues of the TV-fattened professional teams. Universities look to their teams to make them rich and famous, to impress legislators and alumni givers. Many are convinced that judgments even of their academic excellence tend to be made on their sports performance.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;

title: Dominican Envoy Named
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Lowell C. Kilday, a veteran of 28 years in the Foreign Service, as Ambassador to the Dominican Republic. He would succeed Robert Anderson. Mr. Kilday, 54 years old, has been a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State since 1983.

Topics ;   Evolutions ;   Darwin in Traffic A driver friend caught up for half an hour in the long roundabout detour from the George Washington Bridge to the Henry Hudson Parkway was devising a formula to measure the cost of the holdup: Length of detour . . . divided by length of car . . . equals number of cars caught . . . times average hourly pay of drivers . . . divided by two - when he was distracted by some irrelevant facts. In all the time of crawl and stop, he had not heard a single horn blow nor seen a single bumper bumped. The drivers sat stolidly, lifting hand from wheel only to wave an abutting car to pass them into a lane merger.
description: Our friend was wondering if this was good manners or just dumb despair when, approaching the 57th Street exit, he ran into another jam. It was briefer but long enough for him to watch a small hawk - a kestrel, he guessed, from its reddish tail and quivering wings - hovering over the Hudson shore, waiting a full three or four minutes before diving into a patch of reeds, maybe after a mouse.

description: THE city's spring social swing got under way Monday night as 1,500 guests stepped out for a dance at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This mid-April gala is considered the unofficial opening of the spring party season, which is brief - it will last through May - but intense.

title: 11 OPERA-AUDITION FINALISTS IN CONCERT AT THE MET
description: THE Metropolitan Opera National Council no longer names winners for its celebrated annual auditions; instead, each finalist wins $5,000, and they all gather for a friendly concert of arias and ensembles at the Met. But if audience response could have awarded a first prize Sunday afternoon, it would have gone to Julia Faulkner, 27 years old, of Ames, Iowa, and she would have deserved it.

title: 'SIMON BOCCANEGRA,' BY VERDI, ON CHANNEL 13
description: AS many viewers have pointed out with unflagging persistence, ''Live From the Met'' is, for the most part, not live. The repeat broadcasts are certainly not, and even some of the ''premieres'' aren't. Take this evening's broadcast, for instance, being carried on WNET/Channel 13 at 8:30 o'clock. It looks live and, simulcast in stereo over WQXR-FM, it will certainly sound live, but in fact it was, as is explained by an announcer, taped last Dec. 29 at a matinee performance.A different title for the broadcasts would clearly be in order but, admittedly, ''Live on Tape From the Met'' isn't one of the catchier candidates.

The victims and the butchers of Nazism are not equatable.

Nova Park Ruling

Mr. Hatt's largest creditor, Credit Suisse, had argued that Nova owed it 63 million Swiss francs, or about $25 million, in interest on the mortgage for the Zurich Nova Park hotel. Nova's troubles started when Mr. Hatt bought the Elysee hotel in Paris and the exclusive Gotham Hotel in New York. Barry I. Fredericks, a New York attorney for Mr. Hatt, said the court's decision would not affect Mr. Hatt's attempts to regain control of the Gotham from lenders.

title: No Headline

title: ADVERTISING ;   Slogan for WNEW

The ''best'' are the likes of Frank Sinatra and Louis Armstrong, who show up in the commercials, as do such station personalities as Ted Brown and Alison Steele, and George Shearing, who has a live Sunday night show. Sex, Marriage and South Africa

Doing so won't placate blacks demanding political rights, but voiding the Mixed Marriage Act means striking at the legal foundations of apartheid, exposing the system's cruel absurdities. Since American pressure has helped bring about this welcome step, that argues for more of the same.

title: NEW BUILT-IN DESIGNS DO MORE THAN ADD SPACE
description: -dwellers built-in furniture is the solution to the perennial storage problem: an efficient way to organize household goods in a small space. Until recently built-ins have generally been styled flush with the walls, with hidden handles and narrow joints, hardly distinguishable from the surrounding surfaces. As designers move away from flush surfaces and a minimalist look, however, they are discovering - or rediscovering - that built-ins also offer many design opportunities. More flexible than architecture, more permanent and substantial than movable furniture, they are not just service pieces, but can be among the primary design features of an apartment.

HERS
description: -North Carolina border there is - if it still exists - a structure that looks, when one happens on it from the road, like a miniature golf course for child-size cave dwellers. Up close it's a miniature world. Built of stone and mortar and called Shangri-La, it covers perhaps a half-acre: cobbled sidewalks, buildings residential and commercial, schools, post offices, even the Shangri-La jail. Signs exhort the traveler to rest his weary feet, and yet, enchanted as we were to discover it, my husband and I didn't stay long enough to find out whose kingdom it was. Though neither of us would admit it, I think we were slightly uneasy: if we lingered a moment too long, we might never leave.

description: b-Includes a capital gain of $552,000. c-Includes a capital gain of $2,196,000.

title: Electronics Activity
description: Consumer electronics, including foreign manufacturers, contributes more than $40 billion a year and nearly 1.5 million jobs to the American economy, a trade group said today. The figures are from a report prepared by Arthur D. Little Inc. for the Electronic Industries Association, which opposes import quotas.

title: HBO'S 'WHAT SEX AM I?'
description: ''WHAT SEX AM I?'' looks sympathetically at transsexuals and transvestites, exploring the meaning of gender. How is it defined? The Home Box Office documentary, neither salacious nor exploitative, finds ambiguities. It suggests that gender is, and probably should be, beyond definition. The documentary will be seen on HBO at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: COSMOS PAY $19,223 IN FINES
description: With the North American Soccer League in hibernation for at least a year, the Cosmos appeared yesterday to have cleared the last obstacle to plans for a series of international exhibition games at Giants Stadium this summer.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: CEILINGS that are full of bumps, cracks and old patches, or keep peeling and flaking no matter how often they are painted, are an irritating and unsightly problem in many older homes and apartments. Sometimes the problem can be solved by thoroughly scraping off all the old paint and starting from scratch. But often the problem seems to be insoluble.

title: WAR IS PEACE
description: BOSTON Corruption of the language was

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS INCOME UP
description: The American Express Company reported a 30.5 percent increase in first-quarter earnings, reflecting an improved performance from its Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. subsidiary and a narrowing of losses in its cable television business.

title: LEGISLATORS BACK BERKELEY PROTEST ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: California legislators told about 5,000 demonstrators at the University of California today that they would put pressure on the school to give up its investments in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: HERITAGE BANCORP - N J reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Queens String Quartet In Professional Debut
description: The Queens String Quartet, which made its professional debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday afternoon, is a promising young ensemble, but much work remains to be done. The four members of the group - violinists Jule Supplee and Lisa Pitton, the violist Deborah Judd and the cellist Deborah Assael - play with intelligence, an admirable collegiality and obvious love for the music they have chosen.

title: Medgar Evers Has Turned the Corner
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA DEBATES AIRLINE PROPOSAL
description: Contending that Atlantans pay some of the nation's highest air fares, a Denver-based airline proposed two months ago that it move here and use a county-run airport to operate daily, low-cost flights to six cities in the United States.

title: CLEVEPAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes nonrecurring gains of $510,000, of which $290,000 resulted from a change in the company's policies governing vacation pay entitlements for its salaried employees. c-After a loss of $1,692,000 from discontinued operations. There were no share earnings for the year-ago quarter after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Cox Financing
description: Cox Enterprises Inc., the publisher based here, plans to finance its proposed acquisition of Cox Communications Inc., the broadcast company, by borrowing up to $1.8 billion from a banking consortium headed by the Texas Commerce Bank of Houston, according to a document sent to Cox Communications shareholders. The loan would also finance a restructuring of the broadcast company's $241.5 million in existing debt. Cox Enterprises, a privately held company, has offered $75 a share for the 59 percent of Cox Communications stock not now owned by Cox Enterprises or members of the Cox family.

title: MURCER STIRS UP COMEBACK HOPES
description: He refused to call it a comeback, but a once-popular Yankee who since his retirement has been a broadcaster and a front-office executive will play again this weekend - and not in an old-timers' game. After that, who knows where baseball will take Bobby Murcer.

title: SCOUTING ;   He Calls Them As He Sees Them
description: At least one Islander employee who deserves credit for outstanding work during the playoff series with the Washington Capitals wasn't on the ice. Behind the microphone for the telecasts, Ed Westfall gave five games' worth of lessons in how to be a home team's broadcaster without being a homer.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Is Everyone O.K.?
description: ''People are trying to make differences in their lives, to reduce stress and be healthier,'' said Barbara Rose, a nursing student at the Hospital for Special Surgery.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington on Tuesday about leadership changes in the environmental movement incorrectly described the Government service of Douglas P. Wheeler, the new head of the Sierra Club. He was a Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Interior in the Nixon and Ford Administrations.

title: NICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want to apologize to you, brothers, for what has happened, and to you and to Beirut I tender the resignation of the national unity Cabinet.'' - Prime Minister Rashid Karami, of Lebanon. (A6:4.)

title: Sony to Import Its Own Tubes
description: The Sony Corporation has responded to Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's appeal to buy more foreign goods by ageeing to import a known quantity from America: Sony picture tubes.

title: WEICKER QUERIES OFFICIAL'S VIEWS ON DISABLED
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the father of a handicapped child, today confronted an Education Department aide who contended that education programs for the handicapped were ''selfish'' and ''misguided.''

title: COURT CURBS FEES FOR RIGHTS CASES
description: The Supreme Court today limited the ability of successful civil rights plaintiffs to recover all their lawyers' fees from the losing side. The Court ruled 8 to 0 that fees may generally not be recovered for time the lawyers spend in administrative proceedings before the dispute takes the form of an actual lawsuit.

title: SAVINGS BANK OF PUGET SOUND reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter net was increased by $259,000 from the sale of preferred stock received as an extraordinary dividend from the Federal Home Loan Bank of Seattle.

title: BANK VIEW BY VOLCKER
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, urged Congress today to pass broad new banking legislation that would close the limited-service bank loophole, expand the powers of commercial banks and limit entry of thrift institutions into commercial banking activities.

title: DNA FRAGMENTS EXTRACTED FROM MUMMY INFANT ARE REPORTED ALMOST UNDAMAGED
description: Fragments of DNA extracted from the ancient mummified body of an Egyptian infant showed remarkably little or no damage in the last 2,400 years, a Swedish scientist reported yesterday. He said the lack of damage would allow scientists to grow duplicates of the genetic material in the laboratory.

title: GREENERY: TOO MUCH OF A GOOD THING?
description: WHEN foundation plantings have grown too tall and too thick, when the houses' front windows are obscured by a screen of twigs and leaves, it is time to take action. Homes surrounded by overgrown greenery are common sights in many communities.

title: Sprinkel Wins Confirmation
description: Beryl W. Sprinkel was confirmed by the Senate today to be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Bonanno Sought As Witness in Trial
description: Federal prosecutors plan to call Joseph Bonanno Sr., the reputed founder of the Bonanno crime organization, as a Government witness in a trial of several men charged with operating a ruling ''commission'' of organized crime.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alta Technology Inc., a Stamford, Conn., supplier of automated fare collection systems, has elected Pierre Lereboullett president.

title: A. T. & T. PLANS A 5.6% PRICE CUT FOR LONG-DISTANCE SERVICE JUNE 1
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it planned to reduce the price of its long-distance telephone service by 5.6 percent on June 1.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PATRIOT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
On Housework
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: PLAYERS SEEK TIME TO STUDY FINANCES
description: Baseball's dragging labor negotiations were slowed even more significantly yesterday when the players' negotiators said talks could possibly be suspended until June, saying they needed time to study the clubs' financial information and discuss it with all 650 major league players. At the same time, they will take a strike-authorization vote.

title: THE DANCE: 'REAL MCCOY'
description: ''THE REAL McCOY'' would surely have delighted the heroine of Woody Allen's ''Purple Rose of Cairo,'' had she gone to the ballet instead of the movies. Indeed, Eliot Feld's ballet to pieces by Gershwin often resembles a movie, for it is an anthology of images associated with Hollywood and Broadway musicals of the 1930's.

title: Let Him Walk Among the Graves of the Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVERTISING ;   Wilderness Publication Begins Accepting Ads
description: The quarterly publication of the Washington-based Wilderness Society is emerging from the wilderness of adless media to join the crass majority group.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $600,000 for the latest quarter and $1.1 million for the year- earlier period. The year-ago quarter net from continuing operations includes a DISC tax benefit of $8 million, or 26 cents a share.

title: QUOTRON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DROUGHT EMERGENCY DECLARED TO RESTRICT WATER USE IN JERSEY
description: With water levels for this time of year at a 50-year low, Governor Kean today declared a drought emergency, restricting water use in much of northeastern New Jersey.

title: The Philosopher and the Handicapped
description: Whether or not sensitivity ought to be a prerequisite for a position in the Cabinet, it's undeniably an asset. William J. Bennett, who became Education Secretary in February, shows a stunning lack of it by choosing Dr. Eileen Marie Gardner as his special assistant on educational philosophy.

title: POPE & TALBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DISPLAY ON THE RUN: FREELANCERS MAKE WINDOWS A STAGE
description: IT is late on a Friday evening.

Debt Issues
description: Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day commercial paper Tuesday at an average rate of 8.407 percent, down from 8.625 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 8.429 percent, down from 8.871 percent.

title: CALUMET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said share earnings reflect the dilution from the exercise of outstanding warrants and options.

title: Now, 'Smart' Credit Cards
description: CREDIT cards used to be simple. First, there was just the plain, plastic card, embossed with a number. Then came the magnetic strip, three tracks of encoded data that identify the cardholder, speed credit approvals and make it possible to get cash from a teller machine.

title: LEICHTER ENTERS PRIMARY RACE FOR CITY COMPTROLLER
description: State Senator Franz S. Leichter of Manhattan announced his candidacy for City Comptroller yesterday, saying he would make the integrity of the three-term incumbent, Harrison J. Goldin, the major issue of the race.

title: SMITTY KNOWS THE COST
description: On Wednesday the goalie woke up early. He had only had a few hours of sleep, but Billy Smith was eager to see his children and begin the cycle of the next playoff series.

title: CAVALIERS DEVELOP FROM SLOW START
description: A favorite pastime of visiting players and reporters during the last few years was attempting to count the crowds at Cleveland Cavalier games. The Coliseum, in Richfield, Ohio, has a capacity of 19,548 seats, but the crowds were usually in the low thousands.

title: Birth Control Focus of Drive
description: A national campaign to reduce black teen-age pregnancy that focuses on the responsibility of young black men was announced yesterday by the National Urban League.

title: BUCYRUS-ERIE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REAGAN MEETS ALGERIAN PRESIDENT
description: President Reagan and the President of Algeria today discussed at length various proposals for bringing Palestinians into expanded Middle East peace talks with Israel, a high-ranking Administration official said.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $65,000. c-Net loss.

DRUG ABUSERS TRY TO CUT AIDS RISK
description: Intravenous drug users, who make up the second-largest group of victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, are beginning to try to take precautions to avoid the deadly disease, a New York health official said here today.

title: RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U. S. DENIES DISTORTION
description: The White House denied today that the Reagan Administration had misrepresented the views of several Latin American leaders on President Reagan's Nicaragua initiative.

description: The net income for the latest quarter reflects revised depreciation rates effective Jan. 1, 1985, which reduced net income by $47 million, or 5 cents a share.

title: Top Farming County
description: Fresno County remained the nation's No. 1 farming county last year by producing commodities worth $1.9 billion, up 11 percent from 1983, Cosmo Insalaco, California's Agricultural Commissioner, said today. He cited increased cotton acreage and a rising demand for vegetables.

title: ADVERTISING ;   A Warning on TV
description: Right on top of the news, Marcella Rosen, senior vice president and media honcho at N.W. Ayer, warned broadcasters in a speech earlier this week that they would be playing right into the hands of corporate takeover artists if they fuel the fires of viewer dissatisfation by further embracing 15-second commercials or split 30's. ''This hot new tactic may save advertisers' money at a time when the cost of network TV time has accelerated at an alarming rate,'' she said, ''but the resulting clutter, as research has shown, may not be worth the short- term savings.''

title: 53 IN SENATE ASK REAGAN TO CANCEL CEMETARY VISIT
description: Protests against President Reagan's planned visit to a German military cemetery spread today as a majority of the Senate sent a letter ''strongly urging'' him to cancel the visit.

title: LATEST HEART RECIPIENT'S BLEEDING HAS ALMOST STOPPED, DOCTOR SAYS
description: The problems encountered by the latest artificial heart patient and his predecessors are part of the ''trial and error'' process of ''human experimentation,'' Dr. William C. DeVries, the heart surgeon, said today.

title: WESTAMERICA BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PIEDMONT AVIATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
USAIR POSTS 45.9% DROP
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, yesterday reported a slight decrease in earnings in the first quarter, to $60.2 million, or $1.12 a share, from $60.3 million, or $1.13 a share, in the first quarter last year. Revenues rose 9.4 percent, to $1.39 billion, from $1.27 billion.

title: Copters and 225 Officers Hunt Fugitive in Ozarks
description: Four National Guard helicopters and 225 officers focused on a quarry in the Ozark wilderness today in their pursuit of a white supremacist wanted in the slaying of a state trooper.

title: FIRST WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $366,000 on the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Dow Advances by 2.76, to 1,272.31
description: The stock market notched its seventh gain in a row yesterday but remained suspended between the positive push of falling interest rates and the negative pull of economic doubts and weak corporation earnings.

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUNK BEDS MADE SAFER BY TAKING PRECAUTIONS
description: Most children love bunk beds, and for parents they are often a needed space saver, but the Consumer Product Safety Commission reports that consumers should be aware of dangers associated with some of the beds.

title: Connecticut Museum Names Next Director
description: The Hill-Stead Museum in Farmington, Conn., yesterday named Katherine Warwick, an official of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, as its next director.

description: b-After tax provisions of $51,400,000. c-After tax provisions of $5,500,000.

Fatigue May Bother Islanders
description: On the Islander bench in the final minutes of Tuesday night's game, no one could be seen smiling. A trainer massaged a player's neck with a towel. Bob Nystrom watched the game with his elbows on the railing. The coach, Al Arbour, looked solemn, as usual.

title: WYMAN-GORDON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ZIONS UTAH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NCR Amendment
description: The NCR Corporation said its shareholders had approved an anti- greenmail charter amendment that gives the company's shareholders the sole right to approve the purchase of shares at above market value from any shareholder owning 2 percent or more of the company's common stock. Under greenmail, an investor tries to force a company to repurchase its shares at a premium.

title: Uncle Bonsai, Folk-Pop Trio
description: Uncle Bonsai, a folk-pop trio from Seattle, performs funny original songs whose exquisite musical detail and subtle needling wit attain a level of craft not often seen in pop.

title: SKIER IS IN CHARGE OF HIS LIFE
description: Nearly two decades ago, sometime between the day he won a bronze medal for the United States in the Olympic slalom at Innsbruck, Austria, in 1964 and his eighth- place finish at Grenoble, France, in 1968, something happened to Jimmie Heuga. He sensed a problem with his vision. The sense of coordination that had helped him reach the elite level of competitive skiing was not the same. He experienced numbness. For about three years - including the final part of his competitive career - he looked for answers. When he finally found one, it was difficult to understand.

title: MEESE IS DISPUTED ON DRIVE ON DRUGS
description: Attorney General Edwin L. Meese 3d was confronted with bipartisan disbelief today at his assertion before a Senate subcommittee that the Government was ''winning the war against drugs.''

description: President Reagan named 11 individuals and one company today as the first recipients of the new National Medal of Arts for their contribution to American culture.

title: Florida Pest Outbreak Listed as Emergency
description: Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block said today that an outbreak of Mediterranean fruit flies in Florida constituted an emergency warranting the use of Federal money and personnel.

description: The company is a majority-owned unit of Sharon Steel Corp. and is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

description: Two unions announced today that they were ending their 18-month strike against Continental Airlines, saying the walkout ''was no longer effective.''

description: Some fallout from the New Orleans musical ''One Mo' Time,'' which ran successfully at the Village Gate for several years and is still on tour, has arrived at Michael's Pub in the persons of Orange Kellin, Lars Edegran and Thais Clark, who played and sang in the show and who bring with them some more New Orleans jazz and songs of the 1920's.

title: MUCH FLUX IN THE DEMOCRATIC FIRMAMENT
description: The rising stars of Democratic politics have begun to twinkle, but so far they have not been the source of political light some Democrats had hoped for as the party struggles to alter its course.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about testing problems at companies selling semiconductors to the military misidentified one such company. It was the Fairchild division of Schlumberger Ltd.

title: RADAR BLIP HELPS LOCATE ENGINE LOST BY JET
description: A passenger aboard an American Airlines jet carrying 90 people said ''I thought I was dead'' after one of three engines fell off over New Mexico Tuesday.

description: b-Year ago figures were not stated because financial statements for the company, which went public in June 1984, were kept on a cumulative basis.

title: CUBS SEND PHILS TO WORST START SINCE '38
description: Keith Moreland made up for three errors with a three-run seventh-inning double that gave the Chicago Cubs a 5-4 victory today over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: SPRING AND THE TASTE BUDS STIR
description: Never mind the cherry blossoms. Forget those glorious splashes of azaleas, tulips and daffodils. The most delectable signs that spring has arrived in Washington are the soft winds wafting in from the Chesapeake Bay.

title: CHARGES OF RACISM CAUSE TEXAS PAPER TO CANCEL COLUMN
description: The Dallas Times Herald is dropping one of its most popular features, a satirical column called ''Joe Bob Goes to the Drive- In,'' after a spoof on an African famine relief effort prompted heated charges of racism.

title: Israel and Egypt Plan Talks; First Since Sadat and Begin
description: Egyptian and Israeli officials are drafting plans for the countries' first talks since Anwar el-Sadat met with Menachem Begin, Israeli officials in Cairo and Jerusalem said today.

title: DANCE: A NEW WORK BY PAUL TAYLOR
description: THE figures onstage in Paul Taylor's ''Last Look'' suffer from a severe case of burnout. As far as Mr. Taylor's decline-of-civilization pieces go, this one is first-rate - an amazing expenditure of energy to depict, ironically, an enervated world.

title: Pakistan City Patrolled As Rioting Continues
description: The authorities imposed a 24-hour curfew on this riot-torn city of seven million people today.

title: Showboats' Blitz Will Test Flutie
description: Doug Flutie, the Generals' rookie quarterback who has earned passing grades if not high honors in his first professional season, faces another test Friday night in Memphis, the test of the blitz.

title: 13 Cubans Win Reprieve
description: A Federal judge has stopped the deportation of 13 Cuban refugees who came to the United States in boats in 1980, ruling that the Government had not proved them dangerous criminals. The 13 were among 33 scheduled to leave this week. District Judge Charles A. Moye Jr.'s ruling Tuesday did not prevent expulsion of other Cubans.

title: PULITZER PRIZE BOARD REFUSES TO RESCIND ITS ENTRY FEES
description: The Pulitzer Prize Board has turned down a request from two writers' organizations that it rescind its $20 entry fee on books submitted for consideration by its judges. Spokesmen for both groups, the National Writers Union and the Authors Guild, contend that the fees discriminate against smaller publishers.

title: SCOUTING ;   Morning After
description: Perhaps the most striking moment of Tuesday night's telecast over Channel 9 came not during the Islander-Washington game itself but immediately afterward, as the camera panned slowly, and with close-ups, among a Capital Centre crowd that seemed disbelieving. No team in the National Hockey League had ever lost a series of five games after winning the first two, and the tears on a number of faces were evidence of the pain that accompanied the making of this little bit of playoff history.

title: BRIEFING ;   Want an Ambulance?
description: A group of veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade feel the bell tolls for them, in Nicaragua.

description: A Greene County grand jury indicted Alex J. Mengel today for second-degree murder in the death seven weeks ago of a Mount Vernon woman whose car he purportedly stole while fleeing from another crime.

description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission told a House subcommittee today that the agency would cut research deeply and reduce some safety inspections because of constraints in its 1986 budget request.

title: Oscar Nemon, 79, Sculptor Of 50 Likenesses of Churchill
description: Oscar Nemon, the Yugoslav-born sculptor who made more than 50 likenesses of Sir Winston Churchill, died Sunday in the John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford, according to his wife, Patricia Nemon- Stuart.

title: Xerox Announces Development Plan
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday proposed a $8 billion to $10 billion dollar development on 2,267 acres it owns near Leesburg, Va., about 30 miles northwest of Washington, D.C. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., said that its unit, the Xerox Realty Corporation, had begun discussions with local government officials about the mixed-use development, which would include corporate offices, residential units, a conference center, hotels and recreational facilities. But, Thomas Abbott, a company spokesman, last night said no definite plans had been reached.

title: Editors Elect Officers
description: Members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors have elected Robert P. Clark president for 1985-86. He is vice president for news for Harte- Hanks Newspapers in San Antonio, Tex. Three other officers were also elected at the editors' meeting in Washington last week: Michael G. Gartner, editorial chairman of The Des Moines Register, vice president; Katherine Fanning, editor of The Christian Science Monitor, secretary, and Edward R. Cony, vice president for news of The Wall Street Journal, treasurer.

title: CHAUVINISM IN DANCE CRITICISM CAN BE A MISSTEP
description: OH, how dismal was this dance group and how dreary were its works and ways. Thus did an acquaintance rail against a visiting European company. Although I thought she overstated her case, I also thought she had a right to her opinion. Then I discovered she hadn't actually seen all the productions she was scorning. She simply assumed the company couldn't be any good.

description: b-After a loss of $5,200,000 from discontinued operations.

PROCTER & GAMBLE FIGHTS SATAN STORY
description: LEAFLETS charging that the Procter & Gamble Company is an agent of Satan have recently surfaced throughout the New York metropolitan area and the company is starting a campaign to counteract the rumors. Among other things, the leaflets say that the company's logo represents the Devil and the company's profits are used to support the worship of Satan.

Malone Leads 76ers In Playoff Opener
description: Moses Malone scored 26 points and Maurice Cheeks led a defensive effort in the last four minutes tonight that lifted the Philadelphia 76ers to a 104- 97 victory over the Washington Bullets in the opening game of the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: BRIEFS
description: Allied Bancshares Inc. , Houston, said it had formed an affiliate to originate home and other real estate mortgages as part of its emphasis on fee services activiites.

COLLEGES FACING TOUGHER PENALTIES
description: Schools that repeatedly break National Collegiate Athletic Association rules would face severe mandatory penalties - including suspension of competition for as many as two years - under a series of proposals approved today by the N.C.A.A. Council.

title: Woman Killed and Girl Hurt As a Car and a Train Collide
description: A Connecticut woman was killed and her daughter was injured when their car collided with an Amtrak passenger train last night at a railroad crossing in Windsor, Conn., the police said.

title: SCOUTING ;   Feeling Sorry
description: Manager John McNamara of the Boston Red Sox assesses a duel in which Roger Clemens's four-hitter came out second-best to a three-hitter by Kansas City's Danny Jackson: ''It's too bad there had to be a loser, especially since it was our guy.''

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GORBACHEV TAKES TOUR OF MOSCOW
description: Taking a leaf from Yuri V. Andropov's book, Mikhail S. Gorbachev went to the people today, touring a factory, a hospital, a school and even popping into a private home.

title: Pillsbury Issue
description: The Pillsbury Company is offering $100 million of 11 1/2 percent notes, due in 1995, at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The notes are not callable for seven years. They are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P.

title: BANKNORTH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U. S. POWER IN ASIA HAS GROWN SINCE VIETNAM
description: Ten years after the defeat of South Vietnam, there is widespread agreement among policy analysts that the position of the United States in Asia is stronger now than at any time since the end of World War II. In April 1975, it was in shambles.

title: T. W. A. Cuts Loss; Lockheed Up 23.5%
description: Trans World Airlines, benefiting from an extraordinary gain, yesterday reported a smaller loss in the first quarter.

title: CANADIENS BEATEN IN OVERTIME, 2-1
description: Mark Kumpel scored at 12 minutes 23 seconds of overtime to give the Quebec Nordiques to a 2-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens in the opening game of the four-of-seven-game Adams Division final tonight.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians , at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Phil Niekro, today's starter, beat the Indians last Sunday, giving up five hits in seven and two- thirds innings and striking out nine with his knuckler. The Indians are digging a deep, early hole for themselves in the American League East with a 2-6 mark.(Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 8 P.M.).

title: V. A. Mortgage Rate Trimmed
description: The Government said today that it was lowering the maximum interest rate on federally backed Veterans Administration mortgages for single- family homes to 12.5 percent, from 13 percent.

title: MINE TRAPPED FOR 37 HOURS IN A CAVE-IN IS SAVED
description: A coal miner trapped for 37 hours after a mine cave-in walked out unhurt today after rescuers, inching through sliding rubble, rebuilt a tunnel to reach him.

title: BRIEFING ;   All the Ink You Can Drink
description: Up in the National Press Club Ballroom tonight, Washington Independent Writers, a 10- year-old group of 2,000 freelancers, plans to hold an auction for the benefit of its Legal and Educational Fund. The following is only a sample of all the neat (tax-deductible) stuff that will be sold to help finance the writers' rights fund: A year of monthly manicures at a salon of Robin Weir, one of Nancy Reagan's hairdressers; a chamber music concert in your home; a paw- marked copy of ''C. Fred's Life,'' an autobiographical effort by Vice President Bush's dog; five hours in a chauffeured limousine ''with champagne;'' a ''mention'' in The Washington Times gossip column written by Diana McClellan; lunch with Chuck Conconi, author of a Washington Post personality column (no mention guaranteed).

title: UGI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,469,000.

title: PIANO RECITAL BOUBOULIDI IN BEETHOVEN
description: TO play the 32 Beethoven sonatas - as Rita Bouboulidi will do in seven recitals at the Greenwich House, at 27 Barrow Street - requires an even and steadfast kind of stamina. Judging by the first of this series Wednesday night, Miss Bouboulidi has chosen a middle course through these difficult pieces - one which lies somewhere between committed passion and objectivity.

title: Air Controller Mix-Up Caused Near Collision
description: Conflicting instructions from side-by- side air traffic controllers nearly caused two jumbo jets to collide on a Minneapolis airport runway March 31, an investigation into the incident disclosed Wednesday.

title: YANKEES TOP WHITE SOX FOR 4TH STRAIGHT
description: If the Three Stooges and the Marx Brothers had put on baseball uniforms and staged a base-running clinic, they would probably have resembled the Chicago White Sox team that lost a 3-2 game to the Yankees yesterday.

title: JUST ANOTHER STORY FOR CBS, CNN
description: Ted Turner's hostile takeover bid for CBS Inc. has placed two of the nation's most prominent television news organizations in the unusual and potentially awkward position of having to turn their cameras on themselves.

title: Inquiry on Storage
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, which filed in October for protection from its creditors under the Federal bankruptcy laws, said yesterday that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission to determine whether the company had violated ''generally accepted accounting principles.'' The company, based in Louisville, Colo., is a leading maker of data storage devices for large computers.

title: U. S., CITING VIOLATIONS, PLANS TO DENY $22 MILLION FOR OLD WILLOWBROOK SITE
description: The Federal Government said yesterday that it was planning to deny nearly $22 million in Medicaid funds to a state center on Staten Island for the retarded and disabled on the ground that the center, formerly known as Willowbrook, had violated many Federal health and safety standards.

title: AVON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Air Force Plane Crashes In Honduras With 2 on Board
description: A United States Air Force OA- 37 training jet crashed today in northern Honduras with two crew members on board, the American Embassy said.

title: AMR Ratings
description: The long-term debt and preferred stock ratings of the AMR Corporation and its major subsidiary, American Airlines, are under review for possible upgrading, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday. Moody's said higher credit ratings could be warranted by improvement in the company's financial condition and competitive position in the airline industry.

title: VENETIAN OLD MASTERS AT THE DRAWING CENTER
description: THOUGH not yet 10 years old, the nonprofit Drawing Center at 137 Greene Street in SoHo has several times brought major exhibitions of Old Master drawings from Europe. In this way, it has made a distinctive contribution to a section of New York that, though flavorful to an almost unmanageable degree, is not usually associated with the art of the European Old Masters. How the center gets to have those exhibitions is the secret of Martha Beck, its director, and of her unusually efficacious supporters. All that can be divulged here is that they have done it again with the show of ''Drawings From Venice: Masterworks From the Museo Correr,'' which can be seen there through July 27.

description: b-Includes a gain of $6,700,000, or 22 cents a share, from the settlement of litigation, a charge of $5,100,000 for a plant writedown, and a charge of $1,700,000 for the consolidation of manufacturing facilities.

title: WHY ARE ALL THE POLITICIANS WATCHING ROCK VIDEO?
description: In eager pursuit of the youth vote, some political analysts are looking beyond their polling data and demographic statistics and turning to a less orthodox source of guidance.

title: London Baroque
description: London Baroque, a five-member British ensemble being presented by Music Before 1800, will make its New York debut in a program of Handel, Vivaldi, Bach and Scarlatti at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street (666-0675), on Sunday afternoon at 3. Tickets are $7, $5 for students and senior citizens.

title: Concessions on Conrail Sale
description: The Reagan Administration agreed today to deny to the Norfolk Southern Corporation a large part of the potential tax benefits that Norfolk Southern might realize if Congress approves its proposed purchase of Conrail.

THE TALK OF BEFORD-STUYVESANT;

IN BROOKLYN'S BEDFORD-STUYVESANT, GLIMMERS OF RESURGENCE ARE VISIBLE
description: Sometimes it seems there is no Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn, not the way there is a Greenwich Village in Manhattan or a Middle Village in Queens.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Yale to Receive Weapons Of Kent State Shooting
description: Some weapons from the shooting of antiwar protesters at Kent State University on May 4, 1970, should be turned over to Yale University and the Ohio Historical Society, a Federal district judge has ruled.
