title: Salute to Israel Parade
description: Thousands of marchers will take part in the 21st Salute to Israel Parade on Sunday, beginning at noon at Fifth Avenue and 75th Street. The parade marks the 37th anniversary of Israeli independence and will feature floats, posters and marching bands. Fifty bands are expected to take part in an annual competition, with the winner leading next year's parade.

title: W. P. P. S. S. Suit Settlement Shown
description: The Bonneville Power Administration said that under its proposed settlement of a lawsuit that arose from the mothballing of a Washington Public Power Supply System nuclear project, it would provide power to some private utilities for about 35 years.

title: REAGAN LIKENS NAZI WAR DEAD TO CONCENTRATION CAMP VICTIMS
description: President Reagan, standing by his decision to lay a wreath at a German military cemetery next month, said today that most of the soldiers buried there were as much victims of the Nazis as the inmates of the concentration camps.

title: MULTIBANK FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share figures have been adjusted to reflect the 50 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 7, 1985.

title: GORBACHEV'S HARDBALL WITH A SOFT TOUCH
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev does not need to be a super- statesman - though he may yet turn out to be one - to improve the conduct of Soviet foreign policy. For some 10 years, the Politburo could be relied upon to act in a clumsy and inept way that made most American administrations look good by default. From now on, this is unlikely to be true. There is, however, nothing to indicate that any superficial warming of relations will in the end lead to a genuine thaw.

title: STAGE: 'PENN & TELLER'
description: PENN JILLETTE is a tall, bespectacled fellow who looks and sounds like an untenured English instructor driven slightly goofy by too many nights spent grading student term papers. His much shorter partner, known only as Teller, is a gloomy- faced imp who never speaks. In their gray, Brooks Brothers-style suits, neither man is particularly prepossessing, and neither much fits the conventional image of an entertainer. But entertainers they are, and the little show they've brought to the Westside Arts Theater is one of the season's most original infusions of fun.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;   Future in Doubt
description: Joseph Rietano, who resigned as the Sacred Heart College baseball coach after being fined $2,000 for his part in a sports betting operation, said he was looking for another coaching job but not having much luck. ''It doesn't look too promising,'' he said.

title: TRIVIA AND FIRST LADIES
description: For trivia lovers, here is a quiz excerpted from Anthony S. Pitch's book, ''Exclusively First Ladies Trivia,'' published by Mino Publications of Washington:

Supporter of Gandhi Wounded in Punjab

INVESTORS BALK AT UNOCAL BID
description: Major institutional shareholders of the Unocal Corporation have reacted negatively to the oil company's defensive maneuver to avoid a takeover by T. Boone Pickens. Several of them said yesterday that they would probably tender their shares to the investor group led by Mr. Pickens rather than pledge them to Unocal in an offer that may never be activated.

title: JERSEYANS CRITICIZE PLAN TO BURN WASTES AT SEA
description: New Jersey officials and members of environmental groups today criticized the Federal Government's proposal for burning liquid toxic wastes at sea. They warned that the process had not been proven environmentally safe and that accidents, either on shore or aboard ship, could contaminate the ocean and irreversibly damage the marine food chain.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS ;   Dollar, in Plunge, Falls Below 3-Mark Level
description: The dollar plummeted yesterday, falling below the level of three West German marks to the dollar for the first time in seven months, and losing an extraordinary 2 percent of its value in just half an hour.

title: DEMOCRATS TRYING TO CONTAIN DAMAGE FROM KIRK REMARK
description: Democratics on Capitol Hill sought today to tamp down reaction to their party chairman's statement this week that Congress should consider limiting or eliminating Social Security benefits for people ''who don't really need them.''

title: INVESTMENT BANKER IS APPOINTED TO NO.2 POST AT STATE DEPARTMENT
description: A retired Wall Street investment banker, John C. Whitehead, has been named the next Deputy Secretary of State, it was announced today. If confirmed by the Senate, he would replace Kenneth W. Dam, who is resigning to become a vice president of I.B.M.

title: MANTEGNA 'MAGI' SETS RECORD PRICE
description: Andrea Mantegna's ''Adoration of the Magi,'' an Italian Renaissance masterpiece, brought the highest price ever paid for a painting when it was sold yesterday for $10.4 million to the J. Paul Getty Museum of Malibu, Calif., at a Christie's auction in London.

Knight to Join Mets; Schiraldi Called Up
description: The Mets, off to the best start in their 23-year history, prepared yesterday to add even more tone to the team this weekend in Philadelphia. They are expected to reclaim Ray Knight from the disabled list tomorrow and restore him to third base, and soon thereafter will add the hot rookie prospect Calvin Schiraldi as a starting pitcher.

title: Seabrook Plan
description: The New Hampshire Public Utilities Commission approved a proposal by the Public Service Company of New Hampshire to raise up to $525 million for its share of the completion of the Seabrook One nuclear power station.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: SARATOGA HEADHUNTER. By Stephen

title: Olivier Wormser Dies; Former French Envoy
description: Olivier Wormser, a former French Ambassador to the Soviet Union and West Germany, has died, his family said today. He was 71 years old.

title: PARK COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DIPLOMAT FROM WALL STREET
description: John C. Whitehead, who was named yesterday to the No. 2 post in the State Department, will step into a major foreign policy post with much more experience in the business world than international affairs. But his background is consistent with the prior business orientation of Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Mr. Whitehead, who is 63 years old, is to succeed Kenneth W. Dam as Deputy Secretary of State. If confirmed by the Senate, he would move to Washington after spending his entire working life at Goldman, Sachs & Company, a leading Wall Street investment bank that sells securities and arranges mergers for some of the country's biggest corporations.

title: VALENZUELA PITCHES 2D STRAIGHT SHUTOUT
description: Fernando Valenzuela of the Los Angeles Dodgers, showing the form of his Cy Young Award-winning rookie season, threw his second consecutive shutout today, a two-hitter that stifled the San Diego Padres, 5-0.

title: FILM: RED RIDING HOOD IN 'COMPANY OF WOLVES'
description: THE story of Little Red Riding Hood has gone through many versions over the centuries. As Robert Darnton reports in his fascinating study of French cultural history, ''The Great Cat Massacre,'' one of the earliest reported is the unadorned tale told by peasants during the ancien regime, in which the heroine owns no red cloak and thus has no name. She is simply a little girl who winds up being eaten by a wolf. It has no cautionary moral for small children. No happy ending. No life ever-after. Just arbitrary deception and death by ingestion.

title: SCREEN: 'PETIT CON,' BY LAUZIER
description: THERE is genuine comic potential in the idea for ''Petit Con,'' an idea that has in fact made for a successful French cartoon book. Its hero is Michel Choupon, a peerlessly self-important 18- year-old who thinks things like ''Not a hint of rebellion in their frozen calf eyes!'' while contemplating his own family. Needless to say, the family finds him a trial, especially since he is almost as sex-crazed as he is solemn.

title: Cook Seeks Buyers
description: Cook United Inc., a Cleveland- based operator of 53 discount stores, said it had hired Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to look for investors or a potential purchaser to fund a reorganization plan. Cook, which has operated under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws since October, said it had closed 61 stores in two years and was looking for a ''third party purchaser or investors'' to infuse capital.

title: CHINESE EXILE'S RETURN: THIS CHAPTER IS HAPPIER
description: For a firsthand account of the miseries wrought by Mao's brand of Communism, there are few more wrenching chronicles than Liang Heng's ''Son of the Revolution,'' the 1983 autobiography of a young Chinese who suffered bitterly in the political upheavals ordained by Mao.

description: A Rockland County grand jury today cleared a former New York City police officer of wrongdoing in shootings that critically wounded his daughter's boyfriend and left the boyfriend's brother dead.

title: SCREEN: 'MY FIRST WIFE'
description: THE Australian film ''My First Wife'' depicts a marital breakup from the standpoint of a husband almost any woman would leave. It evidently had a very personal meaning for Paul Cox, who directed and co-wrote it. ''There had been real trauma in my life, and I wanted to find out if others had been through the same thing,'' he is quoted as saying in production notes for the film.

description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Friday, April 19 (Reuters) - The Chinese Communist Party leader, Hu Yaobang, said today that China would cut the strength of its armed forces by one million men during 1985.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Ex-Education Official In Indiana Is Indicted

Computerland
description: A state judge signed an order directing the founder of Computerland, a computer retailer, to surrender stock worth as much as $400 million to a group of investors led by a rival retailer. The founder, William H. Millard, was ordered by Judge Donald McCullum of Alameda Superior Court to turn over 20 percent of his stock in Computerland and other companies to the Micro-Vest Corporation under the terms of a jury verdict in a case involving a $250,000 loan. The verdict awarded the 20 percent stake, $125 million in punitive damages, $5 million in dividends and accrued interest and $11 million in attorney fees.

title: BELL ATLANTIC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CAJUN MUSICIANS BRINGING THEIR ART TO NEW YORK
description: DOWN along the Gulf coast of Louisiana, America's Cajuns have done far more than cook up gumbo and blacken redfish. In close-knit communities, they've maintained their own language - an evolved variant of 17th-century French - and a culture that revolves around the land, hard work, strong families and good times. And at houseparties and crawfish- fries, their music whoops, wails and stirs together 500 years of tradition.

title: WALL ST. SKEPTICAL ON SUCCESS
description: Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcasting entrepreneur, yesterday made his expected offer to buy CBS Inc. But the view on Wall Street was that he stood only a slim chance of succeeding.

title: STAGE: 'WHITE GLOVE'
description: ''A BUTTERFLY yellow opens / We are not as we once were,'' goes one of several enigmatic incantations that thread through ''Anne's White Glove,'' Alice Notley's impressionistic theater piece. Miss Notley's work, presented at the La Mama Annex, 74A East Fourth Street, by the Eye and Ear Theater, contains many such Zen-like aphorisms, all of them equally cryptic. Strung together by poeticized descriptions of dreams, interior monologue, and quotations from Walt Whitman, the language tantalizes the ear while offering much too little in the way of overt meaning. The difficulties are compounded by the fact that the theme of ''Anne's White Glove'' is that most private of subjects - personal grief.

title: 'Star Wars' Research Is About Wars, Not Stars
description: To the Editor:

THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''WHAT'S a nice girl like you doing living in a place like Connecticut?'' Mayor Koch was asking Sylvia Sidney in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Pierre.

title: S. E. C. Imposes First Civil Penalty in Insider Case
description: Employing new enforcement powers granted by Congress last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had imposed the first civil penalties, on three individuals accused of insider trading.

description: The company estimated that its sales were reduced by nearly $90 million and its net income by about $17 million, or 15 cents a share, in the latest quarter due to the strength of the U.S. dollar compared with a year ago.

title: The Economy's Warning
description: The sharp slowdown of the economy in this year's first quarter further erodes the credibility of the Administration's predictions and policies for 1985. The remaining quarters will probably be stronger, but the risks of tight money are now enhanced and the need to reduce the Federal deficit has become even more urgent.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH FELL TO 1.3% RATE IN FIRST '85 PERIOD
description: The economy slowed sharply to a weak 1.3 percent annual growth rate in the first three months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Pay Equity Could Begin With Federal Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. PROGRAM IN HONDURAS HELPS FAMILIES OF NICARAGUAN GUERRILLAS
description: The United States Government has begun to provide $7.5 million in medical and other nonmilitary aid to an area near a main camp in Honduras for guerrillas fighting the Nicaraguan Government.

title: BRIEFING ;   Sturm und Polka
description: Eleanor Lansing Dulles, a sister of John Foster Dulles, will receive a medal for promotion of German-American friendship from the German-American Club of Bonn in ceremonies in Wiesbaden early next month. Miss Dulles, who will be 90 years old in June, was asked by a presumptuous guest at a Washington party last week whether she felt up to the trip abroad. By way of reply, she rose to her feet and danced a polka.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE latest in the growing genre of ''meat and potatoes just like mom used to make'' restaurants has opened in a grand old building in the West Village. Called Tupelo Honey, it rustles up such fare as Cajun fried chicken, baked ribs, roast chicken, catfish and hushpup pies and roast turkey.

title: CLOWNS ON A SHOPPING SPREE: IT'S HARD TO BE OUTRAGEOUS
description: It was the day the clowns came to Seventh Avenue.

title: ALGERIAN LEADER ASSAILS MOROCCO
description: President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria voiced concern today about growing tension in North Africa, accusing Morocco of spurning chances for a political settlement of the 10-year-old conflict in Western Sahara.

title: 'TITUS ANDRONICUS' IN SHAKESPEARE SERIES
description: THE BBC's final season of ''The Shakespeare Plays'' comes to its last tragedy tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET/Channel 13, with the always forbidding ''Titus Andronicus.'' In a collection of the plays published in 1948, G. B. Harrison declared that ''Titus Andronicus'' is ''regarded by many critics as Shakespeare's worst play, and as a result ingenious attempts have been made to clear him of the charge of having written it.'' Then, in 1955, Peter Brook staged a widely praised version of the play, which was followed by a successful Laurence Olivier interpretation. The violence of ''Titus Andronicus'' was suddenly being deemed pertinent to the history of the 20th century.

title: International Insurance Plan Backed
description: An international agency that would insure corporate investments against expropriation and other risks in developing countries won general endorsement here at a conference of 148 nations aimed at shoring up the global economic system.

title: UNION PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ECONOMIC SETBACK FOR ADMINISTRATION
description: Just two weeks from now, President Reagan sets off for the annual economic summit conference, this year in Bonn, and the man who recently was offering the American economy as the model for the world now finds it has taken an unexpected but undeniable turn for the worse. The Commerce Department's report today that the economy grew at a rate of only 1.3 percent through the first three months of the year poses difficult new policy questions for the Reagan Administration, both here and in its relations abroad.

title: PROTESTERS AT COLUMBIA UNWAVERING
description: When Mark Lewis, a Columbia University senior, was served with a contempt-of-court summons for his role in a campus demonstration on South Africa, he saw himself as carrying on a family tradition.

Blacks and Small Expectations
description: The summation in the College Board's new report on the educational status of black Americans begins encouragingly: ''Black students have made great strides since 1960 in pursuing and profiting from enhanced educational opportunities.'' But that is accompanied by something very discouraging - the finding that those strides might have been greater but for the problem of small expectations.

title: Bridge: Some Administrators Make Their Mark as Players, Too
description: It is broadly true to say that bridge administrators are not highly expert as players. But there are numerous exceptions, and many of them are found in New York.

description: As the dollar was falling sharply in the foreign exchange markets yesterday, continuing a decline that has seen it lose 15 percent of its value since early February, three large American companies announced sales of new debt issues totaling $550 million in the Eurobond market.

description: Edison Brothers Stores Inc. said it would spin off its Handyman Home Improvement Centers division to shareholders. The St. Louis-based retailer said stockholders would receive one share in Handyman for every four shares of Edison Brothers.

description: A judicial ethics panel said today that it had levied formal charges against Rhode Island's top judge after investigating his acknowledged ties to convicted felons and reputed organized crime figures.

description: Los Angeles, or at least bits and pieces of it, came flashing into downtown Brooklyn Wednesday night, and virtually all of social Brooklyn, cultural Brooklyn, official Brooklyn and political Brooklyn crammed into three floors of Abraham & Straus to celebrate ''The L.A. Spirit.''

title: Edward F. McGinley, Banker In New York and Philadelphia
description: Edward Francis McGinley jr., a former president and member of the board of the Beneficial Savings Bank of Philadelphia, died Tuesday at Point Pleasant Hospital, Point Pleasant, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 84 years old and lived in Sea Girt, N.J.

title: Carbide and Dow Chemical Net Off
description: The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings fell 33.6 percent in the first quarter. The company, the nation's third-largest chemical producer, said the profit was hampered somewhat by the shutdown of its pesticide plant at Institute, W.Va., but it attributed a greater portion of the decline to reduced petrochemical sales.

KOHL BACKS JOINT EUROPEAN PLAN FOR 'STAR WARS' RESEARCH WORK
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, in a major policy statement to Parliament, called today for a joint Western European approach to the American research project for a space- based missile defense.

title: Columbia Gas
description: The Columbia Gas System said it expected a 1985 loss of $60 million to $80 million as a result of its previously announced agreement to cut prices as much as $1 billion, or 11.5 percent, to settle several lawsuits. The settlement, which the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is expected to approve April 26, involved charges that Columbia Gas had paid producers imprudently high prices for natural gas since 1981.

title: SCOUTING ;   Neck and Neck
description: As long as the subject is baseball records, let's make note of another one: The Mets and the Cubs, each at 7-1, are together off to the fastest starts by two teams in the same division since the leagues split in 1969.

description: South Africa announced today that it would restore a measure of self-government to South-West Africa pending international arrangements to give full independence to the territory.

title: Flyers' Defense Likes Workload
description: Somewhere, the Islanders believe, they will find a crack in the Flyers' defense. But the Rangers believed the same thing, and they went home Saturday, swept from their playoff series with the Flyers in three games.

The Editorial Notebook;   Frank Lloyd Wright Goes West
description: A native revisiting Wisconsin expects a sense of loss, yet may be unsettled by its odd nature. Milwaukee, for example, is about to close its last brewery, and the state university has had a hyphen plunged into its name - it is cumbrously called the University of Wisconsin-Madison, for reasons as unsatisfying as the demise of Pabst, Schlitz, Blatz and Miller's in the city they made famous. But the real shocker for this returnee (U.W. '51) was a body-snatching.

description: The Congressional Gold Medal of Achievement that Elie Wiesel is scheduled to receive on Friday is the highest honor the United States Government can bestow on a civilian.

title: DANCE: BOYCE'S 'OUTBACK,' SET TO BRAHAMS
description: JOHANNA BOYCE'S new ''Outback,'' performed at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Sch"onberg Theater (219 West 19th Street) on Sunday, is an engrossing work on a number of levels. Set to a lilting Brahms intermezzo that Isadora Duncan danced to, the solo has a Duncanesque forthrightness.

There will be a world premiere of music by Ezra Sims and New York premieres of works by Dary John Mizelle and Francis Schwartz. Frank Zappa's ''Black Page'' will also be performed. Tickets are $6, $3 for students and the elderly.

description: Mayor Koch and the leader of the city's largest municipal union announced a tentative agreement yesterday on a three-year contract covering 115,000 city employees.

title: Sale of Hong Kong Site
description: A prime Hong Kong property site was sold today at a government auction for $90 million, higher than real estate developers had expected. Developers said the hotly contested bidding for the Victoria Barracks site, won by Swire Pacific, a major trading firm, showed confidence in the colony, which Britain will return to China in 1997. Swire did not say what it would build on the site, once the British military headquarters in Hong Kong.

title: REGULATORY FILINGS BY TURNER
description: Ted Turner is trying to head off any Government opposition to a takeover of CBS Inc. by agreeing to sell the company's radio station and a highly profitable television affiliate, communications analysts said today.

title: NATIONAL BANCSHARES OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REAGAN AND SENSITIVITIES
description: Despite his reputation as a dazzling performer and persuader, Ronald Reagan has made a series of often inexplicable misstatements over the years that have angered many constituencies, mired him in political trouble and dismayed even his close associates and admirers. The storm of criticism over Mr. Reagan's likening of dead Nazi soldiers to Jewish victims of the Nazis is only the latest in a series of comments by him that have offended a wide variety of groups.

title: NEW YORK DEVELOPER SEEKS TO EVICT 1,200 UNDER RENT CONTROLS
description: A New York developer who recently purchased a block of 26 walk-up buildings on the Upper East Side has announced plans to evict more than 1,200 tenants so he can demolish the buildings and replace them with four high- rise towers.

EATON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Cuomo Vetoes Westway Limits
description: Legislation that would have placed new restrictions on state spending for Westway was vetoed today by Governor Cuomo.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Opponents of Marcos Plan for 1987 Election
description: Political groups opposing President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that they would support a single candidate in presidential elections scheduled for 1987.

title: Illinois Clears Dairy Workers In Salmonella Contamination
description: Tests at the Hillfarm Dairy have virtually ruled out the possibility that any of the plant's 281 workers caused the nation's second-largest food-poisoning outbreak, state officials said today.

title: Philip Morris, Reynolds Profits Rise
description: The nation's two largest makers of cigarettes yesterday reported sharply higher earnings results for the first quarter. Philip Morris Inc., which is the No. 1 producer, announced that net income in the three months ended March 31 advanced 25 percent. At the same time, R.J. Reynolds Industries said that its net profit rose by 9.6 percent.

title: BROADWAY
description: THIS hasn't been much of a season for new musicals, but it's cheering to know that in November, Broadway will get the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of ''Poppy.'' It's described by the company as not quite a musical, but a ''panto.'' And if you're wondering what a panto might be, that's described as a British tradition combining vaudeville, satire and music.

title: GEORGIA PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income of $8,000,000 from discontinued operations.

title: PUBLISHING: NEW BOOKS ABOUT INDIA WILL COINCIDE WITH 40-CITY FESTIVAL
description: THE Festival of India is about to open, with art exhibitions and cultural activities scheduled for New York and some 40 other American cities. The start of the festival follows close on the heels of the showing of ''A Passage to India,'' the film based on E. M. Forster's novel, and ''The Jewel in the Crown,'' the television series based on Paul Scott's ''Raj Quartet.''

title: FOES OF REAGAN LATIN POLICIES FEAR THEY'RE UNDER SURVEILLANCE
description: An organizer for a Michigan group that opposes the Reagan Administration's policy in Central America asserted today that first-class letters it mailed in 1985, virtually all among three batches sent, had not reached their destinations.

title: COMBUSTION ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DIVIDED HOUSE TEAM DECIDES DEMOCRAT IS INDIANA WINNER
description: A United States House of Representatives team decided here tonight that Frank McCloskey, the Democratic incumbent, was the apparent winner by four votes in a bitterly fought recount of the Eighth District Congressional election. However, a recommendation to the full House on seating a winner will not be made until after a meeting Monday. According to complete but unofficial totals from the Federal recount, the third recount in the race, Mr. McCloskey defeated Republican challenger Rick McIntyre by 116,645 votes to 116,641. Some House aides called the contest the closest House race in this century.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BEIRUT PREMIER GOES TO SYRIA FOR TALKS
description: Rashid Karami took up a role as a caretaker Prime Minister today, traveling to Syria for talks with President Hafez al-Assad on the deteriorating political situation in Lebanon.

title: Court Reinstates Coast Law Granting Pregnancy Benefits
description: A Federal appeals court has restored a California law guaranteeing pregnant women four-month leaves and reinstatement to their jobs, overturning a ruling that the law discriminated against men.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think that there is nothing wrong with visiting that cemetery where those young men are victims of Nazism also, even though they were fighting in the German uniform, drafted into service to carry out the hateful wishes of the Nazis.

title: BRIEFS
Reynolds Metals Chief To Give Up One Post
description: David P. Reynolds, 69, the chairman of the Reynolds Metals Company, will step down as chief executive next April, a company spokesman said. The spokesman added that Mr. Reynolds has said he would probably be succeeded by the company's president and chief operating officer, William O. Bourke, 58.

title: Bank of Boston Net Up
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation, parent of the First National Bank of Boston, yesterday reported that net income in the first quarter rose 76.3 percent, to $43.9 million, from $24.9 million a year ago.

description: At one point in their quest to build the atomic bomb in World War II, senior American weapons scientists also considered a plan to poison hundreds of thousands of enemy forces with the lethal radioactive form of the element strontium, a recently declassified letter reveals.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: FOR 16 years La Petite Marmite has been quietly servicing the United Nations community and the solid citizens of the Beekman Place neighborhood. This is no small achievement in a city where the average restaurant's lifespan is about as long as that of a first-run movie. One reason La Petite Marmite has endured could be that it represents a mirror image of its clientele: worldly but conservative, amiable yet reserved, inventive but cautious.

title: EDUCATOR ASSAILS COMPUTER 'HYPE'
description: Criticizing what he termed the ''exaggerated claims'' and ''media hype'' that have accompanied the arrival of computers on college campuses, Derek Bok, president of Harvard University, urged fellow educators yesterday to adopt an attitude of ''cautious enthusiasm'' toward the new technologies.

title: New Alcohol Charges Filed
description: The motorist whose killing of a 13-year-old girl led to the national crusade against drunken drivers was in jail today under $200,000 bond after he was involved in another accident involving alcohol, the authorities said. The man, Clarence Busch, 52, who was arrested Wednesday, has a long record of drunken driving arrests. He was convicted in 1980 of involuntary manslaughter for running down Cari Lightner, 13, then speeding off.

title: EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AROUND THE NATION ;   Last Suspect Convicted In 13 Seattle Killings
description: A 28- year-old immigrant from Hong Kong was found not guilty today of murder in the 1983 killing of 13 people in Seattle's Chinatown but was convicted of robbery and assault in the case.

title: NICARAGUA WEEK IN THE CAPITAL
description: He was a wiry young man with smooth, olive skin wearing an open-neck shirt, a rebel commander come out of the mountains of northern Nicaragua to do public relations battle in the United States capital. Yes, ''Commander Invincible'' said in answer to the first question at a news conference downtown, he was a former member of the Somoza-era National Guard. He had never thought it was ''a crime to be a career soldier.''

title: BANK AMERICA INTEREST IN OREGON UNIT IS TOLD
description: The BankAmerica Corporation of California has a team of its executives examining Orbanco Financial Services, the second-largest bank holding company in Oregon, and banking sources in California said they expected BankAmerica soon to announce that it planned to acquire Orbanco, or part of it.

title: NEW EXHIBITION HAILS ART OF THE 'GILDED ERA'
description: IT was ''the greatest meeting of

title: Bank Weighs Suit on Hunts
description: The First Chicago Corporation is contemplating legal action against an oil drilling company controlled by the Hunt family in an attempt to regain some of the $11.9 million the bank lost on a foreign exchange contract, investment sources said.

title: Economic Scene;   Panama Chief's Latin Worries
description: omas G.PRESIDENT Nicolas Ardito Barletta of Panama is an economist who took his bachelor's and master's degrees in agricultural economics at North Carolina State University and his doctorate in economics at the University of Chicago.

title: G. E. AGAIN ELIGIBLE FOR U. S. WORK
description: The Air Force announced today that it was restoring much of the General Electric Company's eligibility to bid on Government contracts, based on improvements in the company's accounting procedures.

title: BURR-BROWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KILLINGS CHILL RIGHTS GROUP IN GUATEMALA
description: Ten months ago, six people founded a human rights organization called the Mutual Support Group for the Appearance Alive of Our Relatives. Today, only two of the six remain. Two have been killed, one is in exile and another has quit the group out of fear.

title: Pill May Increase Risk Of a Venereal Disease
description: Women who use birth control pills may increase their risk of developing chlamydia, the most common sexually transmitted disease in the nation and a leading cause of some pelvic infections, a new study says.

title: Debt Issues
description: Comarco Inc. is offering $10 million of 9 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2000 at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Siedler Amdec Securities.

title: BRIEFING ;   Happy Birthday, Will
description: Speaking of writers, Shakespeare's 421st birthday will be

title: Debut of 'Best Times,' NBC High-School Series
description: Though summer vacation is a fixture of academic real life, school is never out on television. So it comes as no surprise that just when actual students are nearing the end of another year, Channel 4 is offering the debut tonight from 8 to 9 of ''The Best Times,'' a series about faculty and students at John F. Kennedy High School somewhere in sunny California.

title: A FRESH LOOK AT A QUARTER-CENTURY OF PAUL RESIKA
description: THE new taste for figurative painting has caused nonentities to be retrieved from oblivion although they might better have been left there. All the same, the fashion has had the beneficial effect of highlighting artists who, though well known, tend to be taken for granted. Paul Resika is just such a talent, and a show surveying the last 25 years of his output is now at Artists' Choice Museum, 394 West Broadway.

title: A JOY OF NEW YORK: ART IN THE SPRING
description: Wandering round New York this week, I rewrote in my head two of the most famous lines in English poetry. ''Oh to be out of England,'' I thought, ''now that April's here!'' Quite apart from the weather, as the accompanying articles show, we're having a remarkable April in the museums, the galleries all over town, the auction houses, on the street and (literally) up the wall. And always there is the pleasure of just walking around, looking at this, that and everything else, at a time of year when a New Yorker might echo the great landscape painter John Constable and say, ''I never saw an ugly thing in his life.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
Albany's $65 Million Petty-Cash Box
description: To the Editor:

description: agreement with one retailer to

title: DANCE: 2D AVENUE TROUPE AT N.Y.U.
description: THERE was not an inelegant moment on the fine program presented Tuesday by New York University's Second Avenue Dance Company at the Tisch School of the Arts. Notable for its well-chosen dances, the program was performed by a group of graduate and undergraduate students with compelling theatrical presence, clean technique and quiet authority.

title: FILM: 'LILY IN LOVE,' ROMANTIC FARE
description: FITZROY WYNN (Christopher Plummer) is part ham actor, part theatrical genius, a man whose immense ego is being eaten away by his certain age, which is advancing. He has the fine, slightly worn good looks of an old-time matinee idol who finds it difficult to go to bed at night after the show.

MASLAND, C H & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: April 19, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

description: b-Includes a gain of $327,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Energy Post to Be Filled
description: President Reagan will nominate Joseph Salgado, a former aide to Energy Secretary John S. Herrington, to fill the No. 2 position at the Energy Department, the White House announced today. The announcement said that Mr. Reagan would nominate Mr. Salgado, who is associate director of the White House Office of Presidential Personnel, to be Under Secretary of Energy, succeeding William Collins. Mr. Salgado, 41 years old, served under Mr. Herrington when he was director of Presidential personnel.

title: BRIEFING ;   Diplomacy With a Big D
description: Emboldened by the fact that Texas has the longest foreign border in the United States and a history of belligerent independence, Dallas has apparently decided to undertake its own foreign policy.

title: Arturo Tanco Jr., 51; A Former Filipino Aide
description: Arturo R. Tanco Jr., a former president of the World Food Council of the United Nations and his country's Agriculture Minister for 13 years, died of cancer today. He was 51 years old.

title: TWO AIDES QUIT EDUCATION DEPT. IN DISPUTE OVER VIEWS ON DISABLED
description: Two Education Department officials resigned today after their criticism of Federal programs for the handicapped evoked angry protests from members of Congress and groups representing the disabled.

title: BARRY WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Harvard Backing
description: A $260 million financing of the Massachusetts Health and Education Facilities Authority, on behalf of Harvard University, was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. About $230 million of the financing was evenly divided between 5 1/4 percent ''put'' bonds with a final maturity in 2016, which investors may redeem at par on Feb. 1, 1986, and annually thereafter, and 5 1/2 percent ''put'' bonds, which may be redeemed Aug. 1, 1986, and annually thereafter.

title: Of Undiminished Charm
description: To the Editor:

title: A. M. C. Will Slash Its Operating Costs
description: The American Motors Corporation, plagued by poor car sales and expected to report a quarterly loss Friday, said today that it would take steps to cut its operating costs by 25 percent in the next month. A spokesman, Jerry L. Sloan, said the plan, which could lead to white-collar layoffs, would involve every department in the company.

title: MUSIC: 'ZAZA' AT CINCINNATI OPERA
description: The Cincinnati Opera seems to be making a specialty of verismo revivals. In 1983 it offered Alfano's ''Resurrection,'' and Wednesday night the company opened its 1985 season with Leonca vallo's ''Zaz a.''

title: Koch Taxi Plan No. 3
description: Mayor Koch has yet another plan for improving taxi service. He wants the City Council to permit 1,200 more licensed ''medallion'' cabs to cruise New York's streets, and he wants the State Legislature to give the city the right to auction off the new medallions. He also would create a second tier of licensed street-hail service, operating only between points in the outer boroughs.

title: BONN PRAISES PRESIDENT ON HIS CEMETARY VISIT
description: West German officials expressed satisfaction today at President Reagan's apparent determination to hold to his plans to lay a wreath at a German military cemetery during a visit next month.

title: LAMAUR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Tri-Star Offering
description: Tri- Star Pictures Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of common stock, common stock warrants and debentures with a total value of up to $50 million, the company announced today. The offering calls for the issuing of 2.5 million units that will sell for between $8 and $10, consisting of one share of common stock and a warrant to purchase one unit of common stock. The proposal will be underwritten by a group led by Allen & Company, the First Boston Corporation, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Morgan Stanley & Co. Inc.

HARRIS BANKCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: The company said results for the latest quarter include an after-tax writeoff of $4,300,000 to cover an early retirement incentive program.

title: TIME INC. GAINS
description: First-quarter results for the communications companies reporting yesterday were not what they seemed. The American Broadcasting Companies reported a decline in net income, but said that the company would have had a gain if it had not had costs associated with its proposed merger into Capital Cities Communications Inc. Time Inc. reported higher results, but said that its Home Box Office cable television unit was still reporting losses. And, the Cox Communications Corporation, the focus of a $1.2 billion bid by Cox family members, said it had reported a gain only because of a nonrecurring item.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MAPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Byrd Proposes Talks
description: Faced with almost certain defeat in Congress, President Reagan has agreed for now to accept a compromise proposal to postpone military aid to the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government, a White House official said tonight.

title: PANEL BACKS REMOVAL OF FOLEY SQUARE SCULPTURE
description: A panel appointed by the General Services Administration has recommended the removal of ''Tilted Arc,'' a federally commissioned sculpture at Foley Square whose size and starkness has fostered a feverish debate since it was installed four years ago.

title: Western Union Antitrust Case
description: The Western Union Corporation has been ordered to pay $72 million to a man who contended his two teleprinter companies were put out of business by the communications giant.

description: The company said the 1985 results include two months of the Charter Corp. acquired in January 1985 but results for 1984 have not been restated for that transaction.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $849,000.

title: SMALL CHANCE SEEN FOR CBS TAKEOVER
description: Wall Street professionals expressed extreme skepticism yesterday that Ted Turner's takeover bid for CBS Inc. would excite stockholders.

title: BEVILL TRUSTEE GAINS
description: The bankruptcy trustee for the Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Asset Management Corporation won a court judgment yesterday giving him control of $94 million in government securities that had been held by the Security Pacific Clearing and Services Corporation, the principal clearing agent for Bevill, Bresler.

title: President Is Resigning At Magazine Group
description: Thomas H. King, the 50-year-old president of American Business Press, is resigning effective June 30 to get back with a line outfit.

RATES FALL SHARPLY ON G. N. P. DATA
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday after the Commerce Department announced a new gross national product estimate showing that the economy expanded at a slower-than-expected 1.3 percent rate in the first quarter.

title: David Murray Octet
description: The tenor saxophonist and composer David Murray will lead his octet this weekend at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Sunday; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Irish Music Concerts
description: Cherish the Ladies - a series of Irish traditional-music concerts by female musicians - concludes Saturday at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street, between King and Charlton Streets (651-9510). There will be a concert at 8 P.M., followed by dancing at about 10 P.M. Tickets are $5.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CELTICS TOP CAVALIERS, 126-123
description: In the regular season, the Cleveland Cavaliers tied with the Phoenix Suns for the worst record among the 16 teams that qualified for the playoffs. In their first playoff game tonight, the Cavaliers showed little respect for the team with the best regular-season mark, the Boston Celtics, before losing, 126- 123, at Boston Garden.

title: KILLER IS PUT TO DEATH IN VIRGINIA AFTER INMATES RIOT IN HIS SUPPORT
description: James D. Briley, convicted of murdering a woman and her young son, was put to death tonight in the electric chair. He was the 42d person to be executed since the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976, and the 10th this year. Mr. Briley was pronounced dead at 11:07 P.M., a spokesman for the State Penitentiary said. His execution came despite two last-minute appeals and an uprising by fellow inmates seeking to block his electrocution. Mr. Briley, 28 years old, was executed in an electric chair last occupied by his brother Linwood, who was put to death Oct. 12 for a separate murder.

title: THIRD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VOTE ON RESTARTING THREE MILE ISLAND FACES DELAY
description: Opponents of resuming electric power production at Three Mile Island asserted today that repairs to overcome corrosion in the nuclear reactor had not been adequately tested and posed the threat of a another radioactive release.

title: EXCEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AUCTIONS
description: WHAT may be the biggest auction of the year, the sale of the Florence J. Gould collection of 200 Impressionist, post-Impressionist and Old Master paintings, will take place Wednesday and Thursday after exhibition this weekend at Sotheby's. The highly publicized sale - with works by van Gogh, Gauguin, Cezanne, Degas and Toulouse- Lau trec - is expected to break many records and to bring in more than $25 million.

title: TANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects an after-tax writedown of $18,250,000 for the quarter and the nine months on the value of raw materials and finished goods for the company's 2000 microcomputer.

title: AMDAHL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS' NET SLIDES
description: Texas Instruments, in its sharpest setback since it dropped out of the home computer business, said yesterday that it was laying off an additional 1,000 employees after its first-quarter profits fell 88.6 percent, to $9.1 million.

title: ART OF PROTEST ATTEMPTS TO SHOCK AND MOBILIZE
description: SUE COE'S work is about anger, about making art that cannot be absorbed into a system she abhors and about art with the power to provoke political action. In her graphic images, the narrative and expressive currents of contemporary art, as well as the present widespread identification with animals and nature, are channeled into political statements.

title: LOWENSTEIN, M CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from the repurchase of notes payable and debentures of $3,094,000, or 74 cents a share. The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for the 5-for-4 stock split in June 1984.

title: HOUSING AT A GOLF CLUB IN WESTCHESTER
description: -ON-HUDSON, N.Y. - At the old St. Andrews Golf Club, discreet white signs remind the visitor at every turn that the rules in this corner of Westchester County are firm and long established: ''members only since 1888.'' Tradition and exclusivity are also the bywords and the marketing concepts for the large luxury condominium project that has been under way at the club for the last two years.

title: Plane Yields to Errant Driver
description: An 87-year-old driver, cruising along at about 50 miles an hour, mistook an airport runway for an interstate highway and drove off the end Wednesday, going off a seawall and splashing into Tampa Bay, the police say. A plane approaching the runway for a landing was waved away in time.

title: TAIWAN CONVICTS OFFICER IN U.S. MURDER
description: A military court here today convicted the former head of Taiwan's military intelligence bureau of plotting the murder of a Chinese-American writer last year and sentenced him to life in prison.

title: PRESTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AT THE MOVIES
description: THE week of July 27, 1951, brought two versions of ''Alice in Wonderland'' to New York. One was from Walt Disney, and it went on to become a popular success. The other, a live action and animated puppet film by Lou Bunin, got the better reviews and then languished in almost total obscurity. When the Thalia plays Mr. Bunin's ''Alice'' this weekend, it will be showing the last known print of a film that has not been seen here theatrically in nearly 30 years.

title: INLAND STEEL POSTS LOSS
description: The Inland Steel Company, the first of the major steel concerns to report results for the first quarter, said yesterday that it had a loss of $6.3 million in the period.

title: COMMENTS BY WIESEL AT CAPITOL
description: Following are excerpts from the speech today at the Capitol by Elie Wiesel, chairman of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council:

title: REAGAN REMARKS BRING NEW OUTCRY
description: President Reagan's statement today that the German soldiers buried in Bitburg cemetery were as much victims of Nazism as those who died in concentration camps touched off new outcries from Jewish groups across the country.

title: AMF INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Key Preps for Derby
description: One of the smallest fields in the history of the Wood Memorial and several wide-open races at other tracks comprise key Kentucky Derby preps that will be contested around the country tomorrow. More than $1.5 million will be up for grabs as horses will be trying to increase their earnings to win spots in the Derby field, which is limited to the 20 with the biggest career bankrolls.

Reagan Says a Pledge To Saigon Was Broken
description: President Reagan said today that the United States did not lose the Vietnam War on the battlefield, but lost it by breaking its ''pledge as a government'' to support South Vietnam against North Vietnamese violations of agreements.

description: The first quarter results include about $2 million, or 39 cents a share, from R.W. Harmon & Sons, a school bus transportation and sales subsidiary, acquired by Mayflower in October 1984.

title: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Two Americans Missing In Guatemala Highlands
description: Two Americans, one of them a freelance journalist, were reported missing Friday in the Guatemalan highlands.

title: Shell Oil Plan Backed
description: A Delaware Chancery Court yesterday approved a proposal by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group to pay $2 a share more for the Shell Oil Company in exchange for dismissal of a suit by shareholders who complained that the 1984 offer, which expired last year, was inadequate. The suit had charged that Royal Dutch's offer of $58 a share, or $5.5 billion, for Shell Oil was unfairly low.

title: MIKE NICHOLS REFLECTS ON MOVIES -- AND LIFE
description: Mike Nichols was talking about directing movies. Actually, he was talking about life, sex, Aeschylus and salami. And at this particular moment, he was sounding a bit contrary.

BOTH SIDES SEEK LATIN AID COMPROMISE
description: The White House and Congress worked today on a compromise on President Reagan's request for $14 million in aid to Nicaraguan insurgents, but the effort was hindered by procedural complications and wide differences over how the money is to be spent.

title: WOOD POSES MANY QUESTIONS
description: No field for the Wood Memorial has been smaller than today's six since only five went to the post in 1956. But few Woods have been riddled with so many questions.

3 Die After Chemical Blast
description: Three of four workers injured in an explosion at a chemical company near Afton Thursday have died of their burns, an official said today, and the fourth worker was in critical condition. The explosion at the Greenwood Chemical Company resulted from a leak while workers were mixing water with toluene, a highly flammable industrial cleaning solvent, fire officials said.

title: FAINTER TOOTS FROM ATLANTIC LINERS
description: Those with a keen ear can still occasionally hear the customary three long rumbling hoots of an ocean liner's whistle as it departs from the 55th Street terminal on New York's West Side. But send-offs for the huge vessels as they glide into the harbor and out into the ocean are now an infrequent reminder of a more prosperous time in trans-Atlantic voyages.

title: Panel Assails Personnel Chief
description: The Government's personnel chief improperly interfered with the election process by sending letters to the Governors of three states that were conducting nonpartisan registration drives in state buildings, a House committee said today.

title: CHILES TO PROPOSE OWN DEFICIT PLAN
description: Senator Lawton Chiles of Florida said today that he would offer an alternative 1986 Federal budget next week that includes tax increases and a limit, probably a freeze, in the cost-of-living increase for Social Security.

title: BIG HOLDERS AWAIT CBS MOVE
description: Wall Street money managers, who control 60 percent of CBS stock, looked to the media giant yesterday to devise some way to ward off a takeover bid by Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcaster, and still give investors a chance to make some money.

Loss Angers Nets
description: Thursday night they were embarrassed. Today they were mad.

description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that he was gratified President Reagan had reaffirmed his intention to visit a German military cemetery next month, saying it showed he was ''a friend of the Germans.''

title: MYSTERIOUS SPACE RADIATION IS TARGET OF 3 EXPERIMENTS
description: American physicists said here today that new evidence from Europe supported their finding that a perplexing form of highly penetrating radiation was coming to earth from the constellation Cygnus.

title: THE LAMOTTA NUPTIALS
description: Neither of the Las Vegas dailies, nor, for that matter, The New York Times, reported in their society news sections the wedding of Jacob (Jake) LaMotta, 63 years old, erstwhile pugilist, and, Theresa Miller, younger than the bridegroom and decidedly prettier.

title: FRIENDLY BIDS RUMORED
description: The board of Storer Communications Inc. planned to meet today in a special weekend session amid Wall Street reports that it would consider buyout offers to thwart a takeover attempt by dissident shareholders.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: U.S. JUDGE SAYS WATT ERRED IN WILDERNESS DECISION
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that James G. Watt, as Interior Secretary in 1982, erred when he excluded 1.4 million acres of Federal land in 10 Western states from consideration as possible wilderness areas.

title: VODAVI TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on March 22 about the mortgage insurance industry misstated the claims paying rating of the General Electric Mortgage Insurance Company of Ohio. It is rated AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: SWEEP BY U.S. AND BAHAMAS YIELDS TONS OF ILLEGAL DRUGS
description: American and Bahamian officials spread a dragnet throughout 30 Bahamian islands and along 150 miles of the Florida coast in the last two weeks, seizing 5,500 pounds of cocaine and 33,872 pounds of marijuana.

title: PIANO: PETER SERKIN PLAYS BEETHOVEN WORKS
description: When Peter Serkin first captured major attention as a pianist and interpreter, back in the 1960's, he was generally regarded as a young renegade. Like many other artists of his generation, he rebelled against what were felt to be the stale and inhibiting conventions of the concert hall. His famously informal stage costumes seemed the outward sign of an emotional need to break away from traditions and try to find his own approach to music and life. For some years, it appeared as though he might be dissipating a great talent by taking life far more seriously than he took music. He tended to play rather deliberately, at moderate tempos, taking care not to stress the kind of surface brilliance that older virtuosos deal in so successfully.

title: Why Torpedo Justice in Jobs?
description: Should public agencies take race and sex into account in hiring? title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Michigan Two detours into the past between Detroit and Chicago I-94 between Detroit and Chicago is 275 miles of monotonous, heavily traveled highway, but travelers can break that monotony with two detours into the past. Starting westward from Detroit, a visitor would be well advised to spend at least part of a day at Greenfield Village, in nearby Dearborn. The 254- acre complex is Henry Ford's attempt to re- create some of the events and places that were pivotal in the transformation of the United States into an industrial power; the Wright Brothers bicycle shop, for example, where the first airplane was designed, was moved here from Dayton. One of Thomas Edison's laboratories may also be seen.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Massachusetts In the spirit, if not the actual footsteps, of Paul Revere It is no longer possible to follow the routes taken by Paul Revere and Will Dawes when they set out from Boston to warn the patriots in Concord of the approaching Redcoats that night in April 1775. Modern civilization has overgrown the way. But the half-hour drive from Boston to Concord remains a pleasurable and rewarding journey. The drive is particularly pretty in the spring, as New England comes alive after the long gray winter. If the day is warm, pack a picnic to eat in the fields beside the Minuteman National Park. History, literature and nature beckon.

title: BY THE LOOK OF IT, RECRUITING IS A VERY SERIOUS BUSINESS
description: Artsy brochures with covers that look like record jackets are out, but stately four-color portraits of ''Old Main'' are back in. Humor doesn't work, but prospective students apparently like charts and graphs and picturesque photos of students strolling hand-in-hand. ''Personal'' letters from computers are effective, but the mistakes they make can be embarrassing.

title: Preserving The Little Jennie
description: In the article ''In Centerport, A Battle Over Change'' (March 24) it was reported that sizable donations were received by a project to restore the Little Jennie, one of the oldest American merchant sailing vessels.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ;   New Vaccine For Meningitis
description: The first vaccine to protect children against bacterial meningitis was approved by the Food and Drug Administration last week. It should prevent many of the 1,000 deaths of young children that this form of meningitis and related diseases cause each year.
