title: ALBANIANS IN YUGOSLAVIA: POST-HOXHA NATIONALISM
description: As Enver Hoxha, Albania's Stalinist leader, was buried Monday in Tirana, the Albanians who form a large majority in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo neither mourned publicly nor vented any of their clearly mounting nationalistic feelings.

title: ON THE CREST OF THE BLUE RIDGE
description: Spring comes to the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia and North Carolina like a trickster romping through some Appalachian folk tale: tantalizing, contradictory, giving here and snatching away there, and finally erupting in one furious rush of enchanting variety.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Mexico To Cuernavaca: On a clear day you can see Mexico City Visitors to Mexico who spend their time only in the bustling, smog-laden capital or at one of the many beach resorts can come away thinking of the country as a cross between Los Angeles and Miami. A quick drive south from the capital, at least as far as Cuernavaca, can help correct that mistake. The highway is among the best in Mexico, and the features along it well worth individual exploration. Leave Mexico City by the Cuernavaca toll road (take the Viaducto Tlalpan from the Periferico), heading south to climb along the sides of one of the many mountains that surround the capital. About 15 minutes along the way, look back for an overview of Mexico City's ever-growing sprawl; farther along, you will be able to see the two majestic volcanoes, Ixtacihuatl and Popocatepetl, once clearly visible from Mexico City, but now only rarely seen through the city's polluted air.

title: A TIME TO BE ABOUT
description: FROM Inwood to Orient, from Montauk to Great Neck, the sights, sounds and colors are changing as most of Long Island moves outdoors. Winter is a distant memory, while the present, between the raindrops, is a time of preparation for a possibly glorious summer.

title: WENDY C. JACOBS BECOMES BRIDE
description: The Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Wendy Carol Jacobs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Jacobs of White Plains, and Richard B. Hamilton Jr. the son of Dr. Hamilton of Eatontown, N.J., and Doris M. Hamilton of Red Bank, N.J. Rabbi Jerry Heller and the Rev. Carl B. Nelson, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: GARDEN STATE WON BY SPEND A BUCK
description: Spend A Buck emerged as a major threat for the Kentucky Derby tonight when he thrashed eight rivals to win the Garden State Stakes at Garden State Park in 1:45 4/5, only two-fifths of a second off Secretariat's American record for 1 1/8-mile Derby prep. It was believed to be the fastest time ever recorded for a Derby prep at that distance.

title: CAMP DAVID MEANS DIFFERENT THINGS TO LABOR AND LIKUD
description: Last week's political row over Cabinet Minister Ezer Weizman's trip to Egypt was a combination of many intersecting lines of conflict in Israeli politics: Labor versus Likud, Prime Minister Shimon Peres versus Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Mr. Weizman versus his old Likud Party colleagues, to name but a few. But underlying them all was a clash between two very different conceptions of what the peace process between Israel and its Arab neighbors should be about.

title: Funds for Mill Conversion
description: Mayor Thomas Radich, said today that the city had received $500,000 from investors who plan to convert a hot-strip mill at the closed Bethlehem Steel Corporation plant into an aluminum processing plant.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: April 21, 1985

title: AFTER 20 YEARS, IS IT TIME TO RETIRE THE JOB CORPS?
description: At first, it seemed that the annual fight between the Reagan Administration and Congress over the future of the Job Corps would follow the script of previous years. The White House in its budget sought to kill the 20-year-old corps, comparing it unfavorably with its own ''partnership'' training program. But many Senators balked, proposing instead to scale down the Job Corps. And with strong support from friendly committee chairmen, even the program's detractors expected it to survive the Administration's latest attack.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's Region 2, Christopher Daggett, says that the agency's efforts to set guidelines for burning hazardous wastes in the Atlantic are not premature, as environmentalists have asserted.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE EMERGENCY ROOM Written and illustrated by Anne and Harlow Rockwell. Unpaged. New York: Macmillan Company. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 5)

title: RICH, LAZY, AND (AT LEAST ONCE) INSPIRED
description: WITH FRIENDS POSSESSED A Life of Edward FitzGerald. By Robert Bernard Martin. Illustrated. 313 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

title: NISSAN'S NEW TURBO SET FOR GRAND PRIX
description: The new Nissan turned its wheels for the first time this weekend on a test track in the California desert. Like many other Japanese cars these days, the new Nissan GTP ZX-Turbo, a low-slung, rear-engine two-seat coupe, is assembled in the United States.

title: DAPHNE S. THORNTON TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Daphne Sellar Thornton of Newport, R.I., and Henry H. M. Thornton of Ridgefield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elena Martha Thornton to Michael Case Kissel, the son of W. Thorn Kissel Jr. of Owings Mills, Md., and the late Mrs. Kissel. A June wedding is planned.

title: SCIENCE IN SHORT
description: By Robert O. Becker and Gary Selden. (Morrow, $17.95.) If a salamander loses a limb or tail it simply regrows another.

title: SOCIAL EVENTS ;   IN AND OUT OF TOWN
description: Along with dinner at the American Museum of Natural History, guests will have the first opportunity to view an extraordinary exhibition, the first comprehensive showing of 3,500 years of Mayan art. Six years in preparation, the collection of jade, wood, stone, shell and gold artifacts has been assembled from museums in Mexico, Guatemala and Belize and represents national treasures that have never before left those countries. The items reflect the cultural development of the Mayan people from 2,000 B.C. to the Spanish conquest in the 16th century. The exhibition opens its tour of North America at the Museum of Natural History April 26. The black- tie benefit and preview starts with cocktails at 7 P.M. at the museum. Tickets, $250, from 212-873-1300. At the Plaza

title: CHAPAIN'S LEGACY LIVES IN SONG
description: IT'S rather like old home week - some 14 years later - at the Village Gate Downstairs, a cabaret in Greenwich Village. Stephen and Tom Chapin, two of the Harry Chapin's three brothers, and Sandy C. Chapin, his widow - under such respective credits as ''musical director and arranger'' and ''creative consultant'' - are having a behind-the-scenes say in a musical culled from Harry Chapin's songs.

title: MARY N. NOHARA BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Mary Noriko Nohara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Katsuya Nohara of Tokyo, and Steven Meyer Jones, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold D. Jones of Redfield, S.D., were married yesterday at the United Methodist Church in Summit, N.J., by the Rev. Jane Edwards.

title: COLLEGE AS A LESSON IN PERSEVERANCE
description: ''Look through a telescope and gaze at the heavens.'' That was the advice of a friend when I told him that I would graduate from college this summer and wanted to do something special to celebrate.

title: WILDERNESS AREA PROPOSED FOR PINELANDS
description: -managed wilderness area in New Jersey - 67,000 acres in the heart of the Pine Barrens - will be presented for study to the Department of Environmental Protection in several weeks.

title: MARY ANN MIKULICH TO BE WED JULY 6
description: Mary Ann Mikulich, a doctoral candidate at the W. Averell Harriman Institute for Advanced Study of the Soviet Union at Columbia University, and Bertrand Mark Patenaude, a fellow at the Harriman Institute, plan to be married July 6.

title: On Language ;   Public Diplomacy
description: FRST CAME PLAIN old diplomacy , from the Greek word for a letter that has been folded over so that its contents cannot be readily seen.

title: MELODY TROEGER PLANS TO MARRY TIMOTHY SWEET
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Curtis R. Troeger of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Melody Beth Troeger to Timothy Patrick Sweet, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas O'Dowd Sweet of Syracuse. The wedding is planned for August.

title: PAKISTAANI RIOTS FLARE AGAIN: 6-DAY DEATH TOLL IS PUT AT 51
description: Violence broke out again tonight in Karachi, where rioting between ethnic groups and battles with security forces have reportedly killed 51 people and seriously wounded 250 in six days.

title: At Least 80 Go to Hospitals After a Toxic Blaze in Jersey
description: A fire in a work shed spewed poisonous fumes overnight that sent more than 80 police officers, firemen and paramedics to hospitals. The owner of the shed was charged today with creating a hazardous situation.

title: HOMELAND HAYWIRE
description: PAST CONTINUOUS By Yaakov Shabtai. Translated by Dalya Bilu. 389 pp. Philadelphia: The Jewish Publication Society. $16.95.

title: PARADE TODAY
description: The Salute to Israel Parade begins at noon on Fifth Avenue at 57th Street, moving north to 86th Street, then east to Third Avenue and ending at 4 P.M.

title: 'INFORMANCE' BLENDS VIOLIN AND CHAT
description: THE sound was pervasive; the soft, minor-key whistle so persistent that each time Liba Shacht raised her violin to her chin she had to lower it again, distracted by the screech.

title: A BEDSIDE BOOK OF PARADOXES
description: METAMAGICAL THEMAS Questing for the Essence of Mind and Pattern. By Douglas R. Hofstadter. Illustrated. 852 pp. New York: Basic Books. $24.95.

title: On Fire Call It was just a college prank, but setting trash on fire in a stairwell of an occupied dormitory qualifies as first- degree arson in Florida. And when
description: Greg Cox, a 19-year-old University of Miami sophomore place-kicker, and a former teammate,

title: Accordion Facade
description: White Plains has surely set the commercial-development pace for the rest of Westchester County, but some observers think the city's stark new office buildings have brought a coldness to its central business district.

title: YANKS WIN BY 5-2
description: The Yankees were pleased that Mike Pagliarulo returned to their lineup yesterday, but the Cleveland Indians were not happy at all with the absence of Julio Franco from theirs.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES ;   Broadcast TV
description: Made-for-TV movies tend to be the equivalent of instant throwaways, but some last better than others. There is, for current example, ''Games Mother Never Taught You,'' which is being rebroadcast this week Tuesday evening at 9 on CBS.

title: SCIENCE IN SHORT
description: By M. David Stone. (Macmillan, $16.95.) By the time today's schoolchildren enter the job market they will have to be comfortable with the idea of computers.

title: DONALD ROBERTS WED TO JOAN BUTLER DEAN
description: Joan Butler Dean, a daughter of Mrs. John A. Funk and the late Mr. Funk of Rockport, Mass., was married yesterday to Donald Bowne Roberts, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Roberts of Cape Porpoise, Me., and Sanibel Island, Fla. The Rev. Edwin Lane performed the Unitarian Universalist ceremony in the Appleton Chapel at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

title: DEEP TRUTHS IN GAME OF INFINITE MYSTERY
description: IT was in the late spring of 1970 that Willie Mays, by then turned 39 and arguably in his dotage, began running the opposite way on the basepath. Having hung an easy standup double off the right-center wall, he coasted to within 15 feet of second base, executed a smart 180, and hurtled madly back to first. A throw there might well have had him, but none was made, so paralyzed was the defense, among others.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Because only 32 percent of Jersey City's residents returned test census forms last month, the Census Bureau has sent a force of 450 to conduct a door-to-door survey for the next few weeks in the hopes of compiling more-accurate information to help plan for its 1990 census.

title: RAISING BOYS
description: Your article on raising boys implies that parents can choose various methods of rearing and produce predictable results.

title: CLINIC BOMB TRIAL TOLD OF DISORDERS
description: Three of four young defendents on trial here in the bombings of three abortion clinics suffer ''severe'' mental disorders, a defense psychiatrist testified today.

title: LESLIE OSBORNE PLANS TO WED
description: Leslie Anne Osborne, an associate at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, plans to be married June 15 to Samuel Richard Coleman, an associate at the First Boston Corporation in New York.

title: Nigerian Newspaper Closes;Financial Problems Are Cited
description: A Nigerian Sunday newspaper, The Democrat Weekly, is to shut down in the face of growing financial difficulties and a shortage of newsprint, the newspaper's editorial adviser said today.

title: MISS DEWEY IS BRIDE OF KEVIN FITZGERALD
description: -Louise Dewey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Dewey of Lincoln, Mass., was married there yesterday at St. Anne's-in-the-Fields Episcopal Church to Kevin Francis Fitzgerald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Fitzgerald of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Stephen J. White performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Paul Harmon, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY;

SCIENCE IN SHORT
description: RADIANT SCIENCE, DARK POLITICS: A Memoir of the Nuclear Age. By Martin D. Kamen (University of California, $19.95.)

title: HOSPITAL TEACHES STRESS MANAGEMENT
description: THERE was Anne, a self-described perfectionist who works for a large brokerage concern in Fairfield County. And Jim, a neat, bespectacled postal employee who said that beneath his seemingly tranquil exterior, ''I'm operating at 100 miles per hour.''

title: A CENTENNIAL CELEBRATION OF THE ADIRONDACKS
description: THERE IS NO WILDERNESS PARK IN the United States quite like the one in the Adirondack Mountains. It is bigger than any national park in the West, almost three times the size of Yellowstone, larger than the state of New Hampshire. It covers 5,927,000 acres - almost one-fifth of the land of New York State - and 46 high mountain peaks, 2,759 lakes, 1,200 miles of wild rivers, and magnificent pines, spruces and birches beyond counting.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN STUYVESANT SQUARE
description: FOR New Yorkers, the name Stuyvesant conjures up different images -

title: VACCINES ARE BEGUN AT YALE
description: WITH two cases of measles reported on campus, Yale University is conducting a large-scale immunization program.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: Writing under the pen name Delacorta, the Swedish novelist and screenwriter Daniel Odier has created a series of new-wave thrillers in which the roguish middle-aged hustler Serge Gorodish and his 13- year-old punk-waif companion, Alba, kiss, cuddle and con their way across France. The first Delacorta work, ''Diva'' (1979), caused a stir when it was made into a self-consciously stylish movie.

title: SCIENCE IN SHORT
description: By Isaac Asimov. (Dutton, $18.95.)

title: Members of Organized Crime Accused of Murder Scheme
description: A man said to be a manager in an organized-crime group and several ''soldiers'' have been arrested in Florida and New Jersey on charges of plotting to murder two people in the New York area, the authorities said today.

title: THE ECONOMIC SLOWDOWN, AND ALL THAT IT PORTENDS
description: WASHINGTON

title: U.S. Topples Canada In World Hockey, 4-3
description: The United States scored a 4-3 victory over previously unbeaten Team Canada today, and the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia stayed undefeated in the World Hockey Championships.

title: GARDEN STATE BALLET IN PROMISING SEASON
description: HACKENSACK THE Garden State Ballet, with Peter Anastos as its new artistic associate, is offering a spring season of traditional and contemporary work that promises choreographic surprises.

title: THUNDERBOLTS INTO ENGLISH
description: THE DIVINE COMEDY OF DANTE ALIGHIERI A Verse Translation by Allen Mandelbaum. Drawings by Barry Moser. Volume One. Inferno. 307 pp. $24.95. Volume Two. Purgatorio. 303 pp. $29.95. Volume Three. Paradiso. 307 pp. $29.95. Berkeley: University of California Press.

title: Biggs Scores Quick Knockout
description: Tyrell Biggs, the Olympic champion who recovered from alcohol and drug abuse, stopped Mike Perkins at 2 minutes 50 seconds of the opening round of a scheduled six- round heavyweight bout today. The victory was Biggs's second as a pro.

title:
ART;

6 COOL SCULPTORS AT THE BEN SHAHN
description: WAYNE

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Texas For serendipity, just point the car southeast from Austin To most visitors, the Texas hill country west of Austin, with its lakes and mesquite-studded ranches, is perhaps the most inviting destination in this vast state. But it becomes more congested and less Texan by the year, so I often prefer these days to drive east from the state capital, to find the flavor of old Texas. It is here, moving eastward, that the Balcones escarpment flattens into the so-called Blackland Prairie of Texas and Texas turns suddenly from dry to lush, from desert to rich farmland.

title: WORKERS BUY THEIR MILL
description: THE Bridgeport Brass Company officially became the Seymour Specialty Wire Company last week as the first employee buy-out of a United States brass mill became a reality.

title: 'A NEGRO WAY OF SAYING'
description: DUST TRACKS ON A ROAD An Autobiography. By Zora Neale Hurston. Edited and introduced by Robert Hemenway. 348 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois. Cloth, $22.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: ANOTHER READIED
description: Technicians assessed the damage to the space shuttle Discovery today as they pressed to meet an ambitious schedule of eight more shuttle flights this year.

title: 4 Accused of Arms Schemes
description: ''These international operations have nothing to do with political philosophy, national interests or ideology; it's a matter of money,'' Raymond J. Dearie, United Sates Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, said. The reference was to the indictment of four men, arraigned last week, on charges of engaging in a racketeering enterprise to ship military equipment to the Soviet Union, Poland, Iraq and Argentina.

title: CAMPAIGN STARTED TO RESTORE ARCH
description: HARTFORD RESIDENTS of the Hartford area are being asked to give a dollar each to help save a piece of history, the Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Arch in Bushnell Park.

title: Bridgemarket Is Back on the Track
description: AFTER years of delay, final permits are about

title: TOP POSTS FOR COUPLE
description: WHILE it is not unusual for a husband and wife to toil in the same field, few work in the same village, in a similar organization and at the same job level.

title: A JOB PROGRAM IS KEEPING SOME STUDENTS IN SCHOOL
description: While most other high school students are in class this week, 16-year-old Stephanie Berrios will be behind a desk at Warner Communications Inc. in midtown Manhattan, earning $4.50 an hour - and academic credit.

title: COMING ATTRACTIONS
description: SOLID CLUES Quantum Physics, Molecular Biology, and the Future of Science. By Gerald Feinberg. 287 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: CLAY, KILNS AND ESTHETIC QUESTIONS
description: SUMMIT SOME exhibitions are as important for the questions they raise as for the work that is shown.

title: ANN CONNOR MARRIED TO JOHN P. UEHLINGER
description: Ann Marie Connor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Connor of Massapequa, L.I., was married yesterday to John P. Uehlinger, a son of Dorothy Uehlinger McElwreath of Atlantic Beach, L.I., and the late Gerard P. Uehlinger. The Rev. Maurice Sullivan performed the ceremony at Maria Regina Roman Catholic Church in Seaford, L.I.

title: STATE TRYING TO UPDATE AIRPORT PLAN FROM 1969
description: IN the 1960's, when a dollar bought several gallons of aircraft fuel, there was speculation that the Connecticut commuter of the 80's would he hopping a plane, rather than a bus, to get to work. Those predictions did not take into account the oil price rises of the 70's. As a result, air travel has grown far less than expected.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Canadian Rockies The Icefields Parkway, complete with bears ''On beholding the grand dividing ridge of the continent, all that we have seen before disappears from mind,'' wrote David Douglas. Douglas, the botanist for whom the Douglas fir is named, made his observation in 1827 upon first seeing the rugged peaks of the Eastern Main Ranges of the Canadian Rockies. Not much has changed. Except that now you can drive your car along a 143-mile stretch of excellent road, while Douglas had to travel by pack trains.

title: HALF BLANCHE AND HALF STANLEY
description: THE KINDNESS OF STRANGERS The Life of Tennessee Williams. By Donald Spoto. Illustrated. 409 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: KNIGHT ESTATE TO ADD STOCK IN FOUNDATION
description: The Knight Foundation, a relatively small foundation established by one of the founders of Knight-Ridder Newspapers, is likely to become one of the nation's 20 largest private foundations before the year's end, with assets worth more than $360 million.

title: ENDIVE, QUEEN OF VEGETABLES
description: The coffers of Belgium's agricultural heartland overflow with such delights as blanched asparagus, baby carrots and beets, petit pois and haricots verts. But it is Belgian endive - delicate, tightly furled, in stalks six to eight inches long with creamy-white-tipped, pale yellow leaves and their slightly bitter taste - that is the treasure, prized the world over. No small wonder that the cuisine of Belgium is ranked by many above that of France. And the Belgians don't even seem to make a fuss about it.

title: SCIENCE IN SHORT
description: By Niles Eldredge. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Niles Eldredge knows how to make science exciting. He describes his efforts - beginning when he was a graduate student - to find patterns of variation in the trilobite species Phacops rana, a shellfish that lived 600 million years ago.

title: SUFFOLK PLANS FOR 20% BUDGET CUTS
description: DESPITE a period of economic expansion for Suffolk County, a tax protest by the Long Island Lighting Company and looming reductions in Federal revenues have brought a mood of austerity to county government.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SHUN THE FRUMIOUS ZIZ A JEWISH BESTIARY: A Book of Fabulous Creatures Drawn From Hebraic Legend and Lore (Jewish Publication Society, $10.95) . Mr. Podwal removes himself from the tradition of such 20th- century authors of ironic bestiaries as Apollinaire and Jorge Luis Borges. His bestiary is more like the early ones - straightforward compendiums of commentary on the Old Testament - and his flexible style evokes a variety of traditions, from Jewish decorative arts and Hebraic manuscript illustration to Etruscan bronzes.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HOSPITAL BENEFIT RUN

title: NEWTON'S OTHER LAW: GLORY IS THE REAL REWARD
description: IN 1672 Isaac Newton published, in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, ''A New Theory About Light and Colour.'' Newton's paper was reviewed - at the request of the Royal Society, by one of its most formidable members, Robert Hooke - harshly, because Hooke held a wave-theory of light, in a rather rudimentary form, admittedly, and he was not convinced by Newton's argument that light consists of particles.

title: Cable TV
description: As suspense puzzles, Billy Wilder's ''Witness for the Prosecution'' (1957) and Orson Welles's ''Touch of Evil'' (1958) have several things in common. Cable movie buffs can see for themselves this week on WTBS.

title: Flushing Revival
description: A sprawling 33-year-old complex in Flushing, Queens, that had grown seedy in recent years is being revived and will be converted to cooperative ownership. The complex, the former Campus Hall Apartments, is next to Queens College between Main Street and Kissena Boulevard.

title: New Boosters For Public Schools
description: THE Boston public schools, recently desegregated and mired in bitter controversy 10 years ago, are finding new supporters in the business community.

title: New Jersey Tries To Turn Off A Few Spigots
description: After the 1981 drought demonstrated the limits of New Jersey's network of small reservoirs, the state vowed to make some improvements before the next dry spell. But with some of the work still unfinished, Governor Kean last week declared a drought emergency, warning that water levels were at a 50- year low for springtime.

title:
DINING OUT;

INN NESTLED IN THE WOODS
description: -century inn is as splendid as ever. Nestled in the woods next to a rushing stream, the archetypal Colonial house with its burnished wood paneling and glossy wide-planked floors glows with gentle light from candles set in pewter sconces and on tables. The tiny snuggery of a bar repeats the charm and makes a cozy place to sit and sip a drink.

title: A GOOD DRIVER
description: I have a death grip on the steering wheel of a car rushing forward over the road; I try to remember how to turn a corner properly. Here we go: hit the brakes and then trail off, pivot my foot and tap the accelerator with the heel, double clutch and downshift, roll the wheel over and look for the apex - there it is - then drift across the road to the exit point and begin setting up for the next turn.

title: CHANGE CREEPS UP ON HOG WALLOW
description: HOG WALLOW HERE in the dead center of the Pine Barrens, in a town so obscure that it doesn't show on most maps, Emil Brown is carrying on a family tradition.

title: CHICKEN WINGS SUPREME
description: A KEEN APPRECIATION OF FOOD IS A HIGHLY subjective matter. Do you like your roast turkey hot or cold? Do you prefer white meat or dark? Do you balk at, or admire, sweetbreads, brains and kidneys?

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: AT 'WORK' If arts festivals have to have themes - and apparently they must - then ''In the Works'' seems logical for this year's edition of the C.W. Post Center's American Theater Festival. The centerpiece of the weeklong festival is ''Working, a Musical,'' the stage adaptation of Studs Terkel's kaleidoscopic journey through America. And wrapped around the production is a potpourri of other performing and visual arts events directly or indirectly tied to that theme.

title: LESSONS FROM ONE-FAMILY HOUSING IN THE SOUTH BRONX
description: IT looks easy today, and it should have been,'' said Edward J. Logue, writing in hindsight about the experience of bringing into being the Charlotte Gardens development of factory-built single-family houses in the East Crotona Park section of the South Bronx. ''Yet in all my long and varied years in the city building trade, it has been the most difficult project I ever undertook. In retrospect, building Roosevelt Island, tramway and all, seems easy.''

title: ARMY SURVEY FINDS OFFICERS CRITICAL
description: The Army's officers, in a remarkably candid self-evaluation, have expressed severe criticism of themselves, the Army and its senior leaders.

title: INSECT THAT THREATENS RED PINE SPOTTED IN UPSTATE NEW YORK
description: A tiny insect about the size of a pinhead is spreading into southeastern New York State from Connecticut, attacking and killing red pine trees, according to forestry experts in both states.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: A VISIT to 1500 Privado Road, Westbury, is always a trip down Memory Lane for me: all the cars I have driven into the ground since I became a Long Islander, all the licenses and registrations I have had to renew, and traffic jams.

title: TEEN-AGER WHO SHOT TEACHER SAYS HE WAS IN LOVE WITH HER
description: A teen-ager charged with shooting his high school history teacher on Thursday says he did it because he was in love with her and was unhappy about how their relationship was going, according to the police here.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BLACK WOLF: The Life of Ernest Thompson Seton. By Betty Keller. (Merrimack Publishers' Circle, $18.95.)

title: SCANDINAVIAN AND THEN SOME
description: THERE are good reasons, beyond the decorative leitmotif of Viking ships, for naming a new restaurant in Huntington the Great Dane. There is a nod to Scandinavia on the menu.

title:
DINING OUT;

GREEN BROOK: FROM PIZZA TO SUSHI
description: SHOGUN, the name by which the Japanese military ruler was known until the last century, is also the name of a few-months-old Japanese restaurant on Route 22 West in the Somerset County community of Green Brook.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: PENETRATING THE GLOSS OF VACATION BROCHURES
description: Tour brochures are often a source of pleasure and easy to read - but it is frequently difficult to figure out what their enticing language really means. Each year, more and more brochures are remarkably precise. Many of them, however, still resort to such sleights of hand as describing a hotel as ''scenically located'' and, therefore, presumably charming, when it also can mean that it is far from the center of town.

title: Protecting Jobs
description: IN a move to protect workers against

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Vermont New England as you always thought it would be The soul of New England may plausibly be said to lie in the southeast corner of Vermont, amid the winding roads that snake through forests of pine and birch, never far from a burbling stream. Sail past the big, bustling interstate highways and enter Vermont instead by a quieter path, climbing up Route 112 from western Massachusetts. The route runs along an elevated ridge, through apple orchards and clumps of maple trees, across narrow bridges, past farms where outcroppings of rock jut from the dry fields.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: South Carolina Into the Low Country, land of marsh grass and black water Along the Atlantic coast, between the cities of Savannah and Charleston, lies South Carolina's Low Country. It is a flat landscape of black water and marsh grass, one of the last major unpolluted marine estuaries on the East Coast. Seen from the narrow two-lane highways that meander beneath canopies of moss-draped oak, it is a serene and graceful place; a long, low horizon broken only by the flight of herons. Here are small towns and poor houses and roadside stands selling fresh crab. Along the coastal islands that divide the marsh from the sea, there are black communities that date from the time of the Civil War, when freed slaves came to make their living here by farming and hunting and oystering.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ;   Turner Makes His Bid For CBS
description: Ted Turner went public last week with his intentions, never all that private, to take control of CBS. The 46- year-old cable-television innovator, professional sports entrepreneur and champion yachtsman asked the approval of the Federal Communications Commission for his unfriendly takeover bid.

title: PRINCETON CORRIDOR IS SPLIT ON PACE OF GROWTH
description: Faced with the prospect of runaway corporate development that could transform this tranquil university town into the center of a new megalopolis, officials here are waging a fierce legal battle to slow the boom.

title: TOO GOOD TO SUCCEED
description: PIERRE MENDES FRANCE By Jean Lacouture. Translated by George Holoch. Illustrated. 486 pp. New York: Holmes & Meier. $34.50.

title: ACREAGE COVERED IN PROPOSAL
description: THE wilderness area proposed by the Sierra Club includes 50,300 of Wharton State Forest's 108,773 acres.

title: MISS POTTER WED TO FINANCE AIDE FOR A LAW FIRM
description: The marriage of Eugenie Margaret Bucknell Potter, the daughter of E. Clifford Potter and Ruth S. Potter, both of San Francisco, to William de Rham Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. de Rham of Gallatin Gateway, Mont., took place yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. Bishop Robert Rae Spears Jr., who is retired from the diocese of Rochester, performed the ceremony.

title: Boy Shoots Himself in Class
description: Timothy Taylor, a 16-year-old student at Riverside Polytechnic High School, shot himself in the head in typing class Friday and died several hours later, officials said.

title: SUSAN A. MAYERS MARRIED TO MARK J. TUPPER IN RYE
description: Susan Anne Mayers, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Mayers of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Mark Joseph Tupper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Eugene Tupper of Stamford, Conn.

title: Parking Plight Of the Handicapped
description: Last summer, I had an experience similar to the one M. Gillette Jones described (''Not Always in a Wheelchair,'' Opinion Page, March 24) where, although she had a handicapped parking permit, a man threatened to attack her because he didn't think she looked sufficiently disabled to park in a handicapped spot.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Gathering of Rugs At Wholesale Prices

title: DISPOSING OF NUCLEAR WASTE
description: To the Editor:

title: DOUBLED CANCER RATE IS FORECAST
description: The cancer rate in New York State will double in the next 50 years unless there are major initiatives in prevention, according to the State Health Commissioner.

title: THE CAMPAIGN AGAINST CORRUPTION HAS A LONG WAY TO GO
description: In a Mexico City courtroom last week, a commander of the country's Federal Judicial Police defended himself against charges that he had accepted $250,000 to permit the escape of a major drug dealer he had been assigned to capture. Eight other Federal police commanders are being sought on similar charges.

title:
ANTIQUES;

STAMFORD INHERITS AN UNEXPECTED GIFT
description: ONCE in a great while, a local historical society is blessed with an unexpected gift. So it was with the Stamford Historical Society when members learned the organization had been left an extensive collection of Early American furniture, and, equally important, the funds necessary to find a place in which it could be shown, engage experts to catalogue each piece, refurbish and polish, and design an appropriate exhibition.

title: PUBLIC SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GRITTY ELOQUENCE OF DAVID MAMET
description: THE POKER GAME STARTS AT 7:30 EVERY WEDNESDAY night. It ends, David Mamet says, any time between 1:30 A.M. and noon Thursday. The men eat ham sandwiches, drink beer and smoke a lot of cigars, and thousands of dollars move across the table. But if this sounds like a typical card game, it has its peculiarities. The regulars include a painter, a film professor and, in Mamet, a Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright. And their conversation, for all the usual bluffing and cussing, often turns to art or literature or organic gardening.

title: AIR-SHUTTLE COMMUTERS DEVELOP ART OF COPING WITH THE FRENZIED SKIES
description: Harriet Weiss, a public-relations executive, likes to line up early for the Eastern Airlines shuttle, then zoom to the first-row window seat (it must be the left side). But Togo West, a lawyer, breaks from the line for an end run to the plane's rear door, ascending quickly and barreling toward a seat up front and on an aisle.

title: REVIVAL OF HOT SPRINGS AWAITS BUDGET DECISION
description: The decaying bathhouses of this venerable resort, once glittering attractions for those seeking relief from ailments and gangsters seeking a refuge, may soon be reborn as art galleries, theaters, restaurants and fitness centers.

title: WAITING ROOM AT GRAND CENTRAL REGAINS SENSE OF GRANDEUR
description: After a year's work and a cost of $1.5 million, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad has restored to its turn- of-the-century elegance a waiting room at Grand Central Terminal that was once used by long-distance passengers.

title: McEnroe To Face Lendl TOKYO, April 20 (AP) - John McEnroe defeated Yannick Noah, 6-4, 6-4, and Ivan Lendl beat Andres Gomez, 6-3, 6-4, in the four-man, $250,000 Suntory Cup tennis tournament today before a crowd of 12,600.
description: The two winners will play for the $110,000 first prize, with the runner- up receiving $70,000.

title: AN ENCOUNTER WITH JUVENILE CRIME

title: MUSIC BECOMES FOOD FOR THE HUNGRY
description: Recording stars from the United States, Europe and Latin America are discovering that they have the power to raise large sums of money for aid to African famine victims and similar humanitarian causes.

title: Change of Faith
description: Lewis E. Lehrman's ''Jewish identity'' became an issue in the New York Governor's race three years ago, when a group of rabbis wondered why he had married an Episcopalian.

title: SECURITY AGENCY TO GET NEW CHIEF
description: President Reagan has decided to nominate Lieut. Gen. William E. Odom to become director of the National Security Agency, the Pentagon announced Friday.

description: Twenty people were reported killed overnight in fighting in and around the port of Sidon in southern Lebanon.

title: PHYSICIST SCANS 'STAR WARS' PROJECT
description: AT his laboratory at the Polytechnic Institute of New York, Dr. Erich Kunhardt, a physicist, made a simple movement: He plugged in his laser. ''Now,'' he said with a grin, ''how do I do that in space?''

title: Oilers Gain 2-0 Lead Over Jets
description: Paul Coffey scored two goals and assisted on three others tonight as the Edmonton Oilers beat the Winnipeg Jets, 5-2, and gave the Stanley Cup champions a 2-0 lead in their four-of-seven game Stanley Cup playoff sereis.

title: OPERA: PREMIERE OF PERSICHETTI WORK
description: The Pennsylvania Opera Theater - Philadelphia's ''second'' opera company, performing in English, in small spaces and with young singers - gave the world premiere of Vincent Persichetti's first opera ''The Sibyl,'' at the Walnut Street Theater here on April 13. Friday evening's performance, the last of three, sparked interest in the company, if not in the work.

title: SUCCESSOR SOUGHT FOR O'LEARY
description: JOHN P. O'LEARY'S announcement that he would not stand for re-election to the County Board of Legislators - the first such withdrawal by an incumbent this year - has taken Republican leaders somewhat unawares.

title: MISS WALZER WED IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Susan Walzer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard A. Walzer of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Timothy Koechlin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard A. Koechlin, also of Montclair, were married yesterday in Amherst, Mass. Estelle Matusko, a justice of the peace, performed the ceremony at the Lord Jeffery Inn.

title: LOUISE HALLAHAN PLANS TO HAVE JUNE NUPTIALS
description: Col. Robert F. Hallahan, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Hallahan of Vienna, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Louise Michelle Hallahan to William Lewis Stakelin, the son of William F. Stakelin of Georgetown, Ky., and the late Olive Anne Stakelin. A June wedding is planned.

title: TACTICAL AIR COMMANDER KILLED ALONG WITH 4 OTHERS IN JET CRASH
description: Gen. Jerome F. O'Malley of the Air Force, commander of the Tactical Air Command, was among five people who died this evening in the crash of a military jet, according to a United State Representative.

title: JERONIMOS: THE GLORY OF OLD PORTUGAL

title: Chinese Quake Kills 22
description: Twenty- two people were killed and more than 300 were injured in an earthquake that struck Yunnan Province in southern China on Thursday, provincial authorities said today.

description: Whoever is elected President of Guatemala this fall will confront more than the normal challenges inherent in taking over a small, poor and deeply indebted nation.

description: A State Supreme Court justice said yesterday that ''white police have been virtually given a license to shoot and kill blacks with impunity'' and he warned black listeners to ''beware.''

description: In the first week under a new smoking law a special telephone line in the City Attorney's office received 432 calls, 16 of them complaints of violations of the law, a spokesman said Friday.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Florida Not quite a cruise: The Overseas Highway There used to be two drawbacks to driving down to Key West from Miami. Unless you left your car in Key West and flew back, the return trip covered exactly the same territory as the original one. Two thirds of the 150- mile route runs across the Florida Keys over a series of islands and bridges called the Overseas Highway. There is no alternative highway, and it is unlikely there ever will be one.

title: After 28 Years
description: In 1979, the barrier against multifamily housing in the Town of New Castle in Westchester County fell after a six-year legal struggle that resulted in a revision of the town's exclusive zoning laws.

title: ART
description: There has been so much recent activity in the area of landscape painting that not even the Whitney Biennial, with its resistance to anything that does not seem brand new, could fail to take notice. One of the clearest of the spate of recent gallery shows on current landscape painting is ''With an Eye to Nature,'' at the Jeffrey Hoffeld Gallery, 1020 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, through Saturday.

title: SALLY AHERN IS MARRIED TO JAMES MACDOUGALL
description: The marriage of Sarah Margaret Ahern, classified sales manager of High Technology magazine, and James William MacDougall, a vice president in mortgage securities for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Dr. William P. Wood performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;

THE ADVANTAGES OF DIRECT SEEDING
description: A READER requested information about flowers that can be seeded directly in the garden without having to be transplanted. This method does present several advantages: Seeds usually cost less than plants; the extra work of transplanting is avoided and, not having to withstand the shock of being transplanted, many plants get off to a better start.

title: IN QUEST OF A NAME FOR OUTDOOR PURISTS
description: ;Lee Wulff is a sportsman, no matter what anyone else calls it.

description: Princess Michael of Kent, who found herself trying to explain it last week.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ;   Cloning DNA From a Mummy
description: The extraction and duplication of genetic material from the 2,400-year- old mummy of an Egyptian infant, reported last week in the British scientific journal Nature, is the most spectacular of a recent series of accomplishments using molecular biology to study links between modern and ancient life.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: CONTINUING a trend of deinstitutionalizing mentally ill patients, the state plans to reduce the population of Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital in Morris Plains by 25 percent, according to the hospital's chief executive officer. This will mean Greystone will have 670 patients by the end of the decade.

title: SAN DIEGO MAYOR PREPARES FOR NEW TRIAL FOR PERJURY
description: Mayor Roger Hedgecock, who in February narrowly avoided being convicted of violating campaign financing laws, is preparing to defend himself against the same charges again after the collapse of talks aimed at avoiding another trial.

description: GODS OF WAR By John Toland. 598 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95.

title: THE YARD AND THE WORLD

title: SPEEDWAY BACK ON THE BLOCK
description: A YEAR ago, shareholders voted down a proposal to sell the Bridgehampton Race Circuit, Southampton Town's once glamorous speedway, to a developer. Now the proposal is back and the developer, Thomas E. Gill of Southampton, believes he has the votes to insure that the sale takes place.

title: SOPHIA LETTS IS BRIDE OF COURTLANDT B. AULT
description: Sophia McGavin Kenyon Letts, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Gavin Graham Kenyon Letts of Palm Beach, Fla., was married there yesterday to Courtlandt Bromwell Ault, a son of Bromwell Ault Jr. of New York and Edgartown, Mass., and Faith VanClief Meredith of Palm Beach and Edgartown. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea.

title: TOWN FIGHTS SAND MINERS
description: THE Town of Smithtown and two companies that mine sand and then fill the space with construction debris are locked in a battle over environmental concerns.

description: IN the waning days of spring training in

title: DESIGNERS FOR MANSION
description: THE Middle Island School District today will

title: SAUDIS WRING MOST OF THEIR WATER FROM THE SEA
description: There is a story about a former ruler, King Faisal, that goes something like this: Whenever an aide told him about a new oilfield, the King would nod and go on with his work. When the news was about a new water well, the King would smile broadly and say, ''Thanks be to God.''

title: TRACING WILLA CATHER'S NEBRASKA
description: Few Americans seem to realize what a treasure they have in Red Cloud, a veritable little ville musee. How many people know where it is, or have ever been there?

title:
AMERICA'S CHOICES IN NICARAGUA;

2 WAYS TO GO?
description: Whether we like it or not, the political polarization in Nicaragua limits our realistic alternatives. We have only two possible choices now: support for the popular opposition or, in effect, support for the Sandinista regime.

title: IRONIES OF EXISTENCE
description: DIASPORA An Inquiry Into the Contemporary Jewish World. By Howard M. Sachar. 539 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $27.50.

title: LOREN GELBERG IS THE BRIDE OF LLOYD M. GOFF IN JERSEY
description: Loren M. Gelberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gelberg of Teaneck, N.J., and Lloyd M. Goff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Goff of Highland Beach, Fla., and Plainview, L.I., were married last evening. Rabbi Stanley Skolnik officiated at the Sheraton Heights Hotel in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. Mrs. Goff is a clinical social worker at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York. Her husband is a principal of the Goff Security Bureau in New York.

title: THE NON-JOY OF EATING: IF IT'S FRESH, FREEZE IT
description: THE freezer compartment of our refrigerator serves as a customs house for all the fresh food entering our home.

description: The Administration would have us believe that the choice we face in Nicaragua is between funding the ''contras'' or accepting the spread of Marxism-Leninism in Central America. Nonsense.

title: FOR CITY UNION CONTRACTS, YOU'VE GOT TO GET A GOTBAUM
description: After months of false starts, name-calling and posturing, New York City and its largest labor union surprised almost everyone else involved when they announced last week that they had settled on a new contract. They did it the old-fashioned way: Victor Gotbaum, the dean of New York's labor leaders, sketched out a deal in secret with the Mayor's negotiators. It was a year behind schedule, but it was done.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VIEW OF COLLEGE ADMISSION
description: FOR the thousands of Westchester high school students waiting for college acceptances, the month of April marks the end of a long period of test- taking, visiting campuses, writing applications and essays and hoping that the schools they think they want will want them.

title: TOWNS LOSING POLLUTION INSURANCE
description: LAST month, the Town of Southampton joined most of the other towns on Long Island that have sought help from the state in obtaining insurance against lawsuits over damage caused by pollution. The Town Board passed a resolution requesting that New York State provide this type of insurance or that the insurance company that covers the town's other insurance needs be required to offer a pollution policy.

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   Loss Is Put at $1 MillionIn Texas Blood Bank Fire
description: A fire raced through Lubbock's only blood bank early today, destroying hundreds of pints of blood and forcing doctors in a large area of West Texas to cancel elective surgery.

title: PROTECTING A CHILD'S WORKPLACE
description: GETTING a child safely to school often seems a major problem - whether he or she goes on foot, a bike, or in a car or school bus. Once that hurdle is crossed, we assume that the child is safe within the confines of the school building.

title: NEW INSIGHTS INTO FREUD
description: As the editor and translator of ''The Complete Letters of Sigmund Freud to Wilhelm Fliess, 1887-1904,'' I feel it is important to point out that Daniel Goleman avoids the issue that makes these letters of genuine significance in the light of present-day interest in child abuse. He does not mention that these letters contain new and previously suppressed material supporting Freud's early and courageous stance in favor of women - cases depicting the real sexual abuse of children.

title: PHILS HALT RALLY TO TOP METS, 7-6
description: The Mets did not want to grumble about the bad call or the stiff wind. Those things were out of their hands.

description: Penn's heavyweight varsity crew presented its new head coach, Stan Bergman, with his first victory yesterday, defeating Yale and Columbia to win the Blackwell Cup.

title: SOMERS CONSIDERS LETTING CONDOS IN
description: CONDOMINIUMS may be on the rise in much of Connecticut, but they are a touchy subject in the town of Somers.

title: STRAY CATS PLAGUE A COMMACK STREET
description: FOR one Commack neighborhood, the springtime proliferation of kittens has progressed from a cute event to a nightmare. Dozens of stray cats and their kittens have overrun Shinbone Lane yards for several years, causing health and other problems, residents complain.

description: TWO summers ago a company

title: EXPOS TOP CUBS, 4-0, FOR FOURTH STRAIGHT
description: Bill Gullickson gave up two hits in seven innings and Andre Dawson hit a solo home run as the Montreal Expos shut out the Chicago Cubs, 4-0, today for their fourth straight victory.

title:
THE CREATIVE MIND;

THE INNOVATOR
description: I KNOW THIS IS GOING TO SOUND crazy to you,'' apologizes Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation. ''But do you know what really impresses me? I saw a robot pick up an egg !'' He is, arguably, the most powerful industrialist on the face of the earth: chief executive of the world's largest automobile company, master of an empire that spans 39 countries, employs over 750,000 people, sells $84 billion worth of products a year. But as he sits in shirt sleeves in the seat of power - his corner, walnut-panelled office on the 14th floor of the General Motors Building in Detroit - 59-year-old Roger Smith talks of robots with the wide-eyed wonder of a farm boy telling the tale of his first visit to the fair.

title: JOINING HANDS TO CONTAIN COSTS
description: C.I.O. is immersed in a health- cost-containment campaign that, if successful, would establish the nation's first statewide network of Health Maintenance Organizations (H.M.O.'s) based in existing hospitals. It would be known as the Affordable Health Care Plan.

title: New Insights Into Freud
description: It is certain that Sigmund Freud was narcissistic, grandiose and possessed of an inconsistent sense of self esteem (''New Insights Into Freud,'' by Daniel Goleman, March 17). That he suffered from ''anxiety neurosis'' and recurrent periods of depression seems probable.

description: LAMBERTVILLE

description: STREET WITHOUT JOY, by Bernard B. Fall. (Schocken, $7.95.) Beginning in 1953, the political scientist Bernard B. Fall visited Indochina at various times. On Feb. 21, 1967, he was killed in South Vietnam by a Vietcong mine. Tillman Durdin wrote here in 1961 that the book's special importance was its ''portrayal of the Indochina conflict as a major example of the new kind of warfare waged by revolutionary forces that enjoy the advantages of what he calls an 'active sanctuary.' '' Fall's

title: AUTO-LICENSE ISSUE ENLIVENS THE RACE
description: TRENTON THE decision by members of Governor Kean's administration to conceal a potentially lucrative agreement with a prominent businessman has enlivened a generally quiet election year.

title: CHORUS IS MUTE AT L.I. CHURCH
description: -voice choir at Antioch Baptist Church in Hempstead, L.I., is hardly making heavenly music these days. In fact, after a fight with the pastor, the Rev. James Lancaster Burrell, over his salary, it is not making any music at all.

title: 3 CONDOMINIUMS REZONING REQUESTS FACING OPPOSITION
description: AS Long Island's population ages and drifts eastward from Nassau County, town boards in several Suffolk County communities are being swamped with requests from developers for rezoning, particularly for changes to permit multiple-family dwellings in areas zoned for single-family homes.

title:
CRAFTS;

TEXTILE ARTISTS PRESENT GROUP SHOW IN IRVINGTON
description: THE New York Textile Study Group, an association of about 50 members who share a common interest in the fiber arts, is having its first group show in Irvington-on-Hudson. The exhibition, at Vertu Gallery through April 30, features more than 30 pieces executed in diverse media and techniques. Although the gallery space is small, there is an abundant variety of work on view - tapestry, clothing, objects, lace, basketry and sculpture, among many examples.

title:
AMERICA'S CHOICES IN NICARAGUA;

HELP THE 'CONTRAS'
description: Critics of the Reagan Administration's policy on Nicaragua sometimes seem to think that only they know what is really happening in that country. In truth, their central arguments do not hold up to analysis.

title: MISS FIELDS TO WED JONATHAN PEDERSON
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Garsten of Shoreham, L.I., of the engagement of Mrs. Garsten's daughter Patricia Anne Fields to Jonathan F. Pedersen, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard F. Pedersen of Cairo. The future bride is a daughter also of William Fields of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif.

title: KRISTIN CALDWELL IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. York of Water Mill, L.I., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Kristin M. Caldwell, to Dennis J. Schad, a son of Helen Schad and the late Bernard J. Schad of Andalusia, Pa.

title: What Plaintiffs Can Collect
description: If the courts find that someone's civil rights were violated, isn't it only fair that the losing side pay the person's legal costs? That was the thinking behind a law enacted in 1976 giving a successful plaintiff who had sued under a number of Federal civil rights laws the power to collect a ''reasonable attorney's fee.''

title: Subway Drama
description: It was among the crimes that occur

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL ;   MARYLAND TOWN FEARFUL OF CUTBACK
description: DORIS Collins, the Mayor of Brookview, Md., is old enough to remember when there were no street lights in her quiet little town along Marshy Hope Creek on Maryland's Eastern Shore. Now she fears the old days are coming back.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

SUICIDE IN JAILS
description: According to John J. Maffucci , the County's Commissioner of Correction, the apparent suicide of a prisoner in the Westchester County Jail nine days ago was an ''ironic'' coincidence but was not the reason that a seminar will be held Tuesday on ''Suicide Prevention and Recognition of Abnormal Behavior.''

title: LEAVE IT ALONE
description: President Reagan's embrace of Algeria's President this week should remind him that not all governments born in revolution are forever hostile. Marxist-Leninist incantations do not collect garbage or repair roads. The list of countries whose fiery founding parties ultimately settled into cautious pragmatism stretches (alphabetically) from Angola to Zimbabwe. Even our revolution was followed by a turbulent era in which critics were imprisoned and defiance was suppressed by brute force.

title:
SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY;

SCIENCE IN SHORT
description: THE INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY REVOLUTION. Edited by Tom Forester. (MIT, Cloth, $30. Paper, $14.95.)

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   7 Killed in Plane CrashOn Lake Michigan Island
description: Seven people were killed when a twin-engine plane crashed in a wooded area on Beaver Island in northern Lake Michigan, the authorities said today.

title: POWERFUL EASLER HAPPY IN BOSTON
description: IN his first 10 years of professional

title: SOME COAST DEMOCRATS DON'T WANT BRADLEY IN '86
description: Officeholders in the liberal wing of the California Democratic Party say they hope Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles will not run for Governor next year, as expected.

title: Dance
description: Two of the most interesting and individualistic modern-dance choreographers of the past few years will perform their work this week. Elizabeth Streb deals with vivid abstractions that most often involve feats of extreme athletic physicality.

title: MISS HAUPTMAN WED TO AARON A. EPSTEIN
description: Alison Hauptman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey J. Hauptman of North Brunswick, N.J., and Aaron Andrew Epstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira G. Epstein of Salisbury, Md., were married last evening at the Anshe Emeth Memorial Temple in New Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Bennett Miller performed the ceremony.

title: SOME REPECT FOR THE CIGAR, PLEASE!
description: OVER and above the understandably strong rhetoric surrounding America's fascination with tobacco, most especially cigarettes, somebody somewhere ought to recognize cigar smoking for what it is. A moment's repose, a moment's reverie.

title: CELTICS STRUGGLE TO WIN, 108-106
description: The opening round of the playoffs was supposed to to be a warm-up for the Boston Celtics for the better competition to come. Instead, the mighty Celtics were again forced to endure scary closing seconds today before they defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 108- 106, at Boston Garden.

title: DEBORAH WINCE WEDS IN CAPITAL
description: The marriage of Deborah Lynne Wince, a policy analyst at the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, to Andrew Wallis Falkiewicz, founder and president of Dunedin Corporation, management consultant in Washington, took place yesterday in Washington. The Rev. Terry L. Elsberry performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square.

title: EX-HEAD OF SPAIN'S COMMUNISTS PURGED FROM PARTY'S LEADERSHIP
description: Santiago Carrillo, a founder of Eurocommunism and a leader of the Spanish Communist Party for nearly 50 years, was expelled from the party's Central Committee on Friday night in a bitter dispute.

title: Artists in Education
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE TRUTH HURTS. By Jimmy Piersall with Richard Whittingham. (Contemporary Books, $15.95.)

title: SUIT SAYS SITE IN CAPITAL IS POTENTIAL SNIPER BASE
description: Three women have filed suit against the District of Columbia, saying the top four floors of a 12-story office building near the White House should be demolished because the 160-foot structure is a potential base for snipers.

title: LANGER LEADS BY A STROKE AFTER 69
description: Bernhard Langer, who won last week's Masters, came through the pack with a late rush and took a one-stroke lead today in the third round of the $400,000 Sea Pines Heritage Classic.

title: ANNE V. MONTGOMERY WEDS IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Anne Veith Montgomery, a daughter of Mrs. Henry Sanford and Wright Montgomery, both of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Alan MacDougall 3d, the son of Mr. MacDougall Jr. of Los Angeles, and the late Elizabeth Laughlin Douglas. The Rev. Max E. Smith performed the ceremony at St. Michael's of the Valley Episcopal Church in Ligonier, Pa.

title: ENCOURAGING CHILDREN IN THE 'LONESOME ART' OF COMPOSING
description: ELIDE SOLOMON knows about the frustrations of a composer's life. As a composer herself and a former teacher of composition, Mrs. Solomon, who is also the founder of the Purchase Music Ensemble, said she wanted to do her part to help make new musical works heard.

title: ANOTHER JAPANESE CAR MAKER BUYS AMERICA
description: Those ''foreign'' cars are becoming more domestic all the time. Anyone buying a Honda Accord east of the Mississippi River gets one assembled by Americans in rural Ohio. Nissan Sentras from Tennessee and Toyota Corollas from California bearing Chevrolet Nova emblems will go on sale soon. And last week came the announcement that Chrysler Corporation and Mitsubishi Motors Corporation had reached an agreement to manufacture subcompact cars jointly somewhere in the Middle West beginning in 1988.

title: NEW YORK AREA'S DROUGHT A MYSTERY
description: The winter was strangely warm and snow-scant. The autumn and spring rainstorms that normally strike the New York-New Jersey region have been veering away. High-altitude winds that guide weather patterns into the area have been off course.

title: IRENE BROWN WEDS JONATHAN GOMM
description: At St. James' Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Cecilia Ann Irene Browne, a daughter of Ina E. Browne of Austin, Tex., and Maj. Charles T. Browne, U.S.A.F. retired, of San Antonio, was married to Jonathan Townsend Gomm, the son of Mrs. Edward D. Gomm of Glens Falls, N.Y., and Morges, Switzerland, and the late Mr. Gomm. The Rev. Rubin Phillip performed the ceremony.

title: Nets Considering Benching Dawkins
description: With nearly seven months and 83 games behind them, a team just is not able make many technical adjustments. But according to Coach Chuck Daly, whose Pistons used a 125-105 rout of the Nets to take a 1-0 lead Thursday night in their three-of-five-game playoff series, the changes would not make much difference anyway.

title: THE HALLS OF BOSTON LATIN SCHOOL
description: RECENTLY, WHEN I returned to my secondary school, the Boston Latin School, for the first time in years, I initially thought I had stepped into a time warp. For, as I strolled its corridors and looked into its classrooms, I was immediately swept up in seven years' worth of memories - of knowledge and values learned, of failure turned to triumph, of friendships formed. I walked into its empty auditorium and, as when I was a student, the very air seemed to resound with names from its three- century-long alumni roster: Cotton Mather, Sam Adams, John Hancock, Ralph Waldo Emerson, George Santayana, Bernard Berenson, Leonard Bernstein. I felt I stood on hallowed ground, and it was wonderful to be there again.

title: MODERNIST IMAGES BY MAURER AR THE BENTON
description: ALONG with its major exhibition of Northern Renaissance painting, the University of Connecticut's Benton Museum is offering two other shows. Much smaller than the main attraction, these are nevertheless worth checking out. title: SOME THOUGHTS ON THINKERS AND THEIR RESPONSIBILITIES ;   THREE INTELLECTUALS TRY TO WRITE THEIR JOB DESCRIPTION
description: FOR all their intelligence (or perhaps because of it), intellectuals sometimes have trouble explaining themselves to the rest of the world. That seems particularly true when they turn from Dante and Descartes to subjects such as Central American and Ethiopia. Does an ivory tower afford an accurate perspective on politics? Do intellectuals have an obligation to speak out, and should they be listened to when they do? At a conference last weekend marking the 20th anniversary of the quarterly magazine Salmagundi at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., a panel of intellectuals discussed the nature of the job and the responsibilities that come with it. Its members were Conor Cruise O'Brien, Montgomery fellow at Dartmouth College and former Irish diplomat and politician; Leszek Kolakowski, Polish philosopher, fellow at All Souls College, Oxford University, and professor at the University of Chicago; and George Steiner, professor of comparative literature at University of Geneva and fellow of Churchill College, Cambridge University. Excerpts follow.

title:
GARDENING;

THE ADVANTAGES OF DIRECT SEEDING
description: A READER requested information about flowers that can be seeded directly in the garden without having to be transplanted. This method does present several advantages: Seeds usually cost less than plants; the extra work of transplanting is avoided and, not having to withstand the shock of being transplanted, many plants get off to a better start. Conversely, the one disadvantage is that seeding may lead to flowering that is later, since transplants have usually been started and grown indoors well ahead of the time when their seeds can be sown outdoors. But this disadvantage does not always hold true. A number of the so-called winter annuals can be seeded in the garden in early September. They will produce a small rosetta foliage before freezing that will withstand the ravages of winter. Among this group are Shirley poppy, annual larkspur, cornflower and California poppy. They should be protected with a winter mulch of salt hay or straw as one would protect perennials, applying the mulch after the soil has begun to freeze. These plants will start to develop as early as the frost leaves the ground in the spring and will be in flower earlier than all but the largest of greenhouse- started plants. Sweet peas are another old favorite that can be planted in the fall. They are best sown just before the soil freezes, so that they do not germinate until spring. The soil must be well drained so that the seeds do not rot, and they should be planted about six inches deep.

title: PHYSICS AND FICTION: ORDER FROM CHAOS
description: Today most laymen and indeed many scientists would regard as startling Sir Eddington's notions that ''Science aims at constructing a world which shall be symbolic of the world of commonplace experience.'' Surely what science does is not construction, but reduction, the dismantling of wholes into smaller and smaller parts. Surely its aim, if it has a general aim, is to explain the world, not manufacture symbols. And what has commonplace experience to do with particle accelerations, with genetic engineering, with the probing of the dark edges of the universe?

title: OSSINING RECALLS AUDUBON - AND HAVELL
description: THIS Friday, after blowing out the 200 candles and cutting up the birthday cake in honor of the naturalist John James Audubon, be sure to save a slice for Robert Havell Jr., late of Ossining.

title: Vanderbilt Coach Resigns NASHVILLE, April 20 (AP) - Vanderbilt's strength coach, E.J. (Doc) Kreis, resigned today after having been charged Friday in eight counts of a 97-count indictment with illegally selling steroids to athletes, the school's athletic director said.
description: Athletic Director Roy Kramer said that Kreis had not been asked by the university to resign, but that he had taken the initiative. Kreis, 31 years old, has been on a paid leave of absence since January when the Tennessee Bureau of Investigation began the probe that led to the indictment against Kreis and two others - M. Woody Wilson, a pharmacist, and a former employee of Wilson's.

title: Gold Wins, 51-0
description: Bob Gagliano threw four touchdown passes - three to Leonard Harris - to lead the Denver Gold (6-3) to a 51-0 United States Football League victory over the Los Angeles Express (2-7) tonight. Gagliano replaced Steve Young, who was sacked six times in the first half, and completed 17 of 25 passes for 297 yards, in just over three quarters of play.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Missouri Independence: Truman Road To Truman and Main One of the most appealing of trips is that from midtown Kansas City to Independence. The actual drive is only 12 miles - and those are not very interesting ones, a sad departure from the days when Independence was the starting point of both the Oregon and Santa Fe Trails. But a day in Independence offers a chance to steep oneself in the life and times of that simple and complex man, Harry S. Truman. (For visitors with time to spare, the town holds such other attractions as the courthouse where Truman sat as presiding county judge and a jail that once held Frank James.)

title: The Case of The President's Case

title: OUTLOOK FOR SUMMER JOBS CALLED PROMISING
description: A REDUCTION of $11.3 million in Federal funds for the summer jobs program will mean that more than 15,000 disadvantaged youths throughout New York State will not receive jobs this summer, according to state officials. But Westchester officials described the county's summer job outlook as good, predicting, in fact, that this year, as in the last few years, there may be more jobs than there are youths to fill them.

description: Grace Patricia Carley and Douglas Lawrence Kennedy were married yesterday in the Honan Chapel at University College in Cork, Ireland, by the Rev. Paul Taylor, a Roman Catholic priest. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Carley of Cork and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Kennedy of New York.

title: Leasing a Campus
description: As at other educational institutions, flagging enrollment at Fairleigh Dickenson University has lead to staff reductions and a narrowing of course offerings. In an effort to ease its financial crunch, the university, which has three main campuses in New Jersey, has granted a 50- year, $1.8 million land lease for the construction of an independent 175,000-square-foot conference center on its Florham Park-Madison campus in Morris County.

title: NEW YORK AIMS FOR THE TOP
description: MORE THAN ONCE IN RECENT months, knowledgeable observers of fashion have wondered whether a good many of the top American designers were slipping. As one season slid into another, the merchandise varied little in concept, design or fabrication. The same few ideas - big shirts, overscale jackets, short slim skirts, curtain-shirred cocktail dresses - were shown by almost all of them. Often, one well-known designer's interpretation was impossible to distinguish from a colleague's. In the aftermath of last fall's blanketlike obsession with man-tailored clothing - a season in which it was equally difficult to individualize designer offerings - this paucity of creativity, even of clever styling, justifiably produced an aura of apprehension.

More than 100 residents in the neighborhood have formed a group and hired a lawyer to oust a Holocaust studies center and to try to stop a proposed three-story office building.

title: JAZZ: GIORGIO GASLINI
description: IN a solo concert Friday at the Italian Institute of Culture, 686 Park Avenue, the pianist Giorgio Gaslini showed a distinctly European perspective on jazz. Mr. Gaslini, Italy's best-known jazz pianist, prizes the wit, drive, harmonic daring and melodic freedom of jazz; as an improviser, he can dip into almost any period of the music's history or toss off parodies of Classical styles. But he is impatient with straight-ahead swing and long melodic inventions.

title: HOLUCAUST BOARD UNLIKELY TO QUIT OVER REAGAN'S TRIP, MEMBER SAYS
description: A key member of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council said yesterday that the 65-member body, despite feelings of deep anguish, would probably not resign to protest President Reagan's planned visit next month to a German military cemetery.

title: Electric Storm Soccer can be an electrifying sport, especially in England, where charged-up fans have gone on a number of well-publicized rampages. Now officials of the Chelsea soccer club in London are planning a solution to such soccer-induced violence - an electrified fence to keep fans off the field.
description: Ken Bates, the club's chairman, said a fence with a live wire threaded through it would be installed at Chelsea's Stamford Bridge Stadium, where fans stormed the field and attacked a player and the police two months ago. London police officials said they would not oppose the plan.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Southern California A way of life in a nutshell beside the blue Pacific In a stretch of only 100 miles between Los Angeles and Santa Barbara lie most of the elements that contributed so vividly to the legend of the southern California life style. The soigne seclusion of the estates of Bel Air, the treasures of the J. Paul Getty museum, the elegant ease of the playland at Malibu, nature's splendid juxtaposition of mountain and sea are all there to be savored on a sunny, breezy day. And, at the end, there is Santa Barbara, with its old mission and fine shops, one of the loveliest small cities in the country.

title: A FIERCE BATTLE FOR LOCAL HEROES

title: 4 HOSPITALS REBUFFED ON CARDIAC UNITS

That service has had the highest utilization rate of the 10 existing open-heart units in New Jersey.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in Travel Advisory on March 31 omitted one of the dates of the Washington National Cathedral Annual Flower Mart. The event is scheduled for May 3 and 4.

description: George Papandreou and Andonis Samaras were friends at Amherst College in the 1970's, drawn together because they were the only Greeks in the class and both opposed the military dictatorship then governing their country.

title: THEORY ON AIR INDIA CRASH BACKED BY A PILOT
description: A British Airways pilot testified this week about a cockpit malfunction similar to what plaintiffs say caused a 1978 Air India crash that killed 213 people.

title: ABRAMS CRITICIZED OVER TAX INQUIRIES
description: The State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, is taking too long to prosecute cases involving charges of sales-tax evasion by luxury stores, the City Finance Commissioner has complained to his state counterpart.

title: ELLEN GALLAGHER WEDS
description: Eileen Marie Gallagher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Gallagher of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday to William F. Cullen Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cullen of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Paul McKeever performed the ceremony at the Holy Innocents Roman Catholic Church. The bride is the promotion and product manager for the Sam Flax Art and Drafting Supply Corporation in New York.
