description: Going On in the Northeast

title: SCIENCE IN SHORT
description: By James Elliot and Richard Kerr. (MIT, $17.50.) Until a decade of memorable discoveries beginning in 1974 it was widely assumed that Saturn was the only ringed planet.

title: THE HOME OF THE YUPPIES
description: Most Americans may think of Washington in terms of power, polity and pomp, a place where silver-haired lawmakers move magisterially down marble halls. But they've got it all wrong.

title: COUNTY PREPARES TO ACT ON WATER RESTRICTIONS
description: COUNTY and local officials are dusting off ordinances restricting water use that they enacted during the 1981 drought emergency, in anticipation of having to pass them once again by early May. Citing New York City's depleted reservoirs, from which Westchester draws nearly 85 percent of its water, they warn that the current shortage is more serious than the one four years ago.

title: Works of Art Without Emotion
description: In her review of the ''Artists of the Kennedy Era'' exhibit at Hofstra University (''Spirit of the 60's Revisited in Show,'' March 24), Phyllis Braff provides an erudite analysis of the works on display. For example, she uses standard reviewer's rhetoric: i.e. ''produces a rich visual experience,'' ''new vitality,'' ''an important example of the new artistic validity,'' etc.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: The number of annual abortions in New Jersey is leveling off, according to a study by the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a nonprofit organization based in New York City that conducts yearly surveys on abortions nationwide.

title: SAILOR SEEKS ATLANTIC MARK
description: Philippe Poupon, a French ocean racer, is on the lookout for bad weather. Not for anything particularly nasty, but for a sizable low front with winds brisk enough to speed his 85-foot catamaran, Fleury Michon VII, across the Atlantic Ocean in record time.

title: VOLUNTEER FORCE AIDS COUNTY
description: AS she approaches her 79th birthday in October, Lenore Brennan has nothing to do with sitting around in a rocking chair. Instead, she spends four days a week working on the ninth floor of the County Office Building in White Plains, editing Update, the monthly newsletter of the county government.

title: MASTERS AND SLAVES, FRIENDS AND ENEMIES - TRACKING THE LITERARY ROBOT
description: THE robot market is booming, not just in industry but in movies and publishing. The situation is reminiscent of the early 1940's, when magazines about airplanes and the men who flew them could be found on every newsstand. As airplanes grew more commonplace, these pulps vanished. Can we expect a similar passing of the robot craze?

title: Bennett Says SchoolsFail to Teach History
description: The Secretary of Education, William J. Bennett, questioning whether the schools teach values that ''make the case for our political system,'' said Friday that children must know more about history to recognize the Communist threat in Central America.

title: THEATER: 'SIDE EFFECTS,' BY A NEW PLAYWRIGHT
description: Every spring

title: PRESERVATION OF LAND BEGAN IN THE 1960's
description: THE 933,700 acres of Pine Barrens managed by the Federal and state governments are not the ''one million acres of wilderness'' touted by Brooke Shields in a current television commercial for tourism in New Jersey.

title: F.B.I. Says Crime Down,Except Rape and Assault
description: Reported crime decreased by 3 percent last year, including a 4 percent drop in murders, but rapes and aggravated assaults rose at the fastest pace since 1980, the Federal Bureau of Invetigation said today.

title:
GARDENING;

THE ADVANTAGES OF DIRECT SEEDING
description: A READER requested information about flowers that can be seeded directly in the garden without having to be transplanted. This method does present several advantages: Seeds usually cost less than plants; the extra work of transplanting is avoided and, not having to withstand the shock of being transplanted, many plants get off to a better start. Conversely, the one disadvantage is that seeding may lead to flowering that is later, since transplants have usually been started and grown indoors well ahead of the time when their seeds can be sown outdoors. But this disadvantage does not always hold true. A number of the so-called winter annuals can be seeded in the garden in early September. They will produce a small rosetta foliage before freezing that will withstand the ravages of winter. Among this group are Shirley poppy, annual larkspur, cornflower and California poppy. They should be protected with a winter mulch of salt hay or straw as one would protect perennials, applying the mulch after the soil has begun to freeze. These plants will start to develop as early as the frost leaves the ground in the spring and will be in flower earlier than all but the largest of greenhouse- started plants. Sweet peas are another old favorite that can be planted in the fall. They are best sown just before the soil freezes, so that they do not germinate until spring. The soil must be well drained so that the seeds do not rot, and they should be planted about six inches deep.

title: HEIDI GAFFNER, ACCOUNTANT, IS BRIDE OF FRED H. PERKINS
description: At Temple Gates of Prayer in Flushing, Queens, yesterday Heidi Ilyse Gaffner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Gaffner of Bayside, Queens, was married to Fred H. Perkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Lawrence Perkins of Westbury, L.I. Rabbi Mark Hillel Kunis performed the ceremony.

title: EMIGRES CRITICIZE U. S. NAZI-HUNTERS
description: Baltic and Ukrainian emigre organizations have accused the Justice Department's Nazi-hunting unit of using fraudulent evidence from the Soviet Union in its efforts to deport people accused of taking part in Nazi war crimes.

title: Canberra
description: To the Editor:

title: A REBEL NICARAGUA INDIAN LEADER IS PESSIMISTIC ON PEACE PROSPECTS
description: A leader of the Miskito Indian rebels says that after six months of talks with Nicaraguan officials, he has become deeply pessimistic about the prospect of reaching a peace agreement between the Indians and the Government.

title: Education Aides Decide to Drop Out
description: Around the Reagan Administration these days, few of the Government's civilian programs appear safe from attack - although that does not necessarily hold for the attackers. Last week, for example, two recently appointed officials of the Education Department, Dr. Eileen M. Gardner and Lawrence A. Uzzell, resigned after questions were raised about their past criticism of Federal programs for the handicapped.

title: FASTEST MARATHON
description: Carlos Lopes of Portugal, the Olympic champion, ran the world's fastest marathon today, shaving 54 seconds off the previous best time.

title: DONNA ANN FRANCIS IS MARRIED TO ALAN R. TWAITS
description: Donna Ann Francis, was married yesterday in Rutland, Vt., to Alan Richard Twaits. The Rev. Irving French performed the ceremony at Grace Congregational Church.

title: Eight Groups Oppose Dam on the Penobscot
description: Eight environmental groups have challenged a plan by the Great Northern Paper Company to build a hydroelectric dam across what they called ''the No. 1 threatened river in the country,'' the Penobscot in Maine.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

SAFETY LESSONS
description: A simulated smoke-filled room, a puppet show about sexual abuse and video tapes about seat belts will be among the offerings at Child Safety Awareness Day on Saturday, May 4, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., at the County Center.

title: SCIENCE IN SHORT
description: TIME'S ARROWS: Scientific Attitudes Toward Time. By Richard Morris. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.)

title: IN A CORNER OF CAIRO, A HAVEN FOR COPTIC ART
description: The young clerk who was opening the hotel safe to accept my cash and credit cards before I set out for the Coptic compound in Cairo pushed back one sleeve of her jacket and showed me the tattoo of a cross. ''I am a Copt,'' she said, pointing for corroboration to a badge on her lapel. Her given name was Christian.

title: New Leader in Sudan PleadsFor Additional Famine Relief
description: One million children may starve to death in the Sudan if urgent new famine relief is not provided, the nation's new ruler, Gen. Abdel Rahman Siwar el-Dahab, said today.

title: TOWARD A NEGOTIATED MUNICIPAL POLICY
description: SOCIETY does not function well unless there is a feeling among its members of mutual obligation, dependency and a willingness to sacrifice for the common good.

title: RAISING BOYS
description: Just a footnote to Louise Lague's article. We have five sons, now men ages 20 to 30, and feel somewhat knowledgeable about boys.

description: ank's Prospect Triumphs

title: CYNTHIA YATES IS WED
description: Cynthia Ann Yates, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sheldon Yates of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Richard Allen Starr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Peck Starr, also of New Canaan. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: WHERE LEADERS DINED AND MADE HISTORY
description: A museum has closed its doors in Paris. This was the restaurant known as Lucas-Carton on the Place de la Madeleine, founded in 1880 by a French chef, Francis Carton, and an English tavern keeper. Sometime this month a new restaurant known as Alain Senderens-Lucas Carton will open on the site, featuring the sort of nouvelle cuisine that brought renown to Mr. Senderens's former Paris restaurant, Archestrate.

title: IRREPLACEABLE ICONS LOST IN BROOKLYN CHURCH FIRE
description: St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Brooklyn shimmered in the warm midnight light cast by dozens of gilded, oil-burning lanterns.

title: SUSPECT WANTED IN SHOOTING OF MISSOURI TROOPER IS ARRESTED
description: A man found hiding today outside a motel just over the Missouri state line was identified by the authorities as David Charles Tate, a 22-year-old neo-Nazi extremist wanted in the machinegun murder of an Missouri state trooper.

title: DeLorean's Ex-Wife Weds ABC Executive
description: Two weeks after her divorce from John Z. DeLorean, the former automobile manufacturer, became final, Cristina Ferrare, today married Anthony Thomopoulos, president of the ABC Broadcast Group.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IWO JIMA: Legacy of Valor. By Bill D. Ross. (Vanguard, $22.50.)

title: TENURE DENIAL OF NOTED SOCIOLOGIST STIRS TROUBLING QUERIES AT HARVARD
description: Dr. Paul E. Starr, a 35-year-old sociologist, seemed about to taste one of academe's sweetest plums: tenure at Harvard.

title: ENIGMATIC ITALIAN WINES
description: A WINE TIDAL WAVE HIT THE UNITED STATES about 10 years ago. Almost overnight, the country found itself inundated, figuratively, by Italian white wine. And why not? The wine tasted good, it was well- made, it was cheap, and there was plenty of it. Soave, verdicchio, orvieto, frascati - they did not quite become household words, but anyone who drank wine knew they stood for quality at a reasonable price.

title: MERLE R. WOLDENBERG TO WED DAVID WOLFF
description: Dr. and Mrs. David H. Woldenberg of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Merle Ray Woldenberg to David Todd Wolff, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William A. Wolff of West Nyack, N.Y. A fall wedding is planned.

title: THE POETRY OF WAR
description: These lines of poetry about the battle at Seicheprey were written by an anonymous soldier of the Yankee Division, to which the Connecticut men of the 102d Infantry who fought at Seicheprey belonged. The poem was mailed to The Hartford Courant by two Connecticut soldiers, and was printed by the newspaper just before the division returned to the United States after the war.

title: SENATE DEBATES DEFICIT: LEADERSHIP SEEKS VOTES
description: The Senate begins debate next week on a plan to reduce next year's Federal deficit by $52 billion, with the Republican leadership acknowledging it does not have the votes to pass the compromise.

title: FOR A CHANGE, SOME IMPROVISATIONS
description: ONE of the things I enjoy most in the kitchen is improvising. It may sound strange, but I often enjoy making impromptu meals more than carefully planned ones, perhaps because they are such a challenge. I love excavating the recesses of the refrigerator for items to feed unexpected guests and coming up with interesting combinations.

title: Lakers Go Up By 2-0
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 24 points, 20 in the first half, as the Los Angeles Lakers gained a 147- 130 victory over the Phoenix Suns today and took a 2-0 lead in their opening National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: JURORS FAR FROM THE MADDING CROWD
description: Is a sequestered jury a hanging jury? If so, shouldn't a defendant's right to a fair trial include the right to insist that the jurors be allowed to go home at night where they might hear all about the trial on the evening news?

title: ETERNAL PRINCE, 5-2, CAPTURES THE WOOD
description: Eternal Prince, the speedball who set blistering fractions and drew away to score an upset in the Gotham Stakes two weeks ago, yesterday set a slow pace that carried him to an easy 2 3/4-length victory over Proud Truth and Rhoman Rule in the $346,500 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

A RUN FOR THE MONEY
description: Betsy Weiner of White Plains is reluctant to commit herself to a 5-kilometer run, even though she concedes that, for most people, ''it's not all that long.''

description: GREENBURGHA KNOCKOUT. The Oleg Cassini is an absolute knockout. That is what the tall, thin blonde trying it on said, and she was in a position to know - she was buying the slinky beaded number to wear at her third wedding.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

BIRTHDAY PAGEANT
description: The St. James Episcopal Church in North Salem is celebrating its 225th anniversary tonight. That means that it is actually 25 years older than the Episcopal diocese of New York, which has been in existence since 1785. Recently the diocese suggested that all of its churches commemorate the 200th anniversary, along with their own history, and at St. James that commemoration is taking the form of a pageant.

title: GEORGE F. GALLAND
description: George F. Galland, a lawyer who specialized in maritime law, died of cancer Wednesday in Alexandria, Va.

title: CLOSINGS SHOW AM'S FRAILTY
description: THE turntables have not spun in the studios of WNAB-AM for three weeks. The Bridgeport station was the third in the state to cease broadcasting this year because of financial difficulties.

title:
GARDENING;

THE ADVANTAGES OF DIRECT SEEDING
description: A READER requested information about flowers that can be seeded directly in the garden without having to be transplanted. This method does present several advantages: Seeds usually cost less than plants; the extra work of transplanting is avoided and, not having to withstand the shock of being transplanted, many plants get off to a better start. Conversely, the one disadvantage is that seeding may lead to flowering that is later, since transplants have usually been started and grown indoors well ahead of the time when their seeds can be sown outdoors. But this disadvantage does not always hold true. A number of the so-called winter annuals can be seeded in the garden in early September. They will produce a small rosetta foliage before freezing that will withstand the ravages of winter. Among this group are Shirley poppy, annual larkspur, cornflower and California poppy. They should be protected with a winter mulch of salt hay or straw as one would protect perennials, applying the mulch after the soil has begun to freeze. These plants will start to develop as early as the frost leaves the ground in the spring and will be in flower earlier than all but the largest of greenhouse- started plants. Sweet peas are another old favorite that can be planted in the fall. They are best sown just before the soil freezes, so that they do not germinate until spring. The soil must be well drained so that the seeds do not rot, and they should be planted about six inches deep.

description: President Reagan said today that the Soviet Union had ''military personnel'' in the battle zones of northern Nicaragua near the Honduran border.

title: Gypsies Protest Exclusion From Holocaust Rites in U.S.
description: An American Gypsy representative charged Friday that gypsies were being excluded from the Days of Remembrance observances even though 500,000 Gypsies were killed by the Nazis.

title: SHE'S NOBODY'S STEREOTYPE NOW
description: THERE'S an unpleasant little story that makes the cocktail party circuit from time to time. It concerns the suburban matron who boasts that she chauffeurs her child everywhere. ''But can't he walk?'' queries a city friend.

description: Governor Cuomo this week approved legislation raising the basic welfare grant by 10 percent.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Northern California San Francisco to Eureka (with a side trip to Samoa) Whoever was in charge decided to hide some of the most glorious parts of Northern California beyond a jumble of mountains. You are going to have to travel some tortuous roads to see it all. The good news about the hairpin turns is that they require you to drive slowly for a good part of the way between San Francisco and the Mendocino Coast. That way, you get to enjoy the creeks and redwood groves, or even see that there really are clusters of wine grapes on those vines growing out of rocky soil on the mountain slopes. Following this route makes it about 300 miles north from San Francisco to Eureka. Driving time is about seven hours.

title: AT COLUMBIA, THE STAGE IS FAMILIAR BUT THE DRAMA IS DIFFERENT
description: Columbia University administrators spent another week negotiating with students protesting the school's investment policies, then ended the week in what both sides reluctantly accepted as the only possible position - face to face in more negotiations in the chambers of a State Supreme Court judge.

title: SCIENCE IN SHORT
description: By Bernard Lovell. (Oxford University, $19.95.) Astronomers would seem to be primarily concerned with quasars, black holes and other heavenly objects, but Sir Bernard Lovell, the director of England's Jodrell Bank radio astronomy center, also knows about such earthly matters as reinforced concrete, trunnion bearings and bureaucrats.

title: COURTS SUBSTITUTE SERVICE FOR JAIL TERMS
description: ONE night last summer, Mark Rutledge was heading home from a neighborhood pub where he had stopped for several drinks after a softball game.

title: PENTAGON ASSERTS 'STAR WARS' TESTS WON'T BREAK PACT
description: The Defense Department has issued a broad interpretation of the 1972 treaty on antiballistic missiles that would clear the way for extensive testing of weapons designed under the program known as ''Star Wars.''

title: NEEDY FORM A GROUP TO PUSH AUTHORITIES FOR SHELTER AND JOBS
description: A union of the homeless and the unemployed has been organized here to give its members the things most people take for granted: a clean bed, food and a job.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Washington, D.C. Out through the hunt country, back by the canal There are more things to see and do in Washington than in almost any other American city. But what to see and do on that Sunday or free weekday when, suddenly, you yearn to escape the urban bonds? One answer is a leisurely afternoon drive up the Virginia side of the Potomac to historic Leesburg and Waterford, followed by a trip on a Rube Goldberg-ferry across the river to the Maryland shore, thence a return drive along the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal back into the city. The trip is 75 to 100 miles in length, and takes four to five hours, depending on how often you have been diverted by rural vistas, Civil War markers and curiosity.

title: LORI SCHWIND WEDS
description: At St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Ramsey, N.J., yesterday Lori A. Schwind, an account executive with H/K Public Relations in New York, was married to James G. Murray, the senior architect for the City of Jersey City.

description: From early morning, clusters of clerks materialized in the streets to scrape mud from the curbs, professors donned jeans to plant shrubs around the university and factory workers reported for an extra day of work with red ribbons tied to their coveralls.

description: SPRING 1960: Think we finally found it. Three big rooms, it's clean, and only 85 a month! Bad news: It's a basement apartment. Good news: We're only a half-hour from work.

title: NEW YORK CITY ADDS 26 TO INSPECT FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Health Department says it has hired 26 new inspectors to insure that every one of the city's 14,500 restaurants and coffee shops will be inspected by the end of June.

title: MINORITIES IN NEW ZEALAND PUSH FOR EQUALITY
description: At first glance, it might seem that blond hair and blue eyes are almost a residency requirement in New Zealand, so dominant are the descendents of the English immigrants who came here by the boatfull in the mid-19th century.

title: RETIREE, 74, IS NAMED VOLUNTEER OF YEAR
description: ALTHOUGH William E. Goff retired in 1975, for the last few years he has been working as hard as ever. This week he will be honored as Westchester's Volunteer of the Year by the Volunteer Service Bureau of Westchester. ''I do whatever I find needs to be done,'' said the 74-year-old Peekskill resident.

title: ON THE ROAD FROM SEA TO SEA: TIMES CORRESPONDENTS MAP THEIR FAVORITE ROUTES
description: Arizona The Sonoran Desert in all its surprising variety Travel in the Sonoran desert presents a particular challenge to the adept and interested traveler. ''Desert,'' after all, is a word we use for wasteland, a place without any engaging quality. And although the Sonoran desert is at times so lush it should be ashamed to call itself a desert, the thousands of Indians on their way across the Papago reservation or the copper miners on their way to the pit at Ajo, probably consider the drive west from Tucson nothing but two hours of high speeds and tedium.

title: Test on Smoking Attitudes
description: Twelve day care centers here will participate in a program testing 4- and 5-year-olds to determine what effect education has on their attitudes about smoking. ''We're trying to determine if this is an appropriate age group to learn about health,'' said Peggy Marshall, a public health educator. The program, financed by a $4,000 state grant, will get under way in May.

title: NEW ORLEANS ZEST IN STAMFORD
description: SOME restaurants sound the right note from the beginning. Often success or failure depends less on the food than on a winning combination of ambiance, location and timing.

title: Talking Expansion ;   Putting 2 Co-ops Together
description: NEW YORKERS dream about extra living space the way an ambitious king fantasizes about enlarging his realm. In these days of co-op living, the dream often centers on the apartment next door.

title: NONPROFIT GROUPS SAID TO FACE BIG CUTS IN U. S. AID
description: Approval of the Reagan Administration's proposed cuts in domestic spending would cause a substantial loss for the country's 125,000 nonprofit organizations that are active in social welfare, education, health, research, employment and the arts, according to a new analysis by the Urban Institute.

title: PLAYING OR NOT, SMITH AFFECTS THE GAME
description: The man buying popcorn at the Spectrum Thursday night unfolded the cardboard sign he was carrying under his arm: ''We Ain't Scared of Smith. We Want Him.''

description: Joe Dial broke the Kansas Relays pole-vault record he set Friday by soaring 18 feet 8 inches today. The Oklahoma State senior had broken the previous record Friday with 18-5. Today, he cleared 18-8 on his first attempt to beat Steve Stubblefield.
