description: The House subcommittee that spearheaded investigations of the General Dynamics Corporation reportedly plansto release evidence on Tuesday that another major military contractor, the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group, improperly billed the Pentagon for a wide range of personal entertainment expenses.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 22, 1985: *2*MONDAY Airborne Freight Lubrizol Corp Associated Dry Goods Phila Elec Co Dana Corp Public Serv CoInd Edison Bros Stores Rohm & Hass Heck's Inc Sea-Land Corp *2*TUESDAY Allied Stores Norfolk Southern Amsted Indus Norwest Corp Ball Corp Outboard Marine Corp Belo (AH) Corp Overnite Transp Black Hills P & L Public Serv Co NMBurndy Corp Robins (AH) Co Central Ill Lt Rollins Inc Cincinnati Milacron Rubbermaid Inc Copperweld Corp Santa Fe So Pacific Fleming Cos Schering-Plough Great Western Fin Southwest Gas Corp Johnson & Johnson Southwestern Pub Serv Kaiser Alum & Chem Standard Oil Ind Kentucky Utilities Tambrands Inc Loral Corp Thrifty Corp NUI Corp USLIFE Corp *2*WEDNESDAY Alltel Corp Minnesota Pwr & Lt Baker Intl Oneida Ltd Bearings Inc Panhandle Eastern Belding Heminway Philips Indus Bethlehem Steel Potomac Elec Pwr Dennison Mfg Reynolds (RJ) Indus Du Pont Sherwin-Williams Eaton Corp SmithKline Beckman Equifax Inc Standard Pacific Corp Exxon Corp Standex Intl Grainger (WW) Sybron Corp Hercules Inc Transworld Corp Hexcel Corp Trico Industries Houghton Mifflin Tyler Corp Hughes Tool Winconsin Elec Pwr Inland Steel *2*THURSDAY Bausch & Lomb Natl Distillers & Chem Butler Intl Inc Norton Company Corning Glass Works Oakite Products Delta Air Lines (Del)Olin Corp Dexter Corp Pan American BKS Donnelly (RR) & Sons Pennzoil Co Dravo Corp RLC Corp Empire District Elec Sealed Air Corp Entex Inc Smith Intl Inc Handy & Harman Sonat Inc Iowa-Ill G & E Standard Oil Ohio Jostens Inc Tex Amer Bancshares Mead Corp UAL Inc Morton-Thiokol Inc WICOR Inc Nalco Chemical *2*FRIDAY Brown & Sharpe Mfg Sargent-Welch Duke Power Snap-On Tools Ferro Corp Sun Banks Inc Holly Sugar Corp TNP Enterprises Indiana Gas Co Tenneco Inc Kysor Industrial US Leasing Intl L&N Housing Corp Univar Corp McDonnell Douglas Warnaco Inc Mobil Corp Zero Corp Rowan Cos *2*SATURDAY Saga Corp Wackenhut Corp

title: Topics ;   Wrapped in Sheets
description: Pharaoh's GenesCan the dead be brought to life? The answer is still no, but maybe with a caveat. A Swedish scientist claims to have cloned hereditary material from cells of a mummified Egyptian infant that died 2,400 years ago.

title: Game Ended by Fight
description: An international semifinal soccer match between Brooklyn College and Nepal was halted with two minutes left after a scuffle broke out between players today with the Brooklyn team leading by 2-0.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: TRADE PAPERBACKS RESHAPING BOOK PUBLISHING
description: For more than a century, the hard- cover book has been the mainstay of American book publishing, unchallenged in its prestige and durability. It is still the choice of collectors and libraries, and established authors still want to be published first in that format. But the hard cover is now losing its commanding position to the paperback, particularly the trade paperback - that larger-sized, higher-priced paper format that has long been dominant in much of the world.

title: Man Freed on Bail After Toxic Blaze
description: A Dover Township man is free on $1,000 bail after being charged with creating a hazardous situation that led to more than 80 firefighters, police officers and paramedics going to hospitals.

title: MURCER FAILS
description: The rehabilitation of Rickey Henderson, the most recent executive task assigned to Bobby Murcer, assistant to the vice president for the Yankees, was concluded today and considered a success. The return of Murcer as a 38-year-old designated hitter for the Class A Fort Lauderdale Yankees of the Florida State League was a painful reminder that there is little room for a romantic in the sport of baseball.

title: Poland Said to Arrest Clandestine Publisher
description: The fugitive director of a major underground publishing house has been captured by the police and led off to detention with his head wrapped in a bloody hood, according to sources close to the outlawed Solidarity movement.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Acura Car Account Goes to Ketchum Unit
description: American Honda Motors in Gardena, Calif., has decided to give the advertising assignment for its new Acura car to Ketchum, San Francisco.

title: HEADED FIGHTER COMMAND IN U. S.
description: Gen. Jerome F. O'Malley, commander of the United States Air Force Tactical Air Command, died Saturday in the crash of a military aircraft at Wilkes-Barre/Scranton International Airport. He was 53 years old.

title: ROYALS DEFEAT TIGERS IN 13TH, 3-2
description: Everybody dreams of beating the champion, and for the Kansas City Royals outfielder Darryl Motley, that dream came true today.

title: Nonaligned Parley Urges Curbs on South Africa
description: The 101 nations of the nonaligned movement urged today that the United States and other Western powers cut diplomatic ties with South Africa and impose economic sanctions on that country because of delays in achieving the independence of South-West Africa.

title: KOHL SAYS SHAME OF NAZIS PERSISTS
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, at a ceremony marking the 40th anniversary of the liberation of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, said today that he accepted Germany's ''historical responsibility for the crimes of the Nazi tyranny.''

title: INSURANCE PROBLEMS HINDER ASBESTOS REMOVAL AT SCHOOLS
description: The difficulty contractors face in getting liability insurance for the removal of asbestos insulation is expected to impede the scheduled removal of that hazardous material from schools around the country this summer.

title: Prof. Warren Susman, Rutgers Historian, Dies
description: Prof. Warren I. Susman, a cultural historian whose writings were published this year in a collection called ''Culture as History: The Transformation of American Society in the 20th Century,'' died of a heart attack Saturday while addressing the national convention of the Organization of American Historians in Minneapolis. He was 58 years old and lived in Highland Park, N.J.

title: 3 INDIAN PITCHERS HANDCUFF YANKEES, 3-0
description: Julio Franco returned yesterday. If only Brett Butler and Dave Von Ohlen had disappeared for the day, the Yankees might have been able to take another game from Cleveland.

title: Miss Phillips Weds Craig Bloomgarden
description: Stacy Donna Phillips, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald F. Phillips of New York, was married yesterday to Craig S. Bloomgarden, a son of Babette D. Bloomgarden of Hartford and the late Henry S. Bloomgarden of Reston, Va. Rabbi Zvi Dershowitz, assisted by Cantor Meir Finkelstein, performed the ceremony at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

title: 20 PRESUMED DEAD
description: An Israeli gunboat sank an Arab ''terrorist vessel'' with 28 people aboard in an exchange of fire off the Israeli coast Saturday night, a military spokesman announced early today.

title: DEADLINE SET FOR PULLOUT
description: The Israeli Cabinet decided today to complete the withdrawal of troops from Lebanon by early June, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin announced. No precise date was made public.

title: Chase Ohio Bid Backed by Fed WASHINGTON, April 21
description: The Federal Reserve

title: PUTTING A VALUE ON CBS ASSETS
description: CBS INC., now fighting a takeover bid by Ted Turner, has a private market value estimated at between $180 and $200 a share, according to most Wall Street analysts.

title: How Private Nature-Preserve System Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Why a Sex-Education Program Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Drinking Reduced After Law Change
description: Drinking by 17- and 18-year-olds dropped after New York State raised the legal age for the purchase of alcoholic beverages to 19 from 18 in December 1982, a new study indicates.

title: SETBACKS IN LONG-DISTANCE
description: For a business whose fortunes once seemed boundless, the long-distance telephone industry has reported its share of disturbing news recently.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS ;   A Subtle Business
description: Bob Horan was sharing some secrets the other day about how to organize one of those celebrity summer baseball camps, the ones you see advertised promising major league stars as instructors for young hopefuls.

title: Expelled Soviet Envoy Leaves Britain Protesting Innocence
description: A Soviet diplomat ordered out of Britain as a spy left London for Moscow today protesting his innocence.

title: MITSUBISHI MOTORS GREETS MATURITY
description: For Toyoo Tate, the president of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, last Monday marked the day his company came of age.

title: Jules Weiss, Retired Builder Who Aided La Mama Theater
description: Jules Weiss, a former member of the board of directors of the La Mama Experimental Theater Company and a retired builder, died of a heart attack in his Greenwich Village home Saturday. He was 72 years old.

title: GLASS COURTS USED FOR SQUASH
description: New Yorkers will get their first look at professional squash racquets' new ''fishbowl'' court when the Drakkar North American Squash Open comes to Broadway this week.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Chairman Disappointed At National Intergroup
description: Howard M. Love, chairman of National Intergroup Inc., knew that his meeting last week with the chairman of the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, Emil P. Martini Jr., might be unpleasant.

title: EX-OFFICER RECOUNTS AN ORDER TO LEAVE AREA OF RIGHTS RALLY
description: -SALEM, N.C., April 21 - A former police officer has testified that she and another officer were ordered to leave the area of a march against the Ku Klux Klan in 1979 shortly before five demonstrators were shot dead in Greensboro.

title: RUDI GERNREICH, AVANT-GARDE DESIGNER, DIES
description: Rudi Gernreich, the country's leading avant-garde designer during the 1950's and 60's, died of cancer yesterday at the Cedar Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 62 years old and lived in Hollywood Hills, Calif.

title: HIGH TECH AT THE SUMMIT
description: PARIS Advanced technology has become a major European issue,

title: TOURNEY GIVES GOLF LEGENDS SECOND GO-ROUND
description: AFTER dinner one evening during the 1963 Masters tournament, Gene Sarazen phoned the Augusta National Golf Club to learn his tee time for the next day's round. After he hung up, the golfer whose double-eagle 2 had put the Masters on the map in 1935 turned to his friend Fred Raphael and smiled.

title: More Traders See Rate Drop
description: After three months of vacillation over the next move in monetary policy and interest rates, an increasing number of market participants decided last week that rates are headed lower and that the Federal Reserve will signal its intentions by reducing the discount rate it charges on loans to financial institutions.

title: Envoys of New Sudan Leader In Libya to Discuss Relations
description: Two members of Sudan's ruling Transitional Military Council went to Libya today for talks on improving relations, the official Sudanese press agency quoted a military spokesman as saying.

title: 76ers Rout Bullets, Go 2 Up
description: Moses Malone of the 76ers scored only 10 points, but held Jeff Ruland to 12, and with the centers neutralizing each other, Philadelphia had the advantage and beat the Washington Bullets today, 113-94. The 76ers gained 2-0 edge in the three-of-five National Basketball Association opening playoffs; the third game is Wednesday night at Landover, Md.

title: Let the 'Gas' Wars Continue
description: Responding to the lobbying of independent gasoline dealers, more and more state governments are pushing oil companies out of the retail business. Four states have sharply restricted company operations. Maryland has forced refiners to close or sell all their own stations. Similar measures are pending in a dozen legislatures.

title: Wendy Peshkin Wed To Stanley D. Forkner
description: Wendy Ann Peshkin was married in Weston, Conn., yesterday to Stanley Delafield Forkner, a son of Mrs. William A. Cameron of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Dr. Claude E. Forkner Jr. of New York and Sharon, Conn. Judge Samuel S. Freedman of the Connecticut Superior Court performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Peshkin, parents of the bride.

title: CHINA NAMES ENVOY TO U. S., A CHOICE HAILED AS SIGN OF AMITY
description: China announced today that Han Xu, a Deputy Foreign Minister who was a close aide to Prime Minister Zhou Enlai, will become its Ambassador to the United States.

title: DANCE: TORONTO TROUPE PERFORMS IN BROOKLYN
description: A major dance series got off to an excellent start this weekend by giving New Yorkers a first view of a new and very talented modern-dance choreographer, Christopher House.

title: U.S. Falloff Welcomed In Europe
description: Figures released Thursday showing a sharp first-quarter slowdown in United States economic growth are being widely welcomed in Europe.

title: NEW YORK TO SHIFT COURT PROCEDURES TO SPEED DECISIONS
description: New York State court officials intend to reorganize the way judges are assigned criminal and civil cases in an effort to speed dispositions, better measure judicial productivity and hold lawyers and prosecutors more accountable.

title: LEDGERS NOTE WEALTH OF MARTHA WASHINGTON
description: The stained and faded pages of one of George Washington's meticulous ledgers have revealed details of how much wealth his wife, Martha, brought to their marriage.

title: ASIA'S DEVELOPING NATIONS THRIVE
description: The developing countries of Asia, aided by increased exports and lower oil bills, continued to register strong economic gains last year, averaging 5.5 percent growth in 1984, according to the Asian Development Bank.

title: 'TV HALL OF FAME' AWARDS ON NBC
description: IN the awards industry, ''The

title: CUBS' ECKERSLEY SHUTS OUT EXPOS
description: Dennis Eckersley said he believed that the Chicago Cubs' pitching staff was underrated, and few would argue with him after the right-hander pitched his second consecutive shutout today in defeating the Montreal Expos, 4-0.

title: CIVILIAN PRESIDENT-ELECT
description: President-elect Tancredo Neves was chosen to head the first Brazilian civilian Government in 21 years on a wave of popularity unmatched by any ruler in the country's history.

title: SPRING TRAINING IN JAPAN, OR HOW A BOW IS BORN
description: This is the season when young Japan is taught how to bow.

title: S. I. CHIEF'S ROLE IN DEAL TO BE STUDIED
description: The Department of Investigation announced yesterday that it would conduct an inquiry into efforts by Borough President Ralph J. Lamberti of Staten Island to help a former business partner develop a shopping center on city- owned land.

title: SSC&B Reorganization By New Vice Chairman
description: Frank DeVito, who last fall arrived at SSC&B:Lintas USA from Young & Rubicam, to be vice chairman and director of creative services, announced a reorganization Friday of his department, which will have the second layer of management cut from eight to four executive creative directors.

title: Fire Damages Gas Refinery
description: An explosion and fire heavily damaged more than half of the Warren Petroleum Gas Refinery early this morning, but plant operators quickly cut the gas line and prevented the blaze from spreading to the rest of the plant. Firefighters were able to put out the fire within the hour, and no injuries were reported. The cause of the explosion was not immediately determined.

title: R. H. Mond, a Lawyer, Is Wed to Susan Potter
description: Susan Potter and Richard Harris Mond were married in New Rochelle, N.Y., yesterday. Rabbi David M. Frank, assisted by Rabbi Reuben Katz and Cantor Harry Altman, performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of New Rochelle.

title: Houston Fire Chief Defends Resignation
description: Fire Chief Robert L. Swartout says he did not think he owed the city of Houston more than the five minutes' notice he gave when he quit after three and a half months on the job.

title: CUMMINGS HITS 30 AS BUCKS TRIUMPH
description: Successive baskets by Terry Cummings, Paul Pressey and Craig Hodges in the fourth quarter helped the Milwaukee Bucks prevail for a 122-115 victory over the Chicago Bulls today.

title: Legal Arm-Wrestling
description: Lawyers in Washington and New York City have debated informally for years which city is the real legal capital of the nation. As a great financial and communications center, New York boasts many of the most venerable and powerful law firms.

title: REBEL FLAG SETTING OFF CIVIL WARS
description: For the first time in years, the mammoth 20-by-40- foot Confederate battle flag did not fly this spring in front of the Kappa Alpha fraternity house at Auburn University.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS ;   Calling All Joneses
description: If you wonder why they assign nicknames to competitors in the Bobby Jones Annual Golf Open at the University of Michigan, just try putting the entry list in alphabetical order: Robert A. Jones, Robert A. Jones, Robert B. Jones - well, you get the idea.

title: STOCKMAN, FISCAL MERLIN, IN MAKE-OR-BREAK BATTLE
description: In four years as budget chief, David A. Stockman has come to personify the Reagan Administration's highest domestic goal: a permanent reduction in the size and scope of the Federal Government.

title: People
V. F. Prada Weds Jana Beth Singer
description: Jana Beth Singer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ellis P. Singer of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Vincent F. Prada, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Prada of Edgartown, Mass. Rabbi David Straus performed the ceremony at the Tavern on the Green in Manhattan.

title: STALLIONS' DEFENSE HALTS BANDITS, 30-3
description: Cliff Stoudt passed for two touchdowns and Joe Cribbs scored twice, and the Birmingham Stallions stifled the United States Football League's top offense to defeat the Tampa Bay Bandits, 30-3, today.

title: For $150, You Can Buy City Seal - in Cast Iron
description: Dexter and Sinister are the most

title: Israel Backs Free-Trade Zone
description: The Israeli Cabinet approved an agreement today to establish a free-trade zone with the United States, a cabinet communique said.

title: ARGENTINE COUP PLOT IS REPORTED
description: President Raul Alfonsin, appealing for unity, declared on national television tonight that the Argentine armed forces had rebuffed civilian attempts to involve the military in a coup.

title: NEVER SWORN IN
description: The Brazilian President-elect, Tancredo Neves, died tonight from complications following intestinal surgery that had prevented him from taking office as the country's first civilian ruler in 21 years. He was 75 years old.

title: RUDOLF GNAGI
description: Rudolf Gn"agi, twice the President of Switzerland, died today after suffering a heart attack, a Defense Ministry spokesman said.

title: STRENGTHS FOUND IN MILITARY FAMILIES
description: Often considered outsiders in civilian communities and long belittled as ''Army brats,'' ''service wives'' and ''military dads,'' the members of military families are increasingly becoming the focus of studies by social scientists seeking to understand and treat them.

title: 6,000 CATHOLICS GATHER ON L. I. TO MARK SPIRITUAL RENEWAL
description: They came to renew their faith, to hold out their arms, to reach down into their souls for the voice of the Spirit that they felt rested within them. About 6,000 Roman Catholics gathered at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum this weekend to celebrate their charismatic renewal - a return to a fundamental, spiritual expression of the Gospel.

title: U. S. Prison Population Reaches a Record Level
description: State and Federal prisons held nearly 464,000 people at the end of 1984, a record inmate population for the 10th consecutive year that has forced officials to find more space, the Government reported today.

title: NEW CONTRACT FOR DOORMEN AVERTS STRIKE
description: Owners of residential buildings and the union representing 30,000 apartment-house workers reached a tentative agreement early yesterday, averting a threatened walkout by employees in four boroughs.

title: Pentagon Audit Assails Cost Control Program
description: A Pentagon audit of the procedures for buying spare parts says changes aimed at cutting waste and abuse have resulted in ''significantly overstated'' savings.

title: ANXIETY GROWING OVER PERU'S DEBT
description: By last summer, Peru's creditors had reluctantly concluded that no solution to the country's foreign debt problem would be possible before a new government takes office here on July 28.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS ;   John Henry's Riches
description: John Henry, the 10-year-old gelding who rewrites the record books every time he goes to the post, is training in California for a summer return to the races. Each time he runs, he will be trying to add to his career earnings of $6,597,947, which are almost twice what was banked by Slew o' Gold, his closest competitor on the thoroughbred money list.

title: A Tryout for Palm Trees For Battery Park City
description: The midday darkness of lower Manhattan is about to descend on a tiny patch of the Mojave Desert in California.

title: KRISTIANSEN WINS LONDON MARATHON
description: Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway, tiring over the final stages, held on tenaciously today and won the London Marathon for the second consecutive year. Her time of 2 hours 21 minutes 6 seconds established a world best.

title: EX-PRESIDENT FEELS AT HOME IN JERSEY
description: Save for the time an escaped buffalo wandered through town, people here are generally unaccustomed to the arrival of exotic visitors.

title: BROKERAGE FALL HURTS 'INNOCENTS'
description: UNTIL March 19, the only ''certainty'' that commodity futures and options traders could count on was that the margin money placed with their brokers was ''untouchable,'' because Federal law requires that such funds be segregated.

title: PLEA TODAY BY PICKENS FOR DELAY
description: T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, will try today to persuade major shareholders of the Unocal Corporation to postpone the April 29 annual meeting for 60 days until the outcome of his bid to obtain control of the California oil giant is decided.

title: Deborah Glass Is a Bride
description: Deborah Glass, a lawyer with the National Labor Relations Board in Washington, and Ira Schwartz, a photographer with the Associated Press in Washington, were married at the Calvert Collection there yesterday.

title: YOUTH'S CHARGES OF TORTURE BY AN OFFICER SPUR INQUIRY
description: The Queens District Attorney and the police said yesterday that they were investigating allegations that a teen-ager arrested last week on a charge of selling a small amount of marijuana was beaten and tortured with electric shocks by a police officer in a station house.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE RIGHT DIRECTION Directors usually speak to audiences indirectly, through the work they put on film or on stage. They are not rarities in public places, but it is unusual to have two eminent directors discussing their craft at a public forum.

title: MR. ED, THE BEAVER AND TOSTITOS
description: -Locke agency, discovered that it is one thing to get the idea of adapting the ''Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid'' and ''Zelig'' concept to television commercials, but it is quite another to deliver. It required hours of intent watching of old black-and-white TV series. Is anything worth that?

title: ISSUE OF MISSING IN VIETNAM HAS NOT FADED AFTER DECADE
description: Donald Shay's father is retired now. Donald's little sister has two young children of her own. His fiancee finally married someone else. And Donald's mother doesn't bake his favorite apple pie much anymore; the good smell brings back too many bad memories.

title: Bonnett Edges Waltrip
description: Neil Bonnett edged a teammate, Darrell Waltrip, by one car-length today today to post his second victory of the Nascar season in the Northwestern Bank 400 Grand National stock car race.

title: BIG DAY IN PHILLY
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
WASHINGTON WATCH ;   Battle Over Brokered Deposits
description: The row over brokered deposits - funds placed at banks or thrift institutions by money brokers in chunks of $100,000 to secure full Federal deposit insurance - is continuing on two fronts: in the courts and on Capitol Hill.

title: UNION POLITICS PLAYS KEY ROLE IN CITY LABOR PACTS
description: The tentative settlement reached last week between the city and its largest municipal union underscores a little-understood but central reality of labor negotiations in New York City: that personalities and the dynamics of union politics often have as much - if not more - to do with a labor settlement than does substance. The cost of the pact that won approval last Wednesday night does not differ significantly from a proposal rejected overwhelmingly by the Uniformed Firefighters Association just last month. Some analysts even believe that the new contract is slightly less generous than the rejected one, though it does depend on who is doing the analyzing.

title: SAN FRANCISCO CABLE CARS ROLL, BUT NOT SMOOTHLY
description: No matter how happy the tourists are with the renovation of San Francisco's cable cars, people who live here have been expressing discontent for several months.

title: AMERICAN ARTS FESTIVAL FOR BRITAIN
description: The most extensive celebration of the American arts ever held in Europe is to take place in London and other British cities next month under the patronage of the Duke of Edinburgh.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Are there any major leaguers who hit more than 500 home runs and stole more than 200 bases in their careers? How about the opposite - 500 stolen bases and 200 homers?

title: 1ST QUARTER EARNINGS LACKLUSTER
description: Corporate profits in the first quarter, mirroring the weak 1.3 percent economic growth rate figure released by the Commerce Department last week, generally appear to be disappointing, according to economists.

title: SHUTLZ SAYS ARABS HURT PALESTINIANS BY BLOCKING TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz declared today that Arab leaders were prolonging the suffering of Palestinians by not supporting direct negotiations between Israel and Jordan.

title: WOMEN, MEN AND MACHINES
description: MEN are not born knowing how to assemble bicycles, build furniture or install stereo units that look like control panels in lunar landing modules. Nor are women naturally inept in the presence of gears and wires. Yet a number of psychologists, sociologists and students of technology note that people often relate to machines as if being mechanically minded were a sex-linked trait.

title: Homfeld Captures Final in Jumping
description: Conrad Homfeld of Petersburg, Va., won the seventh annual F.E.I.- Volvo World Cup Show jumping finals yesterday in West Berlin.

title: BANKER MAY PLEAD GUILTY
description: Jake Butcher, the former head of the $1.5 billion United American Bank and a two-time candidate for Governor of Tennessee, is expected to plead guilty Monday to bank fraud charges, according to sources close to the case. He would thus avoid the first of five trials pending on charges that he defrauded his bank of millions of dollars before it failed in February 1983.

title: BRAZILIAN TAKES PORTUGAL PRIX
description: Ayrton Senna of Brazil led all the way in winning the Portuguese Grand Prix today on a rain-soaked track for his first career victory.

title: Lexicon
description: Finance ministers and central bank governors from 148 countries have been discussing world monetary problems recently in Washington at meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The working language has been English, but someone new to the meetings might have thought it was Basque, for many terms have been minted to fit the crisis at hand. Following is a lexicon for the uninitiated:

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Chief Is Appointed At Louisiana Utility
description: James M. Henderson, chairman and chief executive of the Central Louisiana Electric Company since July 1983, has retired because of ill health, the utility announced.

title: Helen Wolff Awarded 1985 Goethe Medal
description: Helen Wolff, the American publisher, has been awarded the Goethe Medal this year by Goethe House, the German cultural institute in New York, in recognition of her contributions to international publishing.

title: Storer Studies Takeover Bid
description: Storer Communications Inc. confirmed yesterday that its board met during the weekend to discuss a takeover attempt by dissident shareholders but that no action was taken.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH ;   A NEW PLAN TO BUY CONRAIL
description: WASHINGTON A new suitor may be in the offing for Conrail, the Government-controlled railroad, which the Administration is trying to sell to the Norfolk Southern Corporation for $1.2 billion and other considerations.

title: THREE IN SPOTLIGHT AS DERBY FAVORITES
description: Last Nov. 10, Chief's Crown, Tank's Prospect and Spend a Buck ran one, two, three, in that order, in the Breeders' Cup Juvenile, the definitive race of the year for the 2-year-olds. They have re-emerged after a confusing spring and will be going into the Kentucky Derby 12 days hence as three of the favorites.

title: Brussels Bomb Damages Office of Company
description: A bomb damaged the offices of a West German electronics company today, 20 hours after a bomb caused a fire at the office of the North Atlantic Assembly, an advisory body to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: SALUTE TO ISRAEL PARADE EVOKES PRIDE AND POLITICS ON 5TH AVE.
description: Several hundred thousand spectators lined Fifth Avenue yesterday for the Salute to Israel Parade, an annual event that brought out dozens of politicians who marched in the noontime heat and delivered brief speeches.

title: SAIGON AND MANAGUA
description: WASHINGTON The remarkable thing about the

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 22, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad hoc committee for World Disarmament Conference - 10:30 A.M.

title: Bridge: Two From North Carolina Win in Tournament on L.I.
description: Two experts from Raleigh, N.C., temporarily resident in New York City, are making their presence felt in tournaments in the metropolitan area. Nick Nickell and Henry Rich played outstandingly to win the Long Island Regional Knockout Team Championship on Saturday in Hempstead, L.I., teamed with Phillip Martin and Karen McCallum, both of New York.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Reconciliation with the survivors and descendants of the victims is only possible if we accept our history as it really was, if we Germans acknowledge our shame and our historical responsibility, and if we perceive the need to act against any efforts at undermining human freedom and dignity.'' - Chancellor Helmut Kohl at the site of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp. (A8:2-3.)

title: LLOYD UPSET BY GARRISON
description: Zina Garrison upset Chris Evert Lloyd, 6-4, 6-3, in the final of the Sunkist Women's Tennis Association championship today.

title: Ellen Goldschmidt Wed
description: Ellen Lynda Goldschmidt, the associate editor of Sylvia Porter's Personal Finance Magazine, was married yesterday to Dr. Ronald Jeffrey Dworkin, a first-year resident at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Rabbi James Mirel performed the ceremony at the Reed College chapel in Portland, Ore. Mrs. Dworkin is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maure L. Goldschmidt of Portland, and Dr. Dworkin is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Dworkin of Oceanside, L.I.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Business Day Saturday accompanying an article on a recession in Saudi Arabia misidentified an airport. It was King Fahd International Airport in Riyadh.

title: STRONG SHOWING BY BIG BANKS
description: In a quarter when most of the nation's top banking companies reported stronger-than-usual earnings, the top three spots in terms of profitability were taken by New York-based institutions.

title: Jody A. Ehrich Is Married To Stewart Levy in Jersey
description: Jody Ann Ehrich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Ehrich of Cranford, N.J., was married yesterday to Stewart Scott Levy, a son of John Levy of Milwaukee and the late Lore Levy.

title: Party's Leader Meets Wallace
description: The national Democratic chairman, Paul G. Kirk Jr., met Saturday with Gov. George C. Wallace and said the party should concentrate on the economy, defense and other major issues to regain ground lost in the Presidential election.

title: SHEEHAN WINS IN LAS VEGAS
description: Patty Sheehan withstood pressure from Alice Miller to win a $200,000 golf tournament today with an even- par final round of 72 and a 72-hole total of 275.

title: 18 FIRST LADIES MEETING IN U. S. ON DRUG ABUSE
description: The White House has a problem. It has combed the city and has been unable to locate a typewriter that prints in Urdu.

title: Altschiller and Jameson Both Get New Business
description: Altschiller Reitzfeld Solin Advertising, a general agency, and Jameson Advertising, specialist in book promotion, have both reported new accounts.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Nutty Spelling

title: DIVISIVE BILLS AWAIT ACTION IN ALBANY
description: State lawmakers return from spring recess this week to confront a number of particularly divisive issues, ranging from whether judges should have less discretion in setting prison sentences to whether the drinking age should be raised to 21 and whether convicted murderers should be sentenced to life terms without parole.

title: DOLE ASKS REAGAN FOR BUDGET PUSH
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said today that support from the White House for a compromise plan to cut the Federal budget deficit had been ''slow in coming.''

title: NEW VENTURES PROVIDE PROFIT LESSON IN POLAND
description: In the gritty industrial section of Warsaw, at the end of the tram line and next to the large state- owned factories, lies a modern medical equipment plant. Its private owners are being tolerated and even coddled by the authorities in the hope that they and others like them succeed in transforming the work ethic of socialist Poland.

title: REAGAN CEMETARY VISIT CRITICIZED AT HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS CEREMONY
description: Survivors of the Holocaust cheered loudly and lustily today as one of their most prominent children called for an intensified campaign to persuade President Reagan to cancel a visit to a German cemetery containing the graves of Waffen SS troopers.

title: SALVADOR HALTS WAR FOR INOCULATIONS
description: In what amounted to an undeclared cease-fire, Government troops and leftist rebels stopped fighting this morning to allow medical teams to vaccinate more than 250,000 Salvadoran children throughout the country against five major diseases.

title: Children Get Plastic Surgery From Volunteer Medical Team
description: Volunteer doctors from the University of California at San Diego performed free plastic surgery this weekend on 18 Mexican children with birth defects and facial burns.

title: Dissident Shiite Leader Killed in Beirut Clash
description: A dissident Shiite militia leader was killed in fighting Saturday night, hours after the Sunni Moslems of Lebanon called for an end to the fierce fighting between Moslem groups that shook West Beirut last week.

title: Time to Restore Savings-and-Loan Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Honeywell Plan
description: Honeywell Inc., which is facing stockholder complaints about the weapons parts it makes, has announced plans to spend $500,000 in efforts to racially balance its work force in South Africa. Honeywell, a computer and electronics company based in Minneapolis, employs 175 workers at its South African sales operation, about 30 percent of them nonwhites.

title: OUTDOORS: BEN FRANKLIN TALKED TURKEY, TO NO AVAIL
description: THOSE who sally forth May 1, shotgun in hand, for the opening of New York State's spring turkey season would not be doing so if Benjamin Franklin had gotten his way.

title: Debt Is a Poor Legacy For America's Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigating Who Put The Spice in Education
description: Who sprayed the garlic odor

title: OFFICERS SEARCHING SECTIONS OF SURVIVALISTS' COMPOUND
description: Heavily armed state and Federal officers secured parts of an encampment of paramilitary survivalists today, seizing a number of weapons and moving cautiously for fear of possible land mines.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Cardinals , at St. Louis (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8:30 P.M.)

title: Missile Hoarding
description: To the Editor:

title: U. S. REJECTS NICARAGUAN OFFER OF A CONDITIONAL TRUCE
description: The Reagan Administration today rejected a Nicaraguan Government offer to call a cease-fire if the United States halted aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, APRIL 22, 1985

title: Rioting Continues In Parts of India
description: Rioting continued in the states of Gujarat, Kashmir and Bihar today as mobs raised protests over affirmative-action programs and local issues.

title: Don't Change Rule On Voting Stock
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Stops Czechoslovaks, 3-1
description: The United States, spurred by the goaltending of John Vanbiesbrouck of the Rangers, defeated Czechoslovakia, 3-1, today in the World Ice Hockey Championships.

title: MASS KILLINGS RECALLED BY ARMENIANS AT RALLY
description: Thousands of Armenian-Americans from across the Northeast gathered in Times Square yesterday to mark the 70th anniversary of the mass killing of Armenians by the Ottoman Turks during World War I.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS ;   CATCHING UP
description: * Chris Washburn, the North Carolina State center who was suspended by Coach Jim Valvano in December after being charged with stealing a student's stereo, can return to the team next season, Valvano says. But the coach has some conditions: Washburn must maintain academic eligibility and fulfill obligations imposed by a court that in February convicted him of reduced misdemeanor charges. The list of those obligations means a busy summer ahead. Washburn must pay the court a fine of $1,000 from work on a summer job; check with a probation officer once a week; do 320 hours of community service (some of which he has already completed), including visits to a home for mentally retarded children, washing police cars every Saturday, and spending half an hour every week meeting with former prisoners; submit to counseling by a psychologist, and be liable to search without a warrant by probation officers looking for stolen property on his person or in his car or home.

title: AMERICAN CYCLIST TURNS PRO IN EUROPE
description: NOKERE, Belgium

title: Furor on Nazi Graves Viewed as Damaging
description: The controversy over President Reagan's planned visit to a German military cemetery ''could not have come at a worse time,'' a former key aide said today.

title: Heart Recipient's Outing Includes Fishing Trip
description: William J. Schroeder and his family hung out the ''Gone Fishing'' sign at their Louisville apartment this weekend and took off for a nearby lake, where a hospital spokesman said the artificial heart recipient ''was reeling several in.''

title: MARINE BRIDGADE IN CALIFORNIA PREPARES FOR DESERT WARFARE
description: Summer temperatures in the Mojave Desert sometimes reach 130 degrees or more in the shade and if, as is often the case, an infantryman is forced to lie down, it may be 30 to 45 degrees hotter for him.

title: U.S. SOCCER TEAM HINDERED
description: The road to the World Cup in Mexico next summer is becoming more treacherous for the United States national team because of the confusion in the professional leagues that normally provide the players.

title: SMALL BUSINESS BATTLES TAX PROPOSAL
description: Small business has decided that it does not like tax simplification. But lobbyists have made it known on Capitol Hill and in the Treasury Department that the small-business community could quickly be persuaded to change its mind.

title: Varian Associates
description: Varian Associates Inc. said Friday that it was withdrawing from the seminconductor lithography business because of losses.

title: RECITAL: NEW MUSIC IN VILLAGE
description: GREENWICH VILLAGE'S historic Church of the Ascension served as the setting for an unusual recital of organ music Friday night, part of the American New Music Consortium's fourth annual festival. This festival, which will continue through May 1, is sponsored by New York University, C. W. Post University, the Guild of Composers of New Jersey and several other universities and organizations, and would seem to provide a diverse survey of contemporary composition.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: DANCE: TAYLOR'S 'CLOVEN KINGDOM'
description: PAUL TAYLOR has been thrilling audiences for the last few years with dances that overflow with powerhouse energy and movement. But there were two other characteristic sides of the choreographer on view in his dance company's performance on Wednesday at City Center (131 West 55th Street).

title: ;   'I Was Liberated at Buchenwald on April 11, 1945'
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics ;   Wrapped in Sheets ArmfulLosing track of a baby's diaper in the wash is understandable. So is missing its undershirt or pacifier. But the baby itself? Losing one in the laundry seems beyond belief.
description: Believe it. Three-week-old Hilary Harris, who weighs eight pounds and is, therefore, something of an armful, was found in a pile of sheets in the laundry room of the Cadillac (Mich.)

title: FARMERS SHAKEN AS CREDIT COOPERATIVES FAIL
description: Richard Flannery is surrounded by farmers who are losing money and losing their land. But until last November, by watching his expenses and debts closely, he survived the mayhem of a distressed agricultural economy with relatively few scars.

title: 84-Year-Old Dies After an Overdose
description: An 84-year-old man who went into a coma 10 days ago after he was mistakenly injected with 10 times the prescribed amount of morphine died Saturday afternoon at Auburn Memorial Hospital, authorities confirmed today.

title: Susan A. Strickler Weds Richard Kaye
description: Susan Ann Strickler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert K. Strickler of Norwalk, Conn., was married there yesterday to Richard Paul Kaye, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Kaye of Lawrenceville, N.J. Rabbi Jacob Lantz performed the ceremony at Temple Shalom.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on April 11 about the earnings of J.P. Morgan & Company misstated the foreign-exchange trading results for the first quarter of this year compared with the final quarter of last year. They were up $2.1 million.

title: Boy Shoots Himself in Class
description: Timothy Taylor, a 16-year-old student at Riverside Polytechnic High School, shot himself in the head in typing class Friday and died several hours later, officials said. The principal, Joseph Rile, met with the two dozen students who were in the class and then sent them home for the rest of the day.

title: THE BUTTER THAT'S TRADED OFF FOR GUNS
description: In a long national sleep, Americans have dreamed that the nation could have both guns and butter indefinitely - that military spending is an efficient device for spurring the whole economy. But President Reagan's militarism has shattered this hoary illusion. Not only is it literally taking bread out of the mouths of children, it also is severely damaging the whole economy and imposing a wide range of punishing social costs.

title: THEATER: 'THE NORMAL HEART,' BY LARRY KRAMER
description: THE blood that's coursing through ''The Normal Heart,'' the new play by Larry Kramer at the Public Theater, is boiling hot. In this fiercely polemical drama about the private and public fallout of the AIDS epidemic, the playwright starts off angry, soon gets furious and then skyrockets into sheer rage. Although Mr. Kramer's theatrical talents are not always as highly developed as his conscience, there can be little doubt that ''The Normal Heart'' is the most outspoken play around - or that it speaks up about a subject that justifies its author's unflagging, at times even hysterical, sense of urgency.

title: MONTREAL WINS, 6-4, TO SQUARE SERIES
description: Mats Naslund's second goal of the game at 15 minutes 8 seconds of the third period snapped a 4-4 tie and led the Canadiens to a 6-4 victory over the Quebec Nordiques tonight.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH ;   C.E.A. Back in Business
description: Economics, after nearly a year in the White House woodshed, seems to be regaining favor.

title: Painful Disputes
description: President Reagan's German itinerary aside, this week in Washington shapes up as a time when intense nationalist feelings are likely to be rekindled on both sides of two of the most volatile international controversies around.

title: ISLANDERS STILL AFTER REBOUND
description: The diagnosis is simple. Finding the cure is another matter.

title: LANGER TAKES TITLE IN PLAYOFF
description: Bernhard Langer beat Bobby Wadkins on the first playoff hole and scored his second consecutive victory today, this one in the prestigious Sea Pines Heritage Classic.

title: F.B.I. Calling
description: You've just returned to the United States from a trip to Central America, where you were pursuing private business. The phone rings and the caller identifies himself as an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Could he talk with you about your travels and observations?

title: Ted Bates Agencies Report New Accounts
description: Two agencies belonging to Ted Bates Worldwide - Campbell-Mithun in Minneapolis and AC&R Advertising in New York - also have reported new accounts.

title: HANNA-BARBERA TAPING BIBLE STORIES
description: Over the last two decades Hanna-Barbera Productions has established itself as the major supplier of animated children's fare for Saturday morning television. Now the company that popularized Yogi Bear and Huckleberry Hound is gambling on a new venture in a relatively untried medium: It is producing an ambitious series of animated Bible stories directly for video cassettes. Hanna- Barbera will spend approximately $20 million over the next five years on ''The Greatest Adventure: Stories From the Bible.'' The first six, including ''David and Goliath,'' ''Noah and the Ark'' and ''Samson and Delilah,'' are in production and should be available in video stores by October. The 30-minute cassettes are expected to sell for approximately $20 each.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: THE CALL: An American Missionary in

title: 44 FILIPINOS KILLED IN THEATER BLAZE
description: A rural audience fled in panic from a fire in a movie house complex in the southern Philippines today, and 44 people, most of them teen-agers, were killed, the police said.

title: 12 Seized in Bid;   To Seal Pipeline
description: The police today arrested 12 people aboard a schooner from which members of an environmentalist group had been diving to plug a pipeline that dumps wastes into the Atlantic Ocean, officials said. The pipeline, owned by Ciba-Geigy Corporation, a chemical company, daily discharges about 4 million gallons of waste waters a half-mile off Point Pleasant in Ocean County.

title: COLLECTING AND PRESERVING EVIDENCE IN RAPE CASES
description: A resident physician was excitedly describing her first court appearance to Ellen D. Doherty, coordinator of the rape intervention program at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. ''I explained all about our rape evidence kit, how we use it,'' she said, ''and we won the case.''

title: FLYERS BEAT ISLANDERS
description: Plucking rebounds off the ice, out of the air and beyond the reach of the Islanders, the Flyers got the most from their second chances tonight and scored a 5-2 victory in the 4-of-7-game Patrick Division final playoff.

title: Made in USA
description: Japan's huge trade surplus has created a wave of resentment in this country - and also a dazzling challenge to Yankee ingenuity. Fearing trade war, Prime Minister Nakasone is exhorting his people to buy more foreign goods and cites himself as a model: ''My suits are made in London, my tie is French. I use a Mont Blanc fountain pen and a West German electric razor. My tennis racket is American - Wilson - and my golf clubs also are foreign made.''

title: SUPPLIERS CITE FREEZE BY LERNER
description: Lerner Stores, the 800-store apparel shop chain that abruptly canceled all of its apparel orders 10 days ago, has frozen payments to suppliers for two weeks, according to apparel market sources.

title: Navy Reverts to Fish
description: Just when one might think the armed services would welcome all the leverage they could exercise on Capitol Hill, the Navy has decided to abandon one device that was a powerful friend-maker: naming submarines after influential members of Congress and their hometowns.

title: Topographic Bargain
description: The United States Geological Survey has a special on maps this week. Its 50,000 different topographic maps, which cover 80 percent of the country, normally cost $2.50 each, but this week any customer can buy a single one for $1. In the Washington area, the maps are available at the General Services Administration downtown and the Geological Survey center in Reston, Va.

title: Soviet Said to Build More Missile Sites
description: The Soviet Union is building sites for more SS-20 medium-range nuclear missiles despite its announcement of a moratorium on such deployments, The Sunday Times reported here today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Restaurateur to Head Consolidated Products
description: James W. Williamson Jr., a restaurateur and marketing executive, has been named president and chief executive officer of Consolidated Products Inc. and its principal subsidiary, Steak 'n' Shake Inc., a medium- priced, family-style restaurant chain. The appointment is effective today.

title: PRIVATE CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE ARTS INCREASE
description: Shortly after taking office in 1981, President Reagan asked for reductions in Government spending for the arts and urged the private sector to increase its share, saying that this was the traditional American way to finance culture.

title: RECORDS: PRINCE'S 'AROUND THE WORLD'
description: ''AROUND THE WORLD IN A DAY,'' the first album from Prince since his ''Purple Rain'' album and film made him pop's brightest new star, is being released today by Warner Brothers Records. The album follows Prince's recent announcement, on completion of his long and reportedly grueling ''Purple Rain'' tour, that he does not intend to perform live again, though he will continue to make records, videos and films.

title: METS BATTERED AGAIN
description: If there is a pattern, Dave Johnson does not see it. But the numbers, too obvious to ignore, are suggesting something cruel about the Mets' pitching. In clear terms, they are saying that the Mets invariably find themselves in deep trouble once Dwight Gooden concludes his turn in the rotation.

title: NETS LOSE: TRAIL BY 2-0
description: The Nets learned a painful lesson tonight that they may soon have the remainder of the summer to ponder: The end comes quickly for those who do not play defense in the playoffs.

title: Flip's Pleasure Wins Top Flight
description: Flip's Pleasure won the $168,600 Top Flight Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, but the Grade I race was marred when Nany, the favorite, stumbled at the start, losing her rider, and then interfered with two of the four other fillies in the race while running loose.

title: Craig F. Miller Is Wed To Dr. Benetta Levine
description: Dr. Benetta Iris Levine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Levine of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married yesterday to Craig Franklin Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Miller of the Bronx. Rabbi Steven Steindel performed the ceremony at the Tavern-on-the-Park restaurant in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.

title: Major Treasury Financing Planned
description: The hiatus in new Treasury notes and bonds is coming to an end this week, with the regular weekly offering of two-year notes on Wednesday. The auction is the first sale of Treasury notes since the last week of March, and precedes by one and a half weeks a major Treasury financing in the first week of May.

title: THE STAGE: 'PADUCAH' OPENS AT AMERICAN PLACE THEATER
description: THE bitter memory of the town of Nixville hangs like crepe over Sallie Bingham's ''Paducah.'' Years ago, as president of the bank of Paducah, Clay Baker (William Cain) was instrumental in the flooding of that isolated Kentucky community, destroying the homes of hundreds of people and replacing them with a dam. Now, retiring from the bank and about to run for the United States Senate, Clay reflects on his past and worries that his home and his life will prove to be as evanescent as Nixville.

title: NEW SUMMARY;
description: MONDAY, APRIL 22, 1985 International

title: Sundstrand Purchase
description: The Sundstrand Corporation, which is based in Rockford, Ill., announced late Friday that it had agreed in principle to pay $100 million in cash plus royalty payments to buy the Turbomach division of Solar Turbines Inc. Based in San Diego, Solar Turbines is a subsidiary of the Caterpillar Tractor Company. Turbomach, which had sales of $73.3 million last year, manufacturers gas turbine engines for airborne, ground and vehicular auxiliary power units.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Campaign Strategy
description: A group of students gathered at

title: INTENSE VOLCANO WATCH FINDS STEADY RHYTHM OF ERUPTIONS
description: EARLY yesterday, right on schedule, lava began spurting from a young volcanic cone known as Pu'u O on the east rift zone of Hawaii's Kilauea volcano. The 14-hour eruption, which sent fountains of fiery lava 1,000 feet into the air, was the 32d from that site since a series of periodic eruptions began there in January 1983.

title: AIRBORNE FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $489,000 from aircraft transactions.

title: UNITED FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a special dividend valued at $903,000 from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board of preferred stock in the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.

title: TOURNEY LOSES CROSBY NAME
description: The annual Bing Crosby National Pro-Am golf tournament, one of the oldest events on the PGA Tour, will no longer carry the singer's name because of a family decision yesterday to withdraw the Crosby affiliation.

title: COMPAQ COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MORRISON-KNUDSEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MUSIC: WORKS BY CAPLET
description: ANDRE CAPLET, disciple and sometime assistant composer to Debussy, was a prolific and often imaginative composer himself. ''Inspired'' is not a word that leaps to mind in describing his work, but Debussy's innovations inspired him to a probing, curious, questing style; some see Caplet as an important bridge to Olivier Messiaen.

title: AMERICAN CARRIERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year- ago results do not include $2,620,000 of revenue and $121,000 of net income earned by the motor and control division prior to its acquisition by Pacific Scientific in February.

title: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects a gain of $66,601,000 from the sale of the company's cosmetic and fragrance business and a loss of $42,902,000 from other discontinued operations.

title: 250 ARE ARRESTED NEAR WHITE HOUSE
description: About 250 demonstrators were arrested outside the White House today in a tense but generally nonviolent sit-in that blocked the main gates on Pennsylvania Avenue for most of the day.

title: NEWS SUMMARY;
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 23, 1985 International

title: DRAVO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,149,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Purolator Suspect Granted New Trial
description: The State Supreme Court today overturned the murder conviction of a Purolator robbery defendant, Lawrence J. Pelletier, and granted him a new trial.

title: FIRST SAVINGS & LOAN (FORT MYERS)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $297,040, or 20 cents a share, from a special dividend distributed by the Federal Home Loan Bank.

title: BELIEF GROWS OF A FEDERAL EASING
description: There is a growing conviction among credit market participants that the Federal Reserve is encouraging lower interest rates, though there is much uncertainty about how long the more generous monetary policy will last or how low rates will fall.

title: CCX NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FORMULA FOR COCA-COLA IS EXPECTED TO CHANGE
description: The Coca-Cola Company is expected to announce today a reformulation of Coca-Cola, the world's best- selling soft drink. The Atlanta-based beverage and entertainment company has refused to comment, and bottlers, who are sequestered today in Atlanta, have learned only that they would receive a different concentrate.

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL INSURNCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Union Texas Sale
description: The Allied Corporation said it had agreed definitively to sell 50 percent of its oil and gas unit, Union Texas Petroleum, to an investor group led by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. The group includes members of Union Texas management. As previously announced, Allied will receive $1.4 billion in cash and $300 million worth of Union Texas preferred stock in the transaction.

title: ADVERTISING ;   Travel & Leisure
description: Travel & Leisure magazine next October will break out 250,000 carefully selected subscribers from its regular 975,000 circulation for a new demographic edition labeled the Business Travel edition. The one- time black-and-white ad page rate will be $9,290 and the four-color $12,500.

title: Israeli Music and Dance
description: A program of Israeli music and dance marking Israeli Independence Day is scheduled at 8:30 P.M. next Saturday at Ansche Chesed Congregation, 251 West 100th Street.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF BROOKSILLE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The company did not report share earnings for the year-ago quarter because it converted to a stock form of ownership from a mutual form in December 1984.

title: REJECT THE GENOCIDE CONVENTION
description: The Senate should proceed with the utmost caution next week when the Genocide Convention comes up for ratification for the sixth time since it was proposed in 1949. Today, as before, there is every reason to reject the treaty in its current form, which could so easily play into the hands of those hostile nations that wish to make trouble for America and its allies.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FINANCIAL SECURITY SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A West Virginia Hospital Offering
description: The Monongalia County Commission in West Virginia is offering $91 million of revenue bonds for the West Virginia University Hospital through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The bonds were tentatively offered yesterday with yields ranging from 6.50 percent for bonds due in 1989 to 9 percent in 2000 and 9 3/8 percent in 2005 and 2018.

title: KENNAMETAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A MEMORIAL FOR QUEENS CONGRESSMAN
description: In a ceremony sprinkled with anecdotes, kind memories and humor, Benjamin S. Rosenthal, the late Representative from Queens, was honored yesterday for a legacy of political ideals.

title: Baptist Official Refuses To Back Church Head
description: R. Keith Parks, the head of the Southern Baptist Convention's Foreign Mission Board, said today that he would not support the re-election of the Rev. Charles Stanley as president of the nation's largest Protestant church.

title: KOLLMORGAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: The Sky Watch map on Sunday was inadvertently reprinted from a previous week, although the caption was up to date. A corrected version for this week appears today on page D27.

title: RPC ENERGY SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW JERSEY RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PAN AM PLANS SALE OF PACIFIC ROUTES TO UNITED AIRLINES
description: Pan American World Airways, which pioneered routes across the Pacific and grew into the most extensive global carrier, has agreed to sell its Pacific operations to United Airlines, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Getty Center Acquires Sculptor's Archive
description: The Getty Center for the History of Art and the Humanities in Santa Monica, Calif., has announced the acquisition of the complete archive of the American sculptor Malvina Hoffman.

title: JUSTICES TO HEAR CASE ON DELIBERATE CREATION OF ALL-WHITE JURY
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve one of the longest-simmering issues in criminal law: whether the Constitution permits a prosecutor to shape an all- white jury by selectively removing potential jurors who are black.

title: TECO ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LUBRIZOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (SAN DIEGO, CALIF) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

MERRILL LYNCH & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter net was after a provision for income taxes of $34,276,000 while the year-earlier period's net included a tax credit of $16,052,000.

title: OLD STONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $388,000 for the latest quarter and $944,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: DEPOSIT GUARANTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOODY PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Greece Reaches Accord On National Elections
description: President Christos Sartzetakis agreed today to hold national elections on June 2, four months before the Socialist Government's term expires.

title: PREWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
5 DEMOCRATS IN JERSEY GOVERNOR RACE STRIVE FOR RECOGNITION
description: Robert J. Del Tufo, a former Federal prosecutor who would like to become governor of New Jersey, arrived at a park on the Hoboken waterfront the other day with poster-size photographs of a convicted crime figure and the state's Attorney General stashed in the trunk of his car.

title: ALCAN ALUMINIUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $7,000,000 from the settlement of a contractual dispute in the U.K., a gain of $3,000,000 from the redemption of debentures by a subsidiary, and a tax credit of $12,000,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $9,000,000.

title: SOVIET DISPUTES REPORT BY U. S. ON G. I. PATROLS
description: The Soviet Union said today that it reserved the right to use force against unknown intruders found near Soviet military installations in East Germany.

title: L.I. JUDGE: PASSION FOR LAW
description: When John Copertino rode New York City's buses and subways as a child, other passengers often avoided him.

title: Monsanto Off 50.3%; SmithKline Slips
description: The Monsanto Company, hurt by the strong dollar and a loss of business to foreign competitors, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter plunged 50.3 percent. Sales were off 6.4 percent.

title: GREENWOOD RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CONSOLIDATED-TOMOKA LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
;   How We Can Stay Ahead in Biotechnology
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVERTISING ;   Sylvania Bulb Ads Feature Mr. Light
description: A spokesman for a light bulb brand had better be bright. Maybe that is why Doyle Dane Bernbach, working for GTE Lighting Products, decided not to try to hire an existing personality, but to create one of its own to promote Sylvania light bulbs.

title: U. S. AGENCY TRANSMITS TV PROGRAMS TO EUROPE
description: The United States Information Agency started transmitting television programming by satellite to Europe yesterday, inaugurating a $1.6 million service called ''Worldnet.''

title: SCHOOLS AND THE WAR ON POVERTY
description: ''AS the son of a tenant farmer, I know that education is the only valid passport from poverty.'' With these words, Lyndon B. Johnson, seated in the one-room schoolhouse in Texas that he had attended as a child, signed into law the Elementary and Secondary Education Act 20 years ago this month. It was education's counterpart to the Civil Rights Act. Together, the two measures were the big guns in President Johnson's ''War on Poverty.''

title: AIDS DATA POUR IN, AS STUDIES PROLIFERATE
description: ATLANTA

title: UNITED ILLUMINATING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Historic Asian Flights by Pan Am
description: For half a century, Pan American World Airways has been the prime innovator in commercial aviation between the United States and Asia. Some highlights:

description: ''In the village of Jamaica is a

title: Emhart in Bid To Buy Mite
description: The Emhart Corporation said that it intended to acquire the Mite Corporation for about $125 million.

title: CIRCLE INCOME SHARES INC reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: SEACOAST BANKING CORP OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ROBINS, A H CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $8,490,000 which reflects tax benefits due to a reserve established to cover costs related to litigation over the Dalkon Shield contraceptive device.

title: Little Orchestra Society In Liebermann Premiere
description: The Little Orchestra Society will open its subscription series at Alice Tully Hall on April 29 at 8 P.M. with a concert conducted by its music director, Dino Anagnost.

title: AIDE SAYS KOHL WILL NOT SUGGEST ALTERNATIVE TO BITBURG CEMETERY
description: A close aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that in a telephone call to President Reagan last Friday the West German leader obtained a firm promise that the American would not change his plans to visit a German military cemetery.

title: DANCE: GRAHAM WRAPS UP SEASON

Topics ;   Waiting Games Line LoreA friend of ours who considers herself a connoisseur of queues says that in a supermarket, don't judge the line by its length but by how high its carts are piled. At the passport office, she advises, watch out for applicants clutching manila envelopes. Those envelopes are likely to contain documents that have to be pawed through, perused and questioned.
description: In a bank she avoids the line headed by the person saying ''You have my signature on file,'' and the one that includes a teen-ager with a big back pack. The teen-ager is usually a tourist who's about to have a terrible time cashing a traveler's check.

title: SAVORY PIES: A WORLDWIDE COOK'S TOUR
description: as Cornishmen have been doing for generations - they take with them for sustenance rich and filling savory pies called Cornish pasties, which they pronounce with a broad ''a'' - PAHS- tees. Each one is just large enough to fit in a worker's hand. They are made of leftover meat, chopped with potatoes, mixed with gravy, sealed in a pastry envelope and baked in the oven. (The original version, according to one authority, had jam for dessert at one end.) No one knows precisely how old a tradition the Cornish pasty represents, but by all accounts it is an ancient way of dealing with the problem of the laborer's lunch, be the laborer a miner, sailor, shepherd, student or farmer.

title: Bridge: A Booming Penalty Double May Backfire on the Doubler

It is not only bad manners but also, on occasion, bad tactics. An opponent who is listening to the tone of voice may draw the right conclusion.

title: SEARS, ROEBUCK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CBS HEADS TV RATINGS BUT NBC GAINS VIEWERS
description: CBS finished first among the three television networks for the 1984-85 television season, but NBC showed the results of its revitalization by finishing in a strong second place after its 10-year sojourn in the ratings cellar. ABC finished third for the season.

title: Data General Net Falls
description: The Data General Corporation, a minicomputer maker based in Westboro, Mass., yesterday reported a 36 percent drop in second-quarter earnings and said it would close domestic plants for two weeks this year. Net income fell to $9.1 million, or 34 cents a share, from $14.2 million, or 55 cents a share, a year before. Revenues rose 16.9 percent, to $320.2 million, from $273.9 million.

title: CANDON'S PROMISES A REPRISE
description: BY the end of July, West 54th Street will have lost the last of its two bastions of traditional jazz. Eddie Condon's will be closed by then to make way, with other restaurants and stores on the south side of the block between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, for an office building that will be erected jointly by the New York Hilton Hotel and the Prudential Life Insurance Company. A year and a half ago, Jimmy Ryan's - Eddie Condon's neighbor slightly to the west - was closed after 21 years on West 54th Street (preceded by 22 years on West 52d) in anticipation of the demolition that has now begun.

title: FOR SNEAKES, A FIELD OF FLOWERS
description: 1.*Sneakers and Flowers Hawaiian prints are everywhere, even on old-fashioned sneakers. The rubber-soled Sluggers at Barneys come in two styles - the traditional sneaker, cut low around the ankle, or the ankle-high basketball sneaker. They are available with either blue or rose-colored flowers. The price is $45, in the women's duplex. 2.*For Pedal Pumpers In time for spring, ''20 Bicycle Tours in and Around New York City'' has arrived from Backcountry Publications. Written by Dan Carlinsky and David Heim, this paperback maps out tours ranging from one day to several, and covers the streets of New York as well as scenic areas of New Jersey, Connecticut and Long Island. It costs $6.95 and is available at B. Dalton, Endicott Books and other bookstores around town. 3.*For Friends of Liberty The Statue of Liberty is receiving help from a lot of friends, including the people at Love America's Parks. They have come out with an ''I Love the Lady'' T-shirt, and they say 3 percent of the gross sales will be donated to the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation. The shirts cost $9 each at the Showplace boutique, 503 Fifth Avenue (42d Street). They are also available at the Plaza and the Waldorf-Astoria. 4.*Special Purses Mali Parmi has designed a collection of one-of-a-kind jeweled purses, made in Italy. The pouch-shaped shoulder bag shown here is made of black nylon. It has tan leather trim studded with amber glass and metal tacks.

Senior reached the agreement two days before the communications company was scheduled to appeal an earlier court award of more than $3.3 million. Mr. Senior was dismissed as president of Wometco de Puerto Rico in September 1982.

title: Ames Unit Link
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. and the G.C. Murphy Company said they had agreed to combine their discount retail chains, with Ames paying $48 a share, or a total of $198 million, for Murphy. Murphy's stock, which traded as low as $9.62 three years ago, closed at $47.75 a share today, up $2.375. Ames closed at $37.625 a share, up $2.125.

title: Pacific Telesis
description: The Pacific Bell subsidiary of Pacific Telesis strongly criticized a recommendation made by the staff of the California Public Utilities Commission that the telephone company's rates be cut by $480 million a year. The company's stock slumped $2.25 today, to $68. Pacific Bell said ''the position taken in our current rate proceeding bears no relationship to reality'' and complained that the staff ''ignored the negative consequences which would result.''

title: Careers;   Producing Biotech Products
description: BIOTECHNOLOGY, which includes genetics, is expected to be a big growth industry, just as computers are today. In fact, world markets for biotech products - those used in agriculture, chemicals, food and pharmaceuticals - could exceed $40 billion annually by the end of the century. .
