title: Holmes Will Defend Against Williams
description: Larry Holmes, ultimately going for 50, has signed to defend the International Boxing Federation heavyweight title against what appears to be another in his series of not-quite-ready-for-prime-time opponents. But on May 20, when Holmes meets Carl (the Truth) Williams, the fight will be shown on prime-time television by NBC.

title: JERSEY STARTS TO FEEL EFFECTS OF DROUGHT RULES
description: At the Upper Montclair Country Club here, two large sprinklers pushed twin spouts of water in 50-foot arcs over the lush golf greens. Nearby, however, residents wondered how long it would take for the sun to shrivel their lawns into burned stubble.

title: JERRICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results for both periods include $377,000, or 2 cents a share, from the extinguishment of $5 million of convertible debentures.

title: Election Board Chief In Peru Is Wounded
description: The president of the National Election Board in Peru was shot several times in the face as he rode to his office today, and the Government blamed the Maoist guerrilla group Shining Path, which had threatened to disrupt presidential elections held April 14.

title: ILLINOIS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TALE BEARERS The Brooklyn Philharmonic, led by Lukas Foss, has a strange story to tell, several of them in fact, and it will be spinning them tonight at 8 o'clock at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and again at the same time tomorrow in Manhattan in Cooper Union's Great Hall, This installment of ''Meet the Moderns'' is called ''Music x Narratives.'' The idea is to perform works in which words or other devices help the music spin some sort of yarn. Robert Mann's ''Two Stories by Rudyard Kipling'' has Lucy Rowan narrating ''How the Rhinocerous Got His Skin'' and ''How the Camel Got His Hump,'' with Mr. Mann at violin and Mr. Foss at piano. William Bolcom describes his ''Theater of the Absurd'' as a ''paraphrase'' for live actor, tapes, wind quintet, piano and mechanized eyeballs. Owen S. Rackleff, an actor, speaks and orchestra members answer back as the score develops.

title: DOMTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $5,200,000 from U.S. tax credits. c-Includes a special gain of $5,000,000. Results are given in Canadian dollars.

title: New Haven's Shubert Plans Further Cutbacks
description: The Shubert Theater plans to reduce operating expenses by trimming its staff in the face of higher-than-expected deficits for 1984 and the first quarter of the current fiscal year, theater officials announced.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter net was reduced by $276,000, or 13 cents a share, from a pre-tax charge of $487,000 relating to the reduction in the carrying amount of the receivable resulting from the December 1983 sale of the company's New Jersey printed circuit board business.

title: MEDICINE SHOPPE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DISMISSED DOCTOR HAD 1980 PROBLEM
description: A doctor who was recently dismissed as chief heart surgeon at the Navy's flagship hospital previously had his surgical privileges curtailed at a medical center in Long Branch, N.J.

title: AT ARCHBISHOP'S OFFICE, HE'S ALREADY 'CARDINAL'
description: At the office of Archbishop John J. O'Connor yesterday, the secretaries were answering the telephone with the words ''Cardinal O'Connor's office.''

title: National League;   Homer Helps Cubs Win, 5-2
description: Leon Durham hit a two-run homer, and Davey Lopes had three hits and drove in two runs as the Chicago Cubs beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-2, today. It was the Pirates' seventh loss in eight games.

title: Bird Works Out
description: Larry Bird worked out with the Boston Celtics in Richfield, Ohio, yesterday and said the injured right elbow that kept him out of Tuesday night's playoff game against the Cleveland Cavaliers was not likely to keep him off the court for tonight's fourth game in the three-of-five-game series. ''It felt pretty good,'' Bird said, noting he had been treating the elbow with ice and the Whirlpool.

title: House Fire Kills 3 on Long Island
description: Fire at a house today on the South Shore trapped and killed a woman and her two grown children, according to officials.

title: Kosar Chooses Browns
description: After three years of school and football in south Florida, Bernie Kosar said today that he wanted to go home to Ohio as a member of the Cleveland Browns. The University of Miami quarterback will join the Browns for the 1985 National Football League season via a supplemental draft.

title: COURT PONDERS SUTI ON JOB BIAS OVER OBESITY
description: Catherine McDermott is being a bit facetious when she calls herself ''the Rosa Parks of fat people.'' But there is nothing frivolous about her lawsuit against the Xerox Corporation, which declined to hire her 11 years ago because she was seriously overweight.

title: EX-HOUSING PROJECT SPONSOR AND 3 INDICTED
description: A community activist for whom a Brooklyn housing development was originally named has been indicted with three associates on charges that they stole $40,000 by collecting illegal fees from prospective tenants.

title: ACCURAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST LADIES CONFER ON DRUG ABUSE
description: Nancy Reagan and 17 other first ladies today heard speaker after speaker - including a tearful teen-ager - urge that more parents get involved in the worldwide battle against drug abuse.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS REPORT NO PROGRESS IN ARMS TALKS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that no progress had been made in the first round of the Geneva arms talks with the Soviet Union. They said this was because of a basic disagreement over how the talks should be conducted.

title: First Malpractice Trial For Clergy Begins
description: Pastors of Grace Community Church contributed to a young man's suicide by negligence and improper counseling, a lawyer said today in the nation's first clergy malpractice trial.

title: CCX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge for the reversal of a tax credit of $17,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $211,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,596,000 for the quarter and $1,783,000 for the 9 months. Sales figures for the both 9-month periods were not immediately available. Results for the year-ago 9-month period does not include a provision for domestic income taxes because it had been anticipated on March 31, 1984 that the company would have no domestic taxable income for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1984.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about earnings of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the seven regional spinoff companies misstated a percentage increase in revenues for the BellSouth Corporation. Its first-quarter revenues were up 10 percent from the 1984 quarter.

title: COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GULFSTREAM AEROSPACE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Wilkens Out as Coach
description: He compiled a respectable 553-491 record in 13 seasons as a National Basketball Association coach and made the Seattle SuperSonics a championship team, but the club won only 31 of 82 games last season, which was apparently enough to cost Lenny Wilkens his coaching job. The 47-year-old Wilkens, who coached the team for eight seasons, including the championship year of 1978-79, was moved to general manager yesterday.

title: U.S. FEARS IRAN MAY USE CHEMICAL ARMS
description: The State Department expressed concern today that Iran may have developed an arsenal of chemical weapons to use in retaliation against Iraq, which could lead to a dangerous increase in the use of poison gas.

title: PRINCES OF THE CHURCH FROM FAR AND WIDE
description: Andrzej Maria Deskur A Pole. Born Feb. 29, 1924; ordained Aug. 20, 1950; consecrated Bishop June 30, 1974. President Emeritus of the Pontifical Commission on Social Communications. He is the first Cardinal to be named from the commission, whose importance has grown as the Vatican has become conscious of the importance of mass communications. He has also lobbied, so far unsuccessfully, for formal Vatican recognition of Israel. Those who know him say he is deeply worried about Poland's reputation as an anti-Semitic country. He has been very ill in recent years.

title: SANDINISTA LEADER SAYS HE PLANS TO VISIT MOSCOW SOON TO SEEK AID
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that he would visit Moscow at the end of this month to discuss economic assistance.

title: BALLET: 2D 'ROMEO' CAST
description: WITH its richness of pageantry, Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' ought to have been imposing at American Ballet Theater's performance on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Instead, it was ponderous.

title: JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After investment losses of $133,990 for the latest quarter and $108,103 for the year-earlier period.

title: ART SALE SETS RECORD FOR A VAN GOGH
description: The sale last night of Impressionist and modern art from the collection of Florence J. Gould brought the highest total ever bid for a collection in a single session, and also established a new high for an Impressionist painting - Van Gogh's ''Landscape With Rising Sun.''

title: Executive Enters Pretrial Program
description: The executive vice president of the Six Flags Corporation, which owns the Great Adventure amusement park where eight teen-agers died in a fire 11 months ago, has been admitted into a pretrial intervention program in Ocean County.

title: COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from an exchange offer of $30,144,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: TV MOVIE ON RAY MANCINI SPARKS CONTROVERSY
description: When CBS broadcasts ''The Heart of a Champion: The Ray Mancini Story'' on May 1 at 9 P.M., there will be no shortage of action.

title: PRESIDENT URGES BUDGET SUPPORT
description: President Reagan, declaring that the time had come for the Government to make some ''hard choices,'' appealed tonight to the American public to lobby Congress for passage of a compromise budget that would reduce spending by $300 billion over three years.

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
AUTHOR SAYS OFFICIALS WILL AID ENTRY TO U.S.
description: Farley Mowat, a prominent Canadian writer and naturalist who was denied permission to enter the United States on Tuesday, said today that Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and Joe Clark, Canada's Minister of External Affairs, intend to raise the matter with their ''opposite numbers'' in Washington.

title: THE WAY A 'MAVERICK' POLITICIAN SEES IT
description: Today an address from the voice of candor. (This is not a testament to his honesty. Rather it is a comment on his style, which is unvarnished. He seems at all times to be saying, ''I'm going to level with you.'' And, indeed, he may be doing just that.) The voice comes from a mouth that is usually wrapped around a thick cigar. (Yes, he is a politician and, yes, he has been in smoke-filled rooms, but do not make too much of that cigar. It does not affect the image. As he says, you can smoke a cigar and still be a maverick, which is how he sees himself.) Finally, when people see the cigar coming, they say, ''Hey, Doc, how's it going.'' (He is called ''Doc'' because he is a naturopathic physician, which is not exactly a chiropractor and not exactly an osteopath, but, as he says, ''same church, different pew.'') George L. Gunther, 65 years old, was first elected to the Connecticut State Senate in 1966 and has won every Senate campaign in his district here since. In 1984 he overwhelmed his opponent by 19,588 votes. He is nominally a Republican, which is to say he points his lance as often at his own party as he does at the Democrats.

title: PROPOSAL ON TRACING SUSPECTS ASSAILED AT HEARING IN HOUSE
description: The former head of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency testified today that she did not believe that a Government plan to track white-collar crime suspects and their associates was ''efficient, fair or constitutional.''

title: A SPLASH OF ORCHIDS IN BRONX GARDEN
description: A WONDERFUL orchid show is at the New York Botanical Garden. For the first time in its four-year history, the show occupies eight glass galleries of the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, twice as many as before. There were so many entries this year that growers and private exhibitors had to spread out their displays. Even the botanical garden's own Sarah David Smith collection of orchids has joined the show for the first time.

title: INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STAGE: 'MANEUVERS,' A 3-WAY BATTLE
description: THE battleground of Catherine Muschamp's ''Maneuvers'' is the living room of a British regimental colonel; the main maneuverers are his well-endowed wife and his well-muscled servant, a private who has fought alongside his officer in dirty wars around the globe. The maneuvers themselves take the form of realistically simulated, cheerily sadistic antiterrorist exercises, sometimes directed at an unwary guest. Late one night, for example, the colonel's new second in command finds himself baited, manhandled and confronted by blazing guns. The real war, however, is being waged between wife and servant for the colonel's body and spirit.

title: Slicing Up City Hall
description: While city officials looked on, a demolition crew set eagerly to work shortly after noon yesterday on a lower Manhattan landmark.

DEXTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest quarter include the operations of Permag Corp. which was acquired in February and accounted for as a pooling of interest.

title: HOUSE VOTE ON AID PLAN
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the House of Representatives on Tuesday night rejected, 248 to 180, President Reagan's request to release $14 million for direct military aid to the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government. A ''no'' vote was a vote not to release the money. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to release the money. Voting ''no'' were 208 Democrats and 40 Republicans. Voting ''yes'' were 40 Democrats and 140 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House.

title: Suit Against O'Brien
description: Robert Simels. the lawyer who successfully defended the Jets' quarterback Ken O'Brien against assault charges last year, has sued O'Brien, charging that he owes him $39,310 for expenses and fees. Simels said he had papers served on O'Brien at his home in Sacramento, Calif., last month to notify of the action in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: AFTER DELAY FOR REAGAN SPEECH, DOLE NOW PLANS QUICK BUDGET VOTE
description: Hoping to capitalize on President Reagan's televised speech tonight, Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, said today that he planned to push for a early vote on the Administration's compromise budget shortly after the Senate began debate Thursday.

title: CLEVETRUST REALTY INVESORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of real estate of $10,000 for the quarter and $25,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes gains on the sale of real estate of $8,000 for the quarter and $264,000 for the 6 months.

title: PISTONS SWEEP NETS ON THOMAS'S SHOT WITH .02 LEFT
description: The mission for the Nets, struggling to extend their season, was to stop Isiah Thomas, and for much of the night, they did just that. But when it mattered most, the Detroit Piston playmaker became the hero.

title: RED CROSS TO ACT TO GUARD COMBAT REPORTERS
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross has agreed to examine new ways to help protect journalists during armed conflicts.

title: URBAN HUNTING SEASON FOR TRASH AND TANK GUNS
description: In a city that has raised civic boosterism to a fine art, even a campaign against littering takes on grandiose proportions.

title: ISRAEL PULLS BACK FROM BEKAA REGION
description: The Israeli Army pulled out from the eastern and central sectors of Lebanon today, completing another phase of the second of the three planned stages of the withdrawal of its forces.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Finale of the three-game series. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Golf Houston Open, men's pro tour, first round, at Woodlands, Tex. Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf, seniors, opening round, at Austin, Tex. For the first time in the event that started the senior tour, two women, Kathy Whitworth and Mickey Wright, will join the field of men. S&H Classic, women's pro tour, opening round, at St. Petersburg, Fla. At age 32, this is the longest-running nonmajor championship on the women's circuit. Vicki Fergon, who beat Betsy King by a stroke last year, is back to defend her title. Hockey Islanders vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Nassau Coliseum, 8:05 P.M. The Islanders face elimination, trailing by 3-0 in the four-of-seven-game Patrick Division final series. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 8 P.M.) Minnesota North Stars vs. Chicago Black Hawks, at Bloomington, Minn. The Black Hawks lead, 3-0, in the Norris Division final series. (Television - USA Network, 8:30 P.M.) Squash Racquets Drakkar North American Open, second round, at Park Avenue Squash Club, 3 Park Avenue, noon and 6 P.M. After today, the competition moves to Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. Track and Field Penn Relays, at Philadelphia, 12:30 P.M. and 7 P.M. This afternoon marks the official opening of the country's oldest and largest relay carnival. Only the evening session is free.

title: Riders Fight Tests
description: Bill Shoemaker, Angel Cordero and three other jockeys moved in Federal court yesterday to block a system of mandatory, random drug tests that have been conducted by New Jersey racing authorities since April 1. In a hearing before District Judge Stanley Brotman in Camden, the jockeys' lawyer, William Bowe, called the mandatory urine tests an affront to the jockeys' ''personal dignity,'' and a violation of the ''sanctity of the human body'' and the Constitution.

title: BLACK PRINCIPAL SEEKS PROTECTION
description: A black who is principal of a predominantly white high school has asked a Federal district judge either to order him reassigned or to provide Federal marshals to protect him.

title: GERIATRIC & MEDICAL CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Redskins Said To Get Rogers
description: The Redskins have obtained the running back George Rogers from the New Orleans Saints in exchnage for the Redskins' first-round draft choice in next Tuesday's National Football League draft, according to a published report.

title: 2 OF 4 ARE GUILTY OF CLINIC BOMBING
description: A Federal jury returned a guilty verdict on all counts today against two 21-year-old men accused of bombing three clinics here that performed abortions.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THE last few months have seen the introduction of several tools and other products of interest to do-it-yourselfers. Here are some of them.

description: Year-ago net income and share earnings figures are restated to reflect the company's share of Argo Group Inc.'s start-up costs and operating results.

title: BETZ LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LAW OF BOSTON
description: Archbishop Bernard F. Law, named a Cardinal yesterday, has firmly established himself in Boston as a staunch follower of Pope John Paul II and a versatile figure who moves easily in the city's social and ecclesiastical circles.

title: 'SUNDAY IN PARK' AMONG WINNERS OF PULITZERS
description: For ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' a daring modern musical based on a modernist painting, Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine shared the Pulitzer Prize for drama yesterday.

title: Senator Objects to Trip
description: A United States senator who voted against President Reagan's request for aid to the rebels said today that he would have voted in favor had he known of Mr. Ortega's planned trip.

title: EX-HEAD OF TEAMSTERS ORDERED TO JAIL IN MAY
description: Roy L. Williams, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, must begin serving a 55-year prison sentence next month for conspiring to bribe a United States Senator, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: NEWMONT MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $701,000 and an extraordinary gain of $430,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,649,000. The year-ago quarter figures were restated to reflect Atlantic Cement Inc. as a discontinued operation. The company said its 1984 quarterly net income included a 22 cents- a-share after-tax gain due to upward adjustments of copper inventory valuations by the Magma Copper Co.

title: HERS
description: EVERY morning, as the faces of the missing children stare at me from the milk carton, I'm reminded of a neighbor I'll call Mrs. Grim. If, God forbid, some local child were to be missing, Mrs. Grim would be the first to let us know. She's a purveyor of horror tales, a walking sensationalist tabloid, a raconteur of the kidnapped, murdered and maimed.

description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid April 15.

title: 'HONOR, DUTY AND A WAR CALLED VIETNAM' ON CBS
description: TELEVISION pronounces a benediction on Vietnam tonight. ''Honor, Duty and a War Called Vietnam,'' with Walter Cronkite, is solemn in tone and judicious in purpose. It examines the American experience in Vietnam, and looks for lessons we should learn. The ''CBS Report,'' on Channel 2 at 10 P.M., is trying to write an epitaph.

title: EQUITY IS LOST IN JUNK-BONDAGE
description: I believe strongly in shareholder democracy - including the rights of shareholders to rid themselves of slow-moving, entrenched management. I am not opposed to takeovers, hostile or friendly. But I oppose today's takeover frenzy, financed by junk bonds, which increasingly endangers our savings institutions and our system of corporate enterprise.

title: An Imperative Vote Against Genocide

But that Genocide Convention has languished, unratified, in the U.S. Senate for 36 years, to the profound embarrassment of the nation that sponsored the Nuremberg trials. There never was any good excuse for hesitation. Every argument against the pact has long since been laid to rest.

Some of them, usually large mansions or estates, have been transformed into show houses, where designers have gone all out to create imaginative room settings. Lesser pieces that have been hiding imperfections under layers of paint will probably be cannibalized for spare parts to spruce up better pieces, assisted here and there by the occasional floorboard or strip of paneling or shelving.

title: HOW TO CUT UNEMPLOYMENT, WITHOUT MAGIC
description: Our editorial praise for Martin Weitzman's ''share economy'' (''Best Idea Since Keynes,'' March 28) drew much skeptical comment. The M.I.T. professor contends that a system of sharing profits with workers could virtually end unemployment without creating inflation. Like the mythic shmoo in ''Li'l Abner,'' that idea strikes many as too good to be true.

title: American League;   Vuckovich Gets First Victory Since 1982
description: Pete Vuckovich, who missed most of the last two seasons with shoulder problems, recorded his first pitching victory since his Cy Young Award season of 1982 by scattering six hits in seven innings as the Milwaukee Brewers defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3-2, tonight.

title: 'ROMEO' AIR IS CHARGED BY REALISTIC SWORDPALY
description: Fight scenes are usually the most labored thing in a ballet. At the mere clink of an unsheathed sword, many balletgoers lapse into thoughts of grocery lists or undone laundry. But the stage is charged with excitement these days as the Montagues and Capulets battle it out - with unusual and sometimes dangerous verisimilitude - in the American Ballet Theater's sumptuous new production of ''Romeo and Juliet'' at the Metropolitan Opera House. Suddenly, everyone is talking about the fight scenes, during which 25 men slash, lunge and tumble through swordplay that has sent dancers to the hospital and that has unnerved even Sir Kenneth MacMillan, the ballet's choreographer and artistic associate at Ballet Theater.

title: Andre Kertesz Winner Of Photography Award
description: The photographer Andre Kertesz and the artist David Hockney are among six recipients of awards given by the International Center of Photography for contributing ''toward preserving and communicating the images of man and his time.'' Mr. Kertesz, who is 90 years old, was given a master of photography award for his lifetime work. Mr. Hockney received an award for his use of photography in his artwork. Other recipients and their awards were Masaaki Miyazawa, for an emerging photographer; Alberto Venzago, for news photography; Robert Delpire, for photography in publishing, and Sarah Moon for advertising photography.

title: Musial Recalls A Tip From Cobb
description: On the plaza outside Busch Memorial Stadium in St. Louis, there is a life-size statue of Stan Musial crouched in his celebrated batting stance. Stan Musial stood near it the other day, talking with his old friend Ralph Kiner about a subject dear to their hearts: hitting.

title: THE SIEGE OF BLACK ROCK
description: In the battle for control of CBS, who merits our cheers and who our hisses? Where you stand depends on where you sit. If you are a CBS stockholder, you enjoy having your company ''in play,'' as long as the play is serious. You root for Ted Turner and the ''good guys'' at E.F. Hutton to bid up your stock, although their cashless package of junk bonds seems a risky proposition, especially if interest rates rise. You applaud the Turner audacity and await a more solid offer. If you are CBS management, you root for your own continued control. That means beating off raiders and sneering at any ''unfriendly'' offers - even those rewarding to stockholders - that would snatch away your jobs. If your obfuscatory or intimidating tactics fail, this may mean you seek shelter from a ''white knight'' - like G.E., or American Express, where Henry Kissinger is a director - to take over your company and guarantee your jobs. Or you may elect to ''take the company private,'' using the CBS assets as collateral to borrow the money to buy out the present stockholders. If you are Ted Turner or a corporate raider , you cloak your bid for power and self-enrichment in pious concern for stockholders' rights and undervalued assets. You, like a South American nation, have grasped the central economic idea of the shallow-pocket world: as long as debt is serviced, it need never be paid. Sink me no sinking funds: amortization is dead.

title: WINNERS OF PULITZER PRIZES IN JOURNALISM, LETTERS AND THE ARTS
description: Public Service The Fort Worth Star-Telegram The Star-Telegram won for a series of articles by Mark J. Thompson that revealed that nearly 250 American servicemen had lost their lives as a result of a design problem in Bell helicopters. His articles on the helicopters led to an investigation of the problem by the Army. Mr. Thompson joined The Star-Telegram as a defense reporter in 1979 after one year as a political reporter for The Oakland Press in Pontiac, Mich. Before that he was editor of a weekly newspaper, The Rhode Island Pendulum, in East Greenwich, R.I. He was born in 1953 in New Haven and earned a bachelor's degree in public communication from Boston University in 1975.

FILM: 'RAVEN' FROM ICELAND
description: THE dark, craggy beaches of Iceland are the setting for ''When the Raven Flies,'' a 10th-century saga that owes equal debts to Sergio Leone and Shakespeare. It is from Mr. Leone, not to mention Sam Peckinpah and Akira Kurosawa, that the Icelandic writer-director Hrafn Gunnlaugsson gets his strong, silent hero and much of this tough guy's modus operandi. Gest (Jacob Thor Einarsson) is a young Irishman who 20 years earlier stood by helplessly as Vikings murdered his parents and kidnapped his sister. The film, which begins with a brief depiction of these events in Ireland, charts Gest's revenge.

title: CASE OF DR. GROSS: SORTING OUT THE FINDINGS

title: ISLANDERS OR NO, SUTTERS TO ENDURE

In the not-too-distant future, Louis and Grace Sutter may well continue what has become their springtime tradition, and make that drive 70 miles west to Edmonton, and watch their sons play for a Stanley Cup championship. That their tradition may continue this year, despite the change in the balance of power in the National Hockey League, is a tribute to their hockey harvest.

description: THURSDAY, APRIL 25, 1985 International Nicaraguan rebels won't get new aid from the United States. The House of Representatives, by a vote of 303 to 123, dealt President Reagan's Central America policy a stinging setback when it killed all attempts to provide additional assistance to the insurgents battling the Sandinista Government. [Page A1, Column 6.] The Pope named 28 new cardinals, including Archbishops John J. O'Connor of New York, Bernard Law of Boston, Miguel Obando y Bravo, the head of Nicaragua's Roman Catholic church, and Henryk Roman Gulbinowicz of Wroclaw, an outspoken backer of Poland's outlawed Solidarity union. [A1:1.] Bob Dole urged the cancellation of President Reagan's planned visit next month to a German military cemetery at Bitburg that contains the graves of 47 Waffen SS soldiers among the 2,000 dead. [A1:5.] U.S.-West German ties would suffer if President Reagan called off a scheduled stop at the Bitburg cemetery, according to Chancellor Helmut Kohl's spokesman. [A19:1-2.] No progress in arms talks in Geneva was made because the United States and the Soviet Union fundamentally disagree over how the negotiations are to be conducted, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said the Soviet side, throughout the opening six-week round of negotiations, refused to bargain on cuts in nuclear arsenals until Washington first agreed to negotiate a ban on research and deployment of space defense weapons. [A6:4-6.] Israeli forces pulled out of the eastern and central sectors of Lebanon, completing the latest phase of the second of three planned stages of withdrawal.

title: 'HOT SHOE,' DANCE SERIES
description: EXCEPT for a handful of superstars, ranging from Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly to Twyla Tharp and Suzanne Farrell, dancers are a peculiarly neglected lot. While devoting the best years of their lives to a training program that would leave most professional athletes chronically winded, they spend their careers in near anonymity bouncing cheerfully through a Broadway musical or floating majestically in still another version of ''Swan Lake.'' Occasionally, someone pauses to say thank you. Broadway's ''Chorus Line'' was one instance, the Shirley MacLaine television special ''Gypsy in My Soul'' another. But dancers rarely get a prominent showcase of their own.

title: ERC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Q&A
description: Q. Our home has a forced air heating system that is also used for cooling in the summer. We also have a humidifier built into the system. Although we change the air filter in the system monthly, there is an unusual amount of dust in the house. We are now building another home with a similar heating and cooling system. Can you tell us if there is anything we can do to reduce or eliminate the heavy dust problem? A. There are several possibilities. First make sure you are using a good quality air filter, one fine enough to do the job. Second, check to make certain the filter, and the channel or frame in which it sits, fit properly. Air could be slipping past or around the filter instead of going through it. Also, make sure the filter is properly installed in the right place to catch all the dust. If everything checks out O.K,, perhaps you should think about having an electronic air cleaner installed in your new system. They are more effective than ordinary filters and will take out much smaller particles.

title: OF A TONY CONTROVERSY AND CURTAINS' TIMING
description: IN the long line of issues confronting the American theater, the question of whether there should be a best musical category for the Tony Awards this year is only slightly more urgent than the question of what to eat or drink during intermission - except for those directly concerned with eligible shows. For them, it represents their bread and butter, or, if the musical should win a Tony, their caviar. Winning a Tony, far more than other prizes, is regarded as box-office insurance and as a negation of bad reviews. It can make the difference between success and failure on Broadway.

Economic Scene;   Europe's Fears About Jobless
description: WEST GERMAN economists are troubled about the failure of the current recovery to generate more jobs. With strong demand for its exports, especially from the United States, the German manufacturing industry grew by 3 1/2 percent in 1984, nearly one-third faster than the German economy as a whole. But German economists think it unlikely that industries here will again outperform the rest of the economy in 1985. The German expansion, in their view, is unlikely to exceed 2 1/2 percent - too slow a pace to reduce unemployment.

title: THE SCREEN: 'TOKYO-GA'
description: WIM WENDERS, the German director (''Alice in the Cities,'' ''The American Friend,'' among others), describes ''Tokyo-Ga'' (''Tokyo Images'') as a filmed diary. It's also something a good deal more - a homage to the great Japanese director Yasujiro Ozu (1903-1963) and a perceptive, fascinating if gloomy rumination on the state of our civilization, which Mr. Wenders and his compatriot Werner Herzog, who appears briefly in the film, equate with film images.

title: OPERA: HANDEL 'XERXES'

Miss Behrens, whom we know as one of the foremost Wagnerian sopranos of our day, leaped into this new phase of her career with characteristic abandon, and for much of the evening made a modest success of the enterprise.

Halpin, mostly self-coached, had thrown the international-size hammer 205 feet, which ranked him among the world's leading juniors.

title: A NEW CHANCE FOR ARMS CONTROL
description: The complex arms control talks taking place in Geneva recessed this week with little to show for six weeks of delicate negotiation. Despite the difficulties, however, I believe that conditions for reaching a major agreement are far better now than in the 1970's.

title: ART: GILBERT AND GEORGE, DUO WHO WORK AS SOLO
description: GILBERT AND GEORGE are two influential, internationally-known London-based artists who work as one. Collectively, they conceived, composed and executed every one of the photomurals in their retrospective at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. To their advocates, Gilbert and George are complex, compelling and sometimes comic artists in the forefront of artistic attempts to forge a new future. To detractors, their work is too contrived and contradictory to be in the forefront of anything except the exploration of new materials.

title: A BUSY TIME AT MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY

That is rarely true at the American Museum of Natural History, and this weekend illustrates the case as the museum begins its commemoration of John James Audubon's 200th birthday and, at the same time, introduces an exhibition of Maya art pieces never before seen in the United States.

BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 26, 1985 Companies In an about-face, Storer accepted a $2.1 billion buyout offer from Kohlberg, Kravis. The cable television company rejected an initial bid just 72 hours earlier. The latest offer gives shareholders an equity position in the new concern that would be formed to run Storer. However, a dissident stockholder group said it would continue to seek control of the Storer board. [Page D1.] Federal regulators are considering a proposal to begin rescue efforts for ailing thrift institutions long before they need assistance from a Federal insurance fund. [D1.] The parent of Bell Savings of California reported big losses. [D1.] A tentative deal for Mead to buy Crown Zellerbach failed. Crown then tried but could not reach an accommodation with Sir James Goldsmith, who is bidding for it. Crown also announced a restructuring to split it into three units. [D1.] T. Boone Pickens's bid for Unocal was threatened by a preliminary court ruling. Earlier, Mr. Pickens said he would tender his Unocal stake to the company under a debt-swap offer it made Tuesday. But he said he remained determined to take over Unocal. [D6.] Chrysler earnings fell 28.1 percent in the first quarter, to $507.6 million, largely because of higher income tax payments. [D1.] Searle purchased 7.5 million of its shares from several Searle family trusts, for $388.1 million. [D1.

Several performing artists who were Mr. Bach's friends will take part in the service, including Bobby Short, Blossom Dearie, Margaret Whiting, Bernie Leighton and Dick Hyman. Mr. Bach, a prominent figure in the jazz world for five decades who produced the first network television jazz series in 1949, ''Adventures in Jazz,'' died of cancer on April 9 at Lyford Cay, the Bahamas. He was 70 years old.
