description: The Senate began debate today on a Federal budget that would reduce the deficit by $52 billion in 1986, but the Republican leadership put off a symbolic vote on the plan when it appeared it was short of the votes needed to win.

title: Head of Ames Is Glad He Listened to Brothers
description: When he got out of college in the late 1950's, Herbert Gilman thought he was headed for a career in electrical engineering. But his older brothers, Milton and Irving, had just set up a store in an old textile mill in Southbridge, Mass., and persuaded their youngest sibling to forsake engineering for retailing.

title: CONSUMERS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Yogi's Future: Assume Nothing
description: Meteorologically, it's not the hurricane season. But managerially, it's always the hurricane season at Yankee Stadium, where the name of the storm never changes. And throughout the Yankees' 5-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox last night, the watch for Hurricane George was on. Again.

title: ARIZONA COURT SAYS VIABLE FETUS IS A PERSON
description: The Arizona Supreme Court has ruled that a viable fetus is a person, allowing parents to bring action under the state's wrongful death law.

title: The Sex Education Critics: Not Parents
description: There are at least 16,000 reasons to hope that all 32 school districts in New York City participate in the new Family Life/Sex Education curriculum. Those reasons are the 16,000 students, some as young as 10, who now get pregnant each year - pregnancies, and tragedies, that could be avoided.

title: Union Calls Off City Contract Vote
description: The city's largest municipal union last night canceled a ratification vote on a tentative contract negotiated last week. The union said the city had ''reneged'' on one issue.

title: INGERSOLL-RAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
G.M.A.C. Plans $3 Billion in Notes
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, announced yesterday that it had filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $3 billion of medium-term notes, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Salomon Brothers.

title: U.S. TO LIST SUSPECTS IN WHITE-COLLAR CRIMES
description: The Reagan Administration will develop a national computerized sytem to track white-collar crime suspects, a top Justice Department official told Congress today.

title: JACKPOT ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $253,000 for the quarter and $335,000 for the 9 months.

title: Advertising;   A Way To 'Coat' TV Spots
description: DOG owners frequently get their pets to take pills by wrapping them in little coats of chopped meat. General Foods is discovering that a similar ploy works pretty well with TV commercials.

title: CROSS, A T CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Spy Suspects' Trial Delayed
description: Testimony in the espionage trial of two Russian emigres, Nikolay and Svetlana Ogorodnikov, was delayed today until further notice because of the illness of Federal District Judge David V. Kenyon Jr. The Ogorodnikovs are charged with conspiring with Richard W. Miller, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to pass secret Government documents to the Soviet Union. Mr. Miller is to be tried later.

title: False Records Reported At Vermont Atom Plant
description: An inspection by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has found evidence of falsified records at the Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant, Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin said today.

title: DELTA AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $37,630,000 from the sale of aircraft.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The only way that I could figure they could improve upon Coca-Cola, one of life's most delightful elixirs, which studies prove will heal the sick and occasionally raise the dead, is to put rum or bourbon in it.'' - Lewis Grizzard, a writer and columnist in Atlanta, where Coke was invented 99 years ago. [A15:3.]

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Coastal Petroleum Co., Tallahassee, Fla., has elected Phillip W. Ware president.

title: SCREEN: 'STICK,' WITH BURT REYNOLDS
description: ELMORE LEONARD'S ''Stick'' could have made a terrific movie, possibly even a terrific movie starring Burt Reynolds, although Mr. Reynolds is more than a little off-base for the title role. ''Dustbowl farmer turned hobo,'' Mr. Leonard writes of Stick, a 42-year-old ex-convict who is ''at a low point in his life'' as the story begins. Stick's favorite movie star, Mr. Leonard mentions repeatedly, is the late Warren Oates.

title: JET AMERICA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: TRANSCO ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'Sprechen Sie Brecht?'
description: It is not true that Washington is a city of permanently frozen attitudes. In 1947, Bertolt Brecht, the German refugee playwright, made his last visit to the capital in response to a subpoena from the House Un-American Activities Committee.

title: FUNDS FREED
description: Congress, by letting a deadline pass for approving cuts proposed by President Reagan in the current fiscal year, today permitted the release of $1.5 billion, including $100 million for summer jobs.

title: Czechs Advance
description: Czechoslovakia scored a 7-2 victory over Sweden today and clinched a berth in the medal round of the World Hockey Championships. As a result of Sweden's defeat, Canada also qualified. The Soviet Union, in first place, and the United States previously qualified for the finals.

title: A Trade Bill Tied to Dollar
description: The Republican chairman of the Senate's principal trade legislating panel today warned that Congress would deny the President authority to push through any new trade legislation until ''something is done'' to deal with the problem of the high dollar.

title: A POSTMODERN ARTIST MEETS THE BALLET THEATER
description: American Ballet Theater will present the New York premiere of David Gordon's new ''Field, Chair and Mountain'' tomorrow night at the Metropolitan Opera House. It is the postmodernist choreographer's first ballet, and a controversial one at that. Whoever heard of a ballet company dancing with chairs?

title: DALE ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REBELS SAY AID DEFEAT IS COMMUNIST VICTORY
description: Two Nicaraguan rebel leaders charged today that the defeat in Congress of renewed aid to the insurgents constituted a ''Communist victory'' and said several key Democrats had a responsibility to bring the Sandinistas to the negotiating table.

title: Making a Match At the Garden
description: Nothing has been signed yet, but Willis Reed appears to be headed back to Madison Square Garden for the first time in an official capacity since the Knicks turned him out as coach seven years ago.

title: MAZE OF OVERHEAD WIRES EXPECTED AT S.I. PROJECTS
description: As the home builders on Staten Island remember it, Lady Bird Johnson's campaign to ''beautify America'' had a direct positive effect on the appearance of new subdivisions.

title: SHULTZ LIKENS LATIN LEFT TO INDOCHINA COMMUNISTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, drawing a parallel between Indochina and Central America, said today that the United States had to help the Nicaraguan rebels to prevent repeating the ''horror'' that resulted from the Communist takeover in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

title: U.S. Is Said to Plan Expulsion of Russian
description: The United States, displeased with the Soviet response to the killing of an American Army intelligence officer in East Germany, is likely to expel a Soviet diplomat, probably a military attache, within the next several days, a State Department official said today.

title: MET'S GONE, BUT OPERA IS STILL ALL OVER TOWN
description: THE Metropolitan Opera has finished its season, and the New York City Opera doesn't start up for a couple of months. But hungry vocal aficionados need not despair: New York is not only the city that never sleeps; it is also the city that can't stop singing.

title: 257 IN THE HOUSE BID KOHL CANCEL CEMETERY EVENT
description: A majority in the House of Representatives, saying that President Reagan's planned visit to a German military cemetery ''threatens to have long and serious repercussions in the United States,'' urged Chancellor Helmut Kohl today to withdraw his invitation to the site.

title: FIRST PEOPLES BANK OF N J reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $9,091,000 from the sale of bank branches.

title: Those Dole Rumors
description: Political Washington, as everyone knows, is the rumor factory with the shortest and speediest assembly line in existence. Normally, fully formed rumors dropping off this line involve a variety of national and international figures.

title: ARKLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income of $522,023 from discontinued operations.

title: REAGAN'S REAL GOAL
description: The continuing Battle of the Budget is not only a struggle for deficit reduction; more importantly, it is a climactic clash of governing philosophies - a powerful effort by President Reagan to wipe out all but the most basic elements of New Deal and post-New Deal social programs.

title: FURRIER IS INDICTED FOR SALES-TAX EVASION
description: A midtown Manhattan fur store and its owner were charged yesterday with a scheme to help customers evade thousands of dollars in city and state sales taxes on the purchases of expensive furs.

title: INITIAL ORBIT OF NEW SATELLITE DIFFERED FROM USUAL
description: A secret Air Force satellite that is widely believed to be an intelligence-gathering device was placed in a radically different orbit from many spy satellites.

title: GQ's Florio Is a Man to Watch
description: The magazine community's major mumblings yesterday had to do with Steven T. Florio, the 36-year-old dynamic publisher of Gentleman's Quarterly, the magazine that had a greater advertising page increase than any other monthly last year. The rumor is that he is Conde Nast's selection to be publisher of The New Yorker.

title: MINNETONKA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PUBLISHING: BILINGUAL EXHIBITION OF LATIN AUTHORS
description: A couple of years ago, Isaac Goldemberg was invited to read his poetry at a weeklong fair in Washington devoted to Latin American books. ''On my way home to New York,'' the Peruvian-born author recalled, ''I said to myself, 'If they can get a turnout of 300 to 400 a day in Washington for Latin books, why can't we have something similar in New York?' ''

title: Repeal New York State's Blind Mandatory-Sentencing Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: MALCOLM MCDOWELL AS 'AUTHOR THE KING,' ON CBS
description: AS legends go, King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table have their devoted admirers, even though many observers have reservations about some of the conniving that took place in fabled Camelot. Show business is especially attracted to the story, which has been adapted for Hollywood and Broadway. And now there is ''Arthur the King,'' a three-hour television movie on Channel 2 this evening at 8.

title: E G & G INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of approximately $2,000,000, or 7 cents a share, from DISC tax benefits.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 26, 1985

title: GRAND SLAM KNOCKS TIGERS OUT OF FIRST
description: Ted Simmons smacked a grand slam with two out in the bottom of the ninth as the Milwaukee Brewers scored five times in each of the last two innings and defeated the Detroit Tigers, 11-7, tonight.

title: Still Counting in Indiana
description: Controversy over Indiana's Eighth Congressional District seat continues to grow, while the possibility fades of conclusively determining who actually has been elected to it. It's time for the House to declare the seat vacant so that Indiana's Governor can authorize a special election.

title: PRODUCTIVITY DOWN 1.2%
description: Business productivity declined by 1.2 percent in the first quarter, the Labor Department reported today, reflecting a slowdown in economic growth. Productivity had last declined in the third quarter of 1984.

title: RICHARDSON'S WAYS CRITICIZED
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, smothered by a double-teaming defense, was looking desperately for help Wednesday night as the Nets struggled to hold a 1-point lead in the final seconds of their third playoff game against the Detroit Pistons.

title: Senate Panel Delays Action on Genocide Pact
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today took up the long-delayed United Nations treaty condemning genocide and then put off for perhaps two weeks a vote to bring the matter to the floor.

title: Crocker Officer Resigns
description: The Crocker National Corporation said yesterday that David A. Brooks, 45 years old, a vice chairman of the holding company and its Crocker National Bank unit, had resigned. Mr. Brooks, who has headed Crocker's specialized financial services and real estate group since last August, was not available for comment, but Wall Street analysts said his resignation was voluntary. Crocker said that Mr. Brooks's position would not be filled.

title: PULLMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,920,000 for the quarter and $3,880,000 for the six months. c-After a gain of $834,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter, a loss of $978,000 from discontinued operations for the six months and a tax credit of $26,000 for the quarter and the six months.

title: COMMERCE CLEARING HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Benefit Concert at U.N.
description: The wives of 39 African ambassadors are sponsoring a benefit concert in the General Assembly hall tonight at 7 o'clock.

title: Track Pile-Up
description: It was a one-horse stumble followed by a four-cart pile-on, and when the spectacular chain reaction was over at the Meadowlands Wednesday night, five horses were out of the race, four drivers were on the ground and two had serious injuries, Tom Haughton, with a double fracture of the right leg, and Catello Manzi, with a double fracture of the collarbone. Both were listed in good condition at the Hackensack Medical Center yesterday.

title: Chevron Waiting
description: The Chevron Corporation has not received any firm purchase offers for its 60 percent interest in Gulf Canada Ltd., but efforts to sell the holding are continuing, said Gulf Canada's president, S. Keith McWalter. Chevron acquired the Gulf Canada interest this year, and it assured the Canadian Government that the holding would be offered first to Canadian concerns until April 30.

title: JAPAN TO EASE DRUG PRODUCT RULES
description: Japan has agreed in principle to simplify some of the rules governing access to its pharmaceuticals and medical equipment markets, American trade negotiators said today.

title: TRANSCO EXPLORATION PARTERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ARUNDEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
E.E.C. Prices Up 0.7%
description: Consumer prices in the 10-nation Common Market rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in March from February, the trade bloc's statistical agency reported today.

title: African Pop Music
description: The Zairian guitarist Franco and his group, T.P.O.K. Jazz, including 16 musicians and six dancers, will play African pop music Sunday at 7 P.M. at Manhattan Center, 311 West 34th Street. Tickets are $16 and $20. Information: (718) 493-4500.

title: Delta Net Off; Braniff Gains
description: Delta Air Lines reported yesterday that its income in the latest quarter declined 22 percent, to $41.2 million, or $1.03 a share, from $52.8 million, or $1.33 a share, a year earlier. Revenues for the quarter, the third in its fiscal year, edged up 8.3 percent, to $1.17 billion, from $1.08 billion.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $1.47 billion, to $211.31 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs;   Celtics Clinch Series
description: Larry Bird, playing despite a painful right elbow, scored 34 points tonight to send the Boston Celtics to a 117-115 triumph over the Cleveland Cavaliers, giving Boston a 3-1 victory in their Eastern Conference quarterfinal series.

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are restated for a 100 percent stock dividend paid April 1.

title: WOMEN 3 STROKES OFF LEAD
description: Mickey Wright, 50 years old and once the best female golfer in the world, explained her feelings at the first tee today at the eighth annual Legends of Golf tournament: ''I felt like a teen-ager who had never had a golf club in her hand before and just prayed I wouldn't whiff.''

title: CABARET: NOVELLA NELSON
description: MORE than a decade ago, Novella Nelson began working in a style that set her apart from other contemporary singers, using a brusque, declamatory projection that might border on the conversational if it were not so intense. The basis of her accompaniment was usually the pianist Linda Twine, either alone or as part of a small group.

title: DONNELLEY, R R & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HISTORY DOESN'T DIE
description: The damage has already been done by the incredible mishandling of President Reagan's trip to West Germany next week. German-American relations were fine and didn't require any special, flashy gestures. But in the era of TV politics, men who should be primarily concerned with statesmanship apparently can't resist stagemanship.

title: Labor Board Backs U.M.W. in Coal Dispute
description: The National Labor Relations Board handed the United Mine Workers a major victory Wednesday in its dispute with the A. T. Massey Coal Company, accusing the company of an unfair labor practice for refusing to bargain as a single employer.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Sports Pages on Tuesday with an article about college athletic eligibility gave incorrect median graduation rates for 1977 freshmen as a whole. Each figure in the bottom line of the table, which was taken from a report prepared for the National Collegiate Athletic Association by Advanced Technology Inc., should have been moved one column to the right. The correct rates are 37 percent after four years, 50 percent after five and 55 percent after six.

title: Ruling on Unocal May Hurt Pickens
description: A legal ruling that could potentially derail T. Boone Pickens's takeover move against the Unocal Corporation was issued yesterday.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF COLOADO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday BOOKS WITH A PEDIGREE Looking for a good book? How about the first Latin edition of Marco Polo's ''Travels,'' published in the Netherlands in 1483? The manuscript journal of the Marquis de Chastellux, second in command of French forces in the American Revolution, might offer some interesting reading. And surely the first dictionary of the Aztec language, printed in Mexico in 1571, would intrigue - or perhaps a 17th-century account of a trip to the moon, a document presumed to be fictional until someone proves otherwise. All are among the items available at the 1985 New York Antiquarian Book Fair, which begins today at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue, at 67th Street. More than 100 exhibitors from the United States and abroad will be on hand with books, prints, drawings, maps and manuscripts of all kinds. The book fair is open from 4 to 9 P.M. today; on Saturday from 1 to 9, and on Sunday from 11 A.M. until 5 P.M. Admission is $7. Information: 832-8231.

title: CITY TO HONOR ITS BEST TREES
description: Today is Arbor Day, and at festivities around the city this weekend it won't be hard to tell the guests of honor: they will be the hundreds of trees that dot city parks and the young saplings that will be planted by schoolchildren in celebration of the event.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: RUNNING down the length of the table was fabric in a black-and-white keyboard effect, with silvery musical notes suspended above. At each place a menu in the form of a musical score was headed Etude de Diner and listed dishes named for the guests. There was caviar Coleman (Cy), toasted pita Pakula (Hannah), Frank and Fernanda's fermier de veau (Gilligan), legumes Lerner (Karen), Judy Green beans and Brie a la Buatta (Mario).

title: FROZEN FOOD EXPRESS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rates Show Modest Advance
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday, as hopes of an easier monetary policy seemed to fade at the same time as traders are bracing for a heavy supply of new Treasury notes and bonds.

title: BALLY MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SWEET LAND OF LIBERTY AND CHILI
description: As if Congress didn't already have enough on its plate, what with budget battles and whether to aid the Nicaraguan rebels, now comes another hot issue: Whether to designate chili as America's official food.

title: MUSIC: MARGARET NEWMAN
description: THE pianist Margaret Newman, who played Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall, is a fine miniaturist and was at her best in three pieces by Spanish composers - Manuel de Falla's ''Vida Breve,'' Enrique Granados's ''Maiden and the Nightingale'' and Manuel Infante's ''El Vito,'' which were played leisurely and lovingly, the phrasing imbued with subtle poetry.

title: Gen. Pavel Batov Dies at 87; Warsaw Pact Ex-Staff Chief
description: Gen. Pavel I. Batov of the Soviet Union, former chief of staff of the Warsaw Pact's joint armed forces and a veteran of three wars, has died after a long illness, the Government newspaper Izvestia reported today. He was 87.

title: THE SCREEN: TEXAS, VINTAGE '1918,' DIRECTED BY KEN HARRISON
description: MUCH like its small-town Texas characters, Horton Foote's ''1918,'' directed by Ken Harrison, is a movie of such tight-lipped self-control - and such distrust of fancified melodramatic conceits - that it's not easy at first to get to know it.

title: STAGE: WITH HUCK FINN ON THE 'BIG RIVER'
description: ''BIG RIVER: THE ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN'' is the last Broadway musical of the season - but, more important, it is the first that audiences can attend without fear of suffering either profound embarrassment or terminal boredom. This show has a lot going for it: a tuneful score by the country-music songsmith Roger Miller, exuberant performers and a gifted young director, Des McAnuff, who is full of clever ideas about how to bring Mark Twain's masterpiece to the stage.

title: SEARLE TRUSTS' BIG STOCK SALE
description: In the latest twist in the Searle family's efforts to diversify its holdings, G.D. Searle & Company, the pharmaceutical house that produces the artificial sweetener aspartame, announced today that it had purchased 7.5 million shares of stock from several Searle family trusts, for $388.1 million, or $51.75 a share.

title: U.S. SEEKS SITE IN TENNESSEE AS A DEPOT FOR REACTOR FUEL
description: The Energy Department said today that it was seeking to build a major facility in Tennessee to serve as a national transfer and temporary storage point for spent radioactive fuel from nuclear power plants.

title: NORTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $4,375,000 from the sale of securities.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Saturday about the Henry Street Settlement's Urban Family Center for the homeless described its financing incorrectly. Shelter space is provided by the New York City Housing Authority, and operating funds come from the Human Resources Administration.

title: AS PRICES SOAR, COST OF LAND FOR TIMES SQUARE PLAN IS HARDER TO ESTIMATE
description: In January 1980, a company headed by Michael J. Lazar, a former City Taxi Commissioner, bought a white terra-cotta office building on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues for $1.3 million.

title: STUDY URGES OVERHAUL OF SPECIAL EDUCATION IN CITY
description: New York City's special-education program for more than 116,000 physically and emotionally handicapped students ''is too often special in name only'' and needs a comprehensive overhaul, a mayoral commission said yesterday.

title: Conviction Affirmed In Slaying at the Met
description: The state's highest court today upheld the murder conviction of Craig S. Crimmins in the death of a violinist at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: FUGITIVES WERE ALOOF, NEIGHBORS SAY
description: In the last phase of their flight from a nationwide F.B.I. manhunt, Thomas and Carol Manning used the aliases Charles and Allison Boone.

title: Jacobs Bids For 50.5% Of AMF
description: Minstar Inc., a holding company controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, said yesterday that it would make a cash tender offer of $23 a share, or $276 million, to gain a 50.5 percent stake in AMF Inc., the financially troubled leisure equipment maker that Mr. Jacobs has pursued for weeks.

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $178,400,000 from the sale of Investors Diversified Inc.

title: SONAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PURITAN-BENNETT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gretzky Sparks Sweep
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, April 25 (AP) - Wayne Gretzky scored three goals and had four assists tonight night as the Edmonton Oilers crushed the Winnipeg Jets, 8-3, and swept the Smythe Division playoff in four games.

title: DOSKOCIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $615,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $800,000.

title: THE VISITOR FROM SEOUL
description: Rarely does a day pass without photographs of President Chun Doo Hwan appearing on the front pages of South Korea's Government-regulated newspapers. Nightly news programs begin invariably with long recapitulations of his day.

title: MEM CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FILM: 'UNSUITABLE JOB FOR A WOMAN'
description: AT the very least, an interesting detective film ought to offer an interesting detective. But the heroine of ''An Unsuitable Job for a Woman,'' which is based on a novel by P. D. James, is the young Cordelia Gray. In the film, if not in the novel, Cordelia's inexperience takes the form of methods that are far from irreproachable. Would Sherlock Holmes, in trying to determine whether a supposed suicide victim actually hanged himself with a belt, try to re-enact this himself - and then accidentally kick over the chair?

title: PROMOTER IS GUILTY IN $445 MILLION TAX FRAUD
description: A financial promoter pleaded guilty yesterday to conducting a fraudulent tax shelter scheme that provided $445 million in false income tax deductions for wealthy investors.

title: POLE DENOUNCES POLICE IN SMUGGLED PRISON LETTER
description: In a letter smuggled out of his jail cell in Gdansk, the dissident Adam Michnik has denounced the Polish police, appealed for international monitoring of his coming trial and urged that the treatment of political prisoners be added to the agenda of the Geneva arms talks.

title: Quaker Oats Up 35.3%
description: The Quaker Oats Company today reported a 35.3 percent increase in third-quarter earnings, largely as a result of improved operations in the company's grocery, toy and specialty retail businesses.

title: IOWA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MURPHY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SUIT ON CHURCH'S COUNSELING TESTS RELIGIOUS ISSUES
description: A church that gives emotional counseling based on the Bible stands accused of ignoring modern psychiatric methods and negligently causing a man's suicide.

title: Bar a World War III, Willy Brandt Pleads
description: Former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany received the $100,000 Third World Prize today and called on the superpowers to agree ''on rules which make World War III impossible.''

title: TURMOIL IN TROUBLED PRECINCT CENTERS ON 'THE STRIP'
description: For the last seven years, Officer Abraham Jenkins of the 106th Precinct has patrolled a strip of tattered storefronts in South Ozone Park, Queens. In that time he has made over 400 arrests.

title: JEFFERSON SMURFIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OHIO CASUALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $1,698,000 for the latest quarter and $2,751,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Philip Morris Net Rises
description: Philip Morris Inc. reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings had increased 25 percent, to $256.4 million, from $205.1 million in the 1984 period. Revenues were up 3 percent, to $3.3 billion, from $3.2 billion, and pretax income jumped 24.2 percent, to $465.6 million, from $375 million. A proposal to reorganize the company into a holding company structure was approved yesterday.

title: ANDERSEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
An Air Fair
description: The Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum, the most popular tourist attraction in the capital, has an annex out in Suitland, Md., with five hangarfuls of famous flying machines that won't fit into the big exhibition hall on the Mall. This Paul E. Garber Facility is normally available only for arranged tours, but tomorrow and Sunday the public is invited to inspect more than 90 air and space craft at the annual open house there.

title: CHRYSLER PROFIT OFF 28.1% AS TAX PAYMENTS JUMP
description: The Chrysler Corporation, back to being an ordinary, tax-paying corporation again, today reported that first-quarter earnings dropped 28.1 percent, largely because of higher Federal income tax payments.

title: FIRST DATA MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Put and Call Option Plan
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday announced plans to begin trading put and call options on the securities of 10 over-the-counter companies. The move follows the approval last week of such trading by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The starting date is to be set soon.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: HUBERTS has been known as a restaurant that takes itself oh-so-seriously, the kind of place where it would be unseemly to chuckle when a waiter, speaking with the solemnity of a country pastor, describes dishes with names like scallop waltz, shrimp with smashed cucumbers and country captain chicken. Happily, these gastronomic missionaries have loosened up a bit lately, and their dedication to quality has not. In fact, they are winning more converts than ever.

title: Ferraro Meets With Pope
description: Pope John Paul II received Geraldine A. Ferraro, the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for Vice President, in a private audience in the Vatican today. As usual, Vatican officials did not disclose what the Pope and Mrs. Ferraro, a Roman Catholic, had discussed in their meeting.

title: SAVIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Because the company changed to a calendar year from a year ended April 30, year-ago results are for the quarter ended April 30, 1984.

title: Market Place;   Arco Favored By Analysts
description: SHARES of the Atlantic Richfield Company rose to their highest price since 1981 yesterday in continued heavy trading, thanks initially to an upgraded recommendation by Eugene L. Nowak, who heads the energy group at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: OGDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KOHL, UNBENDING ON BITBURG, IS GRATEFUL TO REAGAN
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl praised President Reagan today as ''a friend of our people'' for agreeing to lay a wreath next month at a German military cemetery, and gave no hint that he intended to release the President from his commitment.

title: RIO ALGOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
7TH AVENUE PRESENTS NEW WAYS TO LOOK FOR FALL
description: From the audacious urchin look of Danny Noble's British-inspired clothes to the cinema-siren glamour dresses of Bob Mackie, the New York fashion openings offer a number of fresh slants on fall dressing. And for women who prefer a middle-of-the-road approach, there is the latest edition of A Trigere Coat. Pauline Trigere's moderate-price versions of her couture-caliber coat designs are being produced for the first season by Lepshire Manufacturing Company, a Chicago-based concern that promises to keep the majority of styles in the $300 to $400 price range.

title: L.I. JURY ACQUITS DEFENDANT IN KILLING OF YOUTH IN WOODS
description: James Troiano was acquitted today of charges that he helped murder Gary Lauwers in a drug-induced frenzy.

title: Apple Bank Filing
description: The Apple Bank for Savings filed for permission to convert to a stock ownership from a mutually owned organization.

title: Jets Get Chiefs' Jackson
description: The Jets yesterday acquired Charles Jackson, an eighth-year linebacker, from the Kansas City Chiefs for the seventh-round draft pick in Tuesday's National Football League draft of college players. The trade was the first time in 10 years that the Jets acquired a front-line player in a trade.

title: Petroleum Reserve Is a Good Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $72,000.

title: Bridge: Poughkeepsie Tournament Includes a National Playoff
description: A sectional tournament beginning today in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., at the Eastman Park Y.M.C.A. will have a national flavor. Running in parallel with the concluding Swiss team event Sunday will be the area playoff in the Grand National Teams.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK & TRUST PALM BEACH reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WARD CALLS TOP NEW YORK OFFICERS TO A MEETING ON BRUTALITY CHARGES
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, reacting to rising complaints of police brutality and allegations that some prisoners have been tortured, yesterday ordered New York City's 377 top-ranking officers to meet with him today at Police Headquarters.

title: Violations
description: The Village Gate, where the musical based on Mayor Koch's book is to open May 13, is on this week's violations list of Mayor Koch's Health Department.

title: 'WHERE'S PICONE?'
description: ''WHERE'S PICONE?'', a new Italian film directed by Nanni Loy (''Cafe Express''), is less a black - or even a charred - comedy than you might think from the opening sequence.

title: Stocks Register A Moderate Gain
description: Oil, insurance and takeover stocks provided most of the excitement on Wall Street yesterday, as the stock market posted a moderate gain on improved trading volume.

title: PETER TESTAN
description: Peter Testan, an early ham-radio operator and a former officer and chief engineer of radio stations WBBC in Brooklyn and WVNJ in Newark, died April 18 at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Morris Township, N.J.

title: LOCALITIES AND STATES PRESS SOUTH AFRICAN DIVESTMENT EFFORT
description: In seven months, as clashes between the police and demonstrators in South Africa have intensified, cities and states at an increasing pace have enacted laws to dissociate themselves from investments linked to South Africa.

title: A CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, a sentence in a letter yesterday from William L. Shirer referring to the idea that German soldiers felt themselves ''victims of Nazism'' was incorrect. It should have read ''It saddens me that the President has embraced it and that he cannot see the difference between these loyal soldiers of the Third Reich and the millions the Germans butchered in the camps.''

title: BRUNO'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid April 12.

title: Diner's Journal
description: SOMETIMES a restaurant of modest scope and ambition is worth noting for one dish that it does well. Such is the case with a curious little place at Lexington Avenue between 28th and 29th Streets called Tracy's. Steamed lobster is the specialty here, and for the remarkable price of $9.25 I enjoyed two one-pounders recently for lunch. They came with melted butter and a nutcracker, which is all lobster fanciers require.

title: Under the Corcoran Dome
description: For reasons not entirely clear, the architect of the Corcoran Gallery installed a domed rotunda in the center of the otherwise rectangular building in the early 1890's, and now, at long last, the museum has an exhibition specifically designed for this unusual space. Opening there tomorrow will be ''the Corcoran Panorama,'' a series of 14 canvases that merge into a single narrative painting when hung in a band around the circular gallery.

title: CRONUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: GUARDIAN PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AIRFORCE SUPERPLANE OF 1990'S SEEN AS FORCING UNWANTED CHOICES
description: The Air Force might have to shrink the size of its fighter plane forces to pay for its superplane of the 1990's, the Advanced Tactical Fighter, according to a Congressional study issued today.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BLACKS FEARING RELOCATION SEND PLEA TO SHULTZ
description: Leaders of a small black community threatened with involuntary resettlement by the white authorities said today that they had written to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, asking him to intercede with the South African Government to prevent their removal.

title: U.S. Charges Bank Officers
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation brought a complaint in Federal court here today against four former Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company officers.

title: TAKING THE HEAT OVER THE BITBURG VISIT
description: There are two photographs in the office of Marshall J. Breger in which Mr. Breger, the White House official for Jewish affairs, is shaking the hand of his boss, President Reagan.

title: GULF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BIC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ENERGY FACTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AT THE MOVIES
description: CHUCK NORRIS has an 18-stitch scar over his eyebrow, incurred when he fell out of a tree making ''Missing in Action 2,'' and a 16-stitch scar below his lip thanks to the original ''Missing in Action.'' This is hardly the only evidence that Mr. Norris flings himself into film making wholeheartedly. Only eight years after ''Good Guys Wear Black,'' his first feature, Mr. Norris has become a one-man cottage industry. By August, when his ''Invasion U.S.A.'' opens, he will have had four films released in New York in less than a year.

title: REAGAN-KOHL TIES: CASUALTY OF DISPUTE?
description: Through a quest for a telegenic symbol of reconciliation, followed by botched staff work, Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Reagan have stumbled into a dispute that Bonn officials fear has undermined carefully orchestrated plans for the 40th anniversary of the surrender of Nazi Germany.

title: Kathryn Crosby Shifts
description: Kathryn Crosby, three days after announcing she was withdrawing the family name from the Bing Crosby National Pro-Am golf tournament because it was controlled by the ''wrong elements,'' has changed her mind, saying she will work to keep the name associated with the annual tour event at Pebble Beach, Calif. The widow of the singer said through a family friend, ''I have been besieged by requests from all over the world to make a final effort to save Bing's tournament.''

title: T. E. Lawrence Story On Channel 13 Tonight
description: Whatever else Thomas Edward Lawrence, the controversial Lawrence of Arabia may have been, he was not boring, and his life has spun off a steady stream of books and dramas. The newest of these, ''Lawrence of Arabia: The Master Illusionist,'' takes to the home screens on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results include losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $516,000 for the latest quarter and $298,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: TIMES MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HEART RECIPIENT'S DEATH ATTRIBUTED TO UNDETECTED BLOOD CLOTS
description: The hospital staff spent the last hours of Jack C. Burcham's life Wednesday desperately trying to determine why blood was rapidly filling his chest. They never did, and Mr. Burcham, the fifth and most recent recipient of a permanent artificial heart, was taken off support systems Wednesday night when he showed no signs of life.

title: SOUTHDOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'Contra' Terrorism Is, Unfortunately, True
description: To the Editor:

title: Hilton Rejects Bid
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said that its board had unanimously rejected a bid by Golden Nugget Inc. for Hilton's unopened Atlantic City casino-hotel. Hilton said that Golden Nugget's offer consisted of $260 million in 8 percent debentures; a 15-acre parcel of land that Golden Nugget valued at $84 million, and a conditional option for Hilton to repurchase the casino-hotel. Hilton said its previously announced negotiations for the sale of the hotel to Donald Trump, the real estate developer, were continuing.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Princess Yasmin Aga Khan Engaged to Basil Embiricos
description: Princess Yasmin Aga Khan, the daughter of Rita Hayworth and the late Prince Aly Khan, and Basil Embiricos, scion of a Greek shipping family, plan to be married this summer. Announcement of their engagement was made in Gouvieux, France, by the future bride's half-brother, the Aga Khan.

title: Frontier Air's President In Surprise Resignation
description: In a move that surprised employees who are negotiating to buy the company, M.C. (Hank) Lund resigned yesterday as president and a director of Frontier Holdings Inc. and its financially troubled Frontier Airlines subsidiary, citing disagreements over the airline's future strategy.

title: REICHHOLD CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest quarter include a pre-tax gain of $5,600,000 from the sale of the company's White City, Oregon, forest products resins plant. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: REAGAN AND THE DEFICIT
description: President Reagan, in appealing for support for a compromise budget to end what he termed an ''immoral, dead-end course of deficit spending,'' struck notes more akin to those Walter F.

title: CANADIENS WIN; SERIES TIED
description: It took the Montreal Canadiens less than 3 minutes to render Michel Goulet ineffective tonight. And, with the Stanley Cup playoffs' top goal-scorer knocked out of the their lineup, the Quebec Nordiques were rendered losers.

title: MASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REBUFF FOR THE PRESIDENT
description: The setback dealt to President Reagan by Congress over aid to Nicaraguan rebels reflects a mood of mistrust toward the President's objectives on the issue and a fear of deepening United States military involvement in the region over the long run.

title: MEAD'S BID FOR CROWN FALLS APART
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation yesterday thought it had a deal to be sold to the Mead Corporation. Then it tried to make peace with Sir James Goldsmith, the British businessman who has sought control of the company. But it ended the day empty-handed.

title: MILLIPORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONNECTICUT HOUSE PASSES LEGISLATION TO RAISE DRINKING AGE TO 21
description: The State House of Representatives, by a vote of 114 to 30, today approved legislation raising Connecticut's legal drinking age to 21, from 20, on Sept. 1.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $286,000. The latest first-quarter net was decreased by $800,000, or 14 cents a share, because of reduced inventories, which resulted in liquidations of LIFO inventory quantities carried at the lower costs that prevailed in prior years.

description: b-After a loss of $322,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and income of $884,000 from discontinued operations for the nine months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,150,000 for the quarter and $2,268,000 for the nine months.

title: UNITED, T.W.A. WARN THEY'LL HIRE IN A STRIKE
description: The top executives of two major air carriers, Trans World Airlines and United Airlines, said yesterday that they would hire replacements to keep operating if some of their unions went on strike.

title: BUSH SIGNALS 1988 BID WITH A PLAN TO OPEN POLITICAL ACTION PANEL
description: In the most telling indication so far that he might make a 1988 Presidential bid, Vice President Bush said today that he would establish a political action committee within the next several days.

title: Interpublic Net Off
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies reported yesterday that it had a 20.8 percent drop in net income in the first quarter, to $3.8 million, or 35 cents a share, from $4.8 million, or 45 cents, in the 1984 period.

title: SOURCE CAPITAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Asset figures represent total net assets. Latest quarter figures are after distributions of $3.125 a share during the 12-month period ended March 31, and a federal income tax liability of 50.3 cents a share for undistributed long- term gains at Dec. 31, 1984.

title: BERGER LIKELY TO GET PORT AGENCY JOB
description: Governor Cuomo and Governor Kean are said to be near agreement on the selection of Stephen Berger as executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: CACI GROUP OF COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Cathedral 'Bomb' Is Only a Clock
description: A 28-year-old unemployed man walked to the main altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral carrying a plastic bag shortly before 7 o'clock last evening, announced that he had a bomb inside and demanded to see Archbishop John J. O'Connor.

title: FILTERTEK COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MUSIC: BEHRENS RECITAL
description: Hildegard Behrens, by her own report, had never given a song recital of any kind until last night, when she made her Carnegie Hall debut with an ambitious lieder program. Miss Behrens, whom we know as one of the foremost Wagnerian sopranos of our day, leaped into this new phase of her career with characteristic abandon, and for much of the evening made a modest success of the enterprise.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates at Shea Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Opener of a three-game weekend series. The Pirates ended the Mets' season-opening string of five victories when they met April 15. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. White Sox at Chicago. Opener of a three-game weekend series. The Yankees swept the White Sox in a two-game series at the Stadium, but left for the trip reeling from losses to Boston that featured sloppy play. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30. Radio - WABC 770, 8:30 P.M.) Basketball Bulls vs. Milwaukee Bucks at Chicago, Game 4 of the three-of five series. Milwaukee leads the series, 2-1. (Television - WTBS 8:05 P.M.) Utah Jazz vs. Houston Rockets, at Salt Lake City. Game 4 of the three-of-five Western Conference playoff series, which the Jazz leads by 2-1. (Television - WTBS 10:30 P.M.) Boxing Troy Darrell vs. Aristides Merced, 10 rounds, junior middleweights, and Horacio Perez vs. Jose Quinones, 12 rounds, middleweights, at the Felt Forum. The undefeated Darrell, 16-0 with 15 knockouts, is a Forum favorite; he has won all 10 of his appearances there by knockouts. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M.) Marlon Starling, champion, vs. Floyd Mayweather, 12 rounds, United States Boxing Association welterweight title bout at the Tropicana Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8 P.M. Starling took a 10-round decision from Mayweather in Hartford in 1980.

title: HAROLD YOUNGBLOOD Jr.
description: Harold A. Youngblood Jr., a former deputy director of special programs at the New York State Council on the Arts, died Monday at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City. He was 53 years old, and suffered from a brain tumor.

Aqaba-Sinai Ferry Is Formally Begun
description: The leaders of Egypt, Jordan, and Oman inaugurated a ferry service this week between the Egyptian port of Nuweiba in southern Sinai and the Jordanian Red Sea resort of Aqaba.

title: PIPER, JAFFRAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange.

title: ART:MAYA TREASURES, THE TINY AND THE VAST
description: FROM evidence dug up so far, it appears that the cleverest, hardest-working and most cultivated people of pre-Columbian America were the Mayas, described by the archeologist Sylvanus G. Morley as ''the Greeks of the New World.'' Architects and stonemasons, they built huge palace and temple clusters without benefit of the wheel or animal transport. Astronomers and mathematicians, they devised a remarkably accurate calendar system. Artists and artisans, they produced a body of sculpture, painting and ceramics that ranks with those of the world's great cultures. And, of all the New World ancients, they developed the only true written language. Their complex civilization is a long way from being fully plumbed, but so lively is the present state of Maya archaeology that each year brings new revelations and revisions.

title: Women Set Penn Records
description: In last summer's United States Olympic trials, Sabrina Dornhoefer of Missouri finished 10th in the women's 3,000-meter run and Piper Bressant of Florida eighth in the 400-meter hurdles. Both learned lessons from those disappointments and turned them into victories in meet-record times today in the 91st annual Penn Relays.

title: NIEKRO'S KNUCKLERS BAFFLE THE RED SOX
description: At 46, Phil Niekro is more than twice as old as Dwight Gooden and throws half as fast, or so it seems. Yet the knuckleballer dazzled the Boston Red Sox with a spate of strikeouts last night and now has a better 1985 strikeout ratio than Gooden, who last seaosn set a major league record with his ratio.

title: $60 Million Is Set For Venture Fund
description: The New York State Common Retirement Fund and the New York State Teachers Retirement System have agreed to invest $60 million in a joint venture capital fund to finance New York-based companies in early stages of growth or in special situations.

title: HBO & CO (ATLANTIC, GA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results have been restated to reflect the acquisitions of Amherst Associates Inc. and Mediflex Corp. which were accounted for as pooling of interests.

title: COLUMBIA PROTEST ENDS, BUT NEW ACTION IS VOWED
description: Student protesters at Columbia University removed padlocks and chains from a major campus building last night, ending their three-week demonstration against the university's investment policy on South Africa.

title: CUBANS LEAVING, NICARAGUAN SAYS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has said that the Government will soon carry out its pledges to send 100 Cuban advisers home and to free a number of people held on charges of subversion.

SHELLING HITS RESIENTIAL BEIRUT
description: Artillery duels broke out today between the Moslem and Christian halves of Beirut, and shells fell on residential areas for the first time in 10 months.

Ecumed Project Shelved in Florida
description: Ecumed, a proposed $775 million medical trade and exposition center scheduled to open in 1988 on 300 acres in southwest Broward County, Fla., was shelved today by its developer, Tishman Speyer Properties of New York.

title: Wish List
description: He doesn't mean to antagonize anybody, John Bassett said in his letter to Commissioner Pete Rozelle and the owners of the 28 teams in the National Football League. In fact, he closed the letter by sending his ''best to Carrie,'' who is the commissioner's wife, and ''my kindest personal regards.''

description: Just 72 hours after rejecting a leveraged buyout offer from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, Storer Communications Inc. did an about-face, and said it would accept a slightly improved $2.1 billion version of the deal, in what would be the largest transaction in which a company went private.

description: When a noted former Mayor of Atlanta fell ill near the end of his life, reporters converged on a city hospital and demanded to know how the patient was doing.

title: Topics;   Strength and Weakness Country Lawyer
description: The strengths and weaknesses of Sam Ervin, who died recently at 88, were both large-scale. For two decades in the Senate he stoutly defended a broad reading of the Bill of Rights.

PERU LEFTIST DROPS OUT OF ELECTION
description: Peru's leftist parties, in a three-hour meeting, decided today to withdraw from the presidential election runoff, handing the office uncontested to a center-left Congressman, Alan Garcia, a spokesmen said.

description: President Reagan's budget speech Wednesday night apparently stirred thousands of citizens to call their representatives in Congress.

title: Union Pacific Chief To Add Top Post
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that William S. Cook, its president and chief executive officer since May 1983, would assume the additional responsibilities of chairman, effective July 1.

title: Schools to Stay Open At Start of Passover
description: New York City public schools will remain open on the first two days of Passover next year because the holidays, marking the Jewish exodus from Egypt and fixed by the lunar calendar, fall three weeks later than the schools' spring recess.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

Lindner May Fight Gannett Proposals
description: Carl H. Lindner, a former owner of The Cincinnati Enquirer, said yesterday that he owned 5 percent of the Gannett Company and might wage a proxy fight to prevent the adoption of several measures that would block an unwanted takeover.

title: MANTLE ON AIR
description: Mickey Mantle has reached a tentative agreement with SportsChannel to join the cable network's team of Yankee broadcasters, according to his agent, who said that the 53-year-old former Yankee slugger could be in the booth at the Stadium as early as the Cleveland game May 4. The Dallas-based agent, Roy True, would not say how much Mantle would be paid, but said he would work only some of the 36 games SportsChannel is scheduled to broadcast to its more than 400,000 subscribers in the metropolitan area. Mantle would be be the fourth man in the booth, along with Mel Allen, Phil Rizzuto and Bill White.

description: Share earnings are per ADR (American Depositary Receipt) and four units of Imperial Chemical's ordinary stock are represented by each ADR. The results reported in pounds sterling have been expressed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.23 to the pound, the rate prevailing on March 31, 1985.

title: SERIES OF CORRUPTION CHARGES FILED IN HARLEM HOSPITAL INVESTIGATION
description: A Manhattan grand jury issued a series of indictments yesterday in what the state described as a continuing criminal investigation of corruption at the Harlem Hospital Center.

title: ISLANDERS TOP FLYERS TO STAY ALIVE IN PLAYOFFS
description: At the edge yet again, the Islanders defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 6-2, tonight and their hopes for still another comeback kept going.

title: BROADWAY
description: ''SONG & DANCE,'' Andrew Lloyd Webber's divertissement about the life and loves of an English girl who moves to America, completed three workshop performances last week and is now aiming for the the Great White Way, perhaps in September. Richard Maltby Jr. would direct, and making his Broadway debut as a choreographer would be Peter Martins, the Danish-born co-balletmaster in chief of the New York City Ballet.

A month ago, the financing unit of the Borg-Warner Corporation began calling in about $214 million in loans to White Farm operations in the United States and Canada.

GREEK JOURNALISTS GET JAIL TERMS FOR ILLEGAL USE OF WIRETAP TAPES
description: The publisher and the editor of the newspaper with the largest circulation in Greece were sentenced today to five months' imprisonment on charges arising from the wiretapping of an office used by The New York Times in Athens.

Governor Cuomo is sympathetic, but offers a bill that would provide only symbolic relief. He and the Legislature need to think harder about the problem.

title: They're Still Brewing Beer in Milwaukee

title: GOULD ART COLLECTION BRINGS RECORD PRICES
description: The record-breaking two-day auction of Florence J. Gould's 200 Impressionist and modern artworks ended yesterday at Sotheby's. Wednesday's sale had set record auction prices for an Impressionist painting and for a single-session sale of art from a collection.

title: RANCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $360,000 relating to the sale of property in Germany.

title: $12,000 for Fire Victim
description: Bert Andrews, the theatrical photographer whose mid-Manhattan studio and 30-year collection of photographs were destroyed by fire Jan. 29, received $12,000 last week to aid in the restoration of his studio and archives.

Advanced Micro

Advanced Micro said that it had no plans for layoffs.

title: DOCUMENTING THE ART OF SURVIVING
description: Marjorie Hunt coaxes ordinary people into surrendering remembrances of things past. In a city often given to a frenzied search for what's next, she specializes in what has been, recording Nimrod Workman's sad and happy times as a Tennessee coal miner or the separate tales behind the ''memory pictures'' that Ethel Mohamed hand-embroidered as her family saga over 50 years.

description: The Mets got a double dose of bad news yesterday when Bruce Berenyi and Mookie Wilson were found suffering from inflamed right shoulders. Both were ordered to rest and seemed headed for the disabled list.

description: The Mayor of New York, a man to whom culinary matters matter, recently suggested several substitutes for striped bass, which is suspected of contamination with PCB's. Grouper, he said, tastes like lobster, and Norwegian salmon is really swell, especially when sauteed with garlic.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE title of this new novel by Charles Dickinson refers to the crow stories that Ben Ladysmith, a biology teacher at a small Middle Western college, was forever telling before he disappeared in a boating accident on Oblong Lake.

description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation, seeking to quell opposition to its bid to buy the Government-controlled Consolidated Rail Corporation, said today that it had offered to enter into agreements with several smaller, regional railroads guaranteeing them access to major traffic transfer points in the proposed merged railroad.

title: ART: IMPRESSIONIST SHOW AT THE I.B.M. GALLERY
description: A HARVARD graduate of 1906, Maurice Wertheim died in 1950, leaving his art collection to the university's Fogg Art Museum. It's been a fixture there ever since, but even fixtures are subject to modification, and because its permanent gallery is being refurbished, the collection has taken a sabbatical. Accordingly, more than half the 43 works that Wertheim collected over 14 years - mostly Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings - can now be seen at I.B.M.'s Gallery of Science and Art on Madison Avenue at 56th Street.

title: Lotus-Dataspeed
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, as expected, said that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Dataspeed Inc., a maker of portable, radio-operated stock market quotation devices. The price, Lotus said, was $6.5 million, and Dataspeed's creditors agreed to be repaid at 60 percent of the face value of the debt.

description: Nancy Reagan's First Ladies Conference on Drug Abuse moved to Atlanta today, where 16 first ladies heard drug experts warn against worldwide abuse of cocaine and marijuana.

24 Hurt in Evacuation Of Michigan Jetliner
description: Some of the 450 passengers awaiting takeoff on a chartered jetliner panicked today when they smelled smoke from a light fixture and were told to evacuate, according to those on the plane. More than 24 people suffered minor injuries in the evacuation.

title: ACETO CHEMICAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects a first quarter gain of $150,000, or 5 cents a share, resulting from a credit for deferred Federal income taxes under changes in the tax law as it related to the company's DISC.

MUSIC: GENERAL PUBLIC
description: GENERAL PUBLIC delivered a peculiar mixture of celebratory music and tense atmosphere Monday night at Radio City Music Hall.

title: 2d Allied Closing
description: The Allied Corporation said it would close its chrome chemicals plant in Baltimore, the second shutdown of a chemical plant that Allied has announced this week. On Tuesday, the company said that it would close a chemical plant in Syracuse by Jan. 1.

title: MAID RECALLS REPEATED EFFORTS TO ROUSE MARTHA VON BULOW
description: Her voice cracking and her lips trembling, Martha von Bulow's maid told jurors today how she cradled her comatose employer in her arms on the evening of Dec. 27, 1979, and waited for a doctor to arrive.

title: SAB HARMON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JAPAN ALLOTMENTS SET ON CARS FOR U.S.
description: Japan's Government told the nation's major auto makers today how many cars each may export to the United States under the new quotas announced last month.

VIEW-MASTER INTERNATIONAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Children and a Quilt
description: The organizers of the continuing demonstrations outside the South African Embassy are arranging for children to protest near the embassy today. The demonstrations are to protest South Africa's policies on race. There will be speeches and a news conference and the showing of an ''anti-apartheid quilt'' made by women in Washington.

title: CHEMICAL FABRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $314,000 related to the formation of OC Birdair Inc., a joint venture between Chemical Fabrics Corp. and Owens- Corning Fiberglas Co.

title: Times Mirror Net Up 2.1%
description: The Times Mirror Company posted net income for the first quarter of $44.2 million, or 64 cents a share, up 2.1 percent from $43.3 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier.

title:
PATENTS;

New Pen Helps To Verify Signature
description: As an aid in signature verification, a pen that indicates both pressure and acceleration has been originated for the International Business Machines Corporation in Armonk, N.Y. The inventors listed in patent 4,513,437, issued this week, are Timothy J. Chainer, Robert A. Scranton and Thomas K. Worthington, staff members.

title: Your Money;   Pension Credit After Age 65
description: A MOVE is under way by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to require companies to make pension plan contributions on behalf of employees who continue to work beyond age 65. If successful, this effort to force benefit accruals for service after the normal retirement age would be costly for many employers but would provide substantially higher monthly payments for many men and women who retire later.

title: Hundreds At Carolina Rites For Ex-Senator Sam J. Ervin
description: Some 350 friends, family members and dignitaries filled the First Presbyterian Church here today for funeral services for former United States Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., who chaired the committee whose inquiry led Richard M. Nixon to resign the Presidency.

title: Bridge;   Missed Opportunities Make For a Gloomy Post-Mortem
description: To discover in the post-mortem that a different line of play would have produced a top score is not uncommon. Nor is the realization that a different bid would have had the same happy result.

title: Tyner and Trio
description: The pianist McCoy Tyner and his trio will perform tonight at Mikell's, 760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832). Sets begin at 10 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: SPS TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Trade Talks In Tokyo End
description: High-level trade talks ended here today with American officials dissatisfied with progress in the electronics sector and asking for further concessions in telecommunications.

title: U.S. EXPELS A SOVIET AIDE OVER KILLING A MAJOR
description: The United States today ordered the expulsion of a Soviet military attache in retaliation for what it called ''the unacceptable Soviet position'' toward the killing of an American Army officer in East Germany last month.

title: VOLCKER BANKING COMPROMISE
description: In announcing his position on interstate banking earlier this week, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, achieved what had been considered by many to be nearly impossible - he came up with a compromise just about everyone could accept.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NO NEED TO FEAR A DOLLAR OUTFLOW
description: It is generally agreed that there is a positive side to today's strong dollar and enormous trade deficit. This is the inflow of foreign capital into the United States credit market - a foreign ''subsidy'' that is keeping interest rates lower than they would otherwise be. But what worries many people is whether this inflow can be sustained.

title: VON BULOW MAID DESCRIBES FINDING BAG OF DRUGS
description: Over the repeated objections of lawyers for Claus von Bulow, his wife's maid described today how she found ''a little black bag'' with vials of drugs in his study in the couple's New York apartment in February 1980.

title: PALESTINIAN AND MOSLEM MILITIAS CAPTURE, LOOT AND BURN LEBANESE CHRISTIAN TOWNS
description: Hundreds of Palestinian guerrillas and Moslem militiamen overran Christian villages in the hills east of the southern port of Sidon today. There were reports of widespread looting and burning of houses that had been abandoned by Christians.

title: EX-ENVOY AND JERSEY OFFICIAL
description: Katherine Elkus White, a former chairman of the New Jersey Highway Authority and Ambassador to Denmark during the Johnson Administration, died Wednesday at the Riverview Medical Center in Red Bank, N.J. She was 78 years old and lived in Red Bank.

title: Rudolf Hess Turns 91
description: Rudolf Hess, a former deputy of Adolf Hitler and the only survivor of the Third Reich hierarchy, marked his 91st birthday at Spandau prison today in the company of his wife, Ilse.

title: ELGIN NATIONAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: More Cubans Are Deported Under Agreement With Cuba
description: Forty-four Cubans were sent back to their homeland today in the fourth deportation flight under an agreement between the United States and Cuba.

title: CANADIAN OFFERED ENTRY TO U.S., BUT REFUSES
description: The United States Immigration Service said today that it would grant the Canadian author Farley Mowat a special visit to the United States, but Mr. Mowat refused the terms, saying he would ''not go under a shadow.''

title: Newspaper Stake for Sale
description: Sallie Bingham, a member of the family that owns The Louisville Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times, along with other properties, said yesterday that she expected to sell her 18 percent share in the family's holdings to an outside buyer soon.

title: GOLDSMITH MAY REBID FOR CROWN
description: Sir James Goldsmith yesterday canceled his offer for the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, a day after the forest products company announced that merger talks with the Mead Corporation had failed and that a major restructuring would take place instead.

WESTCHESTER MURDER SUSPECT DIES IN STRUGGLE WITH STATE POLICEMEN
description: The man accused of killing a Westchester County police officer and a Mount Vernon woman was shot and killed in a state police car on the Taconic State Parkway today.

title: All-Day Music Program
description: A free, daylong music program with the Levite Symphony Orchestra will be offered tomorrow at Franklin D. Roosevelt High School, 20th Avenue and 58th Street, in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

title: TREASURY YIELDS DECLINE A BIT
description: After three days of generally rising interest rates, yields for short- and long-term Treasury issues fell modestly yesterday.

title: Bogeys Inspire Casper
description: Billy Casper hit into two bunkers on the first hole today, and his partner, Gay Brewer, drove out of bounds off the first tee. That led to a bogey-start for the defending champions in the second round of the $500,000 Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf, a better-ball senior tournament.

title: New Cruise Ship
description: Norwegian Caribbean Lines said it plans to build a 2,500-passenger cruise ship that will be the largest luxury liner in the world. Then it will continue looking at plans to build one twice that size. The company's president, Ronald J. Zeller, estimated the first ship would cost between $150 million and $200 million and would have the capability for world-ranging cruises.

description: Results include gains on the sale of assets of $382,000 in the latest quarter and $684,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: TEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A.T.&T. Wins Backing
description: The foundation that stages the Bing Crosby National Pro-Am today welcomed an offer by Crosby's widow to reconsider her decision to cut the family's ties to the golf tournament. But the Monterey Peninsula Golf Foundation also said that it would stand by its ''solid commitment'' to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company regarding the company's sponsorship of the event.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 27, 1985 Companies Sir James Goldsmith canceled his offer for Crown Zellerbach. But many on Wall Street doubted that Sir James was giving up his effort to win control of the company. The withdrawal followed a day of turbulence for the forest products company in which a proposed takeover by the Mead Corporation fell through and Zellerbach then announced it would undertake a radical restructuring that would split the company into three parts. [Page 31.] Confusion abounds over what caused the collapse of the Mead offer for Zellerbach. [33.] Ford's earnings dropped 12.7 percent during the quarter. The company said the decline, to $783.3 million, was caused by higher taxes and increased product-development costs. [31.] Unocal must postpone its annual meeting for two weeks, a Federal judge ordered. The delay had been sought by T. Boone Pickens, who has been leading an effort to take over the company. [33.] Another bid was made for Multimedia. Jack Kent Cooke, the owner of the Washington Redskins, offered $63 a share, or $1.05 billion. Multimedia's chairman said its founding families had rejected the offer, which is the third recent one by an outsider. [32.] U.P.I.'s board authorized a bankruptcy filing. The news agency did not say when it might file for protection from creditors but did say service would not be interrupted. [7.] A 3 percent increase in private-line long-distance rates charged by A.T.&T. was approved by the F.C.C. The increase would cost customers, mostly businesses, about $1 billion annually.

title: Bomb Damages Office Of World Bank in Paris
description: A powerful car bomb exploded early today outside the Paris offices of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, causing extensive damage but no injuries, the police said.

description: Jack Kent Cooke, the entrepreneur and owner of the Washington Redskins football team, yesterday offered to acquire Multimedia Inc., the communications company, for $63 a share in cash, or $1.05 billion.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 29. 1. This girl is performing an annual rite of spring in Japan. What is it? 2. In a confidential Army survey of its officer corps, (very few/half/almost all) of the respondents agreed with the statement, ''The bold, original, creative officer cannot survive in today's Army.'' 3. For Jose Holguin, the burial of Herman Knott at the National Cemetery in Farmingdale, L.I., ended a 42-year quest. Explain. 4. Vladimir Horowitz plans to give a recital at Carnegie Hall. But he will be sitting in the audience while he does. Explain. 5. Although he had never served as President of Brazil, Tancredo Neves was buried wearing the Presidential sash. What were the circumstances? 6. A 99-year-old formula has been revised, and a 135-year-old trademark will be removed. What companies announced these changes? 7. The nation's oldest public school, established on April 23, 1635, or MDCXXXV as they put it, celebrated its 350th anniversary. What school is it? 8. A champion who recently spoke of retirement will risk his title again. Who is he and explain? 9. The White House tried to prevent Republican members of the House of Representatives from signing a letter, sent by 257 Congressmen, asking Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany to withdraw his invitation to President Reagan to visit the military cemetery at Bitburg. True or false? 10. The Federal authorities made arrests and seized weapons at the Ozark headquarters of a group called the Covenant, the Sword and the Arm of the Lord.

title: One-Hitter For Hershiser
description: Orel Hershiser fired a one-hitter, and Pedro Guerrero ripped a two-run double in the third to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 2-0 victory tonight over the San Diego Padres.

title: 3 DESIGNERS WITH LUXURIOUS IDEAS FOR FALL
description: The fall fashion openings moved into high gear yesterday as Geoffrey Beene drew almost every New York store president to his show at the Hotel Pierre in the morning, along with some 600 buyers and press representatives. Louis Dell'Olio proved he was a master of the sportswear idiom at the Anne Klein presentation in the afternoon. In between, Carolina Herrera solidified her position as one of the women, like Jacqueline de Ribes, who used to be content with wearing stylish clothes and now designs them.

title: MICKEY MOUSE MUGGED IN WALL STREET
description: If you were around in the 1930's you recall that ''Made in Japan'' was another way of saying ''junk.'' When you bought something that fell apart on the way home from the store, somebody always said, ''Must have been made in Japan.'' 202.4,0,266.8,2 ,266.8,0,156.4,2,266.8,0>Nobody says that anymore. Nowadays you buy something that falls apart on the way home and Americans look at you with the contempt paupers deserve in a fat society and think, ''The poor bum is so broke he can't afford anything but American goods.''

description: What is constantly saddening about scandals in police departments is that they always seem to confirm that the rest of the community doesn't know its police very well and doesn't really want to know them.

title: THE ARMENIAN DEAD
description: This week marks the 70th anniversary of the 20th century's first act of genocide: the massacre of 1.5 million Armenians by Ottoman Turkey. Even today, Turkey has never admitted its guilt. Why must the United States connive at that ugly denial?

title: ACROSS THE RURAL SOUTH, SEGREGATION AS USUAL
description: When a well-dressed black visitor to the Terrell County Courthouse here recently asked a white secretary in the probate judge's office for directions to the ladies' room, she was told, ''Just go downstairs.''

title: TV: LESSONS OF VIETNAM ARE EXPLORED BY NBC
description: If you see only one television news program about Vietnam, make sure this is it: ''Vietnam: Lessons of a Lost War,'' an NBC ''White Paper,'' on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tonight. In fact, if you see only one television news program, make sure this is it. The ''White Paper'' is a model. This is Vietnam without tears, but with sorrow; Vietnam without bitterness, but with blame. Reporting replaces conjecture. Analysis depends on facts. At the moment, television correspondents are all over Vietnam, memorializing, commemorating, pondering, explaining: Saigon fell 10 years ago next week. ''Vietnam: Lessons of a Lost War'' doesn't leave home. It doesn't have to.

CUOMO IS EXPECTED TO NAME NEW LEADERS FOR 3 AGENCIES
description: Governor Cuomo is planning changes in the top state officials who oversee transportation, housing and economic development, members of the Cuomo administration said today.

title: Another Borbon On the Way Up
description: Pedro Borbon Jr., son of the former Cincinnati right-hander, was a frequent visitor to the Reds' locker room as a tot. What he saw must have pleased him, because now, as a senior at DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, he has hopes of being in a big-league clubhouse on his own merits one of these days. And as his performances during the last week or so have made abundantly clear, his chances of getting there are pretty fair.

title: S.M.U. Officials Testify
description: A National Collegiate Athletic Association committee investigating possible football recruiting violations at Southern Methodist University, heard testimony yesterday from the school's president, L. Donald Shields; the athletic director, Bob Hitch, and the football coach, Bobby Collins.

description: Hundreds of marines and forest rangers battled along a 20-mile fire line today to hold back towering flames that threatened dozens of homes on North Carolina's tinder-dry coast.

description: The successful Universal movie ''Mask,'' which tells the story of a young man whose face is deformed by a bone disease, has presented a complex publicity problem for the studio: how to advertise the film without frightening audiences away.

Someone, perhaps Alice Roosevelt Longworth, perhaps Tallulah Bankhead or Ethel Barrymore, once labeled him ''the little man on the wedding cake,'' and the characterization stuck.

title: Change at Clemson
description: James C. Brummitt resigned as Clemson's chief law-enforcement official yesterday, saying the publicity surrounding the school's drug scandal had been ''kind of getting to me.'' Mr. Brummitt, who will remain as a university investigator, had been questioned recently about why there had been a monthlong delay before the school's president, Bill Atchley, was informed that some Clemson coaches had admitted dispensing prescription drugs to athletes.
