PLAYERS
description: Just a few feet away, under the scoreboard clock at the west end of Franklin Field, entrepreneurs in warm-up suits were selling the Official Penn Relay T-shirts at a rapid pace. Competitors raced past on the other side of a chest-high chain-link fence. On the outside of that fence, runners warmed up, warmed down, listened to music, stretched, concentrated, laughed, made new friends, took in the sun, and enjoyed being part of the 91st Relay Carnival. And Mary Ellen McGowan wept. She will represent Villanova in the Penn Relays one last time this afternoon as the leadoff leg of the 3,200-meter relay. She will step onto the track on what could be the most glorious of Penn Relays days, with temperatures in the 70's helping to attract as many as 40,000 fans who will provide track and field with one of its greatest stages. She will take the baton already having experienced the giddiest high and the emptiest low the Penn Relays can offer.

title: Brunner Moves On
description: When Scott Brunner became a former Giant before the 1984 season and moved on to Denver, he could look back on a career at quarterback in New York that included the cheers of the 1981 playoff season and the boos of the 3-12-1 season in 1983. Yesterday, when he became a former Bronco and moved onto Green Bay as a backup for Lynn Dickey, he could look back on a blank. Brunner, who started 30 games for the Giants before he was sent to Denver for a fourth-round draft choice, suffered a knee infection and didn't play a game last season. The Packers gave up an undisclosed future draft choice to get him.

title: Concert by Frisell
description: The electric guitarist Bill Frisell will play a solo concert tonight at 8:30 at the New York Open Center, 83 Spring Street, east of Broadway (219-2527). Tickets are $6.

title: THE SCREEN: 'JUST ONE OF THE GUYS'
description: ''I mean, I write an excellent article and just because I'm cute no one takes me seriously. It's not fair!'' In ''Just One of the Guys,'' which opened yesterday at the New Yorker and other theaters, a high school student named Terry (Joyce Hyser), the author of the above complaint, finds her own way of getting even with the teachers who have ignored her talent. She dresses up as a boy - a cross between Elvis Costello and the Karate Kid, according to one classmate - and attends a neighboring school. Her experiences turn out to have the makings of a prize-winning article, and perhaps a sitcom, too.

title: Goalie Suspended
description: Greg Stefan, the goalie, went down swinging when the Detroit Red Wings were eliminated from the playoffs by the Chicago Black Hawks two weeks ago. Yesterday, after a hearing in Toronto, the National Hockey League suspended Stefan for the first eight games of next season for having repeatedly struck Al Secord, a forward, with his stick. The incident, which had drawn Stefan a match penalty and automatic suspension from the game, occurred near the end of the Red Wings' 8-2 playoff loss April 13 that gave Chicago a three-game sweep.

title: MCI Rate Rise

The company said the higher rates are scheduled to go into effect Saturday. MCI said its rates were based on duration and time of day as well as distance.

title: Anheuser Suit
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, as expected, filed a lawsuit yesterday in Federal District Court in Dallas seeking more than $250 million from Paul Thayer, a former director of the brewery, as well as several brokers and brokerage firms. The suit was filed in connection with earlier allegations that Mr. Thayer had used inside information concerning a Busch merger in 1982 to benefit several friends. The suit also names A.G. Edwards & Sons of St. Louis; Bear, Stearns & Company, and several friends of Mr. Thayer, who was also a former Deputy Secretary of Defense.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE GENERAL Ulysses S. Grant, who led the Union armies to victory in the Civil War, and Julia Dent Grant, his wife, are entombed above the Hudson shore in a solemnly domed granite structure on Riverside Drive at 123d Street. After Grant's Tomb was completed in 1897, it became a top tourist attraction. A delightful, long ride on a double-decker bus wafts visitors to the monument along the scenic river bank.

description: The Champion International Corporation expects to reduce by about $600 million this year the $1.9 billion debt it incurred from the acquisition of the St. Regis Corporation last year, its president, Robert F. Longbine, said. Mr. Longbine said that Champion has worked off ''more than $200 million'' debt with the sale of three manufacturing operations, by taking an $85 million gain last week from an overfunded St. Regis pension fund and from a previously disclosed sale of its flexible packaging business.

title: USP REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,101,987 from the sale of property.

title: CHIEF AUTOMOTIVE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-There were no share earnings for the year-ago periods because at the time the company was privately held.

title: The Trials of Argentina
description: Something remarkable is going on in Argentina. A democratic Government is prosecuting the dictatorship it replaced for crimes committed against the human rights of their people.

title: Heights or Depths At the New Hofstra?
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times;   Mike on the Ginza
description: TOKYO WOES. By Bruce Jay Friedman. 187 pages. Donald I. Fine Inc. $14.95. Mike Halsey, the hero of Bruce Jay Friedman's new novel, isn't exactly a lonely guy - he's got a nice gal, Pam, and a nice life in the country - and he doesn't have the kind of mother problems or wife problems that fellows like Harry Towns (''About Harry Towns''), Harold Wonder (''Scuba Duba'') and Joseph (''A Mother's Kisses'') had to deal with. For the most part, Mike's all right and, being a sort of cautious fella, he keeps pretty much to the middle of the road. Still, there are these weird swerves every now and then. Like the time he quit his management job (after 16 years, no less) and got into restoring old houses. Or the time his feet got itchy, and he wound up bumming around Finland. One can never tell when one of these Walter Mitty episodes will strike next, and sure enough, Mike sets out one day to buy the morning papers, and finds himself on a plane to Tokyo.

title: COLUMBIA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'The Stakes Are Momentous'
description: President Reagan's apocalyptic television warning about the Federal budget deficit is a welcome sign that he's finally recognized its importance. If only he were as willing to face up to the necessary remedies.

title: FIRST COLUMBIA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Swedish Leader Denies Report on A-Bomb Test
description: Prime Minister Olof Palme has denied a report that Sweden carried out nuclear-weapons research as late as 1972 despite a 1957 ban by Parliament.

title: Ambassador to Iraq Named
description: David G. Newton, a Foreign Service officer, has been nominated as the first United States Ambassador to Iraq since diplomatic relations between the two countries resumed, the White House announced today. Mr. Newton, 50 years old, a native of Boston, has been the charge d'affaires at the American Embassy in Baghdad for the last five months.

title: CITY RETAILERS LAG IN NATION
description: New York's big retailers are reaching out to customers with sprightly springtime promotions. Lately, however, consumers just have not been buying.

title: Wiggins Is Missing
description: The San Diego Padres were looking for Alan Wiggins yesterday after the second baseman failed to appear for a game against the Dodgers in Los Angeles Thursday night and was still among the missing as the Padres reported for last night's game. ''We've checked with the police department, we've checked with the hospitals, we've tried to call his home,'' said the Padre manager, Dick Williams. ''We know his clothes are in his hotel room, that's all we know.''

title: WESTERN CAPITAL INVESTMENT CORP.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 27, 1985

title: TRIAD SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Commodore Has a $20.8 Million Loss
description: Commodore International Ltd., which less than a year ago looked like one of the few survivors in the home computer market, said yesterday that it lost $20.8 million in its third quarter and would post a loss for its fiscal year ending in June.

title: VENDO CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRINCE PAOLO BORGHESE
description: Prince Paolo Borghese, prominent socially in Europe and North America, died Wednesday of a stroke in Montecatini, Italy.

title: WARNACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results include operations of Olga Co., which Warnaco acquired June 4, 1984.

title: Judge, Backing Pickens, Postpones Unocal's Annual Meeting to May 13
description: A Federal judge today ordered the Unocal Corporation to postpone its annual meeting, scheduled for Monday, by two weeks, to May 13.

title: RECITAL: ELIOT FISK, GUITARIST
description: Two dominating characteristics ran through Eliot Fisk's guitar recital at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday evening. One was his technique, which was rock-solid in the most testing trials of endurance; the other was his willingness to bend meter and tempo in the service of melodic line.

title: ATLANTIC FINANCIAL FEDERAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,680,000, 88 cents a share, from the distribution of preferred stock of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Co.

title: AYDIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
5 WEAPONS FOUND AT FUGITIVES' HOME
description: Five weapons, including two with the serial numbers filed off, were found by the F.B.I. in a search today of the rented home of Thomas and Carol Manning, two suspected terrorists and fugitives arrested here Wednesday.

title: REALIST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DIANNE BRILL REIGNS OVER A WORLD OF PARTIES
description: Some people have all the fun.

title: TRANS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $202,939 from discontinued operations. c-Net income.

title: KOCH DECLARES AN EMERGENCY ON WATER USE
description: Mayor Koch declared a drought emergency in New York City yesterday and imposed mandatory restrictions on water use by all residents and businesses.

title: Penn State Ties U.S. in Soccer
description: Amr Aly, the 1984 Hermann Stophy winner from Columbia University, looped in a high-arcing shot from the right side with 8 minutes 12 seconds left in the first half to give the United States national soccer team a 1-1 draw with Penn State in an exhibition soccer match tonight.

title: PROGRESSIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a securities gain of $772,000 and a tax credit of $557,000. c-Includes a securities gain of $891,000 and a tax credit of $1,123,000.

title: 78 Are Killed in Fire In Argentine Hospital
description: At least 78 people were killed and 150 were injured tonight in a fire at a six-story mental hospital, the city health director said.

title: ATLANTIC CITY ELECTRONICS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CADMUS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ATCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,364,000.

title: SCIENTIFIC SOFTWARE INTEROM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Chicago Board Options
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it expected to begin trading options on 12 over-the-counter stocks within 30 to 60 days. Options will be listed on American Greetings, Apollo Computer, Apple Computer, DSC Communications, Genentech, Intel, Intergraph, Liz Claiborne, Lotus Development, LSI Logic and Tandem Computer. Options trading in MCI Communications will begin upon approval of a modification of the Chicago Board Options Exchange's options listing standards, the exchange said.

title: ARTHRITIS: WARNING ON 'CURES'
description: NEARLY 36 million Americans suffer from arthritis. Though there is no known cure for the disease, there are countless people who claim they have the cure. Congressional studies estimate that Americans spent nearly $2 million on quack remedies in 1984.

title: Gypsy Moth Chemicals Banned by U.S. Judge
description: Federal District Judge James A. Redden today banned the use of synthetic chemical insecticides to spray for gypsy moths, stopping their use in Oregon immediately and nationwide in January.

title: Loss Bigger At Wheeling
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation today reported a net loss of $25.8 million in the first quarter, compared with a $4.9 million loss in the period last year.

title: SWENSEN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pictures at a Reception
description: The Phillips Collection, the oldest modern art museum in the country, is becoming one of most fashionable places in the capital to rent out for a reception. The museum is an old but recently renovated mansion whose walls are hung with the masterpieces of Bonnard, Cezanne, Degas, Renoir and Rouault, among others.

title: SCREEN: 'THE NEW KIDS'
description: ''THE NEW KIDS,'' which opened Friday at the Embassy 2 and other theaters, is a teen-age revenge melodrama that is both sadistic and wimpish. It's about a couple of decent kids - a brother and sister, orphans newly arrived in a small Florida town - who are terrorized by the high-school bullies.

title: ZOO CELEBRATES ITS 37th YEAR
description: FRANK TERRY, owner of the Terry Lou Zoo in this Union County community, will tell you that he and his wife, Louise, are ''like father and mother to the animals.''

title: MARY B. COE HAS NUPTIALS
description: The marriage of Mary Beall Coe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neile H. Coe of Greenwich, Conn., to David W. Mooney Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mooney of Purchase, N.Y., took place yesterday. Col. John J. Cunniffe, who retired as vice chancellor of personnel of the Army's Military Vicariate, performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: PEACE OF MIND
description: THIS MORNING, ABOUT AN HOUR AGO, my young son discovered what it's like to drink the icy mist of a cold mountain stream. Dylan enjoyed it. His eyes opened wide and bright, as they do when he makes a discovery, and his mouth broke into a broad, if cockeyed, smile.

title: A QUESTION OF HAPPINESS
description: In his article, David Dworkin reflects on his seemingly fruitless search for happiness.

title: Best Sellers;   April 28, 1985

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A PIECE OF EARTH. By Kenny Marotta. (Morrow, $14.95.) The politics of intrafamily hatefulness are, in part, Kenny Marotta's subject matter in this first novel set among Italian-Americans in a large city in the Northeast around the time of the Depression.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch last Sunday from Jubail, Saudi Arabia, about a water desalting program misidentified the president of the country's Saline Water Conservation Corporation. He is Prince Mohammed Faisal.

title: Rent-Controlled Units
description: Question: Can you tell me how many rent-controlled apartments there were when vacancy decontrol was passed and how many there are now? . . . A. B., Manhattan Answer: Vacancy decontrol for rent-controlled apartments was passed in 1971, when there were about 1.2 million rent-controlled apartments. In 1974, the Emergency Tenant Protection Act placed decontrolled apartments in buildings with six or more units under rent stabilization after rents were allowed to go to comparable market levels. The New York City Housing Vacancy Survey by the United States Bureau of the Census says there are now about 219,000 rent-controlled apartments. Old Sublease in New Co-op Question: The apartment in which I was living was converted to a co-op on a noneviction plan. But just before I bought the apartment, I arranged to sublet it for three years. Now the board is requesting only one-year leases, Does my subtenant abide by the existing sublease, or does he have to enter into a new one-year lease? . . . A. C., Manhattan Answer: If the prior landlord gave permission for the sublet, then the sublease ordinarily should be valid and binding until it expires, said David Clurman, a lawyer who specializes in co-op conversions. He noted that there have been situations in which sponsors have granted permissions after a closing and before the new board was elected when the board challenged the sublet. See a lawyer. Electricity Surcharge Question: The landlord of my rent-stabilized apartment has added a surcharge of $19.11 a month to rents since June 1984.

title: Norman Wins $51,200 In Skins Golf Challenge
description: Greg Norman survived persistent rain and some tricky pin placements to be the leading money winner on the first day of play of the $288,000 Australian Skins golf challenge today.

title: HANG-UPS
description: CHARACTERS

title: RESIDENTS SEEK TO PROTECT FAIRFIELD SHORE
description: REACTING to predictions from ecologists of continued erosion along the shoreline in Fairfield, residents are calling for action from town officials to prevent further damage.

title: ARUBA'S FUTURE, ONCE BRIGHT, NOW A MUDDLE
description: This was supposed to be a happy time for this little island of 60,000 people just north of Colombia and Venezuela.

title: 'Facing Nature'
description: GOOD novelists who also write good poetry are very rare. In this century there have been Vladimir Nabokov and Kingsley Amis, Tom Disch, James Dickey and mavericks like Charles Williams - though you could more properly put Mr. Dickey into the category of poets who write novels, along with Louis MacNeice (one pseudonymous novel), C. Day Lewis (detective stories), John Masefield (books for children), Roy Fuller and John Fuller. Among the Victorians, we remember Emily Bronte, Thackeray and Meredith. Dickens interpolated ''The Ivy Green'' into ''The Pickwick Papers,'' along with Mrs. Leo Hunter's famous ''Ode to an Expiring Frog'' and the anonymous ''Lines to a Brass Pot.'' In fact, Victorian novelists had a tendency toward parody and light verse - very noticeable in Thackeray (''Little Billee'' and ''Sorrows of Werther'').

title: WRIGHT, WHITWORTH LIVE UP TO LEGENDS
description: Mickey Wright and Kathy Whitworth, the first women to play against men from the same tees in a sanctioned professional tour event, have little or no chance to win the eighth annual Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf. But they did not really expect to win in this senior men's team event at the Onion Creek Club, although some may have dreamed a little of the women presenting a challenge to the top teams.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;

PRESSING WALNUT OIL IN THE DORDOGNE
description: Starting in the fall, everyone in the Dordogne in southwest France seems to be engaged in an off-season Easter egg hunt. People are seen all over the countryside and along the roadways, tagged by children and family dogs, doubled over and scrutinizing the ground with eagle-eyed concentration. What they are seeking, however, are not eggs but walnuts. The Dordogne is walnut country, where production of the nut is a study in waste-not. Walnuts figure in nearly every aspect of a menu, from bread and salad dressing to ice cream, walnut cake and liqueurs. (Fresh walnuts macerated in the French brandy called eau de vie also make a mellow aperitif - liqueur de noix - when served over ice.) One of the best byproducts of the region's walnuts is oil (huile de noix). An appreciation for it is heightened by a visit to the mill at Ste.-Nathalene, which is about five miles northeast of Sarlat, just off Route D47. The mill, powered by water and employing wood-burning fires for heat, has not changed its method of production, and has been in constant operation, since the early 16th century. How this ancient method, compared with a modern mechanization, affects the final product may be a matter of debate, but the Ste.-Nathalene oil is unquestionably a highly refined version. Whereas some local walnut oils can be so harsh and assertive in flavor that they need some olive or peanut oil to cut the intensity, Ste.

title: Pennsylvania Led U.S. in '83 In Use of Prescription Drugs
description: Pennsylvanians used more prescription stimulants and depressants per capita in 1983 than residents of any other state, the state Health Department said this week.

title: FORGETTABLE SEASON ASSESSED BY NETS
description: It will become known as one of the most forgettable seasons in Nets' history. Incessant injuries, turmoil between players and coaches, and an ignominious three-game sweep by the Detroit Pistons in the first-round of the playoffs labeled this as a year of humility.

title: CROSROADS FARCE FALLS WIDE OF THE MARK
description: THE Crossroads Theatre is closing a winning season with a loser, the ''world premiere'' of a play that does not seem destined to go anywhere, except the route of nonprime-time television.

title: Sudan Moves Closer to Libya
description: Sudan's new military rulers sought help last week from its former enemies, Libya and Ethiopia. The Sudanese announced that they were restoring relations with Libya and that its leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, had promised to help end the rebellion in southern Sudan.

title: SAFETY VIOLATIONS GROUND AN AIRLINE
description: Susquehanna Airlines, an upstate commuter carrier, has been grounded for safety violations, the Federal Aviation Administration has announced. If the order is not overturned on appeal, the grounding will be permanent.

title: SECURITY INCREASED AT STONY BROOK
description: THE State University of New York at Stony Brook is heavily increasing security to help stem large-scale thefts and provide a greater feeling of personal safety on campus.

title: NEW CASSETTES: CLASSICS ABOUND
description: ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' stands at or near the top of the Tennessee Williams canon - which is to say that it also stands at the summit of the American theater. The 1951 film version is just as special: Unlike most Hollywood adaptations of major plays, it upholds the power of the original work.

title: YALE AND UCONN LEAD SHIFTS IN TOP POSTS
description: THE announcement last week by A. Bartlett Giamatti that he was resigning as president of Yale leaves both the state's largest public and private universities looking for new leaders.

title: DEFENSIVE USE OF STUN GUNS INCREASES
description: Charges made last week that several officers of a police precinct in Queens had used electric stun guns to torture suspects have shaken the New York City Police Department. But in New York and other cities across the country, the battery-powered devices that shoot volts instead of bullets are gaining popularity among law-enforcement officials and civilians who consider them a benign and effective method of self-defense.

title: NEW LIFE FOR A HANDEL OPERA
description: In 1968 Stephen Simon experienced what he calls the kind of ''fortunate happenstance that runs one's career along a certain track.'' One fine day 17 years ago he was visiting a New York office having to do with the music business when a man came in and said he was looking for someone to conduct a recording of ''Solomon,'' a Handel oratorio. Mr. Simon, then barely past 30, announced his availability and ended up with the job. Handel has been very much on his mind ever since.

title: WANDA DOUGLAS IS BRIDE IN CAPITAL
description: Wanda Camille Douglas, an associate at the New York law firm of Townley & Updike, and Phillip Thigpen Jr., an associate at Salomon Brothers, were married yesterday at the Peoples Congregational Church in Washington. The Rev. A. Knighton Stanley performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IN LOVE & WAR: The Story of a Family's Ordeal and Sacrifice During the Vietnam Years. By Jim and Sybil Stockdale. (Harper & Row, $18.95.)

title: JERSEY TO PLANT TREES TO BEAUTIFY TURNPIKE
description: Governor Kean has announced that the state will embark on a five-year project of planting three million trees along the New Jersey Turnpike as part of a plan to beautify the roadway.

title: TIGERS WIN AND REGAIN FIRST
description: Dan Petry of the Detroit Tigers doesn't mind playing the percentages when it involves Willie Hernandez. Petry went 8Y innings before giving way to Hernandez as the Tigers posted a 3-2 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers today to regain first place from Baltimore in the American League East.

title: CANCER RESEARCHER AT SLOAN-KETTERING
description: Dr. George B. Brown, a professor of biochemistry and a former vice president of the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research, died Monday at his home in Milwaukee of pulmonary and heart diseases. He was 71 years old.

title: BEACHES LOOK FOR A BANNER SEASON
description: The first tour bus, as sure a sign of the season on Martha's Vineyard as the buds on the willow trees, was sighted April 9, earlier than anyone here could remember. Its appearance prompted Edgartown's Chief of Police, George Searle, to note to the Selectmen of this old whaling town that it would soon be time, once again, to change the traffic pattern to accommodate the annual onslaught of summer people.

title: Data Bank;   April 28, 1985
Headliners;   Barred From the States
description: Was a Canadian nature writer who was once honored by the Boys Club a threat to American national security? The United States immigration officials who stopped Farley Mowat, author of the popular ''Never Say Wolf,'' from boarding a Los Angeles-bound plane in Toronto last week would say only that he was kept off under a law barring Communists, anarchists and subversives. True, Mr. Mowat said, he once joked about shooting down American B-52's with ''my trusty little .22.''

New edition of a standard work. 6 THE ONE MINUTE MANAGER, by Kenneth Blanchard and Spencer Johnson. (Berkley, $6.95.) How to increase your productivity. 7 THE BILL JAMES BASEBALL ABSTRACT 1985, by Bill James. (Ballantine, $7.95.) Statistics of the game and their analysis. 8 DIETS DON'T WORK, by Bob Schwartz. (Breakthru Publishing, $9.95.) A regimen for losing weight without dieting. $9 MORE SNIGLETS, by Rich Hall and Friends. (Collier/Macmillan, $5.95.) More words that should appear in dictionaries, but don't; with cartoons. 10 THE ARTHUR YOUNG TAX GUIDE 1985. (Ballantine, $6.95.) Instructions prepared by a leading accounting firm.

title: NATUE WATCH
description: CHINESE MANTIS Tenodera aridifolia Size: To three and three-quarters inches.

title: PETER T. FINCH IS WED TO KATHLEEN S. UPTON
description: Kathleen Sammie Upton and Peter Templin Finch were married yesterday at the Palo Alto (Calif.) Community Center by Judge Stanley Evans, who is retired from the Santa Clara County Superior Court.

title: NEW NERVE GAS WEAPONS URGED FOR MILITARY
description: A commission appointed by President Reagan last month to study the nation's chemical warfare policy has recommended that the Pentagon acquire new ''binary'' nerve gas weapons and destroy existing stockpiles of ''unitary'' weapons, a Congressional source said today.

title: BROOKLYN OWNER SEEKS WAIVER OF RENT LAW
description: THE OWNER of a 549-unit federally insured apartment complex in Brooklyn is seeking the removal of the property from rent stabilization, which could lead to rent increases of as much as 20 percent.

title: METROPOLITAN MATH
description: An appropriate place to absorb facts is on one of Cetral Park's 7,674 park benches, where the entire population of scarsdale, N.Y., could comfortably sit three to a bench while feeding the park's 6,900 squirrels. Or you might ride in one of the 68 horse-drawn carriages that roll through the park while gazing at some of the 2 million trees - 100 different types, from American elm to ginkgo - that cover the 26,168 acres of city parkland.

title: Jumpers
description: Wood warblers are singing as if these mean streets were the Adirondacks; several cormorants have paused in their northward migration to fish for eels off Greenwich Village, and other spring rites are in progress. Newton Grant, for example, a one-man band in a red vest and cowboy hat, is playing his trumpet, accordion, bass drum, cymbals and castanets simultaneously on weekends at the Battery. He is otherwise employed at Macy's.

title: IS EVERYBODY DEAD AROUND HERE?
description: BLOOD MERIDIAN Or The Evening Redness in the West. By Cormac McCarthy. 337 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: MISS KORYN TO MARRY ROBERT COHEN IN JUNE
description: The engagement of Nanette C. Koryn and Robert H. Cohen has been announced by her parents, Miriam Koryn of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Theodore Koryn of New York. Mr. Cohen's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Irving Cohen of New York. A June 9 wedding is planned.

title: FIRST ON FIELD AND AT THE GATE
description: EVERY game is a carnival.

title: 3d Avenue Chic
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: MASTERPIECES FROM LENINGRAD, JERUSALEM DAY
description: Hermitage Art To Be Shown In Rotterdam Catherine the Great and the czars of Imperial Russia are remembered in many ways, good and bad - and among the good is their taste in art.

title: MY OLD KENTUCKY HOME: MEMORIES OF 36 CLASSICS
description: EVERY YEAR, it's the same wretched predicament. I walk out of that ramshackle wreck known as Churchill Downs after 10 or 12 hours reporting or just plain living through the events of a Kentucky Derby, and as I trudge in the darkness through and over broken glass, mounds of paper and the occasional groaning body toward the parking lot, I say to myself - sometimes even out loud for the ghosts of derbies past to hear - I will never go through such a rat race again in my life. I swear it.

title: The Russians In Afghanistan
description: Though I generally agree with Richard Bernstein's article ''Remaking Afghanistan in the Soviet Image'' (March 24), I would like to emphasize a couple of points.

title: THE JOYS OF SPRING ARE NOT FOR EVERYONE: HAVING FUN CAN BE TOO MUCH HARD WORK
description: SPRING is here. I know because I have been dodging joggers on country roads and checking out next to matrons in tennis togs at the A. & P. I am just not ready for it. I could use a few more weeks of the kind of serenity that the dull, dark, do-nothing days of a New England winter can offer.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN LONDON
description: The endless days of spring and summer, when the light lingers long past 10 P.M., offer a perfect time to visit London. The strength of the dollar makes it easier to stay here although you may find yourself compelled to buy another suitcase before you can leave.

title: Koch Aide No Longer Assails Abrams' Pace
description: New York City's Finance Commissioner, who complained recently that State Attorney General Robert Abrams was taking too long to prosecute sales tax cases, said this week that he had no complaints with Mr. Abrams and never had.

title: JOKING AROUND
description: Coke Dates We remember how we used to belly up to the soda fountain after school - only we didn't have a belly then, or much of anything else, for that matter - and say ''Lemon coke, Bobby.'' Older people took it straight, jerks took it with cherry syrup or a splash of chocolate, but our crowd took it with lemon.

title: LEAD SERIES, 3-2
description: The Quebec Nordiques didn't have Michel Goulet tonight. But they did have some of the game's lesser offensive talents, like Brad Maxwell, Alain Lemieux and Brent Ashton. And they did have Dale Hunter, grinding, hacking, chopping and instigating as usual.

title: JOBS ARE FOCUS AS HISPANIC JOURNALISTS MEET
description: Like most of the several hundred journalists who gathered here for the National Hispanic Media Conference, Alfredo Corchado's mind was on finding a great job at a major newspaper or television network.

title: THE POWER SHORTAGE IS A MIRAGE
description: OVER the past two decades, the utility industry has consistently overestimated electricity demand, at a tremendous cost to the economy. Expectations that power use would continue doubling every 10 years, as it had in the 1950's and 1960's, led to an ordering binge for nuclear plants that turned into a flood of cancellations when annual growth fell to 2 percent in the late 1970's. These plants will cost utility ratepayers and investors up to $50 billion.

title: Talking Mortgages;   Offers Of Fast Approval
description: BUYERS in the market for mortgage financing are being beckoned with tantalizing offers of quick loan approvals. Instead of having to wait a month or more, they are told, they can get an oral or written commitment within days or even hours.

title: A Feminist Bible?
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN WILL PRESS TRADE PARTNERS TO HASTEN GROWTH
description: President Reagan will leave Tuesday for an economic summit conference in Bonn to press six other industrial democracies to adopt the policies that made the United States economy the world's fastest growing for the last two years.

title: RESCUED FROM HIS PROTECTORS
description: THE COMPLETE LETTERS OF SIGMUND FREUD TO WILHELM FLIESS, 1887-1904. Translated and edited by Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson. Illustrated. 505 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $25.

title: LOOKING FOR SEYMOUR GLASS
description: My life as I now live it would have been impossible had I not had, as a young girl, the imagination of the city as a place distinct from everything about my life. A place that shimmered with desirability but one that I could get to, simply by knowing it was where I really belonged and by talking my two best friends into jointly defying our parents and boarding the subway at 179th Street, Jamaica, on a Saturday morning.

title: BEWARE OF THE DECEPTIVE DRAW OFFER
description: Beware of old codgers offering peaceful draws. They are not always sincere.

title: EUROPEANS REACT TO BITTBURG FUROR
description: Western Europeans, including those from countries once occupied by Nazi Germany, watched the furor over President Reagan's planned trip to a German military cemetery for several days with little comment or protest of their own.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FACE. By Cecile Pineda. (Viking, $14.95.) Cecile Pineda's lucid first novel explores the darkness of human nature. Helio Cara's real-life nightmare begins with a fall from a cliff in Mexico that leaves him horribly disfigured.

title: AWARDS BY JURIES IN INJURY CASES
description: It may sometimes seem that there is little rhyme or reason to the damages awarded by juries in personal injury cases. Nor is it clear that there can be, given the difficulty of placing a dollar value on an arm or a leg.

title: A KINGDOM BY THE SEA
description: The Mediterranean port city of Hav is a quirky, cosmopolitan place, whose inhabitants range from White Russian emigres to Chinese racketeers. To a visitor, it presents a variety of natural and architectural wonders. It is also entirely imaginary - the creation of Jan Morris, who describes the city in her book ''Last Letters From Hav,'' to be published next month by Random House. Here are excerpts from that work.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: WIESEL IN WESTFIELD Elie Wiesel, who on April 19 accepted a medal from President Reagan at the White House - and then told the President that he should cancel his visit to a German military cemetery - will lecture Saturday and next Sunday at Temple Emanu-El in Westfield.

title: TAX SAVINGS FOR SMALL, NEW BUSINESSES
description: FOUR years ago, a New Jersey woman decided to open a store that would rent and sell video cassettes and video recorders in a small nearby shopping center. At the same time her husband, who owned a successful manufacturing company, was shopping around for a tax shelter. He found his solution close to home: Edward Mendlowitz, a partner with the accounting firm of Siegel, Mendlowitz & Rich, set up the wife's business so that her initial start-up losses sheltered part of her husband's income.

title: GORBACHEV HAS A TALK WITH JARUZELSKI BEFORE FLYING HOME
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, who has been here for a meeting of the Warsaw Pact treaty, conferred today with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader. After Mr. Gorbachev's departure for Moscow, a communique said:

title: MARK STARR OF GARMENT UNION
description: Mark Starr, the education director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union for 25 years and a longtime activist in political and civic affairs, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Boulevard Hospital in Sunnyside, Queens. He was 90 years old and lived in Long Island City.

title: NAVY CREW WINS ADAMS CUP
description: Navy confirmed its No. 1 ranking among Eastern crews this morning, winning the Adams Cup from second-ranked Harvard and sixth-ranked Pennsylvania. The margin was 1 second, or 15 feet, in a time of 5 minutes 54.4 seconds for the 2,000-meter course.

title: CATERING TO THE ARMCHAIR TRAVELER
description: Can Tulsa, Okla., become America's gateway to the world? It seems a formidable challenge, but the Satellite Program Network, a basic service whose headquarters are in that Middle Western city, is attempting to make its name as an outlet for programming that brings bits of the globe to viewers sitting snugly at home.

title: N.F.L. DRAFT: 1985
description: Teams are listed in first-round drafting order. Player named in bold face reflects possible first-round selection for all teams but the Seattle Seahawks and Washington Redskins, who have traded their first choices. Seattle has 12 picks over all and Washington has 11.

title: BEHIND THE BROWNSTONE DOOR
description: Edith Wharton in her memoirs speaks of the New York of her childhood, in the 1870's, as having been ''cursed with the universal chocolate-colored coating of the most hideous stone ever quarried.'' She compared its gridiron uniformity unfavorably with the noble parks and fountained squares that she had seen in contemporaneous Paris and Rome, whither her parents, in those happier days, used periodically to retreat in the interests of economy. But in my own childhood, half a century later, I had not the advantage of the European contrast, which may have been why I viewed my brownstone environment - and I had lived in three such houses - with different eyes.

title: Cable TV
description: For movie buffs, the oldest pearl of the cable week is Erich Pommer's ''The Beachcomber'' (1938). Yes, it's back - and hallelujah! This is not the rather prettified remake but the original British version of Somerset Maugham's ''The Vessel of Wrath,'' with Charles Laughton and Elsa Lanchester.

title: WEAKENING DOLLAR MAY AVERT RECESSION
description: AT times, Americans seem to have an almost genetic bias toward exaggerating the importance of short-run economic data. Early blips on our economic radar often prove to be mirages, but we still react to each blip as if it were reality. The problem is to distinguish between blips and incoming economic missiles.

title: Save Us From More Politicizing of Science
description: To the Editor:

title: HAPPY BIRTHDAY, WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE, AND KEEP THOSE PLAYS AND SONNETS COMING
description: IT is interesting to recall, as those who celebrated Shakespeare's 421st birthday last Tuesday probably did, that it was an American who originally launched the public attack against his authorship of the plays. Before her book appeared in 1857, no published writer of substance doubted Shakespeare had written Shakespeare's plays. Starting with Ben Jonson and down the years through Dryden, Pope, Samuel Johnson, Goethe, Lessing, Hazlitt, Coleridge and many others, no serious critic questioned that the man from Stratford was the greatest poet and playwright in the English language.

title: THE DYRE AVENUE SHUTTLE
description: The influence of Manhattan on the eastern portion of the Bronx that borders Long Island Sound and the East River has been negligible. WPA Guide to New York City, 1939 In the 40's my parents and I moved from Hillside Homes to a neighborhood in the Bronx that is now dominated by what was then known as the Einstein-Jacoby medical center. It was bordered by hundreds of acres of undeveloped land. What I remember most distinctly about that land, beyond a huge, flat-topped rock studded with a lifetime supply of mica chips, are the many hills that were covered by tiger lilies in the spring, poison sumac in the summer and perfect snow for sledding after any reasonable winter storm. Early on there were a few squatters farming land near those hills; later they disappeared. And early on I was content to stay in our beautiful new neighborhood, while later there wasn't enough there to hold me.

title: TAYLOR INVENTS EMOTIONAL COLORS IN 'LAST LOOK'
description: ''We don't know what all the colors are and every man invents new ones.'' These lines were written in 1908 by Guillaume Apollinaire, the French poet and art critic, in an essay on painting. Apollinaire, an early defender of Picasso and the modernist avant-garde, was speaking here of painters - of what he called their ''divinity'' in a creative mission, to find the new colors of whose existence we are unaware.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a technical failure, five lines of an article by Jan Morris are omitted from some copies of the Travel section today, in column 4 of page 41. The incomplete passage should read: ''The building is 11 stories high, deliberately built a story higher, so legend says, than any of the Arab structures of the city, and it is capped by a conical roof of green glazed tile, heavily eaved and surrounded by pendant bobbles. In 1927 Prof. Jean-Claude Bourdin of the Academie Francaise wrote a pamphlet about this building.''

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. With Bruce Berenyi on the 15-day disabled list, Roger McDowell of the Mets will make his first major league start. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. live and 8:15 P.M. tape. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. White Sox, at Chicago. (Television - Channel 11, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2:30 P.M.) College: Mississippi State at Alabama (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M. live). Basketball Bucks vs Philadelphia 76ers, at Milwaukee. This is the opener of the four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference semifinals. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Celtics vs. Detroit Pistons, at Boston. The other opening game in the Eastern semifinals. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Nuggets vs. San Antonio Spurs, at Denver. Fifth and final game of of Western Conference quarterfinal round. (Television - WTBS, 10:05 P.M.) Football Bulls vs. Birmingham Stallions, at Jacksonville, Fla. (Television - Channel 7, 2:30 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Flyers, at Philadelphia. Game Five of the Patrick Division championships, and for the fifth time this spring the Islanders are one defeat from elimination from the playoffs. (Television - Channel 9, 7 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 7 P.M.) Black Hawks vs. Minnesota North Stars, at Chicago.

title: DARYL KAY BEAN WEDS
description: Daryl Kay Bean, a daughter of J. Wayne Bean of Islamorada, Fla., and Mrs. John W. Anderson of New York, was married yesterday to William Jeffrey Stein, the son of Sanford Stein of Vero Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. Stein. The Rev. William McLeod performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church in Oviedo, Fla. The bride, who will retain her name, is a farrier. Mr. Stein is a lawyer for the Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company in Orlando, Fla.

title: NEW HEAD MAKING PLANS FOR HILL-STEAD
description: WHEN Katherine Warwick was 4 years old, she and her mother came to Washington from New York and went to the National Gallery of Art. ''The way the story goes,'' Miss Warwick recalls, ''is when I saw all that space, I threw up my hands and just started dancing around the rotunda.''

title: THE KIRKPATRICK FACTOR
description: SHE IS A PHENOMENON IN American politics: a woman who has never run for office, who failed to get the Government posts she really wanted, and who is now being seriously talked about as a possible contender for the Vice Presidential - maybe even Presidential - nomination in 1988.

title: Bengal Countersues
description: It was last December when a deputy sheriff in New Orleans went to the visiting team's locker room at the Superdome before a Saints game against the Bengals to serve legal papers on Glen Collins, a Cincinnati defensive end, in connection with a bank's suit to collect a $20,000 loan it said Collins had not repaid. The appearance of the deputy, Charles Kertz, 20 minutes before the game annoyed the Bengals' coach, Sam Wyche, who was later charged with resisting an officer by slamming the locker-room door on Kertz's hand, a charge Wyche denied.

title: Brooklyn Team Wins
description: Prospect Heights of Brooklyn prevented a sweep by Jamaican schools today in the three championship relays at Franklin Field with the help of three runners who had come from that Carribbean island.

title: ON LAND AND SEA
description: Barnard Benefit April 30 - Drop in for a drink at Sotheby's on York Avenue at 72d Street from 5:30 to 7:30 P.M. and meet the irrepressible Ruth Gordon, who hasn't stopped acting and writing since her Broadway debut in 1915, and her husband, Garson Kanin, the director and playwright. The benefit is for the Barnard College Scholarship Unit. Tickets, $75 ($40 for Barnard graduates of the last five years), at the door. Nautical Evening May 2 - Come aboard the 377-foot bark Peking, one of the largest sailing ships afloat. Sip cocktails, eat a buffet dinner, dance on deck and wander around the 74-year-old ship, built in Germany and seized as war reparations by the British following World War II. The party aboard the four-masted ship, permanently moored at the South Street Seaport, starts at 7 P.M., and guests are invited to wear nautical clothes. The evening will benefit Cancer Care, the social-service agency founded 40 years ago to help cancer patients and their families cope with the illness. Tickets, $125, from 212-221-3300. For the Disabled May 2 - In its 30 years, the World Rehabilitation Fund has assisted 150 countries with programs to help the disabled, training 5,000 medical people in care for the disabled and more than 1,000 specialists in making braces and artifical limbs. All told, 3 million patients have been assisted. Dr. Howard A. Rusk, founder and chairman of the fund, will be among those honored at a 30th anniversary black-tie celebration at the New York Hilton, starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. and followed by dinner and entertainment.

title: 'Blood Meridian,' by Cormac McCarthy
description: "BLOOD MERIDIAN'' comes at the reader like a slap in the face, an affront that asks us to endure a vision of the Old West full of charred human skulls, blood-soaked scalps, a tree hung with the bodies of dead infants. But while Cormac McCarthy's fifth novel is hard to get through, it is harder to ignore. Any page of his work reveals his originality, a passionate voice given equally to ugliness and lyricism. Over the past 20 years the brutality of his subjects may have kept readers away, but the power of his writing has earned high critical repute. Three early novels, in fact - ''The Orchard Keeper,'' ''Outer Dark'' and ''Child of God'' - have been reissued in the Ecco Press series, ''Neglected Works of the Twentieth Century.''

title: CREATE A WOODLAND FANTASY BY PLANTING A FERN GARDEN
description: Cool greens, soft fronds and dappled shade are a summer's oasis from the oppressive heat of a July afternoon. When flowers and vegetables flourish in the sunshine, I wither and withdraw to the fern garden. Even the mere sight of them collected among a jumble of stones offers visual relief from the heat.

title: STAGE: 'FOETUS,' A TRAVEL COMEDY
description: IN the late 1960's and early 70's, in such plays as ''Bigfoot'' and ''Queen of Greece,'' Ronald Tavel considerably lightened the New York theater scene. As co-creator (with John Vaccaro) of the Ridiculous style of playwriting and performance, he managed to combine a nose-thumbing disregard for convention with a literate wit.

title: 'Blood Meridian'
description: ''Blood Meridian'' comes at the reader like a slap in the face, an affront that asks us to endure a vision of the Old West full of charred human skulls, blood-soaked scalps, a tree hung with the bodies of dead infants. But while Cormac McCarthy's fifth novel is hard to get through, it is harder to ignore. Any page of his work reveals his originality, a passionate voice given equally to ugliness and lyricism. Over the past 20 years the brutality of his subjects may have kept readers away, but the power of his writing has earned high critical repute. Three early novels, in fact - ''The Orchard Keeper,'' ''Outer Dark'' and ''Child of God'' - have been reissued in the Ecco Press series, ''Neglected Works of the Twentieth Century.''

title: A LESS-THAN-SOLEMN MUSEUM
description: THE expression one sees on most faces in a museum is one of solemnity, sometimes grandiose glumness. Perhaps many people feel that the objects they see carry with them the burden of enlightenment or the gravity of understanding a cultural heritage, and that such an expression is appropriate.

title: PISCATAWAY IS LEARNING THERE'S LIFE AFTER TV
description: DESPITE his pledge of abstinence, Jay Kennedy sneaks out to the garage sometimes to catch the sports scores on a portable television set. But his two daughters, Corrie and Devin, check up on him, feeling the set to see if it is warm.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

CANADA WILL RELEASE COINS FOR WINTER OLYMPICS
description: Canada will issue 11 precious-metal coins to commemorate and help finance the 1988 Winter Olympic Games in Calgary. One is in gold and 10 are in silver. All are legal tender.

title: MARGARET ADAMS WED IN DELAWARE
description: Margaret Harding Adams, a lawyer, and Scott Linn Hunter, the luxury-car marketing plans manager for the Lincoln-Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company, both in Detroit, were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert MacLeod Smith performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Wilmington, Del.

title: RONALD DEERE
description: In the course of a speech to the Gridiron Club a month ago, President Reagan jokingly suggested that the country should ''keep the grain and export the farmers.'' The comment did not produce much laughter then or later. Now Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, reports seeing a tractor in his home state carrying a sign reading: ''Keep the missiles and launch Reagan.''

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: LOOK AT ME and PROVIDENCE, by Anita Brookner. (Obelisk/Dutton, $7.95 each.)

title: ANTI-SEMITISM LINKS VIOLENT GROUPS
description: The men of the Covenant, the Sword and the Arm of the Lord, mostly bearded, talk quietly, smile often and are friendly even to strangers. They are affectionate, hugging each other and dandling babies on their laps. There are lots of babies. Where an earlier generation might have exclaimed, ''Oh, wow,'' the Covenant people say ''Praise the Lord!'' and they say it often.

title: BUS FLEET SALE
description: AFTER a series of malfunctions in a new fleet of 851 buses the New York City Transit Authority threw in the towel in February 1984. It ordered all the buses, Flxible models, out of service as unsafe and sued the manufacturer, the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, L.I., for $324 million.

title: Vietnam in America
description: To the cry of ''No More Vietnams,'' the United States has tied itself into knots over Nicaragua. The President wants a virtual declaration of war against the Sandinistas - no more piecemeal humiliations by Soviet proxies. Congress, in a stunning demurral, says no more piecemeal investments of prestige in a war we're unwilling to send American boys to finish.

title: SHOULD SURGERY BE PAINLESS?
description: A CALCULUS OF SUFFERING Pain, Professionalism, and Anesthesia in Nineteenth-Century America. By Martin S. Pernick. Illustrated. 421 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $35.

title: SHOREHAM EVACUATION PLANNING CLOUDED
description: WHEN the Long Island Lighting Company's emergency planning troubles began, it had one enemy: the Suffolk County Legislature.

title: AN OUTDOORSMAN'S SHANGRI-LA: 900 SECLUDED ACRES TEEMING WITH QUAIL, TROUT AND DEER
description: Jack Oberwager died a while back nd now his dream is up for sale.

title: A JULY 4 WEDDING FOR RACHEL WEBB
description: Drs. Kempton and Nancy Webb of Ridgewood, N.J., and Vergennes, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rachel Drake Webb, to William Joseph Scott Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Scott of Framingham, Mass.

title: TURNING HEADS
description: There was no perceptible change in the din at Ernie's when Quiet Riot, the heavy metal band, walked in. They were noticed, the five men and their date, and heads turned. But at Ernie's, filled every night with the dazzling and the dazzled, attention is fleeting, and no one holds the interest of the crowd longer than it takes to sip a drink, not even the band whose album ''Metal Health'' rose to No. 1 on the charts with ''Cum On Feel the Noize.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PEGASUS BRIDGE: June 6, 1944. By Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $14.95.) To many Americans, the story of the seizure of the bridges across the Orne River in Normandy by British glider-borne troops on June 6, 1944 is almost unknown.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ANNA BANANA AND ME By Lenore Blegvad. Illustrated by Erik Blegvad. Unpaged. New York: A Margaret K. McElderry Book/Atheneum. $9.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: CUOMO'S MEDICAL-MALPRACTICE PLAN CRITICIZED
description: The State Bar Association has criticized a plan by Governor Cuomo for reducing medical-malpractice insurance rates, saying his proposals favored ''careless medical practitioners.''

title: HINTS OF PAST GRANDEUR ALONG THE APPIAN WAY
description: Let's say you plan to drive from Rome to Naples. If you manage to find the right exit on the Grande Raccordo Anulare, the belt road that girds the Italian capital, you get on Motorway A-2, a 130-mile section of the north-south Autostrada del Sole (Motorway of the Sun), and in two hours or so reach the scruffy suburbs of Naples, rather distant from its magnificent bay. The highway has practically no speed limits, tolls cost at least $5, and you won't have seen much besides humdrum concessions, service areas and an amazing number of trailer trucks.

title: Dance Film Series At Donnell Library
description: Twenty-seven films will be shown at the Dance Camera Film Festival, starting today at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street, sponsored by the Dance Films Association. The festival opens at 1:30 P.M. with a panel discussion on practical issues involved in filming and taping dance, to be followed by screenings. Additional films will be shown tomorrow at 5:30 P.M., Wednesday at 4 P.M., and next Saturday at 1:30 P.M. Daily video tape screenings will take place Monday through May 4 at the library's lower level.

title: SOUTH KOREA EASES UP ON ITS GAG RULE
description: The police checkpoints that had encircled Kim Dae Jung's house only a few weeks ago are gone. Street advertisements for a magazine carry his picture along with that of another leading dissident politician, Kim Young Sam.

title: DR. BARBARA D. BARTLIK WEDS DAVID S. CARROLL
description: Dr. Barbara Dawn Bartlik, a resident in psychiatry at the New York University Medical Center, and David Scott Carroll, a lawyer with American Express in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. William D. Roberts performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: THE MIDDLE IS SHIFING IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, looking healthier than he has in months, has recently been tightening the ranks of his party to meet the challenge of an opposition that has overcome its divisions and agreed to a single - though not yet selected - candidate to oppose him in the next election. The election is scheduled for 1987 but many expect it will come earlier.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE ADVENTURE OF THE ECTOPLASMIC MAN. By Daniel Stashower. (Morrow, $12.95.) In 1893 Arthur Conan Doyle got rid of Sherlock Holmes in a plunge down the Reichenbach Falls, but later revived him and explained how he had survived.

title: CONNECTICUT REPUBLICANS AGREE ON A BUDGET PLAN
description: The Republican majorities in both houses of the General Assembly agreed this week on a fiscal plan that would provide more tax cuts and less spending than had been sought by Gov. William A. O'Neill. Both houses were scheduled to begin voting on the fiscal measures next week, with legislative leaders forecasting approval.

title: THE BONES AT THE END OF THE ROAD
description: PICTURES FROM A TRIP By Tim Rumsey. 320 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent Passbook Savings * 5.50 At savings institutions Tax-Exempt Bonds * 9.39 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index Money Market Funds * 8.24 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield Bank Money Market Accounts * 7.86 Bank Rate Monitor Home Mortgage 13.70 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 16.75 Continental Illinois, Chicago 15.30 Bank of America, San Francisco 19.50

title: Recent Sales
IN VIETNAM, REFLECTIONS ON THE WAR
description: Workers scaled utility poles to unfurl the red flag of a unified Vietnam, and young men and women marched through the twilight at the end of a working day to the final rehearsal tonight of the big parade.

title: Police Fire on Crowds In Western India
description: The police opened fire on rampaging crowds in the western Indian state of Gujarat today in the 10th day of riots over the Government's affirmative action policy for disadvantaged castes and classes.

title: MARY UNDERWOOD TO WED DOUGLAS M. MULLER JULY 27
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul B. Underwood Jr. of Charlottesville, Va., and Isle of Palms, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Barton Underwood, to Douglas Manning Muller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Lee Muller of Greenwich, Conn., and Quogue, L.I. The wedding is planned for July 27.

title: Loss Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance
description: Every so often, the word of mouth in the dance world is that a new group is doing something with a special twist. The company that calls itself Kinematic is in that category.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: LOST AND FOUND At the stroke of 2 A.M. today, it became 3 A.M. To cope with the elision of daylight-saving time, Amtrak simply planned to run the affected trains (there was only one in the Northeast, the Night Owl between Boston and Washington) an hour late if necessary.

title: SHEPARD'S 'WEST': A TALE WELL TOLD
description: SAM SHEPARD has been acclaimed not only for his acting in films such as ''The Right Stuff'' and the more recent ''Country,'' but also for his stunningly imaginative and original plays. He is the prolific author of more than 40 plays, one of which, ''Buried Child,'' was awarded the Pulitzer Prize.

title: THE UNEXPECTED ENTERS THE CONCERT CALENDAR
description: DIVERSITY is one of the happy characteristics of the music calendar over the next couple of weeks, so in addition to more ''normal'' fare, we can partake of such unexpected pleasures as programs featuring the viola d'amore, harp, horn and mandolin. To enjoy the throaty, sensuous sounds of the viola d'amore, take the short drive across the Bronx border to Riverdale, where Walter Trampler plays a 3 P.M. recital today in Wave Hill's Distinguished Artists Series. Far and away the most celebrated concert advocate of this once-popular relative of the violin, Mr. Trampler will play works of Vivaldi and Bach before turning to the modern viola and sonatas by Hindemith and Brahms. For directions, call Wave Hill at (2l2) 549-3200.

title: A Fed Official's Slowdown Fears
description: Last week's warning from Preston Martin, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, that a ''growth recession must be considered a real threat'' seemed all the more serious in light of the Labor Department's subsequent report on business productivity. In the first three months of the year, the report showed, production efficiency dropped 1.2 percent, underscoring other recent reports of economic slowdown; and unit labor costs, which reflect productivity and wage changes, jumped 7.3 percent.

title: By Rumor Possessed
description: True, not many consumers think that their boxes of Pampers or Duncan Hines cake mix are possessed by the Devil. But to rid itself of that bizarre rumor once and for all, the Proctor & Gamble Company, the maker of those and other popular household products, performed a marketing exorcism last week.

title: IN NEW HAVEN, JAZZ HAS A REVIVAL
description: THE 20 people inside Humphrey's Hickory Grill listened intently to a young jazz saxophonist and his trio.

title: 'THE GODS MUST BE CRAZY' - A TRULY INTERNATIONAL HIT
description: Some directors go to great lengths to find just the right actor to star in their films, but probably none has ever made a search like Jamie Uys did. The 63-year-old South African director spent three months crisscrossing Africa's Kalahari Desert searching for the right Bushman to play a leading role in his film, ''The Gods Must Be Crazy.''

title: MISS DUNCAN HAS NUPTIALS
description: The marriage of Katherine Simmons Duncan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brooke Helm Duncan 2d of New Orleans, to Stephen Carter Sherrill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Virgil Sherrill of New York, took place yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in New Orleans. The Rev. Hill Riddle performed the ceremony.

title: EARLY LESSONS
description: Nobody can appropriate a great city. Every citizen tries to, inas many ways as that city has streets. New York and I have been together since I was born. I own tone poems of its sounds, playable on no earthly casette of present design. My brain is scrawled with its old byways, which, if streets has sexes, must several times have shifted roles. What's more, I tremor - happily, in most cases - toward their next trnsformation. Because I know I have to. I know the rules.

title: TRUMP BUYS HILTON'S HOTEL IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: The Trump Organization yesterday purchased the unopened Atlantic City Hilton Hotel, a 624-room structure in the gaming center's marina area where it wants to operate a casino.

title: COMMERCIALIZING OLYMPIC CHAMPIONS
description: UNTIL a few years ago, only Joe Namath, O.J. Simpson and a handful of other athletes commanded the celebrity status to sell products just by saying they used them. But the physical fitness mania sweeping the country has made numerous corporations anxious to include athletics - and thus athletes - in their advertising campaigns. Thus, a growing number of amateur athletes can now be seen hyping McDonald's hamburgers, mugging for Vidal Sassoon's latest styling mousse, and generally plugging products that have little to do with the sport they play.

title: A Golden Touch For Best Sellers
description: In his article ''A Golden Touch for Best Sellers'' (April 7), N. R. Kleinfield writes, ''The extent of her [Phyllis Grann's] editing ranges from just about nothing (for instance, she left the 1,176-page '. . . And Ladies of the Club' virtually untouched) to enough to make a writer stagger to the nearest bar.''

title: TOO GREAT EXPECTATIONS
description: THE PERSONAL PRESIDENT Power Invested, Promise Unfulfilled. By Theodore J. Lowi. 221 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $19.95. FOR some time now, experienced observers of American government and politics have been arguing that our 18th-century Constitution is ill suited to the fast track of the 20th century. Lloyd Cutler, who was President Carter's counsel, bemoans our inability to ''form a government'' in the European sense of a coherent leadership that wins office on a given program, promptly enacts it and is judged on the results at the next election. Richard L. Strout, the dean of the Washington press corps, points with increasing vehemence to the virtues of the parliamentary system. James MacGregor Burns has been sounding the alarm at least since 1963, when he published ''The Deadlock of Democracy.'' The universities and think tanks are full of constitutional Hildy Johnsons reading the musty prose of Articles 1 and 2 and shouting in effect, ''Sweetheart, get me rewrite!''

title: Don't Write Off Domed Stadiums
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Iraq Says It Attacked Ship Near Iranian Port
description: Iraq said today that its warplanes raided an unidentified ship near Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal, the fourth such announcement in four days and the 66th this year.

title: CATHERINE PROPST WEDS THOMAS PERUN
description: Catherine Lamb Propst, the daughter of the late Eliza Mills Propst of Nashville and the late James Pinckney Propst of Charlotte, N.C., was married yesterday to Thomas John Perun, a son of Mrs. John T. Perun of Binghamton, N.Y., and the late Mr. Perun. The Rev. Dr. Joe D. Mills, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour, Oatlands, in Leesburg, Va.

title: Schoolchildren Picket South African Embassy
description: More than 100 Washington-area elementary schoolchildren and their parents demonstrated at the South African Embassy today against that country's policies of racial separation. There were no arrests.

title: WATERFRONT ISSUE: HOW TO FILL 300 JOBS
description: IT HAS been 32 years since hiring on the rowdy piers and docks on both sides of the Hudson River was taken away from stevedore companies and unions and put under control of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

title: Bach's Vocal Music
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES E. HORNE
description: James E. Horne, executive vice president and director of industrial relations of the New York Printers League, an association of commercial printers, died Friday at the Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J., after suffering a heart attack a week earlier.

title: WHO RUNS NEW YORK NOW?
description: Edward Costikyan knows power when he sees it. For several years, beginning in the mid-1960's, the Park Avenue lawyer and former head of Tammany Hall compiled an annual roster of New York's 10 top power brokers - the most significant individuals making the most important things happen. He gave up the list more than a decade ago. ''If I wanted to do something today and was promised 10 people to make it happen, who would I pick?'' Mr. Costidyan asked rhetorically. ''I'd be hard pressed. Because when you say, 'What is power?' one question is, 'Is there power?' ''

title: PARSIPPANY POLICE TRAIN FOR TERROR
description: A WOMAN'S screams, coming from a recreation center, shattered the silence in Knoll Park as a police officer routinely checked a car parked outside the building around 5 A.M. Then a man's voice warned the officer to ''back off'' or the woman would be killed.

title: ISN'T IT ROMANTIC?
description: Pressed against the wood of the elevator walls, they ride up 15 stories to the penthouse, he with his crooked smile and she with her tousled hair. The doors open, they step out, up the three stairs and to the right.

title: VOICING CONCERNS OF MANUFACTURERS
description: AN organization of manufacturers founded last winter to promote their legislative interests is voicing its members' concerns in Hartford.

title: YANKEES LOSE LEAD AND FALL IN 11TH, 5-4
description: Wherever he was today, George Steinbrenner must not have been smiling.

title: VICTORIA BULLERT MERTENS, A LAWYER, IS BRIDE OF WALTER EDWARD THORMAN
description: The chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Victoria Bullert Mertens and Walter Edward Thorman. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Mertens of Hilton Head Island, S.C. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Ernest Thorman of Wantagh, L.I. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Arts and Collectibles At Auction/Tag Sale The Hudson River Museum Auction and Tag Sale in Yonkers Friday through Sunday will feature furniture designs by Gilbert Rohde collected during the 1930's when he became known for using new materials in simplified form while associated with the Herman Miller design firm.

title: PIANISTS AND A VIOLINIST IN RECITALS
description: AMONG six pianists who made New York debuts this week the most accomplished was Sylvia Toran, who played Wednesday night at Cami Hall (165 West 57th Street). Miss Toran graduated from the Royal Conservatory of Music in Madrid, and later earned a Masters degree from the Juilliard School, studying with Earl Wild and Beveridge Webster.

title: MAKING IT STRANGE
description: FACING NATURE By John Updike. 110 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN PALISADES PARK
description: EDWARD MEIER shifted a bag of groceries into his left arm and pointed with his right hand across Broad Avenue, the main street in Palisades Park.

title: EFFORT TO BUILD AUDIENCE IN MT. VERNON
description: CALL it a cultural exchange in the middle of Mount Vernon.

title: Of Enver Hoxha And Major Ivanov
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada, Soviet Union Gain in World Hockey
description: Kevin Dineen scored two goals and Ron Francis got the winning goal today as Team Canada gained a 6-3 victory over Sweden and the third spot in the preliminary round of the World Hockey championships.

title: GIAMATTI GIVES NOTICE, AND SOME CHOICE OBSERVATIONS
description: THE president of Yale University since 1978, A. Bartlett Giamatti, announced last week that he would be leaving at the end of the 1985-86 academic year. Following are excerpts from an interview he had after the announcement with Edward B. Fiske, education editor of The Times.

title: LIVELY NEW SPOT IN SOUTH NORWALK
description: ONE more example of the new vitality of South Norwalk is the appearance of yet another new restaurant, Jasper's.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: VIRTUOSI FINALE Although it has been around only a scant three years, the New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony has made its presence felt on the Island's professional music front. With New York Philharmonic instrumentalists at its core (hence the name) and Kenneth Klein on the podium, the ensemble has created a loyal and enthusiastic following, and today it closes its current season with an all-Baroque concert. Joined by the prize-winning violinist Daniel Heifetz, who performs Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons,'' the symphony also plays Bach and Pachelbel at 3 P.M. at the Wunsch Arts Center, 1 Forest Avenue in Glen Cove. For ticket information, call 671-2557.

title: VOTE DISPUTE STILL RANKLES IN INDIANA
description: Leesa Craig says there hasn't been so much to talk about in this southwestern Indiana hamlet since they tried to build a 10-story replica of an Egyptian pyramid down the road from Bob Evans' store.

title: The 'Lumpy' Co-op Market Gets Tougher to Track as It Grows
description: TO enter the cooperative housing market in New York is to enter a world of shadows. It is a murky place in which buyers and sellers alike must often rely on the flimsiest of rumors and suspected trends to find their way. Turbulent submarkets, like investor demand for occupied apartments in converted buildings, further cloud the waters.

title: HARLI DIAMOND TO WED AN ARCHITECT ON JUNE 1
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Diamond of Manlius, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Harli Fait Diamond, to Israel Leon Rozental, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Salvador Rozental of Miami. The wedding is planned for June 1.

title:
GARDENING;

MAKING THE MOST OF SHADE TREES
description: WHEN we think of shade, trees naturally come to mind. Who among us has not wiled away a sultry summer's afternoon in a lawn chair, hammock or even lying in the grass beneath the spreading branches of an old oak or maple? The rustle of the leaves overhead and the soft breeze might well be thought of as nature's own lullaby, for who could resist a relaxing nap under such conditions?

title: IN QUOTES
description: 'The time has come for Congress, as part of more comprehensive banking legislation, to authorize some interstate banking.'

title: BRAZIL'S INFANT DEMOCRACY MAY HAVE COME OF AGE
description: In the emotional moments that followed the death of President-elect Tancredo Neves last Sunday, Brazilians closed ranks around his successor, Jose Sarney, as a way of safeguarding the country's embryonic democracy. But already some politicians have begun maneuvering to replace Mr. Sarney through new elections.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Stephen Sondheim's ''Sweeney Todd'' is coming to public television this week. The ''Great Performances'' presentation can be seen Friday on channels 13 and 49 at 9 P.M. Actually, this production was seen on cable television in 1982 as a presentation of RKO-Nederlander and the now defunct Entertainment Channel. It had been taped a year earlier at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles. Directed for the stage by Harold Prince, it has been directed for television by Terry Hughes.

title: ELISABETH H. ROSS IS WED IN CAPITAL
description: Elisabeth Hewitt Ross and Harte Peary Stafford, both lawyers, were married yesterday at the Women's National Democratic Club in Washington. Judge Oscar H. Davis of the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia officiated.

title: Settlement Approved In a War Protest Case
description: The Federal Government and the Honeywell Corporation have agreed to pay $35,000 each in damages under a settlement of a suit by antiwar activists who said the Federal Bureau of Investigation had infiltrated their groups.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: On Helliconia, the planet where each season lasts for centuries, snow is falling. HELLICONIA WINTER (Atheneum, $17.95) is the concluding volume in Brian W. Aldiss's masterful trilogy whose theme is nothing less than the interrelationship of all living (and nonliving) things. This time Mr. Aldiss has narrowed his focus a bit. Unlike ''Helliconia Spring'' and ''Helliconia Summer,'' which told of the rise and fall of entire cultures, the new novel has a single protagonist, Luterin Shokerandit, a princeling on Helliconia's northernmost continent, where efforts are being made to preserve law and order during the long freeze.

title: WHEN AN OLD MASTER COLLECTION LEAVES ITS HOME
description: When Old Master paintings identified with a particular taste and environment are exhibited in an altogether different setting, there is invariably a problem. The 1982-83 traveling exhibition from the Mauritshuis, the Royal Picture Gallery that is the artistic pride of the Hague, was a case in point. The collection has one masterpiece, Vermeer's ''View of Delft,'' exceptional works by Paulus Potter, Rembrandt, Jacob van Ruisdael, Jan Steen and others, and numerous paintings which contribute in some way to our understanding of 16th- and 17th-century Dutch and Flemish art. However, the ''View of Delft'' and a major Rembrandt did not travel. When those paintings that were sent were installed in large American museums, so alien in character and scale from the 17th-century house that is the collection's home, it may have been hard for visitors unfamiliar with the Mauritshuis to imagine why some people return to the intimate, stately Dutch institution again and again.

title: Heroin Arrests in Singapore
description: Narcotics officers have seized heroin worth $2.5 million at Changi Airport and have arrested a woman and two men, the Government-run radio said today. The woman was arrested at the airport Friday with five pounds of heroin strapped to her body as she was about to board a plane for the United States, and the men were arrested later, the radio said. Officials said all were Singaporeans.

title: CONCERTS BY THE DOOMED
description: MUSIC IN TEREZIN 1941-1945 By Joza Karas. Illustrated. 223 pp. New York: Pendragon Press/Beaufort Books. $16.95.

title: INFIDELITY'S KINGDOM
description: WITHOUT GOD, WITHOUT CREED The Origins of Unbelief in America. By James Turner. 316 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press.

title: $8 Million in Bogus Bills Seized by Secret Service
description: Secret Service agents seized $8 million in counterfeit $100 bills and arrested two men who they said hoped to pass the money off in South America, officials said today.

title: Investigation Opened Into Killing of Mengel
description: The Dutchess County District Attorney has begun an inquiry into the killing of a murder suspect by a state police investigator, authorities said today.

title: MYSTIC PRESSING TO KEEP 'SEAPORT' IDENTITY FOR ITSELF
description: ''SEAPORT'' is more than a word - it is a service mark, according to officials of Mystic Seaport, and they want the service mark all to themselves.

title: ON THE TRAIL OF OWAIN GLYNDWR
description: THE MATTER OF WALES Epic Views of a Small Country. By Jan Morris. Photographs by Paul Wakefield. 442 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.50.

title: MITCHELL HINZ MARRIED TO DIANA SCHLESSINGER
description: Diana Schlessinger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gunther Schlessinger of Manhattan and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to Mitchell Stuart Hinz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald J. Hinz of St. Clair Shores, Mich. Justice Harold Baer Jr. of State Supreme Court officiated at the Manhattan home of the bride's parents.

title: TAKING THE KINKS OUT OF INTERSTATE 95 LIFELINE
description: Tom Fling, a truck driver from Tuscaloosa, Ala., was killing time among the cowboy boots on sale at the Mayflower Truck Plaza here as he awaited repairs to a broken power-steering hose on his rig.

title: Policemen Charged With Torturing Their Suspects
description: A teen-ager arrested on a minor drug-dealing charge set off a chain reaction of suspensions, reassignments and arrests of New York City police officers last week when he said police officers had tortured and beaten him to force him to confess. The youth, Mark Davidson, had been picked up near his home in Queens by six officers from the Ozone Park precinct. He was accused of selling $10 worth of marijuana to an undercover agent. Mr. Davidson said that two of the six, Sgt. Richard A. Pike and Officer Jeffrey W. Gilbert, held him in a room at the station house and shocked him more than 40 times with an electric stun gun. He said the session lasted 20 minutes, ending only when he offered a confession that he later said was false. The two officers were arrested and charged with felony assault. Three other people subsequently accused members of the Ozone Park narcotics unit of using a stun gun to get confessions from them.

title: ART BREATHES FREELY AT M.I.T.'S NEW CENTER
description: A first sight of the new Albert and Vera List Visual Arts Center in the Massachusetts Institute of Technology aroused memories of a poignant but nonetheless blissful sort in this particular visitor. It should, however, be said at once that the new Center is a great addition to M.I.T., and an addition of a new kind. Designed by I. M.
