Pei & Partners, it includes contributions by Kenneth Noland, Scott Burton and Richard Fleischner that are not so much independent works of art as an integral participation in a joint endeavor. The List Center is dignified at this moment, moreover, by examples of contemporary art that have been chosen with the kind of commitment that comes about when one person, and not a panel or committee, does the choosing. Though not yet quite complete - Fleischner's landscaped sculpture has to proceed at nature's own pace - the Center is already a very pleasant place in which to see both major and minor works of art, and in which to learn to tell one from the other.

title: Scoring Mark Set in Lacrosse
description: Tim Nelson became the leading scorer in Division I college lacrosse today, notching a goal and two assists in Syracuse's 15-6 victory over Rutgers.

title: Competition for Lewis
description: Carl Lewis, who won four gold medals at the 1984 Summer Olympics, will face stiff competition today when he lines up for the 100-meter dash at the Mount San Antonio College Relays in Walnut, Calif.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BAD HABITS: A 100% Fact-Free Book. By Dave Barry. (Doubleday, $14.95.) In Dave Barry's introduction to this collection of his syndicated humor columns, he states (boasts?) that ''there are no facts left in this book.''

title: ALTERNATIVE ROUTE TO TEACHING: CRITIQUE OF A CRITIQUE
description: AS A public-school administrator, I have had to deal with teacher education and certification in practical, rather than theoretical, terms. I therefore welcomed the opportunity to serve as chairman of the State Commission on Alternative Teacher Certification, whose recommendations were made with a strong sense of responsibility and dedication to public education and the teaching profession.

title: NURSE RECOUNTS MISSION TO ETHIOPIA
description: EDITH WALD is back in her waterfront home in Rye, after three months of living in a tent in Ethiopia and struggling to decide which of the many starving children there should be fed.

title: MISS NOUMAIR TO WED JOHN COTTER JR., C.P.A.
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George J. Noumair of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Deal, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Adele Noumair, to John Terence Cotter Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cotter of Crestwood, N.Y. The wedding is planned for September.

title: PAY RISE
description: A PAY increase of 5 percent for managerial employees in the county government was approved in a 15-to-0 vote last week by the Westchester Board of Legislators. The increase does not apply to the legislators themselves, to the County Executive or to a small number of other top county officials, but a similar raise will be considered for these categories when the Board holds its next scheduled meeting on May 6.

title: Tarte Tatin
description: To the Editor: While Patricia Wells traced the tarte tatin to its source in France (Travel, March 24), your readers might want to bring the legendary upside-down apple tart into their own kitchens.

title: STATE ASSAILED ON WATER INACTION
description: AN investigation into the state's ''apparent lack of preparedness'' for the drought conditions in the northern part of New Jersey is being sought by Assemblyman D. Bennett Mazur.

title: Agency Warns Parents Against a Baby Formula
description: The Food and Drug Administration has issued an alert telling parents not to use the infant formula Nutra-Milk because it was severely deficient in essential nutrients.

title: FIRE IN CLINIC KILLS 79 IN BUENOS AIRES
description: A fire at a psychiatric hospital here killed 79 people and injured 247 Friday night, and today Government officials questioned two representatives of the institution, the police said.

title: DRAFT HERSCHEL WALKER
description: IF the Giants are to develop into a Super Bowl contender, they need a running back who will intimidate opposing defenses the way their linebacker Lawrence Taylor intimidates opposing quarterbacks. And when the National Football League draft begins Tuesday, such a running back is eligible to be chosen. Once a world-class sprinter, he is 6 feet 1 inch and 222 pounds. And he's only 23 years old. His name is Herschel Walker and he's worth the Giants' first-round choice, even though he's not immediately available.

title: MAYDAY'S CHILD: Charles R. Schwab;   THE BIGGEST DISCOUNT BROKER ADDS FRILLS - AND RISK
description: TEN years ago, Charles R.

title: THERE IS NO NEWS FROM AUSCHWITZ
description: The most terrible thing of all, somehow, was that at Brzezinka the sun was bright and warm, the rows of graceful poplars were lovely to look upon and on the grass near the gates children played.

title: SECRETS OF JANE ST. INTRIGUE JERSEYANS
description: They arrived, 30 strong, in groups of three and four in cars with new Jersey license plates, and they were surprised to find parking spaces so easily. It was 11 A.M. and they had come, for a fee of $22 each, from towns on the Jersey shore, to ''Meet the Real Greenwich Villager.''

title: BUTTER'S SOUR MILK
description: AS ADULTS, MOST OF us are inherently drawn to the flavors of childhood. Perhaps a licorice stick, a malted milk or a chocolate-covered almond bar. Whatever. One of my favorite foods happens to be buttermilk, which, in my infancy, I presumed to be simply another beverage that was consumed ice-cold in the middle of the afternoon. Or, once in a while, with a meal of fried chicken and corn bread. The reason for this addiction probably has to do with my involvement in the liquid's production. In my Mississippian childhood, I had a nurse who acted as surrogate mother, and we would spend many afternoons, Aunt Catherine and I, sitting in a rocking chair and manipulating the old-fashioned churn that produced both buttermilk and butter.

title: HASTINGS SHOW, 'ON THE LINE,' HAS SPONTANEITY
description: IN the drawing show mounted by The Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson, there are densely worked shapes in charcoal, pencil, pastel and watercolor; there is also a handful of collages. The overall impression, though, is of lightness and spontaneity expressed mainly in line - hence the show's title, ''On the Line.'' Assembled by Gil Kerlin, Marilyn Lurio and Joy Rosen, the display - the first of two - numbers 17 artists living in Westchester, New York City and New Jersey, and it remains at this gallery, housed in Hastings' Municipal Building, through May 12.

title: FOUNDATIONS HEAR INVITATION TO REJOIN U.S. POLICY ARENA
description: The nation's foundations, once attacked in Congress for meddling in politics, are now being told by lawmakers that they are too timid about sharing in developing Government policies.

title: A Question Of Happiness
description: David L. Dworkin's article ''A Question of Happiness'' (About Men, March 17) touched me deeply, as parent and grandparent.

title: A CHANGE AT THE TOP
description: FROM THE LATE 1960'S TO THE MID-1970'S, millions of women thronged wig counters to play out fantasies of living life anew as a blonde, redhead, brunette or ebony-haired ''China girl.''

title: ONE WOMAN LEADS TO ANOTHER
description: THE NORTON ANTHOLOGY OF LITERATURE BY WOMEN The Tradition in English. Edited by Sandra M. Gilbert and Susan Gubar. 2,457 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $28.95. TWO years before her death in 1979, Elizabeth Bishop explained in a letter to a friend why she resisted inclusion in women's anthologies. ''Undoubtedly gender does play an important part in the making of any art,'' the Pulitzer prize-winning poet wrote, ''but art is art and to separate writings, paintings, musical compositions, etc., into two sexes is to emphasize values in them that are not art.''

title: THIS JOURNEY COMES ONCE IN 76.3 YEARS
description: Travelers dream of spectacular destinations throughout the world, but the next major trek for as many as 10,000 North American adventurers may be to gaze at something entirely beyond this world - the return of Halley's comet next April.

title: DENIES GOAL IS A NAZI WHITEWASH
description: The West German Government spokesman today affirmed Bonn's intention not to release President Reagan from his commitment to visit a German military cemetery next weekend.

title: CREWS OF 3 NAVY SHIPS FAIL IN NUCLEAR SAFETY TESTS
description: The Navy crews of three nuclear-powered warships recently failed annual tests of their ability to operate nuclear reactors safely, according to Defense Department officials.

title: Pan American's Smaller World
description: When Pan American World Airways announced last week that it wanted to sell its Pacific routes to United Airlines, it did more than agree to give up nearly a quarter of its operations. The deal would close a chapter in the history of aviation that began a half-century ago when Pan Am's famous China Clipper made its maiden trip from San Francisco to the Philippines in 59 hours.

title: STUDENT ENROLLMENT UP SLIGHTLY IN STATE
description: A MODEST turnaround in declining school enrollment is taking place in elementary grades throughout the state.

title: BROOKLYN'S COMFORTING INFINITUDE
description: You can't know Brooklyn. Not even the dead know Brooklyn, since it covers more than two-thirds of the earth's surface, and their proportionately huge cemeteries are confusing even to someone who is awake and full of energy. That the place is virtually infinite has several consequences and effects.

title: TEXAS, CALIFORNIA AND FLORIDA SHOW MAJOR POPULATION GAINS SINCE 1980
description: Half the population growth in the nation since the 1980 census has occurred in just three states - Texas, California and Florida - according to middle-decade estimates.

title: A BROTHERS' RELATIONSHIP BUILT BY SPORTS
description: IT seems that every day while reading the sports pages, we are bombarded with stories about point-shaving scandals, recruiting violations, strikes, salary disputes and other negative aspects of the sports world. The stories are there, and they need to be told. Conversely, the wholesomeness of sports is not written about enough.

title: BOSSY'S SCORE INSPIRES TEAM
description: The worst part of a Mike Bossy slump is that no one gets to see the quick artful shot, the one made with the player still moving, one skate up, body balanced on the toe of the other skate, chin almost to the ice. And Mike Bossy does not get the sensation that trails from it.

title: THE YEAR OF LIVING NARRATIVELY
description: THE EDITORS' CHOICE

title: MARILYN A. COATS BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Marilyn Ann Coats, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Walter R. Coats of Pennington, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Geoffrey Brian Thomas, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Trevor E. G. Thomas of West Orange, N.J., and Westerly, R.I. The ceremony was performed by the father of the bride at the Pennington Presbyterian Church, where he is the pastor, assisted by the father of the bridegroom, who is rector of Holy Innocents' Episcopal Church in West Orange.

title: No Headline
description: Parks are for people, the saying goes. But deciding for which people is a profound political problem in New York City. Where do the rights of softball players, for example, cross the interests of bird watchers? When does the pursuit of profit disturb the pursuit of peace? And, most important, who should answer questions like these? In two separate ways last week, these sorts of questions were aired as New Yorkers debated the use of two of their scarce open spaces, Central Park and Bryant Park.

title: SUSAN ALEXIS BUCKLER TO WED R. O. LIKOFF
description: Susan Alexis Buckler and Robert Owen Likoff plan to be married June 9. The future bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Buckler of Kings Point and Amagansett, L.I., who have announced her engagement to a son of Helene Gelb Likoff of Bellerose, Queens, and the late Daniel Likoff.

title: STRATEGIES FOR AVOIDING THE CROWDS IN EUROPE
description: One day early in April, an American visitor to London walked into Huntsman, the Savile Row tailors, and asked to order a bespoke suit.

title: OUR CULTURAL FOUNDATIONS
description: A HISTORY OF ARCHITECTURE Settings and Rituals. By Spiro Kostof. Original drawings by Richard Tobias. 788 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $45.

title: Navratilova Triumphs In Florida Final, 6-1, 6-0
description: Martina Navratilova overwhelmed 15-year-old Katerina Maleyeva of Bulgaria, 6-1 6-0, today and captured Chrysler-Plymouth Tournament of Champions for the sixth straight time. She did not lose a set in taking the $50,000 first prize.

title: Buying Workshop
description: By last count, the City Department of Housing and Preservation owned 65 percent of the brownstones in Harlem. Next month, 150 of them, acquired by the agency because of tax delinquencies, will be sold through sealed bidding.

title: Suit Over Height of Building In Washington Is Dismissed
description: A lawsuit by three Washington residents who want to stop construction of a downtown building that would overlook the White House has been dismissed by Federal District Judge John H. Pratt.

title: Votes in Congress;   Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Insider's Guide To Outside Dining
description: In a city where space is such a scarce commodity, New Yorkers find antidotes to claustrophobia wherever they can. Restaurants, particularly those with outdoor cafes, seem to have become the living room for the middle class; they offer space, comfort, attractive decor, food, drink and endless possibilities for socializing. These are some of the outdoor cafes that I particularly enjoy.

title: TIBET-NEPAL FRONTIER TO OPEN TO FOREIGNERS
description: After decades of mutual suspicion, Nepal and China have reached agreement to permit travel by foreigners through the spectacular mountain passes of the Himalayas into Tibet.

title: BENEATH THE BILTMORE CLOCK
description: The Clock at the Biltmore Hotel. Beautiful, bright coeds from out of town waited beneath it on school holidays, I had heard, ready to be gathered, something on the order of ripe grapes. So I set out at 18 from the Bronx, wearing my tan linen jacket purchased cut-rate at Simon Ackerman from plain pipe racks, armed with my best repartee developed on street corners and dates with Bronx high school girls. And I stood at the Clock at the Biltmore - an outsider in the wrong jacket.

title: BABYLON CHIEF IN G.O.P. CLASH
description: THE stormy political career of Anthony Noto, the Babylon Supervisor and former leader of the Suffolk Legislature, could reach a critical point in the next month.

title: NANCY MCGOVERN WED TO ROBERT CARL DRIES
description: The marriage of Nancy McGovern, a broadcast associate for CBS News, and Robert Carl Dries, an associate producer for CBS News, took place yesterday in the Notre Dame Chapel of Trinity College in Washington. The Rev. John F. O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: States Fined in Benefit Errors
description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Margaret M. Heckler, has levied $81.7 million in penalties on 25 states and Puerto Rico for failing to lower their error rates in child welfare and Medicaid payments.

title: SCREEN: 'DEF-CON 4'
description: In the first few minutes of ''Def-Con 4,'' a Canadian melodrama that was shot mostly in Nova Scotia, the crew of a spaceship returns to earth after the end of World War III, which appears to have been started by the Libyan Government.

title: Woman and Daughter Die in 16-Floor Plunge
description: A woman and her 13-year-old daughter were killed early yesterday morning when they plunged 16 floors from the window of an apartment at Co-op City in the Bronx, according to a police spokesman.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline on an engagement article last Sunday misidentified the fiancee of Michael Case Kissel. She is Elena Martha Thornton, the daughter of Daphne Sellar Thornton and Henry H. M. Thornton.

title: NEW TV STATION GOES ON AIR TODAY
description: THE first new commercial television station on Long Island in 12 years is scheduled to go on the air today.

title: UNITED'S GAMBLE ON FOREIGN SKIES
description: IN the late 1970's, when most airline executives viewed talk of deregulation as tantamount to heresy, Richard J. Ferris, the youthful president and chief executive of mammoth United Airlines threw his weight behind regulatory reform. He insisted that the big carriers had much to gain from setting their own rates and choosing their own markets.

title: SEEKING A PLACE IN THE SUN
description: SOME group renters say the stringent ordinances in the Village of Ocean Beach have caused them to relocate to other sections of Fire Island. ''There were just too many restrictions,'' said Pam Gottfried, who is moving to neighboring Ocean Bay Park this year after spending the last two summers in Ocean Beach.

title: REAGAN TRIP TO EUROPE IS SHADOWED BY SETBACKS
description: LESS than six months after his landslide, Ronald Reagan seems, quite suddenly, politically vulnerable. His decision to proceed with the visit to a German military cemetery next Sunday despite the rage of Jewish and veterans' groups and bipartisan opposition in Congress was a ''disaster,'' several senior White House officials acknowledged.

title: THE AGE OF MUSICAL ARCHEOLOGY IS AT HAND
description: Western music is in an excavation period, a time when hunting for old manuscripts occupies the energy of a surprising number of talented artists and musicologists as well as legions of dust-sifting scholastics. The recent exhumation of 33 lost chorale preludes of Bach stirred the imagination of many people, aside from the musical importance of the find, simply because the idea of buried treasure fascinates us all. It appeals to the hunting instinct in the human animal. We avidly follow the detective work that results in the discovery of mislaid pages by Debussy or Verdi, of Strauss's last song or of an entire opera by Donizetti (by my New York Times colleague Will Crutchfield). And we speculate about what wonders may yet lie undetected in libraries and opera house basements. No musicologist has yet come upon the fabled 100 lost cantatas of Bach, which would rank with Heinrich Schliemann's coup in unearthing the four layers of Troy, but in this age of computerized scholarship who knows what is possible. At any rate, serious fans of treasure hunting, fed from youth on Robert Louis Stevenson and Poe, feel free to daydream. The lost Bach cantatas are the Atlantis of musicology.

title: Father Held in Death Threat
description: A 66-year-old man has been accused of trying to have his son killed by a hired gunman who turned out to be an undercover state police officer. The father, Raymond L. Lirosi Sr. of Abington, was ordered held without bail Wednesday.

title: ABROAD, NOT EVERYTHING IS A BARGAIN
description: It was surely just my luck that the day I arrived in Paris last month was the day that the dollar, which for weeks had been commanding more than 10 French francs, began its slip. It was nothing dramatic - it hovered around nine and a half francs for the next few days - but it had an effect at least as sobering as the rain clouds that failed to break for an entire week.

title: Do Not Rush Jury Selection
description: I write this letter to address the oft discussed and very controversial issue of jury selection in the courts of the State of Connecticut [''Jury Duty Set to Change,'' March 10] .

title: SS UNIT'S HISTORY OVERLOOKED IN U.S. PLAN ON GERMAN VISIT
description: Among those buried in the German cemetery that President Reagan plans to visit are soldiers from the Waffen SS division that committed one of the worst massacres of World War II, according to information from a German war-graves group and from historical sources.

title: AGE HASN'T COOLED THE FIRE INSIDE ALI
description: THE SPRAWLING, three-story house was quiet, except for the tinny too-wa, too-wee of birds in a small aviary next to the office room on the first floor. It was early on a recent morning and the cool, shadowed office was dimly lit by two antique candelabras which had a few of their small bulbs burned out. An antique lamp was also lit and with its slightly crooked shade peered over the large black mahogany desk scattered with letters and an Islamic prayer book. Nearby were several open boxes stuffed with mail.

title: SPECIAL WEEKEND FOR MYSTERY FANS
description: MYSTERY lovers will be in for a weekend of murder and suspense - all make believe, of course - when the Hotel Stamford Plaza presents its first tribute to Sherlock Holmes next month.

title: U.P.I. Announces Pact With Its Main Lender
description: United Press International has reached agreement in principle with its main lender for continued financing, Luis G. Nogales, the news agency's chairman, said today. The agency has indicated it will file for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a film distributor's change of plans, a film listing today in The Guide, section 2A, carries outdated theater information for ''George Stevens: A Film Maker's Journey.'' It opens Friday at the Embassy 72d Street.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: On the Shores of the Mediterranean By Eric Newby. 448 pages. Little, Brown. $19.95. Scores of storytellers - from Homer to Goethe, from Herman Melville to Mark Twain - have been inspired by the Mediterranean world to turn out a travel book or two before getting on with their regular work. The busy D. H. Lawrence actually produced three classic travel books set against the Mediterranean (''Twilight in Italy,'' ''Etruscan Places'' and ''Sea and Sardinia,'' gathered together in one Viking Penguin edition called ''D. H. Lawrence in Italy''). Full-time travel observers, such as the American Kate Simon, as distinct from guidebook writers, are still rather unusual.

title: At Odds Over Washington's Land Policies
description: President Reagan's proposal last week to add 382,000 acres and nearly 174 miles of river to the Federal wilderness and scenic rivers systems was of little cheer to the conservation-minded.

title: WAITZ-VIRGIN TEAM ROMPS IN TREVIRA
description: Grete Waitz returned yesterday to Central Park, the site of her greatest triumphs, and came within a second of what she believed was a world best for a 10-mile race by a woman.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 28, 1985

title: THE ANXIETY OF BEING A JAPANESE-AMERICAN
description: MY BASE CAMP WAS THE Hyatt Regency Hotel, an imposing fortresslike structure towering above downtown Phoenix.

title: BARBARA C. MILLER TO BE WED JUNE 1
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lindley Garrison Miller of Upper Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Cromwell Miller to Daniel Matthew Spallone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Nicholas Spallone of Lindenhurst, L.I. The wedding is planned for June 1.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ON Friday, Chris Borgen, a WCBS-TV reporter, will depart from his usual style of urban news story. He'll be giving the story - that is, the history - of the 25 years of Ridge Elementary School in Ridgewood.

title: On the Golden Mile, a Huge Office Park
description: Mount Pleasant, N.Y., has given the go-ahead for a 1.5-million-square-foot office park that town officials say is the largest yet approved for Westchester County.

title:
ART;

SIMPLIED FORMS, FORCEFUL POSSIBILITIES
description: DURING the last 15 years, the New York artist Richard Nonas has been building an international reputation as an advocate of the forceful possiblities of simplified, geometric forms. His stark, sometimes unsettling sculptures and drawings have been presented in l50 exhibitions (over 50 were solo showings) ranging from ''Documenta 6,'' in Kassel, West Germany, and a Solidarity Union show in Poland, to museum installations in Stockholm, Paris, Brussels, Rome, Zurich, Munich, Milan, Los Angeles and New York City.

title: THE LIVING AND THE DEAD
description: There is something else to remember on the 40th anniversary of the end of the last war: not only the dead but the living, not only the disasters of the past but the achievements of these last 40 years.

title: SEASON'S SLATE OF FLEA MARKETS
description: IN 1958, when the first outdoor antiques show was held in Salisbury, few people could understand why anyone in his right mind would hold a show in a meadow. And in those early days even more collectors wondered why the shows were called flea markets.

title: NEW STAGE FOR 24ND ST. IN JEOPARDY
description: A plan to build a playhouse for small, regional theater productions in the roof garden of the New Amsterdam Theater at Times Square has been stalled by opposition from community groups and some members of the city's theater industry.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: COMPOSING FOR FILM The movie scores of six student composers can be heard at 7 P.M. Wednesday in a free program at the Yale Art Gallery auditorium. The scores will be played while the films for which they were composed, mostly documentaries, are screened. The students are enrolled in a 14-year-old graduate school course that covers the technical aspects of composing for films. It is given at the Yale School of Music by Frank Lewin, an adjunct professor.

title: 20 TRIUMPHS OF GREED
description: FAMOUS FINANCIAL FIASCOS By John Train. Illustrations by Pierre Le-Tan. 112 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter/Crown Publishers. $8.95.

title: Required Reading;   Of Bath Oil and Peas
description: Excerpts from ''Ask Dr. Dustin,'' a column of health hints in State, a magazine published for Department of State employees here and abroad:

title: A $2 Problem Scrubs Shuttle Delivery Plan
description: Preparations for the liftoff of the space shuttle Challenger, set for noon Monday, advanced smoothly today, but a problem with a $2 battery forced the space agency to cancel the deployment of two small satellites from the shuttle.

title: HOW SECURE MUST 'THE PEOPLE'S HOUSE' BE?
description: President Monroe was so terrified of assassins that he hid sharpshooters in the trees of the White House and in 1818 surrounded the grounds with an iron fence.

title: Peking Police Put Limits On Foreign Journalists
description: The police ejected foreign journalists today from the City Hall area, where more than 100 people exiled from Peking to the countryside during the Cultural Revolution have been staging a sit-in, demanding the right to return.

title: NEW CASSETTES: CLASSICS ABOUND
description: This highly recommended release shows one of the world's great ballet companies in a sensitive staging of a beloved classic. Since the title role of ''Giselle'' is a coveted one, it's rare when a production is as notable for its ensemble as it is for its star.

title: GROUP FOR DIPLOMATS MOVES TO ARMONK
description: ''IN foreign countries, the briefing of diplomats going to those countries is usually done by governments,'' said James Stoutenberg, president of the Executive Council on Foreign Diplomats, a 23-year-old organization that recently moved from New York City to Armonk.

title: Concern Is Voiced in Capital On Pledge to Help Homeless
description: Advocates for the homeless have expressed concern that the Government is stalling on its promise to turn the capital's largest shelter into a model home for street people.

title: GONE TO HEAVEN AT THE APOLLO
description: Her name was Miss Jackson, and in the predominantly West Indian enclave in Brooklyn where I grew up, she was our only close family friend who was from the South. She was a hairdresser, known for the magic her small deft hands and smoking-hot comb could produce and for the prodigious number of soggy fried-fish sandwiches she consumed while working her transformations; and known, loved and remembered for her large and inexplicable acts of kindness to little second-generation Barbadian-American girls.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: All of Me Starring Steve Martin, Lily Tomlin, Victoria Tennant; directed by Carl Reiner, 1984 Thorn/EMI/HBO Video 93 minutes.

title: KEEPING UP WITH SIDEWALK SOCIETY
description: He makes it look easy, sitting out there in his hat, sunglasses and tan linen suit at the Cafe de la Paix on Central Park South, tossing off bons mots, sipping cool drinks and smoking cigarettes in Continental fashion.

title: Getting Tough on Arms Contractors
description: The Department of Defense occasionally blacklists small-bore contractors suspected of shady dealings. But last week, it announced it was considering barring two executives of General Dynamics Corporation, whose extensive line of hardware includes the Trident submarine and the M1 tank, from any further work on Government contracts.

title: 'THE NEW KIDS'
description: ''THE NEW KIDS,'' which opened Friday at the Embassy 2 and other theaters, is a teen-age revenge melodrama that is both sadistic and wimpish. It's about a couple of decent kids - a brother and sister, orphans newly arrived in a small Florida town - who are terrorized by the high-school bullies.

title: A QUESTION OF HAPPINESS
description: When researching the cause of drug abuse, alcoholism and suicide among physicians, I found that for many it was the ultimate Weltschmerz described by Mr. Dworkin: ''Is this it ? Is this all I worked for?''

title: East German Leader Marks Russian Victory
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, today commemmorated the 40th anniversary of the liberation by Russian troops of the Brandenburg penitentiary, where he was imprisoned for Communist activities during the Nazi era.

title: JOANNE PASSANO TO MARRY IN JULY
description: The engagement of Joanne Addington Passano to Christopher Hammond Bartlett 2d has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Moore Passano Jr. of Gibson Island, Md. The wedding is planned for July 27.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ELIE WIESEL LECTURES Elie Wiesel will lecture at the State University of New York at Purchase at 8 A.M. Tuesday in Theater A of the Performing Arts Center. His topic will be ''The Book of Job.'' Because of an unusually large number of reservations, the university has arranged for a simultaneous screening of the talk in Theater B. A total of 2,000 can be accommodated in the two theaters. There is no charge for admission but reservations are necessary and can be made by calling 253-5192 from 8:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. Monday. A question-and-answer session and coffee hour will follow the talk.

title: PLAY BY L.I. GIRL, 12, STAGED IN FESTIVAL
description: FOR a time, even Jules Feiffer, Mary Rodgers and Stephen Sondheim thought it couldn't be done.

title: A War Memorial on the Colorado Slopes
description: To the Editor:

title: IN CROTON'S SKIES DREAMS FLY ON WINGS AND PRAYER
description: THEY flock to Croton Point Park on Sundays, especially when the sun shines. There, overlooking the Hudson River, amid the buzz of engines, they practice their passion: flying miniature radio-controlled aircraft.

title: Saudi Draft Reported Near
description: Plans to introduce military conscription in Saudi Arabia are at an advanced stage, the Deputy Defense Minister, Prince Abdel Rahman ibn Abdel Aziz, was quoted today as saying in an interview with the daily Asharq Al Awsat. He gave no details. Military service in Saudi Arabia is voluntary now, and the armed forces are believed to have about 50,000 men.

title: A LOOK AT THE COUNTY THROUGH ITS ARCHITECTURE
description: IN the beginning there were the Indian dwellings, bark and reeds placed on a circular framework of poles lashed together at their tops. Then, in 1639, Jonas Bronck came to the county and became the first white settler to build a house here. The hammers haven't stopped since. Jonas Bronck's house still exists, although on land that is now part of the Bronx, the New York City borough that bears his name. However, the county's architectural history hasn't necessarily suffered because of the loss.

title: WASH IT, WEAR IT
description: FOR SOME THREE DECADES, MEN HAVE RELIED ON wash-and-wear suits for summertime comfort, convenience and durability. This suit - in a classic tan or navy poplin blend, seersucker or a gray wool blend - is affordable, nearly maintenance free and universally accepted as proper business attire.

title: A CHOICE OF SPECIAL HOTELS
description: More than six million Americans are planning to visit Europe this summer, according to early surveys. And competition for lodging space, particularly in big hotels in big cities, promises to be intense. Yet the Continent abounds with charming and little-known places to stay, tucked away in charming and often little-known spots.

title: POLITICIANS IN YONKERS ASSESSING FIRST WARD
description: A POLITICAL struggle over the representation of minorities on the Yonkers City Council appeared to be developing last week in the wake of a court settlement of a Federal voting-rights lawsuit.

title: SOVIET PUBLISHES DIPLOMAT'S LETTER
description: The Government newspaper Izvestia published a letter today from Ambassador Arthur A. Hartman, recalling the meeting of American and Soviet soldiers on the Elbe River 40 years ago and saying that the United States seeks peace.

title: Moved By the Righteous
description: I would like to tell you how much I enjoyed and how moved I was by the article by Anita Leibowitz [''Remembering the Righteous,'' Opinion Page, March 31] concerning the harboring and raising of Jewish children by Christian families after the Jewish parents were murdered by the Nazis.

title: Chinese Protest Exile From Peking
description: During China's Cultural Revolution, in the late 1960's, millions of young city dwellers were sent to the countryside to ''build socialism.'' Last week, several hundred of the longtime exiles were so unhappy about country life that they defied a ban on demonstrations and staged a sit-in on the steps of Communist Party headquarters in Peking.

title: Q&A
description: Question: My friend and I are planning a bicycle tour in Nova Scotia in late August or early September. Where can we write for camping information and what kind of weather can we expect? What are the costs of the ferries from Maine? - S. L., Burlington, Vt. Answer:Camping information is available from Nova Scotia Tourism, 129 Commercial Street, Portland, Me. 04101 (800-341-6096). The many commercial and provincial campgrounds are listed in the 370-page Nova Scotia Travel Guide, which the tourism office issues free. The guide also lists hotels, restaurants and attractions, and includes regional maps of the province. Nova Scotians say August is their warmest month, with temperatures then and in early September often in the 70's during the day and in the 60's in the evening. But occasional rain can be expected.

title: NUN AIDS FAMILIES UNABLE TO PAY FOR FUNERALS
description: One day last fall, Sister Margaret McCleary got a call about a family in need. She was accustomed to regular requests for food and shelter, but this appeal was a bit different. The family needed a grave.

title: IT'S THAT TIME OF YEAR WHEN UNUSUAL MOVIES BLOSSOM
description: At least once every year - but never at the same time each year - there suddenly opens in New York a flock of films that are either truly offbeat, not easily categorizable, or apparently seem that way to their distributors who, clearly, haven't known what to make of them. Quality has nothing to do with it. Some of them are very, very good, some dreadful and some of the mixed-up kind that drives the sanest of reviewers into incoherence.

title: SHANKER URGING SHIFT IN STRATEGY TO AID TEACHERS
description: Albert Shanker, who built his career on helping teachers gain favorable labor contracts, said today that teachers ''must take a step beyond collective bargaining'' if they hope to be fully accepted as professionals.

title: HOME SWEET APARTMENT (EVEN IF IT'S STILL A RENTAL)
description: MY husband and I have a lovely duplex in Fresh Meadows and have lived in this one apartment for about 25 years. We raised our family here; we barbecued hot dogs and hamburgers with our neighbors and their children, when everyone here was barbecuing with the neighbors and small children. Those were the days before we knew that those delicious backyard franks contained nitrites. Oh, why couldn't they have found it in cottage cheese instead?

title: WHY FEWER AIRLINERS CRASH THESE DAYS
description: Federal investigators last week were trying to find out why a rear-mounted engine ripped off an American Airlines jet over New Mexico on April 16 and what new safety measures might be needed.

title: CONFRONTING A CRISIS WITH INCENDIARY PASSION
description: Ibsen described Dr. Thomas Stockmann in ''An Enemy of the People'' as ''muddle-headed,'' and he is, in the sense that he never learns, he cannot learn, the positive uses of pragmatism. In his headstrong pursuit of truth he consistently ignores political, economic and personal realities. Blunt, outspoken and adversarial, he is an innocent in a land where, in his words, people chase after expediency. He further weakens his own case by proclaiming that the majority is never right, thereby alienating those who could provide a measure, if not a maximum, of support. Although Stockmann's position may seem like moral elitism, there is a certitude in the purity of his vision. At the end of ''An Enemy of the People,'' stripped of his medical practice and treated as a pariah by the community he is trying to save from disease, he quixotically clings to his self-respect. It is his conviction that ''the strongest man in the world is the man who stands alone.''

title: KUWAITI PAPER REPORTS A VISIT TO BEIRUT HOSTAGES
description: Reporters for a Kuwaiti newspaper have visited an American Presbyterian minister and two other Americans who are being held in Lebanon, the paper, Al Watan, reported today.

title: FINIAN'S RAINBOW ROOM
description: At the Glocca Morra Pub, where they draw a good pint of Guinness, the regulars are particular about the depth of the head on their stout. ''Give us a cardinal's collar,'' they will say, or a bishop's collar or a priest's collar, and one of the redheads behind the bar, Paul Keane or his brother Pat, will oblige.

title: GETTING AROUND EUROPE IN A BANNER SUMMER
description: If you dislike making a lot of advance travel arrangements and prefer simply to follow your momentary mood, think carefully before you head for Europe this year. Even with no reservations, you will not be turned away, but you may face many disappointments and be forced into compromises.

title: FALTERING ECONOMY SHOWS UP IN PROFITS
description: Industry is hit hard by the new weakness in the economy. Factory orders and use have been falling, and orders for durable goods were off 2.3 percent in March. Most economists blame the strong dollar because it makes American goods expensive, but some also blame manufacturers for not taking advantage of the earlier expansion. Administration officials insist inflation is under control, despite a five-tenths of 1 percent jump in consumer prices in March. But business productivity was off 1.2 percent in March, and first-quarter profits are lackluster at best.

title: ANOTHER STEP ON THE WAY OUT
description: The Israeli army continued to roll back its troops in Lebanon last week, completing another phase of the three-stage withdrawal.

title: ARDENT READINGS OF BARTOK'S QUARTETS
description: Postwar America came to Bartok's string quartets by way of its own musicians - mainly through an ardent espousal by the Juilliard Quartet in concert and on records during the late 1940's. The performances showed an eagerness to place Bartok in his time, to establish his originality and his stubbornness in the face of convention. Yet admirable as was this fierce, objective clarity, it often deflected an equally important message of this music - the intenseness of Bartok's bond to his own soil and his own past.

title: WINE ON TAP
description: The wine bar of my dreams doesn't exist. But the one that comes closest in this town is the Wine Bar in SoHo, more commonly known as the SoHo Wine Bar.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TEN PHILOSOPHICAL MISTAKES. By Mortimer J. Adler. (Macmillan, $12.95.) The perpetrators of Mortimer J. Adler's 10 errors in modern thought - regarding consciousness, words, morals, free choice and human nature, among other topics - include Hobbes, Descartes, Locke, Hume, Kant and many contemporary philosophers whose thought has been corrupted by their predecessors' mistakes.

title: SPANISH LEFT SAID TO LEAN TO THE RIGHT
description: The stripping of power last week from the longtime Spanish Communist Party leader, Santiago Carrillo, appears to be part of what its new leaders say is an effort to make the party more open and moderate.

title: MY TEEN-AGE BIRTHDAY GIRL WANTS JUST ONE THING: MORE
description: THE Bean Sprout had her 13th birthday and, despite the offerings we brought her, despite the amusements we shared, despite the fact that my husband and I did everything to please her except stand on our heads, she let us know with sobs, sulks and shoulder shrugs that it wasn't enough. Our efforts, though passable, were useless. Her friends, on their birthdays, had received more.

title: WHAT KILLED THE DINOSAURS?
description: Richard Muller's article was a fine explanation of the process of scientific investigation and discovery.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: QUEENIE. By Michael Korda. (Linden Press, $17.95.) Part British, part Indian, or ''chee-chee,'' (a word her darker-skinned mother will not tolerate, saying, ''We are Domiciled Europeans!''), beautiful Queenie Kelley knows she has to get out of India.

title: CONGRESS FACING FAMILIAR AGENDA
description: Congress is looking forward to a familiar agenda in the days ahead after the most turbulent week of the current session, marked by a series of unaccustomed legislative rebuffs to President Reagan.

title: A HIGHLY PRIVATE LITTLE GUESTHOUSE
description: When an interior designer named Rodney G. Perry set out last year to convert a mansion near the center of the historic city of Wilmington, N.C., into a private guesthouse, he had in mind something quite different from the usual bed-and-breakfast establishment found elsewhere in the South. ''What we wanted was to create the sort of place where the Astors or the Vanderbilts might have been comfortable spending a few nights,'' he explained, with absolute seriousness.

title: Black Driver Bows Out
description: The effort by Willy T. Ribbs to become the first black driver to enter the Indianapolis 500 was sidetracked yesterday when he withdrew hours after taking his first practice laps at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. He cited a lack of time to prepare his new March-Cosworth car and unfamiliarity with his new racing team.

title: FLOYD IN 3-WAY TIE FOR LEAD
description: Keith Fergus, Payne Stewart and Ray Floyd edged away from a closely packed field to share a one-stroke lead today after three rounds of the $500,000 Houston Open.

title: Escape Into War
description: CARLINO By Stuart Hood. 144 pp. New York: Carcanet. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $7.50. THIS enthralling autobiographical fragment by Stuart Hood, a World War II British intelligence officer, tells of his escape from a prisoner-of-war camp in Parma and his life on the run with Italian partisans in the Resistance. Mr. Hood, formerly the head of the BBC World Service and responsible for scheduling programs at BBC Television, is now a freelance producer of documentaries and a scriptwriter for the BBC and ITV networks, and his skills as a writer are much in evidence here.

title: PHILADELPIA SEEKS TO RECLAIM BETSY
description: ONE thing on a list of items to be sold at Sotheby's, the New York auction gallery, struck Philadelphians as odd: the only known autograph of Betsy Ross, being offered by Elsie O. Sang, a Chicago collector of historical documents.

title: WORKS OF WHIMSY FOR THE CHILD INSIDE EVERYONE
description: IF it holds true that there's a bit of child in every adult, it must be that artists are especially endowed with this quality - at least those practicing their arts today. For when the Heckscher Museum set about assembling an exhibition that could capture and hold the attention of young museumgoers as well as their elders, Barbara Coller, guest curator, had little trouble finding works by contemporary artists that could fit that double bill.

title: McEnroe Beats Leach To Gain Atlanta Final
description: John McEnroe wiped out the upset hopes of Mike Leach today, eliminating the former National Collegiate Athletic Association champion, 6-3, 6-3, to reach Sunday's final of the $375,000 WCT-Atlanta tennis tournament.

title: EUROPE'S TOUGHER LABOR POLICIES
description: FOR decades, Western European nations have stood almost as one in defense of their workers and of an array of social benefits and job security rules that far exceeded anything the United States Government offered. But now, hardly a week goes by without a sign that European leaders are taking a harder look at the wisdom of their ways:

title: PAYING THE STATE FOR A STABILIZATION PHASE-OUT
description: For years, realty interests have advocated vacancy decontrol of rent-regulated apartments. Now, as the State Legislature faces renewal of the laws that govern the rent-regulation system, the Real Estate Board of New York has proposed a new plan to allow owners to buy out of the system. In an interview, Larry A. Silverstein, chairman of the board, and Richard M. Rosan, president, discussed the proposal. Q. How would your proposal work? MR. SILVERSTEIN: Roughly 125,000 housing units turn over each year in the five boroughs. If and only if an apartment becomes vacant, the owner would pay $1,000 into a state-controlled housing fund for the privilege of having that unit freed from rent stabilization. He can then take that apartment and rerent it at market value. Say 75 percent of those 125,000 units paid $1,000 to a state-controlled fund. Then about $93 million would be paid into that fund in the first year. Over 10 years, about $750 million would find its way into that fund.

title: The Pope Appoints His Princes
description: Pope John Paul II has sought to internationalize the Sacred College of Cardinals, the Roman Catholic Church's highest governing body, reducing the influence of Europeans in general (and Italians in particular) and increasing representation from the third world. He has also used his appointments to buttress his theological politics. Both objectives were apparent in the selection last week of 28 new ''Princes of the Church.''

title: EX-LEADERS WANT ATOM TESTS HALTED DURING TALKS
description: A meeting here of former government leaders from 24 countries today urged a total ban on nuclear testing for the duration of the current Geneva arms talks and new steps to strengthen the world's monetary and trading arrangements.

title: SUIT ON PRINCETON CORRIDOR GROWTH DISMISSED
description: A Superior Court judge in Trenton has dismissed a lawsuit by Mercer County and the Borough of Princeton that sought to exert greater control over the development of a 26-mile strip between Trenton and New Brunswick.

title: SURVIVAL: THE NEW YORK JOKE
description: The West Coast has some awfully nice young comics these days, it really does. Byron Allen, for example. He loves it out there. But he loves to visit New York, too - perfoming in the city is different, he thinks, a bracing slap in the face, and a comedian needs that once in a while, even if he has to be a little more sarcastic with the audiences than he is used to back in West Hollywood.

title: GUESTS OF TRUMAN
description: IT was a simple ceremony in Independence, Mo., on the porch of a white Victorian house at 219 North Delaware Street. Margaret Truman Daniel, the only child of President Harry S. Truman and his wife, Bess, cut a ribbon, and the house where the Trumans spent much of their family life was dedicated last May as the National Park Service's 334th unit.

title: Nigeria to Open Borders To Allow Aliens to Leave
description: Nigeria is reopening its land borders, closed for the last year, to allow 700,000 illegal immigrants to comply with a Government order to leave, a senior immigration official said today.

title: 'LIVING STANDARDS' CAN BE CONFUSING
description: Is the American standard of living rising, or has it stagnated? Can each generation still expect to ''do better'' than its parents'? Those questions underlie the political debate over the budget and the economy. But it is hard to find a definitive answer, because different measures point in different directions.

title: JOHN McCRARY IS WED TO MARGARET M. DALY
description: The marriage of Margaret Mary Daly, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Daly of Manhasset, L.I., to John Allen McCrary, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. McCrary of Jacksonville, Fla., took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset. The Rev. Francis J. Evans, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Lawrence D. Costello.

title: PUBLIC ADVOCATE AWAITS JUDGESHIP
description: THE Senate is expected to confirm this week the nomination of Joseph H. Rodriguez, New Jersey's Public Advocate, to the Federal District bench.

title: No Headline
description: WAVING to the Politburo comrades seeing him off to Warsaw last week on his first trip abroad as Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev broke into a broad smile. With that, a routine Soviet ritual suddenly took on a new shape. This was not a sick and aging man arduously struggling with his ceremonial tasks, but a real chief evidently secure in his position and at ease with his mission.

title: JERSEY CITY LANDFILL STILL BURNING ISSUE
description: FOR 30 years now, underground fires have been burning on about 25 acres of the P.J.P. Landfill, a 77-acre parcel around the corner from Lincoln Park and two housing projects here. Residents have complained about thick smoke for at least five years.

title: SUITED FOR SPRING
description: WITH vigor appropriate to the season, the tailored suit has re-emerged this spring, but in new proportions, shapes and combinations.

title: FOR MOST TEAMS, BIG HELP EXPECTED
description: Despite the limited number of quality running backs and the absence of outstanding quarterbacks, most National Football League teams should be able to improve considerably through the college draft scheduled on Tuesday.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BEHAVING BADLY. By Catherine Heath. (Taplinger, $14.95.) ''What makes you think all [older women] want is peace and quiet and grandchildren?'' asks Bridget Mayor, the spirited 50-year-old heroine of the English novelist Catherine Heath's new work.

title: DRUG-ABUSE CLINIC FOR COACHES
description: IN the wake of national news reports of drug and alcohol use by professional and college athletes, 93 high school coaches gathered last week in Cortlandt to discuss the pressures that accompany the glory of sports and the need to prevent drug abuse among students.

title: 23 VICTIMS OF UNREST ARE BURIED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: With a fervor only slightly dulled by repetition of a sad event, the blacks of South Africa's torn eastern Cape buried the dead of recent unrest today, 23 of them in all.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Gardnertown Farms, Newburgh, N.Y. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (914) 564-6658.

title: Creme Fraiche Takes Trial
description: Woody Stephens saddled the winner of the Derby Trial Stakes for the third year in a row when he sent Creme Fraiche out to a narrow victory today in the one-mile Kentucky Derby prep at Churchill Downs. The winner will now attempt to become the first gelding since Clyde Van Dusen in 1929 to win the Derby.

title: WOLF TRAP'S SUMMER: A MUSIC-DANCE BOUQUET
description: ''It's like city kids going to summer camp for a week,'' said Beverly Sills, the general director of the New York City Opera, and the ''kids'' to whom she referred are her singers.

title: WEDDING GOWNS FROM PAST
description: THE sign by the imposing historic white house reads, ''The General's Residence.'' You glance across the sweeping lawn and there like a ghost in the middle of the yard stands a headless body form dressed in an ornate wedding gown from an era long ago.

title: JUDGE FREES A MAN WRONGLY CONVICTED OF MURDER
description: A judge has reversed a murder conviction, saying that new evidence proved the convicted man could not have committed the crime.

title: CHILDREN IN 2 WELFARE HOTELS RECEIVING AFTER-SCHOOL CARE
description: With an $87,000 gift from eight corporate philanthropies and the New York Community Trust, the Children's Aid Society is providing a new after-school program for 100 youngsters now housed at two welfare hotels in Manhattan.

title: RESTORATION OF CITIZENSHIP SOUGHT FOR SCIENTIST
description: German rocket scientists who were brought to the United States after World War II are seeking restoration of American citizenship for one of their number who has been accused of forcing wartime slave laborers to work in inhumane conditions.

title: China's Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: NUPTIALS PLANNED BY MISS GREITZER AND J. J. DURRELL
description: A June wedding is planned by Elizabeth Ann Greitzer and John Jeffrey Durrell, her parents, Carol Greitzer and Herman Greitzer, both of New York, have announced.

title: Jazz/Pop
description: From Zaire comes the most popular music on the African continent - a rolling, lilting update of the 1940's Cuban rhumba, laced with Zairian percussion, lyrics in African languages and quicksilver guitar lines that shimmer and twinkle somewhere between rhythm and melody.

title: SPECIAL DRAFT CASES STIR QUESTIONS ON N.F.L. RULES
description: Seventeen college football players who do not meet the National Football League's requirements for draft eligibility will be included in Tuesday's draft as ''special-eligibility cases,'' raising a question whether the N.F.L. may be trying to relax its draft regulations to avoid court actions challenging the legality of the draft itself.

title: Free Again, Legally
description: For years, the family and friends of Eugene Day knew him as a hard-working, upstanding citizen of Alliance, Neb. But last fall, when he was arrested on an assault charge that was later dropped, the world found out that the 61-year-old man was really Mayland Groo, a fugitive who escaped from a Washington state prison nearly 27 years ago. Mr. Groo, who had served three years of an eight- to 30-year term for the attempted robbery of a Spokane restaurant, went back to prison.

title: A Bind for the Fed
description: The March trade figures, which will be announced in Washington on Tuesday, are likely to continue the familiar saga of huge merchandise imports and anemic exports for the United States.

title: OPERA: 'ALBERT HERRING'
description: NEW HAVEN - The Long Wharf Theater took its first step toward opera Friday night with a production of Benjamin Britten's ''Albert Herring.'' The company has turned to the New Haven Symphony for help, and the two in collaboration will be offering 48 performances of Britten's sly and sophisticated piece until June 2.

title: Protecting Pregnant Women
description: What may be the first law in the nation designed to protect pregnant women has gone into effect in New Mexico.

title: A QUESTION OF HAPPINESS
description: On the question of happiness, Mr. Dworkin should know that there are many philosophic answers to this age-old question - not merely that it is unanswerable.

title: THE GREAT QUEST FOR HOTEL GUESTS
description: Some of the same people who were his guests before are now his guests again, although this time he is on Madison Avenue, not West 54th Street. His good friend Calvin Klein designed some of the uniforms for the handsome young men who carry bags and staff the front desk. His good friend Bianca Jagger stayed for some time in one of the suites. People call. The hotel business, so far, is just fine.

title: EXPLORING CUSTER'S LAND
description: Dave Clements, a hospital administrator from Omaha, barrels over a small knoll, calling to a knot of people gathered around a large square hole. ''We got some good stuff,'' he shouts excitedly. ''A rib, a spine, a tooth. We've even got some skull fragments.''

title: ANTITHEFT DEVICES IMPROVE
description: WHEN they smashed the Cadillac's window, the thing that kept them from stealing the car was my Chapman lock. It didn't keep them from rifling the glove box, of course, but the loss was small, thanks to the lock, which attaches to an armored cable and bolts the hood at the same time that it shorts out the ignition.

title: AFRICAN COLLECTIONS IN BERGEN
description: TWO Bergen County establishments about a mile from each other are becoming active centers of African art.

title:
DINING OUT;

IF NATURAL FOODS ARE YOUR DISH
description: IN 1981, we reviewed a natural-foods restaurant in an East Rutherford storefront called Park & Orchard and gave it two stars. In the intervening years, Buddy and Kenneth Gebhardt, the young owners, sticking to their formula of wholesome, eclectic dishes and generous portions, have moved twice, each time to larger quarters in the same Bergen County community.

title: HOWELL STARS IN NEW ROLE
description: Jay Howell on his new role as Oakland's No. 1 relief pitcher:

title: Colorado Gets Space Post
description: The Defense Department selected Peterson Air Force Base for the headquarters for the newly created United States Space Command, Representative Ken Kramer, Republican of Colorado, said Friday.

title: DONNA KINNEY TO WED WILLIAM SPEERS
description: Announcement has been made by Lieut. Col. Donald E. Kinney, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Kinney of Bedford, Mass., and Ripton, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter, Donna Elizabeth Kinney, to William Savage Speers, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Center Sandwich, N.H. An August wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DE ALFONCE TENNIS. The Superlative Game of Eccentric Champions: Its History, Accoutrements, Rules, Conduct and Regimen. By J. P. Donleavy. (Dutton, $16.95.)

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: A romantic comedy about a New York bachelor who falls in love with a mermaid. ''A standard love story, albeit one with some delightful new twists. 'Splash' could have been shorter, but it probably couldn't have been much sweeter.''

title: Sports of The Times;   Islanders Are Buying Time
description: THERE is something very basic about being young. It is the spring in Kelly Hrudey's legs as he scuffs up the ice to the rhythm of a rock tune in the seconds before the opening face-off. It is in the energy of Alan Kerr and Roger Kortko as they pump up and down the ice.

title: NEW 'RIGOLETTO' BEING OFFERED
description: THE first American performance of a new edition of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' will be presented by the New Jersey State Opera at Symphony Hall here tonight.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

CHRISTMAS TREES
description: It was months before Christmas, When all through Muscoot Trees were being planted, In hopes to take root. The holes were dug By the Boy Scouts with care. In great expectation Of what soon would be there. 1,000 small seedlings - pine, fir and spruce A gift from the state For Westchester's use, So that they might bring, When reaching full height, A Happy Christmas to all If all things go right.

title: Exploiting Young Players
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: The essay ''Faith in Words and Pictures'' April 7 incorrectly described the books stocked by the Provident Bookstore chain of Scottdale, Pa. About two-thirds are religious and one-third is secular.

title: Nervousness In Argentina
description: After 16 months of elected civilian government Argentines are still strong for democracy, but doubts were growing last week about the competence of President Raul Alfonsin's administration.

title: DESIGNFOR DRINKING
description: Architects have been trying for years to figure out what makes a wonderful bar. But most of them, even the best of them, haven't a clue, which is why there are so few bars in the city that stand out as works of architecture. Even restaurants are easier to analyze; space and decoration and color and texture, all the things architects try to manipulate, are more tangible in a restaurant than in a bar, where mysteries of mood seem to mean everything.

title: THE WINNER'S CIRCLE GOES PUBLIC
description: LET us fantasize for a moment, as does everyone connected with the horse business, from $2 bettors to purchasers of the equine securities proliferating in the financial markets. Suppose that Rhoman Rule, currently a 12-to-1 long shot, were to win the Kentucky Derby next Saturday.

title: WE NEED THE ELECTRICITY FROM SHOREHAM
description: LONG ISLAND is facing a serious problem: a shortage of electricity. The Suffolk County Legislature and our Governor haven't noticed. They are too busy trying to bankrupt the Long Island Lighting Company and force abandonment of the Shoreham nuclear power plant. People who hate General Motors can buy a Toyota. Long Island can't buy electric power from Japan.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: STAR TREKKERS? THEY'VE got only two days more to wait, but Tuesday can't come soon enough for three Long Island teachers who have been in orbit since it was announced that they were among the New York State finalists in NASA's competition to select the first teacher to go into space.

title: 'MY FIRST WIFE' - BROUGHT FORTH IN PAIN
description: Missing the pillow that was supposed to cushion his stinging blows, John Hargreaves hit Wendy Hughes, his co-star in ''My First Wife,'' just below the ear.

title: FAMOUS MOMENTS IN YACHTING
description: GLEAM and Northern Light, majestic 12-meter yachts under full-bellied spinnakers, run once more up Long Island Sound, an echo of 1938. Schooners turn a racing mark near a square-rigged ship in 1865, and trophies shine with the names of yachts and skippers from generations ago.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

'FLOWERS' FOR ALL
description: Henry B. Blumberg may be 88 years old, but, as he tells it, he is ''a forward-looking person, doing things all the time.'' Indeed, one of the Eastchester resident's most recent projects was undertaken to cheer older people not as lucky as he is: he makes ribbon bouquets for trays taken to shut-ins receiving home-delivered meals.

title: DEMOCRATS SCRAMBLE TO FIND FOE FOR PURCELL
description: NASSAU County Democrats are scrambling to come up with a candidate to run against County Executive Francis T. Purcell, a popular Republican.

title: A Ban on Bitburg
description: In advance of his trip to Europe, President Reagan has been giving special interviews to Washington-based correspondents for foreign newspapers.

title: What Killed The Dinosaurs?
description: Richard A. Muller's article ''An Adventure in Science'' (March 24) is one of the neatest I have read about scientists and theoreticians. It is almost a conversational tour de force, penetrating yet humble, and it zeros in on how the quintessential researcher's mind operates. IRVING A. UNKIN, M.D. Santa Fe, N.M.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CAT & CANARY Written and illustrated by Michael Foreman. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books/E. P. Dutton. $11.95. (Ages 4-8) WHAT do all those city cats do while we go about our daily lives? Many children, trudging off to the rigors of after-school enrichment classes must wonder. And how to reconcile that awful fact of life: that those marvelous bright-eyed felines so often like to gobble up the equally wondrous creature, the bird? ''Cat & Canary,'' with its panoramic illustrations of New York, answers both questions with charm and excitement.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: The lawn mowing ritual has begun; set mowers to cut high at least one and one-half inches. . . . Use fungicides on peony shoots to prevent botrytis and Cygon on iris leaves to prevent borer. . . . It is too early to set out tomato, pepper and eggplants; wait several weeks. . . . Sprinkle wood ashes around lilacs. . . . After planting saplings, woody plants and new perennials, water deeply and mulch.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Streets Paved With Love After reading Grace Paley's stories, you understand why some women walk through the streets carrying secret smiles as if they'd gone shopping for them. In this passage from ''Later the Same Day'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), it is love - the memory of it as well as the present and future prospect - that gives the cityscape a benign character. Walking along a street, encountering no neighbor, I hummed a little up-and-down tune and continued jostling time with the help of my nice reconnoitering brain. Here I was, experiencing the old earth of Vesey Street, breathing in and out with more attention to the process than is usual in the late morning - all because of love, probably. How interesting the way it glides to solid invented figures from true remembered wraiths. By God, I thought, the lover is real. The heart of the lover continues; it has been propagandized from birth.

title: WHY TV AUDIENCES LOVE TO PLAY GAMES
description: Game-playing is becoming a way of life on television.

title: Theater Haunts
description: For decades Sardi's has been synonymous with the world of Broad-way and a must on any tour of the theater district. In addition, there are a number of restaurants in Manhattan where, if you spill a drink at the bar, chances are it will dampen the shirt of some-one connected with the world of acting. And more than likely the person rushing to your aid with a towel will be an actor moonlighting as a bartender between casting calls. But don't expect every Broadway cliche from the movies. It has probably been a long time since someone dashed in with a first edition of the paper, jumped onto a table and read aloud a rave review while the crowd cheered. Still, the presence of professional actors and those with theatrical aspirations lends a kinetic aura to these places - and you can always imagine the rest.

title: WHAT KILLED THE DINOSAURS?
description: If the Earth is subjected to a catastrophic visitation every 26 million to 30 million years, Richard Muller neglects to report on any mass extinction that should have occurred 26 million to 30 million years ago - roughly half the distance in time between now and the extraterrestrial annihilation of the dinosaurs, 65 million years ago. HAL MARC ARDEN New York City

title: DRESSING UP THE PROCESSED WORD
description: SELECTING software for any given application usually involves, as a matter of necessity, a trade-off between ease of learning and the number of available features. Nowhere is this more true than in word processing. Most people do not need - and never use if they have them - 90 percent of the fancy features offered by the so-called powerful word processors. This has led to an explosive growth in the sales of such meat-and-potatoes packages as PFS:Write and its clone, the I.B.M. Writing Assistant.

title: OILERS WEIGH SUIT ON ROZELLE RULINGS IN DRAFT OF KOSAR
description: The Houston Oilers have notified the National Football League that they are prepared to file a lawsuit tomorrow, charging that the decisions allowing the Cleveland Browns to gain the rights to Bernie Kosar are illegal.

title: A JAZZ VISIONARY EYES THE EVOLUTION OF LIFE ON EARTH
description: Albert Einstein is said to have asserted, in a conversation on the relationship of his relativity theory to chance or random factors, that ''God does not play dice with the universe.'' George Russell, a composer and band leader, who has been making visionary contributions to jazz since the mid-1940's, suggests that ''perhaps God did play dice once, in Africa some 5- to 20-million years ago. God said grace, and rolled the dice on the human race. That's when the African game began.''

title: California Governor Criticizes President on Armenian Issue
description: Gov. George Deukmejian of California, who is of Armenian descent, said today that President Reagan was ''buckling under to Turkish pressure'' by not endorsing a Congressional resolution honoring 1.5 million Armenian genocide victims.

title: SANDRA JEANE CZARNECKI MARRIED TO JEFFREY GROSS
description: At St. Michael's Lutheran Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday Sandra Jeanne Czarnecki, a daughter of Dr. Stephen Czarnecki of Lincolnshire, Ill., and Loretta Cichon Czarnecki of Manchester, Conn., was married to Jeffrey James Gross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd James Gross of Newtown, Conn. The Rev. Elwood Stark performed the ceremony.

title: Bitburg Visit Puzzles a Young German
description: To the Editor:

title: BROOKLYN FINDS 'COSBY SHOW' GOOD FOR BUSINESS -- AND GOSSIP
description: Bill Cosby loves bagels - big bagels - and Louis Autino of Brooklyn knows just what kind of bagels Bill Cosby loves.

title: AT 90, ANDRE KERTESZ REMAINS A PET OF THE EVERYDAY
description: The view from Andre Kertesz's 12th-floor apartment overlooking Washington Square arcs from New York University to the Hudson River, the World Trade Center Towers marking its midpoint. From the kitchen window or a tiny terrace, Mr. Kertesz surveys New York through the glass of a telephoto lens, making pictures that are full of intimate, human-scaled encounters and unexpected visual delights. And it is from here, his home for 34 years, that the photographer - one of the pioneers of photojournalism and an internationally acclaimed master of small-camera lyricism - has turned the dross of ordinary life into the gold of esthetic pleasure.

title: NEW CASSETTES: CLASSICS ABOUND
description: A specialist in dramatic monologues that explore the fears and prejudices of all sorts of oddball characters, Randy Newman is American pop's master of irony, and his songs add up to a darkly quirky portrait gallery of offbeat American types.

title: DANCE: A BALLET THEATER MIXED BILL
description: DANCING, pure and not so simple, was on display in American Ballet Theater's first mixed bill of the season Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: 39-Acre Mall In Middlesex
description: The fast pace in office development on Route 1 in New Jersey from North Brunswick to Princeton has spurred residential and retail development in Middlesex County.

title: THE BEST-LAID CAREER PLANS HAVE A WAY OF GOING AWRY
description: I'M WEARING a two-piece Evan Picone today. I look the part. Leather attache case cut in just the right feminine line and the mandatory bow tie, but in a subtle print of silk. It's all in place.

title: Under the Chesapeake Bay
description: Most Washingtonians and farther-outlanders who converge this season on the Chesapeake Bay naturally concentrate on the part of this enormous natural resource above the shoreline - its numberless inlets, wooded vistas, camp and cottage sites and bird and animal habitats. But a new five-year study of the bay is focusing exclusively on the huge underwater area, making maps of it and recording how that topographic pattern evolved over millions of years, from estuary to river valley and back to estuary again.

title: RACHEL SCHACHTER TO BE WED JUNE 8
description: Drs. Joseph and Judith S. Schachter of Pittsburgh and East Bear Island, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter Rachel Susan Schachter to Jonathan Toll Edelson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Marshall Edelson of New Haven.

title: SUMMER BASKETBALL IS TURNING PRO
description: WALT ROBINSON hopes his new professional basketball team fares better than his advertisement for tryouts did. The ad, for prospective players for the new Connecticut Colonels, ran among the wedding and engagement announcements in one paper last Sunday.

title: FROM THE WIZARDS OF FIZZ, COKE II
description: ''SMOOTHER, rounder, yet bolder. It's a more harmonious flavor.'' If the words seemed worthy of a fine old Bordeaux, it was no accident.

title: STRICTER INQUIRIES IN BRUTALITY CASES PLEDGED BY WARD
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday announced the abrupt retirement of the top commander in Queens and ordered major changes in the way brutality charges are to be investigated.

title: IN NICARAGUA
description: IS NICARAGUA A MARXist-Leninist state? Is it another Cuba or is it on its way to becoming one? To find the answers to these questions, I traveled to the heart of the revolution.

title:
GARDENING;

MAKING THE MOST OF SHADE TREES
description: WHEN we think of shade, trees naturally come to mind. Who among us has not wiled away a sultry summer's afternoon in a lawn chair, hammock or even lying in the grass beneath the spreading branches of an old oak or maple? The rustle of the leaves overhead and the soft breeze might well be thought of as nature's own lullaby, for who could resist a relaxing nap under such conditions?

title: REGAN SEEKING TO TAKE FOCUS OFF CEMETARY VISIT
description: The White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, is seeking to shift attention from President Reagan's planned visit to a German military cemetery next Sunday to a concentration camp site earlier that day, White House officials said today.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

PALATIAL STABLES FOR THE IRON HORSE
description: Anyone who has traveled abroad will find it difficult to fend off a sense of nostalgia or wanderlust on opening GREAT RAILWAY STATIONS OF EUROPE (Thames & Hudson, $29.95). This handsome collection of finely reproduced photographs is the product of a collaboration by Marcus Binney, the editor of Country Life in Britain; Manfred Hamm, a photographer, and Axel Foehl, the curator of historic industrial buildings in Germany's Rhineland, whose brief, informative historical and technical notes follow the photographs.

title: WHAT KILLED THE DINOSAURS?
description: The Nemesis hypothesis is interesting, but is unlikely to survive. No such macro-catastrophe could account for so selective a set of extinctions. DAVID G. RIGGS Meredith, N.H.

title: Nothing but Blue Skies
description: All the wonderful weather this spring has spread gloom over the metropolitan area. With the state's reservoirs less than two-thirds full, New York City and Westchester County last week declared a drought emergency, restricting car washing and lawn watering, among other activities.

title: CASE 1439/81: DAYS IN COURT WITHOUT END
description: The State Supreme Courts in New York City disposed of 31,137 civil law suits last year. This is the chronology of one of them, case number 1439/81, a claim by an office manager against her former employer. It offers an indication of why state court officials want to change the way the system works.

title: Gas Contracts
description: To the Editor:

title: Heart Recipient Is Buried
description: Jack Burcham, the world's fifth recipient of a permanent artificial heart, was buried today with a 21-gun salute and a tribute to his ''courageous spirit.'' About 250 mourners attended the ceremonies at Oak Grave Cemetery. Mr. Burcham, 62 years old, died Wednesday, 10 days after the implant operation was performed at Humana Hospital Audubon in Louisville, Ky. He was a retired Amtrak railroad engineer who was a veteran of World War II.

title: OCEAN BEACH STEPPING UP BATTLE AGAINST 'GROUPERS'
description: ON Fire Island, most of the stores and the houses are still shuttered. On the beach, a solitary jogger leaves a trail of footprints that are soon devoured by the waves.

title: A VOICE THAT'S UNSTILLED AFTER DECADES OF SONG
description: WHEN Vivian della Chiesa was a three-pound infant in her native Chicago, her grandfather picked her up, placed her in the horn of an old-fashioned phonograph and turned on a recording of Enrico Caruso singing the aria ''Che Gelida Manina'' from ''La Boheme.''

title: Crash of 1940's Stunt Plane Kills 2 Before Navy Air Show
description: A World War II-vintage plane crashed into the chapel at the Marine Corps Air Station here today before the annual Navy Relief Air Show, killing the pilot and a passenger, the authorities said.

title: ARKANSAS CAPTURES THREE MORE RELAYS
description: For more than a quarter-century, Villanova men have dominated the Penn Relays. No more, not as long as Arkansas keeps outrunning the Wildcats from Philadelphia's Main Line.

title: ADVICE OFFERED ON AUCTIONS
description: WITH the spring auction and tag sale season in full gear, potential buyers may avoid a great many pitfalls if they heed the advice of the appraiser John Markham of Chappaqua. Mr. Markham will share his expertise at the May 3 preview of The Hudson River Museum Auction and Tag Sale in a talk entitled, ''Secrets of Successful Bidding.''

title: AID VOTE IS A POLITICAL BLOW FOR NICARAGUAN REBELS
description: The House vote last week that cut off American military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels is unlikely to have an immediate effect on their fighting ability, diplomats and Sandinista Government officials say. ''They can get $14 million from a lot of different places, so the money isn't that great a loss,'' a Western Ambassador said. ''The real damage is more difficult to measure. You have to wonder how many people are going to want to get behind a cause that the United States Congress has abandoned.''

title: Computer Passion;   COMPUTER PASSION
description: Many tycoons of the computer industry have written begging me to tell them how to recover from the sales slump threatening disaster for the personal-computer business, and I do so gladly, for it is painful to see a tycoon in despair.

title: CHICAGO PROVES LIVELY FOR DEMOCRATS' SESSION
description: A meeting of the Democratic Party's state chairmen that ended here today would have been a dull affair if it had been held anywhere but Chicago.

title:
UTILITIES LOOK TO THE 90'S;

THE IMPENDING 'ELECTRICITY CRISIS'
description: BEFORE the end of the decade in the Northeast, and not long after in many parts of the country, the term ''electricity crisis'' very likely will become as familiar as the term ''energy crisis'' was in the 1970's. The same factor that underlay the crises in the supply of oil and natural gas - price controls - is at work in electric power. Price controls at the state level have removed the incentive to supply, demand is currently outrunning supply and, as a result, a shortage is looming.

title: ACTING: IT'S A HARD-KNOCK LIFE
description: This is a story of the actress's life.

title: BALTIMORE BANS 'SQUEEGEE KIDS'
description: THE Baltimore City Council has tentatively voted to ban ''squeegee kids,'' young people who dash into traffic with squeegees and soapy water to wash the windshields of cars stopped at traffic lights, hoping to earn tips.

title: MARY ELIZABETH WALCH BRIDE OF THOMAS DOE
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan yesterday Mary Elizabeth Walch, director of media at Mitchell & Webb, an advertising agency in Boston, was married to Thomas Glover Doe, director of marketing and sales for Municipal Market Data, an investment advisory firm in Boston. The Rev. Michael Lux performed the ceremony.

title: REVIEW BOARD HAS HAD CRITICS SINCE ITS START
description: The Civilian Complaint Review Board of the Police Department is not, in a strict sense, a civilian complaint review board. It is, rather, a panel of seven civilian employees of the department who meet twice a month to review complaints against police officers.

title: THE ART OF MAKING MONEY TURNS OUT TO BE FUN
description: ''The Wall Street Connection'' is a little like a Populist manifesto: Bulls and bears will get you if you don't watch out.
