Wall Street reaches into our lives in ways we scarcely know, dimly suspect and constantly fear. A bunch of guys (there are women, but they behave just like the guys) read a tape or make a deal, and somewhere, somehow, misery strikes. Factories close, people are homeless, neighborhoods and cities are blighted. ''The Wall Street Connection'' pretends to be a documentary, but it's really a moral disquisition, an examination of greed at work. The irony is that the greedy people clearly enjoy what they're doing. As an intelligent, evenhanded report, ''The Wall Street Connection'' leaves much to be desired; it is to journalism what ''Entertainment Tonight'' is to the ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour.'' At the same time, the WCBS-TV production, even if it doesn't always mean to, has an element of fun. The one-hour program, notable because the local station is presenting it in prime time, will be seen at 10 tonight.

title: JAPAN-BASHING IS POINTLESS
description: Blaming the Japanese for the trade deficit may make domestic political sense in the United States, but it makes little logical sense.

title: East Meets West On Long Island
description: MANY a frustrated employee may say, ''My boss and I just don't speak the same language,'' but Mari Poola and the five other Americans working at Autonumerics Inc. in Hauppauge, L.I., mean it literally.

title: Senator East Is Ill
description: Senator John P. East of North Carolina is suffering from ''acute hypothyroidism,'' which causes chemical imbalances in the body, his office said Friday.

title: Vanderbilt's Drug Fight
description: Vanderbilt's chancellor, Joe B. Wyatt, and its athletic director, Roy Kramer, have assured university trustees that a new drug-testing program has curbed the illegal use of steroids by Vanderbilt athletes. ''As soon as the problem was discovered, we moved quickly,'' Wyatt said after he and Kramer met with the trustees Friday.

title: TRANSLATING THE WARNING ABOUT SUSPECT'S RIGHTS
description: In its landmark ruling in Miranda v. Arizona, the United States Supreme Court declared that police officers must inform criminal suspects of their right to remain silent. Left unanswered, however, was a question faced recently by a court in Brooklyn: whether Miranda warnings must be translated into Ukranian, or whether Russian will suffice.

title: CITRUS GROWERS DIVIDED ON A POSSIBLE END TO U.S. REGULATION
description: In the citrus groves of California and Arizona, growers have sampled the juices of unfettered competition this spring but cannot agree whether its taste is sweet or sour.

title: INVESTIGATION IN HELICOPTER CRASH CENTERING ON ENGINE MALFUNCTION
description: Federal investigators yesterday began trying to find out what caused the engine of an airport-bound helicopter to fail Friday, plunging the craft into the East River shortly after takeoff from the 34th Street heliport.

title: On Language;   YOU NOT TARZAN, ME NOT JANE
description: AMERICA'S RELAtionship with New Zealand, a nice country with a democratic tradition, ain't what it used to be. Wellington doesn't want our nuclear-armed vessels visiting its ports, and Washington thinks a military alliance must be a two-way street. Seeking to capture the new feeling between Yanks and Kiwis in a phrase, I hit upon a song that Russ Columbo made famous, recalling its title as ''Friends, Lovers No More.''

title: ISRAELI SENDS SHULTZ A PLAN TO MEET ECONOMIC CONDITIONS FOR NEW AID
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, in the latest in an unpublicized exchange of letters with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, has outlined a program he hopes will reform the Israeli economy and thereby meet American conditions for $1.5 billion in emergency aid, Israeli diplomats said today.

title: CARTOON PRODUCER RECALLS EARLY DAYS
description: WHEN she was 18 years old, Margaret J. Winkler worked as a private secretary to the motion-picture magnate Harry Warner in his Manhattan office. At 26, she began her own company to produce and distribute animated cartoons, including Pat Sullivan's ''Felix the Cat'' and Walt Disney's ''Alice in Cartoonland.''

title: A HOMETOWN BOY RETURNS
description: IT was the season for Woodstock, Vietnam and the Amazin' Mets.

title: THE STAGES OF LOVE
description: I WAS barely 9 years old when I fell in love for the first time. No one was more surprised than I that spring at my sudden change of feelings. Only a month before I had been punished for bullying the same little girl who now filled me with an unfamiliar tenderness.

title: JOKING AROUND
description: Contagion In finding Dr. Elliot Gross ''not guilty'' of any misconduct, the Liman commission committed a verbal misdemeanor. Its compendious report into autopsies and homicide cases refers prominently to ''grave problems'' in the office of New York City's Chief Medical Examiner.

title: IN THE MIND OF A MURDER
description: CONFESSIONS OF SON OF SAM By David Abrahamsen. 245 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $19.95.

title: Article 199570 -- No Title
description: An 84-year-old man who nearly lost his home after a loan company lent $41,000 to a stranger who put the house up as collateral has won more than $2.5 million in damages from the loan company. When the borrower, who has never been caught, ran off with the $41,000, the company, Aames Home Loan, began foreclosure proceedings against the homeowner, Carl Rookhuizen, officials said. Mr. Rookhuizen was awarded $200,000 for emotional distress and $2.35 million in punitive damages Friday by a Superior Court jury.

title: WHATEVER HAPPENED TO DRAWING-ROOM COMEDY?
description: Forty, fifty, sixty years ago, the most common of plays in the West End was the one involving the least common of people. The names at the top of the cast list, which you'd have read as you settled into your orchestra seat in your dinner jacket or evening gown, would typically have been Lady Frinton, Lord Grenham, the Hon. Willie Tatham. Then up would have swept the red-velvet curtain to reveal the draped and paneled grandeur of a house in Mayfair, complete with a butler sedately carrying a silver salver from the bureau on the left to the sofa on the right. There would be a little gingerly exposition - ''Not a word from my wife for the last eight days!'' ''The mails from Egypt are all wrong nowadays, sir.'' - and then we'd be plunged into the plot, which would be about minor sexual indiscretions among the upper classes.

title: CITY URGED TO START A STRATEGIC PLANNING UNIT
description: A coalition of 26 private groups, contending that city government ''has been slow to uncover and respond to the deep and fundamental changes taking place in the city,'' has urged Mayor Koch to establish an Office of Strategic Planning within the Department of City Planning.

title: TOXIC WASTE CONCENTRATION SPURS EXTRA EFFORT
description: The Northeast faces more serious problems with toxic wastes than other sections of the United States, according to Federal officials and public health specialists, but it is moving more aggressively than the rest of the country to clean them up.

title: BEDONNA WEISS, PSYCHOLOGIST, IS WED
description: Dr. Bedonna Rae Weiss, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Weiss of Youngstown, Ohio, was married there last evening to Dr. Arthur William Perry, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael M. Perry of Highland Falls, N.Y. Rabbi Samuel Meyer performed the ceremony at the Temple El Emeth.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: THE INS AND OUTS OF CHARTER FLIGHTS
description: As summer nears, newspaper travel sections abound in advertisements for travel to Europe by chartered plane. The prices virtually leap at you: as low as $399 for a round trip between New York and Paris, for example, compared with a minimum of $689 by scheduled flight on a major carrier like Air France. Chances are that the bargain will prove to be as real as it sounds, but before you part with your cash, there are some basics about charters you ought to know.

title: THE JOYS OF SPRING ARE NOT FOR EVERYONE: THE GARDEN FANATICS ARE IN BLOOM
description: SPRING is the season that people really look forward to. Well, most people. Let's start with the weather. People talk a lot about the weather at this time of year. Some talk about how good the sun feels, how it is nice to have more hours of sunlight. Others revel in the warmth and the lushness of nature. They gush with excitement.

title: France
description: To the Editor: On April 8, 1984, the Travel Section published an article by Bannon McHenry on the medieval towns of the Luberon countryside in Upper Provence. We visited most of the stops suggested by the author, and experienced some unforgettable days. The Abbey of Senanque and Gordes, and in fact, most of the countryside, left us with indelibly etched memories and scenes that we cherish.

title: AMY HURD IS BRIDE
description: Amy Susan Hurd and Michael Edward Fetchko were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Dr. George E. Chorba and the Rev. Dr. Albert J. D. Aymer, Associate Dean of the Theological School at Drew University, performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter Charles G. Hurd of New Vernon and the late Susan Crane Hurd. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Fetchko of Warren, N.J.

title: TAKING THE MYSTIQUE OUT OF FLY FISHING
description: A BEGINNER is often needlessly overwhelmed by the intricacies of fly fishing for trout.

title: Topics;   Joking Around
description: On Crying Wolf Readers know Farley Mowat as a Canadian chronicler of wildlife and Eskimos. The U.S. Immigration Service, however, considers him an inadmissible alien.

title:
GARDENING;

MAKING THE MOST OF SHADE TREES
description: WHEN we think of shade, trees naturally come to mind. Who among us has not wiled away a sultry summer's afternoon in a lawn chair, hammock or even lying in the grass beneath the spreading branches of an old oak or maple? The rustle of the leaves overhead and the soft breeze might well be thought of as nature's own lullaby, for who could resist a relaxing nap under such conditions?

title: Prime vs. Score
description: To the Editor:

title: SLOGAN RIVALRY
description: STATES near New York have been hard put to outdo the highly successful ''I Love New York'' tourism slogan. But they keep trying.

title: MAKING GOOD USE OF EXPENSIVE SHRIMP
description: HERE'S a good question: Are shrimp worth the money they cost? A universal favorite, this variety of crustacean runs anywhere from $6.95 to $15 a pound in fish markets, the price depending on their size. And except for a brief period in late winter they are nearly always frozen, thawed for sale by the retailer. In restaurants the tariff of $1 to $2 for each shrimp in a banal shrimp cocktail is not uncommon.

title: WHERE BREAKFAST FOOD IS STILL KING
description: Deserted storefronts line this city's downtown pedestrian mall, which even at noontime seems strangely quiet. Just around the corner, however, things are bustling, with carpenters and construction cranes noisily at work on the Kellogg Company's new headquarters.

title: ARTIFICIAL EARS SPARK DISPUTE AT 2 HOSPITALS
description: IN the race to overcome deafness with an artificial ear, two rival medical teams in the New Haven area are jostling for a post position.

title: FROM COLUMBIA TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: As protests against South Africa's racial policies at Columbia Universiy were halted last week, a group of Columbia law students began planning a trip to South Africa to engage in activism of a different kind.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You should not and will not become a law unto yourselves.

title: THE STRUGGLE TO HAVE A CHILD
description: FOR the past four years, I have been fighting a constant battle to have a child. The fight has taken a high toll on me.

title: WITNESS SAYS A MAN IN UNIFORM SHOT AQUINO
description: A prosecution witness in the trial of Philippine military men accused of killing the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. has said in a signed statement that she saw Mr. Aquino shot by a man in a military uniform, a Manila daily reported today.

title: LESSONS OF VIETNAM
description: We went into Vietnam, Henry Kissinger wrote recently, on the assumption that Hanoi was ''the cutting edge of Sino-Soviet global strategy.'' But ''in retrospect,'' he said, ''we know that Hanoi was working for its own account.''

title: Padre Seeks Treatment
description: Alan Wiggins, the San Diego Padre second baseman who did not show up for the game against the Dodgers in Los Angeles Thursday night and missed the second game Friday night, has made arrangements to enter a drug-treatment center, according to the club. ''The mystery is pretty much over with,'' said a team spokesman, Mike Swanson.

title: INSTRUMENTS NEW AND OLD INTERPRET THE CLASSICS
description: Nikolaus Harnoncourt founded the Concentus Musicus about 20 years ago to perform works of the Baroque on period instruments, but, on a group of digital LP's from Teldec, a German import label, he abandons authenticity to give us Mozart with modern instruments.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening.

title: Lebanon's Christians Flee Southern Towns
description: Thousands of Christian refugees have been streaming into the Christian town of Jezzin in southern Lebanon after fleeing from villages around the nearby port of Sidon.

title: The Thrill Is the Chase
description: Margarett Loke's article ''Collecting's Big Thrill is the Chase'' (March 17) was interesting to me because I have been doing the same thing as the collector Sam Wagstaff, except that I started in 1933, and my collection has been restricted to photographs of United States naval vessels.

title: Is Obesity a Disability?
description: Normally, ''fat people just walk away,'' says a woman who did not. Catherine McDermott weighed 249 pounds at 5 foot 6 when the Xerox Corporation pronounced her too heavy to hire as a systems analyst 11 years ago.

title: Acting Dean Selected To Head Yale School
description: The acting dean of the Yale School of Nursing has been appointed the seventh dean of the school for a five-year term starting July 1, the president of Yale University, A. Bartlett Giamatti has announced.

title: SIBERIA: THE 'WILD EAST'
description: Siberia's first road to China lay through Irkutsk, the eastern capital. Today Irkutsk is a major stopping point between Mongolia and China to the east and Europe to the west. And if visitors cannot yet penetrate to the heartland or glimpse more than a minuscule fraction of the magnificent taiga, or forest, the 63,000 rivers and the million lakes, tourism has at least touched Siberia and travelers to Irkutsk are warmly welcomed.

title: A CALL TO ARMS - FOR MET MUSEUM
description: THE talk was guns - but not just any guns. Guns of art and guns of history: a hand-engraved Colt revolver, inlaid with gold and covered with fine scrollwork and designs; a 19th-century Austrian hunting rifle, inlaid with platinum; a flintlock pistol used by an American Revolutionary War soldier.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BONNETS AMID BILLS
description: WITH about six weeks still remaining in the current session of the General Assembly, legislators managed last week to find some diversions from the tedium of making laws.

title: RANCHO LIBIDO AND OTHER HOT SPOTS
description: REASONS TO LIVE By Amy Hempel. 129 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: MARY K. DAVIS IS BRIDE
description: At St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Wyckoff, N.J., yesterday Mary Kennedy Davis, the promotions coordinator for The Runner magazine, was married to John Thomas Garone, an assistant treasurer of the Bank of New York. Msgr. Cyrus Kenny, the bride's great-uncle, performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Davis of Wyckoff and Mr. and Mrs. John M. Garone of West Islip, L.I.

title: A RENAISSANCE BESTIARY
description: Medieval and Renaissance works of art - bronzes, stained glass, enamels, ivories and glass vessels - may be scarce these days, but they exist in sufficient quantity to fill three exhibitions at New York galleries. A bronze bestiary has been installed at Rosenberg & Stiebel, glass vessels and stained-glass roundels are on view at Michael Ward, and a variety of bronzes, glass wares, ivories and enamels is at Edward R. Lubin. All three shows remain through mid-June.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: LAKERS TURN BACK BLAZERS IN OPENER
description: Byron Scott scored 20 points, 12 as Los Angeles took command in the first half, and the Lakers whipped the Portland Trail Blazers, 125-101, today in the opening game of their playoff series.

title: STREET SCENES
description: CHILDREN OF THE CITY At Work and at Play. By David Nasaw. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday & Company. $18.95.

title: State Finds No Buyer For Mountain Camp
description: New York State has failed to sell Camp Topridge at a public auction here. Although three prospective buyers showed up at the auction this week, there were no bids when the lavish, rustic retreat in the Adirondacks was put up for sale at a minimum price of $900,000.

title: MARC W. FARLEY, LAWYER, MARRIES KIMBERY C. REED
description: Kimberly Carol Reed and Marc Wharton Farley were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Siena in West Simsbury, Conn., by the Rev. John Dwyer Hurley.

title: TEXAS SCHOOLS BEGIN TEACHING A HARD LESSON
description: Less than four months after the Texas Legislature put math and reading ahead of band and football, Irving High School near Dallas is feeling pinched.

title: LEARNING TO SAIL IN NEW YORK CITY
description: If sailboat manufacturers could make a wish, they would probably ask for free sailing lessons for every man, woman and child in the United States. Dealing with a public that does not know how to sail has been touted as one of the major deterrents to success in the industry - a deterrent that the power boating industry does not know much about.

title: Fatal Prank Brings Jail
description: A 21-year-old man who participated in a prank that resulted in a bicyclist's death has been given a suspended sentence of one-and-a-half to four years, fined $1,500 and ordered to perform community service. The man, Thomas J. McLoughlin of East Allen Township, had pleaded guilty to involuntary manslaughter in the death of Earl J. Huber, 56, of Wind Gap. Mr. McLoughlin and two juveniles had stretched a string across a road as a prank to stop cars and Mr. Huber rode into the string on his bicycle. He died 12 days later.

title: PUBLIC URGED TO UPHOLD DRUNKEN-DRIVING EDICT
description: Members of Mothers Against Drunk Drivers (MADD) invite the public to join in protesting what seems to be a softening of the Kean administration's stance on drunken-driving violations.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A DAY OF SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE
description: THE annual ''May in Montgomery'' fete has been known to satisfy a broad range of interests, including those in quest of antiques, and this year's event should be no exception.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LUCIFER: The Devil in the Middle Ages. By Jeffrey Burton Russell. (Cornell University, $24.95.) Jeffrey Burton Russell, who teaches at the University of California, Santa Barbara, knows the trickiness of his subject: ''The history of the concept of the Devil reveals all that can be known about the Devil, and it is the only way that the Devil can be known.'' Some history! The Devil has been around next to forever. But Mr. Russell is undaunted. In ''The Devil'' (1977), he tracked old Nick from antiquity through the New Testament; in ''Satan'' (1981), he followed him through the fifth century; ''Lucifer'' brings him up to the 16th, and a fourth volume is in the works. Mr. Russell begins ''Lucifer'' with the speculations of a sixth-century Serbian monk who opens the door onto Byzantine diabology. Byzantine devils were interesting but tame. It was in the West that they got really vicious - and sometimes comic. In this account they romp through plays, poetry and legends, belch brimstone from pulpits and torture saints and witches in ingenious hells. But it is the devil in the mind that is important to Mr. Russell. He recounts theolo-gians' arguments with an economy and clarity that makes them exciting. And his conclusion is a surprise - the Devil was sidelined not by skeptics but by St. Anselm of Bec and St. Thomas Aquinas who argued that Christ's death is not a ransom of captive sinners but an act of satisfaction to God for mankind's original sin; their resolution of the problem of evil and salvation in a world ruled by a just God made Lucifer a bit irrelevant in theology.

title: HOT-DOG DISPUTE NEARING RESOLUTION
description: A WIDOW confronted with the loss of her only source of income - a hot-dog stand in this Bergen County community of 9,700 - may have reason to be optimistic after all.

title: VERBATIM: AGE OF MAJORITY
description: 'Our society cannot afford to keep losing the number of teen-agers we keep losing.'

title: BRUTALITY INQUIRY WIDENED IN QUEENS
description: The Queens District Attorney, citing a new complaint, yesterday broadened his inquiry into alleged torture of suspects at a police precinct to encompass all allegations of police brutality in Queens during the last year.

title: LADY GUMSHOES: BOILED LESS HARD
description: A YOUNG college student has been brutally murdered. The victim's father hires a private investigator who uncovers sinister underworld connections to the crime. While working the case, the detective packs a .38 Smith & Wesson, cuts down a couple of heavies with expert karate techniques and indulges in some serious drinking and athletic sex on the side.

title: DEALING WITH THE QUESTION OF TIME
description: Ever since the 1950's when two French players made a habit of cogitating for 20 minutes or more over a single deal, tournament officials have been faced with the problem of slow play - admittedly much more difficult to control than it is in chess. They have wavered between slightly unsatisfactory regulations and an ostrich policy: Put your head in the sand and hope the problem will go away.

title: Why Service Corps Can't Do the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: IS WALL STREET READY FOR MAYDAY 2?
description: MAY 1, 1975. The day that changed Wall Street forever. Mayday.

title: OF BRIDGES, PUSHCARTS AND OIL WAGONS
description: The United Nations Postal Administration will issue six new definitives and four new postal stationery items on May 10. The United Nations New York stamp denominations are 22 cents and $3. The Geneva, Switzerland issues in Swiss Francs are 0,20 and 1,20 and the Vienna, Austria values are $4.50 and $15. Postal Stationery issues are a 22-cent pre-stamped envelope, Swiss francs 0,50 and 0.70 postal cards and a S4 postal card.

title: MISS SCHECHNER IS WED TO THOMAS ALLEN GART
description: Marjorie Schechner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Schechner of Maplewood and Deal, N.J., was married last evening to Thomas Allen Gart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Gart of Denver. Rabbis Alexander Shapiro and Manuel Laderman performed the ceremony at the Mountain Ridge Country Club in West Caldwell, N.J.

title: CONFRONTING A PARALYZING FEAR
description: I SHUDDER when I look at all those dates I have marked with black ink on my calendar; the nights my husband will be in Boulder, Dallas, Tokyo, Zurich, Montreal, and I will be alone in bed in the dark - his place next to me empty.

title: ANOTHER CAR, ANOTHER TRAFFIC JAM -- INDOORS
description: A VISIT to 1500 Privado Road, Westbury, is always a trip down Memory Lane for me: all the cars I have driven into the ground since I became a Long Islander, all the licenses and registrations I have had to renew, and traffic jams.

title: JULIE OSLER IS MARRIED TO ARNOLD MARK HUBERMAN
description: Julie Osler, president of Julie Osler Public Relations in New York, was married yesterday to Arnold Mark Huberman, a vice president of Goldman, Gschwind & Company, an executive search agency in New York. Rabbi Daniel B. Syme performed the ceremony at the Manhattan home of the bride's sister and brother-in-law, Susan and Jordan Metzger.

title: 'Secret' News Travels Fast
description: They did not sink any ships, but loose lips made a shambles of last weekend's test of how well, and how discreetly, a band of reporters sworn to secrecy could cover a military combat operation.

title: 1985: A VERY GOOD YEAR TO CELEBRATE MARK TWAIN
description: Almost everybody knows, or soon will, that this is Mark Twain Year: the 150th anniversary of his birth, the 75th anniversary of his death and the centenary of the publication of ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.'' From the riverbanks of Hannibal, Mo., to Hartford and Redding, Conn., from Charleston, S.C., and Berkeley, Calif., to Elmira, N.Y., and New York City, activities and studies are designed to keep the American humorist's ideas alive.

title: TWO FOES OF KOCH IN A WAR OF NERVES
description: Supporters of City Council President Carol Bellamy and Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. are seeking to portray the Democratic mayoral primary race as a two-candidate contest, with each of Mayor Koch's challengers arguing that the other will not be a serious factor in the race.

title: Columbia Protest Adjourns
description: When more than 100 students began a sit-in earlier this month to protest Columbia University's indirect investment in South Africa, officials talked tough but bided their time. Last week, the strategy paid off.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: Star Trek III: The Search for Spock Starring William Shatner, DeForest Kelley, Judith Anderson; directed by Leonard Nimoy, 1984 Paramount Home Video 105 minutes.

title: Paying for Capital Improvements
description: AMONG the legislative proposals affecting housing that the the State Legislature is considering this year is one that would cut back substantially on the rent increases owners are permitted when they make major improvements to apartment houses.

title: TRAPDOORS TO HONOR
description: SURPLUSSED BARRELWARE By Vassily Aksyonov. Edited and translated by Joel Wilkinson and Slava Yastremski. 195 pp. Ann Arbor, Mich.: Ardis Publishers. Cloth, $23.50. Paper, $5.95. IMAGINE a writer with the prolific versatility and discipline of, say, John Updike - but an Updike who was forced to store a dozen years' worth of manuscripts in a drawer and then to publish them all within an extremely short time. This is the problem a reader faces in responding to ''Surplussed Barrelware,'' the third substantive work published in English translation during the past 18 months by the Russian emigre writer Vassily Aksyonov.

title: MARY S. CALDER ENGAGED TO WED
description: Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth T. Calder of New York and Hot Springs, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Susannah Calder, to Jeffrey Stuart Johnstone, a son of Frances D. Johnstone of Worcester, Mass., and Rodney S. Johnstone of Stonington, Conn.

title: A PLAN TO AID FIRE VICTIMS
description: EDWARD A. WICKS began looking for a way to save people trapped in burning high-rise buildings in 1980, when 84 people were killed by a smoky fire at the 26-story MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev. The Danbury resident watched reports of the Nov. 21 tragedy on television and said to his wife: ''Something

title: NEW HISTORIC GUIDE DETAILS HISTORIC DISTRICTS
description: THE number of new historic districts formed in Connecticut has been declining since the mid-1970's, largely because of fears of what the designation would mean to a neighborhood, preservationists say.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: COMMENTING on the public clamor over pollution and pollution controls, William D. Ruckelshaus, former Administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, once said that the country was in a ''troubled and emotional period.''

title: Calvin Smith Wins Two Sprints at Drake
description: Calvin Smith twice sprinted to victories, and Danny Harris pulled off an upset in the 400 meters for his second title in the 76th Drake Relays today.

title: KAROLYN CARR IS AFFIANCED
description: Announcement has been made by Rosalie Carr and Alvin J. Carr, both of Yardley, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Karolyn Frances Carr, to Richard Essner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Essner of Miami. Miss Carr and her fiance expect to graduate May 13 from the Emory University Schools of Nursing and Medicine, respectively.

title: SUFFOLK MOVING TO REVERSE RULE ON WATER PURITY
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY health officials have agreed to allow industries that use or produce toxic chemicals to move into areas of eastern Long Island that have been identified as being highly susceptible to ground-water pollution.

title: FIXING OVERHEAD GARAGE DOORS
description: MOST houses now have overhead garage doors that that roll up or swing up out of the way, rather than hinged doors that swing open horizontally. One reason that overhead garage doors have become so popular is that they are much easier to open and close because they have large springs to counterbalance the weight of the door as it goes up or down.

title: Report Defends Dr. Gross
description: Dr. Elliot M. Gross returned to active duty as New York City's Chief Medical Examiner last week for the first time in three months, armed with an official report that declared he was innocent of any misconduct in office. In a series of articles in January, The New York Times published accusations of co-workers and others that Dr. Gross had helped to cover up the cause of death of several people in police custody.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/YOU OUGHT TO BE IN PICTURES
description: Take One: A Star Is Born It is a chilly Saturday morning on the campus of the high school here, and a feature film is being made. Zach Brettler, a 21-year-old with compelling green eyes, has just been elevated from mere extra to bit player. Someone has annoyed him, as indicated in the script, and he has reacted with sufficient menace to impress one of the producers.

title: Hail Magna Carta
description: Magna Carta, after a prolonged stay elsewhere, is coming to the National Archives for a one-year exhibit. A 1297 version of the document goes on display this week in the archives' rotunda, the hall that holds its American descendants: the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence.

title: SOCIOLOGISTS EXAMINE AN ISSUE THAT'S VERY CLOSE TO HOME
description: IF economics is the dismal science, sociology may well be the divided one. Is it a discipline of survey-takers who make charts and graphs and publish them in academic journals or one in which deep thinkers are free to let their minds wander, perhaps onto the best-seller list? To use their own words, is it quantitative or qualitative? To a certain extent, the split became public in the case of Paul Starr, a 35-year-old Pulitzer Prize winner (for his book, ''The Social Transformation of American Medicine'') who had been called ''the most brillant sociologist of his generation,'' but who was nevertheless denied tenure at Harvard. Although most of the senior members of Dr. Starr's department at the university generally favored his promotion, an outside academic team called in by Harvard to guide the sociology department was split and Derek Bok, the school's president, sent him packing (to Princeton, as it turned out). The divisions among sociologists are not just academic, of course. Most Government social programs rely on sociological research for their focus, and its influence can be felt in fields from education to welfare. The Week in Review asked several sociologists last week to discuss their discipline and where it is - and should be - headed. Excerpts follow.

title: ELIZABETH BALDING HAS NUPTIALS ON L.I.
description: Elizabeth Balding, the daughter of Barbara Whitney Balding and Bruce Balding, both of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to William Fredrick Ruprecht, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Ruprecht of St. Louis. The Rev. Calvin C. Adams performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: METS BEATEN, 3-2, AS OROSCO FAILS
description: If Pittsburgh rates as the most ''livable'' city in the United States, as a recent survey found, the good folk in Steel Town must have learned how to live without much hitting. The Pirates learned how yesterday. Taking advantage of shoddy relief pitching and even shoddier relief fielding by Jesse Orosco, they scored three times in the eighth inning to hand the Mets their first loss of the season at Shea Stadium, 3-2.

title: Continents in Trouble
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SEARCH FOR SYMMETRY
description: THE BLOOD OF ABRAHAM By Jimmy Carter. 257 pp. New York: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95.

title: 'LOCAL' PLAY SET FOR BROADWAY
description: IF ''Doubles,'' a comedy that evolved from staged readings in Westport, were opening on Broadway three nights sooner, it could be a Tony Award contender and constitute Connecticut's attempt to help save a sad Broadway season.

title: REPUBLICAN ANGER TIES UP THE HOUSE
description: A band of angry Republicans kept the House of Representatives in session throughout the night and last Monday filled the chamber with impassioned speeches. By Thursday, the Republicans had employed so many delaying tactics that the Democrats gave up and quit for the week.

title:
INVESTING;

WALL STREET STARTS SPURNING THE BIG 3
description: BIG THREE auto stocks are likely to sputter for the rest of 1985, according to many Wall Street analysts, who believe General Motors, Ford and Chrysler will lag behind the stock market over the coming year. Their reasoning: These issues have already enjoyed most of their climb for this economic cycle. And large institutional investors apparently agree - they have been dumping the auto issues throughout 1985, according to a Salomon Brothers Inc. study of the flow of institutional funds.

title: We meant Alice Faye
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ABORTION: Moral and Legal Perspectives. Edited by Jay L. Garfield and Patricia Hennessey. (University of Massachusetts, Cloth, $30, Paper, $13.95.) The intensely emotional debate about abortion is not conducive to polite intellectual debate about metaphysics, moral philosophy or constitutional theory.

title:
DINING OUT;

A LIVELY NEIGHBORHOOD SPOT
description: LIVELY conversation will never flag at this neighborhood eating spot decorated in early garage sale. The buzz from the commodious, three-sided bar, which fills quite half the restaurant, begins at around l0 P.M., picking up the sound from the diners in session since 5 P.M. If customers aren't talking about the old advertisements, photos, postcards and prototypes of now familiar electrical gadgets that fill walls and crannies, they are most likely talking about the food, which has been pleasing neighborhood regulars since October, when Su (Suthap) Theanthong bought Upstairs. Many remember Mr. Theanthong's style from his years at Larchmont Yacht Club.

title: O'ROURKE PRESSES PLAYLAND PROPOSALS
description: LIKE Mark Twain reacting to his own obituary, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke indicated last week that reports of the demise of the Playland plan he unveiled last November were greatly exaggerated.

title: BOK CHOY AND DAIKON GAINING GROUND
description: ON most Long Island farms, spring heralds the planting of potatoes, cauliflower and cabbages, traditional crops of the region. On a few others, however, the vegetables are less familiar and more exotic-sounding: bok choy, nappa, daikon, gai lohn and yow choy.

title: Gallup Finds Kennedy Ahead of Bush for '88
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy narrowly leads Vice President Bush in an early sampling of Americans for the 1988 Presidential election, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: SPAIN BECOMES A TEMPTING MARKET FOR IMPORTED TERROR
description: When a group calling itself Islamic Jihad said it was responsible for a bomb that killed 18 people in a restaurant near an American air base here this month, Spaniards took it as a sign that their country had indeed become part of Western Europe: international terrorism had arrived.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET IN 'LA VALSE' BY BALANCHINE
description: THE power of dance to enchant was affirmed by three works that the New York City Ballet presented Thursday night at the State Theater.

title: STATE JEWISH GROUP MARKS HOLOCAUST
description: TWO years ago, at a Washington gathering of Holocaust survivors, Ruth Eckhaus Restler of Cherry Hill was approached by a stranger, a woman who later said she had come through the Nazi death camps.

title: THE BIG SHIRT
description: Loose-fitting and versatile, these tops are good summertime cover-ups, whether with bathing suits, pants or skirts.

title: Russell's Celtics Won 11 Titles
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FM NEEDS A GOOD ANTENNA
description: It is an old and not entirely facetious maxim among audio fans that the most important part of an FM tuner is the antenna to which it is attached. It is also a maxim mostly ignored.

title: NOTES ON MUSIC
description: When Marc Blitzstein was killed in Martinique 21 years ago, his concept of the social-comment musical must have seemed tired and worn. It was out of step with the times: the generation whose emerging political consciousness he might have hoped to address had already found its musical allegiances far from the sound of Broadway as it existed then. The representative of Brecht and Eisler in America in the 1930's and 40's, he was not fated to be the musical voice of the new social justice movements of the 60's. For all intents and purposes, his operas ''Sacco and Vanzetti'' and ''No for an Answer'' would seem to have died with Blitzstein.

title: A RATIONAL FARM-POLICY PROGRAM
description: AS A member of the State Senate, a former state director of the Farmers Home Administration for Delaware, Maryland and New Jersey and the head of our own family farm - one of the larger operations in the state - I am vitally concerned with the financial problems facing farmers here and nationwide.

title: Korean Retains Title
description: Chang Jung-Koo of South Korea was awarded a 12-round decision over his Mexican challenger, German Torres, today and retained his World Boxing Council light-flyweight title.The victory was Chang's 27th against one loss in his four-year pro career. Torres has a record of 48 victories, 1 draw and 8 losses.

title: FOREIGN PARTS AND HOMELANDS
description: AT THE OCEAN'S VERGE By Ralph Gustafson. 155 pp. Redding Ridge, Conn.: Black Swan Books. $20. RANSOMS TO TIME By Andonis Decavalles. Translated and introduced by Kimon Friar. 142 pp. Cranbury, N.J.: Fairleigh Dickinson University Press/ Associated University Presses. $18.50.

title: Freud, Rank and the Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: JONATHAN LEOVY STANLEY PLANS TO WED DEBORAH LAWLER MEAGHER ON SEPT. 14
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Coupe Meagher of Hyde Park, N.Y., and Waitsfield, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Lawler Meagher to Jonathan Leovy Stanley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Stanley of Canton, Conn. The wedding is planned for Sept. 14.

title: BUSINESS BOOKS: BRIEF RUNDOWNS
description: THE enormous success of books like ''Iacocca,'' ''In Search of Excellence,'' ''The One Minute Manager'' and ''Megatrends'' has tended to divert attention from the numerous self-help and how-to business and financial books that abound. Every month a dozen or more roll off the presses of commercial publishers, dispensing advice about everything from making a killing in the stock market to becoming a real estate tycoon. While most contain some valuable tips and information, almost all need to be approached with discretion and discrimination. The following are some of the better recent books in those broad categories:

title: FOR REFUGEE WOMEN, AN EVEN HARDER ORDEAL
description: Refugee women suffer all the familiar problems of life in exile: a sense of isolation, powerlessness and loss of status. But a growing number of relief workers, physicians and psychologists say women who have left their homelands bear extra burdens as well.

title: How to Prevent Runs on Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberals in Canarsie
description: To the Editor:

title: DOLE PONDERS NICARAGUA TRADE EMBARGO
description: Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, said today that President Reagan should ''seriously consider'' imposing a trade embargo on Nicaragua.

title: 2 Die Off British Columbia
description: A storm off northern Vancouver Island sank four boats, killing at least two people, the Coast Guard said Friday. One person was reported missing and 20 people were rescued. Search crews faced 30-foot waves and 65-knot winds, the Coast Guard said.

title: ROBIN BRONZAFT BRIDE OF MICHAEL D. HOWALD
description: In the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations yesterday Robin Bronzaft, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Bronzaft of New York, was married to Michael D. Howald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Douglas Howald of Huntington Beach, Calif. The ceremony was performed by Justice Betty Weinberg Ellerin of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court.

title: NEW YORK RESTAURANTS LISTED FOR VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 111 food establishments cited for violations of the city's health code.

title: THOSE PUBLIC MUSIC LESSONS CALLED MASTER CLASSES
description: Imagine a crowded concert hall. On the stage are a teacher and a musician who - having just performed - anxiously awaits a critique. The teacher takes a moment to collect his thoughts, then offers a few suggestions - perhaps a word about the tempo or the dynamics, maybe an observation that the mood needs rethinking. The student listens intently and begins his performance anew, this time with a fresh quality that was missing before.

title: NANCY BREE IS MARRIED
description: Nancy Ann Bree, a daughter of Jacqueline Burstein of Tenafly, N.J., and Warren H. Bree of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to John M. Babyak, the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. J. Babyak of Basking Ridge, N.J. Mayor Richard K. Van Nostrand of Tenafly performed the ceremony at the Montammy Golf Club in Alpine, N.J. The couple graduated from the University of Vermont. The bride's father is a senior vice president of Oppenheimer & Company in New York.

title:
GARDENING;

MAKING THE MOST OF SHADE TREES
description: WHEN we think of shade, trees naturally come to mind. Who among us has not wiled away a sultry summer's afternoon in a lawn chair, hammock or even lying in the grass beneath the spreading branches of an old oak or maple? The rustle of the leaves overhead and the soft breeze might well be thought of as nature's own lullaby, for who could resist a relaxing nap under such conditions?

title: SATELLITE INSTALLATIONS SPLIT SUSSEX
description: FOR MORE than a decade, most of the 17,000 or so people in this community of verdant valleys and mountainous ridges have lived close to and at peace with clusters of prodigious white dishes that receive and transmit coded signals from and to satellites.

title: Shore Utility Turns Developer
description: AFTER the Garden State Parkway opened up an easy route to the shore in 1955, thousands of people decided that, instead of just visiting on weekends or during vacations, they would move to one of the oceanside towns in Monmouth County and commute to work in New York City. Since 1960, the county's population has grown by more than 50 percent, to 503,000, and county planners expect that growth to continue through the turn of the century.

title: City Newly Named Chernenko Is a Booming Hub of Industry
description: A former Siberian farm town newly named for Konstantin U. Chernenko, the former Soviet leader, is in the midst of an industrial boom, according to recent Soviet press reports.

title: RAWLEY OF PHILLIES BEATS CUBS
description: Shane Rawley checked Chicago on four hits in 7Y innings and Glenn Wilson drove in three runs with a triple and a sacrifice fly as the Phillies beat the Cubs, 6-1, tonight, snapping Philadelphia's three-game losing streak.

title: Troubled Express Triumphs
description: Kevin Nelson carried the ball 20 times for 85 yards to lead the Los Angeles Express to a 17-12 victory over the Portland Breakers tonight in what may have been the last game for the Express.

title: LUCY RIEGEL THACKARA MARRIED TO KEVIN KENNEDY
description: Lucy Riegel Thackara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Thackara of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Kevin Patrick Kennedy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kennedy of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Richard E. Stearns performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Vincent O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Another Chapter In the Page Riddle
description: It has become a routine among fight fans to discuss a Greg Page fight as if three fighters were involved, instead of two. There is Page's opponent, of course, but it's always a tossup about which Page will show up: Will it be Greg Page the prodigy, or Greg Page the pudgy?

title: STAR GAZING
description: Several decades and many martinis ago, debutantes and movie stars such as Errol Flynn and Bogie could be seen sipping their drinks draped over the bars in the town's top nightspots. But celebrities of the mid-80's don't seem to sit at bars. They prefer tables. The very best places for celebrity spotting are those where the tables can be seen from the bar or, ah joy, those with bars the celebrities must pass on the way to their tables! In this category, the reigning champions, equally convivial yet different as vodka, beer and wine, are - hands down, bottoms up - the Russian Tea Room, Elaine's and Mortimer's.

title: THE EMPHASIS IS ON AUTOMATION
description: AUTOFOCUS 35-millimeter cameras are a phenomenon in today's photography. These new compacts are beating out the popular 35-millimeter single lens reflex cameras in sales. Even professional photographers have embraced them enthusiastically.

title: LEGAL-SERVICES UNIT SUES TO KEEP FUNDS
description: IN one of his more controversial actions, Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke has tried to cut off funds to a private legal agency serving the poor because the agency, which receives some of its funds from the county, has been bringing some of its legal actions against the county.

title: In the Village Of Oyster Bay
description: Even today it would be hard to find an article on Oyster Bay that did not make at least a passing reference to President Theodore Roosevelt. The informative and well-written piece of March 31 [''Oyster Bay Hamlet Getting a Facelift''] also gave due recognition to the ''trust buster'' who could get a czar and an emperor to make peace, yet drop all domestic and foreign matters and leave the White House to read to Oyster Bay schoolchildren each Christmas Eve.

title: SHOW BUSINESS
description: THEY WERE TIRED of the run-of-the-mill fund-raisers - of balls and bridge parties, luncheons and fashion shows. So a determined group of women in Hillsborough, Calif., decided it was time to come up with an alternative. ''We agonized for months, analyzing the best of each kind of charity event,'' recalls Shammy Lawrence. ''When we put all the ingredients together, the notion of a decorator's show house was born.''

title: IN AMAGANSETT, AN OLD RELIABLE
description: GORDON'S in Amagansett has become something of an institution, a successfully long-running establishment. A revisit after about five years proved that it remains a pleasant place for some reliably good food, nicely served.

title: SLEEPY HOLLOW SENDS A TRAVELER TO SCHOOL
description: BILL ORSER wears many hats in his work as a guide, or ''interpreter,'' at Philipsburg Manor, the once-thriving 18th-century farm and trade center that is part of Sleepy Hollow Restorations. He is often found working as a blacksmith, using the tools and methods used by blacksmiths two centuries ago. Or he might be at the mill, helping to grind wheat or corn into flour.

title: NEW CASSETTES: CLASSICS ABOUND
description: Fifty-two years later, you can't beat this cast. Or the characters - a colorful mix of couples and one loner invited to dine with a Park Avenue shipping tycoon who faces ruin.

title: 71 HOMES PLANNED
description: A plan to preserve most of the 522-acre Mortimer L. Schiff estate in Mendham Township, N.J., by selling a portion of it for residential development moved a step closer to reality when township officials accepted for review a proposal to build 71 single-family homes on a parcel of 120 acres.

title: Poems and History In a Cemetery
description: Many thanks for the article on one of my favorite Hartford historical sites, the ancient burial ground next to Center Church [''Hartford to Renew Its Burying Ground,'' March 24] .

title: Chilean Team Fined
description: Chile's national soccer team has been fined $5,770 for spectator violence and ''poor stadium organization'' at a March 24 World Cup qualifying game against Uruguay in Santiago, the International Soccer Federation said today.

title: BONN CENTRAL BANKER COOL TO FUELING OF ECONOMY
description: Karl Otto Pohl, president of the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, sees little scope for additional measures to stimulate growth of the economy.

title: HOSPITAL PROPOSAL ADVANCES
description: THE University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey will seek state approval to convert its University Hospital, now a public teaching hospital here, into a voluntary, nonprofit facility.

title: THE WORLD IN A KEG
description: The modest exterior belies its legendary status, at least in certain circles. The Peculier Pub, on West Fourth Street, is the mecca of malt lovers on the East Coast, offering more than 250 domestic and imported beers. ''If you know your beer, you know this joint,'' volunteers a rumpled-looking businessman in a brown tweed suit. He is sipping the foam from a tall glass of St. Sixtus Trappist ale from Belgium.

title: THE CITY UNVEILS A BLUEPRINT FOR RENOVATING CENTRAL PARK
description: The most comprehensive analysis ever done on Central Park - a 96-page management and restoration plan so detailed that even the trees were counted - has just been published by the City Parks and Recreation Department.

title: 1764 HOUSE REOPENING AFTER FIRE
description: THE Dr. Alexander King House is ready to face the public again.

title: JAZZ: JOE ANDERSON
description: Joe Henderson is one of those rare jazz saxophonists who have such a commanding presence - built on virtuosity, imagination and self-confidence - that, like Sonny Rollins, John Coltrane, Coleman Hawkins and Ben Webster, they seem to obliterate everyone else on the stand.

title: KOCH WARNS LANDLORDS ON CO-OP WAREHOUSING
description: Mayor Koch said last week that he would seek an end to the conversion of rental apartments to cooperatives or condominiums if what he called the ''unconscionable'' practice of keeping vacant apartments off the market was not ended.

title: South Africa Indicts 16 Blacks; Clashes Continue
description: South African authorities fought back against persistent black unrest last week by indicting 16 black leaders for treason and arresting two others. Still the violence went on in widely scattered townships. About 300 people, almost all of them blacks, have died in clashes with security forces since September.

title: 'EXILE' IN MONTAUK PRODUCES 5 PLAYS
description: WHAT does a producer who recently bought a beach house in Montauk do with a playwright who must deliver a play on deadline? Get the writer to the house fast, of course, and leave him there, far away from big-city pressures.

title: WITHOUT CULTURAL COMMISARS
description: BEYOND FRONTIERS By Jasper Parrott with Vladimir Ashkenazy. Illustrated. 239 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95.

title: BRIEFING;Say What?
description: Sometimes memorandums written by members of Congress pay more attention to touching all the political and bureaucratic bases than to saying what the lawmaker really has to say. A sterling example is a press memo issued the other day on Capitol Hill that opened with this: ''Congresswoman Mary Rose Oakar (D-Oh), chair of the House Administration Committee's Task Force on Libraries and Memorials, and member of the Joint Committee on the Library, representing the Honorable Frank Annunzio, chairman of the Joint Committee on the Library, will join Senator Charles McC. Mathias, vice chairman of the Joint Committee, in announcing the recipient of a $50,000 commission ($25,000 from the joint committee and $25,000 from a matching grant from the National Endowment for the Arts), to create the Martin Luther King Jr. memorial sculpture for placement in the United States Capitol.''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 29, 1985:

title: Fish Nets $30,000
description: John Roides of Rochester hauled a chinook salmon weighing 31 pounds 12 ounces from Lake Ontario today to win the $30,000 grand prize on the last day of the nation's biggest fishing derby. An estimated 12,000 anglers competed in the $255,000 Empire State Lake Ontario Trout and Salmon Derby, which began Thursday.

title: Miss Cohen, a Writer, Wed To Robert Palmer, a Critic
description: Debra Rae Cohen, a freelance writer, and Robert Franklin Palmer, a music critic for The New York Times, were married yesterday at the New York home of the bride's mother, Joyce Cohen. Rabbi Phineas Kadushin officiated.

title: FOR ONE ZEALOUS JUDGE, HARD BARGAINING PUSHES CASES THROUGH THE COURTS
description: Justice Harold J. Rothwax is angry again.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: LEGENDS GOLF WON BY LITTLER-JANUARY
description: Gene Littler sank a 30-foot, wide-breaking putt downhill for a birdie on the final hole today that gave him and Don January a one-shot victory in the annual Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf senior team tournament.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;HIGH INTEREST RATES PERSIST
description: Speculation that the Federal Reserve Board will encourage lower interest rates still lives, even though those hopes were partly hidden last week when interest rates rose in advance of record-sized Treasury note and bond sales in May.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;New Names, Faces
description: You've heard of Martina Navratilova and Mary Lou Retton, but what about all those other female athletes, especially the younger ones who have not yet earned the kind of fame that comes from winning tennis championships and Olympic medals?

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;G.M.-Ford Plea on Mileage Rule
description: It will be June before the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration decides whether to propose a change in the passenger car fuel economy standards for American-made cars. Attention is focusing upon May 14 hearings before the Subcommittee on Energy Regulation of the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources.

title: POLICE GIVE CONFLICTING TESTIMONY ON DETAILS OF '79 CAROLINA MARCH
description: Three top Greensboro police officers testified last week that the police were absent from a 1979 anti-Klan march at which five demonstrators were fatally shot because of confusion over the route of the march and because the department had adopted a ''low profile'' strategy for dealing with the demonstration.

title: AS LEBANON'S CHRISTIANS YIELD TOWNS, DRUSE SEIZE COAST HIGHWAY
description: Druse forces took control of the coastal road linking Beirut with the southern port of Sidon today while other Moslem militiamen continued their advance against Christian positions in the hills east of the port.

title: PRIVATE CONCERNS GAINING FOOTHOLD IN PUBLIC TRANSIT
description: With strong encouragement from the Reagan Administration, private companies are edging into the business of public mass transit.

title: THE REGION;Train Runs Added In New York State
description: Several additions to Amtrak's schedule throughout New York State, including more weekend trains and a Friday rush-hour express between New York City and Albany were made today, the State Transportation Commissioner, James L. Larocca, said.

title: SANTUCCI SAYS SOME OFFICERS ARE AIDING TORTURE INQUIRY
description: Some cracks'' have developed in a ''blue wall'' of silence by police officers who have refused to cooperate with an inquiry into charges that suspects had been tortured with electric-shock devices, according to the Queens District Attorney.

title: Cathy Fran Shufro Wed to Psychiatrist
description: Cathy Fran Shufro, a daughter of Edith Zwick Evans of Berlin, N.Y., and Arnold Dan Shufro of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Marshal Mandelkern, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leo Mandelkern of Tallahassee, Fla. Rabbi Robert N. Levine performed the ceremony at the Burr Homestead in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Terry D. Smith Is Wed To Hugh H. Jacobson
description: At Temple Emanuel in Paterson, N.J., Terry Diane Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Smith of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Hugh Howard Jacobson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sherwood Jacobson of New York. Rabbi David Panitz, assisted by Cantor Abraham Weisman, performed the ceremony.

title: Stallions Subdued By Bulls
description: The Jacksonville Bulls' defense held the Birmingham Stallions in check in crucial situations to help gain a 27-17 victory today.

title: Judge Denies Crown Motion
description: A Federal District judge in Nevada on Friday denied a motion by the Crown Zellerbach Corporation for a temporary restraining order barring Sir James Goldsmith from purchasing additional Crown shares following the withdrawal of his cash tender offer, a source close to Sir James said yesterday.

title: Rating School Principals Is Not Fair Play
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: 'HAUNTED LANDSCAPE'
description: A HAUNTED LANDSCAPE'' by George Crumb was a New York Philharmonic commission that the orchestra first performed at last June's Horizons new-music festival under Arthur Weisberg's direction. Now it has been taken up as part of the regular subscription programs with Zubin Mehta conducting, in concerts Thursday night, Friday afternoon and Saturday night in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: NEW XEROX PUSH IN THE OFFICE
description: A Xerox Corporation executive was asked recently to assess his company's performance in the office-automation market. ''It has been a long, hard road - a real grind,'' he said.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Journalists in Italy Strike Over Wages
description: Italian journalists working for newspapers and the Government broadcasting network went on strike today, creating a news blackout in the country.

title: Treasury Announcement Tuesday
description: Treasury financing developments this week include today's regular sale of new bills due in three months and six months plus an announcement tomorrow of a major note and bond financing in the week of May 6.

title: ROVING GANGS ROB CHARITY WALKERS
description: A festive fund-raising walkathon through Manhattan for the March of Dimes ended in turmoil yesterday as packs of roving youths attacked and harassed scores of marchers in and around Central Park, snatching neck chains, purses and other property.

title: FED SEEMS UNLIKELY TO EASE SHARPLY
description: Despite sagging economic growth, falling productivity and the perilous condition of savings institutions, the Federal Reserve appears to have decided against an aggressive relaxation of its monetary policy.

title: U.S. COMPANIES CUT SOME SOUTH AFRICA LINKS
description: Publicly citing declining profitability in South Africa, some American corporations have begun to scale back - or sell off - their South African operations. But analysts and some company officers say that the increasingly militant campaign against American involvement in South Africa is also having an impact.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Honor From a Nation
description: Harrison J. Goldin has been made a Knight in the Order of Merit of the Republic of Italy for his service to the Italian community in New York.

title: JETS SEEKING HELP FOR CURRENT NEEDS
description: IT has taken the Jets 10 years to erase the memory of the horrid trades in which they mortgaged their future for quick fixes and wound up without a future or a present.

title: ORDER ON 3 STORER CABLE UNITS
description: A Connecticut judge has issued a temporary injunction ordering a group of dissident Storer Communications shareholders not to take ''any action to terminate the currently constituted corporate existence'' of Storer's three Connecticut cable television subsidiaries without approval from utilities regulators.

title: Wage Rate Up 3% in Quarter
description: Wage increases continued to be moderate in the first quarter of 1985, with annual rises averaging just 3 percent in major collective bargaining agreements, the Labor Department reported Friday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Air-Conditioning on the LL
description: The hour was late as the Canarsie-bound LL train rumbled along the elevated tracks in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Untouched and unbroken, a pane of glass simply fell from one of the doors to the track below. A few riders in the crowded car looked up and gave a knowing shake of the head. Then they then went back to reading or sleep, grateful for the unexpected fresh air on a balmy spring night.

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;North Stars Win In Overtime, 5-4
description: Dennis Maruk scored on a 25-foot wrist shot at 1 minute 14 seconds of overtime as the Minnesota North Stars rallied tonight to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 5-4.

title: ALBERT MALTZ, A SCREENWRITER BLACKLISTED BY INDUSTRY, DIES
description: Albert Maltz, an Academy-Award-winning screenwriter and one of 10 Hollywood figures jailed in 1950 and blacklisted by the movie industry for refusing to answer questions of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, died Friday of complications resulting from shingles in Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. Mr. Maltz was 76 years old and lived in West Hollywood.

title: John Post Weds Sarah Ann Dana
description: The marriage of Sarah Ann Dana, an assistant manager with Citibank in New York, to John Richard Post, a Citibank vice president, took place yesterday at the Belmont (Mass.) Country Club. Rabbi Roland Gittelsohn performed the ceremony.

title: ROCKETS OUSTED BY JAZZ
description: The Utah Jazz overcame the loss of 7-foot-4-inch Mark Eaton, who had a knee injury, and rallied to defeat the Houston Rockets, 104-97, today in the deciding game of their first-round playoff series.

title: OSHA's Health and Safety
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration - OSHA - must be at or near the top of Bill Brock's list of things to do something about as the new Secretary of Labor. But what to do?

title: BANK-BILL DRAMA NOT ENDED YET
description: After four long days of hearings, after numerous opening statements, questions and answers by witnesses and Congressmen, the House Banking Committee finally seems to have the will to pass banking legislation.

title: CHILDREN ARE TWICE BLESSED BY ARRIVAL OF TWIN DOLLS
description: See the twins. They are dolls. What are their names? Jim and Dandy. Tomax and Xamot. The Cabbage Patch Twins. The Heart Family's Boy and Girl.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;No Comparison
description: Start telling Shirley Beckwith about hitting records, and she'll start talking about batting averages. Mention hitting totals to her sister, Beverly McLaren, and she'll be off and running about hits per game. Bring up the subject with their brother, Jim, and the next thing you know he'll be trying to sell you an asterisk.

title: TO EVERY TIME THERE IS PURPOSE
description: Time is money,'' Ben Franklin told a young tradesman back in 1748.

title: Wells Fargo Truck Is Stolen
description: Five unidentified men stole an armored truck early this morning after overpowering four employees at a Wells Fargo garage at 350 West street, the police said. The vehicle was believed to contain money or other valuables, which were stored in the truck overnight, the police said. Authorities were unsure of how much was lost in the theft.

title: A Balanchine Service
description: There will be a memorial service todnight for George Balanchine, who died in 1983, at the Cathedral of the Lady of the Sign, at Park Avenue and 93d Street. The service, organized by the New York City Ballet and the School of American Ballet, begins at 7:30 P.M. and will be conducted in Russian. It is open to the public. Information: 877-7635.

title: The Sorrows of Armenia
description: Americans with their scant sense of history must be mystified by the resurgence of Armenians' anger about an atrocity that occurred 70 years ago. Impermissibly, that anger has recently been invoked by terrorists to justify the murder of Turkish diplomats. But fittingly, it also moved Armenians the world over to memorial observances last week. They plead that Turkey at least acknowledge the massacres of their ancestors and that the State Department remove the word ''alleged'' from its references to the 1915 slaughter.

title: Puerto Rico's Status Needs to Be Resolved
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE NATION;Crews Begin Cleanup After N. Carolina Fires
description: Crews from three states cleaned up today after wildfires that destroyed nearly 6,000 acres of parched coastal woodlands, and some of them began going home.

title: McEnroe Wins
description: Top-ranked John McEnroe survived 13 service aces from Paul Annacone today to capture the $375,000 World Championship Tennis-Atlanta tournament, 7-6, 7-6, 6-2.

title: Afghan Refugee Dies in Fight
description: One person was killed and several were wounded in a gunfight between two groups of Afghan refugees in the North-West Frontier Province, on the Afghan border, official sources said today. They had no immediate information about the cause of the clash Saturday at a refugee camp.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With 2 seconds to play in an N.B.A. game, Team A, trailing by a basket, prepares to inbound the ball from the midcourt line. The Team A player makes a looping throw-in toward the basket in the hope that another Team A player can outleap the defenders and direct the ball into the basket before coming down, thereby tying the score and perhaps even drawing a foul shot. However, the jumper's timing is off and the ball is thrown a mite too far, going directly into the basket. Does the basket count, and if not, is the play a do-over?

title: Harassment of Press Is Seen
description: The White House Correspondents Association asserted today that security measures set up around President Reagan are used by the White House staff to limit press access to the President.

title: AT EMBATTLED GUATEMALA COKE PLANT, PEACE REIGNS
description: When the Coca-Cola bottling plant here reopened after an extended labor-management confrontation, spontaneous soft-drink parties were held in many poor neighborhoods of Guatemala City.

title: UPSTATE VOLUNTEERS COUNT HAWKS BY THOUSANDS
description: Laura Moon swept her binoculars across a slate-gray southern sky.

title: CONCERT: MURRAY PERAHIA AT THE PIANO
description: MURRAY PERAHIA made his formal New York debut almost 20 years ago at Carnegie Recital Hall. The next day in these pages Allen Hughes noted the precision, clarity, shapely interpretations and musical vibrancy that have since become so familiar and also reported that accents and fortes were ''apt to be unduly harsh most of the time.'' Mr. Perahia's most characteristic playing in the intervening years has rarely been subject to that particular criticism, but it came to mind often Friday as he gave his first recital in the big auditorium next door. It was nevertheless music-making of a high order, and the crowded audience seemed to rejoice at the thought of having such a pianist among them and still young.

title: F.C.C. BARS PENALTY ON RACISM ON AIR
description: The Federal Communications Commission has ruled that the broadcast of programs advocating racial hatred and disregard for the Government is not ground for denying the renewal of a radio broadcast license.

title: CELTICS SINK PISTONS, 133-99
description: After the Boston Celtics had struggled to eliminate the Cleveland Cavaliers in the first round of the playoffs, their real front line reappeared today and helped overwhelm the Detroit Pistons, 133-99, at Boston Garden.

title: U.P.I. SEEKS PROTECTION ON DEBTS UNDER FEDERAL BANKRUPTCY CODE
description: United Press International, the country's second-largest news agency, filed documents today seeking protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code. A company spokesman said U.P.I. took the action in order to gain ''breathing room to reorganize and restructure,'' its troubled finances.

title: Chief's Crown Now Critics' Choice
description: FIVE days ago, Chief's Crown looked like one of at least half a dozen colts with roughly equal chances of winning the 111th Kentucky Derby next Saturday, and most of the racing world considered him a vulnerable favorite. Today, he stands alone as the strongest Derby favorite in six years and a legitimate aspirant for a sweep the Triple Crown.

title: ADVERTISING;Account
description: Gaines Foods to Benton & Bowles for Gaines-burgers, Top Choice, Puppy Choice and Prime Variety soft-moist dog foods.

title: Coast Shelter Attorney Under Fire
description: In February, Federal authorities, armed with a subpoena from a Federal District judge here, gained custody of two tons of documents that were being stored behind the Ample Hamper, a grocery store in Tortola, one of British Virgin Islands.

title: 2 ARRESTED IN ARGENTINE FIRE
description: The federal police said today that the director and another administrator of a private hospital were being held for questioning about the cause of a fire in which 79 people were killed and 247 injured.

title: BALLET THEATER: A NEW WORK BY DAVID GORDON
description: NATALIA MAKAROVA, Kevin McKenzie and the much younger soloist, Amanda McKerrow, are visibly making a special mark upon American Ballet Theater's new season, standing out even within its first week. Yet the dancing has also picked up excitingly elsewhere in the company, which presented the chief novelty of its Metropolitan Opera House engagement Saturday night - a New York premiere by the experimental modern-dance choreographer, David Gordon.

title: FARRELL AND BELLAMY, AT A FORUM, CRITICIZE MAYOR
description: Mayor Koch's major opponents in the Democratic primary criticized him rather than each other yesterday as they spoke at a candidates forum in midtown Manhattan.

title: RANCOR IS EVIDENT IN COMMEMORATIONS OF DACHAU
description: Thousands of people, many of them former inmates, attended ceremonies today marking the 40th anniversary of the liberation of the Dachau concentration camp. But the ceremonies, at the camp site outside this rural Bavarian town and in Munich, 10 miles to the south, reflected the rancor here over how to interpret the collapse of Nazi Germany and the end of World War II.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Polish Activist Loses Job After Rights Talks
description: A senior Solidarity activist who discussed human-rights issues this month with the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, has been dismissed from the Polish Academy of Sciences, opposition sources said today.

title: Smoke Bomb Hurled Into a Temple on L.I.
description: A smoke bomb was thrown into a synagogue here tonight, filling much of the building with smoke, but injuring no one, according to the Nassau County Police.

title: AUDIT CITES PENTAGON CONTRACTORS
description: In the latest Federal investigation of impropriety in the weapons business, an audit of seven major military contractors by the House Armed Services Committee, released today, has found widespread abuse of overhead charges.

title: USING INFLATABLE WHALES TO ELUCIDATE ECONOMICS
description: The problem: How to explain to the television audience how junk bonds - high-risk, high-yield securities -- are used in corporate takeover bids.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;BRONX GETS PIECE OF SILICON VALLEY
description: FEW people would confuse the South Bronx with Silicon Valley, and Rafael Collado and Ramon Morales agree that the differences are clear: for high technology, they say, the Bronx is better. Not only is it near a number of universities, but it is a subway ride from major users, such as Wall Street and publishing. ''It amazes me that this didn't become the high-tech center,'' Mr. Collado said.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Catching Up
description: The Miami Marlins' bold experiment - getting a batch of former major leaguers to play at the Class A level - hasn't gone all that well. Rain is partly to blame, but it's a fact that attendance is averaging about half last year's rate of fewer than 600 a game. And through Friday's play, the refugees from the big time stacked up this way: Mike Torrez was 2-1 with a 3.00 earned run average, Eric Rasmussen 0-1 and 4.16, Juan Eichelberger 0-1 and 4.33, and Ed Farmer 1-1 and 4.20. Jim Essian was batting .214, and Broderick Perkins was at .242 and was on the disabled list. Who's even halfway good? Derrel Thomas, at .289.

title: GOLDEN NUGGET PURSUING HILTON BID
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation's sale of its unopened Atlantic City hotel-casino to Donald Trump, the New York real estate developer, will not affect Golden Nugget Inc.'s bid for 27 percent of Hilton, Stephen A. Wynn, Golden Nugget's chairman, said yesterday.

title: CHRYSLER PROGRAM SAVES MILLIONS IN HEALTH COSTS
description: A yearlong campaign by the Chrysler Corporation against rapidly rising medical costs saved the company $58 million last year, according to Chrysler officials.

title: IN ZIMBABWE, A REMAKE OF 'SOLOMON'S MINES'
description: The ribbon of bleached dirt roads leads to great slabs of granite, which boast bushman paintings, and a film set where people talk in verbal hieroglyphics like ''561 - take 2.''

title: Yankee Scenario Is All Too Familiar
description: Billy Martin, back for his fourth term as manager of the Yankees, once was dismissed by George Steinbrenner before he was supposed to have returned. That was only one of the intriguing aspects of Martin's long and stormy relationship with the Yankees' principal owner.

title: ITT'S KEY WEST GERMAN UNIT
description: When Standard Elektrik Lorenz A.G., the West German electrical company, abandoned devastated Berlin for this trim south German city after World War II, the only space available, company officials recall, was the underground assembly plants of a defunct aircraft manufacturer.

title: Philippine Debt Accord
description: A major obstacle to an agreement for rescheduling the foreign debt of the Philippines was overcome Friday when a Saudi Arabian bank agreed to participate, an officer of one of the banks involved in the talks said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Security on First Avenue
description: Q: What costs $4,500, is eight feet long, weighs 8,000 pounds, sits on the sidewalk at 45th Street and First Avenue and is desperately in need of ivy?

title: Let the Sun Shine On
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Rare Play Seldom Makable By the Person Who Needs It
description: There is a small paradox concerning some rare plays: The player who needs them usually is not capable of making them.

title: ADVERTISING;Batten, Barton
description: Household International, of Prospect Heights, Ill., may have had a little corporate advertising in the past, but it never had an agency in charge of it. Now they have. It is Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn in Chicago, which is already serving the Thermos Company, a division. The corporate budget is $1.5 million. Household is also comprised of National Car Rental, Household Finance, Household Manufacturing and Household Merchandising. It has annual sales of about $8 billion.

title: BRIEFING;Come Back Now, Hear
description: A Washingtonian recently returned from Nicaragua reports that the Government tourist agency, Tur-nica, asked departing visitors to respond to a questionnaire. Under ''Reasons that made you decide to visit us,'' the options were:

title: For a Unified Military Medical Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: KIRKLAND URGES UNIONS TO IGNORE PLEA TO FOREGO EARLY CHOICE FOR '88
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., urged local union leaders here today to ignore a plea by the national chairman of the Democratic Party to forgo an early endorsement of a Presidential candidate in the 1988 primaries.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;7 Soldiers Are Killed In Sri Lanka Attack
description: Seven soldiers were killed today by a land mine that blew up a truck in a convoy in northern Sri Lanka, officials said.

title: ALLIED'S PLAN TO LEAVE SHOCKS SYRACUSE AREA
description: After 104 years as an institution in Onondaga County, the Allied Corporation has announced plans to dismiss 1,400 workers, dismantle its local plant and leave its industrial site here a grassy field.

title: BOWDITCH'S STREAK ENDED IN SQUASH
description: Top-seeded Jahangir Khan routed Steve Bowditch, 15-4, 15-5, 17-15, yesterday and took the $75,000 Drakkar North American Squash Open tournament for the second consecutive time.

title: RELATIONSHIPS;WHEN A WIFE IS ACHIEVER
description: SHE was being made a partner in her law firm while he was still struggling with yet another business venture that was going nowhere. She was getting a raise just as his company was turning him down. She was being promoted to vice president while he seemed permanently stuck at middle-management level.

title: TUBBS'S TITLE SHOT ENDS LONG JOURNEY
description: Not quite 10 years have passed since Tony Tubbs gave up fighting in empty parking lots in Cincinnati and dedicated himself to becoming a legitimate prizefighter.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Derby Favorites
description: It's hard to find an impartial Kentuckian come Derby time, since most of the owners, breeders, jockeys and trainers have a horse, or a friend with a horse, in the race. Among the few without a prejudice but with an opinion, sentiment runs strongly, though not universally, toward favored Chief's Crown, as a sampling taken at Keeneland suggests.

title: VIETNAMESE HIT CAMBODIA REBELS TO BAR NEW BASES BEFORE MONSOON
description: Vietnamese forces, apparently trying to prevent Cambodian guerrillas from re-establishing bases before the rainy season begins, have been attacking the guerrillas at several points along the Thai-Cambodian border in recent days.

title: Washington Watch;On Confirming Fed Nominee
description: JAKE GARN, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, has been back from outer space for several days, but there is still no indication of when the Utah Republican will call for a committee vote on President Reagan's nomination of Martha R. Seger to serve on the Federal Reserve Board.

title: THE REGION;400 Acres Burned In L.I. Pine Lands
description: A brush fire spread quickly Saturday and destroyed 400 acres of pine barrens near the former Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center here, authorities said.

title: FINALE LOSSE FOR BERRA
description: Yogi Berra went down fighting.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Campbell Soup Names U.S. Division President
