description: The Campbell Soup Company said that Herbert M. Baum, a marketing executive, had been named president of the company's American divisions.

title: Advertising;'Inday' TV Network To Jordan
description: JORDAN, CASE & McGRATH beat out five other advertising companies to become agency for the Independent Daytime Network, which will be a supplier of original daytime programming to the nation's independent TV stations.

title: 1,000 CHINESE IN POOL OF FUTURE LEADERS
description: In an effort to entrench the policies he has introduced, Deng Xiaoping, the country's pre-eminent leader, has had the Communist Party apparatus select 1,000 middle-aged officials as the core of China's future leadership.

title: EFFORTS FAIL TO APPEASE OILERS
description: When the Houston Oilers threatened the National Football League with a lawsuit over the rulings in the Bernie Kosar case, three teams began exploring ways to satisfy the Oilers and forestall legal action.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: LACK OF STUDENTS AND MONEY BESETS CALIFORNIA 2-YEAR COLLEGES
description: The California community college system, which set a standard for the nation by making free higher education accessible to virtually anyone, is bedeviled by falling enrollment, serious financial problems and what administrators describe as an identity crisis.

title: MIDDLE ATLANTIC JOURNAL;MONOPOLY, RENEWAL, ACID RAIN
description: When you say ''state store'' in Pennsylvania, everyone knows what you mean. That is where one must go to buy liquor and wine, and it has been a highly visible institution in this Commonwealth for more than half a century.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;30,000 Rioters Set Fire To an Indian Slum
description: The police opened fire today on 30,000 rioters who had set fire to a slum colony in the western state of Gujarat during protests against a Government affirmative action policy. The policy reserves a quota of Government jobs and university placements for disadvantaged castes and classes.

title: The Boys Of Winter
description: LET'S talk about the New York Islanders in the past tense. Let's say they were the best New York team of this decade, and let's say they were the most admirable team I've ever covered, and let's say their time is gone.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: He's the boss. He can do what he wants. I'm used to this.'' - Yogi Berra. [A1:2.]

title: Ellen Arky, Editor, Weds Matthew Lorenz in Jersey
description: Ellen Carol Arky, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Arky of Aberdeen, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Sharp Lorenz, a son of Lee Lorenz of Easton, Conn., and Joan Lorenz of Hamden, Conn. Rabbi Philip E. Schechter performed the ceremony at the Richfield Regency in Verona, N.J.

title: 5 DIE IN KENTUCKY IN GAS LINE BLAST
description: An explosion in a natural gas line Saturday night killed five people, gouged a 20-foot-deep crater and flattened six buildings in a tiny community about a mile east of here, the authorities said today. The blast set off fires visible 20 miles away, they said.

title: Columbia Tops Coast Guard
description: Columbia's heavyweight and lightweight crews had the most successful day of their 1985 season yesterday, defeating the United States Coast Guard Academy in four of the six races contested on the Lions' home Harlem River course.

title: The Israeli Sugared Pizza Invasion
description: You've probably heard that Japan excluded imports of American baseball bats on the pretext that Louisville Sluggers might violate Japanese ''safety standards.'' But how about the customs officials who halted imports of frozen pizzas fearing someone would extract the tiny amount of sugar they contain and sell it cheap?

title: PROSE PIECE IS ATTRIBUTED TO BYRON
description: The existence of a piece of prose fiction apparently written by the Romantic poet Lord Byron as a satirical attack on his critics was disclosed here today.

title: Mets Outlast Pirates in 18th on Error, 5-4
description: It was Super Sundae yesterday at Shea Stadium, and in an 18-inning game with all the fixings, topped off by a tie for first place, the Mets defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-4, although outhit, 18 to 6.

title: RECITAL: ANDREI GAVRILOV IN NEW YORK DEBUT
description: THERE are debuts, and then there are debuts. Andrei Gavrilov's recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall happened to be his first appearance in New York, but his performance of an all-Chopin program was anything but that of a fledgling. No one in the audience could have been surprised, however, since the Soviet pianist has been a familiar name on the international concert circuit and on recordings for a decade now, ever since he won the Tchaikovsky competition in Moscow in 1974 at age 18.

title: Required Reading;Freedom and Art
description: Excerpts from a speech by President Reagan on Tuesday, when he presented the National Medal of Arts:

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;STORMS OVER FRANCE
description: The French Assembly, where Socialists have an absolute majority thanks to the old election law of one representative per district, has just changed the rules. Legislative elections due next spring will be by proportional representation in each of the 95 departments.

title: NOW FOCUSES ON PAY EQUITY FOR WOMEN
description: Elizabeth Holtzman recalled that when she became Brooklyn District Attorney three years ago, she found ''not one single woman in a position of authority'' in the District Attorney's office.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about recent West German television programs dealing with the Nazi era incorrectly described a mini-series, ''The War of the Bombers.'' The series did mention the Luftwaffe's bombing of London in 1940.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Arlington, Tex. Opener of a three-game series and first meeting of season with Rangers. (Television - SportsChannel, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8:30 P.M.) Boxing Greg Page, champion, vs. Tony Tubbs; James Broad, champion, vs. Tim Witherspoon; Hector (Macho) Camacho vs. Roque Montoya, at Buffalo. Page and Tubbs are scheduled for 15 rounds for the World Boxing Association heavyweight championship, Broad and Witherspoon, 12 rounds, for the North American Boxing Federation heavyweight title and Camacho and Montoya ,12 rounds, for vacant N.A.B.F. lightweight title he won from South Africa's Gerrie Coetzee last Dec. 1. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M.) Football Generals vs. Orlando Renegades, at Giants Stadium, 7 P.M. The Generals are unbeaten in four games at home this season and beat the last-place Renegades, 28-10, in the second week of the season. The Generals won third straight last week, and the Renegades had their two-game winning streak broken in 31-10 loss to Jacksonville. (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 7 P.M.) Other Events HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight). THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 1 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:30 and 11 P.M.). Garden State, 8 P.M. TRACK AND FIELD: Collegiate Track Conference Decathlon, at United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I., 1 P.M.

title: GENERALS FIND AN ARTFUL BLEND
description: The Generals play the Orlando Renegades tonight at Giants Stadium, and Coach Walt Michaels's plan will be to do more of the same. That means Doug Flutie handing the ball to Herschel Walker, a formula that has served the Generals well recently.

title: TEXTUAL SCHOLARS MAKE POINTS ABOUT POINTS IN BOOKS
description: The point of contention was the size of the period at the end of the 17th chapter of James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' - whether it should be just a little bigger than a . or more like a

title: Futures/Options;Index Trading Requires Study
description: TRADERS in stock index futures and options were again taken on a wild roller coaster last week, as the market in terms of the Dow Jones industrial average closed unchanged Monday, then soared 12.15 points, dipped 0.22, jumped 6.29 and on Friday plunged 9.80 points, to finish at 1,275.18.

title: REAGAN'S SON VISITS SOVIET FOR MAY DAY
description: Ronald P. Reagan, son of the President, arrived in Moscow today with his wife and two friends for what he said was a private visit that would include the May Day parade in Red Square.

title: Patricia Dean Is Wed To David F. Schreiber
description: Patricia Susan Dean, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Dean of Ferguson, Mo., was married yesterday to David Franklin Schreiber. Rabbi Edward Feld performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Schreiber, parents of the bridegroom, in New City, N.Y.

title: SHUTTLE IS POISED FOR LIFTOFF TODAY IN SCIENCE MISSION
description: A pair of chattering monkeys and two dozen squeaking rats were put aboard the Challenger today in preparation for a seven-day scientific mission. They are to share the space shuttle with a crew of seven astronauts.

title: ADVERTISING;Paula Green Regains Cardio-Fitness Account
description: Winning accounts is the thrill of the advertising business. Winning back accounts that had been previously lost is an even bigger thill.

title: Lucas, Duralith
description: Lucas Industries said Friday that it was offering to acquire the Duralith Corporation of Millville, N.J., for $24 million. The offer, $20 a share, is subject to approval by Duralith shareholders, who are expected to vote within two months. Duralith makes graphic control panel assemblies.

title: Louis Russek, 89, Dies; Founder of Health-tex
description: Louis Russek, the founder and former chairman of Health-tex, one of the largest manufacturers of infants' and children's clothing, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 years old.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;Against Railroad Re-regulation
description: To bolster its case before Congress against re-regulation of railroad rates and services, the Association of American Railroads will this week release a brief ''Economists' Statement in Support of the Staggers Act.'' The Staggers Act is the 1980 law that put the wheels of deregulation into motion.

title: A FORMER HUDSON RIVER PORT TO CELEBRATE ITS BICENTENNIAL
description: In 1783, four Quakers from New England seaports came up the Hudson River in search of a haven for their whaling ships, which had suffered attacks by the British during the Revolutionary War.

title: MACHINE TOOL INDUSTRY REPORTS GAINS FOR MARCH
description: The machine tool industry, continuing a gradual comeback from several disastrous years, reported healthy gains in new orders and shipments in March.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map in Science Times on April 16 with an article about earthquakes incorrectly placed Los Angeles. The city is about 90 miles southeast of the position shown.

title: AVON BOOKS TO PUBLISH HARD-COVERS NEXT YEAR
description: Avon Books, a major publisher of paperback books, will publish hardcover books also beginning next spring. Although it plans only about a dozen hard-covers a year, including several titles from its backlist, Avon's decision is the latest example of the blurring of lines between traditional hard-cover and mass market paperback publishers.

title: NEWS STORY INSPIRED BANKS'S 'DRIFT'
description: Russell Banks was at work on a historical novel about Franklin Pierce and Nathaniel Hawthorne when he read a newspaper clipping that altered his course. The article, which appeared in October 1981, was an account of a tragedy involving the Coast Guard, a smuggler and a boatload of Haitians off the Palm Beach, Fla., coastline.

title: David S. Ingalls, an Executive
description: David S. Ingalls, a former Navy pilot, lawyer, business executive and politician, died Friday at the age of 86.

title: KOHL IS REPORTED FIRM ON BITBURG AMID WARNINGS ON U.S. RELATIONS
description: The controversy over President Reagan's impending visit to a German military cemetery in Bitburg sharpened today, but Chancellor Helmut Kohl was reported determined that the visit would go ahead.

title: Market Place;Low Multiples And Little Debt
description: SCOTT M. BLACK is a Boston-based money manager who marches - quite successfully - to a different drummer than most of the Wall Street parade. His investment in CBS Inc. serves as an example.

title: PILOTS PLANNING TO FORM UNION FOR CONTROLLERS
description: Leaders of the Air Line Pilots Association, which refused to honor picket lines when air-traffic controllers struck illegally four years ago, are now moving to organize controllers into an affiliated union.

title: OUTDOORS: ON LAKE ONTARIO FOR FLY FISHING
description: LEAPING and twisting out of the dark water five times, the silvery steelhead that took my Mickey Finn fly was quickly subdued and brought to the net.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOMETHING TO REMEMBER There's no library business like the show business that is the specialty of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue at 65th Street (870-1600). In its several exhibition areas, there is almost always something to catch the eye.

title: DETROIT EMBARKS ON THE GREENING OF ITS RIVERFRONT
description: In the early 1700's a French immigrant named Charles Chene tilled the fields of a ''ribbon farm,'' a narrow strip of land extending from the banks of the Detroit River into what is now the city's east side.

title: TEEN-AGE DEBATERS RESOLVE WHO'S BEST IN NEW YORK STATE
description: Note from the outset that the team of Holly Raider and Christopher Janak came in first, and the team of Mark Brisman and his twin sister, Michelle, came in close to last.

title: Pickens Bid To Continue
description: T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company. will continue to seek proxies from shareholders of the Unocal Corporation to have Unocal's meeting adjourned another 60 days, even though a Federal judge on Friday postponed the meeting until May 13, an executive close to Mr. Pickens said yesterday.

title: MIAMI EMPIRE BUILDER COPES WITH E.S.M. FALL
description: Szmuel Bobrowice, a 14-year-old Pole, was hardly off the ship that carried him to Canada 65 years ago when he made a splash. The Montreal Daily Star - giving publicity to a group that aided Jewish immigrants - carried a prominent article on July 30, 1920, describing the round-faced, Yiddish-speaking orphan as full of bright prospects.

title: Mark D. Dissin, Producer, Married to Lena B. Olsson
description: Lena Birgitta Olsson, a personal assistant to the chief of protocol of the United Nations, was married yesterday to Mark David Dissin, a senior producer at W.&W. Films in New York. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: 2 City Parks Restrict Vehicles for Summer
description: Starting today and lasting through October, several roadways in Central and Prospect Parks will be closed during weekday hours for sumertime use by pedestrians and bikers.

title: Hammermill Pact
description: The Hammermill Paper Company said Friday that it had reached an agreement in principle to buy the Nicolet Paper Company from Philip Morris Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash. Nicolet makes glassine and greaseproof papers, and its sales in 1984 exceeded $60 million. Earlier last week, Philip Morris sold two other industrial subsidiaries to the Chesapeake Corporation.

title: ESSAY;FREE SPEECH V. SCALIA
description: If you were a lawyer and wanted to become the next Chief Justice of the United States, what cause would you embrace, or philosophy would you expound, to ingratiate yourself with Ronald Reagan?

title: AMERICA'S OBJECTIVE IN GENEVA
description: The Soviet Union seems determined to prevent American research on strategic defense - research that the Russians themselves have long been conducting. In fact, the United States' immediate goal at the arms control talks in Geneva is to reach agreement on deep reductions of all nuclear arms in a way that strengthens deterrence and enhances stability. But our strategic defense research is a crucial part of that effort.

title: Widow of Columnist Dies
description: Maybelle McIntyre, widow of the newspaper columnist O. O. McIntyre, died Saturday at a nursing home in Point Pleasant, W. Va. She was 101 years old and had lived in nearby Gallipolis since leaving New York 15 years ago.

title: Sidney Lurie, 74, Dies; Stock Market Analyst
description: Sidney B. Lurie, a financial analyst and executive vice president of Josephthal & Company, died of cancer last Wednesday at his home in Sands Point, L.I. He was 74 years old.

title: Gayle Grass and Dr. Jay Fishman Wed
description: Gayle Anne Grass, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Grass of Madbury, N.H., was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to Dr. Jay Alan Fishman, a son of Dr. Alfred P. Fishman of Philadelphia and the late Florence H. Fishman. Rabbi Albert Ginsberg performed the ceremony in the Memorial Church at Harvard University. He was assisted by the Rev. Gerald Osterman, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Population Reversal And Energy Demand
description: To the Editor:

title: 76ERS START FAST AND TOPPLE BUCKS IN OPENER, 127-105
description: A primary strength of the Philadelphia 76ers has always been the ability to ''turn it on'' when they have to, particularly late in the game. In the opener of their Eastern Conference semifinal playoff against the Milwaukee Bucks today, they turned it on at the tip-off, and kept it on.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Animal Rights Group Fights Baboon Research
description: The Pennsylvania Animal Rights Coalition has repeated its call for an end to experiments on baboons in research at the University of Pennsylvania on head injuries.

title: WORKING PROFILE: HOWARD H. BAKER JR.;EX-G.O.P. LEADER FINDS THER'S LIFE AFTER SENATE
description: His letterhead proclaims ''Senator Howard Baker.'' His telephone is answered ''Senator Howard Baker.'' He is still served by a secretary and a chauffeur who worked for him in the Senate. His Senate political action committee remains active, and he meets regularly with a coterie of former aides, who have formed a political consulting firm just across the street.

title: BASEBALL;DODGERS' VALENZUELA SETS MARK IN LOSS
description: Tony Gwynn hit a one-out home run in the top of the ninth inning to give the San Diego Padres a 1-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

title: THE REGION;Boy Touches Wire With Pole and Dies
description: A 13-year-old Long Island boy was electrocuted while climbing a tree when the metal pole he was holding touched a high-tension wire, the Nassau County police said today.

title: THE POLITICS OF PARANOIA
description: A few days before the votes in Congress on President Reagan's plan to aid the Nicaraguan rebels, I testified at a Congressional hearing on their human rights practices. It was an ugly occasion, perhaps the ugliest of the scores of such hearings I have witnessed. It seemed to me to say something about the political climate today and, more troublingly, about the nature of American public life.

title: BRIEFING;New Old Gold Cup
description: The Virginia Gold Cup is one of the principal sporting (steeplechase) and social (high-tea tailgating) events of the spring season. The race will be run for the 60th time Saturday in the hunt country west of the capital, but this year it will have both a new site and a new trophy, which is actually 85 years old.

title: 2 Million in U.S. Grants Going to Visual Arts
description: The National Endowment for the Arts plans to announce 144 grants totaling almost $2 million to visual arts organizations on Monday.

title: GIANTS' PRIORITIES ARE RECEIVER AND END
description: WITH all their problems with a stagnant running game last season, the Giants appeared sure to choose a halfback in the first round of tomorrow's National Football League draft. Then the auto accident that will probably wipe out Kevin Belcher's season seemed to change their priorities, because they needed a center.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Nigeria Imposes Curfew To End Religious Riots
description: A dusk-to-dawn curfew has been imposed on the northern Nigerian town of Gombe, where more than 100 people have died in religious riots, an official statement said today.

title: SOUTH AFRICA MINE IN 'STATE OF SIEGE'
description: A prominent black labor leader accused the police today of using tear gas to dislodge thousands of black miners from their hostels after their dismissal Saturday at the world's biggest gold mine.

title: MEETING CRUCIAL TO U.S.F.L. FUTURE
description: Although the agenda for today's meeting calls only for affirmation of their decision last August to play in the autumn rather than the spring, the owners of the United States Football League's teams have other pressing matters to discuss.

title: CAMBODIA ISSUE AGAIN FLARES IN U.S.
description: Ten years after the United States withdrew from Phnom Penh and the Khmer Rouge Communists marched into the city, the issue of what Americans should do about Cambodia is again a matter of political dispute.

title: Software Counterfeiter
description: A Taiwan business executive was sentenced Friday to a year in prison and fined $1,500 for counterfeiting computer software that had been copyrighted by the International Business Machines Corporation. The Taipei District Court convicted Tsai Tun-yi, 27 years old, manager of the Data Sources Company, after the Government-financed Electronic Research and Service Organization reported that an operation system manufactured by the local company was 98.5 percent similar to I.B.M.'s.

title: Free Market Missing In Treasury Tax Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;An Enchanting Kingdom
description: You can tell right away from the look on their faces,'' said Leslie Pansarasa, a park ranger whose post is the roof of Belvedere Castle.

title: What 'Intrapreneurs' Expect and Accept
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CAPTAIN MAXIMUS. Stories by Barry Hannah. 101 pages. Knopf. $11.95. NOWHERE. By Thomas Berger. 190 pages. Delacorte/Seymour Lawrence. $14.95. IN ''Captain Maximus,'' Barry Hannah seems to be calming down a little. ''I went to a bar in Dallas before the great ride over the desert that I intended,'' writes one of his personae, Ned Maximus (''but they call me Maximum Ned''), in the story ''Ride, Fly, Penetrate, Loiter.''

title: BRIEFING;Duck!
description: A wide, deep and continuous stream of paper floods through the office of the average member of Congress, and it takes something a little unusual to catch the attention of a senior staff member, much less an actual Senator or Representative. With this perhaps in mind, the Navy's Report to Congress for the fiscal year 1986, now circulating on Capitol Hill, has worked up an effective way to dramatize its claims of ''very high accuracy'' for the 16-inch guns on its battleships.

title: WOUNDED' BY BITBURG CRITICISM, REAGAN PRESSES AHEAD WITH VISIT
description: President Reagan has been ''upset'' and ''wounded'' by criticism of the visit he plans next Sunday to a German military cemetery, the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, said today.

title: ISLANDERS IN EARLY DEMISE
description: The end came quicker than last year. But for the Islanders, now two years removed from their dynasty days, the finish was again something beyond their understanding.

title: British Deficit Wider
description: Britain's foreign trade deficit widened in March, but a surplus in services transactions erased half of the merchandise deficit, the Department of Trade and Industry said Friday. Britain's trade deficit increased to L900 million, or about $1.1 billion, last month, from a deficit of L259 million in March 1984. The surplus in services trade resulted in a current account deficit of L456 million, or about $547 million, compared with a surplus of L32 million a year ago.

title: Price Strain Between Auto Makers and Dealers
description: To the Editor:

title: MARTIN REHIRED TO MANAGE YANKS
description: George Steinbrenner, who said two months ago that Yogi Berra would be the Yankees' manager for the entire 1985 season no matter what, dismissed Berra today, just 16 games into the season, and brought back Billy Martin for his fourth term.

title: BRIEFING;This One's No Actor
description: Former President Jimmy Carter is appearing in a television spot in Georgia to show there is a field in which he is not competent. It is not politics or government but theater, and Mr. Carter recites ''Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears'' with less than dramatic persuasiveness by all accounts. The spot is one of four to raise funds for the Alliance Theater in Atlanta, all arranged ''to have the acting done poorly to convey the message that acting should be left to the professionals,'' a local promoter explained.

title: Connors Defeats Noah in Final
description: Jimmy Connors defeated Yannick Noah, 6-4, 6-4, in the final of the Bank of Oklahoma Tennis Classic today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Action Graphics Inc., a graphic arts supplier based in Hackensack, N.J., has appointed Allen J. Merganthaler executive vice president.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET OFFERS 'LA VALSE'
description: THE NEW YORK CITY BALLET offered a glittering, effervescent day of dancing on Saturday at the New York State Theater. Some of it was familiar and expected, but some debuts added to the luster.

title: DECANTER IS AUCTIONED
description: An 1816 cut-glass decanter made for Dolly and James Madison was purchased yesterday at a Washington auction as a gift to be presented to the White House.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Economist Newspaper Unit Head
description: After a year-long search, The Economist Newspaper Ltd., publisher of the influential weekly magazine, The Economist, announced that Marjorie M. Scardino, a publisher and a lawyer, had been named president of its fast-growing American subsidiary, The Economist Newspaper Group Inc. The appointment is effective June 3.

title: The Worm and the Apple;Cleaner Sweeps
description: New York's alternate-side-of-the-street parking rules are designed to clear the curbs for the Sanitation Department's big mechanical brooms. Yet dodging of the rules, a way of life in many city neighborhoods, routinely prevents a clean sweep. The department and the Bureau of Traffic Operations deserve apples for a rescue effort.

title: JEWISH SEMINARY STARTS DRIVE TO ENDOW SCHOLARLY WORKS
description: The Jewish Theological Seminary of America, which will celebrate its centennial next year, announced yesterday that it was beginning a $25 million fund-raising drive to finance a planned Center for European Jewry and other scholarly programs.

title: WEST EUROPE LIKES REAGAN, BITBURG ASIDE
description: President Reagan's standing and popularity among West Europeans - apart from the aura of blunder and insensitivity surrounding the Bitburg cemetery visit - seem, on the evidence of polls and interviews, to have strengthened moderately over the past year.

title: U.S. BUSINESS LOANS TO SOUTH AFRICA SOAR
description: While most of America's leading banks have stopped lending money to the South African Government or its agencies, the banks' lending to South Africa's private sector - and especially to South African banks - has snowballed.

title: WASTE DUMPS FACE POSSIBLE CLOSINGS
description: Many of the nation's active toxic waste dumps may be forced to close this fall because they will not be able to meet requirements for monitoring the contamination of underground water.

title: SPAIN SEEKS TALKS TO CUT U.S. FORCES
description: Spain's Foreign Minister said in an interview published here today that Madrid would demand a cut in the more than 12,000 United States troops stationed here.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 29, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Subcommittee on Petitions, Information and Assistance - 10:30 A.M.

title: ADVERTISING;4 Agencies in Running For Amoco Oil Account
description: The Amoco Oil Company, which has been reviewing its longtime relationship with D'Arcy MacManus Masius in Chicago, has placed that activity on hold at the request of D'Arcy, according to an industry source.

title: FOURTH TIME AROUND, MARTIN WILL STRESS DISCIPLINE
description: Billy Martin, reclaiming the job that has perhaps the most visibility and the least security in baseball, said last night that he expected to manage the Yankees ''for a couple years,'' then move into the front office after training his successor.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Honor From a Hospital
description: The Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University got a new name yesterday - it is now the Jack D. Weiler Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University.

title: CLIFF ROBERTSON IN 'THE KEY TO REBECCA,' A TWO-PART MOVIE
description: THE KEY TO REBECCA'' is reasonably civilized and moderately entertaining, a good deal short of compelling, but never quite becoming tedious. Cliff Robertson, as a British officer, pursues David Soul, as a Nazi spy, through the alleys and cafes of Cairo. Field Marshall Rommel frets in the desert. The four-hour, two-part movie begins on WPIX, Channel 11, at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: SAD SWITCH FOR YANKS
description: DURING the days last week when George Steinbrenner began sighting Yogi Berra on the crosshairs of his sniper's rifle, one of the Yankee players was asked what he thought about the possibility of Billy Martin returning as the Yankee manager for the fourth time.

title: NEWS SUMMARY MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1985
description: International

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Chairman Elected At Aubrey Lanston
description: Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, the Government securities brokerage house, announced that John B. Ford has been elected chairman and chief executive.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Judge Orders Schools To Allow Religious Club
description: Federal District Judge Norman Black has ordered two high schools to allow students to conduct meetings of a ''Christian club'' on school property.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, APRIL 29, 1985 Companies Some U.S. companies in South Africa are scaling back operations. They cite declining profitability, but analysts say protests against apartheid are also having an impact. [Page A1.] While most leading U.S. banks no longer lend to the South African Government, lending to the private sector has snowballed. [D8.] A House audit of military contractors has turned up instances in which the Government was billed for such things as sports tickets and executive haircuts. [D1.] Golden Nugget's bid for 27 percent of Hilton is still on, despite Hilton's sale Saturday of its unopened Atlantic City hotel-casino to Donald Trump for more than $300 million. [D5.] A San Francisco attorney is again under fire for tax shelters that Federal authorities say he fraudulently set up for clients. As part of its investigation, Federal agents are going through two tons of offshore tax records that could have an impact on 5,000 tax cases involving more than $100 million in taxes. [D7.] Dissident Storer shareholders were barred by a Connecticut judge from taking action that might disrupt Storer's three Connecticut cable television subsidiaries. [D5.] The Economy The Federal Reserve is unlikely to relax monetary policy, despite the slowdown in economic growth, falling productivity and instability among some savings institutions. Top central bankers say they do not think the economy needs much stimulation, especially since signs of higher inflation have emerged. [D1.] Interstate banking legislation will probably be passed by the House banking committee by June. But the two bills being considered might not satisfy everyone. [D1.] Machine tool orders increased 17.6 percent during March. Analysts said that volume was still weak, however. [D6.] Today's Columns The Senate has still not acted on Martha R. Seger's nomination to the Federal Reserve Board, although she has been serving since last July. Washington Watch. [D2.] Index traders could avoid the market's roller coaster action by studying the relationship between the S.&P. 500 and the broader Value Line survey, an analyst says. Futures/Options. [D4.] Delphi Management seems to find bargain stocks that others are avoiding. Market Place. [D6.] Higher interest rates last week dampened hopes of an easier monetary policy. Analysts say the market needs some good news to attract investors. Credit Market. [D7.]

title: HASTINGS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GALILEO ELECTRO-OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ASTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bail Is Denied In Trooper Killing
description: Thomas W. Manning, who is charged with the 1981 slaying of a New Jersey state trooper, was ordered held without bail today while he awaits extradition to New Jersey.

title: ARTEL COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
G.O.P. PLANS A SHOWDOWN TODAY ON DISPUTED INDIANA HOUSE SEAT
description: Republicans vowed today to force a showdown Tuesday on the disputed Indiana House race and said they would bring Congressional business to a halt if they lost.

title: PAGE LOSES TITLE TO TUBBS
description: Critics of Greg Page - and some admirers as well - have said that the 26-year-old boxer needed something, perhaps a bolt of lighting, to permanently free him from the notion that he was going to be the next Muhammad Ali.

title: JUSTICES BAR JURY INSTRUCTION ON PRESUMING INTENT
description: A sharply divided Supreme Court ruled today that jurors may not be instructed to presume that a criminal defendant has intended the ''natural and probable consequences of his acts.'' The Court said such an instruction was unconstitutional even if the jury was also told that the presumption of intent can be outweighed by the evidence.

title: ACADEMY OF SCIENCES ELECTS 60 MEMBERS
description: The National Academy of Sciences, the nation's most distinguished organization of scientists and engineers, has elected 60 new members, the academy announced last week at its annual meeting here.

title: 3 Associates of Walesa Are Reported Arrested
description: Three associates of Lech Walesa were reportedly arrested today after joining in calls for May Day protests against price increases and the detention of political prisoners.

title: GRAPHIC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AFTER 16 YEARS, MONKEYS ARE BACK IN SPACE
description: FOR the first time in 16 years monkeys are flying aboard an American space mission, and cages for experimental animals seem likely to become permanent fixtures aboard the shuttle.

title: Benign Trickery on Social Security
description: Federal spending needs to be reduced, and it makes sense that some of the burden fall on older Americans able to bear it. That's why we support President Reagan's proposal to limit cost-of-living increases for Social Security. But make no mistake. The plan is more clever than wise, justifiable only as a means to a desirable end. The need for trickery when it comes to Social Security is a depressing commentary on how little the public understands about the subject.

title: HIDDEN WAVES TRACED IN STRAIT OF GIBRALTER
description: SPACE photography has made it evident that many areas of the world's oceans are affected by internal waves that do not appear to any large extent on the surface.

title: BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $397,000,000 from a cumulative adjustment of domestic international sales corporation income.

title: HEMOTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CITY RESTUDIES PARK USE AFTER THEFTS
description: Parks Department officials said yesterday that they were reformulating ground rules for use of Central Park after learning that many of the youths who robbed participants in Sunday's March of Dimes walkathon apparently went there in the mistaken belief that a rock band would be playing.

title: Judge Rules State Farm Discriminates in Hiring
description: A Federal district judge today decided that the State Farm Insurance Comany discriminated against women in California, saying the company excluded them from potentially lucrative jobs as agents.

title: ASTRONAUTS LAUNCH ONE SATELLITE, BUT THEY FAIL TO DEPLOY A SECOND
description: Seven astronauts rocketed into orbit aboard the shuttle Challenger today to devote a week of scientific inquiry to the mysteries of both inner man and outer space.

title: Guilty Plea Is Entered In Coast Brink's Case
description: A former employee of Brink's Inc. pleaded guilty in Federal court here today to charges that he provided information to leaders of an anti-Semitic extremist group that led to the $3.6 million armed robbery of a Brink's truck last July 19 near Ukiah, Calif.

title: Justices Overrule Donovan Over Grand Jury Documents
description: Former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, who faces larceny and fraud charges, lost a Supreme Court appeal today that was aimed at forcing New York prosecutors to surrender Federal grand jury records of a related investigation.

title: ISRAELIS GONE, SHIITES TRY TO KEEP P.L.O. OUT
description: Within hours of the departure of Israeli troops from the port of Tyre in southern Lebanon today, Shiite militiamen set up checkpoints at the approaches of three Palestinian refugee camps, apparently in an effort to head off the return of guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: BIOSENSOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SOCIAL WORKERS VAULT INTO A LEADING ROLE IN PSYCHOTHERAPY
description: A QUIET revolution is going on in psychotherapy. As a result, by far the largest portion of the nation's therapy is now done by nonmedical professionals.

title: ANDREW CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Killed and 35 Hurt In Clashes in India
description: Two people were stabbed to death today in fighting between rival ethnic groups, and 35 people were hurt in a separate clash between policemen and protesters, the Press Trust of India said.

title: BRIGGS & STRATTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GULF APPLIED TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results include a realized gain of $671,000 from asset sales and a tax credit of $302,000.

title: ARDEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $5,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $331,000.

title: Rogers Looks to Astros
description: Steve Rogers, the veteran pitcher for the Montreal Expos, could be headed for the Houston Astros if some ''problems'' can be worked out, according to his agent, Dick Moss. ''There are discussions going on with the Houston Astros,'' Moss said.

title: Happy Landings
description: Lurks there the child in us who has not wanted to drop eggs from some high place onto the pavement below? Well, youngsters from the fourth grade of Public School 41 got that chance yesterday, as they dropped eggs 30 feet from the tallest turret of Belvedere Castle.

title: CHROMALLOY AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss which is after a loss of $264,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are restated to reclassify certain businesses to discontinued operations and to consolidate Chromalloy Finance Corp.

title: Canada Topples U.S. in Hockey
description: John Anderson, Mario Lemieux and Doug Lidster scored goals, lifting Team Canada to a 3-2 victory over the United States in the first medal-round game at the World Hockey Championships today.

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: HANDSOME is as handsome does. So when Estee Lauder had a luncheon yesterday for 100 of the handsomest men in New York, the list included Norman Parkinson, Arnold Scaasi, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr., Spencer Haywood, Alexis Gregory, Jerome Zipkin, Harrison J. Goldin, Francis Kellogg, Gil Shiva, Osborn Elliott and Ahmet Ertegun.

title: EQUIPMENT CO OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $75,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $55,000.

title: Turner to Show S.E.C. Football
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. and the Southeastern Conference announced today a two-year agreement providing for the telecast of 12 to 14 football games a year in 1985 and 1986.

title: NO. 3 ON POLICE FORCE RETIRING AMID TORTURE CASE
description: The abrupt retirement of the commander of all uniformed officers in the New York City Police Department will be announced today in a continuing shake-up stemming from charges that suspects were tortured at a station house, police officials said yesterday.

title: On the Sly
description: The St. Louis Cardinals have already stolen 36 bases this season, a pace that has them on track to shatter easily the National League record of 260, set in 1977 by Pittsburgh.

title: That Baldrige Trip
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W.

title: BUCKHORN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $222,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $814,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ANDERSON GREENWOOD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $184,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Water Savers
description: Before the water emergency was even a week old, parched patches were already growing downtown and uptown.

title: ENERTEC CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,757,000 on the conversion of certain debentures of the company's Energy Resources Corp. unit into preferred stock, and a charge of $6,775,000 from additional depreciation, depletion, and amortization resulting from writedowns of both producing and non-producing oil and gas properties. c-After a charge of $2,762,000 from additional depreciation, depletion, and amortization resulting from writedowns of both producing and non-producing oil and gas properties.

title: PREJUDICE AGAINST VON BULOW DENIED BY MAID
description: Martha von Bulow's maid, Maria Schrallhammer, strongly rejected a defense suggestion today that she was prejudiced against Claus von Bulow for breaking up what she called a ''beautiful, fairy-tale'' first marriage between her employer and Prince Alfred von Auersperg.

title: CAMACHO WINS 12-ROUND DECISION
description: The easy three-round evening Hector (Macho) Camacho predicted for himself turned into a grueling 12 rounds tonight as the flashy lightweight scored a unanimous decision over Roque Montoya to win the North American Boxing Federation lightweight championship.

title: COMPONENT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for 15wk to April 14
'HELLO, SWEETHEART, GET ME THE PEPTO-BISMOL'
description: What with all the eggs and bacon, quiche and chicken salad that journalists, political officials and lobbyists must consume in a week in order to gather, trade or disclose information, even the gourmand must occasionally pale at the thought of another ''working'' breakfast or lunch.

title: GENRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOUR LATE RUNNERS CAPABLE OF AN UPSET
description: ''Whoever beats Chief's Crown gets the money on Saturday,'' Woody Stephens was saying this morning, ''and I don't know that my colt can do it. Maybe he's just running for second. Maybe everyone is.'' Stephens, who will saddle Stephan's Odyssey in the 111th Kentucky Derby here Saturday, trained last year's Derby winner, Swale, and says he cashed a good bet on him, too, at 3 to 1. This year, though, he says he wouldn't bet against Chief's Crown, even with Confederate money.

title: PREVENTIVE TREATMENT FOR POLICE BRUTALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH PLAINS OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NAVY PLANS TO REDUCE TIME CARRIERS ARE OVERSEAS
description: The Navy plans to cut the time aircraft carriers, the most visible sign of American naval power, sail in foreign waters in an effort to reduce the strain on the large crews and to save money, according to Defense Department and Congressional officials.

title: Violent Weather in Texas Has Caused 10 Deaths
description: An outburst of violent weather that has caused 10 deaths battered parts of Texas again today.

title: ELSINORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. The company said results of the Atlantis Casino Hotel are reported on a consolidated basis for the latest quarter but not for the year-ago quarter.

title: HANNAFORD BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MODEMS: HOW MUCH SPEED MAKES SENSE?
description: AFTER several years of fanfare from the personal computer industry, modems are finally coming into their own. But at the very moment when personal computer usage seems to be extending beyond the office environment, where those who use the machines usually have a knowledgeable compatriot to turn to when they need help, all the rules of the telecommunications game are changing.

title: BODY FOUND IN LOT BEHIND SYNAGOGUE
description: The body of a young woman was discovered in a vacant lot behind a synagogue in the Carnarsie section of Brooklyn yesterday by children playing there in the grass, police said.

title: ISLANDERS REFLECT ON SEASON
description: From the steaminess of the dressing room, where the feeling of losing had begun to sink in, the Islanders walked down the circular white concrete hallway and through some mirrored doors that showed them in a row - Bossy, Gillies, Nystrom, their bags slung over their shoulders.

title: BONRAY DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $9,019,000 from a writedown of drilling equipment.

title: Preventive Treatment for Police Brutality
description: To the Editor:

title: GREAT SOUTHERN FEDERAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MEXICO DRUG ARRESTS: 'TIP OF ICEBERG'
description: While encouraged by recent progress in rooting out drug-related corruption here, Mexican and United States officials are concerned over indications that it may reach to higher levels of the Mexican Government than first thought.

title: ELECTRONIC ASSOCIATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $2,431,000 for the settlement of a contract dispute.

title: Special Bargain for Special Ed
description: The New York City school system's special education program was designed to help mentally, physically or emotionally handicapped children who can't cope in regular classrooms. Yet the program seems misused, at enormous expense, as it enrolls more and more children who are not seriously impaired. A mayoral commission now proposes ways to contain the costs and rationalize the program at relatively modest cost. Its report deserves close scrutiny.

title: GILBERT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COCHRANE FURNITURE CO reports earnings for 14wks to March 2
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: RED GROOMS. By Carter Ratcliff. 252 pages. Illustrated. Abbeville. $85. RED GROOMS began as he meant to go on. The earliest work by the creator of ''Ruckus Manhattan'' reproduced in Carter Ratcliff's monograph on him is a colored pencil drawing called ''Brawl at the State Fair,'' signed but not dated, which the artist thinks he must have drawn in 1950, when he was 13. It is a gaudy and accomplished picture in which a sailor and a tough-looking type have begun trading blows, while a crowd bustles around; people, booths, tents, fairground contraptions are all rendered in the same bright colors, and though the sailor has already given his adversary a bloody nose it is excitement, not anger, that the picture conveys. Amid the other attractions the brawl is simply one more sideshow.

title: FLYER GOAL COPIED FROM ISLANDERS
description: Perhaps the play was offside.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SWIMSUITS AND COLLARS New York is the nation's fashion and garment center and it is only fitting, a word you may apply as you wish, that the Fashion Institute of Technology should have a sumptuous gallery in which to review what Americans wear and have been wearing. The gallery, one flight down in the Shirley Goodman Resource Center, 227 West 27th Street at Seventh Avenue, has a definitely sporty air about it these days.

title: 'THEY JUST FIRED YOUR DAD'
description: In the Yankee clubhouse at Comiskey Park late Sunday afternoon, Dale Berra was drying himself with a towel as he strolled out of the shower room. But moments later, his serenity was shattered when he saw Don Baylor suddenly and angrily spill a trash can all over the floor. ''What's that all about?'' Dale Berra said. ''They just fired your dad,'' Don Mattingly said.

title: JET SIGHTS ON DEFENSE
description: On the eve of the National Football League draft, the Giants announced yesterday they had negotiated a multiyear extension of the contract of Bill Parcells, their head coach. This will be the last year of Parcells's original three-year contract.

title: NICARAGUAN, IN MOSCOW, IS PROMISED AID
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua met today with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, who promised continued economic aid for ''friendly Nicaragua.''

title: PLAN FOR A UNIVERSITY PANEL EASES RACIAL TENSIONS AT BROWN
description: After weeks of protest and uneasiness, Brown University administrators have agreed to establish a committee to recommend ways to improve life on campus for blacks and members of other minority groups.

title: NEW MATH CURRICULUM COMES UNDER ATTACK
description: SINCE the turn of the century, students entering New York State high schools have found themselves face to face with daunting obstacles: the basic building blocks of math.

title: 'BRAVE LITTLE GIRL' HONORED
description: Raimie Finn, a 12-year-old who died trying to help a schoolmate escape a bus stalled in a train's path, was among 15 people honored today by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission.

title: CHANGE IN SEX LAW UNSETTLES PROPS OF APARTHEID
description: Not too long ago, a scholar named Hans Heese came up with a series of studies that showed South Africa's dominant Afrikaners to be, in some cases, less than racially pure.

title: BRIDGE COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $226,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,000.

description: b-After a charge of $40,630,000 due to an adjustment in the carrying value of the company's interest in Petrosar Ltd. c-Net income. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: PORT CITY WOOS BATTLESHIP SQUADRON
description: Four centuries after the Spanish discovered there was no El Dorado hidden in the piney hills above Pensacola, there are hopes once again that this old Gulf port is going to hit pay dirt.

title: More Aid for Turkey Sought
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he had promised the visiting Turkish Defense Minister that the Reagan Administration would continue to press Congress to provide $789 million in military aid in the fiscal year 1986. Mr. Weinberger made the comment as he and Zeki Yavuzturk, the Turkish official, met with reporters.

title: GENERALS WIN, TIE FOR LEAD
description: The Herschel Walker-Doug Flutie display had its most effective game of the season tonight as the Generals trounced the Orlando Renegades, 24-7, before a crowd of 38,084 at Giants Stadium.

title: Hitler Regime Victimized a Great Many Ordinary Germans
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELIS COMPLETE STEP 2 OF PULLOUT
description: Israel completed the second phase of its three-stage withdrawal from Lebanon today, pulling out of the southern port city of Tyre, the last major city under Israeli military occupation.

title: LISTEN TO THE OPPOSITION, NOT SEOUL
description: South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan's visit to the White House last week has been described as a particularly cordial meeting that fully reaffirmed the security ties between the two countries. In fact, it is unlikely that these talks penetrated much below the surface or recognized the need for serious readjustments in United States policy toward South Korea.

title: CATCHING UP WITH THE YOGI BERRA STORY
description: Did you guess that Yogi Berra would be dismissed as Yankee manager this weekend? If you did, where did the thought come from?

title: MOVE NO SURPRISE TO FORMER YANKS
description: By now, there is not much that George Steinbrenner could do that would surprise the Yankees' alumni corps. For some recently departed Yankees who played for both Yogi Berra and Billy Martin, Martin's return for a fourth term certainly came as no shock.

title: U.S.F.L. AFFIRMS SHIFT TO FALL SLATE
description: The United States Football League, at a meeting of its owners, today affirmed its plan to shift from a spring schedule to an autumn one next year and to continue to operate the Los Angeles Express franchise until the end of the current season.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 30, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Body for 1985 Conference on Women's Decade - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FROM BILL BLASS, ELEGANCE IN WOOL JERSEY
description: The fabric of the fall season, it is now clear, is wool jersey, and Bill Blass makes the most of it. In the collection that opened the second week of Seventh Avenue fall fashion shows yesterday morning, he showed a memorable short beige jersey dinner dress with a twisted halter neckline, jersey trousers with a paisley jacket and blouse, and a series of long, slithery jersey dresses that cling to the body in a regal manner. The clothes have some of the elegant simplicity that used to mark styles by the late Norman Norell and were considered the high point of American fashion in the 1950's and 1960's.

title: NEW CHIEF HAS HIS WORK CUT OUT FOR HIM
description: By now it is generally accepted in Washington officialdom that in the months before Raymond J. Donovan resigned as Secretary of Labor, the work of the department ground largely to a halt.

title: COURT TAKES CASE ON VOTING RIGHTS
description: The Supreme Court set the stage today for the first major legal test of the amended Voting Rights Act, which Congress rewrote three years ago to make it easier to prove infringements of the right to vote.

title: Nicaragua Frees 16 Rebels
description: Military officials said today that they had released 16 prisoners, most of them Miskito Indians, as part of an agreement between the Government and the Misurasata rebel group. The prisoners were set free Sunday in ceremonies in the Caribbean coast towns of Puerto Cabezas and Bluefields. Misurasata is composed of about 2,000 Miskito fighters.

title: A SLEEPER FOR PENNY
description: Four months ago, Penny E. Harrington, a graduate of Michigan State, a veteran of 20 years of police work here, the victor in numerous sex-discrimination suits, became the first woman to head a major police force. But the problems of law enforcement make no allowance for gender, as Chief Harrington is being dramatically reminded.

description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation, denied a New Jersey casino license, was granted an adjournment of a second round of Casino Control Commission licensing hearings today so it can sell its unopened Atlantic City casino to the developer Donald Trump.

description: Because of an editing error in some copies, a front-page article on Thursday about campus protests around the nation misidentified a university. It was the University of Wisconsin at Madison.

description: Frank Layden is the National Basketball Association's resident humorist. As coach of the Utah Jazz and on the banquet circuit, where he is in big demand, the Brooklyn-born Layden has become noted for his his witty stories and quick one-liners.

description: Two men who the Government believes helped the Nazis persecute Jews and other civilians in World War II have permanently left the United States rather than face legal action, the Justice Department said today.

description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said today that he still did not know if he had the votes to win a first, symbolic vote on the White House budget package.

description: There are 2.6 million stories in the Tree City. Not every one ends happily.

title: 'ARTHRITIS INFORMATEL,' A TELETHON
description: TELETHONS are a staple of television, a way to raise money for good causes since the medium was young. Ordinarily, they leaven their pleas for funds with entertainment: show-business people get up and do their thing. The ''Arthritis Informatel,'' on WOR-TV for six hours Sunday afternoon, was different. It wanted to educate more than amuse. As such, it was pure public service.

description: b-Includes income of $214,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $249,000. c-Includes income of $69,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $95,000.

title: Phone Tape Provides Lyme Disease Facts
description: Westchester County has set up a 24-hour telephone tape on the causes and prevention of Lyme disease, county officials said today.

title: Breakfast Boycott at U.N.
description: Maybe it was the 2 cents for an extra lemon wedge that brought the crisis to a boil. Several hundred employees lined up patiently yesterday for a free breakfast provided by the United Nations staff union on day one of its self-proclaimed ''Cafeteria Crisis.''

title: TWO HAWKS AND A DOVE: HOW THEY LOOK AT THE INDOCHINA WAR NOW
description: Dean Rusk says the lesson of the Vietnam War is that the United States should look very carefully at the possible implications before it enters into any security treaties.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS CEMETERY TRIP 'MORALLY RIGHT'
description: President Reagan said today that it was ''morally right'' to visit a German military cemetery, and added that the purpose of his visit next Sunday is to symbolize ''the great reconciliation that has taken place'' between the United States and Germany.

title: Peru Tries Democratic Change
description: In Latin America, preserving democracy has always been even harder than periodically restoring it. If Peru actually inaugurates Alan Garcia Perez, the victorious candidate of the American Popular Revolutionary Alliance, as president in July, it will mark the first time in 40 years that power there has been transferred democratically.

title: A Happenstance
description: The letterhead is red, white and blue and the name of the organization is the Washington Connection. The notices began arriving in Washington area mail boxes last week, describing the Connection as ''a new organization whose goal is to establish an effective dialogue between the Jewish community and your President.''

title: NEW CEMETERY ISSUES RAISED BY FOREIGN-SOUNDING NAMES
description: The lush springtime grass in the trim cemetery of Bitburg covers a multitude of mysteries.

description: Baseball Mets vs. Houston Astros, at Shea Stadium. This is the opener of a two- game series, with Dwight Gooden going for his third victory.

title: BONUS, NOT RAISE, IN AIRLINE ACCORD
description: Leaders of the Transport Workers Union are asking the 11,800 members at American Airlines to accept annual bonuses rather than the usual percentage wage increases in a new three-and-a-half year contract.

title: Holmes Site Shifted
description: The Larry Holmes-Carl (the Truth) Williams fight on May 20 will be held in Reno, not Las Vegas. The International Boxing Federation heavyweight title fight will be televised in prime time by NBC and will be supported by heavyweight bouts featuring relatives of Joe Frazier.

description: HOME computer microprocessors are capable of performing thousands of computations a second. While this is slow in contrast to the newest supercomputers, whose speed is measured in billions of operations a second, it is still pretty darned quick compared to a pencil and scratchpad.

title: 2 Ex-Housing Officials Plead Guilty to Bribery
description: Two former superintendents of City Housing Authority projects in the Bronx pleaded guilty yesterday to demanding bribes and kickbacks from private vendors who sold maintenance equipment to the city.

description: This year's Paul Keres Memorial Tournament in Tallinn, in the Soviet Estonian Republic, was won by the 26-year-old Russian grandmaster Sergey Dolmatov, who scored 9 1/2-4 1/2.

description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez confirmed today that Spain planned to reduce the number of United States troops stationed here, but said the reductions would not be made until the current troop treaty expires in 1988.

description: The Sudan's new military leader said today that his Government would put on trial any officials involved in the airlift of Ethiopian Jews to Israel when Gaafar al-Nimeiry was in power.

300 Are Arrested As Fare Evaders
description: Transit policemen arrested yesterday more than 300 fare evaders during a day-long sweep of 38 Brooklyn subway stations, including 56 people who were repeat offenders or were being sought by the police for other crimes, officials said.

description: The likelihood of a teen-ager's committing suicide is significantly higher than normal if the youth had a difficult birth or a mother who was chronically ill in pregnancy, a group of clinical psychologists reports.

Kansas City Schools Offered More Desegregation Money
description: The state of Missouri will budget $40.6 million, more than four times what was previously proposed, for desegregating the Kansas City schools, according to a plan filed today in Federal District Court.

title: BARCLAY G. JOHNSON
description: Barclay Giddings Johnson, a civil engineer who was decorated in World War II for his logistical role in the Normandy invasion, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Plainfield, N.J. He was 75 years old and also had a home at Point O' Woods on Long Island.

title: GUARANTEE FINANCIAL CORP OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reviving 'Dead' Lakes
description: A few of the ''dead'' lakes of the Adirondack Mountains, the nation's most clear-cut victims of acid rain, have been temporarily brought back to life by scientists from Cornell University.

title: MAESTRO OF TASTE AND MORES
description: RUSSELL LYNES lunched at the American Stanhope Hotel, formerly The Stanhope, across from the Metropolitan Museum the other day, and he was amused. ''This used to be the Rembrandt Room,'' he said, taking in the dark paintings and genteel chintzes. ''Why do you suppose they call it the Saratoga Room?''

title: CENTRAL VERMONT PUBLIC SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW YORK TO PAY ITS FEDERAL DEBT WITH NEW BONDS
description: New York City will refinance virtually all of its federally guaranteed debt next month, bringing to a close a chapter of the municipal fiscal crisis of the 1970's, city officials announced yesterday.

title: METS RECOVER FROM MARATHON GAME
description: The National League schedule and Manager Davey Johnson are all heart. The Mets had a day off yesterday.

title: ZACCARO ASKS TO BE ALLOWED TO KEEP REAL-ESTATE PERMIT
description: In an emotional plea to a state hearing officer yesterday, John A. Zaccaro asked that he be allowed to keep his real-estate broker's license despite his conviction in a realty-fraud scheme.

title: That Seating Chart
description: Knowledgeable Washingtonians like to study seating arrangements at the White House correspondents' dinner for clues as to political alliances and source relationships. Saturday night top conservatives in the Administration seemed eager to send a signal about The Washington Times, which has often been a good editorial friend of President Reagan. Seated with the paper's editor in chief, Arnaud de Borchgrave, were the Attorney General, Edwin Meese 3d; the national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, and former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: SURVEY FINDS CANCER DEATHS ARE INCREASING STEADILY
description: THE overall number of deaths from cancer increased steadily from 1960 to 1980 in the industrialized world despite advances in preventive measures, according to a new analysis by the World Health Organization. Further, the researchers found, the rate of cancer deaths rose even after the rising age of the population was taken into account.

title: PHILS WIN IN 10TH, END EXPOS' STREAK
description: Juan Samuel's two-out infield single in the bottom of the 10th inning drove in Darren Daulton from third and gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Expos tonight.

title: GUNMEN ROB WELLS FARGO OF $8 MILLION
description: Four masked gunmen surprised four Wells Fargo employees early yesterday morning at a company depot in lower Manhattan and escaped with almost $8 million in unmarked bills, the police said.

title: OFFICER INDICTED IN DEATH OF A 20-YEAR-OLD IN POLICE CUSTODY
description: A New York City police officer was indicted yesterday in the death of a 20-year-old man whose neck was broken last December when the police tried to subdue him.

title: FINGERMATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SAGA OF CITY COLLEGE
description: WHEN I meet an alumnus of the City College of New York during my travels, the first question is usually something like: ''What's happened to City?'' The tone suggests that terrible things must have happened. The implication is that open admission, introduced in 1970, let a mass of unworthy students in and drove quality out.

title: NOTED ADVISER ON ECONOMICS
description: Paul N. Rosenstein-Rodan, an economist who had been an adviser on development to the Governments of India, Italy, Chile and Venezuela, died of a heart attack Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 83 years old and a resident of Boston. At his death he was professor emeritus of economics at Boston University.

description: A business traveler was pleasantly surprised, a family had a Sunday outing, and a cab driver was distraught as this city's long-awaited rail line to the Philadelphia International Airport opened.

title: WOMEN'S CULTS OF ANTIQUITY: THE VEIL RISES
description: THE excavation of a mysterious shrine in southern Italy has renewed scholarly interest in a shadowy all-woman cult that was among the oldest and most prestigious of all the religious groups of ancient Rome.

title: Ethics Review of OSHA Head
description: The Office of Government Ethics will formally review the activities of Robert A. Rowland, director of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, according to the director of the office, David H. Martin.

description: The State Senate approved today legislation to allow New Yorkers to bet on the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness at sites that offer simulcasting. Approval by the Assembly was expected.

description: President Reagan likes to make jokes about his age, which is 74, and his capacity for repeating himself. Talking to the National Association of Realtors recently at a Washington Hotel, he said: ''You know, I'd like to tell a story.

title: BEYOND FEDERAL DEFICITS
description: In their oratory, Democrats and Republicans agree on the need to reduce huge Federal budget deficits. But for Reagan Administration officials, the push for deficit reduction this year is also an opportunity - perhaps their last - to achieve the President's enduring, central goals of reducing the role of Government and, specifically, dismantling a number of Federal programs.

OPERA: 'FALSTAFF,' AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: A PERFECTLY cast and perfectly performed ''Falstaff'' can easily exist in the theater of the mind, but in what prosaic persons insist on calling the real world, Verdi's final opera can never completely satisfy. That said, I must add that last night's performance of this magical work by Sir Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall came as close to perfection as may be expected in an imperfect world. Conductor, orchestra, solo singers and chorus had been molded into the kind of tightly meshing ensemble that one dreams of hearing in ''Falstaff'' and seldom experiences in the opera house.

title: FARM FRESH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SEES PALESTINIAN ROLE IN TALKS
description: King Hussein of Jordan said today that efforts to convene a meeting between American officials and a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation were continuing, and that Jordan, the Palestine Liberation Organization and the United States were exploring suggestions for reviving the stalled peace process.

FINANCIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MODEL OF SHRINE GETS SHOWING IN NEW YORK
description: A full-sclae of a part of the New York Vietnam Veterans Memorial was exhibited yesterday in a ceremony at the Municiapl Art Society.

title: STROCKMAN PRESSES SENATORS TO END AMTRAK SUBSIDY
description: David A. Stockman, the Federal budget director, urged a Senate panel today to ''solve the Amtrak waste problem'' by shutting off the railroad's Federal subsidy and letting it go into bankruptcy.

title: POTVIN SADDENED, BUT HOPE REMAINS
description: Perhaps it was a sign that he is getting on in years, and perhaps it was nothing more than being at the wrong end of a 1-0 hockey game, but time was playing tricks on Denis Potvin's mind on Sunday night. He remembered looking up at the scoreboard clock above center ice at The Spectrum and seeing that there were 15 minutes to play in the Stanley Cup playoff game the Islanders had to win to extend their season. He remembered looking up again such a short time later and seeing that there were only eight minutes to go. ''I thought, 'My God, they're cheating us somehow,' '' Potvin remembered thinking. He seemed to mean the fates, not the timekeeper.

title: Executive Shift at Bantam
description: Alberto Vitale, chief operating officer of Bantam Books, has also been named president and co-chief executive officer, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Vitale will share the chief executive post with Louis Wolfe, who has held that position since joining Bantam in 1980. Mr. Wolfe was also named chairman of the board of Bantam, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bertelsmann Publishing Group of Munich, West Germany.

title: AS BITBURG VISIT NEARS, KOHL, UNDER FIRE, SAYS IT WILL GO ON
description: The West German Government today rejected warnings that its plans for President Reagan's state visit would profoundly damage relations with the United States and said that the American leader would lay a wreath at a German military cemetery Sunday as scheduled.

title: COLONIAL LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is a very happy day for those of us who recall the grim days of 1975.

title: RARE GASES MAY SPEED THE WARMING OF THE EARTH
description: TINY quantities of more than 30 rare gases threaten to warm the earth's atmosphere even more rapidly over the next 50 years than carbon dioxide will, according to a study by a team of atmospheric scientists.

title: BURRITT INTERFINANCIAL BANORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $31,000. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $24,000.

title: THE STAGE: STORIES BY CHAPIN
description: HARRY CHAPIN carved a small niche for himself in pop history as a sort of folk-rock Sherwood Anderson. In his short-story songs about ''ordinary'' Americans, Chapin compiled a folksy American portrait gallery whose subjects ranged from mail-order brides to mass murderers, from lonely waitresses to aging disk jockeys. Many of his characters are driven, desperate dreamers, and the plots of his songs - especially the later ones - often revolve around supernatural twists.

title: BUILDERS TRANSPORT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AT BENDEL'S, INNOVATIVE DISPLAYS ON 2 NEW FLOORS
description: For some time, shoppers at Henri Bendel, the specialty store on West 57th Street, have known that there were some big changes afoot in the design of the third and fourth floors. Now, the two handsome women's clothing floors, called 4 Plus 3, are nearly finished and will be officially unveiled tonight. They not only offer an innovative merchandising concept but also achieve a high-class, understated look that many department stores attempt without success.

title: Hai-Kyung Suh, Piano, At Alice Tully Hall
description: Hai-Kyung Suh, who made her New York debut Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, has studied piano with Sascha Gorodnitzki at the Juilliard School for the last six years. She won the Busoni Competition at the age of 20, for which she was awarded South Korea's Medal of Culture, and recently became the first woman to receive the Juilliard William Petschek Piano Debut Award.

title: STEINBRENNER LOST FAITH IN BERRA
description: George Steinbrenner said yesterday that he was ''willing to take a chance'' with Billy Martin a fourth time because ''he's going to be the disciplinarian I want.'' Steinbrenner acknowledged that Martin displayed a lack of self-discipline in 1983 but said, ''I have great confidence in Billy that this time that isn't going to occur.''

title: JUSTICE DEPT. STOPS REQUIRING OFFICIALS TO REPORT FINANCES
description: The Justice Department acknowledged today that it no longer requires some 50 officials in policy making or supervisory positions to file financial disclosure statements, which are used throughout the Government to spot conflicts of interest.
