description: b-Includes a tax credit of $62,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $88,000. d-There is no comparable year-ago share earnings figure because the company wasn't public until December 1984.

title: PORT'S ECONOMY IS FOUND STEADY IN AGENCY STUDY
description: Shipping in New York Harbor contributes $14 billion a year to the region's economy and generates 191,600 jobs, according to a study released yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: GALOOB, LEWIS TOYS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ATLANTIC RICHFIELD TO DISPOSE OF 2,000 GAS STATIONS IN EAST
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the nation's sixth-largest oil company, took a series of bold steps today to respond to changes sweeping the nation's oil industry.

title: POLICE CUSTODY CASES AND THE CORONER
description: The case of Jose Llopis-Perez was one of several that led to accusations in a series of articles in The New York Times that the Chief Medical Examiner had produced misleading or inaccurate autopsy findings for people who had died in police custody.

title: Obscure Start
description: It was three months ago, when the United States Football League conducted its own selection process, that the Generals drafted five quarterbacks, then said that they would make efforts to sign each of them. Those efforts soon bowed to the expense of reeling in Doug Flutie, which in turn meant that the four others remained candidates for today's draft: Calabria, Peter Muldoon of Holy Cross, Mike Tomczak of Ohio State, and Joe Shield, who in four modest eight-game seasons threw for 6,646 yards at Trinity of Connecticut. Trinity of Connecticut? That's right, and if you've never heard its name spoken in the same breath as mention of the N.F.L., there's good reason. The Hartford school may have its own rich tradition - it's 161 years old - but it also has a student body numbering only 1,800, and only half of those are men. The Bantams belong to the New England Small College Athletic Conference, a league that embraces 11 schools, all of them in Division III.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 30, 1985

title: COMPUTERVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: EMULEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Police Say Bomb in a Church May Have Been Planted in '79
description: A homemade bomb found in a church and detonated by the police was probably planted six years ago by a man who died in a 1979 bomb explosion there, the authorities said Sunday.

title: PAPANDREOU'S PATH DIVIDES GREEK-AMERICANS
description: Political developments in Greece in recent weeks have stirred concern - and created strains - among Greek-Americans.

title: CHAMPION SPARK PLUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Air Service From Westchester
description: New York Air inaugurated service at Westchester County Airport today, starting four jet flights a day on weekdays to Washington - two of them to Washington National Airport and two to Dulles International Airport.

title: GREGORY MOSHER TO HEAD LICOLN CENTER THEATERS
description: Gregory Mosher yesterday was appointed director of the Lincoln Center Theater company, charged with bringing artistic life to the long-dormant Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi Newhouse theaters. The announcement was made by former Mayor John V. Lindsay, the theater company's chairman.

title: HITLER REGIME VICTIMIZED A GREAT MANY ORDINARY GERMANS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DIRECTORS BACK LINCOLN CENTER CHOICE
description: The New York theater world appeared unanimous in its support of Gregory Mosher's appointment as director of the the Lincoln Center Theater Company yesterday. But several theater figures said that although Mr. Mosher's artistic and organizational credentials were well-established, he would need something more to be successful at the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi Newhouse theaters.

title: NIELSEN SURVEYS TV VIEWING HABITS
description: The greatest amount of television viewing these days can be found in households with at least three members, followed by households with children and households receiving subscription program services such as Home Box Office and Showtime, according to the latest survey of viewing habits conducted by the A. C. Nielsen rating service. The survey found that American households with television sets, of which there are now 84.9 million, watched on average 7 hours and 8 minutes a day through the 1983-84 television season. The previous season, the average household watched 6 hours and 55 minutes a day.

title: Cause of Pipeline Blast Sought by Investigators
description: An explosion in a natural gas pipeline that killed five people and spewed flames that could be seen 20 miles away does not appear to have been caused by nearby construction, an investigator says.

title: TOXIC WATER THREATENS MANY WILDLIFE REFUGES
description: Many of the nation's wildlife refuges are threatened by water contaminated by farm chemicals and other substances, according to Interior Department reports.

title: CONNECTICUT NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TAKING THE JOY OUT OF BASEBALL
description: This is my annual baseball column. Normally, it would simply be an uninhibited celebration of the new season's arrival combined with some combative remarks about the unbrotherly rivalry between my team, the Boston Red Sox, and the local American League team, the New York Yankees.

title: SEYMOUR ADELMAN, COLLECTOR OF RARE LITERARY MANUSCRIPTS
description: Seymour Adelman, a prominent collector of American and British books, manuscripts, letters and prints, died of cancer Thursday at Jefferson Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 78 years old.

title: Bridge: An Upstate Foursome Wins Grand National Team Event
description: An upstate foursome won an important Grand National Team victory in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., Sunday.

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Waiting for Wiggins
description: Ballard Smith, president of the Padres, says he will wait for the second baseman Alan Wiggins to contact him before he makes a decision on the player's future with San Diego. The 27-year-old Wiggins, who began drug treatment at an undisclosed location over the weekend, has not talked to team officials since his disappearance Thursday from his Los Angeles hotel room.

title: WHY THE RUSSIANS FOUGHT THE NAZIS
description: The Western democracies are making a mistake in inviting the Soviet Union to participate in our celebration of V-E Day. Why, after all, must we maintain the pretense that the Soviet Union helped us to liberate Europe?

title: GIBSON GREETINGS CARDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $3,360,000 from the settlement of a previously terminated acquisition of Gibson by Walt Disney Productions. The company said share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March 1985.

title: Memphis State Inquiry
description: The Metro Conference confirmed yesterday it has notified the National Collegiate Athletic Association of possible violations concerning the Memphis State basketball players Keith Lee and William Bedford. The conference learned of the possible violations through the school's athletic department, the conference commissioner, Steve Hatchell, said. in Atlanta.

title: Labor Secretary Sworn In
description: Bill Brock was sworn into office today as Secretary of Labor at a private White House ceremony attended by President Reagan, a White House spokesman said. Mr. Reagan's nomination of Mr. Brock to replace Raymond J. Donovan was confirmed by the Senate Friday.

title: HEALTH OFFICIALS ALARMED BY FISH POISON CASES
description: TO celebrate her 35th birthday, Christine Topper prepared dinner for herself and her husband, Mark. The entree was yellowtail grouper, a succulent, extremely popular fish in the Virgin Islands where they live.

title: FRANTZ MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. ACTS TO STOP QUOTAS ON HIRING IT BACKED IN PAST
description: For the first time, the Justice Department has taken a city to court to overturn existing quotas for hiring women, blacks and Hispanic workers.

title: HISTORY AND HINDSIGHT: LESSONS FROM VIETNAM
description: For a month the public has been immersed in a flood of retrospection and introspection about the Vietnam War, which ended 10 years ago Tuesday. The outpouring indicates that many people are at least as interested in revising history as understanding it.

title: 13 Resign From Paris Paper
description: Thirteen senior journalists, including the two chief editors, have resigned from the leftist daily newspaper Le Matin after Max Gallo, a former spokesman for the Socialist Government, was named chief editorial writer. The journalists said the appointment jeopardized the paper's independence.

title: TWO HAWKS AND A DOVE: HOW THEY LOOK AT THE INDOCHINA WAR NOW
description: The passage of time has not dulled the bitterness that the former United States Ambassador to South Vietnam, Graham A. Martin, feels over the loss of the Vietnam War.

title: CODENOLL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Oilers Won't Try to Halt N.F.L. Draft
description: The National Football League's 50th college draft will proceed as scheduled today, starting at 8 A.M. at the Omni Park Central Hotel and finishing when the 336th player has been selected at the end of the 12th round.

title: ATICO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $514,000 from the sale of a citrus grove. c-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $3,191,000 from the sale of a citrus grove.

title: AMERADA HESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
3 Painters Union Officials Are Given Prison Terms
description: A Federal district judge sentenced three members of a Bethlehem painters' union local to prison terms today on the ground that they were a danger to the community.

title: AMERICAN MEDCENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are pro forma. The company went public in January 1985.

title: FIRST AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STAGE: 'AREN'T WE ALL?' - COLBERT AND HARRISON
description: WHILE no one is likely to mistake Frederick Lonsdale's 1923 comedy, ''Aren't We All?,'' for anything other than an antique trifle, the revival at the Brooks Atkinson is not without its passing pleasures. Watching this play must be what it was like to eavesdrop on afternoon tea at Claridge's during Mayfair's halcyon days - when the English upper class still had hard cash and American tycoons didn't yet monopolize the reservation list. For two hours, we watch attractive aristocrats whisper bright, sweet nothings to one another, with pauses for the occasional tiff, embrace or whisky and soda. And sometimes there's an event of saucer-rattling magnitude: Royalty, in the form of the actress Claudette Colbert, will saunter into the sumptuously appointed drawing room.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Karen Hutchinson In Debut Piano Recital
description: The pianist Karen Hutchinson opened her debut program last week at Carnegie Recital Hall with a first-class rendition of Mendelssohn's ''Variations Serieuses.'' Miss Hutchinson has a rare grasp of the composer's elusive esthetic - which combines a nascent Romanticism with Classical poise; she played lyrically, but with an architectural sense of structure.

title: FIRST SOURCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid February 15.

title: DR. LAZARE TEPER, FORMER ECONOMIST AT GARMENT UNION
description: Dr. Lazare Teper, an economist and statistician for organized labor, died at New York Hospital last Thursday after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
U.S. PROPOSES NEW RULES FOR REVIEWS ON DISABILITY BENEFITS
description: The Government proposed new rules today for Social Security disability examiners to follow in deciding whether a person's medical condition had improved enough to warrant a benefit cutoff.

title: RANGERS 7, YANKEES 5
description: It seems as if he had never gone. Billy Martin, back for his fourth term as Yankee manager, wasted no time instituting changes today, naming a new coach, reaffirming old guidelines and altering a starting lineup that had fallen to last place in the American League East.
